description:
They have really unique dishes here that I don't think I've seen anywhere else! My friends and I made a reservation for a Friday night and the place was packed - definitely shows how popular it is :)

We got the lamb dosa and chicken curry. The dosa was massive and just the right texture: crispy but soft, and sturdy enough to hold the fillings. The chicken thigh in the curry was really tender and the curry was flavorful without being too spicy. 

My friends got some fancy cocktails that they enjoyed a lot, but I didn't order a drink so I'll take their word for it. Would definitely recommend this place if you're looking for solid Indian food.
author: Katy Y.

description:
The Chutney Sampler was really good! It's fun to mix them together and have people guess which two/three flavors are mixed. This was my first time having Dosa and they came out as a surprise. These things are huge! We had the Lamb "Keema" and Habanero-Mango Masala. The Masala has a warning because of the heat, it was pretty spicy. 

I'm excited to go again and try the deserts or smoke drinks!
author: Robbie P.

description:
The paper masala dosa was sooo good!! It came with the crispy paper crepe thing (the crepe part of the dosa), and I preferred the softer vs crispier parts to scoop up the potato filling, the very rich tomato sauce, and the mint chutney. The caramelized onion uttapam was ok, I would not get it again. It had the same rich tomato sauce and mint chutney as the dosa, nothing else, and the bread part wasn't that good, it was just cooked dough with stuff inside it. 

Next time I would like to try the regular dosa masala, but the paper masala dosa was really good as well and I would be excited to get it again. I would not get a uttapam again.
author: Patricia P.

description: Haven't been to the Valencia location in so long. It's still so delicious ! We love the thin dosa and seafood masala. They even make interesting drinks. Centrally located in the heart of the Mission district, if you're ever in the area and craving good Indian food like I do, check out this restaurant!
author: DJ Nocturna R.

description:
Pretty great Indian food. Not necessarily my favorite but love to have great dosa. Felt the idli was a bit overcooked and the mung a bit undercooked.

The vibes are great!

The vada pav is my favorite dish here. That and a few dosas. The sambar is good too.
author: Aakash G.

description:
Got the steph curry - is this a drink that he orders? it was decent but red wine is kind of weird with whiskey..he has weird taste.

The lamb "keema" was good. Decent portion for lamb and I could see why "keema" was in quotes. AVOCADO CHAAT was fine but nothing special. I'd recommend ordering the chutney because it goes well with almost everything you'll order.

Service was pretty good.
author: Sang P.

description:
DOSA on Valencia is my favourite restaurant in SF! It's where I go when friends or family is visiting, date night or when I am craving good south Indian food (happens all the time).

DOSA's dosas are great! They have an authentic AND interesting menu; which is a rather hard to find combination. Their sambar is the best I've had in the Bay Area (not just San Francisco) and their chutneys are really good! I usually end up picking dosa's but I've tried several of their starters and other entrees and have never been disappointed.

I like their Valencia branch more than the Fillmore one because it's so cozy; I also feel like the food tastes better, but that's probably just me!

The only drawback is that they could have long wait times. Make sure to make a reservation on Yelp before you go.
author: Divya S.

description: Full disclosure, I have really high standards for dosa. This place is delightful for the ambiance and cleanliness, however, it's not the best dosa in the Bay Area. The chutneys weren't that rich in taste, the dosa itself didn't have the roasted ghee rich flavor, and the sambar was mediocre. In addition, the price is a little high for such a simple plate. Tried the prawn masala and it tasted more Thai than Indian to me. Food was overall enjoyable but it's not authentic Indian food.
author: Vinayak P.

description:
Late-ish night eats at Dosa on Valencia. Still poppin' at 10pm--we sat at the bar. Menu was minimalist and clean, as was the decor. 

Ordered:
- lamb and keema with dosa: lamb and diced potatoes was surprisingly delicious! Really enjoyed the contrast with the crispy dosa. 
- mushroom uttapam: lots of arugula, felt pretty healthy eating it, felt like I was eating Indian pizza, was delicious

Also drooled over the poori but controlled myself. $6 for two?! What a steal...next time I'll order some for the ride home.
author: Cindy T.

description:
A place tats got everything but their food(Cuisine too) right
The place is accessible, small but cozy and packed. The staff is great. They even got us a seat in jus about 2mins on a saturday night. The menu has variety and its calld the Kerala Dinner. 

Growing up in south india, i know how the food tastes. 
While the names on the menu looked familiar, the taste just did not. We ordered 5 items for the 3 of us cos we jus needed to get some great indian food as we drove all the way to SFO from LA. 

The kerala fish fry costs $12 bucks and has 6 peices of some fish that was definitely not indian(0.5''x0.5'') placed on a yellow base with some fruit peices on it(my guess is Mango).
The dosa looked great but dint taste indian. The tomato chutney was jus plain tomato puree that you get in a store(tomato chutney is supposed to have alot more than jus tomatoes)and the coconut chutney was jus ground coconut. Both the chutneys desperately needed tempering. Kerala is the land of spices and i wished one of the items on this menu had them.

The food looked really nice and i found alot of non-indians liking it. Its because this was not INDIAN.
I am not saying the food sucked. IT WASNT INDIAN OR MALAYALI CUISINE OR EVEN REMOTELY SOUTH INDIAN. 
This is jus catering to the non-indians living in the area. I was fooled. DO NOT GO HERE IF YOU WANT TO HAVE INDIAN.

Request to the management- pls call your restaurant an INDIN FUSION restaurant. Tats appropriate. Sorry if i offended you. I came in expecting indian food. I dint get bad food, it just wasnt indian
author: Raja E.

description:
This was one of the first somewhat upscale Indian restaurant I had been to in the Bay Area. Now there are few more.

I continue to enjoy this spot, really good food and service. I got the truffle dosa which was great.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Nice place and service. We tried mango-habanero dosa and a paneer curry.

I'm a big South Indian food fan and the spiciness in the dosa over-powered the flavors. Sambhar and chutneys were pretty good. 

The curry came with lemon rice and was beautifully flavourful. Will absolutely recommend the place!
author: Dhwani P.

description:
Definitely an authentic spot to hit in the city - i come from Making everything from scratch ...

The food presentation is hyped up - well the taste talks for the food - almost everything on the menu is good - and they got a full bar with the drinks that compliment with what you can order.

If you have a date and on mission st get to this spot
author: Victor D.

description: Amazing vegan options! I loved the setting of the restaurant and the staff was also great and catered to my vegan diet. I had the Channa Poori and the Caramelized onion Uttapam made vegan...so delicious! For drinks I had the Steph Curry and the Tumeric Mule. I was a bit skeptical based off the names of the cocktails but they were delicious. Overall, great food, drinks and experience. Definitely worth a visit.
author: Elizabeth A.

description:
Amazing variety of food.

I had a duh moment after eating here. We decided that everyone would order one plate (after a round of appetizers) and we would pass it around so people could try everything. When the dishes came I was surprised that there were so many dosas. I remember thinking that's weird that we all have the same tastes and got dosas. Well, hello, the name of this restaurant is Dosa because they specialize in dosas! I'm glad my husband wasn't there to witness that moment because I'd never live it down (although he sometimes reads my Yelp reviews, so if you're reading this, don't say anything).

Digression aside, you really should order a dosa. That's what they are known for and they are delicious. If you see the pictures, you'll notice that they are huge! I looked at it and thought I can't eat it all. False! Since they are hollow on the inside other than the filling, you can eat it all if you truly believe! (Kidding aside, I found myself slightly on the fuller side of full by the end, but not uncomfortably so). 

We started with the Dahi Vada, Lemon-Chile Scallops, Spiced Avocado Chaat (which we asked them to make not spicy so we nixed the habanero), and the Southern Samosas.  Everything was delicious and variety is the spice of life so I definitely suggest trying a bunch of appetizers! 

Out of all the entrees the three that stood out to me were the Organic Mushroom and Arugula Uttapam, the White Truffle Dosa (see a pattern? I'm a huge fan of truffle), and the Hyderabadi Lamp Chops. The lamb chops were so tender! I don't think you could go wrong with any type of dosa (I loved all the ones I tried), I'm just super partial to truffle oil!

Service was the only thing that was a bit of a con. It was super slow! We ended up going to pay at the counter because our waiter was taking too long to bring the check. He actually brought it after we already paid. 

Takeaway is if you need to get in and out then this may not be the best place, however, if you want a good meal and you have time to spare then I would suggest coming here! 

Pro Tip: They take Yelp Reservation so you don't have to wait!
author: Christina G.

description: A small yet homely place to grab a dinner with my friend. They have splendid choices on drinks by the way. Their decor, ambience and lighting is just perfect. It's not too bring yet it's very cozy. They are known for their South Indian fusion dishes. I have to say that everyone must must just try their Ras Malai!! It's is amazing . In the photo below you can see the sprouts salad with paneer, tomato uttapam and spicy mung masala dosa.
author: Julia J.

description:
The service was great, and the decor was eye catching. The egg dosa and corn chaat was interesting. Not my favorite but pretty tasty. 
Check it out!
author: Samantha K.

description:
I will never be back. The service was horrible and the food was really mediocre. Don't even bother with the happy hour wines or food. Our waitress failed to get us more papadam, even though we ordered the papadam with sauces & asked for it 3 times. They brought us the wrong dish and she didn't come to check on us for a long time. When she did come over, we asked if that was the right one, she said no and asked us if we wanted to keep it and not have what we ordered! She also could not describe to us what the dish would be like. Major fail. I was really disappointed because the last time I was there, the service was excellent & so was the food! It looked like they changed the menu as well, which is sad. 

I do recommend DOSA by Dosa in Oakland! They have a different menu & different vibe.
author: Kylie F.

description:
5 stars is rare, but I'm good with it

Vegan options abundant 

Ask for the white truffle dosa 
It's not on the menu, but they are happy to make it

Absolute perfection
author: James C.

description:
Some very solid Indian food for a pretty rowdy group. Our group of about 10 went on a weeknight. Lucky for us, they take reservations. So we were seated immediately. We ordered a few cocktails, wine, and appetizers. The cocktails were delicious... but I usually am limited to very few of those with all the sweet/spicy/excess and go to an old favorite, craft beer. They had a very nice selection and I found one that I was digging.

The menu seems to have changed since I went, so some of the dishes are a little spotty. But for the apps that table shared, the samosas and scallops stood out. I kind of wish we had gotten three orders of EACH of those. Very tasty.

We also decided to do a big tasting of the entrees. Which obviously was not as easy as the appetizers. But a great way to taste a bunch of different things. I got one of the lamb curries and like with most lamb curries I have had at great Indian places, this was really good. But nothing more exceptional that I have had at some other Indian spots in San Francisco.

All in all a great experience. A perfect spot for our loud group since it was pretty loud in there overall. But not so much that you couldn't hear. As with so many spots in San Francisco, I may not be dying to get back here in my short time in the city. But it was certainly one of the more solid meals I have had in the bay area.
author: Will B.

description: This place is on point with their dosas! The staff was very nice and the ambiance is great. My husband and I ordered the Chennai Chicken, Avacado Chaat, Vadda Pav Sliders, and Dosas! We both got the masala dosa but next time I'm definitely going to try the truffle dosa based on the review below me. I also tried the Indian monsoon drink and my husband had the fresh mango juice. Very good stuff! You can ask to remove any ingredient from the monsoon drink and their more than happy to since it is freshly made. I am not a ginger person so I asked them not to add the ginger and it was perfectly fine. Overall great experience and highly recommend this place!
author: Sophia K.

description:
Just an ok experience and would give 3.5 stars. The place is smaller than it's other branch and tables are very close to each other. It's a nice place if you are not in a group and gets a window seat. Inside since you are too close to the adjoining table, you cant help but listen to other people's conversation. Also the food smell will also come to you and the servers will bump into your hands and feet if they are not inside your table.
Food quality seems to be better than that of Dosa at Fillmore but both of them are expensive. The only time I would recommend going here is when you just need a nice ambience in a smaller place with less light.
There are definitely better Indian restaurants in the city.
author: Saumya A.

description:
Great cocktails - the Bengali Gimlet and Steph Curry (lol) were refreshing and decently strong.

Chennai chicken made a great appetizer. 

Lamb pepper fry curry and masala dosa were packed with flavors and delicious.   

For dessert, we unfortunately didn't like the pistachio barfi but thought the Madras coffee was a great end to the meal.
author: Christine A.

description:
This was an absolute pleasure. Located in San Francisco, this really reminds you of South Indian food and delicacies. I went here on a Saturday night and had to wait for and hour to get in owing to its popularity!! So be ready to wait.


I had the Mysore masala dosa - an amazing choice of you have not tried this before, not too spicy yet tasty. If you want something spicy,try he mango habanero dosa. Besides this we had the vada pav-more a north Indian food, but it was yummy. The tamarind chutney stoke the show. 
We had the dahi bass too : try if you are a yoghurt fan.... 

If you like beer, you should try the kingfishes beer. Reminds you of Indian beer and a must have at this place. The food service was very good, quick and prompt despite the rush. The piece was on the higher side, but affordable enough. 

So if you're in the mood for Indian food, do try this place as it's different compared to the North Indian buffets you get around in SFO.
author: Saarthak C.

description:
DOSA brings a punch of authentic Southern Indian cuisine in a lively, modern environment. 

Walked in as a party of 2 on a Friday night with no wait. The ambiance is high-energy, with gorgeous decor and a prominent bar area. For dinner we shared 3 dises: the fried lentil shared plate, the sprouted Mung salad, and the chicken curry. The lentil dish was a 5/5, with incredible Indian flavors balanced by the coolness of the yogurt. The Mung salad was also excellent, though I wish the paneer flavor came through more. The chicken curry was certainly flavorful, but a disappointing portion size for the $25 price point. The basmati rice was light and fluffy, cooked perfectly. 

Overall, a very good restaurant for a nice weekend dinner in the Mission!
author: Aaron C.

description:
Made a three-person reservation for Friday night three days in advance. Showed up with four people around 15 minutes late, but we managed to get a table ready in 10 minutes.

Food was tasty, though the portion was on the smaller side. For vegetarian dish, go give the brussels sprouts curry a try. The brussels sprouts were crunchy and the sauce was really rich -- yum! That was also our first time having dosa. It looked deceivingly large (and heavy) on pictures, so we thought one masala dosa for four people was enough. Definitely *not* enough, don't make the same mistake. 

Last but not least, the complimentary papadums were hands down the best I've had so far. You know it's a good sign when restaurants serve free appetizers that taste good.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Although we were about 15 min early, someone who seemed to be the manager let us in early -- and override the other staff member who told us they were still not opened. The manager definitely saved us from going next door. They let us settle in, browse the menu, gave us water, while they were still setting up, which was no problem for us visitors into this city.

The waitor was very nice, explained the menu and favorite dishes. We ordered right soon after: chicken curry dosa, mushroom naan with mango lassi. The chicken curry cup was delicious with the rice and dosa. The other many sauce cups were beautiful and amazing to try. The mushroom naan dish was covered in arugula, I felt may have camouflaged the mushrooms.

Overall great service except the hostess who continuously booked reluctant until I checked in, enchanting clean sleek interior, and great food. Totally recommend this place for a nice elegant meal experience.
author: Esther J.

description:
If you want amazingly fresh and scratch-made food, definitely check out DOSA! I had never had Southern Indian cuisine and visiting was an absolute eye opener to dosas and uttapam. The whole dining experience was amazing and I highly encourage you to come try this restaurant.

The priciest item here is for sure the cocktails, in fact our cocktails ended up being the most expensive thing on our bill. As delicious as the ginger cocktail was, I think next time we visit it will be a sober dinner.

The South Indian Moon dish, which is a sampler dish of 5 different uttapams, was delightful! So amazing to taste all the flavors and the 3 sauces were great!

We also got the Dahi Vada, which was unique in taste, but not my favorite. I think for me I will stick to the dosas and uttapams when I come to  visit!

Thank you DOSA for a great dinner! Looking forward to a return visit!
author: Caitlin A.

description: This was my first time at DOSA. My friends and I were looking for a place to eat that wasn't too pricey and had a nice vibe. I can definitely say that, at least for SF, the prices were reasonable and the vibe was relaxed. So all good things there. The staff was also really nice; they greeted us warmly and were super patient when we asked a number of qs about the menu (yes, we were those people). Anyway, then came the food. I went for a dosa made w/ veggie oil (as opposed to ghee) and enjoyed it. I wouldn't say I was blown away, but it did the job. I was stuffed before I finished and ended up taking the rest of it home. It also came with a small soup and a tomato and mint chutney. Those were nice and tasted fresh, though I definitely preferred the mint one. I don't know when I'll be back, since I don't have Indian food often, but I wouldn't mind having DOSA again one day.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Haven't ordered from here in quite some time and my wife and I ordered in an appetizer on a Sunday night -idly fries. Being a "high end" Indian restaurant and considerate of vegetarian dietary needs, we didn't anticipate any issues with our order. However, after we got through half of our fries, my wife bit into one and spit it out and frantically asked me what it was (note that she has been a vegetarian her whole life). I took a look at it and sure as hell, it was a piece of fried chicken. For being a nice upscale Indian restaurant, they really need to get their act together as this is simply not acceptable. I'm actually very surprised they don't even have separate fryers for the meat and vegetarian items to be honest. We typically are more careful and ask
At other restaurants but didn't expect it from DOSA! Oh and to top it off, they forgot the Madras coffee we ordered!
author: Milin P.

description:
The food here is so good, it's an experience. 

Re: Food - My friend and I got the chicken curry (substituted in a side of dosa instead of rice) and the Five Moons (uttapam sampler). INCREDIBLE. Texture of dosa was amazing with the chicken, which was full of flavor. Uttapam sampler was fun; the one packed with onion was my favorite! The sauces were like nothing I had ever tasted before, but went well with everything. My friend and I spoke very little after the food came out because *damn*. 

Re: Service - Very kind and attentive! The waiter even let us know when he thought we may have been ordering too much food (lol). Gave great food recommendations. Understanding of gluten allergy. 

Re: Ambience - Sat next to the window, and it was beautiful having the natural light. 

Do yourself a favor and check this place out!
author: Susie C.

description:
Solid Indian food place that doesn't disappoint. Dosa always deliver authentic flavors even though Valencia street is quickly gentrifying. This particular Valencia location is a bit more casual than the Fillmore one on ambience. 

My favorite dish:
Chennai chicken. Tender and flavorful with onions. Oven roasted. Right on for texture and flavor. 

Solid dishes:
Corn poriyal with sea beans, coconut, cashew, ginger and Chile - matches up with its Mexican counterpart. 

Channa poori (puffed thin bread) with garbanzo beans and masala - with just the right spice with garbanzo beans. This dish is super filling - too much even for two people to share.

Out of the wine, try Tempranillo from Rioja (by the glass) with the Indian food - pairs nicely. 

The papadum is always amazing at Dosa - don't be afraid to ask more. One of my favorite things at Dosa!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Made a reservation on Christmas Eve for 3 at noon.  Turns out we didn't need one since everyone was out of town for the holidays. We were one out of two groups in the restaurant. 

We ordered a classic dosa, a lamb dosa, and the south Indian moons (sampler plate of uttapams). Also, got a mango lassi. Nice and smooth. Could really taste the cardamom. Each table also gets complimentary chips. They were lightly fried and flavoured with Indian spices. Our food arrived quickly after. The dosas were huge. I loved the thin and crispy texture they had, with a chewy consistency in the middle. The dosas and uttapams all came with the same sauces and what was like a chunky soup. The lamb dosa came with another little soup container filled with the lamb itself. 

The lamb dosa pastry was plain, but there was potato inside the classic dosa. The uttapams were more chewier in texture, packed with flavor from all the different stuff they put inside. Not sure what was in the sauces, but I liked the red sauce the best. It had a strong hearty flavour. It was a bit spicy though. The green sauce was more refreshing in terms of its flavour. 

The itemized prices on the bill we got at the end was different from the prices on the menu, but i think it evened out in terms of the differences across all items, so we just didn't mention it. 

Would definitely come back if I was craving a crispy dosa.
author: Christine L.

description:
Pricey but yummy!! I was expecting heavy food but Dosa was a pretty light meal! We ordered the chicken masala curry and regular dosa to share. The curry portion was a bit small but the chicken and sauce were delicious. The dosa on the other hand, was huge!! I was like a thin crispy pancake with mashed potato wrapped in, and came with 3 dipping sides. We devoured pretty much everything.

Our server was friendly and the ambience is really nice for a date night. I want to come back to try other types of dosas!
author: Sophia H.

description:
I've been to this place twice before writing this review. Last time I went on a Saturday evening. The wait time was none and the place was moderately crowded. I have to this place before once and I enjoyed the food back then. Hence I was excited to go here again and was hoping to have a similar experience. However I was throughly disappointed. 

We ordered samosas, Idli, paneer dosa and paper dosa. Samosas were bland and we're unevenly cooked. The food was overall bland and tasteless. It lacks consistency in terms of quality and taste. A resturant with primarily south Indian cuisine is judged on the quality of its sambar (lentil liquid curry), which was not tasting as it should in terms of spices.
author: Jigar G.

description:
I think the menu was EXTREMELY limited, and the prices were kind of high, but it's hard to give it less than four stars based on the flavors, ambiance, and kudos (Best Indian 2014, Reader's Poll- SF Bay Guardian, and the honorary 5 red dots from Bombay Michelin).

OMG.  Good luck reading the menu if you're over 40.  The font is one.

I guess it is southern Indian, so I was expecting "masala chicken and waffles" or "naan biscuits and gravy" and confederate flags, but southern here, according to their website, means lighter, spicier, and more varied in flavors.  So you may need to go to a northern place if you want tikka masala. 

The southern samosas were likely the best I ever had.  Fried like an eggroll, with creamy, peppery potatoes and firm onion slices.  The spiced lentil soup tastes more like a chili (which isn't a bad thing- just don't expect the earthy lentil taste).  It was my first time having poori, which was both amazing AND how I felt after the check.
author: Glen N.

description:
For a long time I haven't tried anything as similar to authentic indian food, that could resemble the mix of flavors that indian food in India has left in my paladar every time I've been there... until I found DOSA. 

This is one of those places that not only cook the same dishes and reminds you the one you tried in the past, but it really brings the quality and freshness of ingredients with excellent flavors.

The manager (I don't remember his name) suggested for our table of four, to order a platter with different dishes. We were there having Sunday Lunch.

That was a great idea, because we got to try different dishes and choose what we liked more for our next visit.

Whenever we got the food, he took the time to come to our table and explain to our friends every part of our dish, what it was, how to eat it, giving details of the order to eat them to expand the experience.

My favorite was masala dosa, crunchy and the curry was great, my friends also ordered chendai chicken and to be honest, I usually run away from any southern indian food, because I know it is super extra spicy to the point to don't being enjoyable at all.. This wasn't the case! The spice was there but the flavor was strong also, so I enjoyed it; and briyani (rice), (I'm a rice lover, so I loved it!) 

We ended up having a lot of food on our table! Haha but it was all good.

I will go back and explore more their menu and drinks, because we only ordered plain water...

If you are new to Indian food, this is the place to go. Ask the staff and get ready for different flavors! We had a great experience I'm very happy that we found this place.
author: Bella C.

description:
I tried their Mysore and their spicy mung dal dosa this evening with few friends; favor the later more. It's weird that they charge extra for chutney but provide the popadums for free. This is like  providing the bread without olive oil or butter. 
I'm a die hard south Indian food lover and I've tasted several great restaurants outside India and Dosa stands as an average one in comparison. 

PS. Their reservation staff  (over the phone) can use some politeness especially when they are dealing with customers who are visiting from outside the city. They need to be a tiny bit flexible! I'm so not impressed with the person I spoke with for making my booking. Giving them 1 star less for their sheer inflexibility and rudeness.
author: Neha T.

description:
This was my 1st time at this restaurant.  I was happy with the Dosas (namesake) and they serve them with flavorful garnishes.  The staff were very nice and helpful when choosing off the menu for eats and drinks.

I liked the chicken and lamb meats, for this style of cooking was a new experience with Indian cuisine for me.

The prices were decent, for what you get.  I didn't like the 6 percent charge added to the bill for the city of SF charges a fee that is passed on directly to the customer.

Overall, I would bring friends and try this restaurant again.
author: Edwin A.

description:
Don't go here! Go to the Fillmore location.

I've been to the Fillmore Dosa countless times and it is truly my favorite restaurant in SF. On a whim I took my nephew to the Valencia location... 
1. The food was flavorless & far less quality than what I'm used to. It was like the fast food of dosas. 
2. We both got sick that night. 
My nephew was taking a red eye home and spent his last hour before heading to the airport worshiping the porcelain gods. What a night!

I left a message the next day but did not receive a call back. 
So, to all you hungry people out there, if you go here you will be disappointed! ...and possibly very sick.
author: Karen B.

description:
This is my fourth experience here. And it was the most mediocre so far. I met a friend here for my birthday on July 29th about 615 pm. She arrived first and sat at the not crowded bar attempting to order a glass of rose, as the bartender ignored her for several minutes chatting with her friend.

We were seated and chatted and nibbled on the complementary crackers for over 20 minutes until our order was finally taken.  

One thing I loved about Dosa in the past was the extremely hot Chilli uttapam. It seems to have been change because the past several times I've ordered it, it has significantly been watered down. I want the chilli uttapam to blow my head off, but now it's barely got any heat to it.  And the other thing I loved was the passion fruit ganache tart with bittersweet chocolate crust and pineapple syrup. BEST DESSERT! 

So sad my two favorite reasons for visiting Dosa are gone and the service was a bit lackluster.
author: Charlotte M.

description: Thali is too pricey. Taste was bland. Drinks that we tried were realy bad. Lamb kheema dosa was relatively better. Their dosa was sort of burnt and the masala was tasteless
author: Anj C.

description:
I really enjoyed this place. The ambiance is incredible - they decorated the place really well. However, the lighting was very dim. It's great for a date night, but not if you're doing a dinner with a large group.

The staff was very nice. I got early and before my other 3 friends for our reservation, and they still sat me and served me water. A lot of restaurants make you wait until you have the whole party, which can be frustrating, but they sat me immediately.

In terms of food, I ordered a chai and the Paper Masala Dosa. The chai is very good! It's not very sweet, so make sure to ask for sugar if you're expecting something sweet. The Paper Dosa was really good and filling! The potato masala it comes with is a great side to the dosa. I would recommend it.

Overall, great food and service. I would recommend it.
author: Remy B.

description:
Amazing combination of spices and flavors! Dosa represents contemporary Indian food at its best--there are a variety of creative small plates on the menu as well as larger curry plates, dosas, and uttapam! Everything here is delicious and there's a reason this cramped little restaurant in the Mission is so popular!

We started off with a couple of appetizers--the farmer's market salad was made with juicy chunks of heirloom tomatoes and donut peach, served over a nicely spiced turmeric raita. The avocado chaat with grapefruit and coconut had a surprising raw chile flavor from habaneros that really packed a punch! One of my favorite dishes of the night was the lamb kebab pav sliders--the lamb was so tender and it was served with a yogurt and red pepper chutney sauce that brought the whole sandwich together! The sliders were also surprisingly spicy, so do be warned--but the flavors were absolutely incredible.

Then on to the dosas! The best part of the huge masala dosa was the thin, crispy lentil batter crepe, and we also had the paneer and peas dosa, which was a dosa wrapped around a mixture of peas and paneer. Both of these came with two different chutneys (my favorite was the cooling coconut mint chutney) as well as a lentil soup, all of which were perfect for dipping with torn pieces of dosa.

Finally, for our main course, we had the incredible green mango halibut curry. Oh my goodness--the curry was so flavorful, creamy, and savory, and the fried halibut fillet that sat on top was so flaky and tender. The plate also came with coconut rice and was dressed with crunchy taro chips. We ordered a side of the bhatura, a huge, puffy fried bread that was perfect for mopping up every last bit of the curry sauce.

Overall, this was an absolutely fantastic restaurant that will take you on a little flavor and spice adventure. Though a little bit cramped on the inside and though the service is a bit slow, don't let that stop you from coming to enjoy Dosa's modern, fusion take on South Indian food.
author: David K.

description: Food was really disappointing. The food is over priced and it doesn't even taste good. I ordered lamb expecting   actual pieces of lamb not ground lamb. The flavor is lacking with each dish as well.
author: Jacky C.

description:
So we were a group of 3 people and we reached this place on a Saturday night around 10.25 pm (after searching on Google and YELP that this place is open until 11 pm)

However, we were not allowed to get in as the receptionist told us that they are closed while there were many tables (5-6) which were still occupied by the customers.

We argued that we came there only after doing our Homework on Google and YELP but she still did not allow us to get in by saying that we forgot to update the timings online.

A request to you guys to please make these changes as soon as possible else many people like us will suffer the same issue again.
author: Pratham V.

description: Even the pickiest of first generation Americans who grew up with Indian immigrant parents are going to actually like this place. I stayed away from most Indian restaurants growing up, but DOSA really gets it right when it comes to fine tuning flavors and making it all approachable to a western palate without being TOO westernized. They found that balance, and it is fantastic. So take a journey and dive into the nuances of all the spices. Make sure you order an appetizer, a cocktail, and a curry or two.
author: Gerson M.

description:
Mind blowing....
Great ambiance, superb service and AMAZING Cuisine!!!

Lots of Gluten and Dairy free items, this makes me soooo happy! 

Also, side note they serve water with NO ICE! This rocks my WORLD!!!
author: Malia D.

description: Delicious food. The Chennai chicken and the Pulled Lamb were perfectly seasoned and cooked! Service could have been friendlier. Atmospehere was great!
author: Sara S.

description:
Good for groups *AND* they accept reservations over Yelp. Winning before the meal even begins!

DOSA is a SF classic, whether it's the Fillmore or Valencia location. The latter is a bit more casual of the two but still fancy by Mission standards. Food is on the pricier side, but the portions are what one might expect in San Francisco as well.

What to get: wine on tap, samosas, dahl vada, and of course a dosa! As many of the reviews have stated, dosas are like Indian crepes. A little bit bigger and a little bit crispier, with unique ingredients within.

Best practices when dining with more than five other people: Everyone order 1-2 dishes that they'd like to try, then pass the plates around for a small taste. Hopefully everyone gets their original order back in front of them to finish. It's hard to do this with small plates, but the regular portions are much easier to split and sample.

Also to note for groups: automatic gratuity added to the bill. NBD, just worth mentioning. 

Overall, an upscale Indian experience beyond the typical Tikka Masala that takes people out of their comfort zones in a tasty way.
author: Abby S.

description:
Ordered the paper mandala DOSA, lamb DOSA, samosas and coconut rice. 

Pros: 
- delicious 
- great service

Cons:
- a bit pricey
- not good in a rush
author: Capers B.

description:
This is not the Indian food that I'm used to, but it is SOOO GOOD! Our group of 9 set out to do the sharing thang - which I am a huge fan of! The ladies started off with sharing a carafe of white wine - on tap! This "on tap" thing seems to be quite the norm in San Fran! It was so good we ordered another! The dudes ordered mixed drinks as well as beer.

We started with some appetizers for the table which included;
Dahi Vada
Scallops
Vada Pav

Then we each chose an entree to share. There were a ton of Dosa being passed, but I was drawn to the lamb chops! OMG these tender chops of pure joy were amazing! I'm a huge fan of lamb and typically order it when it's on the menu. These did not disappoint! 

Now I know the difference in South Indian cuisine! Thanks Dosa!
author: Kellie M.

description: On our last night in SF, my friend and I decided to check out this place! Very happy with the decision we made! The food was impeccable and so was the service! We really enjoyed it! My masala dosa was so delicious ! I'm definitely going to come back here on my next trip to SF!
author: Tahini R.

description:
Where do I start?  Such an evening of up and down.  First, foremost, AMAZING front house manager.   She knows her business, and knows how to please customers.  I would recommend this owner does not lose her.  (Glasses, arm tattoos, short hair - Her name is Jean.  Owners - KEEP HER! She is amazing!)

So, first of all, here with my in laws, first visit EVER in 9 years.  So, just trying to make sure good impressions.  They are Indian, husband is Indian, I am not.  

Wine we ordered, out of it, but manager comes over, upgrades us to next level for same price. So far, so good!

Order "snacks" or appetizers as we usually call them.  Four of us, so double order of the samosas.  $13 each order..... and they arrive, tiny. I could eat two myself. (And folks, I am 6' and 165.  I don't eat like a pig). Ok........ chicken Chennai as the other. Good.  Decent size to share, not huge.  

Another appetizer - Onion pakora... Tastes great, but tiny shreds, not the usual battered clumps we are used to. Tasty however.  Not large.

First main arrives - shredded lamb.   The portion was the tiniest I've seen outside a tapas place.   My in laws stare at me, laugh (thank gods) and say - what is this? Is this a dinner?  (I begin to sweat)

I look at the manager (she was helping to serve, it was busy) and say "I hope the next dish isn't this sized." Hurried explanation on this being "small shared plates", come to find out. Surprise. Fail on the waitress for not advising when ordering.  It also didn't help the bowl was about 7 times larger than it needed to be. 

Manager handles the remark well - and I wasn't even that mad, just surprised.  In laws are watching!  

Manager returns (hello waitress? Where are you?) and says "I've doubled the portion of the chicken for you, I just want to make you happy.  (We ordered fish.... but, ok, I'll swing at this point - and waitress even warned us it would take an extra 15 min for fish....I'm just sweating bullets here). Channa arrives (chickpeas) - tastes, okay size, not a meal for one. 

DOSA arrives - the dosa itself is huge - now I think, ok, they are being funny now.... again, tasty accoutrements to the dosa.  But a dosa is just batter.

In the the end, a surprise dessert arrives (does the manger read minds and know I was freaking out about making sure the in laws were happy?!)

We get a 10% neighborhood discount.  waitress only took our order and served the bill - she best tip back really well to everyone else!! That was it.  Servers filled our water, manager served our meal.  

So, with 4 appetizers, 4 mains, 1 bottle of wine, 10% discount and comped dessert it was $195 plus a $40 tip.  I think bill is $$$ though.  I would say the restaurant is $$$ not $$.   Rents are high in San Francisco, so I get it.  Waitress better give most of the tip to the manager

We've been here 4 times over 3 years. Service is always really uneven.  The manager saved it this time.  But food is tasty.  Price is high though for what it is.
author: Todd M.

description:
This is a great option for south Indian food in SF. My menu favorites are: their dosas, Chennai chicken, their cocktails, uttapam dishes.

Their brunch (which they started serving not very long ago) is also a great option for a laid back, off the grid brunch option in SF. For brunch, their egg curry is a must!
author: Miriam L.

description:
Must Try for SF Restaurant Week!

Luckily, my friend and I were able to make reservations during SF restaurant week. We've heard nothing but great things about DOSA so we were very tempted to try it out. What better time to try it out than SF Restaurant Week?

What We Ordered:
SMALL PLATES (pick 3)
- Batata Vada: It's similar to croquette and was packed with a lot of flavor and spices. 
- Chennai Chicken: it's like eating popcorn chicken strips, do add the lemon to enhance the flavoring. 
- Lemon Chile Scallops: MY FAVORITE! Normally I don't like eating scallops, but I couldn't resist! A picture is worth a 1,000 words (see my picture)

DOSAS, CURRIES & MORE: (pick 3)
- Lamb 'Keema' Dosa: everyone's top recommendation and they were not wrong. it comes with this crepe-like bread to dip the sauces
- Mixed Mushroom & Truffle Oil Uttapam: It's like eat flat bread with mushrooms, a great pick for mushroom lovers!
- Coconut Chicken Masala: it was a bit spicier than I imaged but that didn't stop me from using the poori to dip it. 

SIDE: 
- Poori: it's like a giant puffy bread that's bigger than your head and super yummy to dip with all the sauces. 

DESSERT: (pick 2):
- House Made Sorbet: mango sorbet, really yummy!
- Pistachio Barfi: it's like a fudge bar with pistachio shreds sprinkled on top.

Great experience, great food, and great company!
author: Eva O.

description:
The food is quite average or below. Service is very very good, ambiance is ok. The sambhar was just not what a good sambhar shd be, though the idlis were nice and soft. The tomato chutney was the best. The dosa was average. The taste just isn't there. Thali was ok, Papdi chat while looked good tasted meh. It's not authentic Indian food. 
Our check came before we cd even order dessert, which might have been a good thing since taste is below par.
Oh and there was no line, that shd be an indication since Udupi in the vicinity had a line around the block.
author: Vicky S.

description:
Oh maaannn, this has got to be one of the best food (and service) experiences I've had so far! After putting off an Indian food dinner date for a few weeks, my dude and I decided to try DOSA while we were in the city. And man oh man, were my taste buds in for a treat! We had about a 15 minute wait after one other party (dinner on Saturday night), but we were fairly early at about 6:30. I believe the wait got longer as time went on- tip: the hostess told us we would be texted once a seat became available, but we didn't receive a text and were lucky to have been back in time!

Ambience is chill- they played tropical house music and there was definitely mood lighting. We were seated next to the window, which was a kind of off seating because there were four seats, so we sat side by side, knowing we would be sharing the meal.

I loooove that they give pappadum to start! They're these tasty lentil wafers/chips are so addictive, and the waitress even refilled ours after we finished them while waiting!

As far as our orders, we got:

-Mysore dosa with lamb keemah: My favorite dish of the night! Mysore dosa was deeelish with stuffed spiced potatoes, accompanied with chutneys, a soup like broth, and the lamb keemah. It was a bit spicy (but a delicious and bearable heat), and enough to open up sinuses...sorta

-Prawn malai curry with rice: This was delicious, but for the price, it wasn't worth it. I believe there were 7 prawns in curry- for $26. I would've opted for another DOSA :P

Delicious meal, 5 stars because the dosa lives up to the name. 10/10 would return to try the Utthapam and other dosas!!
author: Mary F.

description:
Absolutely Fantastic !!! My first reaction Two years back and today.           I am frequent visitor and so far this place has not disappointed me. 
I think this place deserves 4.5 stars overall. 

Ambiance :- 

I will not say its very spacious and comfortable restaurant but it is defiantly cozy and warm place with amazing food. I can certainly understand running very spacious restaurant in the city of San Francisco could be very expensive so overall considering all other operational factors in restaurant business I will rate 3.5 for the Ambiance. 

Service :-  

I found Service is little slow in comparison with other restaurants but it hardly matters because they will treat you with really good quality unlimited fried Papadam. 

Tip 1 :- Order Chatani sampler, this will really test good with fried Papadam. But make sure that you don't over eat papadam which will spoil your apatite for main course. 

Tip 2 :- I will really suggest restaurant management to inform guests about Chatani sampler. Getting that on the table is quick and it also enhance the entire dining experience.

Food :-  

I have tried almost entire menu and I really don't have any negative about the food quality. Veg / Non Veg , order anything it is prepared with absolute perfection. 

Indian food is prepared here without any western twist. They are very close to authentic Indian food experience. 

Pricing :-  

In my opinion pricing is not extraordinary and it is completely sound in resonance with food quality. 

Overall I will rate this restaurant 4.5 out of 5. 

San Francisco does not have many fine dining Indian restaurant but such restaurants are really giving good test of Indian food which really keep my hopes alive of for the future :) :)
author: Sourabh P.

description:
This was a unique Indian food experience in the heart of the Mission! We had excellent service on a busy evening. We really enjoyed the wine selection and the recommendation from the server. The food was wonderful and we enjoyed the chicken curry and loved that they had gluten free options and gluten free chips. The peas and cheese left much to be desired though and we wouldn't recommend it. 
We will be back next time we are visiting San Francisco!
author: Courteney M.

description: Small restaurant with a good ambience. Sambar (curry for dosa) is the best. Very good food and service. Rava Dosa is a must try.
author: Arthy N.

description:
After waiting 25 minutes for a beer (yep, a beer) I was about ready to throw in the towel and go to another joint, but seeing as how it's so highly rated I decided to stay. The food, while super flavorful, is a hit or miss in terms of quality from the dishes we sampled.

We started with the scallops appetizer. Priced at $18, it only included TWO scallops. Say whaaa?? Small scallops at that. I'm not sure if they'd run out in the back or what but that's pretty crazy. They came in a pretty tasty curry- the menu said lemongrass/greens/curry- there wasn't any lemongrass or greens so maybe it was just a bad menu choice all around for the evening.

I was also disappointed by the dosa we selected, the spicy mung masala. It was basically bland mashed potatoes inside a dosa shell- no lentils or any spiciness at all. Really wondering if they brought us the wrong one as it was so far off the menu description.

Our coconut chicken masala curry was probably the highlight of the meal- a solid curry by all accounts. We opted to get it over cauliflower rice which was also really tasty.

The food is good, however, I don't feel like we got what we ordered (again, not sure if there were just issues with the service/kitchen??) and that the price of the scallops was way off for what we got.
author: Elliott W.

description:
The dosa was great! 

Probably wouldn't challenge myself with another salty lassi for the time being, but will definitely go back to try all their interesting appetizers :)
author: Eve M.

description: Decent south indian food. Have been to this place a few times. Lamb keema dosa is also good. I have tried their lamb sliders couple of times. Both the times they were super dry.
author: Ashutosh K.

description: We love DOSA, specifically the Valencia St. location They have vegetarian options can be veganized. My wife and I had dinner with a couple that have food allergies & also gluten sensitive. No problem - lots of options. We had the avocado chaat, sprouted mung salad, channa poori, pulled lamb curry and raita.
author: Al G.

description:
Great array of dishes and the staff is so helpful and attentive. 
Great for small groups and a variety of dietary needs.
author: Krystal P.

description: This cozy upscale Indian restaurant makes for an excellent romantic dinner spot. We especially enjoyed their dosa and prawn vada!
author: Regina L.

description: This place is SOOOO good. I highly recommend getting the sliders from here. Great for vegans and vegetarians as well.
author: Kalani R.

description:
Amazing food and great ambience.

Idle spot for a date! (Fine Dinning)
We had loads of fun watching a friend try out their habanero Dosa.

He literally cried and asked the waiter to take it away!!

Disclaimer: Bit crowded on weekends..!
author: Deebs M.

description: Best South Indian in the city. Graceful service. Beautiful ambiance. Shout out to Anjan and team!
author: Vinith J.

description:
This is a review on their restaurant week menu.

I came to DOSA for restaurant week and, HOLY MOLY, this place one of the best Indian restaurants I've ever been to! 

Firstly, 40 dollars for 8 dishes is a steal! We had so much food! I wish I could remember the names of the dishes but I can only describe my favorites.

Appetizer we had beet cumin soup- it was very tasty and the perfect balance of beer and cumin. I'm hoping I can make it at home! It's like a tomato soup consistency so very comforting. Good for a rainy day. We also had a spicy chicken dish. Very tasty as well with a yogurt dipping sauce. Third, we had an arugula lentil salad... very good as well.

Entrees we had the lamb DOSA, a shrimp rice dish, and mushroom truffle dish. I wish I remembered the names! The lamb DOSA was very flavorful. And the lamb wasn't gritty.... I'm always 50/50 with lamb, but here it was good! The shrimp rice dish was maybe the least favorite of the dishes- still very good but I was still thinking about that lamb. The mushroom truffle was a good balance between the two protein dishes.

Dessert we had mango sorbet and a pistachio chocolate dish. The mango sorbet was very light and no overpowered in the sugar department. Very refreshing! The pistachio chocolate was okay- I probably wouldn't order it. 

I am very excited to come back to DOSA to try more dishes!
author: Marcie A.

description: This place is incredibly hyped up and is probably made for people that want to ease into South Indian food...the food was okay, but it definitely wasn't worth the prices.  The truffle dosa was good, when you got a hint of truffle oil, but otherwise it was like an extra oily dosa with very little masala filling.  We also ordered the Chennai Chicken, which was also extremely oily and hard to eat...If you want real South Indian food at better prices, I'd recommend Udupi which is right down the street.
author: Arthi N.

description:
We had diarrhea after the dinner. 
waitress so fake 
They need to improve the service
author: Ram L.

description:
Parking: Side street parking along residential area or take the bus/train.

Food: I love Dosa's they are very delicious and yummy. This place gives a huge variety of different flavored dosa's and a variety of fillings. We made early reservations for 4, it wasn't that packed when we got there but later on in it became very packed. The food was delicious, I just got a paper dosa - my friends got the lamb dosa. They were all really good and delicious.
author: Lisa Y.

description:
Pretty good dosas. Iffy service and prices. 
I might be biased because I grew up going to dosa places in suburban Jersey but I was kind of blown away by the price. It's not bad for SF standards, but I just didn't realize dosas could cost ~$15. 
Despite the price, these dosas are good. They're huge, the size of your arm.  They taste good, come with sambar and tomato and coconut chutney.  I got the lamb keema dosa with came with the meat on the side. I liked it as it did not have to strong of a lamb taste. It was nicely seasoned and went well with the dosa. 
The drinks here are pretty hit or miss. My boyfriend got the kittenzmittenz which was great. I got the bengali something which tasted like a mix of curry powder and mango nectar. All the cocktails (that we had) were somewhat spicy. 
One thing that irked me was the wait time. You definitely need a reservation here. We were told that we'd be seated in around 45 minutes. While we were waiting, we made an online reservation for an hour later just in case. We ended up being seated via the online reservation before I got a text for my in person reservation. Oh well. 
Overall I'd probably come again for dosas, drinks, and a nice date night atmosphere.
author: Amy X.

description:
Despite always being skeptical of fusion food (particularly when the presentation is pretty), but every visit to DOSA wows me with their tantalizing flavors and overall unique dining experience.

You start off with complimentary papadum (like an ethnic version of chips) which are light but frankly quite addicting with the nutty/lentil-y tastes. If you manage to save any, they pair well with the sauces of the main courses.

South Indian moons ($14.50, chef's selection of 5 different mini-uttapams): Although the pancakes were not crispy as I had expected, they were packed with ingredients. I think my favorites were the mushroom (an assortment with a seamless blend of spices) and the egg poriyal (the brunch version of the uttapam, remotely akin to huevos rancheros with the incorporation of potatoes and chiles).

Thali ($24): This traditional platter showcases a tour of South Indian flavors. The server did a great job introducing each one and even explained the order in which they should be eaten. It's more information than your typical restaurant setting attention span may be used to, but it was an enriching experience to learn about the ethnic cuisine in depth. (Disclaimer: the dishes below are not listed in order. If only I had photographic memory to recall things like this!)
- Seasonal vegetable porlyal: beets, quite pickled.
- Sambar: a lentil broth, light and pleasant.
- Rasam kootu: a sophisticated vegetable soup, subtly sweet from tamarind.
- Idili gunpowder: turned out not as explosively spicy as I had imagined (I was bracing myself for something akin to ghost peppers). Rather, it was a more multifaceted, refined interpretation of spiciness from various spices, beans, chili, and garlic. The texture was notably fine and soft (like gunpowder!)
- Raita: I may be too used to tzatziki, because I found this too watered down. It did do its job of cooling you down from the gunpowder.
- Achaar: I think this was my least favorite, very pungently sour.
- Payasam: a mildly sweet rice pudding. It seemed to be more aromatic with cardamon compared to other places.
- Paratha: pull-apart, deliciously flakey layers. Not too rich; a perfect vehicle for all the side dishes. I wish there were more paratha to mop up all the sauces from the other dishes as well P:
- Coconut chicken masala: I had dismissed the coconut as a trend, but it could have not have been better. The coconut added a distinctive and synergistic dimension to the masala, turning it into something of a Thai-Indian fusion curry. The portions were generous too, with the cup full of large meaty chunks of chicken.

Mysore dosa ($12.50): Given that we were dining at DOSA, we also got an obligatory dosa and the mysore was quite tasty. It had a bold spiciness, yet the base of masala potatoes and lentils anchored the dish to an overall homemade flavor profile. As expected, the dosa was excellent, thin and crepe-like with a satisfying filling of spicy lentil chutney.

While the Mission location lacks the grand tall ceiling of DOSA on Fillmore, it is still considerably ambiancey with the minimalistically colorful touches and modern design. Service was attentive, and our server was helpful in helping us navigate the menu and decide what to order. Metered parking isn't too bad in the area (especially during weekend brunch time... when half the city flocks to brunch hotspots).

In this era of overpriced toasts, I am definitely a fan of DOSA's vast menu for South Indian/California fusion culinary adventures (bonus: it's Instagrammable!)
author: Edna C.

description:
I ate a Dosa about 2 years ago and have been wanting to take my husband since then!   What a delightful meal!   The staff were just wonderful in explaining the menu and informing that the inspiration is from South India.::different from typical Indian cuisine.  the owner checked in with us and was so friendly and informative!   
We really enjoyed the Market Salad which had lovely Heirloom tomatoes, peaches, Chinese Radish and the most delicious curry dressing ever!  I wanted to lick the bowl!   
St the end of our dinner the hostess brought us a beautiful desert!   We will be back!!
author: Kim H.

description:
Disappointing experience compared to my first time at Dosa on Fillmore. The Mission location was heavily crowded, oddly humid and very noisy. This is a stark contrast to the upscale brasserie feel of the Fillmore location that has high ceilings and a considerably classier ambience.

That's forgivable to some extent because what isn't crowded in the Mission? However, the cold dosas cannot be forgiven. All of our meals but one came out within 5 minutes - the last taking about 20 minutes to come out. I joked that this last meal must actually be made fresh. Sadly this was true and it was the only plate served with a warm dosa :(. The curries were warm, mind you, but a warm crispy dosa is the best part of a masala dosa!
author: Sunil S.

description:
This was a terrific meal tonight and half-way through realized we had been here once probably about 10 years prior. Today we decided to have all small plates/starters rather than entrees. 
We had the chutney sampler with pappadam, corn poriyal, chicken chennai and the farmers' market salad. The corn and chicken chennai as well as the chutneys were my favorites. The tomatoes in the farmers market salad weren't as ripe as they could have been so it wasn't my favorite but the peaches were awesome and I bet later on in tomato season this salad would be spectacular. 
I didn't want to drink anymore alcohol tonight so had a South Indian Monsoon which had fresh ginger and was very refreshing. At the end of the meal I also enjoyed a madras coffee--mildly spiced coffee with cream. Yum!!
I would definitely come back here again the next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Heather B.

description:
As much as I want to hate Dosa on Valencia--and I have wanted to hate it since at least 2010 and possibly 2009, when Alyssa G. and I used to make fun of the fact that people always added the "on Fillmore" or "on Valencia" to the name for no good reason--I can't, not really.  Yes, it is sceney, and its Yelp ads at bus stops make it look even scenier.  (They don't do its owner and executive chef or whatever his title is any good-publicity favors, either.)  And yes, it is expensive.

All of those caveats are my wordy way of admitting fault, because the food is really good.  I mean really good.  You should come here to try it.  If you're scared of the scene, avoid weekends and maybe even Thursday nights.  Or you could come during Taste of the Mission Week (TotMW), aka Burning Man.  I came on the first Monday of this year's TotMW, and that day happened to have street-food specials, and of course I had to try one of them.  I tried the idli fries, and they are one of the best things I've ever eaten on Valencia Street, and I'll remind you that Valencia street is home to Udupi Palace and used to be home to Boogaloos (RIPish) and Herbivore (RIP, although this location wasn't good).

The crowning glory of my wrongness about Dosa on Valencia was when the owner and executive chef or whatever his title is came out and actually asked me about the food and talked to me a little bit.  Mind you, I was frumpily dressed (as usual), and I was eating by myself with a large backpack occupying the other seat at my table.  The guy had plenty of reasons and dollar signs to talk to much more important- and rich-looking people than me, but he took the time to ask me what I thought of the idli fries, and I couldn't lie, and I still can't.

The service is really good as well.

I don't think I'll ever be a regular, but I would definitely bring out-of-towners here, and the food really is good and worth the price as long as you don't come too often.
author: John S.

description:
Just as everyone says, this place is pretty bomb diggity.

Hopefully this helps a good bunch of you who are interested but I came here for Restaurant week 2017 after reading @lucyatcal 's medium post about the Best and Worst deals of SF Restaurant week--she had Dosa at the top of the list with almost $163ish dollars worth of food for about $40. If anyone is reading this during the week of Restaurant week (Jan 18- 29) first thing I have to mention is that the menu on the site is NOT the same as what they are serving in store! Hopefully they change that... but just a heads up, I actually think it's better because it includes more options of small plates and a choice of dessert.

My roommate and I (whom I'm sure you'll see her reviews of this place too ;) (shout to to you Marcie!) decided we had to finally try this place after hearing all about it and of course, realizing it was the best RW deal! So the two of us made a reservation and came here along with my boyfriend.

A couple things to note about restaurant week: as a table you pick 3 small dishes, 3 main dishes and 2 desserts and you share with the table. The waitress will portion it between however many people you have. I think the best deal is coming with 2 people but in any case, the servers are really good at making sure there is enough food so even with a big group, I'm sure it would be great :)

We decided to pick the following:
Small Plates:
- Red Beet and Cumin Soup
This was super good! Nicely spiced with a perfect bit of sweetness, this was like a gazpacho (except warm) or like a tomato soup, except with beets. Super smooth and luxuriously rich with a ton of amazing flavor. Definitely going to try and imitate it ourselves! It seems simple but so good and perfect to warm up your soul

- Sprouted Mung and Paneer Salad
This was nice--nothing to speak lengths about but it had lentils and a nice crunch from the mung bean. It was pretty refreshing overall, nice and light but also very filling. Ours came with only two small pieces of paneer and we each had a solid couple spoonfuls to try it. 

- Chennai Chicken
OMG so bombass. This was super good, moist and delicious chicken (probably the thighs) and it was covered in a crust and deep fried. It came with this yummy yogurt marinade and all three of us could not stop eating it it was so good, The perfect little appetizer and a taste for all palates :P

Main Dishes:
- Shrimp Biryani
This was really good, a sort of fried rice mixture with really soft rice and a bunch of spices plus a couple of mix ins and some shrimp. We got maybe 4-5 pieces of shrimp and a good helping of rice. This was a great compliment to the meal and just an overall solid option.

- Lamb Keema (Dosa)
In case you don't know, a dosa is almost like a mixture of a crepe and like a chip--it's fried on one side so that it's crispy and the other side is a little bit doughy but overall, the dosa at Dosa is pretty thin--great as like a cripsy and flour tortilla in one or a one sided crispy injera (yea, poor description but the closest I can think of!). You'll fill it with sauces, and mixings, just as you would like a taco or crepe or like Injera (ethiopian pancake). Our dosa came with this really nice spiced lamp mixture with some potatoes and on the sides we also got this like coconut green sauce, a spicy red sauce, and a big bowl of this reddish orange curry. Overall it was delicious, especially just mixing everything together!

- Organic Mushroom and Arugula Uttapam
This was basically like a pancake--it reminded me a lot of a vietnamese pancake or a part pancake, part omlette-y crepe. It was filled with delicious mushrooms and truffle oil and topped with fresh arugula. This also came with the chutneys and assorted dips which really complimented the dish. We described it as kind of like a pizza pancake aha

Dessert:
- Pistachio Barfi
This was a decadant little chocolate sort of cake. So good.... layers of cashew milk fudge with pistachios, ganache and all sorts of goodies layered into a perfect little cake. Its a small serving but so rich that we barely finished it given the small piece we recieved!

- Mango Sorbet
The best kind of sorbet period. You really can't go wrong with this, it's the besttttt

And that's that! At $42 a person and then additional tax and tip, it was a TON of food and RW was a great way to taste so much of their menu without breaking the bank, since this place is normally pretty high end. The food is really outstanding though and I know I would definitely be back and recommend this to friends. We were all STUFFED and I'm so happy I took advantage of this deal. Really looking forward to coming back!
author: Nerissa C.

description: Really love this place, my wife and I are frequent guests. Very authentic, well prepared south indian food and a great ambiance.
author: Ann L.

description:
Good food.  Distracted service.  We liked our cocktails and ordered 3 dishes to share.  The first two were quite tasty, but we never got the third one, When we finally got the attention of the waitress, she didn't have a clue where it was or what had happened.  We were pretty full, so we just left without ever getting the third choice.  

On food alone, my rating would be higher. . . it is very good always.
author: Brooke B.
Miko B.

description:
Dosa the best meals I've had all week! 

Puns aside, DOSA really was the top of my list of great meals I've had lately. Street parking can be a pain but there's a pretty decently priced garage next to dosa which is worth it because there are a number of things to stroll by on the Valancia. We went in to find a beautifully decorated, inviting interior and were greeted by the loveliest of workers (manager? owner?) who ended up being the one that took care of us the entire meal. He was incredibly elaborate with explaining the menu to us which was very helpful since Indian food is not something I am used to and know about. We asked him for a suggestion about the street food portion which I am so thankful we did because his recommendation was amazing. The menu changes frequently so asking for a suggestion is probably the better option as opposed to searching through yelp photos since they might not have something you're looking at. Our meal was shared between 3 people and we were all STUFFED. 

PANI PURI (small hollow crispy breads meant to be filled with cilantro-mint-chile, tamarind, black chickpeas, mung, squash) : Our servers recommendation and my personal favorite! He came to do a demo at our table on how to eat these since it was our first time seeing these. You are basically given hollow fried bread balls and you delicately poke a hole through it, as to not crack the entire thing. You then fill it a little with the mixture of chickpeas, mung, and squash. Next comes the sauces which you adjust amounts depending on your taste, the tamarind being sweet, and the cilantro mint chile having a kick! Fill that baby up with sauces and then quickly put the entire thing in your mouth before the sauces make it soggy. It was definitely a delicious experience. 

COCONUT CHICKEN MASALA: This came with an extremely lemony rice that complimented the coconut chicken masala very well and brought the flavors out deliciously. The dish was creamy, rich, and not shy of flavor at all. A must get! We used that warm naan to scrape up all the remaining saucy goodness.

MASALA DOSA (filled with creamy spiced potatoes, onions, & cashew nuts, served with coconut and tomato chutney, and sambar): If you love potatoes (which I'm sure you do unless you're an evil person) then you'll love this. It has so many spices in it you could see the specks of it through the creamy potato mixture. The dosa is so perfectly crispy, it contrasts the creamy potatoes and then the sambar (vegetable stew) is hot and comforting to wash it all down.
author: Maleah M.

description:
I don't usually write reviews on bad stuff because that's boring and I haven't had anything worth writing a bad review for but I need to get this off my chest about Dosa on Valencia ... the food on the night we went in fine ... no problems... the service good... that night.... however 
Can someone please tell me how I call this location on January 28th and ask about a lost sweater I left here last Sunday January 21st, and the hostess happily describes said sweater to a T and when I arrive to pick up sweater she was "mistaken" and brings me a bag of the lost and found with not a single piece that resembles my sweater and what SHE described o me on the phone?????  Maybe because this sweater had a petty pricy label on it???? All I have to say is KARMA and my patronage to this location is done and so are my recommendations.
author: Minette M.

description:
Expensive Indian food where you can taste the organic freshness. 

We came for weekend brunch and ordered the Masala Dosa, South Indian Moons (5 different types of uttapams), and Chennai Chicken. I enjoyed trying the different uttapams- my favorites were the one with mushrooms and paneer. The chennai chicken (aka: popcorn fried chicken bites) were decent but not mind blowing. 

The waiter said the Kerala Egg Curry is a popular brunch dish. It looks like 2 hard boiled eggs over rice with gravy pulled over. I eat A LOT of eggs in my life, so I decided to skip on this. I saw several other groups order it though. 

Friendly service. Beautiful environment with high ceilings, open environments, and excellent natural lighting (i.e. open windows in front). A lot of different people come here, and I've heard from my Indian friends that this place is legit. 

If you want to spend less $$, there's Udupi Palace just across the street. Never been there, but also has good yelp reviews.
author: Joanna L.

description: Great food! Nice service at the table, they're always open to explain anything if you have any questions about the menu.
author: Alejandra R.

description:
When you walk in, it doesnt look like An Indian restaurant...its more modern, cool lights decorations by the bar area. Although yelp says that you can dress casual but it looks very trendy where you kinda dress up a little

Since it was my first time coming here, my waitress was able to gave me some recommendation of whats good...

Here are what i got:
This place you free chip...a salty but crispy 

1. Mango fish curry...when it says curry on the menu, i thought it would be fish in a bowl of mango curry covering the fish, but it come out on a wooden circle plate with one filet fish on top of thin sauce of mango curry sauce with vegetables on the side. This dish was quite pricy...$29. 
2. White truffle masala dosa...indian version of a crepe/pancake. It was very long crepe/pancake. It depend on what filling you want to get...the one we got was mostly potatoes and some green looking pepper. It comes with 3 sauce
3. Chennai chicken salty a little spicy fried
Although the foods were food, the foods were quite expensive..,,
Friendly staffs
author: Julie N.

description:
Good: 
Truffle dosa was outstanding and creative.  
Specialty cocktails were inventive too, with unique twists inspired by the cuisine.  And they make a mean mango lassi.

Mixed: 
Asparagus vada (fritters) were super tasty.  Almost like fried cheese curds, with small bits of asparagus providing color and extra sweetness.  It was served with a chili seasoned mayo sauce.  I thought it was outstanding.  BUT...the portion size was very disappointing.  Five gumball-sized pieces were not enough for sharing with more than two people.  Even for one, it was a poor value at $12 for the plate.

Poor:
Uttapam with caramelized onions was not pleasing.  It was too heavy on the onions, and rather than caramelized they were crunchy and almost raw.  They were browned a little on some edges, but not a deep caramelization and sweetness like we were expecting.  The menu description hinted at another unique twist on a classic South Indian dish, but actually it tasted no different than uttapams I've had for a third the price at other South Indian spots, some just a few doors away. 

And the cheese and peas dosa was very dull.  It was just all cheese, a chopped up paneer with a hint of turmeric for color.  I found that filling flavorless.  But it pleased our 10 year old cheese lover, so maybe that's the target audience for it.  A little heavy for a kids menu item, in that case.

So overall, the room and bar area is trendy and fun for a date night.  But for food, it's too uneven, too pricey, not creative enough, and doesn't execute any better than South Indian places you can find in Sunnyvale, Berkeley, Fremont, or yes, in the Mission.
author: Joe P.

description:
We first visited the one of Fillmore, which is bigger and a tad fancier - it may be just the size that makes it look like that, the decor is kinda similar. Btw, I've never eaten a better Indian food - and I'm passionate about it and I tried quite a few - and my husband agrees with me! The price is ok, not super cheap like others, but the quality is absolutely worth it. 
The first time I had the egg curry - served with a paratha and some coconut rice that I absolutely need to try again because it's GORGEOUS - and the second the egg dosa (I need some animal protein at every meal and since I don't know where meat and fish come from...at least eggs are cage-free). The sambar and the red chutney are a little too spicy for me, but I have zero tolerance ;) 
I only wish they had a dairy-free alternative for their Chai Tea :/
author: Valentina G.

description:
Had to dine on the open bar because of long wait; so kindly reserve.
5* for vegetarian food that we ordered.
author: Nitya S.

description: nice atmosphere and great food. they charge 20%  for tips automatically that i didn't know till saw recipt.
author: えりか

description: I have dined here multiple times and the review is long overdue.Its an upscale indian restaurant with great food and drinks option.This particular location is a little small as compared to Fillmore one but I like this one better.There is almost always a wait of 20-30 minutes but the food is worth it.The idli fries are super delicious but I guess they just have those on some particular days.not every time.The servers are friendly and the service quick.The serving size is big enough and the drinks are so good too.I almost always try their "aaram se" cocktail and the bartender almost always gets it right.If you are in mood for good dosas and conversations with friends,this place is perfect.Avoid the weekends if you can.
author: Nikita S.

description: Loved! Slightly pricey given the size of the plates, $15 for a small plate. However, I can overcome any negative because the food was delicious. I had the chef's selection of uttapam- highly recommend. Be prepared to order several things to fill up, but both the food and the drinks are worth the trip. The Steph Curry is a very unique cocktail that was a crowd favorite when I went.
author: Mackenzie H.

description:
We spent HOURS looking for a place to have dinner in SF. We're from LA, so we were looking for something authentic, but gluten-free. We had actually put our name down at another restaurant nearby, but stumbled on this gem by chance. Let's just say, we canceled our rez at that other place. 

DOSA was a dose of greatness and more. We had the Spicy Mung Masala dosa, the chicken Masala and the Brussels sprouts. The food was scrumptious, filling and decently priced. The tomato chutney especially got our tastebuds tingling. 

But the biggest shoutout goes to our lovely server, Priscilla. She went above and beyond the call of duty and explained what the items on the menu were for us plebeians with absolute charm. She was able to discourage my boyfriend from eating the spiciest thing on the menu, and he never backs down from a challenge. But in the end, we were all glad he didn't. :)

Will definitely recommend to any and all visiting this bustling bay city. And we will no doubt be coming back next time 'round.
author: Erik V.

description:
This is our third consecutive bad experience at Dosa. Twice at Fillmore and now at Valencia. 

We ordered 3 items and none of the items were even close to good. 
1. Papri chaat 
Papri chaat was tasteless with overpowering avocado and little tamarind chutney. Good papri chaat will have yogurt as well as date tamarind chutney which will make it little sweet. 

2. Fried Idli
Friend idli was way too much oily. 

3. Thaali with Tamil Curry vegetarian
This was the worst among all three items. It was no way close to South Indian thali that you would get in many other South Indian restaurants. Thali had a basmati rice (instead of South Indian rice), stale lemon rice, oily paratha, raita (tested like it was made couple of days ago), ok dessert, ok sambhar. 
Other things were ok. For $20, you would expect much better food. 

On a side note, vada paav is served only in the evenings. It was a bummer for us as we went their specifically for vada paav.
author: Priyank G.

description: They got the dosa, sambar  and chutneys right. It tasted very authentic. The dahi vada was stale something that is always tricky to get right. The Madras coffee tasted like nescafe and was not the filter coffee I was expecting, so I did not touch it after taking a sip. But if you want good dosa, you should try this place. It had the right amount of crispiness with generous amount of ghee.
