For those of you who don't know what Dosa is, it is basically a crispy fried crepe packed with Indian food deliciousness (amount of deliciousness varies). If you've never had it, stop what you're doing right now. 

Seriously. Stop it. 

Go find Dosa and make damn sure it's good. Better yet, put Dosa on your GPS and get here now. 

This place does not disappoint, not in the least bit. There's a little bit of everything here for everyone, lamb lovers, chicken lovers, vegetarians, Indian cheese lovers (yes this is a thing). 

Tonight, we ended up tasting from the Dine about Town Menu which gave us an opportunity to try a couple things we normally wouldn't have. 

We started off with the Cochin calamari and Chennai Chicken. The chicken was coated and fried with a great cumin flavor. The calamari was definitely my favorite of the two though. The hints of coconut milk come out and give it a great balance and the calamari was perfectly tender. 

Second course was the Spicy mung masala dosa and Paneer and peas dosa. The Spicy mung dosa had a decent amount of heat to it and I found it a little bit harder to eat. I'm typically not a huge fan of mung (just the word sounds gross...mung...mung...bleh) but this dish was definitely tolerable and probably good if you actually like mung (bleh). Now Paneer I have a special place in my Indian stomach for. 

I will eat paneer like it is my f***ing job. 

This particular dosa was incredibly flavorful, which can sometimes be hard because paneer often just takes over the flavor of whatever it's in, kind of like an indian tofu mozzarella cube. 

My only gripe is that my friend I was eating with is an asshole. Now if you have read any of my yelp reviews, you'll know that spice is not always my friend. Well spice reared it's ugly head again and beat me mercilessly into submission. 

**DISCLAIMER**

Do not, I repeat, do not order the Mango habanero sauce unless you are prepared to be clutching a pillow for the next two hours, deduced to nothing but a puddle of heat sweats and shear pain. This is not white person "OMG, LIKE JALAPENOS ARE SO HOT" hot. No, it's "I rub ghost chilis in my eyes for fun" hot. It's flavorful, you think it's okay, then you start getting adventurous and put more and more on there. Then you realize that the enamel on your teeth have begun to wear down from the fumes. You've been warned. 

We finished off with the pepper chicken and pepper lamb with rice and yogurt. These were alright and honestly probably the weakest part of the night. Both were a little bit too salty for my taste, but they both had a great flavor profile (whatever the means). 

I will now digress. 

If you have read all you need to know to convince you to go to Dosa, please stop reading. But for the love of all that is great in this world (see puppies, ice cream, and Nicholas Cage), they have Pappy Van Winkle here. 

There are few bars, restaurants, homes, etc. in San Francisco that have Pappy Van Winkle. For those that are unaware to the world of bourbon, Pappy (in this case a 15 year) is the pinnacle of good bourbon. It's about $18 for a pour, which is actually really cheap for this particular blend, and you will be so much happier after having it. Also, who wouldn't want to have bourbon from a bottle which has an awesome old dude smoking a cigar? 

Anyways, look this is a great place and you should go check it out for yourself. The staff is pretty friendly, and the wait isn't too bad, provided you're willing to sit at the bar. Otherwise, make a reservation and please go stuff your face with some of the best Indian food in SF.
author: Brian C.

description:
Super surprised- especially considering the ultra-modern flair. Chutneys were buttery and flavorful and the dosas are spongey and crispy. Go for the super spicy dosa, they'll give you a sample of the sauce and it will be kind of unbearably hot, but order it anyways. You'll thank me. 

Honestly, best dosas in SF. If you're looking for better head out of the city. I just wished this place were full-veg. A tad pricey too.
author: Liz R.

description: Always a great experience. Brought my friends who are gluten and soy free and they had plenty of options and everything was delicious! Great cocktails, too!
author: Niki L.

description:
MOST OVERPRICED MEDIOCRE SOUTH INDIAN FOOD IN SF

So if you want good South Indian food in SF skip this joint and walk down the block to Udupi Palace if you can manage to get past all the lame ass people that hang out on this stretch of Valencia in the Mission these days, especially on a weekend night.

Doso is only ok taste wise and way overpriced plus they made this big deal about how their prices had to be raised due to Healthy SF. Cry me a fucking river and fuck off. The 100% yuppie/hipster crowd puts the icing on the turd cake that is this place. You can do better.

If you want legit Doso's head over to Vik's Chaatroom in Berkeley, it kicks this fuckin place's ass sideways.
author: ben s.

description:
I am a big fan of Dosa, every meal I've ever had is inspired and creative. I love the mixed drink too. 

You've got to get one of their masala dosas along with the cocktail that has beet juice (I can't remember the name). Great wait staff too. 

When restaurants have so many reviews I tend not to want to pile on, but this place is the real deal and I eat and cook a ton of Indian food.
author: Yvette K.

description:
Food was very good and fresh.  Not your typical Indian fare.  Service was good.  Atmosphere was upscale chic.  The only reason I am not giving it 5* is I was very disappointed in the portions of the Dine About Town 3-Course Dinner.  It's more of a petite sampler.  The portions were definitely smaller than ordering from the main menu.  

Maybe this is a false impression I have, but I thought Dine About Town was to promote business during a notoriously slow month for restaurants and that they have the 3-course dinner so patrons can try their food at a discount.  Not the case here.   I have been to other Dine About Town restaurants where they serve you the regular menu size.  The 3-course was $36.95.  Here, if I ordered off the menu, it would have been $47.  For the 21% discounted rate of $36.95, I felt like I received about half of the normal food.  I was not the only one who felt this way.  Like us, the lady next to us ordered the Kerala Chicken on the special.  I heard her pick up one of the few morsels of chicken and say, "Now, this is just sad."
author: Janelle O.

description: This place is crowded, service is slow, food is overpriced. Chutney has a lot of water In it which loses its taste. Worst of all the waiter fooled us into ordering some chocolate ganache dessert . We asked to make it togo as we were full. The waiter told us that the ganache dessert has small scattered pieces of cake, but ganache was most of the dessert . Since we don't eat eggs we asked her to not put cake in the takeout box. What we got was a mini kitkat size dessert for 10 freaking bucks ???? They looted us. The worst of all, it tasted like medicine and was the worst ganache I ever tried. Never coming back here again. Shame on you Dosa for treating your customers this way. I believe their other location on Fillmore is much better.
author: Jimish S.

description:
Dosa is my favorite Indian restaurant in SF.  I have eaten here at least a dozen times both for dinner and brunch.  I have NEVER been disappointed.  The food is amazing!  They use fresh organic ingredients that are in season.  

If you've never had south Indian cuisine, then you don't know what you are missing.  The food is unbelievably delicious!

Some of my favorites...  You can never go wrong with the mung salad, chennai chicken, a paneer and peas uttapam or dosa, seasonal curry or any of the brunch dosas.  They also have wonderful cocktails to wash down all that spicy food.

For anyone with a nut allergy, they have a special menu just for you.  With Indian cuisine it can be difficult as they use a lot of cashews and other nuts so this separate menu is very much appreciated by my friend with a severe nut allergy to cashew and pistachios.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Delicious! We came here on a Saturday afternoon so the restaurant wasn't too crowded, however we made a reservation just in case. Three of us ordered a cocktail each and all had a unique kick to them. I tasted the Peony and would probably get it for myself next time -- spicy and a little fruity (coconut I believe?) at the same time.

We got the pani puri as an appetizer and it was the perfect serving for the three of us to share. It was flavorful and the presentation was lovely. We then all shared the chicken karavali and the spicy mung curry dish and it all tasted great! I found everything to be perfect however my boyfriend and friend found it to be a bit spicy. 

Service was friendly and attentive; our waiter (although I didn't catch his name) was extremely helpful in our spice-level decision, and our food came out in a timely manner. The decor was minimal but had a few Indian pieces. I would definitely come back and would love to check it out for dinner.
author: Jamie B.

description: So far the best Indian restaurant I have been to in the Bay Area. I highly recommend the Dahi Vada for starter--great for a summer dish. The Dosa made an interesting dining experiences. Love the texture. Huge portion too.
author: Alexa X.

description:
It's a solid indian place with a delicious focus on dosa. I've never seen dosa anywhere else, which either points to my breathtaking ignorance or its relative uniqueness.

I've enjoyed everything I've eaten here except for the Habanero-Mango Masala. Unless you have incredible tolerance for spice, you will have a bad time with that particular dish. I pride myself on being able to handle legitimately spicy foods, but that menu item humbled me pretty quickly.

The White Truffle and regular Masala are fantastic and it's a great place to bring friends. It's pretty affordable and easy place to enjoy a cool meal.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
Excellent food. We ordered the lamb pepper curry, which was a little bit on the salty side, but very delicious otherwise. The prawn curry was excellent too. The chutney sampler appetizer was a very good beginning. 
Another thing that was a very pleasant surprise was that there was minimal delay time between order and delivery. Even in the middle of our meal we ordered a dosa and it appeared within minutes.
author: Rahul R.

description:
Differences between Valencia location and Fillmore location: The Valencia location is a lot smaller and has the Crispy Fish Pakora, while the Fillmore location feels a lot more hip/trendy.

Holy moly I love this place. Been here a couple times, and I've liked every single thing I've tried so far. Plus the papadums (lentil chips) they give you to start with are DELICIOUS ... I inhale them all in 30 seconds and have to ask for another bowl.

Pani Puri - These gems are AMAZEBALLS. 7 little pani puris for $8 - I would say this was the best appetizer. It was on a special mini appetizer menu so I don't know if they always have them, so get them while you can! Pani puris are little hollow crispy flour balls, and you poke a hole on top. Then they give you 3 items to fill it with (chickpeas, mashed potato, and mung beans) and then they give you 2 sauces (a slightly spicy mint chutney (sauce) and slightly sweet tamarind chutney) to pour on top. The guy who served them to us was so nice, and asked us if we knew how to eat them (we didn't), and expertly showed us how to make one/made one for us! The mint chutney was seriously YUM and I literally ate it by itself and poured it on everything else I ate the rest of dinner.

Crispy Fish Pakora - These are SO good! Little fried fish sticks. But now that I've had them a couple times, I'm starting to think they're not worth the $$$ (5 sticks for $11). Good to try if you've never had them before, though, and they didn't have them at the Fillmore location when I went.

Chennai Chicken ($9.5) - This was also very small but very delicious and flavorful, and comes with yogurt for dipping. ($9.50)

Lamb Pepper Fry ($19.5) - Good tender lamb but a little salty (and now that I'm looking at the menu prices, expensive too holy cow!). Very small for the price - think one cup of curry. We got it with the lemon rice ($3) but everyone said was good but personally, I'm not a big sour fan, so I'd probably go for coconut next time.

Channa Bhatura ($15) - "BIG PUFFY THING" - GET THIS! Fight with your friends over who gets to be the first to rip a hole and deflate the steaming bhatura. Slightly sweet, slightly crispy, and slightly chewy. You will have leftover chickpea masala so you can eat it with the rice or dosa or something later on.

Spicy Mung Masala Dosa ($11) - Best bang for your buck. Really good! Basically a giant crepe folded over with mashed potatoes in the middle. It also comes with a lentil soup, which you can also eat with rice too wooot!

White Truffle Masala Dosa ($12) - If you come here a lot like me and get bored of the Spicy Mung Masala Dosa, you should get this one! The filling is the normal potato/onion/cashew mix you you'd expect, but with truffle oil. I love truffle oil and you can really taste it here! 

Fennel and Spinach Dosa ($13) - This one's a little different from the other dosas. Instead of one big crepe, they divide it into a couple of smaller rolled up crepes. And it doesn't have masala, so there are no potatoes, and the filling is sauteed spinach and more vegetable-y. I personally like the other two dosas listed above better.

Uttapam: South Indian Moons ($14) - These weren't BAD, but they were nowhere as good as the other dishes. This was a sampler of all five uttapams and they were all pretty unimpressive, and kind of all tasted the same. Kind of like a small thick not-sweet pancake with different things on top. I would just not order an Uttapam and get another Dosa instead lol.

Drooling after writing this review... can't wait to go back!
author: Cynthia W.

description: OMG! The food was outstanding and only surpassed by the warmest and friendliest service from all the staff and in particular Jenny!
author: Sandeep M.

description:
We tried this place recently because we have heard so much about it although we live in Cupertino.

Thoughts:

1.  This is a fusion restaurant catering to Americans or Indians born here.
2.  Eggs in Dosa?  This is a sin.
3.  The service was horrific after waiting an hour. The staff behaves as though they are doing me a favor.
4.  The food was average in spite of being fusion.
5.  It is way over priced in typical Silicon Valley fashion. Charge more because rich techies feel better about themselves when they pay more.
6.  They also nickel and dime you on extras etc.

Not worth driving 45 miles for this place. It's just a fad that lasted longer than it should have.
author: Ash G.

description:
If you're looking for spicy and complex flavors with 'comfort food' feeling after you eat, this is a nice place to try. 

Giving three, instead of four stars, as our wait-staff was really overbearing, selling us on things that weren't exactly our taste, and insisting on her favorites, rather than helping us come to our own decisions.
author: Best M.

description:
Paneer peas dosa - good! 
Vada Sambar, Masala dosa.. And lassi was ok! 
Freshly made!!!
author: Sakshi T.

description:
I've been here about 3 times (and the one on Fillmore once or twice) and it's deserving of the rave: the food and service are fantastic (why aren't there more South Indian cuisine places??). While I blurrily recall the cocktails on Fillmore as being excellent, I more lucidly recall the meals (and lighter drinks) I've had on Valencia. 

Most recently I had the Peppercorn Chicken and my husband had the Hyderabadi Lamb. both were super spicy but Uttarly (sorry, couldn't resist a little Indian humor here)  delish. 

Of course, the signature dosas are super tasty and I've tried the Uttapam which, as one may surmise, is not unlike the Ethiopian injera, the spongy flatbread used to soak up and offset the spicy goodness.

The crispy tasty 'chips' served to start a meal are such a bonus, as are just about any bread-related side dish you get. All with fantastic service. Just don't abstain from the rice - you will need it!
author: Diane B.

description:
Hey, vegetarians, give us the room for a second. I need to talk to the meat-eaters. 

Are they gone? Nothing but carnivores reading this?... OK, good. 

I know that Dosa's page says "Vegetarians go nuts for this spot." In fact, most of their menu is filled with meat-free dishes that everyone around me was enjoying thoroughly. But once the entrees arrived, I realized Dosa's true secret. The secret that never seems to get mentioned on Yelp, but I'm about to shout from the rooftops.

Dosa...this Yelpy Insight for being super-vegetarian friendly (which they are)...has the best lamb I've ever tasted. There, I said it. I ordered the Lamb Pepper Fry and after one bite, I almost grabbed my fork and fought off the rest of the guests just so I could have it all to myself. If you have vegetarian friends who are sick of eating salad whenever you pick the restaurant, TAKE THEM HERE. They get inventive Indian cuisine, you get delicious, mouth-watering lamb that makes you believe in miracles.

Start off with the chennai chicken if you want to prepare your palette for all the sumptuous meat that most of the patrons will be missing out on. You won't find your traditional Indian fare (chicken vindaloo, etc.), but you'll expand your horizons, and maybe, your definition of great Indian food. 

Now call the vegetarians back in, and tell them you'll take them to Dosa tonight. For them. For putting up with your meat-eating ways. You're welcome.
author: Kevin B.

description: Fantastic! Their uttapam and pappadams brought me alllll the way back to India. Can't wait to go back, especially for the south indian fish curry!
author: Tasha R.

description: Cochin Calamari was fantastic.  The dosa was too salty.  The chutneys and sambar was sub par.  I can skip this place next time.
author: Vijeev M.

description:
I'm usually not an Indian food fan, but this place takes Indian food to the next step.

Sure, there is curry on the menu, but everything else is different. I guess this is "southern indian" food which is famous for dosas and uttapam? 

Disclaimer: clearly I'm no Indian, so I judge Indian food like how American's judge Chinese food --- if it fits my appetite, who cares if it's real.

I've been here twice. Here's what I think about what we got:

Chennai Chicken --- bite-size fried chicken pieces. Nothing too fancy but a nice appetizer.

3-cheese Dosa Roll --- this is the s**t. It's good. I mean this place makes good dosas and how wrong can you go with three cheese blends? Crisp dosa rolled with a rich, creamy, salty cheese. Even though it's an appetizer with just two slender rolls it will make you very full!

Watermelon, Paneer & Mung Sprout Salad --- a very light, refreshing, and beautifully balanced salad. Fully recommended.

Lotus Stem Day Boat Scallops --- juicy, thick scallops that were lightly burned on one side and lightly sauced with a side of fried lotus slices. Yummy!

Hyderabadi Shammi Kebabs --- weird stuff. It's like a tiny pancake-y thing topped with a mashed protein substance that is supposed to be lamb. And yet it's called a kebab. My husband thought it was OK but I thought it tasted like sad sheep.

(forgot the name) baked brussel sprout & squash with coconut sprinkes -- a hearty healthy dish. The coconut sprinkles bring that extra sweetness to the warmth of the veggies.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Where else can you find a bhatura the size of your head? I love this place. It's one of my top SF Indian restaurants. I've been here several times and the food is always consistently delicious and filling. There can be a wait, but once you get in the staff are friendly and the service is good.
author: Ada C.

description: Food was good, but lacked the special tastiness of yesteryear's Dosa. A bit more like Trader's Joes fare now, like it was mass produced.  We ordered wine, not even mixed drinks and it took forever to show up. I mean, way after the food arrived. And the food also arrived randomly, one little dish after another, never all at once. Waitress spoke as if she were an auctioneer.  Maybe it was an off night? It wasn't too busy and perhaps the service (and food) improves when the staff is under pressure. (Also they list the SF health fee on the bill, which is pretty tacky.)
author: Adam K.

description: I'm happy to write my first yelp review ,The valentines dinner was so special with great wine pairings here, the Restaurent was jam packed,let me start with food - we got lamb chops as part of the 4 course menu which is a great deal and it tasted spicy n tender but delicious went well with wine pairing ,second course we had saffron uthappams topped with cheese n green peas , we tasted real saffron in it and yummy by itself, sambar was tasty too, but I enjoyed eating both seperatly , third course was the salmon perfectly seasoned , the quinoa n brown rice with coconut tasted perfect with the mango curry ., moving to dessert the lava cake was rich in chocolate saw the lava flowing out ., overall it was a wonderful valentines with my partner and both will come again for sure., -:).
author: Rambo R.

description: The food and the ambience made this a great choice to end our San Francisco trip.  It was a lovely evening with the family leisurely eating and good conversation.  There are a lot of great restaurants in the city but the noise level diminished those experiences for me and made this one stand above.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Came here with a couple of friends looking for some spicy food. And boy did we get it!

The ambiance is pretty good inside. It was dark with intimate tabling, and fairly crowded during dinner. I was a bit inebriated so I can't recall what we ordered, but besides the curry we had an interesting spicy puffed bread per the recommendation of our server. Spiciest night I've had in SF for sure.
author: Christophe C.

description:
My Indian BF (like that gives me more CRED to rate an Indian restaurant?? ROFL.) settled on Dosa after we watched The Geezer at The Marsh across the street (great venue, great people-- different review for a different time.) I had initially wanted to take him to Upidi but he pointed out, "Its Vegetarian." SO, we checked out Dosa on a Saturday night around 7p (we had tried to do an open table reservation around 6p (during intermission) and open table pulled up 8:45p as the first table available at Dosa. We decided to go and check it out at 7p anyway and actually had no wait to sit at the bar. (Fortune cookie advice: If you're desperate to eat and can't wait for your reservation, try your luck. You may get lucky.)

We had the fish pakora as an appetizer, 5 stars. Perfect crunchiness with great fish texture and sweetness. Have had better chutney than the two they supplied. 

Masala dosa & lamb pepper fry with lemon rice on the side: both saltier than I like but overall alright. Loved the dosa (BF: "this is authentic. 4/5") and the lamb (BF: "3/5"), just wished things were less salty. 3 stars out of 5 (my boyfriend's lamb dish is much better), have had much better sambar (though, it may be because I like okra in mine *it is key to any good sambar!* and this one just had some squash and potatoes and carrots?) So, I guess it would be a subjective 2 star rating because I've had better (which, is the definition of a 2 star on Yelp) and I can't deal with salty foods. But, since the fish pakora was worth another trip, I'd say it was a 3 star, A-OK in my book. I think I'm becoming an SF food snob. :) 

Had the South Indian Monsoon as a drink and it was pretty good-- I really like ginger. Chai was alright: heavy handed on the cardamom, per my boyfriend. And he said his Chai was better... can't argue with that.
author: Vicki T.

description:
Having heard a lot about this place, my girlfriend and I decided to check it out, despite the pricey menu. We took the BART from Fremont and got delayed by half an hour. We called ahead and explained to them that we were getting late. They were very courteous and said it wouldn't be a problem as long as we were done by 830 pm (we reached at 730 pm).  All that didn't matter as they had our table ready and we had pretty much decided what we wanted on the way to the place. 

Once seated, service was quick and our waitress was really nice and friendly. We ordered our food and less than three minutes later, we had our Dahi Vada. Being Indians in a very pricey restaurant, I guess our expectations were equally high. The $9 Vada was not even worth half as much. The presentation was nice, but that was it. The Vada was old, had too much cumin, and was a huge letdown, especially since we'd heard it was a favorite. Just based on that, I immediately gave it 1-1.5 stars. Next, I ordered Rasam for my itchy throat and literally the only thing good about that was that it was hot and seasoned with spices reasonably well. It tasted pretty sad though. My rating was now a solid 2. My girlfriend still hovering at 1-1.5. At this point, we were actually talking about opening our own restaurant and how much better we'd be at making Indian food. 

Then came our main course dishes and lifted our ratings to 3 stars. We ordered a Channa Batura and a Masala Dosa. The Batura was the largest I've ever had, and that includes restaurants in India. It was a standard affair, except of course, it's sheer size. The Channa was, well.. We make it better at home! The Masala Dosa was bland as a wall, but the tomato chutney and sambar were very nice. In all fairness, we didn't ask for it to be spicy, because, well, we didn't know what to and what not to expect. The Dosa itself was well cooked and tasty, if of course, you didn't care about the flavor too much. All that these dishes did was add $25 to our bill of $13 and boost our rating of this place from 2 to 3 stars. 

We would never go there again, if we could help it. If you like Indian food, but can't handle the spices that normally go in it, go there!
author: Akshay I.

description:
I'm addicted to this place...
Start with the Dahi Vada for sure. Then go for any Dosa except for the White Truffle Dosa (what were they thinking?!) My favorite is the Rava Masala. Then end with Rasmalai!
author: HipsterChick S.

description:
This was my first time at the restaurant and my first time having a Dosa. Success! I went there for dinner at the suggestion of a coworker. The ambiance seemed nice. While there I saw groups, couples and folks at the bar enjoying themselves. The staff was pleasant and the food presentation was pleasing.
I ordered the tasting menu with the Fennel Spinach Dosa and Prawn Masala. Everything was fresh and amazingly seasoned. Three sauces were provided with the dosa and each offered a diiferent, but very yummy experience. 

I'll definitely dine at Dosa the next time I'm in SF.
author: Christian C.

description: Dosa is amazing!!! Everything from the food, desserts, drinks to the service. Try the Peony cocktail and house made icecream. Jenny, the waitress, provided the best service at a restaurant I have ever had. I didn't know much about the food before I went, but when I left, I learned so much (see you later delicious, but typical tikka masala haha). She was super knowledgeable about the food. Thanks again Dosa!
author: Meghan R.

description:
My boyfriend and I had a great meal here the other night. The Vada Pav (vegetarian sliders) is easily one of the best things I've ever eaten in my life.

Must orders: Vada Pav, Lamb curry (get it with the lemon rice-- killer combo recommended by our waiter)

Just ok: Pumpkin Dosa

Skip: Chennai Chicken (flavorless)

** I also must note that our waiter was fantastic. He was incredibly attentive and told us exactly how to enjoy each and every part of our meal as it came out (i.e. dip this into that before dipping it in this other thing). Great service !
author: Jaime M.

description: 2nd time here, and honestly horrendous service. Food is good, but it just didn't make up for the wait & bussing staff tonight. I don't remember leaving with such a bad taste in my mouth after my 1st visit, so maybe they were all having a terrible night. Maybe they'd all just been told they were getting a pay cut. Or they were getting fired. Who knows. But everyone we spoke to after the host was just rude.
author: Ashley C.

description:
Okay...I have NO idea what I ate or what was ordered but it was all delicious!! The service was really attentive and helpful, too. 

I'm not big on Indian food and Dosa is South Indian which apparently means less curry? Honestly I have no idea but the lamb dish and all the breads were very tasty. 

I would go again and am currently craving it so badly I just might!!!! I have never said that about Indian food in my life.
author: Jay H.

description:
There aren't many times when I come home for a visit and we get seated promptly for Sunday brunch/lunch, but yesterday was one of the exceptions. I guess it didn't hurt that we arrived around 2:30 pm - one hour before they closed. The restaurant was pretty empty so our waiter was very attentive to our table. I was pretty excited to come here because I love Indian flavors and this place also made Michael Bauer's 'Top 100 Bay Area Restaurants for 2009' list, which just came out the previous weekend.

I was sad that they ran out of the meat curries by the time we got here, but I am pretty used to eating vegetarian Indian cuisine. In fact, the flavors from the lentil soup were very similar to the Vedic food that I've had from Hare Krishna in San Diego. As for the menu, our waiter was very helpful in suggesting the dosa and uttapam plates. Dosas are very reminiscent of crepes and uttapams are similar to scallion pancakes. 

We ordered the masala and spring dosas and the caramelized onion, paneer & peas, and seasonal fruit napoleon uttapams. They all came with a coconut and tomato chutneys and a sambar (soup). I loved the smokiness of the sambar and the coconut chutney didn't have an overpowering coconut taste. We also added an egg plate of which I don't remember the contents. The flavors were simply amazing. I actually preferred the uttapams to the dosas because the thin crispy dosas had a tendency to get cold very quickly. We also tried six additional chutneys of which I only remember three. The spicy habanero is not for the faint of heart and the sun-dried tomato one was too overwhelming. I did enjoy the sweet mango one. 

As a diner, sometimes I love having the choice of creating different flavors for my meal. But in some instances, I need the chef to do the directing. The multitude of dipping chutneys was very confusing. I know that people have different preferences, but it would have been nice if one chutney paired well consistently with one dosa or uttapam, like a wine pairing. There was a lot going on with flavors already and to throw in so many things was a little overwhelming - in the end, everything started to taste the same. I also didn't care too much for the mango lassi - it looks better than it tastes. We saw a couple people have this at other tables, but the yogurt was too thick for my liking. Despite my complaints, Dosa is a top-notch restaurant. The staff is very professional and it shows that they put a lot of effort into their food.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Wonderful place. Great food. Great music. Awesome host. 
+1 for the tea. They put a western touch to south indian food without messing with the basics.
author: Anant K.

description:
So it's just me and my boyfriend, and all we ordered was two entree's and two drinks which weren't even alcoholic beverages mind you...

And yeah the food was good not necessarily extraordinary but OMG! So the bill came out and you know what it came out as? $30 PER PERSON (including tip)!!! $30!!! For an Indian restaurant?!?!? ARE YOU FREAKIN KIDDING ME!

I was so traumatized that I called my best friend (who is Pakistani) and told her what just happened that she was shocked to the core.

I mean yeah, the atmosphere is nice but...but $30!!! (T^T)

I think I would prefer a hole in the wall nice Indian family serving me any day!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Our waiter was nice and attentive. Door staff (bartender in a hat?) was unpleasant when I walked in. No one greeted me when I entered, so I decided to find my party on my own. When I took a step towards the dining area was when staff decided that they wanted to acknowledge my presense and get up off a bar stool in a "whoa-whoa not so fast" manner. 

Luckily the food made up for a rather unpleasant entrance- we ordered the channai chicken, cochin calamari, South Indian moons, mango habanero dosa, and prawn masala with coconut rice.

The dosa was amazing and fi-yah! The waiter was like "Are you suuure? Let me have you sample the paste first before you go and order that." After tasting the paste, we went for it. I could handle the spiciness, but my dear friend was near tears. All I can say is.... proceed with caution*

Both channai chicken (did not look like the pictures posted on here...was a little disappointed) and cochin calamari starters tasted delicious and my faves of the whole meal. The moons were also very good and I enjoyed sampling the varieties. The prawns were large and plentiful. Also very good. 

I would return if someone else suggested it and we were nearby. Not necessarily at the top of my list though.
author: Neeners H.

description:
That's right... It's my first 5 star for a restaurant!

I've been to this Dosa location twice and both times I've left extremely happy!

Our group ordered a vegetarian thali, the habanero mango dosa, and rava dosa.

The thali had great variety and the food stays true to its South Indian roots. I was disappointed that the habenero mango dosa wasn't spicy enough- but I may be an  anomaly! 

The rava dosa was crunchy and soft .....all at the same time...

For great South Indian food in a 'not so typical South Bay Indian restaurant' setting visit Dosa!

Great Dosas with great drinks! Who can resist!!
author: Anitha C.

description:
We had Chana Bhatura and Prawn Masala and it was good. I would have given it 5 stars but the price for the items were ridiculously high. It is perfect for non-desi's but as we prefer flavors, spices in our indian food, I think that was missing. 
The cocktails are really good though. Definitely worth trying.  Highly recommend Shere Khan.
author: Mukul B.

description: Yum! I'm not a super adventurous eater all of the time, but loved trying this place! Shared the paper dosa and a spicy chicken curry with my man. The paper dosa was amazing, it looked like a huge bugle (those weird corn chips) that came with spicy mashed potatoes and the most amazing lentil soup to dip it in. All the flavors were great and fun to mix and match all the dips, sauces. Mint lemonade, refreshing! Also my friend is gluten free and there were so many options for her, which was really nice!
author: Amanda M.

description:
This is truly as good as it gets. 

Whether you've tried Indian food or not - are a meat or veggie lover, you're sure to find something here that is mind-blowing. 

Recommendations:
Vada Pav - think: Indian sliders
Truffle Masala Dosa
Dahi vada - if you're a yogurt lover. Also, presentation is gorgeous
Paper Masala Dosa - more traditional than truffle 
Bhatura
author: Nadine H.

description:
My order - Habanero masala dosa, coffee and coconut custard cake

Taste - Excellent. Creative south Indian food. Best dosa in Bay area. Authentic taste. Habanero chutney added twist to the dosa taste. Coffee was not filter coffee, bit disappointed. Coconut custard cake was coconut burfi with curry leaf tempering. 

Proportion - Decent

Ambiance - Bright and happening place. 

Staff - Friendly

Value for money - Expensive

Wait - Quick

Visit - Masala dosa is a must try !
author: Dee S.

description:
Ate here after more than five years... hoping that it had improved. 

Bad idea. Ordered the Keema Dosa. I couldn't finish even 30%. The dosa was terrible - probably cooked in reused oil. The meal was so heavy and unpalatable. I cannot believe that this place is still open. 

The worst South Indian food in the bay area.
author: noflaps c.

description:
This! This is what I have been looking for in Chicago -- South Indian food that makes me whip my hair back and forth (just whip it). Dosa, I have a concussion because I have been whipping my hair back and forth since I ate here (and dry eye syndrome for weeping that you are so far away from me).

To begin with, Dosa is so on top of it, I ate here during a SF heat wave. You heard me. Evidently, things like 'air conditioning' are unheard of in (some? many?) SF restaurants. So, I was fortunate enough to be walking the streets like a hooker during these hot times in the city. What to eat on a hot day? Indian! So, the fact that I loved the experience despite sweating like a wh0re in church really says something about the quality (and company).

I discovered Dosa thanks to one of my oldest friends with whom I'd recently re-connected (later in the evening, one of my best buddies and his gal pal joined us). Psyched to be catching up, I ignored the menu for a while to just sit and talk. But, talking can only take me so far. I needed food. And, we got it. Before I chat up the food, though, I need to give much thanks to our server. She was helpful and present without being hovering or obtrusive. Nicely done. Check this spread:

Calamari sauteed in coconut milk and served with greens -- succulent. Each bite burst with flavor. To do the dish justice, couple the meat with the milk with the greens. Perfection. It got the point that even though we hadn't seen each other in years, my friend and I sat in silenced and grubbed on the octopus;

Prawns with coconut rice, chile, coriander, and more good stuff -- ridiculous. These prawns had been living the good life; they were huge. Their natural sweetness when added to the spice of the chile and coriander created a party in my mouth. The coconut rice dulled the heat enough to leave amazing flavor on the plate and in my belly; and

Cilantro Mint Masala Dosa. So, this is what dosa is supposed to taste like. I'd had a dosa experience in Chicago that... wasn't like this. I loved it. I loved every bite. The crepe was flaky, the sambar was interesting without being overpowering, the chutneys were a taste and texture success, and the mint/cilantro went brilliantly with the potatoes and onions.

I washed down all this yummy food with a couple of glasses of Chilean rose and I couldn't have been happier. It had been years since I'd seen my friend. It had been years since I'd eaten delicious Indian food. I had *never* had memorable South Indian food. Everything blended perfectly on that hot summer day. Dosa is made of win.
author: Johnny T.

description: I had some doubts because this place sounded kind of fusion-y and i've generally been disappointed by that kind of stuff in san francisco. but I was pretty pleasantly surprised, I got the paneer & peas dosa that came with sambar and two chutneys, and it was all really good. The only problem was that for what you pay, this place had really small portions. I could comfortably eat two of their dosa entrees, so I just wish it was more food.
author: Amaresh S.

description:
It was my first time going to this location, but the food is the same at both locations, and I appreciate the consistency. I appreciate the variety of dosas this place has to offer. I like to try different dosas every time I go. 

I love anything spicy so last night I decided to try to the Spicy Habanero Masala Dosa. My server warned me that it's REALLY spicy ams I decided to order anyway. Whooooooo..... I can usually out spice most people I know but this dosa was ridiculously utterly out of this world HOT!!!  Consider this warning. I had to order a Mango Lassi with my dosa to finish it which I'm proud to say I actually did! 

The only bad thing was the service could have been faster and a bit more attentive even though it was close to closing time. On the plus side, we were there well after closing time but they were nice enough to let us leave on your own instead of kicking us out.
author: Hiral H.

description:
I'm tough on Indian food ... So this could very well have been four stars.

I have eaten a lot of really good dosas ... Of all kinds (plain, masala, Mysore, rawa, keema and many others). I typically rate a dosa restaurant based on their masala dosa and their rawa masala dosa. In this case, the masala dosa was fine, but the rawa masala wasn't. There are definitely better places for dosa ... Sadly they are all in the South Bay. 

Interestingly enough, their meat dishes (chicken chettinad, lamb etc) were quite good. Overall, average food, nice ambience and good cocktails.
author: Ankur V.

description:
I came here on a Saturday with a few of my coworkers. We had a reservation so we got seated pretty quickly, the restaurant was crowded and bustling..yet homey, earthy romantic and warm.  It was my first time at DOSA and I wasn't too familiar with the cuisine at all, so basically what we did was shoot in the dark and ordered a whole bunch of random appetizers from chicken dishes, salads, soups, meats... Sadly, I honestly can't give you all the technical names of these dishes.. but what bodes well for a restaurant is that a naiive indian food eater like me can order about 7 random appetizers and dishes and like each and every one of them. 

The cocktails were delicious - they have a full bar, or my FAVORITE which was a make your own cocktail - you describe to the waitress what you want and they bring out a surprise. this can quickly get dangerous because I asked for a sweet and tangy drink that packs a strong punch! 

Overall - next time around i'll pay attention to more of what we ordered, but definitely would come back! It's a a hard to park in neighborhood unfortunately :(
author: Christine B.

description: Came here on a tasting tour and this place knocked it out of the park. I really want to update when we can come back and comment on the service/ prices, but for now I'm dreaming of the Dosa with truffle oil we had. Easily the best thing we ate all day (and we went to several Mission hot spots), and I can't wait to return!
author: Alyssa J.

description:
Personally not a huge fan of Indian food but my friends who I was staying with highly recommended this place.

Great experience, wait staff could have been a bit more attentive (mainly the reason for the 4 star instead of 5).

Food was good, well described on the menu especially in terms of the level of spice. 

I had the Hyderbadi Lamb Chop w/ lemon rice which was excellent, I recommend trying that if you do enjoy lamb.
author: Sean M.

description: Went here with a friend who had gone to India with me back in 1987 as part of an undergrad program.  She was here from Boston with her family and we hadn't seen each other in years - I wanted to go somewhere special and more modern fusion.  She is vegetarian and we have both had many many Indian meals together and apart from hole in the wall to uber upper end.  She married an Indian man and he just calls it 'food' 8), but she and I have a ritual of Indian dinner every time we see each other, which isn't often.  We hesitated because she and her husband had planned to go here the next day ... she felt like she'd be cheating on him ... but I convinced her that it would be no waste to go two days in a row - plus she could go to the one on Fillmore for comparison.  Just perfection! We LOVE dosas and the variety here is amazing, each one is truly unique and yummy.  The coconut chutney is amazing, light, crunchy, cool.  My all time favorite snack is the Dahi Wada (which are little rice dumplings in yogurt sauce with tamarind drizzled on top).  The Dahi Wada's here are very small compared to ones I've had other places, but they are delicate, almost fluffy and I could eat them every day!  The cocktails are artisinal, the atmosphere hip but warming comfortable.  The portions are small for the price (like if rice comes with your dish, it's like a half of a cup shaped sweetly with a garnish of cartelized onions on top) but you don't leave there feeling gorged (unless you went whole hog ordering tons of things, which is easy to do).  The smaller portions allow you to order more and taste more, so I think this is actually a bonus.  We left feeling very very satisfied and even a little giddy. p.s. they give unlimited papadum! YUM!
author: Deborah H.

description:
Northern Indian food at its best in San Francisco.

Lots of great stuff here. Ask your server to help you pick some things. I'd definitely recommend eating "family style" and sharing several dishes. This is the best way to go with a lot of the curries and chutneys.

It can get very crowded here, and when it's crowded, it's LOUD. Definitely make a reservation.

It's simple, but I love to get the masala dosa every time I come here. Personal favorite!
author: Nick D.

description: It's a nice place and I am a regular costumer and close to my house last on labour day they were closing at 10 and I reach at 9:58 one of the employe says kitchen close at 10 and they can't take any order to take but they can order if I eat in Resturant. I didn't like it then I went out and then I go back in to ask what time other location close and some one els  attended me and she was so nice while I ask for another location time and leave she came to the end of the block and ask my order and I feel so good about that she turn all my anger in good way before I was so upset and feel insulted that's they can't take my order even I show before time.
author: Irshad S.

description: I have eaten here a couple of times in the  past few years and it's consisently been good.  On my list of one of the better south India places in SF (and on the West Coast). Friendly staff, seating is a bit tight in places.  Typically have had the Spicy Mung  or Sweet Potato Dosa.   Portions are huge (but ample.) Chutneys are good (although on a couple of occasions they seemed a bit watery.)
author: Beth J.

description:
Solid spot. Some good wines and great late hours.

 I love the veggie sliders, so much flavor packed into each morsel.

The Torrontes is a great wine,  and it compliments their food very nicely.  

Service is consistently good. Try the paper dosa and come hungry because portions are huge.
author: Jacklyn H.

description: Shikampuri Lamb Kebab, Habanero Mango Masala Dosa and Truffle oil Dosa are out of the world! Its so good I have not gotten myself to try a fourth dish there yet!
author: Sandra M.

description:
Really good, really authentic Indian food.  Spicy and delicious and really well informed staff.  Service was great except that we had to ask for more Naan bread a few times.  Would have been ok except my mouth was on fire and I was dying.  The table next to us hardly touched theirs and I almost reached over a grabbed a piece.  

The place was packed and LOUD and that was on a Tuesday.  Given the quality of the food, location and service, it is very well priced.
author: Jamie C.

description: Not typical Indian cuisine. I can't say it was the best Indian food I've had but they messed up my order and took care of the bill. Hence the 4 stars.
author: Michael A.

description:
Wow!! I believe the word is PHENOMENAL!!  :) Every bite of our dinner was delicious! 

An overall fantastic experience! From the hostess who graciously asked a couple if they could move down one seat at the bar to make room for us to avoid a 45 min wait, to the bartender who made me an amazing drink (Peony), to the most tender, juicy, flavorful lamb my boyfriend and I have tasted! We shared the lamb entree and a masala dosa, which was plenty for two!

VISIT Dosa - your taste buds will thank you!
author: Paula W.

description:
This was our first South Indian experience and it was good.  

When I originally called to make an 8:30 reservation, they were booked and suggested I call back around 8 to get a table.  I did just that and we found ourselves at the top of the list at 8:30, perfect!
author: Elizabeth M.

description: They were packed on a Friday evening. Susana at the reception was super nice and got us the table we wanted. The food is the best south Indian food we have ever had. Will be back. Super highly recommended!,
author: Yugan S.

description:
We went there last night for dinner. It was very crowded for a Monday night. We were a group of 4 and we shared the following dishes amongst us: 

Onion Rava Dosa 
Very crisp. Came with some tasty chutneys and sambhar. The sambhar tastes different but nice. 

Idli 
Was one of the best Idli I have had in the bay area. Very soft and came dipped in sambhar. They are not stingy with the sambhar and give out extras too if asked. 

Lamb baida roti 
The minced lab was very tasty. But the roti seemed like the ready-made ones. 

Masala dosa 
Had loads of butter and was crispy. Really good! 

Onion tomato uthapam 
Was spicy and delicious! 

In all, it was a great dining experience. Looking forward to coming back again.
author: Dee V.

description: Amazing gin drink with fig and cardamom tonic! The fire lentil soup is also amazing - I could do a meal of that alone. At the suggestion of friends, I skipped my usual mung bean salad and got a spring vegetable uttapam. It was good but saltier and oilier than I would have liked. Next time, I think I'll return to my usual...it makes me happy, what can I say?
author: Erin W.

description: Ordered "Lamb Pepper Fry",  "Paneer and Spinach Dosa" and two beers. Both dishes are tasty and delicious . Portion is okay. It's a sit-down and nice place. For two people, the bill came to $65, including tips. A little expensive.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
Dear bartender with the soul patch,

You saved my life last night.  

As a guy with a strong nut allergy, I did not know that most of my orders contained a bunch of cashews (the Cochin Calamari, Spicy Mung Masala, and the Pepper Chicken).  As I bit into the Calamari dish, I loved it.  But after 5 minutes or so, I was dying.  

Thankfully, my g/f was there with Benadryl, a lifesaver she is.  But you, Mr. Soul Patch, you also saved me by changing my orders and giving me food that didn't have the poisonous nuts.  And you did so while not having a jerk or being ignorant like other people out there in the world.  How nice of you!  You changed my entrees to the Tomato, Onion & Green Chile Uttapam along with the Kerala Chicken.  Both of them were yummy.  The vanilla chai gelato was also delicious.  You were there to give me water throughout the dinner which helped a lot, too.  For this, I double-tipped you.

I went home feeling like crap and took a very long nap.  I am okay though, but it could have been much much worse.  Overall though, I plan on going next time to give it a second chance.  You are a pretty awesome guy.

Sincerely,
Me

P.S.  Your food is a tad bit expensive, and it's too dark.  But I guess that's how it goes, I suppose.
author: Ren L.

description: Hands down one of the best restaurant I have been to in SF, great ambiance, very nice service. We tried the spicy mung masala dosa, it was a crepe like dish served with three dips (chutneys),a coconut one, a lentil one and a tomato one, all very tasty and also spicy. The Bathura was also a great complement to all the dips.
author: Sasan A.

description: If Udupi Palace, which I love love love, wasn't on the next block, this Dosa location would get a higher rating from me. Dosa is ok. I would return to their Fillmore location, as the interior is spectacular, but I would not go back to Valencia when my beloved Udupi Palace is a hop and a skip away.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Absolutely love DOSA... been to this location and to the Fillmore one plenty of times... and will go back again, and again. 

Want a great ambience, authentic south Indian tastes, and innovative menu items?? This is the place for you. 

Some of my favorites:
Chennai Chicken
Vada Pav
Paneer and Peas Dosa
Persimmon Idiappam (will blow your mind!)
South Indian Thali (Can't go wrong!)
ANYTHING with their delicious SAMBAR

And also don't miss out on their cocktails! Really unique and delicious! :)
author: Krithika H.

description: Fantastic in every respect. Phenomenal food, lots of bright fresh flavors. Hip yet warm atmosphere and very friendly service, from the bussers to the owner who checked in on us throughout the meal. And the beet nectar and ginger martini? Off the chain. Can't wait to come back!
author: Michael M.

description: The food here is a bit disappointing. The crepes are a fun idea but the flavor of the soup and chutney are just not developed enough. The rice is very sub par - it did not appear to be fresh and it cost $6! I have had much more flavorful Indian food. The bread was, by far, the best item! The service was a little cold and the prices are a little high.
author: Marie-Claire S.

description: I really like the food here.  After a long hiatus, I came back a month ago and have been back twice since.  So far I've had the masala dosa, the fall vegetable curry with a side of dosa, the spicy spinach mung bean salad with pomegranates, the spinach/fennel dosa, and the paper masala dosa.  The food is delicious, and they have great drinks (my friends love the mango lassi).  The three negatives are a) the waits for a table are really super long (easily an hour on a weekend if you don't have a reservation), and often long even if you have a reservation, b) the service is really super slow and often not great, so you have yet another long wait for food, and c) the parking situation on Valencia is horrible.
author: Vivian W.

description: The food is good, but it's definitely a little overrated. Great place for vegetarians, without a doubt (I mean, what are those free chips they give you?? They're slightly spicy, but very thin and delicious). The onion pakora is a great appetizer to split while you wait for your entrees (which do take a super long time, but the service is very prompt and courteous here). As for the dosa, the paneer and peas can't be beat. It's rich, but not too heavy, and all three of the dipping sauces work extremely well with it. Very pricey place (without a great drink selection), but not a shabby place for a date at all.
author: Danny C.

description:
I went there on Saturday evening with my spouse. Called in around 6:15 to get reservation and was told they have nothing.
Anyhow I walked in at 7:00 Pm and was lucky to get table within few mins.

I am not a great fan of South India food and just wanted to try this place as I had heard about them a lot.
Well I was not disappointed.
Food (we just tried dosas) is great, nice collection of wines. All in all great place for casual date.

If you do not mind spending more on South Indian food and want to experience some fusion, then definitely try this place. Plus their $12 dosa is well worth & justify its price against 5 dollar dosa you get in hole in a wall places.
Keema Dosa is amazing.

I would suggest this is worth a try (not something that you can do on regular basis as their prices is 3 times the regular south Indian food)
author: Rishi K.

description: Sunday dinner after muir woods hike. Pretty awesome experience. Big place with best ambience in downtown. Service was quick and food was delicious. It was expensive though. But I thnk in such place in city it is expected. I would love to visit again.
author: Swapnil S.

description: We had peas and paneer dosa, mysore masala dosa along with some cocktails. The chutneys were great. Very nice ambience.
author: Darshan S.

description: My husband and I really enjoyed the food here. We stumbled upon it looking for a later dinner and had to wait a bit to get in. We tried a few different things since the Southern Indian food is a bit different then what you normally see in most Indian restaurants. Everything tasted great and flavorful. Definitely want to go back and try more of their dishes.
author: Natalie R.

description: First time trying southern Indian cuisine! Food was delicious and service was fast. The waiter was kind enough to instruct us on how to eat our dishes. I ordered the Paneer & Peas and my friend ordered Lamb Thaili.
author: Teresa J.

description:
We went last night for my girlfriend's birthday with a few friends.  Restaurant was full with a few people waiting to get in.  Fortunately, I made a reservation and the Mission parking gods favored us with only a 20min drive around.  

Unfortunately, we found Dosa a tad overpriced and the food good but not spectacular.  The ingredients seemed to be of good quality but the dishes seemed spiced for a more general palate.  I also thought charging for side dishes a bit petty.  $1 for a thimble of achaar? Really... ?

My biggest peeve was the service.  It wasn't outrageously bad but was less than expected for a meal that cost $60+/person.  Our waiter seemed preoccupied or perfunctory in his duties all evening.  We were seated promptly but initial ordering took a bit longer than expected, advice on ordering was non-existent, and our waiter did not bother to hand off service when he left early.  He stayed to make sure we got the bill but left without checking if there were any other needs, e.g.- birthday dinner may mean a birthday dessert, hmmm?  Seems getting a guaranteed tip from a party of five means less than it used to.  
  
On a better note, the waitress who took over was much more attentive and apologized for the lack of noting the birthday party request.  Hopefully tips are pooled at Dosa and she received credit for pulling extra weight.  

Overall, I would be willing to eat at Dosa again but won't be going out of my way to do so.
author: G P.

description: Consistently good. Fabulous Michael and sweet giggly Jenny were so attentive and made it a special evening bday celebration. Especially attentive since we dropped about 10 pieces of silver ware between us and couldn't stop laughing.
author: An N.

description:
Mediocre food. We had dosa, masala and fish. Food was a bit bland and the masala had a grainy texture. Overpriced for the quality.

We had a reservation but still had to wait 30 minutes. 

Service is slow and a bit inattentive. They forgot one of the dishes we ordered.

We split the bill in half, and they gave us back incorrect amounts (they added 6-7$) for the bills!! When we told the waiter we didn't get any apologies, just "yeah, that's fine, we are only gonna do the final charges to the card later anyway". Seriously?
author: Anders H.

description: Came here for SF Restaurant Week 2017 as a group of 4. We ordered the family-style restaurant week menu, which consisted of 8 courses (3 small plates, 3 entrees, and 2 desserts) to be shared among the group. Food wise, this place is amazing - really nice complex flavors, great dosa, and interesting South Indian cuisine. However, I want to point out the portion sizes for the restaurant week menu are NOT the same as for the regular menu. So when you compare the price of something on the RW menu to what it would cost on the regular menu, you may not be getting the same amount of food. They portion out the RW items per person, but to be honest as a group of four we received some of the dishes in small bowls that looked like they would be more appropriate for a party of two. The same dish off the regular menu was much larger (that we saw at other people's tables). So, I would say that overall I'd recommend trying the RW menu if you're a group of 2 since you'll get to experience a lot of variety, but if you have a larger party you may end up getting more bang for your buck food-wise (although perhaps less variety) if you order off the a la carte menu. That said, I'll probably come back.
author: J L.

description:
Long line.  Must be really good right?
Its pretty good sort of.  They have rather good Dosa's and Im really sold on their sweet bread.  It was delicious.  I couldnt stop eating it.
We had four people and shared everything, there was a lot of variety.
The place is super crowded, super dark, noisy, and the service is slow.  I wouldnt blame them, they have to be very careful when they move around that place.
Bad place for large groups, and bad place for a romantic outing.  Definitely bad place for children.  Gotta be careful they dont get accidentally flattened into a dosa.

*************************
One of the owners of Dosa contacted me after the above review, and he brought up a good point I would like to share.  Going at an earlier time is usually less noisy and not as crowded, so its a good suggestion to go for an early evening dinner.  The food here is rather good and they have a lot of variety to choose from which is unfortunate to have been dampened by all the other parts of my experience. 
So, since the food is pretty good, if you want to try this place try to go earlier so that you can enjoy it more without all the little annoyances that come along with eating there at high traffic time.

The owner is one dedicated guy!  Props to him for caring.
author: Ami T.

description:
A few of my friends and I visited this place yesterday. We only ordered vegetarian food (although some of my friends were non-vegetarians).

The dosas were very nice. Mysore Masala Dosa, South Indian Moons, Rava Onion/Masala, Spring Uthappam - all of them were very good. The last one is not of Indian origin (likely) yet tasted very nice. The chutneys were very nice. The thing that needs to be specially mentioned is the sambar. It is very original and tastes just like back home. Right amount of tanginess, thickness and proportion of vegetables. Innovative dishes like fried upma are very nice too. Their decoration with chutneys is impressive too.

The ambiance of the restaurant is very good. The waitresses and waiters were very kind and understanding. Another thing worth mentioning is their helpfulness: I forgot my receipt and wanted a copy of it. I called them and requested to email me a picture of the receipt. They searched through all the receipts at 1 am and sent it.

Overall, a very good dining experience.
author: Sandeep P.

description:
Not going back again.

The food is alright, service is not great and for the kind of bucks you pay, you would expect both to be of much better quality.

We ordered day's special Bengali fish curry platter, Mysore masala dosa, Persian pomegranate juice and chutney sampler. 

The fish platter was a healthy assembly of grilled fish, coconut gravy, coconut rice, sautéed veggies (which they called poriyal but tasted nothing like one) and chips. I found it good but nothing even remotely close to Bengali fish curry of any sort. Not authentic at all.

Chutney sampler was certainly disappointing as NONE of the four chutneys tasted authentic.

Mysore masala dosa was average.

Service wasn't impressive at all as our server wasn't available to refill water or get something we want. In a crowded and super busy place on a Saturday evening peak dinner time, she was busy chatting with a patron who she knew beforehand (so it looked) while we (along with other customers she was attending) kept waiting frustratedly. This went on for about 20 minutes or more.

Overall, for the kind of bucks you pay, your expectations will be way higher. I've had much better food and service for lesser bucks.
author: Neelanjana D.

description: Amazing authentic indian food. Loved the lamb thali, it's worth a try. The owner was really friendly and the service was excellent. Great decor. Will definitely be coming back to try the dinner menu, especially the vada pav :)
author: Sheetal P.

description:
Everything I want to say is probably covered by the 1166 reviews. 
While the Fillmore location has a nicer bar and fancy hand dryers in the bathrooms..the service is better in the Mission location.
author: Mimi T.

description: Amazing South Indian food combined with excellent service. Landed there without an reservation given we were passing through the city. Despite the rush , they managed to accommodate us. The food was really good.
author: Rajesh M.

description:
Staff was very helpful and knowledgable. Mango mimosa was the perfect chick drink. The chicken masala was falling off the bone goodness and the lemon rice was clean and refreshing. We ordered the tomato & onion umpata (??), the deep fried bread, paneer salad, classic masala and a ton of sauces. We loved the soup that came with the masala and overall everything was amazingly flavorful and delicious. I didn't really care for the habnero sauce only because it was just hot without any flavor but mixing it with the mango chutney fixed that. 

We would def go back!
author: Jade W.

description: Authentic Indian cuisine, AHmazing dosa! Five stars to both food and service.
author: Margaret L.

description:
I was really excited about going to Dosa but I have to say I was a little disappointed.  The food was really well made--I thoroughly enjoyed the White Truffle dosa.  However, I thought that for the money, it wasn't worth it.  The dosas were too similar to well made, cheaper dosas at a non-upscale place (e.g Vicks).  I like that the restaurant tries to push the boundaries of what dosa can be but they don't push far enough. The flavor profiles were too similar to traditional dosas.  

I will say that the cocktails were excellent...I would definitely come back for a drink.

In summary, wasn't completely blown away but wasn't horribly offended either.
author: Sharad W.

description: I've been here twice so far and I love it! The ambience here is one of the best :) With candle lights all over the place and very very courteous people! It is very crowded though so you will have to make reservations before! Their appetizers are good, and their dosas are also very good. Oh, and they have very good mango ice cream too!
author: Anusha P.

description: Delicious delicious delicious. The dosas are fantastic. I love me some authentic dosas. The lamb curry was also out of this world. I thought our appetizer was weakest-- the lentil dumplings were just pouches of goodness smothered in a yogurt sauce. The sauce was delicious, but I thought the "dumplings" were overwhelming and it was just a giant bowl of sauce. The server was very helpful and gave stellar recommendations. I would definitely come back.
author: Stef S.

description: Best Indian food I've ever had. Lamb keema dosa is always solid and their chutneys are fantastic. Just as good as the Dosa in Japantown.
author: Rob G.

description:
OK, so to all your naysayers who told me I was being too harsh (and to owner Anjan M. specifically who harassed me to no end for a week about my supposedly unfair and biased review - DO NOT EMAIL ME AGAIN FOR THIS REVIEW EITHER)....

I gave it another go, to be nice to a group of friends who really wanted to visit from out of town. Thankfully, this time, the staff wasn't rude and vindictive and actually gave a good wine suggestion to one of my friends. It looks like they had some new people working that day, so was a nice change. I also like your crispy bread snack (yes, I do not know the name, I admit)  for while people wait for food. So for that, I'll give you another star. But, sorry, your food still isn't good. And you can say that that has to do with my "palate" not being "accepting" of Indian cuisine, except that I LOVE Kasa Indian Eatery in the Castro and have on several other occassions enjoyed home-cooked Indian food with close friends who are native to both north and south India. And your food is just wayyy to expensive. 

To each his own, right? I can see why people rave about this place (because there isn't a lot of great Indian food places out there in general, especially if you aren't living in SF or Berkeley) and why people don't because of poor experiences. And that's why we have over over 4500 restaurants in SF to pick from. So Yelpers, enjoy what you will!
author: Alita M.

description:
The White truffle masala dosa was perfect- enough for two for sure. 
You must order the BHATURA with ANY meal! It is sweet, fried and chewy- perfect to dip in any dish. I am allergic to nut- and the allergy menu was very helpful. They were also super accommodating to remove the nuts or serve it on the side. 

I was visiting from Alabama- and this was a HUGE recommendation from several people for delicious INDIAN

make a reservation online!
author: Carrie M.

description:
Indian food is one of my favorites -- especially being a longterm vegetarian. 

I brought my out of town friend here for an early Sunday dinner this past weekend. Even though I like the convenience of Valencia street, I think I have grown to like the Fillmore location better -- ambiance, service level, cleanliness, etc. 

I had the veggie slider which was delicious and the Paneer and Peas Uttapam which was just okay. She had the calamari and the masala dosa. Overall the meal was nice but not "amazing." Perhaps it was because we didn't imbibe? Who knows... 

I will be back to the Valencia location for their early weekday Happy Hour specials but will only do dinner at the Fillmore location.
author: Whitney W.

description:
Dosa catered a wedding I attended in Healdsburg. I figured if they could make dosa that big, crisp and delicious in a makeshift outdoor kitchen, what can they do in their REAL kitchen? The answer is: an equally good and even more ginormoid dosa, I mean, Texas-worthy-big. And some other stuff too:

Red Beet Soup - Light, smooth and very pretty
Bhatura - Even more Texas-sized - This thing is a monster, bigger than my head, turns heads whenever one passes by. Tasty dipped in the beet soup.
Masala Dosa - Crisp dosa and creamy inside
Paper Masala Dosa - Not kidding, as big as a bullhorn
Asparagus & Fiddlehead Pakora - Fried but kinda boring
Chennai Chicken - Fried and still boring
Carmelized Onion Uttapam - Best Uttapam I've had in a long time, not greasy

Remarkably not heavy or greasy, and a nice change from Northern Indian Fare.
author: Snuffles B.

description:
I've been to Dosa twice, and both times I enjoyed the fare. They try to be creative with their menu - which I appreciate. I consider myself to be a bit of an Indian food aficionado, so I enjoy when Indian restaurants try new things, and execute well.

Dosa loses points due to their service and execution, however. Everything felt a little bit like a machine to me, a machine programmed to turn tables around as fast as possible. Our food arrived very quickly (too quickly, in my opinion), which meant their assembly-line kitchen was simply cranking out dishes, not putting care into each. Our server was also hovering - removing plates the second one of us finished, and immediately bringing us a dessert menu. No time to digest, or enjoy the space.

I'll try Dosa again - maybe on a less busy night. I hope that's when you can get a real dining experience that lives up to the quality of their food.
author: Mike S.

description: I want my last meal on earth to be the lamb kofta. That is all.
author: Patricia D.

description: The food here is very flavorful and the staff is attentive. They'll provide good advice for first-timers. With that said, the parking is a nightmare unless you cough up the $4.50/hr needed for the nearby structure. The prices here are also high for what you get.
author: Eugene H.

description:
Wow. Delicious. I rarely give 5 stars but ambiance, service and food were all incredible. Favorite dish of the night was the calamari in a coconut sauce. Had the unibraue beer which was perfect as well. 

Must experience.
author: Alleah F.

description: Excellent! Great vibrant atmosphere, wonderful service and my selections were perfect for my taste buds! Be sure to make reservations!
author: Julie C.

description:
Possibly the best Indian food I've ever had. Highly recommend making reservations via OpenTable and Yelp.

I blame my tardy post for not remember exactly what we had, but I do recall the white truffle dosas were more than memorable. 

I had the "Aaraam se" which means to "relax". Pick your poison and the bartender will whip up a cocktail just for you! I chose whisky to whisk me to a fun night, and it didn't fail to deliver.

I can't wait to go back.
author: Annie L.

description:
My highschool friend had her birthday dinner here.  I was very petrified as well as pessimistic about eating Indian food.  I never eaten Indian food and could never see myself eating up until this day.

Since it was the dine about town which they offer here, we took full advantage of it.  The menu looked really good and we can select four dishes for $34.95.  Seemed really reasonable.  I remembered what I ate but don't know what it is called.  The only thing I have to say is that it is pretty spicy.  I love spicy food but this has a whole new meaning to spicy.  It was good and very tasty.  I was impressed that I could actually enjoy Southern Indian cuisine.  Scary thought too.

But when it came to for the dessert, I ordered what looked like a fried donuts soaked in sugary water-like.  It was horrible.  It was awfully sweet and hurts my tooth just biting into it.  I felt like I had a cavity right there and then.  The entrees were decent but just pass on the dessert.

Their services lack a lot as well.  It happened to be a very warm night that nite and where we were sitting literally had no venitlations.  We kept asking them to please increase the fan.  Their responses were that is as far as it will go.  Then half an hour later, we noted those fans were going so fast.  WTH?!!!!!  Trying to ask for ice water was like pulling teeth.  Come on.  Water is free and it is hot in herre......

Overall, the food was ok.  The services needed alot of improvements.  The nite was young and because we were here for a celebration, we made it our goal to not let this ruin our nite.
author: Angela L.

description:
This place is delicious!

We came without a reservation but luckily we had come a bit early before the dinner rush so the wait was not long.

We were seated right next to the door on a high rise table.

The food was awesome and so was the service. Everything from the lassi, appetizer, and their masala was amazing.

I will definitely come back in the future :)
author: Thanh N.

description: All their food is so delicious and the waiters were so helpful. We weren't very familiar with the cuisine as it came from another region in India, so we got everything our waiter recommended. All were great choices.
author: Hana A.

description: I used to love this place, but it's gone down hill in the last year. Their dosas are still amazing and super crispy and delicious. However, the chicken caravali was terrible. It was the stringiest chicken dish I've had. Couldn't hardly find any chicken meat! The pepper lamb was just ok - also chewy and stringy. Two stars for the chicken and lamb. 4 stars for the dosa.
author: Rene G.

description:
I don't think I had anything like this before. South Indian cuisine with a very healthy kick to it. Every bite was bursting with fresh flavors. I had a very enjoyable lunch with my best friends. It was new for most of us and I think that alone made the lunch a great experience. 

We had the Pani Puri which is kind of a fun dish where you use your knife to crack the small hollow crispy bread to fill with different things. Interesting but I think I would like it better if there were meat fillings too.

The Masala Dosa and Spring Dosa, both were really good. 

The South Indian Moons Uttapam which I thought was ok. Came in 5 small different toppings of pancake. Lacking flavor for me, but my friends liked it. 

Overall, I think it is a wonderful first time experience to try South Indian cuisine from Dosa but I don't know if I would come again. Food is good, just not my taste.
author: Linda L.

description:
I loved the ambience. And 100000 stars for our amazing server Chris. We went there for our anniversary dinner. New to the city, we were hoping to dig into some real real South Indian food. But the food here is a joke, a black mark on authentic South Indian food. A restaurant called dosa should know how to make one. The dosa was not crispy and not warm. The sambhar was on the sweeter side and thick. Oh no no. Sambar is NEVER thick. The chutneys were bland. I have enjoyed some very authentic South Indian foods for the past 15 years. This place comes nowhere close to the real deal. The owner writes back to reviewers who criticize the food and explains that every ingredient is so very fine, etc etc. all that is great mr owner, but where are the flavors?? DOSA needs to learn how to deliver a real DOSA.

Loved Chris the server. So amazing you were!
author: Richa D.

description:
In general, I really enjoy Dosa. After last night's dining experience, I have to give a lower rating.
For some reason, our service was sub-par.
Our food came out later than the couple next to us, even though we ordered well before them.
Here's how ordering my Habanero-Mango Masala Dosa went down:
Me: I'd like the Habanero-Mango Dosa, please.
Lindsey (server): Are you sure, most people don't like it when once they've tried the chutney.
Me: Is it due to the flavor or the heat?
Lindsey: The spiciness.
Me: I'll have it.
Lindsey: Let me bring you a sample, just to be sure.
*Brings sample*
Lindsey: Don't eat the whole spoonful. (as I'm eating the whole spoonful)
Me: I'll have it. It's delicious.
*Lindsey leaves with my confirmed order*
Upon receiving my dish, there was no habanero chutney in the dosa; NONE. I brought this up to Lindsey. She indicated that the chutney was cooked in the dosa. No chutney was to be found upon dissecting my dosa. The flavor of hot habanero was most definitely not to be found in eating a few bites from various aspects of the dosa. Lindsey brought out a ramekin of habanero dosa, which I slathered over the dosa and proceeded to consume delightfully.

I feel that, for no particular reason, this server denied me my right to order spicy food due to my ethnicity. The habanero-mango chutney is spicy. However, I love (and really wanted) a particularly fiery dish. If self-imposed suffering is perceived by a third party, that is on them. For me, I say, bring it!
author: Wendell A.

description:
It's like and Indian Tapas bar for allergy-prone San Franciscans.  On my new dairy-free, wheat-free diet, this place was an amazing find!  Paleo-Dieters - TAKE NOTE!  Fun atmosphere, nice wine list, great service, and really amazingly tasty food.  

Starting off the evening with the Indian Slaw was the way to go!  For the main course, we split the pepper chicken, seasonal vegetables, and the ridiculously large DOSA.  A lovely white organic wine recommended by our waitress kept us happy.

I'll definitely come back here again.
author: Hilary A.

description: We have been to the Dosa on Filmore many times and LOVED it. We get the tasting menu with the wine pairing and are always delighted. Last Saturday we went to the one on Valencia and were underwhelmed...the food was not as good and the service was meh. I wouldn't go to this Dosa again.
author: Jessica H.

description: do not trust them if you have allergies they assured me that the dosa was gluten free for the last two years, we checked every time we ordered. Today we were told when there was an issue with our order that the dosa has wheat. I have been trying to find the culprit that has been making me ill for sometime, This is the second restaurant that has given me misinformation.
