Repeat do not trust their allergy information either by phone or on their website.
author: oscar o.

description: I'm gonna keep this review short. Took a friend who was visiting out of town to this place. Ordered their Almond and Paneer Kofta curry with coconut rice. My friend said it's the best Kofta curry he ever tasted. I agree with him. What makes it interesting is that both of us are from India so we know our "Kofta" curries. Well done Dosa!
author: Ravi T.

description:
The papadums that come free are ridiculously addictive. Since it's made with lentil flour, it is very light and crispy, almost like tortilla chips, but better. 

Each dish we had was full of bold, exciting flavors. I loved the: 

chennai chicken- marinated, deep fried chicken w yogurt on the side
masala dosa- crispy, crepe-looking dish filled with a spicy potato mixture
there was also a fish dish, I don't recall the name, but it came with rice and a spicy sauce. 

Our server was an American guy wish a deep love for Indian food. He was very helpful in guiding us towards the right dishes. I can't wait to come here again and try more.
author: Cris S.

description:
I've lived by here for years and yet I haven't tried it... until now! The menu is a bit confusing or maybe I'm not really used to eating a clean Indian joint with attentive service... lol. Naan and Curry's menu is simple just saying, but both establishments aren't the same by any means... kind of like saying Chinese and Japanese food are the same right? (Sike). Anyway, menu has quite a bit... and if you were a noob like me... the whole menu was basically overwhelming.

Ordered the calamari dish. Not your traditional calamari but it was good. The free chip like thing that came out was really good... cumin or whatever seasoning they used... the inner asian in me wanted more and luckily they kept refilling the bowl. Not sure if it was THAT good but my friend and I were starving, so the chips seemed THAT good. Got the lamb dish that everyone was talking about and it was pretty good. Shared a dosa with my friend and it was pretty big when it came out. It was tasty though. But other tables that ordered dosas... each one came out a different shape and I swear each one got bigger and bigger lol. Overall the meal was good. Some of the plates seem tiny, but in the end you'll come out feeling full. Service is very good too. Good place to try!
author: Johnson S.

description:
This place rocks. It is quite difficult to find an Indian restaurant which marries ambience, service and quality South Indian food all at once in this country (incl. CA) but DOSA (on Valencia) seems to have nailed it on pretty much all 3 dimensions at once.

Try the Paneer Utthapam & Spicy Mung Masala dosa if you can. Their cocktails and appetizers are pretty awesome too, as are their desserts. Definitely get a reservation (and even if you have one, be prepared to wait a little) as this place is really popular and cozy, hence tends to fill up quickly even on weekdays.
author: Rahul G.

description:
Not the most terribly nice hostesses, who were chatting to each other and seemed a bit affronted that I had come in and wanted a seat for myself. I sat at the bar, and the bartender was nice enough to tell me more about Southern Indian food, which is what Dosa is, as well as explain some items on the menu. My interaction with him felt rushed - about 2 seconds after I got a menu, he began to tell me about the cuisine and the menu, and then immediately asked me what I wanted to order. It was just a different restaurant experience than I was expecting - the bartender was pretty chatty, but I guess that is normal when I am the only one sitting at the bar eating.

The paper masala dosa is like a giant crepe with curry-like meat (?? it just had a blander, earthier taste, which I actually prefer to the typical spicy Indian foods), and comes with several dipping sauces. The bartender told me you're supposed to pick up the whole dosa and eat it with your hands, since it originated as a street food, but I was kind of apprehensive about the whole messy food thing, so I just ripped pieces off to dip.

Thanks 7x7, for finding me the one Indian cuisine I like!
author: Melody L.

description:
I chose this place for my Hubby's birthday treat. So Glad I 

did!

First impression- the ambiance is contemporary indian. Loved 

the Bollywood poster.

Highly recommend the Thali.We tried the Masala dosa with 

truffle oil (i am buying some truffle oil soon).I must admit, 

we went overboard ordering the chutney sampler- it was good 

but we had already ordered too much.The south Indian Moons 

was great (if you want to taste a variety- this is the dish for 

you).

South Indian Monsoon is super refreshing.

Our meal came a full circle with Pistachio Dacquoise with 

Chocolate chille Mousse- yelpers listen up- it is just 4 bites in 

size but totally worth each bite.Proof of the pudding- thats 

the 1 thing my husband talks about when asked what he did on 

his birthday..LOl...

Dosa gets 5 stars for me because in additional to the 

delicious food it has (drum rolls...) Great Service. The 

staff is extremely knowledgeable on the menu.And I am so 

thankful for the harbanero sauce sample- it rightly steered 

me away from the mango harbanero dosa (which sounded so 

delicious, i was planning to have it all by myself).

I wish we had a "Dosa" in Austin- anyone listening???
author: Swatz S.

description:
My friend and I decided last minute to go to dinner at Dosa last Wednesday night for dinner. We didn't have reservations, but decided to chance it, because we'd been wanting to try it for sometime. There were no tables, but two seats at the bar had just opened and we decided to snag them. 

Let me just say this was the best experience I have ever had dining at a bar. Theo helped us out and he was just amazing. From choosing our bottle of wine (2010 L'Alycastre Rose, dry, crisp, delicious perfect with Indian food btw,) to recommending food options, as well as how many dishes to order, it was an absolute treat to have him help us out. 

The food? Amazingly delicious. I have had my share of bad Indian food, but this was fabulous. We ordered two small plates, a curry (we ordered the lamb, awesome!), a dosa, and a bread and it was a good amount of food! There was definitely no room for dessert, but I will absolutely be back!
author: Jane F.

description:
Dosa really has their act together! In most instances, restaurants provide tasty food but the service pales in comparison - ultimately ruining the dining experience -  but Dosa excels in both.

My friends and I ate there last Thursday and ordered a mix of appetizers, main courses and drinks. One member of our party didn't receive her glass of wine until she reminded the waitress at the end of her first course and another member didn't receive his main course until the rest of us had already finished ours. Naturally we were disappointed with the service, but we didn't have to say anything: the Manager walked over (I think his name is Leo - thank you Leo!), apologized profusely and deducted the glass of wine and the main course that took long to arrive off our check. He turned our experience around with his simple yet very thoughtful gesture!

Food: 4/5 (Everything except the lamb kebabs were great)
Service: 5/5!
author: Meg B.

description:
Had a fabulous meal here in December with about 10 Yelpers for an UYE sponsored by Daniel L and Maybelline (who unfortunately got sick and wasn't able to attend)

Daniel L treated us to several appetizers including pani poori.  Our sweet server demonstrated how to make a little crack in the delicate mini poori and filled it with potatoes, onions, garbanzos and sauce.  She then gave the poori to me  and said to pop it in my mouth.  I opened my mouth as wide as 
I could but ended up squirting rays of sauce on my fellow Yelpers--sorry.

I got the Masala Dosa and it was absolutely the BEST I've ever had
The dosa was light and crunchy and the filling was perfect.

Hubby ordered another type of dosa and was equally smitten.

Most of the Yelpers enjoyed their meals.


Food and service are top  notch but on the pricey side.

The company was topnotch too!  And to literally add icing to the cake, Daniel brought this wonderful cake.  Too yummy!
author: Rinky N.

description:
My search for spicy Indian food in San Francisco is finally over! After complaining about the general lack of spice in anything in San Francisco, I ordered the habanero masala dosa. This is where I tucked my tail under and realized I was beaten. I was sweating, turning red, and guzzling water. Finally. It was so spicy that I ended up taking it home because I couldn't finish it (also, habanero gets less spicy as it sits). Unfortunately, that's pretty much the only thing that is spicy. The other items on the menu were also pretty good, just you know, not what I'm looking for in Indian food :(. 

Service and atmosphere was also pretty topnotch, but not unexpectedly so, if that makes any sense.
author: Sonia J.

description: I ordered online, they sent a confirmation mail and told that they will deliver the food through uber but that uber guy calls up n says he gave food to someone else at night 11 pm, pathetic service  had to sleep hungry
author: Sushma P.

description:
I had a friend come into SF who has just been diagnosed as gluten sensitive.  It's really important during this time that she is especially cautious to ensure that this is really what has been ailing her for so long.

Anyhow - after searching for some food options for us to choose from, we decided on Dosa for our Saturday lunch. They had a special gluten-free menu for her to order from and seemed to be very knowledgable about being sure to not cross contaminate anything in the kitchen.

The food was amazing.  I ordered the Spicy Mung Masala Dosa and my friend ordered the Carmelized Onion Uttapam.  We were both totally overwhelmed with how gorgeous and delicious everything was.  I can't wait to go back and try more! Yum.
author: Autumn B.

description: Authentic Mango Lassi, Dosa, great cocktails & customer service good in relation to how busy it was. Not a butter chicken insight which was unsettling at first but it made us try something new.
author: Sarah C.

description: A great place for a variety of dosas to satisfy everyone. Service is a bit spotty and customization is a problem but can't complain about the food.
author: Stawan K.

description:
Love, love this place.  The dosas are THE best in the SF Area and the variety of dosas and chutneys is unbeatable.  Try the paper thin masala dosa; you will not be disappointed!  And the price ($12) is very reasonable, especially given the upscale dining experience. 

Cocktails, appetizers and desserts are good too.
author: Jane D.

description: I can see why a lot of people love this place - the space is beautiful and the menu is definitely creative. For those who are new to indian food, especially south indian food, this is a pretty good place to give it a try for the first time. For those who are more familiar, Dosa suffers a bit from a value perspective. I had the dosa with truffle oil, which was definitely unique and tasty but didn't quite cross the threshold into delicious. The standout element of my meal was the drink selection, which creatively puts an Indian twist on some classic cocktails. Overall it is an interesting place to try, but it is not the best South Indian food out there and comes with a SF restaurant price tag.
author: Manu V.

description:
Have eaten here & Fillmore many times.  Consistently delicious & good service.  

Recommend:  Kerala chicken, bhel puri, tamil lamb curry, mung salad
author: Dagmar H.

description: The ambiance of this place is top notch. From the decor, to the unbelievably amazing smell of food as soon as you walk in. I had finished eating my dinner and started craving another lamb dosa almost immediately! Although, our server wasn't the friendliest. Not sure if it was the fact that it was a Friday evening and it was busy, but she seemed kind of out of it. It honestly didn't even matter so much.. the food was enough to have us wanting to go back! : )
author: Kimberly M.

description:
Wow! Unbelievable food and service. My boyfriend and I had a great time chatting with the manager Leo who was also super helpful in providing tips on places and things to do around town while we are here visiting from the east coast. He also suggested what we order and was right on the money with everything.

Would def recommend the chennai chicken,  prawn masala w coconut rice and the spicy Mung masala. It was plenty of food for the two of us and gave me leftovers for lunch. My mouth is watering just thinking about it!
author: Meg H.

description:
Ok, so I had a long, hard day at work like most of us typically do, so to treat myself I drove upto SF from Palo Alto to go to Dosa to have a nice relaxing meal to take my mind off meetings, subordinates, superiors, etc. I got seated at the bar tables eve though the restaurant was unusually sparse. That's fine. I didn't mind,  I got the Masala Dosa. It was good. Not as good as I remember, but still good. About 15 mins into my nice relaxing meal, the manager and a disgruntled waitress sat down one table down from me and have a very lengthy, sort of loud conversation about her work issues, how to handle her section, up selling, getting along with her coworkers. This went on for about 30 mins. I tried to ignore it, but I just kept hearing an employee complaining/discussing issues with her manager and the longer it went on, the more tense I got and the more I was reminded about my long, miserable work day. With each complaint, Each bite started to taste less fulfilling :( I'm sure this probably and anomaly and not a reflection on the food, but, man, that meal was not fun. I don't know if my stomach was getting upset from the spicyness of the sumbar or the screeching of the waitress-manager complaint session in my left ear. 

It wasn't intentional or malicious, just inconsiderate of the customers experience. I just wanted a nice relaxing meal, is that too much to ask?

...oh and I think I might have scurvy. I got to remember to eat more oranges when I'm at sea.
author: Ahmed A.

description:
Michelin rated Indian restaurant in the Bay Area?  I couldn't wait to try it.  Went there for brunch as I wanted to have the chaat along with my dosa.  

Cocktails:
-Bloody Mary - curry and chile in my bloody mary?  yes please!  nothing like a kick to jump start the morning!

Starters: 
-Pani Puri - Indian street food that I don't frequently see at other Indian establishments.  Love the mint and tamarind water, a great starter and palate cleanser
-Idli Sambar - was expecting the lentil dipping sauce to have more of a kick but gave the patties enough flavor to eat

Curry:
-Tamil Lamb Curry - omg so succulent and fall off the bone tender, the lemon rice paired perfectly with the curry as it helped cut the grease

Dosa: 
-White Truffle Masala - what genius finally decide to put some truffles in masala?  oh so good!
-Habanero-Mango Masala - ooh, the spicy habanero chutney was delicious, it is intense heat so only order this if you love spice.  we loved it so much that we asked for extra spicy habanero chutney to go!  

Dessert:
-Saffron Cheesecake - dessert after brunch?  the hubby and i contemplated ordering a dessert but when the waiter brought out the menu we knew we had to try the saffron cheesecake, and we are glad we did!  not your traditional Indian dessert but it was straight up fusion deliciousness!

Overall:  service was excellent and food was great.  While they have traditional Indian food this place is more Indian fusion than traditional.  Can't wait to go back for more habanero chutney!
author: Shirley C.

description: My SF Restaurant Week journey continued at Dosa last night.  This was my second trip to Dosa and maybe my 7th, experience with Indian Food.  The food is fantastic.  Service very good and professional.  Noise level in the dinning room make conversation difficult .
author: EC N.

description:
Great food with great service! This was my second there in as many weeks.  The staff were very friendly and made great recommendations on the menu. The atmosphere is energetic!

I do recommend making a reservation, otherwise it may be over an hour long wait for walk-ins on weekends (found that out my first time there, but still worth the wait).
author: Ali T.

description: Dosa cares about disability access!  Dosa has been in the Mission for a long time - if you like Indian food, vegetarian food, or both, we suggest you try this inclusive restaurant!
author: SF Disability Awareness N.

description:
I took my parents here and they were unsure of what to expect when I told them it was "Indo-American fusion". After the meal, however, they were thoroughly impressed and still talk about how good the food was. 

We ordered 2 appetizers: dahi vada and sweet onion pakora. My mom really liked the dahi vada and trust me, thats one of her favorite dishes. The sweet onion pakora is a twist to the traditional pakoras and it was really good and unique. We ordered the onion rava dosa (hey, we're Indian. we love onions) and spicy mung masala. Both were good but I liked the onion rava dosa more. The sambar and coconut chutney were delicious. I even  took seconds of the sambar, which almost never happens (they were nice to give us seconds of the sambar for free). 

I really want to go back and try some of the other unique dosas since there are so many options. 

The only slightly annoying thing was that I made reservations for 8:30 and my whole party showed up but we weren't seated until closer to 9. They were really busy so its understandable. Also, parking is tough so be ready to circle around a few times.
author: Krishna S.

description:
What an opportunity it was to celebrate the end of 2009 with fellow Yelpers Manabu M, Amy C, Tom R, Cassie J, Dorothy C and her husband Peter, Bradley N and wife Camelia, and Rinky A and husband Mike. It was a momentous occasion for Elite and soon-to-be-Elite members to break bread at Dosa. We helped Manabu to celebrate his second month anniversary as a Yelper, scheduled a New Year's lunch with Tom R, and for the rest I can tell a story about each person based on our interpersonal relationships and from following their reviews. As people took turns to stress the inclusive nature of this event compared to those that required the Elite status, I glanced across the table and knew exactly how we became friends through Yelp and the relationship we have developed over time regardless of age, profession, educational background, and other visible markers that often set us apart in this divided world. 

Although Dosa wasn't initially our first choice, it turned out to be a fabulous venue for such an event. From wall to wall the place was clean, spacious, and filled with fresh vibrant orange and brown décor with a good mix of natural and artificial lighting. Seated by the corner right behind the bar, our group had plenty of room and privacy to work with. We started off with a slew of appetizers to share and later each person had their main course individualized.

Dahi batata puri: Small hallow crispy breads that came with yogurt, potatoes, mint, and tamarind chutneys. It was a one-bite sensation with the entire bread collapsing to let the fillings run wild. It was decent.

Dahi vada: A beautifully presented yogurt with tamarind and mint smothered on top of lentil dumplings. Some people didn't discover the lentil dumplings at first since they were well hidden but I thought the dish was okay. I'm not too big on dishes served chilled and it was a bit heavier in taste than the rest.

Bhel puri: Amy C told me that this dish tasted like a mix of instant noodles and spices and I have to agree in terms of its texture. It came with an exciting mix of mango, potatoes, tomatoes, onions and other seasoning and it was crunchy and delightful.

Pani puri: Another set of small crispy breads where we had to manually poke a hole in the middle and fill it with spoons of chickpeas, mung beans, and potatoes before filling mint and tamarind water to capacity. I probably like this appetizer the most as the fillings had a lot of substance while the mint and tamarind water brought a refreshing sour and mint balance to bring it all together. Yum yum.

For the main course, I had the chicken curry special and it was fresh and creamy without it being unnecessarily oily. Chicken pieces were generous with lots of flavor and seasoning. The slight kick added flavor to a generous serving of coconut basmati rice. I thought the rice was not as good as the one at Burma SuperStar, but it was still a powerful sweet-spicy combination. Additionally, I also had a taste of Amy C's eggs dosa which is what they specialize in brunch. The eggs were nicely scrambled with tomatoes and onions with a fluffy external layer of savory dosa to keep the fillings together. Her side of coconut and tomatoes chutney was mildly spicy and creamy delicious.

Service was excellent. Our water was constantly refilled and our server Lindsay was very knowledgeable and attentive. Not sure what we had worked out with them prior to lunch, but they also charged us for cutting the Saint Honore cake and plates which was an unexpected detail to note. From a personal standpoint, I have to agree with Tom R and Bradley N that their food could be spicier, but I also saw several people at the end of my table who really struggled with what they were having. This said, I thought their culinary purpose was the necessary medium for a large group like ours. 

Finally, I would remiss without thanking Maybelline C for organizing this event. May and her husband Marc have been fabulous to work with and it was troubling to learn about her illness on the morning of the lunch. Despite her illness, her efforts to coordinate up to the moment of the event were significant in making it a success. With May being the face of our current and future events, I have no doubt that people will continue to gather and redefine for themselves what Yelp is really all about. As for Dosa, I would absolutely love to return for your brunch items. 4.5 stars for the overall experience. 

Have a Yelpalicious 2010, everyone!
author: Daniel L.

description:
Everything about this place is awesome. The food, the service, and the atmosphere. There's a reason why they have a Michelin award proudly displayed in their window.

There was surprisingly a short wait. We ordered samosas, Dosa Masala and Dosa Masala Chutney. We barely finished our meal. The menu has a lot of variety, including a huge alcohol menu. I was surprised at the sheer size of the Dosa Masala and Dosa Masala Chutney. They're like giant pancakes wrapped in yummy Indian food goodness. The dipping sauces are tasty as well. My favourite was the lentil one which you can also eat as a soup when you're done dipping to your heart's content. It reminded me of Ethiopian food because you eat it with your hands too. I had to start using my utensils though because it was getting a little messy.

I would definitely come back here because we ended up pleasantly surprised that it lived up to the hype. I was happy I finally got to try it after walking by it so many times.
author: Amy J.

description:
One of the best Indian food I had in US. The food is tasty, presented well and the ambiance is  great. 
Try the Dahiwada.
author: Raj M.

description:
I'm a big fan of Dosa on Valencia.  It's the original location!  It's a lot smaller than the Fillmore location, but I prefer the coziness of Valencia.  They don't really dumb down the spices, which I love!!  If you're into more mild items, they have those as well.  

Chennai Chicken Boneless organic chicken, marinated in yogurt & spices, fried - Delicious, but rather heavy.  It's basically deep fried chicken straws with a yogurt dip.  

Masala Dosa - This is the most basic dosa, with potatoes and spices.  The three dipping sauces were fab.  I loved the sauce that came in the bigger bowl, not sure what it was called.  The coriander sauce was also tasty.  Definitely use the sauces.  I started eating the papadum (Indian chips) with these three sauces.  

Spicy Lamb with lemon rice - This dish is rather spicy, but that's how I like it.  It's not as spicy as vindaloo, but close.  The lamb chunks were tender and the sauce was thick and flavorful.  

All in all, the meal was delicious.  I would get one app, a dosa, and one entree for two people.  We still had half of the lamb dish left.  Beware, this food is super heavy, totally coma food.  I went home and passed out (HARD), shortly after dinner.
author: Wendy S.

description:
We went to Dosa this afternoon with a UYE bunch. Enjoyed the place enormously and the Yelp group even more.

I'll try to describe the Dosa experience although I'm sure others in the group will do better than I.  In fact, I suspect that they will post pictures which will make my laborious explanations quite moot.

But here goes...

The round of appetizers allowed us to taste a variety of different tastes. We learned how to fill little round puff shells with an assortment of flavors and textures and pop them into our mouths quite neatly. 

At least the others did....I never quite managed to keep the whole shebang in my mouth before it squirted tamarind juice out onto my plate. I was, however quite proud of the fact that NONE of the sauces escaped from my plate to the table.  Nor did any sauce dribble onto my shirt...I mean, if I wasn't truly neat, at least I wasn't a true slob.

Each person ordered a main course. I had a cilantro potato filled dosa that quite literally filled my plate, and perched precariously over the table. It was sublime...apparently its a favorite with the folks in the kitchen. Absolutely yummy. 

Everything offered at lunch is veggie...but you could have put it by me. The crispy texture of the outer wrap contrasted beautifully with the warm soft interior. To me quite frank, were I to live near this restaurant, I could be come a vegan easily!

The wait staff was attentive. Our large group was served quickly and unobtrusively. Although each meal had to have been prepared individually "in the moment" there was no sense of delay in the service to each person. All plates of food were served exactly as intended with no sense that they had been left on a warmer or re-heated.

I can only imagine the type of coordination that was required in the kitchen to put together such a feast. It was quite successful. 

Dessert was an amazing light cake brought to the event by Daniel L. Again, others will post pictures and provide many more details than I ever could...I'll post a review of the dessert shortly.

In any event...Peter and I had a grand time. Enjoyed Dosa. We'll be back. Real soon........
author: Dorothy C.

description:
I came here on a foodie's recommendation. I ordered a cocktail and it had a BIG fly in it. They apologized but I was not impressed, I expected more from a restaurant of this caliber. They did not make up for it by offering better service during the rest of my meal. 

My date ordered a Peony cocktail and it was alright, it is definitely for the more adventurous - it had coconut milk and chili. We had the lamb keema dosa, baby eggplant kofta: presentation and food was good. 

My experience was definitely let down by the fly in my drink. Hope you get better.
author: Mira L.

description:
Inferior on the ambiance when compared to Dosa @ Filmore , what it misses in the space this restaurant delivers in flavors . 

Staying true to Indian roots , not compromising on spice and flavor , Dosa's Indian food can be truly stated as SFBay's best Indian fine dining . 

Ordered Scallop , Calamari , Idiyappam  for appetizer , Chicken Bartha and Prawns for Entree . All the dishes hit on flavor profile. 

Sambhar that accompanies Dosa/Uttapam is refined and authentic at the same time. 

Had 4 Desserts all them were very tasty.

Service was spot on - Two waiters changes during our order , but the order taking was flawless . 

Dosa @ Valencia - A must visit Indian restaurant.
author: Steve S.

description:
The Valencia location is much different than I expected from the Fillmore location, but also great in its own way.  I prefer the Fillmore location because the Valencia spot is about the size of the bar in the Fillmore spot.  Tiny and very casual with small cafe style tables, rather than the nicer furniture, spacious layout, high ceilings, and decor of the Fillmore spot.

That said, grading this restaurant independently of comparison to Dosa Fillmore, it was great (4 stars).  The drinks and food were very well done, and nice service.
author: Adrienne K.

description:
I love trying new places, I like to check out others reviews and bookmark spots when I see something that interests me. Out on a rainy night for dinner, a friend and I stopped in to check out Dosa.

The place was crowded and a little noisy, but that didn't stop us from having a good time. Not knowing what to get, we examined the menu and went with:

* Samosas 'North & South' Savory pastries filled with caramelized onions & vegetables (South), and spiced potatoes (North).
* Kerala Chicken Organic, boneless, chiles, cilantro, mint, grated coconut, tomatoes, cauliflower, spices (great w/ coconut rice)
* South Indian Moons Chef's selection of five different Uttapams

The food was very good. When I go out to restaurants I try to identify the flavors in the meals and let them inspire me in the kitchen. I have to say that I was unable to figure them out, but it did get me to come up with a few ideas for brunch the next day.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
I think I've been here a bunch of times and never managed to write a review. Not like Dosa needed it. What could I say that hadn't been said now 1500 times before? But I'm putting together a list of some of my favorite places in the Mission for a friend, so a-yelping I go.

When this place opened a number of years ago, it was impossible to get a table. You'd wait over an hour. It's still packed now, even on a Thursday. But by some miracle, we happened to get seats at the bar within 5 minutes. And I got to introduce two friends to their first dosas. That in itself was worth the price of admission. It was also interesting to try to describe a dosa in French to someone who hasn't had one before. South Indian crepe? South Indian burrito? 

Yes, Dosa does go out on a California cuisine limb, and have distinctly non-Indian varieties of dosas and uttapams, but that is what we love about San Francisco, isn't it? We don't leave well enough alone. We mix and match. We put our own stamp on things. We try to make what was good enough just a little bit better. That is what we do.

And after having travelled to India, I can say that the dosas and sambar are great. The uttapams are great. After having eaten about a half-dozen dosas this year, I got the uttapam sampler. All of the different uttapams were so delicious that it seemed like almost a shame to dunk them in the sambar.

Gluten-free notes: Dosas and uttampams are naturally gluten free. But be aware of rava dosa -- rava is semolina (wheat! gluten!) so avoid it. They do some labeling of what is wheat-y on the menu.
author: Ellie P.

description:
White Truffle Masala Dosa- EXCELLENT!!!!!!!!! 
and the restaurant has a nice ambiance too :)
author: Jenny J.

description:
Excellent service and ambiance. Food is delicious and full of options, a great place to bring friends. Their Dosas and little plates are very good and so are their drinks. Highly recommend anyone to check this place out.

Quick tip: parking is not so hard in that district
author: Johanna P.

description:
We were a very large party, and I'm sure that we ate everything. No, really. With 20 you can order one of everything and share. 

Service was impeccable, drinks were quite good, and I was not disappointed in any way by any item I had there. 

Atmosphere is very classy and beautiful. Highly recommend.
author: Celeste T.

description:
Dosas the size of tires.  Really.

During Yelps' drink week awhile back, we ventured in here to take the edge off from hunger.  Shared: dosa masala, a GINORMOUS but thin lentil crepe filled with creamy spiced potatoes, onions and cashews served with various chutneys.  A slightly spicy but refreshing smooth yogurt based mango lassi and glass of red rounded out the meal.  Be prepared for tire-diameter sized dosas.  One order can easily feed two.  We also saw huge pillows of bhaturas being served at a nearby table.

The restaurant's stylish decor of shimmer from capiz chandeliers, quartz bar counter tops, warm saffron walls, candlelight and house music sets the tone for a mod, upscale but lively eatery.

Happy hour 5-7, Sunday-Thursday & late night (9 until closing).  The waitstaff and bartender were extremely helpful answering our questions as enormous bread concoctions were being served.

Definitely need to return for happy hour and more dosas & mango lassis!  My birthday is coming up. Hint, hint.
author: Jen L.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed my mung bean dosa. the filling was fluffy and nicely spiced. the service was quick and efficient but the waiter was a bit patronizing with his "knowledge" of the menu. I guess that's his job. He also thought that I ate fast, "praising" my hungry self for pounding down my food. Excuse me for enjoying my food.Definitely felt judged for not dressing nice enough as well but such is life. 

The chai tasted like burnt kheer, hardly spiced and no tea leaf flavor. Literally worse than any "chai tea latte" I've had anywhere else.

All in all, I had a decent experience. The place seems to cater to a largely White clientele, with spicing being relatively mild. That being said, I would come back for the dosa but I would definitely prefer other joints a little farther in San Jose or Sunnyvale that don't sacrifice authenticity for novelty.
author: Radhika P.

description:
I finally got to try Dosa and I was not disappointed. The food was fantastic! The chicken was tender, curry was spicy and flavorful, and dosa was crispy and delicious. 

The restaurant was pretty full at 9 pm on a Monday. Service was decent and the place is cute. Too bad the restrooms weren't updated.

I can't wait to come back!
author: K V.

description:
Our reservation got bumped a little bit and we stood in the cold, then inside, where there was nowhere to stand.. so that wasn't the best.

The food was great, as usual and we had a great time. 

I got the masala dosa and my wife got the paper masala dosa.  Both were great.
author: Dave W.

description: Lovely place whith quite sophisticated decor. Service was excellent and scrummy indian food was likewise. bonus was finding an amazing selection of single malt scotch whiskey - some from the Island of Islay!We had two vegans in our party and the menu had a few really nice dishes which they were able to order.
author: Jason B.

description:
Loves it!

So I wasn't sure about a fancy Indian place. But, it was my friends' choice, and it was great! There were also actual Indians there, which made me feel better about it being a "fancy" Indian place and gives the impression that it's legit.

So, dosa is like a very thin crepe. We got the paper dosa which was HUGGGGE and crisp. Amazing. It was like a megaphone, but bigger. We also got the white truffle masala dosa. I think I prefer the white truffle dosa... drizzle some truffle oil on it and I'll love it. haha.

We also got some curry with chicken and eggplant which was delish. But, the star definitely was the white truffle dosa. 

The service was also pretty good. We were able to make resos which I always appreciate. 

Overall, def love. Def try again.
author: Hannah K.

description:
Being a South Indian, I would like to make few comments on this restaurant.

We tried Masala Dosa, Idli Sambar, Kheema kabob, Kerala chicken and coconut rice.

Dosa was very crispy, I am used to Dosas which are crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, this makes it easy to break them into bite sizes and scoop chutney and potato otherwise the Dosas will break into pieces. The sambar and chutneys were good but not extraordinary. 

Idlis were puny, just 2 in an order and they are not cheap too. We ordered 2 extra Idlis costing us 5$ more! These are the most expensive Idlis I have ever had in my life.

For $12 we got just 2 tiny Kheema kabobs! 

Kerala chicken and coconut rice were ordinary.

Overall the food tasted above average. Many of the foods are not South Indian. The cost was super expensive, so watch out your pockets. 

I felt like I was lynched.

The place is small and crowded. I am used to it and in fact liked such an ambience. Service was good. 

My 2 star rating is based on cost, cost and then value for money.
author: Girish B.

description:
I came here for dinner with my girlfriend for some much needed girl catch up time.  We ordered the heirloom tomato & idiappam, vada pav, dosa masala, chicken and eggplant bharta, and saffron cheesecake.  The heirloom tomato was pretty tasty.  It was a little spicy, but the delicious coconut milk cooled it down.  I LOVED the vada pav.  I thought it was so fun, interesting, and delicious.  The dosa masala was pretty darn tasty as well.  We barely touched the chicken bharta, but from what little I had it was pretty good.  The saffron cheesecake wasn't quite my cup of tea though.  I didn't really care of it and kind of wish we had ordered a different dessert.  Lastly, we also ordered the South Indian Monsoon drink, and it was DELICIOUS!

Overall, it was pretty good.  Not the best Indian food I've had, but it's still pretty tasty.
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
If you like high quality Southern Indian food in a trendy setting, this is your place.   I've had equally good, possibly better Southern Indian food, but it always seems to be in a place that looks like a run-down Summer camp mess hall.   This place is hip.

Got the paper dosa with dipping chutneys to share with friends.   The thing comes out looking like a monstrosity- honestly, it looks like someone rolled up a bath mat.  But it is really light  (and filling) and great with the chutneys.

My party got Lamb Vindaloo, Poppy Seed Prawns, and Baby Eggplant Kofta.   Every dish was outstanding (although the lamb was a bit spicier than the other dishes).  We each even had leftovers due to the ample serving sizes.  I highly, highly recommend you get one of the flavored rices that compliments the dishes- my favorite is the coconut rice, but the others are quite good as well.

All of this for 3 people, each sharing, leaving totally full from a cool restaurant with leftovers for about $55 with tip....not bad.
author: Derek C.

description:
It's always been insanely crowded in this place every time I've come (only for dinner) and you should expect a wait, but if you're willing to tough it out, it's worth it!

You know how they say a picture speaks 1000 words?  Check out my picture...aaaand the delicious paper dosa that is as long as my arm!  It goes down well with the pomegranite cocktail, too.

If you're looking for a comparison to Dosa on Fillmore, I think that 1) this one has a more southern Indian feel while the other Dosa seemed more northern Indian, and 2) the menu didn't seem as big here as Fillmore.  That didn't affect how delicious and well cooked the food here was though.  We got a chicken dish, and the meat was so tender you didn't even need a knife to cut it!

(Pro tip: If it's just 2 or 3 of you, try to grab a seat at the bar!  The wait is way shorter.)
author: Alice C.

description:
YUMMMMY!!!!

This is definitely the BEST(!) South Indian (perhaps Indian in general???) food that I've ever had.
author: Anne B.

description:
Oh I love Dosa. And, though the Fillmore location is a little more glitzy, I think I like the service at Valencia and the feel there better. It's still nice and feels like a night out, but without trying too hard.

I have been eating here for a while and love everything (vegetarian--haven't tried the meat) on the menu. The green mango and paneer dosa is delicious and I have always loved their uttapams. One of my favorite things here is actually a side dish--the dahi rice. Yes, dahi rice is a simple and seemingly unglamorous dish (yogurt, rice), but Dosa does it so well, so creamy, and so perfect. Great with their hotter dishes--I scoop it with the poppadums they bring to the table :)

I also like their drinks here--cocktails are good and the wine they serve pairs well with the south indian flavors.

Note: When they say something on the menu is spicy, it really really is. I like spicy food, was raised on spicy food, roll my eyes when people tell me something is spicy, but the Habanero still makes my eyes go really wide and is almost intolerably hot.

In summary: Eat at Dosa. It is delicious.
author: Pri C.

description:
My wife and I recently visited Dosa for brunch and had an absolutely outstanding meal. The brunch menu is different than the dinner menu and worth trying, in some ways I found it even more intriguing. 

I think of Dosa as a flavor rich interpretation of South Indian cuisine ... I'm not an expert but the flavors are the most intense -and indian is intensely spiced in general- of any Indian restaurant I've even been to.

The other thing worth pointing out was the quality of the service. The host was very welcoming, paid just the right amount of attention to us, and was well versed in the history of the cuisine. It was a very memorable and delicious experience that we'll come back for.
author: Roland S.

description: Good Indian food, but a bit of a hassle on the lines.
author: Aaron W.

description:
I haven't had southern Indian food in a decade, but my mouth opened when I saw the size and simplistic assortment of the dishes.  Start off with any appetizer, but save room for the dosas.

Service is fast and friendly.  Despite the small size of the restaurant, the ambiance is simple, clean and cozy without being cramped.  Street parking can be tough in this area.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Made a reservation while riding on the bus using their OpenTable passthrough on their Yelp page. Worked out great, we got off the bus, and our table was ready. 

I have to give these guys some credit. Food was excellent, service was excellent, and fast. Prices were a bit high, but worth it.

I will absolutely eat there again.
author: William T.

description:
So as an Indian (South---Tamilian, specifically) I've grown wary and deeply skeptical over the years of Indian restaurants. I feel many are over accommodating to the tastes of the patrons and end up lacking in authenticity. So when I moved to SF and everyone was telling me about Dosa, I was indeed wary. 

My cousin and friends treated me to a dinner there on my birthday and I was quite pleased. Dosa definitely does a great job of keeping things authentic, while adding an element of elegance through ambience and presentation. I would have preferred the portions to be larger for the price, but they weren't unreasonable.

This was months ago, so I can't honestly remember what we ordered, but I remember the dosa was crispy and perfect and my drink, the Ginger Ante, was deeeeelicious!
author: Suganthi J.

description:
4 stars for the good quality and flavor of food. Can be a little pricey but the portion is not small either. I went there for a Sat. brunch and saw about 95% people dining there to be Indians. That says a lot about the authenticity of the dishes. 

For gluten-free folks: A "dosa" is a savory crepe made of rice and lentil so it is GLUTEN FREE! It is thin and very big piece there and you can dip it in the chutney or lentil dipping soup they have. I think most of the stuff on their menus are vegetarian. I was needing some animal protein so I ended up ordering the curry chicken dish. It was very tasty, not too spicy and big portion. I saved half of it for dinner. 

Will definitely come back next time I'm in the area.
author: Claire W.

description:
I didn't like the food there.. Really disgusting (and expensive).
The place was dirty, with insect on the floor.
author: California G.

description:
Like this place needs another great review. Had the calamari, prawn curry-type thing with the coconut rice, and the paper masala. I recommend them all, especially the first two (the last one I've had before and it's great, and a bit of a novelty, so having it a second time I wasn't as excited as the first time).

As a big dessert person, I also want to say that I loved the goat cheese/ banana thing. And I rarely take interest in desserts when I try Indian cuisine.

For me, Dosa is yummy comfort food -- of course very different from Don Pisto's (except they're both spicy), but both foods kind of have this effect on me.
author: F K.

description: It was extremely busy Saturday night and we didn't have a reservation, so we made a reservation for Sunday night and the place was much less full when we were seated. The service was friendly and helpful about dietary restrictions. We got the tasting menu and were extremely pleased. Everything was delicious! Kale and mung salad was lightly dressed and the combined fruit worked well. I couldn't put the spinach and fennel dosa down and the mung dosa was just as good. The chutneys with both were awesome and we saved a bit for our entrees. Lotus root kafkta with cashew creamy sauce was sweet and succulent and came with soft, fluffy rice to help with the heat from all the other foods. We're ready to make our next reservation already!
author: Tara B.

description:
Pretty good stuff. They use a lot of ghee in their dosas, but then again that's the good stuff in life (dont count calories for the day please ). Lived through and loved the habanero mango dosa, lives up to the warning on the menu.

Highly recommend any of the doses on the menu. The thali was good too.
author: Nikhil B.

description:
I was kinda apprehensive about Dosa because I had never paid this much for Indian food, but I really enjoyed our meal here. 

We didn't have reservations and were lucky to snag a seat at the bar on a busy Saturday night. Typically, I don't like sitting at the bar, especially when you're paying this much for a meal, but it worked out in our favor. We were able to pick the brain of the bartenders and ended up with some really great entrees. 

We started off our meal with drinks: the Port of Call and the Ginger Ante. The Port of Call was like a hot, naughty, spiked tea with tons of alcohol and a kick! The Ginger Ante was acidic, and refreshing. 

For an appetizer, we tried the Chennai chicken. This dish was like Japanese chicken karaage: battered strips of juicy, tender chicken with a creamy sauce. It was really delicious, but slightly overpriced for the portion.

The bartender recommended that we get the Paper Masala: a thin, pliable and crispy version served with spicy mashed potatoes, onions, cashew nuts and various chutneys. When our paper masala arrived at the bar, I think half of the restaurant was looking at us. It was GINORMOUS. (see my yelp profile pic!) Imagine a crispy crepe the size of a saxophone placed in front of you. Did I mention it was HUGE?! And let me tell you, in this case, size does matter. We thought that there was no way we could finish it but it was so delicious that we did. The crispy texture of the dosa was the perfect foundation for the savory spiced potatoes and sweet chutneys. 

Next, I had quite possibly the best lamb curry I have ever eaten: Tamil Lamb Curry. The lamb was impossibly tender, but not faling apart. It was in a savory sauce of fennel, tomatoes, poppy seeds, caramelized onions and spices. The recommended side of lemon rice was a light and refreshing contrast to the subtle gameyness of the lamb and the earthy spices of the sauce. 

We ended with the Fresh Cococut Custard Cake, but I wasn't that thrilled with it. 

Overall, Dosa lived up to the hype for me. I can't wait to come back and try different kinds of dosas.
author: Monelle A.

description: One of the fine dining restaurants in bay area..their drinks are really awesome ...you should definitely try Icon which has really nice cinnamon kick in it...must a try ...i also tried gulmarg the first drink which was on warmer side ...but definitely a try....i had spicy mung dosa it was ok not that great !!!
author: Akshay K.

description: First time with South Indian food and it was delicious! Highly suggest this place, try the ginger cocktail and the Lamb Dosa.
author: Cecily G.

description: excellent  -  seems  to be grounded in  authentic south indian floor  and  style - yet  with  some  unusual ingredients which add  novelty -  breads are super  - staff friendly
author: James W.

description:
Fantastic, upscale Indian food. Excellent service as well. 

Make a reservation
author: J. M.

description:
After spending the whole day cooped up indoors, my gf and I decided to take the fancy new purse she just bought out for a spin. We headed to Dosa and were seated at the bar as the place was already buzzing at 6:15pm on a Saturday. Our bartender-server was attentive and provided some great suggestions for our meal. 

We started off with some cocktails, the Port of Call and the Ginger Ante. The Port of Call, a hot (as in temperature) drink that tasted like spiked tea, was surprisingly good. The Ginger Ante was refreshing and had a mild finish. 

Our meal started off with the Chennai Chicken, which was well seasoned and moist, similar to Japanese chicken karage. My only gripe is that it is somewhat overpriced for the portion. Our main entrees were the Tamil Lamb Curry accompanied with lemon rice, and the Paper Masala dosa. I'm by no means an expert in Indian cuisine, but I will have to say that the lamb curry with the lemon rice is one of the tastiest curries I've had, probably ever. The lamb chunks were perfectly moist and the curry rich and nutty. The Paper Masala dosa was quite the eye catcher, as it appeared to be huge crepe folded into a cone stretching about 1.5 feet across the plate. It tasted wonderful, and went well with the Masala (a very well seasoned mash potato) and the various dipping accompaniments. 

For dessert, we tried the Fresh Coconut Custard cake. My girlfriend wasn't wow'd by it, but it grew on me as I kept eating. I enjoyed the texture of the coconut that lined the bottom of the cake. 

Total damage came out to $90 including tip. Definitely on the high side, but my gf and I splurged a bit with drinks and dessert. Most of the dining options on the menu are reasonable, averaging around $10-12.
author: Lael A.

description:
South Indian Hot...not even close.  Just say, "overpriced average indian food"

For the price, the food is very substandard.  I had their newest Goa Shrimp curry dish which supposedly is the "most knarly hot dish" but the overwhelming flavor was sugar, not chili.    For 2 people, the bill was 85 bucks with a few Kingfisher beers.  For 20$, I'll take my friend to Viks chaat house in Berkeley for real dosa flavor.

It's swanky, yes, but not worth the price.  Find a good dive Indian place like Alhambra on 16th near Valencia for cheap food yet better flavor!
author: Michelle R.

description:
Got seated by Emily, great service

Mango lassi was great
Onion rava crispy and yum

Hyderabadi lamb shammi kabob, not to my liking
author: Sonal A.

description:
The cute Mexican bartender steered me away from the Habanero Dosa, thank God.  I wound up with a Spicy Mung Dosa and it proved plenty hot for my fiery tastes.  

Calamari was a yummy starter as was a shot of some Korean alcohol.  

If you go the Dosa route, there's a lot of "same flavored" food to plow through, so mix up your menu a bit by incuding some non-Dosas (like the aforementioned calamari).  

Ambience is low-lit and friendly.  Full menu available at the bar.  

Nothing not to like... not at all.
author: Tracey A.

description: So very delicious.  I had the white truffle masala dosa.  Although not the traditional Indian restaurant... who cares?  The Bay Area is full of traditional Indian restaurants.  This is much better in my book!  Great atmosphere, full bar, and reasonably priced.  A gem!
author: Melissa B.

description: I had the best mung dosa here in the whole town of San Francisco. Sambhar needs a little work and some spices.
author: Shivam T.

description: Great food! Very unique and delicious. The service was wonderful and everyone was night. A little on the expensive side, even for San Francisco, but portions are fair and worth it!
author: Lilly B.

description:
Indian Delight!
Take me to the smells, sounds and tastes of fancy New Delhi.
Love Dosa.
The Dahi Vada is to die for. The corn soup is amazing. The drinks are original and flavorful. They have an unending gluten free menu and the service is always on par.
Will of course, be back.
OM YUM OM!
author: Sara D.

description:
With friends in the Mission I've finally had a chance to tackle Dosa, thank the holy lord (and his unicorn) since I was such a huge epic fail living near the Fillmore twin for a year and never made it out.

Main event: Spicy Mung Masal Dosa. Tasty tasty stuff that dosa, I was impressed. The flavor of the filling was there without being covered up by the wicked spicyness. Sometimes when food is hot like this the flavor of the ingredients are lost in the burn. Not so in this case. The "fire broth" soup was simple and a good starter, again well played on the spicy. I love Indian spicy done right. Have you ever seen someone have a moderate allergic reaction to something? Sweating, redness in the face, tears, runny nose, and a general look of despair? That's just how I look when I'm finally eating Indian food that I think is just right on the spiciness. Yea, this physical proof work out really well for me, especially with the ladies... :/

I only had one concern, and I will address this on my next trip. My food was really good, so of course I wanted to I try a chunk of my friend's dosa. She went for the Spinach & Fennel Pooriyal, I was stoked to try it as the description is not very close to mine at all, so I'm thinkin' "Sweet, I get to try two pretty different dosas". Hmmm not so much, yes I could pull in a slight spinach flavor but for the most part.. her's tasted a lot like mine. I'm not talking the chutney and sambar, I know those are the same, but the filling in hers was pretty close and equally spicy (even though there was no note of "spicy" in the description). On a financial note, $10 seems reasonable to me for the dish. 

To the vegans out there they have a very helpful allergen chart where you can cross reference any dish on the menu to see if it has dairy. Very clear, very easy. The servers will be glad to explain dishes that can be altered to fit the vegan diet too, they seemed to know their stuff.

So I'm gonna go all MythBusters and roll back and try something as far away from the description of my last dish as possible. If it comes out and it's amazing AND unique, then *wipes sweat of forhead* the 4 star stands. If it turns out to taste a lot like rest.... I maybe won't be so sure anymore. Ball is in your court Dosa, make me proud.
author: Justin N.

description:
Still a great spot after many years.
I will admit that I prefer the location on Fillmore as it is larger and has amazing design.
That being said, the food is great, no matter what you order.
Drinks are really good, though I feel that one of the bartenders at the Fillmore location is better at creating a drink especially for you than at the Valencia location.
And to be clear, I typically sit at the bar at both locations and try to interact with the bartender.
author: Markus S.

description:
Found a really good review on yelp and expected something great. Interior was good, the mood was awesome, but the service... I never met such bad quality of service: our server (woman with black hair) was very impolite and arrogant.

And habanero mango masala wasn't spicy enough.

Horrible.
author: Antony B.

description: The service is impeccable: the bartenders are at my service right before I finish my drink, the food is served timely and in perfect flow from appetizer to dessert. The food is also gourmet Indian, with a presentation that is not to contend with. The music is ambient, cheerful, and zen altogether. The best part about it is the management. They obviously have their shit together to run such a spectacular establishment like this Dosa. Thank you for making my day and continuing to provide an errorless experience. For anyone who thinks otherwise, good luck to you and your endeavors.
author: Haley D.

description:
Great place for a meal, if these dishes suit your palate. Every dish we ordered was heavily flavored by many different spices, which is to be expected from this type of cuisine. I thought it was amazing (unfortunately, the rest of my party wasn't partial to such flavors). One person said that the first dish we shared (South Indian Moons) was a pleasant surprise, but as the meal went on, she didn't like that each successive dish also had a bit of a kick.

Be warned, if you don't particularly enjoy spicy dishes. If you do though, everything tasted as good as it looked. For reference, I ordered a three-course meal with cochin calamari (goes nicely with the included uttapam), trumpet mushrooms uttapam, and seasonal vegetable curry. The rest of my party ordered a three-course meal with hyderabadi shammi kebabs, trumpet mushrooms uttapam, and prawn masala with Louisiana shrimp (the included seafood is quite large), as well as the daily special (mahi mahi - looked quite good), and the channa bhatura (the included bread is huge, but shrinks greatly in seconds.

One thing, though: don't order both the south indian moons and an uttapam from the three-course meal as the dishes are almost identical. I'd imagine that the same goes for a dosa from the three-course meal and something from the Dosa section of the menu. I would have preferred to try something else, in addition to the uttapam.

Also, the place is quite small and cramped, as is typical of establishments in San Francisco. I'm not from SF so I was a bit surprised, but it shouldn't be a problem unless you're morbidly obese.
author: Jonathan J.

description:
I have been dining at Dosa at this location for 6 years and they have been great with their food and service. I tried almost everything on their menu and these are my favorite dish:

Paper masala Dosa
Bhatura bread
Channa Bhatura curry (they don't carry this anymore: (    )

The Taj Mahal beer goes really well with the food. The owners are friendly and care about their customers. 

Thanks Dosa for making it an awesome experience everytime I dine in your restaurant.
author: steph t.

description: Un-freakin-believable! Best Indian meal ever. I went with a friend who knows Indian food better than I do and she ordered tons for us to taste (And fire soup for her since I can't do super spicy). I'm not sure what I ate (the delicious cardamom gin and tonic had me in a fog) but I'm sure I was in food heaven.
author: Wendy C.

description:
Songwriting time...

Diggity Dosa, the spicy chicken,
You have a mini poori and you brain stops tickin'
Drinkin' house gin with the lights low
We're dans la mission
I hope the Lamb is nice in this one

...aw screw it...

If I go any further I'll start to show my age...and I wasn't even a big barenaked ladies fan.

But I am a fan of Dosa.

Having always gone to the Filmore location, this was my first stint at the mission location and i have to say...i think I like mission more.

I know the Filmore location isn't pretentious at all but somehow this location seems less so and more inviting.  

Either way, I ate too much and drank too little.

For some reason though, it had the same effect on me as when I do the opposite.

Chutney.
author: Archie R.

description:
Pros: accepts credit, good service, clean bathrooms
Cons: all vegetarian entrees with exception of lamb keema, $$ dishes, lack of non spicy dipping sauce available

My friends and I came here on a Wednesday night around 7pm. There was a good amount of diners already in but we were seated fine. Our waitress came and gave us the quick run through on the Dosa menu and after taking our orders, it took around 10 minutes for all of our dishes to come out. I chose the Lamb Keema because it seemed like the only meat dish on the Dosas menu! I didn't notice until I saw that my friends weren't eating any meat dishes. The dosa itself was huge. A gigantic crepe. It came rolled like a poster on my plate. There was also a delicious spicy dipping sauces and two chutneys on the plate additionally to the mound of lamb. The sauce was too spicy for some friends and the waitress informed us that there is no mild sauce and that the only thing she could do was to replace it with a yogurt sauce. I found that odd that there wasn't any mild soup dipping sauce in an Indian restaurant. I for one found that spicy dipping soup to be so good! I thought $15 was a little high for the amount of lamb you receive, but it was pretty good so it can slide by this one time. The menu overall is very pricey with the lowest priced item on the menu being around $9. I never knew vegetarian food to be so expensive.......
author: Alex T.

description: Sambhar is the best !!! Definitely worth a visit !!
author: Shyam Jindhe A.

description:
Great food, great drinks, great ambiance! 

They were very accommodating to one of the people in our group because she is allergic to nuts. They gave a separate menu with foods with no nuts and offered to have some of the dishes cooked without nuts.

Fair warning...DO NOT ask for EXTRA SPICY!! Especially if you cannot handle it! Our whole table was in tears and it messed up all of our stomachs for two days! It was horrible! The cream/yogurt sauce they gave us to neutralize the spiciness helped us eat the food, but it did not help us with our stomachs.
author: Sandra F.

description:
We've made a reservation but the table wasn't ready when you arrive. Then they gave us really uncomfortable chairs with no back seat. We asked to move and after 15 we decided to move.
Bad service basically.
author: shai m.

description: Excellent food. Surprising for an Indian restaurant with such a bad name. Everything I've tried has been great. Good service too. Can't complain.
author: Grey Z.

description:
Ended up eating here last night by accident and it was awesome.  Excellent service and some great recommendations since none of us were well acquainted with the varieties of Indian food served here.  The ambiance is casual and comfortable, service is friendly and attentive, 

All of their cocktails are infused with Indian spices; I had the Peony and it was fantastic, just enough to kick to start the meal off.

We shared:
Cochin Calamari - a little light on substance but the flavor was amazing
Chennai Chicken - heartier and beautifully prepared, a little more heat
Lamb Pepper Fry - the spiciest of the trio and served with rice, an excellent finisher

The wait was shorter than most places nearby but that may have been from the holiday weekend; either way I'd highly recommend it.
author: Adam H.

description:
The staff was awesome.  The bartender put together some unique cocktails which were a big hit.  Just tell him what you like and he puts together something fun and unique.  

Food wise, very consistent - always good food.  The cochin calamari is very good app to start.  

Some of the combos - I had the chichen w/ side of Dosa is great - but honestly its a lot of food - I think next time its best to go family style that way you get to try all the other cool items!  

Also the Dosas are made crispy - so if you would like it different you need to let them know.  

We didnt have any desserts but the Chai - I thought was good.  

Definitely a SF staple!!

Bon appetit fellow yelpers!
author: Bhavin M.

description: Amazing Indian food, but dinner for three ran $210 on my visit.  That's three tasting menus, a few drinks, and one dessert.  Everything was very good, hard to go wrong on the food selection.  Park around the corner on the garage at 21st, love that place.
author: Patrick S.

description:
This place was amazing. We were walking around Valencia and came across Dosa which had a great trendy vibe. When we arrived there was a large party of Indian people already eating there, which we took to be a good sign of quality and authenticity.

We first had southern Indian in Denver, Colorado (where there is a great place called Masalaa which serves wonderful vegetarian dosas http://www.masalaausa.com/). We would even drive over an hour from another city to eat there since it was so popular with my boyfriend. But after moving away, it has now been over 2.5 years since having a proper dosa.

For his birthday last February I even tried (and failed) to make them myself...

Anyhow, we started off with the mint lemonade and mango juice. The lemonade came with fresh mint leaves and the mango juice was perfect - sweet, thick and refreshing. Next we were served crisp papadums and before we could get started our dinner was already arriving. 

He orded the traditional Paper Masala Dosa and I got the Lamb "Keema". With both orders our curries were served on the side rather then inside the dosa which was fine for us and made it more convenient to share. My minced lamb was fantastic as were the  chutneys (one was a tomato and the other a cilantro-mint dipping sauce). Our dosas were large and magnificent. They tasted wonderful and were thin and crispy. 

The service was great - quick, efficient, and friendly. The host was welcoming and let us pick a seat, our waters were refilled a number of times, our dinners came out together and piping hot, and the waiter was willing to answer questions and didn't act impatient or rushed.

We were both impressed and definitely are planning a return trip. I think next time we would like to try the dumpling appetizer the customers next to us ordered.
author: Nina E.

description:
The restaurant has a nice ambience to it. The menu is quite different, has innovative Dosa combinations. 

Pros
The Sambar and chutney given along with the Dosa is excellent. Nice Ambience.

Cons
The food was good, but not as authentic to South Indian cuisine as I would have liked. It gives a good idea of South Indian food to Americans though. But being from the land of dosas itself, I might be judging on too high standards. Felt good to have Dosa after a long time.

The place gets pretty crowded, so make sure you get there early.
author: Varrun R.

description:
This review is for brunch only, and albeit it was a little on the pricier side with drinks, I would say thats the case for any nice brunch place in SF.  Of course the ambience is great and has nice presentation.  My husband is from Bangalore so we have pretty high expectations but this place did not disapoint!

We ordered the mango martini and curry bloody mary, which were both delicious.  I dont even like gin but this bloody mary tasted delish!  My husband and brother ordered the south Indian omelet, and i got the egg poriyal dosa. The omelet was really good and the sambar was to die for. (BTW impressive that the servers and waiters know how to actually pronounce sambar!).  My egg poriyal dosa was almost like an indian egg burrito which was actually really good.  I enjoyed it.  My brother in law got the thali, which had a bunch of different curries and rice, which he very quickly finished to the end. 

Gotta say, trying something a little different than the traditional south indian meal was a fun and satisfying experience.   Thanks Dosa :)
author: Namita A.

description: The masala dosa and vada pav are really good.  Unlike the fillmore location, the bartenders here are awesome, especially Jake.  He makes my favorite vodka gimlet in the city!  Yay!
author: Amy M.

description:
So I'll probably just repeat what others have said - but here goes...

D-elicious. I'm kind of a sucker for indian food and my boyfriend is South Indian so there's even more encouragement from him to like indian food.

First, both locations (Fillmore and Valencia) are really cool spaces. The Valencia location is much smaller than you'd think and thus the wait can be long if you come after 7pm but the Fillmore location is a lot bigger, but maybe just not as convenient to get to.  

Not many people have mentioned this, so I will - the drinks are AMAZING. Oh my god, I did not expect to come into this place with such an awesome menu of mixed drinks, but dang, I loved every sip.  And they are well presented and strong!! 

Avocado and peach salad - really tasty and surprisingly tangy.  Huge chunks of peaches and avocado with an almost spicy dressing. Mmmm. 

Vada sambar - very tasty and well presented. Pretty filling too for an "app". 

Tamil lamb curry - So tender, SO good. 

Dosas - obviously get one, or two. They are huge, but they can be used throughout the meal to soak up all of the other delicious sauces available.

Lastly, the desserts were surprisingly good... specifically... RASMALAI. Super creamy and honestly making my mouth water as I think about it. Mmmmm..... 

Big fan of Dosa. You should check it out. But know there might be a wait (sitting at the bar is not a bad option!).
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
In the Bay Area it seems everyone loves Indian food. Well, I am an Indian guy that does *NOT* like Indian food.

Nevertheless, when my parents came down to visit, I figured I would bring them to this place since I'd heard good things.

I have to say, this restaurant is amazing. I got the tasting menu which is a great deal for $35.

Cochin Calamari: I love Calamari in general, and wanted to try an Indian twist on it. This was good calamari, but not that innovative. 3/5 stars

South Indian Corn Soup: This was great. Not hot at all, and just the right amount of spices. We liked this so much I tried Googling for similar recipes at the table. 5/5 stars

White Truffle Masala Dosa: My parents always dragged me to this crappy Dosa place back in Ottawa, and I've hated Dosas ever since. Fortunately the dish has been redeemed with this rendition. The filling was great, and the truffle oil took it over the top. The bread wasn't overly spicy or bitter like Dosa bread can be sometimes. 4/5 stars

Paneer & Peas Dosa: Paneer is one of the few vegetarian Indian dishes I like (it's freaking cheese, everyone loves cheese). The dish had the flavor of paneer throughout, yet was complex enough to stay interesting with all the other stuff like the spiced peas, filling, etc. 5/5 stars

Tamil Lamb Curry: Very good. I find in lamb curries, the curry has to be strong enough to balance the gamey taste of the lamb. The curry in this dish was great. The lemon rice matched it perfectly and was great in itself. 5/5 stars

Fresh Coconut Custard Cake: With all the interesting inventions they had, I couldn't leave without trying dessert. Most Indian restaurants have the usual Gulab Jamun, Rasmali, etc. The cake was great, although you should like spices in your dessert if you want to get this. If you like Mexican Hot Chocolate, you'd probably like this. 5/5 stars

Finally, unlike most Indian restaurants, the inside is modern looking and really quite nice, with lots of dark woods and intimate lighting. Definitely a great place for a special occasion or important night.
author: Rishi G.

description:
The food was a amazing one the taste was so good that i really think of dining often.
As a Indian i felt it as one of the best restaurants in bay area...
author: Dilip Prakash V.

description:
Every dinner I've eaten at Dosa has blown me away.  From the papadum in the beginning to the lamb curries that have just the right amount of spice, it is all SO good!  

I prefer to eat at the Fillmore location because it is bigger (and fancier) but eat at this location when I hang out in the Mission.

Try as many of the Dosa breads as you can, they are amazing. I look forward to my next dinner here!
author: Carmel U.

description:
Be careful which Dosa you meet at.. There are two... 

I came here with three other friends, and we were able to make a reservation for a Friday night. 

I had a delicious Rava dosa! Can't say it was the best I've had but it was tastey and I was starved. I did find it bizarre that the potatoes/filling was underneath the dosa instead of inside it. Also, $12-15 for a dosa is on the extremely steep side, and that's the reason Dosa only gets 3* from me. 

I do like how almost all their wine are priced between $40-50. It makes you really pick a bottle based on what you want and not based on price (if you're price conscious). 

Overall, I can't say I'll be back due to the steep price for what you get. But good experience to South Indian food if you've never had it before.
author: Eric H.

description:
I am an Indian guy who has extremely high expectations of Indian Food. Based on my rating - you can guess that Dosa's did not disappoint. 

I had a Ghee Dosa and a Bhel Puri (Chaat - Indian Fast Food). Both of them were good. My friend ordered a South Indian Thali which looked scrumptious. 

The place was really clean and modern looking, with lots of dark wood and intimate lighting. Definitely a great place for a special occasion or an important night. 

Our server was extremely friendly and gave us good recommendations on what to try for dessert. 

Although this is not the best Indian food I've ever had, this was probably the best Indian food I have had in San Francisco. IIf you have had bad experience with Indian food in the past, this is a restaurant that could change your mind.
author: Rohith S.

description:
BECAUSE I CAN'T UPDATE MY REVIEW YET, I HAVE TO POST THIS NOW (and try hard not to KNOCK ANOTHER STAR OFF)...

One of the owners, Anjan, just sent me a message in response to my review. TOTALLY RUDE, IF I SHOULD SAY SO MYSELF.  HERE IT IS:  

"Hey Angella - Thanks for visiting us at DOSA.  Did you actually knock off a star because we didn't refill your water! Tough! :-)

Anyway, I apologize for the service  but I did want to let you know that we work as a team so you could've grabbed anyone to help you...another server, runner, busser or a manager.  

I find it very difficult to believe that your server was missing for 30 minutes.  If so, I'd be glad to to fire them! (Just kidding!).  

I hope you join us again.   We take service very seriously and I'll make sure your water glasses are filled at all times."
------------------------------------------------------------
HIS RESPONSE IS TOTALLY SARCASTIC.  I SHOULDN'T HAVE TO "GRAB" ANY RANDOM MEMBER OF THE STAFF TO REFILL WATER IN A HOT AND SPICY JOINT.  AND YES, 30 MINUTES WAS ACTUALLY AN UNDERSTATEMENT BEING THAT OUR SERVERS CHANGED MID-SERVICE.
------------------------------------------------------------
Here is my review from last night:
Oh Dosa...

Why did you do this to me?

I was sooooo about to bump my rating up to five stars because the food is FANTASTIC, STUPENDOUS, TREMENDOUS!  Dosas are to die for and you gotta love the uttapans.  That thin crunchy chip-ish thing they serve is addictive.  Dosa is a medium-spicy veggie heaven.    

But the service.  UGGGG.  You really stepped in POO POO last night   :(
----------------------
So here's the story...I was with a friend's parents from Oklahoma.  Needless to say, they don't eat much spicy food and were certainly newbies to this type of Indian cuisine.  Everyone was happy until mama took a spicy bite and her face turned red.  She then began that subtle little "omg-that-was-way-too-hot-but-I-don't-want-anyone-to-notice" kind of cough.   

I looked around and our waitress was NO WHERE to be found.  She came strolling back around over 30 minutes later and never even noticed that the water was empty.

Such a shame because I actually really like this place; I'll surely be back at some point.

And no, my friend's mom didn't die...I just hope she wasn't traumatized.
author: Angella S.

description:
So I'm a big fan of this place. True, I've always been partial to some fantastic South Indian cooking. And true, I do the like the pomp and circumstance of being presented with a dosa the size of a Dead Sea scroll.

But aside from all that I also love the spice fused cocktails and the departure from the usual family-owned 'cheap eats' feel of most Indian restaurants to a more funky, up-market vibe. 

I think I've just talked myself into going again this weekend..
author: Matt T.

description: Just get the straight up traditional dosa and call it a day. For the price you pay though, you can find much better Indian food places in the bay area.
author: Isaac R.

description: Nice for hanging with friends. The food is really good. Try the white truffle dosa, really yummy.
author: Marina V.

description:
Indian fine dining.. Of course I was going to like it.  A friend had visited SF and told me about his experience here (actually, I think it was the Fillmore location) with plated Indian food, or the presentation matching fancy shmancy restaurants where soups or yogurt get poured over a plated bowl in front of you, and since then I'd been wanting to try it.

I think it was over a year before I got to trying it and it didn't disappoint.  Even though I don't typically care for masala dosas, I decided to go with the truffle masala dosa, mainly because I'm a sucker for anything on the menu that uses the "t" word.  I asked for the masala on the side which was a nice way to have it.  It was delicious!  They did not skimp out on adding truffle oil as it was apparent in each bite.  The appetizers we got were also delicious - and the staff was super friendly.  A few of my friends I went with are regulars, so they were definitely friendly and chatty with the waitress.

If it weren't for the cost I'd definitely be frequenting it more often.. but I do look forward to going back to try more off the menu!
author: Rachana S.

description: One of the best Indian restaurants! Loved the chicken karavali... The kale mung salad was delicious.
author: Margherita T.

description: My family and I came here for my birthday dinner and enjoyed excellent food, service and ambiance. This venue is much more intimate and casual compared to Dosa on Fillmore. Of course, the food and drinks are equally good at both locations. I can't wait to go back!
author: Ashley C.

description:
Pros: Great food, a nice variety of southern Indian dishes, convenient location. 
Cons: Really loud, often hard to get a table, a bit pricey.
However, the food really is outstanding. That's what really matters most to me, so I will be going back in the future for sure!
author: Ashley T.

description: Very nice ambiance, absolutely delicious food, good service. The pumpkin dosa is great. Only thing I don't like is that since you eat dosa with your hands, it would be nice if they would provide water bowls and washcloths to wash your hands before and after your meal rather than having to trek off to the bathroom.
author: Jackie W.

description:
Was looking for my review for Dosa & realized I've never reviewed it. WHAAAA??

I'll be honest. It's been a few weeks since we were there, so I've forgotten a lot of the details. But what I do remember is that we walked in randomly around eight on a Friday or Saturday night (can't remember which) & were able to sit down at the bar within 10 minutes or so. (The wait was 30-45 minutes for a table, but we like sitting at the bar because we are close to cocktails. :)
