They offered to box up the rest of my meal for me. Something in the back of my mind told me they would wrap up the sauces for me and I knew I should've said something but I didn't. Drats, what a waste of packaging.

It ended up being $35 for two Dosas and a beer.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
I can't believe it's been almost 3 years when I was last here.  But, a lot has improved since then.

Service is excellent.  Staff was very friendly without being in my face.

Possibly the biggest improvement is that their food is much tastier and not as bland as I remember (which was the biggest reason I had been avoiding this place for such a long time).  We had the spinach and fennel pooriyai dosa and the goat curry special.  Both were really tasty.  However, the star for me was the bhatura bread.  What's not to like about deep fried bread?  I could have eaten it all evening.

Prices are still a little steep but I've come to accept it.  The goat curry was $18 which I resigned myself to but wasn't happy about.  It's funny how much just a couple of dollars make.  If it was $15 I would have said okay.  I hope they are using Bill Niman goat at that price.

In conclusion I would probably come back but still not that often because $50 for a meal for 2 without any alcohol is more than I want to spend on a weekly basis.
author: Jean K.

description:
Outstanding food. This is not authentic south Indian - but this version/fusion is so good, that I love it as much as the real thing. Their Sambar is very flavorful - different from what you would find in a Udipi place in India, but still great. Rasam could do with some extra salt, but was nice and spicy and left my nose and eyes watering. Their dosas are very large, tasty and crispy - the potato masala could have done with some extra salt/chilli. 
I ordered a bloody mary mix which was very interesting...apparently, they blend in some herbs into the tomato, so the taste is unique and very very good. 
Their chicken appetizer was average - nothing "indian" about it. 
There is a parking ramp (City) right around the corner, so that makes it very convenient. Dont expect street parking. Or just take a taxi to get there. 
The food is best described as fusion-Indian. Apart from the Dosa, nothing was as I remember it from childhood....but that does not decrease my enjoyment. I have been there several times, whenever I visit SFO.
author: Ravi R.

description:
Hurrah! This place rocks! They even have a special menu outlining which items are vegan, dairy and egg free and gluten free!!! 

Chutney sampler- wow
Spinach and fennel dosa- wow wow
Sunchoke uttapam- wow wow wow

Vegetable curry- was delicious but the dosa and uttapam are way better

Service was really great too. We ate at the bar and loved it! Def recommend and great for big groups. Really great fun vibe!
author: Candace D.

description: Well, I have been here before and I loved the food. This time around though, the food just wasn't that great. Poorly seasoned and just lacking flavor. The only redeeming feature was the vada pav and the excellent rasam (which is why I am giving this place three stars). Service was shoddy, with the wait staff not bothering to follow up on orders/ requests. Not sure if I will go back.
author: Ramya I.

description: I'm not very familiar with southern Indian cuisine, but I thoroughly enjoyed the lunch we had here with my family. The food was fresh, bright with the most interesting vibrant flavors. The staff was very knowledgeable and helpful with suggestions. My favorites were the dosa and lamb curry...yummmm.  I'm looking forward to my next visit :) .
author: Colleen H.

description: Pretty good indian food with a different flare - simple ingridients made to perfection
author: Sp S.

description: This is one of the places that I'm happy I tried, but I feel no need to come back. The servers were all friendly, the decor was really nice, and me and my friends were seated at a real sweet spot near the window on a nice warm day with the sun shining through. Sounds like it would be a great dining experience, but in actuality it was simply okay. And as friendly as the servers were, our actual entrees came out about an hour after our appetizers. And people who were seated after us, received their meals first. I don't get too upset about that, because sometimes when that happens to me at good restaurants the food ends up being really tasty, and I forget that I waited forever. But I get my white truffle masala dosa (doesn't that sound amazing?) and it's just simply okay. I've been wanting to try this place for awhile and I didn't know what to expect. I like Indian food, and I love me some masala. But this plate that I had, did not give my stomach the love it deserved. Maybe I should have went with another dish?  I did try my friend's egg uttapam and my other friend's egg dosa, and I thought those were a little bit better than mine, but not enough to keep me coming back. I'm OVER it.
author: April D.

description:
love this place.
last week was my 5th time there and it always satisfies.
indian food with an americanized touch.
cocktails have an indian edge and are original and great.
really steps out of the typical trendy cocktails nowadays.
chole bhatura is a must get. incredible.
paneer dosa is a fave.
fish pakoras were just ok...not enough fish.
will always stop here on my SF trips.
author: Robbie B.

description:
I greatly appreciate the special dietary needs menu! This place is vegan-friendly and they serve up some very delicious food. It is pricier than Udupi Palace just up the street, but you do get "fancier" food...

The dosas here are awesome... So thin, crisp, and scrumptious. That bright yellow potato filling that usually comes with your dosa is amazingly well spiced and bursts with flavor. I've had plenty of the uttapams on the menu, and they are also fantastic - I especially love the chili cilantro uttapam. And their soupy sambar stuff is out of this world... It's spicy, warm, and so flavorful. The pooris they have are super yummy, but what else could one expect from fried bread? And I think my favorite thing at Dosa is their coconut chutney. It's so very mouthwateringly delectable, I can't ever get enough! I'd buy a tub of that if it were available.

Needless to say, I enjoy Dosa very much...
author: marianne c.

description:
"Dosa! Dosa! Dosa!" is what I'm thinking as I cross the Bay Bridge on my way to SF. No way there's going to be a trip to this city without one or several stops at Dosa. 

I've even been known to visit this hip Indian spot twice in one day. I think that says it all, review done! Okay, okay, I'll tell you more about why this place should not be missed...

GO SOUTH: It can be difficult to find South Indian fare since most Indian restaurants feature the more popular Northern cuisine. And secondly, it can be difficult to find South Indian faire that tastes good. Well, Dosa meets both requirements, and it does so better than I've ever found. Ever!!!

SARDINES:  They do pack you in like sardines in this small Mission spot. Be prepared to know intimate details about your neighbor's life. But, it's all good. In fact, after my food arrives, I get so into the delicious bites that I forget about the love triangle squabble going on next to me!

OH THE FOOD:  My recs after sampling my way through:

*Chutney sampler: Slather your papadum in one of four chutneys - tamarind, dahi mint, sweet onion, and chile-garlic.
*Rasam: Spicy tomato broth soup that is perfect to drink (yes, I drink it from the bowl, why bother with a spoon) or to dip your dosa in. 
*Pani Puri:  Small crispy breads filled with chickpeas and potatoes. A very interesting and tasty dish. 
 *Masala Dosa:  Classic dosa served with a filling of potatoes, onions and cashews. I love savoring this one and dipping it in sambar. This item is my true love on the menu that I have to have. Oh, I'm craving it now!
*Habanero-Mango Masala:  This one comes with a Warning Label!!! It's an intensely hot masala dosa spread up with a habanero chutney. I do love spicy, but this spicy is off the radar! I still crave it, so I've found a compromise where I get the masala dosa and get the habanero chutney on the side so that I can still get the spice without being pained. 
*Brunch drinks: The brunch drinks add a twist to the usual staples. They feature a Bloody Mary 'Curry' and Mimosas that can be served with the standard OJ or Pomegranate or Mango juice.
*Brunch (never heard of Indian brunch before this place, but somehow it works): They feature brunch-y type foods with eggs in them. Then, you get the best of both worlds: Indian food and brunch!  Plus the eggs are cage-free!

DON'T MISS OUT:  If you love Indian food, you owe it to yourself to visit this spot. They also have a Fillmore location that worth checking out too, but personally, this Mission spot carries a more friendly vibe. Dosa, I'll be thinking of you and can't wait 'till we meet again!
author: Danielle W.

description:
5 stars for the quality of the food. Dosa serves authentic South Indian food (and I've been to Udupi and Saravana Bhavan in Sunnyvale). I highly recommend starting with the Chennai Chicken (think Indian style chicken tenders) and trying the classic Masala Dosa. If you're a fan of chickpeas then definitely order the Channa Bhatura. The garbanzo bean masala is delicious!

Minus 1 star for the noise and the fact that your clothes smell after eating here.
author: Helen Y.

description: The best Indian food in San Francisco! Lots of veggie options, the veggie curry is the best I've ever had. Service can be a little scattered when they are busy but the drinks make up for that.
author: Priscilla M.

description:
If you're craving South Indian cuisine (maybe because you grew up eating it virtually every day and can't recall why you ever left home...), Dosa is definitely a must-visit in SF. The venue is very warm and comfortable is complemented by friendly staff who show great patience with the many folks who crowd in here for some authentic Indian cuisine. The dosas are delicious - large portions made with pretty authentic sambar / chutney (I could go there and just eat chutney all day...). I tend to prefer the masala dosa, as the masala is always filling, healthy, and reminds me of home.  The prices (especially for a good restaurant in SF) are very reasonable as well.  All in all, I always enjoy eating at Dosa (this review is a bit overdue), and can't wait to go back!

Note: Parking in the mission, while frustrating, is probably worth it if you're coming here.
author: Rishi N.

description:
Very good food - although, some of the portions were very small and found too expensive for the price.

Wine suggested by waiter was pretty good; the waiter was not very friendly but soon warmed up to us and was very helpful towards the end. I can understand that, as the place got very crowded and loud, and could have been distracting for him :)

The ambiance was pretty good - but was a little over crowded. May be this place is pretty successful, I think.

Out of the 6 or 7 dishes we tried that evening, one of them was not good. The rest of them made up for the bad one. Also, two of the dishes we ordered,  knowing  it to be spicy, was really spicy ! in a good way and we were very happy.

Overall Great Experience
author: Naru K.

description:
Real delicious Indian food!!!

Been here twice. First experience was a sweaty, mouth-watery (from a good, tasty to hot, burning sensation) upon my return which wasn't as hot but still had the great cuisines!

This place can get a little hot so make sure you know what you're ordering. If not, feel free to ask the servers if it's spicy or not.

They are pretty good at refilling your glass since I was sweating which I don't know if it was due to the food I was inhaling or the many layers I was wearing. 

Overall, two hot thumbs (in water)!!!
author: Jay C.

description: I don't think they deserve a star. The food was worse than pathetic. I have been to several globalized Indian restaurants but none have murdered the Indian cuisine the way Dosa have managed successfully. As a foodie, I strongly recommend staying away when there are better options.
author: Ar B.

description:
really fresh flavors. ambiance is a little dark and crowded, but overall i would recommend this place for a casual weeknight dinner out or for lunch.

favorites:
-the peony (cocktail)
-bhatura (puffy bread)
-masala dosa
author: Esther H.

description: Dosa has worked out some of the kinks in their food and it's back up to a good standard. I absolutely adore the staff at the Valencia location as they treat us so well. Even on an incredibly busy night, they each take time to stop at our table and check in even if they aren't our server. I always look forward to eating here! :)
author: Whitney A.

description:
To me, Indian food is butter chicken and naan.  Boy, did I learn something new tonight. 

A group of friends and I went to Dosa on Valencia for dinner. We had reservations for 8 people, but had to change last minute to 10 minute. The hostess was very friendly about this and we were seated within 15 minutes (reasonable, it was pretty busy at the time!).

The waitress was very friendly. She explained every section of the menu and answered any questions we had.

I ended up ordering the paper masala (recommended by a friend) and my boyfriend ordered the lamb curry. The paper masala was definitely different ... it was a huge, rolled up thin and crispy piece of ... I want to say pancake, but I dare not. Basically, it was thin, crispy and came with a bunch of dips and mashed potatoes. YUM! My boyfriend thought the curry was good, and the lemon rice he ordered on the side was tasty as well.

The curries are a bit pricy because they do not include the price of a starchy side (3 dollars for rice), but the paper masala was only $11. The plus side is that both sides are definitely filling so you're getting your money's worth :)
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Warm atmosphere, good food, and attentive staff.  It's a little fancier than your average Indian restaurant, and while I enjoyed the food it didn't blow me away.  

I was more much impressed by Aslam's down the street.
author: Rachel G.

description:
Well I finally met my match. I've been to multiple Indian and even Thai restaurants and none of them have been able to impress me in the spice department. I love excruciatingly spicy dishes that make my nose run, my brow bead with sweat - something that really makes my face flush.

Well, tonight after eating their Habanero Mango Dosa Masala... Dosa officially has kicked my ass.

When I ordered the waitress asked if I had ever tried it. I told her I hadn't but that I was familiar with the spice of habaneros. I eat them raw you see. 

It's a bit deceiving. I thought the masala that had habaneros in it so I gobbled up the dosa but the heat didn't seem to go down. Only went up. Well turns out it was the dosa that was infused with habaneros. 

*Stomach grumble*

I'm gonna hurt tonight.

Totally worth it.
author: Sara M.

description:
We're not familiar with South Indian cuisine so we didn't know what to expect, but we were soon very happy to discover that we really liked it.

The restaurant is festive (aka loud) and very nicely appointed.  I just read that it had been redone, and it shows.  If not for the noise, it would be a great atmosphere.

We started with the avocado and peach salad, which was extremely fresh and very tasty.  Then I had the masala dosa and my husband had the paneer peas.  Both were excellent - a slight kick but not too spicy.  We passed on dessert.

Service was okay - nothing to complain about but nothing to compliment either.  The waitress seemed a bit distracted.  The manager, however, was very engaged and made his way around to all of the tables.

I would definitely go back again and wish I had taken advantage of some Groupon-like deals I had seen for this place.
author: B. Y.

description:
So after our ususal weekend drive to SF downtown, we wanted to have dinner at a nice,classy fine dinning place. On our friends suggestion and after trying the DOSA at Fillmore, we thought of trying Dosa on valencia!!

As we entered, it seemed to be very small as compared to the Dosa at Fillmore(This is very spacious and ambience is great too). We didn't make any reservation so had to wait for 20 mins but guess our timing was still good, we reached at 6:45, otherwise minimum wait is for 45 minutes.
So as were seated, we ordered VADA PAV's( staple maharashtrian appetizer), rasam( spicy lentil soup) and chennai chicken. They were all great and wasn't  typically indian style. Vada pav's were just AWESOME and so full of flavour.  The chutneys were so different and that adds to the taste.

For main course, we ordered Egg dosa, Mung dosa and the HABANERO MANGO dosa. Yes, those who have tried  the habanero-mango dosa know what i am talking about. It was so SPICYYYYYYYYYYYY!!

Although I like spicy food but before coming to DOSA, wherever i have tried indian food, even if i request to make the disy spicy, the spice leve was always mild SO i ignored the warning on DOSA menu that the habanero dosa is very intense and guess what, even between 2 of us, we couldn't finish 1 habanero dosa with 4 portions of SWEET CURD and 6 glasses of water.

It is that spicy!! It's a big big NOOOOOO to HABANERO MANGO DOSA.

I am not giving this place 5 only because the place is too small but the food is really great and worth trying. I would definitely come back.
author: Kanchan S.

description:
I'm a good cook. I grew up in both India and the US. I'm really picky about Indian food. And I give Dosa a thumbs-up. I like the rava dosa (though you have to eat it quickly because it's no good cold).

I've been there twice and enjoyed the food both times, but dessert was terrible, I thought. I sent the "tearamisu" back to the kitchen, it was that off-putting. The chocolate cake was really pretty enh. I'd say get your dinner here and then walk over to Bi-Rite for ice cream.
author: Neha B.

description:
Dosa has pretty much everything I'm looking for in a restaurant: great food, wine, and ambiance.  Do those three things well, and I'm willing to overlook some previously-mentioned, relatively minor flaws (slightly inflated prices, crowded location).

The paneer and peas dosa is absolute heaven.  Dunk it in the coconut chutney provided, and you will be planning your return trip before you've paid the bill, I assure you.  The sunchoke uttapam is also wonderful, and I love to accompany everything with the dahi rice (rice, yogurt, veggies, and spices).  For dessert (if you still have room), I highly recommend the coconut gelato.  When we take out of town guests here, that combination of foods generally keeps everyone quite happy.

A few other points:
- we dined with a friend who has a gluten allergy, and the folks at Dosa could not have been more accommodating (they have a special dietary restriction menu) or have had a wider selection of foods available.
- for those who complain about the parking, there is a reasonably-priced garage no more than a 2 minute walk away, on 21st St.  Problem solved.
- make a reservation on OpenTable - you will thank yourself later.
author: Laura R.

description: Fresh, delicious ingredients. Loved the spicy mung bean dosa and the calamari app.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Pretty good, but they forgot our rice for takeout!

Want to try again.
author: Michael E.

description:
I have to admit Dosa is not your typical indian restaurant. There's no Naan, there's no Chicken Tikka, there is Uttappa though, which I loved back home. The Tomato sauce that came with my Uttappa was the best thing, the Dal was good too. A fair warning.

The place though is overly expensive, while they probably use better organic ingredients and whatever else, I just don't think the flavor and the taste are worth the price when you get just as good indian food at half the cost. 

Me and my friend ordered drinks, Chai Russian and I forget the name but it was Soju + Mango Lassi. The Chai Russian wasn't very good, for some reason the mixture seemed wrong, I did prefer the taste of Chai to coffee but not sure. The Soju+Mango Lassi was quite good though, the taste of the Soku was masked quite a bit by the Mango Lassi so it turned out quite well, the mint leaf also provided a decent amount of flavor.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Still one of my favorite places for South Indian food. Their sambar is delicious, my favorite dosa is the Spicy Moong, and they've several fusion dishes on their menu that are excellent. Other dishes I'd recommend are the 'Channa Bhatura', and the 'South Indian Moons' Uttapam platter.

The dosas, though pricier than most other places are totally worth it. The appetizers and other dishes I feel are relatively over-priced. Udupi Palace right next door is a great option if you're looking for a more economical meal, but Dosa is the place to go when you're looking for a more chic dining experience.

I used to go to Dosa almost once a week to introduce a new friend to this place, but not anymore. Last year had a not so positive experience with the owner, and have heard similar feelings from a few other people as well, which has since turned me off Dosa. Since then, I've been here only about once every 3 months, maybe less. Udupi Palace next door is my new favorite South Indian restaurant.
author: Anubhav J.

description: I had my first dosa at Dosa and I'm definitely a fan. The crispiness of the dosa was perfection and the condiments each had a unique and wonderful flavor. The mango lassi was everything I wanted it to be and the lamb was cooked to perfection. Another person at the table tried the lamb curry which was perhaps the best lamb curry I'd ever tasted. For starters, we had the lentil fritters, idli sambar, and vada samabar- none of which I'd ever tried before and all of which were awesome. It will be tough next time to choose between trying new things and reordering those which we enjoyed so much!
author: WaltzingMatilda T.

description:
TODAY (9/25): the day i finally waited... trying the DOSA goodness. the hype has been out there with this south indian import, and let me tell you.. DELISHness all over and around the corners. me and my lovelyyy friend were super amazed by the size of dosa, itself. we were definitely perplexed with the size and even the taste of it (we totally thought that it's some HUGE cheese crisp.hahaha)

we had the today's special which was chix curry with eggplant, unbeknownst to this greatness that dosa embodies. i always knew DOSA but it's just wonderful to at least try it once.... honestly, eating at DOSA doesn't need to be an everyday routine but it's a very special indian in my heart.
author: Marc K.

description: This place is delicious. I walked by on my way to a birthday party and the smell alone convinced me to make a reservation the next week. I had the tasting menu - it was delicious. The lentil sauce they give you with your dosa is excellent. I really liked the sweet potato dosa. The tasting menu was a lot of food so I may go for just a dosa next time - the non-tasting menu ones are huge, like maybe not-fit-on-the-table large. I have to go back soon to try a few more things!
author: Christine H.

description: Solid South Indian food. Good dahi vada. Good vada pav. Slowest waitress ever. Had to get the bus boys to help us with basic needs. Can't blame them for one bad apple though.
author: Neel M.

description: I recently went to dosa for dinner, and it was amazing!!! The service was great, and friendly and snappy. The server made good suggestions and when learned of all of our various eating oddities provided us with an entirely different menu. This menu is amazing it had everything from vegan gluten free options to just regular meaty goodness. The people at dosa know how to make us difficult eaters feel not so awkward and have everyone have plenty of options. Not having to bug the server about all my questions was a nice break and it was refreshing to have everyone have a great meal with no complications. THANK YOU
author: Sarai T.

description: Best Indian food I've had yet. Favorite place to eat in San Fran! I'm a huge fan of Indian food and I am constantly looking to have my tastes buds impressed with a twist on authenticity. We got the traditional Paper Masala Dosa with the green mango spicy relish and extra chutnies. It's HUGE. We made it through, but could barely eat our next entree. That's a great deal for $11. We also got a giant puff bread with a chickpea curry. AMAZING, except was I was stuffed after the Dosa. The flavors were in perfect balance. Reservations are a must or you'll be waiting around for the bar. It's a smaller place. When you make the reservation, ask for the window tables, it can fit 3 people and is very intimate. Their cocktails paired perfectly with indian food. The waitress was soooo helpful. It was the best dinner that I had in San Fran. Must visit.
author: Alissa N.

description: We stopped in on a whim, and we were blown away by the puffy "Dosas" that passed our table as they came from the kitchen. How delicious! I was impressed by our servers knowledge, and the way she offered suggestions for our meal. The chutneys were very filling, and flavorful! Would recommend to a friend, and will stop in again!
author: Anne S.

description: The location on Valencia has a great atmosphere and the food was fresh and yummy! Most of us ordered dosas--large, savory, crepe-like things with flavorful fillings. My friend ordered the truffle dosa, which, if you like truffle oil YOU MUST TRY. I had the traditional masala, which was mainly potatoes with wonderful Indian spices. My s.o. had the paneer and peas which was also quite good. Although I didn't try any of their desserts, the menu looks fabulous and so creative--it was really really hard to resist. This is a fun take on Indian food that I haven't seen very much. I would definitely recommend this for a dinner with friends or a romantic dinner for two if you're in the mood to try something a little different.
author: Zoey M.

description:
Came back to Dosa a couple weekends ago, but I was a little put off by the way my boyfriend and I were treated. Food wise, the pani puri was a hit again, and I tried the vegetable uttapam, which was also good. The masala dosa was good but only partially filled (see picture).

What was a little off putting was that the staff came over to ask us several times (not one person, but two), whether we knew how to eat Indian food, and whether we wanted a demonstration of how to eat the sambar with our dishes, or how to put together the pani puri. We explained we eat a ton of Indian food (north, south, you name it) but they kept saying that chaat was a little different. I would have appreciated the extra time and attention if I had no idea what I was doing, but it didn't seem to help that we already said we knew how to eat it? They came back a couple times at separate occasions. I don't know. Confusing.

Will still be back though, like the food and the people watching =)
author: Katherine P.

description: Visited this place based on Yelp reviews during a visit to the bay area from LA. The food and service was pretty good. I was just not impressed with the cleanliness of the place. The restaurant, and the restrooms were pretty dirty. I just hope that the kitchen is kept up in better condition. I would have given 4 or even 5 stars if the restaurant was cleaner. It is not very appetizing to see greasy and dirty floors while you are eating.
author: Ari M.

description: Very compact but still serves the best chili dosa mixed with unimaginable combinations. I was in awe with their menu and how they gave the traditional South Indian dosa for a toss and pepped it up with some cool ingredients. You will not find a single person walking away unhappy after eating here .... LOVE IT LOVE IT LOVE IT!!!
author: Aparna K.

description:
When we arrived there was supposed to be an hour wait, so we thought we might check out another place. When we decided it had to be Dosa's we came back and they took my cell phone number so they could just call me when our table was ready- SO AWESOME! We just went down the street and had barely ordered drinks at Amnesia's- when they called and said they had a table! We came back and were seated immediately.

And that's just the start. We proceeded to stuff our faces with RIDICULOUSLY delicious  food, served by very attentive, helpful and awesome waiters etc. 

SUPER great and helpful service + Delicious food = easy choice- go here immediately. And um, take me with you!!! LOL :)
author: Aimee P.

description: The food here is amazing.  I know that when most people think of Indian food they might not have had the best impression but the food here at Dosa will definitely change your mind and leave you wanting more.  The flavors are beautifully captured in each and every dish.  The Chennai Chicken is an amazing starter and if you get there on a Monday you must try out their Dosas. Delicious!
author: Kevin J.

description:
My husband and I were there on a dine-about-town deal and ordered their tasting menu.  For starter, the Chennai Chicken was good, but they are really just deep fried chicken, i.e. nothing special.  Lentil dumplings were on the authentic side and tasted ok.  For dosa (South Indian style pancakes), we tried the Masala Chutney and Paneer & Peas - former was ok, but Paneer and Peas were really outstanding.  The pea filling was soft and tasted so good with the pairing sauce.  For entree, Pepper Chicken and Spinach & Paneer Prawns were just like any other Indian dishes I had, i.e. nothing special.  Dessert was coconut sorbet and glazed donut holes, which tasted ok but again - nothing special.  

The only highlights I have for this place was the Paneer & Peas dosa - it was really delicious.  But I heard you can get the very same quality dosa in some Indian joint in South Bay for $2, which leads me to think it was complete overpriced.  In conclusion, the food was not bad, great ambiance, and service was above average.  But for the same money I spent, I can probably get better things elsewhere.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Ate here two weeks ago with a friend.  Ordered lamb. I expected more for the whole experience.  My bill was rather high considering that I only ordered one entree plus a glass of wine and for that I would appreciate something more substantial.

I ordered 3 accompanying sauces to go with my meal, and they were extremely salty, so I really was as odds as to how to properly use them.  

The atmosphere/environment was pretty cool, but in the future I am going to try out different Indian food locations.
author: Alanna F.

description:
What what? Why have I never had southern Indian food before? So different than northern Indian and now I know why. The waiter was very informative in schooling me on the difference something I haven't seen in many other restaurants and appreciated. 

I really enjoyed the food, drinks and atmosphere here. This is definitely one of those places to keep close in your "tourist deck" for visiting friends who haven't been so fortunate in experiencing new cuisines. Hell, I may not tell anyone about this place and keep it to myself....
author: Leanne S.

description:
I went here with a group of 10 to celebrate a friend's birthday. A timely, attentive, terrific staff served us nothing but amazingly tasty food. We did the signature 4-course tastings. 

Starter: Cochin Calamari: tender & tasty. I do not hesitate to send back tough, rubbery calamari. This was very tender and sautéed with a mildly-spiced coconut milk sauce, served with mixed greens. I tasted my friend's friend Chennal chicken which was nicely done too!

Mini Dosa: Spicy Mung Masala: It was hard to choose among these options, but I think mine was one of if not the best of the group. Mung lentil dosa with green chiles, chopped onions, cilantro and spiced potatoes. The sauces & soup complemented the dosa as well.

South Indian Entree: Tamil Lamb Curry: the lamb was perfectly spiced and so tender. I'd definitely order this again. Description: Free-range & natural, fennel, tomatoes, poppy seeds, caramelized onions, spices, with heirloom tomato rice & raita. 

Dessert: I have a weakness for Gulab Jamoon, and it was worth it. You know it's like one soggy donut hole in a pool of melted sugar. My friends' sorbets were good too.

Dosa on Valencia is now on my short list to take groups to in the future, and even for a carry out when I'm in the neighborhood. Good job!
author: Tony K.

description:
Wow I really really really really loved this place.

Okay so my husband and I were walking back to our car when we decided we'd better eat something before heading home because there was nothing to eat at home. Feeling extra adventurous he wanted to try this Indian place (mainly because we were walking right by it already). 

Still scarred from my last Indian food experience I really did not want to go in. (The first and last time I tried Indian food was unfortunately at a shabby looking strip mall place where all the food was over cooked and overly spicy/spiced I dunno which.) So being very moronic I whined about hating Indian food quite loudly. There was a man at the front door who looked at me ruefully and then my husband said "c'mon in fairness that was not a good example of Indian food." Finally being more rational I said Ok, I know that strip mall place was probably the worst example of Indian food so I should give it another go. We went it.

I LOVED THE FOOD SO MUCH! We got lamb curry which was to die for and a dosa (honestly I don't remember which one other than it had marsala in it) and that was amazing too!!! Everything tasted perfect and I was practically licking the plates clean. The man who was "judging me" outside when I was being a whiny bitch was apparently either the owner or manager, he came over and asked me if the food was alright. Very embarrassing! But he seemed very nice and I let him know the food was AWESOME!!

I've been dreaming about going back for ages now but my husband has been working against me. It is very rare that he will venture away from his comfort foods so I have to wait for that day when he "feels like Indian" again. 

Or I'm just gonna crack and go with my friends hahaha. Actually it is a great place for catching up with friends or even a date!
author: becca w.

description: Not the best, not the worst. The waitress was pretty odd and the food was medium. A bit too oniony for me. Great drinks!
author: Alexa C.

description:
The place is really small- if you're coming with a group, expect not to have any elbow space, and people consistently bumping your chair. 

Aside from that, everything we ordered had amazing flavors. The Dosa here is fantastic!!!! The servers and bartenders are just as fabulous. They take the time to help you navigate through the menu, and also figuring out what you would probably like. However, everything on the menu is a winner- so just pick something :) It's nice that they explain to you that it's perfectly normal (and  highly encouraged) to eat with your hands instead of utensils.

Very satisfied with our meal and our experience. Just make sure you make a reservation- and even then, you will probably get seated much later.
author: Mar A.

description: The dosa's are crisp, the dipping sauce were spicy and had a good amount of heat. The dessert (sea salt caramel sauce) had us almost licking the plate and the coffee was wonderful. The specialty cocktails were great too!
author: sophie p.

description:
Dosa needs another review 
like I need a hole in the head,
and the damage done to my wallet
is equally as merciless.
But this evening, my gums are so tender,
swollen from the fresh salvo of flavors
exploding like Chinese fireworks on Kim Ill Sung's birthday.
I weep into the coconut chutney and dahl
for you, paneer and pea dosa. 
My palate pens a sweet encomium
for you, dahi vada. 
I drown in a swirl of mint and tamarind sauce.
Tonight, as always, a standing ovation.
author: Ligaya T.

description: Great dosa place, I'll be back to try more of their dishes. Fair prices. I enjoyed the mango lassi too.
author: Rahil S.

description: Love the food!  The ambiance is great, too.  This is a great date night place or place to go with a couple of friends.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
The most ridiculously over-priced and over-rated place I've ever been to. Being a native south Indian myself, calling this south Indian food is an insult in the face of south Indians worldwide. Of course, it's easy to get away with that technicality by calling it fusion cuisine, so I can't say anything about that. We went as a group of eleven people and they madeup a rule on the fly that a group of more than seven should do most of the orders from a limited choices three course menu (costing 40$ per person), where none of the options were what I wanted. 
First I thought, thank God, they did not insist that everyone in the group has to get a three course meal, as my wife is a light eater. I orded one three course meal for myself and some vada paavs and dosas for my wife. But after looking at their extremely small portion sizes, I realized my mistake.
Speaking of the food itself, the vada paavs were passable (South bay has better. Try ICB). The dosas themselves were alright (Paneer peas and mango habanero were our choices), although I must say the mango-habanero sauce was good and spicy. The "Indian fruit chaat" is what really made my blood boil. Some fruits with some Indian seasoning, salt and lemon on it somehow stands as a menu item on its own? The lotus kofta curry was laughably bad, with too much of Indian spices added to it that I couldn't even have two spoons of gravy (Btw, other than the Dosa, none of the items I mentioned were South Indian in any sense).
And the worst part was the bill itself, which for 11 people, was my total one month rent for the studio I stayed in, when I first came into the bay area. And it got me wondering, I actually spent 55$ per person for what? The ambience was nothing close to any of the fine dining cuisines I've been to. The food was hardly south Indian. The only thing south Indian in the menu was the dosa which they use like crepes to wrap random things to create their menu items.
May be I am biased because of the multiple good options for south Indian restaurants available in South bay (Madras Cafe, Anjappar, Madurai Idli, Aachi appakadai and may be if none of those is open, even Saravana Bhavan). Or may be I was the odd man out in this place (seeing how there are so many good reviews already). Or may be this place works for ridiculously rich people who want to have an alternative for their daily routine of burning dollar bills, while claiming that they had Indian food. Or may be this is how South Indian food tailored for the American palette should taste like. But if you want to eat authentic south Indian food, look elsewhere. Although I must confess, if you want south Indian restaurants with a good ambience (I for one care more about how good the food tastes, more than the ambience), your choices are limited.
author: Sri V.

description:
I can't say anything negative about this place after eating here a couple times now. Service is perfection; every server I've had is knowledgeable, helpful and friendly. Dishes arrive in good time between courses. While the place is always packed, there's never any pressure to 'eat up.' And  I've always been seated on time for a reservation. 

The food is awesome and I've made sure to get different things each time, never disappointed. I love getting the bill and being surprised at how low it is for such delicious, plentiful food whether dining with 2 or 8.
author: Meredith R.

description:
I made reservations here with a friend and I loved the atmosphere of this place. Pretty lights and intimate setting. 
The server was extremely helpful and explained how to eat the dosa based on my friend and my confused face. The vegetable curry was delicious but pretty spicy! Order at your own risk!

I would definitely come here again to taste their delicious dosa again!
author: Aurora A.

description:
Eye yam arrest-rot loyal-list. Isle ike two cell-licked a vain-ewe own two bee grate attics spec-shell-tea anne ne-far goat who amy otter comp-editor.  Butt eye eight hear won thyme whip sum free-end sand act-shoe-lee quest-yawned my the-eerie: tea me-y'all taze-dead quiet dither-rent tan otter indie-ann breast-our-aunts aye you-shoe-ally biz-hit.  Ape-hair-rent-leigh nor-thin-diane quizing is berry dividend tan spoon-job-bee.  Prizes where ape hit tiger tan tee otter blazes eye freak-went, butt knot soap ricey tatt I wood-end teat their egg-hen.  Thud E-core waste-haste-fuel with dork lie-ting an log soft me-yours. Oh-verile, wheat-oat-ally glove tit.

In the end, I decided that sometimes trying something different can be pretty cool.
author: Mari C.

description:
People.  
When you are at a jam-packed restaurant on a Saturday night, please be cognizant of the line hanging out the door and don't leisurely chat for an extra 30 minutes after the bill's been paid while some poor patron is forced to wait an extra half hour after her scheduled reservation.    

But kudos to Dosa for managing this unfortunate situation by being appropriately apologetic, and comping our entire party our cocktails while we waited.  We were happily buzzed by the time we sat down, and after dining on some outstanding South Indian cuisine, I was singing Dosa's praises as I wandered up and down the Mission.

I'd recommend the lamb and the masala dosas - very good, and very filling!
author: Cindy W.

description: I went to Dosa to meet up with some friends. We had two tables full but unfortunately the other table wasn't close enough. We all ordered different things and they were good! I can't remember all the dishes unless the menu was in front of me. I did like the monsoon drink. It was really refreshing and non-alcoholic. We also had a tomato salad, veggie and lamb curry dishes and more. We had a table full of Chinese and Koreans and another table of Chinese and Burmese friends. We all liked flavorful food. Check out my pictures for a visual. I also like there was a parking structure right around the corner. Dosa doesn't validate unfortunately. The price was also pretty reasonable (based on what everyone said).  We ate it all up!
author: Anna S.

description:
Dosa, another restaurant in our cool, hipster neighborhood of Mission.  Sorry, Dosa but you didn't really live up to the hype for me.  Ambiance wise, Dosa was really trendy with a busy bar, cool dim lights, and young yuppy crowd.  The food is different from your typical Indian curries.  Breaking down the food:

Cocktails:  I didn't get any but took sips of my friends'.  The Ginger Ante (10) was too bad while my friend thought the First Date (10) was way too strong and had to exchange it for another Ginger Ante.

Tamil Lamb Curry (18):  This was one pricey dish for a lukewarm, non-tender lamb in a non-distinct curry sauce.  Truth.

Regular Dosa (3):  This giant, think crepe was used to eat with the curry.  Light and crispy, it is a highlight of the meal.

Masala Chutney Dosa (10.5): was the best dish of the night.   A indian crepe filled with a potato-eggplant filling.  This was delicious.

South Indian Moons (13.5): A sampler plate of Uttapam, smaller thicker versions of dosas that are more like pancakes.  These were not bad, but truthfully, I could not to much difference between the different types of fillings.  

Overall, the food at Dosa is unique, but not quite scrumptious.  I would return here but only when in the right mood for this food.  Otherwise, I would suggest Vik's chaat corner in Berkeley for similar flavors and food!
author: Alex T.

description:
I wish there were more south Indian style/ dosa serving restaurants in san francisco. 

My recent trip to the Mission location of Dosa was alright. I had the spring dosa filled with shredded veggies that was mostly cabbage. The chutneys on the side were not as flavorful as I remember them being at the other Dosa location (Fillmore). Also, the sambar contained some long beans that were actually two hard to even chew or swallow. 

My boyfriend got the habanero and mango dosa which was way too spicy for us to enjoy. In their defense, the server and menu warned that it was very hot and even offered to bring a sample of the filling so he could try it ahead of time. He didn't take the sample. If you are thinking about trying this dish definitely sample the filling ahead of time! I couldn't even taste the mango under the habanero spice. 

The cocktail I had was very good and inventive but I feel like the Fillmore location has a larger and more interesting cocktail list.

So basically, if i want to go to Dosa again I will go to the fillmore location and if I am in the mission looking for a Dosa I will check out Udipi next time.
author: Leuwam T.

description:
Went here with four friends on a Saturday night. Pretty delicious food; spicy Niman Ranch lamb curry and sumptious bread. Spicy soup and I loved the Dosa Masala. This could have been a four or five star review, except for the inattentive waitress who didn't bring us our second order of bread, and the uhh..pubic hair in my friend's soup. I am assuming it was not actually a hair from the nether regions, but it was quite curly. 
UPDATE: The day after I originally posted this review, one of the owners called me to apologize and said he would look into the issue with his employees. That's the way to handle these situations. More restaurant owners should take these reviews seriously. Good job Dosa, my 3-star review becomes a 4-star!
author: Johnny O.

description: really liked the lamb curry and the masala dosa, friendly wait staff
author: Long C.

description:
Wonderful food, spiritless service.

Dosa is an upscale South Indian restaurant that exposes westerners to flavors more common to the southern part of india with dishes like dosa (a crèpe-like flat bread with a potato side filling and wonderful sauces and idlis and sambar.

The two times I have visited this place, I was very much delighted by their well prepared dishes.

The quality of service, however, lacks any of the charm and wonder of their food. Even if you make a reservation for Dosa, be prepared to wait about 15-20 minutes after your reserved time. Once seated, you may be waited upon by someone like Ariel who clearly was tired and not interested in delivery service commensurate with their prices. It was quite difficult to get her attention for anything and we frequently relied on other waiters for refills and other things.

Dosa, knows they're in demand and so they don't work hard for your business. But this shouldn't deter you from trying the place at least once; just be prepared to wait and made to feel like an inconvenience.
author: Derek B.

description:
A big thumbs up for bringing back the zing in Indian restaurants. Honestly, having Indian food at a restaurant is always more of a task than an experience.  It is definitely a place for an occasion. 

Dosa on Valencia backs up the classy decor with some real lip smacking dishes. Cochin Calamari, Pepper chicken and the Lamb are among the highly recommended dishes.

This is one restaurant I was happy to pay the extra dollar for.  Keep it up! 

Minus 1 star for the wait despite the reservation.
author: Vikram D.

description:
I came because of the allergy menu, but would have to say that the server did not seem to "get it" at all, even though I offered her my gluten intolerance awareness cards.  
My friends tried to specify that they did not want or order any sauces on the side for the shared food that might make me sick, but she brought them anyway ON TOP OF THE DOSA, so that I could not eat it.   

Ate only my dish, but felt sick after.
author: Bo D.

description:
Now this is a South Indian restaurant I can get behind. I've been wanting to come here for ages and was stoked when this venue was suggested for brunch/lunch. Although it's in the Mission area, it's more in the "charming neighbourhood, restaurant row" area than the traditionally grimy/grungy image associated with Mission.

Between the three of us, we tasted idlis, vada, plain utthappam, the spiced mung salad and the habanero/mango masala dosa. The first three were as expected, and props for the texture of the utthappam, which was just the right balance between soft and crispy. The mung salad was unbelievably delicious and has me tempted to try to recreate it at home. Only beef is that the portion size is a little small for the $9 price tag.

Now, a word to the wise for those foolish enough to brave the habanero dosa. Even though I was given a taste of the chutney and knew what kind of heat was in store, I naively thought that my tongue would be able to withstand the assault of the habanero-mango sauce with the hot masala and the hot sambar. Alas, I could not finish the delicious dosa without two glasses of water and three cups of yogurt. Seriously, if you think you have a high spice tolerance, beware. I'm glad I tried it but am more than happy to experiment with something a little less fiery the next time. The sambar and chutneys were tasty, with just the right amount of tang and spice.

For dessert, we split the rasmalai, which was surprisingly not cloyingly sweet. I was tempted to try the Tea-ramisu (with a chocolate-chai sauce, chai-infused rum and paneer), but will save it for next time.

The service was the only letdown - they forgot the dahi vada we ordered and took much longer than expected to bring the food out, given that the restaurant was not packed. Luckily, I was in the mood for a leisurely lunch, but this would have bugged me a lot more under normal circumstances.

Make sure to stop by if you're in the area. Heck, make sure to make a special trip to this area in order to get a taste of South India.
author: Kavita B.

description: Excellent food. All three of us selected the seasonal summer uttapam, with corn, asparagus, and tomatoes - very yummy. Came with two sauces and a chunky potato soup (not my favorite, but certainly fine). We shared the bhal puri (sp) to start, which was delicious and came with two fab sauces. Only two negatives I can mention are: 1)  it took a very long time to get our tap water, after the server tried his hardest to do the upsell on bottled water. 2) there are chairs/stools closely positioned so that it's almost impossible not to brush against other people when exiting and entering your table, as well as along the main walkway to the restrooms and the back of the restaurant.
author: Amalia C.

description:
How does one go about writing the 246th review for a place!

First, the full disclosure - the owner is a friend / former colleague. I will still try to keep the review as real as possible!

Starting with the wait - could be looong, even after you reserve a place. So be prepared.

The place gets packed, so try be as light as possible there i.e leave your bags elsewhere.

The food - definitely the best South India food in the city. If you can't make it all the way to SF, I would suggest trying out Annapoorna in San Mateo for a more real taste. Dosa will get there given enough time.

The utthappam, idli/vada, chutney were all good, and highly recommended.

This was my second visit, having returned from a 30-minute wait at the bar the last time around. Goes without saying, this is a happier visit too.
author: Guru T.

description: I came here with a group of 6 people. I understand that larger groups are occasionally a bit challenging, but the service here was really, really unfortunate. The appetizers were cleared before we were able to finish them. If this was because the main courses were ready, I completely understand. If not, I don't know, but the staff didn't seem to care. My boyfriend ordered a gin and tonic, and was brought something else entirely (it was pink). When the main courses came, mine was delayed for about 10 minutes. It was pretty unfortunate. While I encouraged everyone to start without me, we were rather close to the door and I'm sure the temperature of their food suffered. After a few minutes a member of the waitstaff came over and told me they had forgotten to make mine, so everyone ate. When it did come, it was not actually what I had ordered. I decided to cut my losses. You would think that they would at least comp the main that came out so delayed and incorrect. Nope, no acknowledgment at all. I would guess the wait staff knew they were locked in at a 20% tip and decided not to care. Will have to find an better spot for Indian food.
author: Laura G.

description: Been wanting to check this restaurant out for a really long time. You hear a lot about and for some stupid reason I hadn't been until last week. It was so delicious! I love the little sauces that they give you - so cute and a nice tasty touch. The owner is super cool and passionate about the food. He lived in India for a while and I've gotta say he learned a lot. He does a great job of explaining the food, the region and style of cooking and cares about the ingredients. He talked about how seasonal the food is in India and how the menus are always changing based on what you can buy at the market that day. Quite different than your typical Americanized Indian restaurant. You can see that in their menu - it's always changing. How fun. Really great foodie experience for me.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Went with a party of 4. Ordered 2 appetizers - Dahi Vada and the Calamari. Both were excellent. At first, the yogurty texture of the Dahi Vada makes your tongue do a 360. "SAY WHAT?!" After a few chews and the swallow however, you realize that this dish is delicious and attempt to lick the plate clean. We all enjoyed the beautiful presentation as well, which was reminiscent of a Turkish watercolor. The calamari were not the typical fried variety (poached perhaps?) and came coated in a very original coconut-flavored sauce. Very tender.

For main course, we shared a keema dosa (ground lamb with peas) and the South Indian Moons (variious uttapams). The lamb part was excellent although a little bit small of a portion for 4 people. The uttapams were also very good but I wouldn't say mind-blowing. I think I would have preferred the items that we ordered the first time I came here - the Tamil lamb curry with dosa, and the paneer & peas uttapam.
author: Richard Z.

description: Yum yum yum!  I loved this place and can't wait to go back.  I am a gluten free vegan and often find it difficult to find delicious and interesting food when I go out, however, DOSA was phenomenal!  The food was outstanding, the cocktails were delicious and creative, and there was even a menu guide to help me find if items were, gluten free, dairy free, egg free, or nut free.  What a treat!  I plan on going back for more delicious dosa very, very soon! You guys are rock stars!
author: Michaele K.

description:
All around delicious. My friend and I ordered a couple of dosas, thought that we would still be hungry after but walked away stuffed. The dishes there are packed with flavors and character and definitely worth a visit. 

We also appreciated the friendly service when one of the staff members came by and offered advice on how to properly enjoy our dish since we clearly didn't know what we were doing. He was probably just profiling since we were a couple of white boys that obviously looked intimidated when they brought out the giant dosas but he called that one spot on.
author: David S.

description: love the ambience! great food.great atmosphere..try the cilantro dosa.definitely worth a visit
author: Sucheta P.

description: Dosa on Valencia allows you to have a very different experience than you would have at any other indian restaurant. The ambiance itself gives off an indian/hipster vibe, perfect for the younger generation of indian food buffs. Our waiter was very knowledgable of the menu, and took into consideration what I liked and disliked before he made a recommendation.  I had the "Dahi Vada" as a starter and the "Fennel and Spinach Dosa" as my main course. Both dishes were presented beautifully and tasted just as good. This place is great for having dinner with a date, friends, or with family.
author: Arati M.

description:
Where do I begin? This place blew me away. I came here on my birthday and OH MAN what a good bday dinner it was. Atmosphere, cocktails, incredibly friendly manager (Leo), and just pure awesome food. Everything we ate we loved. It also rates rockstar high for vegetarian & vegan options- I was almost overwhelmed with choice. Only solution is to keep coming back for more ;-) 

I love Indian food but am used to the somewhat heavier-feeling curries and naan bread; Dosa's menu is filled with an amazing array of South Indian cuisine though- which includes different curries, veggie dishes, small plates, rice dishes, uttapam, and-of course- dosas. Come here and get as many dishes as possible and share them. 

As I said, we came here for my bday, and I must have spent about 10 minutes just reading through the front page of the menu- the seasonal tasting page- it all looked so awesome I didn't even think to open up the menu. When I finally did, not only was it filled with more amazing menu items, there was also a card in there. Turns out my mother had given us a gift certificate for drinks (thanks, MA!) and the manager, Leo, had completely taken care of arranging things and had hid the card in the menu. Knowing my mother, I'm sure he spent a fair amount of time making sure her requests were met, and he could not have been any sweeter. Leo came over to our table and was just completely welcoming, friendly, and funny, and went well above and beyond. He even emailed my mom about our meal afterwords- how nice is he??! When there's that much hospitality and attention to detail by the higher-ups in a restaurant, you know you'll be well taken care of. 

But don't get me wrong, I'm not just going with 5 starts because I think their manager is a cool guy- this place hit all my marks food-wise. We started with some of the grilled corn & coconut soup, and OH MY GOD it was delish. Get it, love it. I also particularly liked the seasonal veggie dosa and the summer uttapam. Even the frickin pompodoms were the best I've ever had. Actually, I wish they sold those things.... Anyway, a lot of the dishes (aside from the soup) did have a little spice kick to them, so something to be aware of if you have completely boring-palate friends, but there is enough choice on the menu I think to keep everyone happy.

I can't wait to come back to try more. And hang with my mom's new BFF Leo ;-)
author: Kristen L.

description:
DOSA is generally a good place.
AND it was featured in 7x7's list of Food for Foodies in SF 

SO

a group of friends had pre-planned a backpacking trip that interfered with another friend's birthday (who is a Foodie) - so we thought it'd be great to take him to dinner on that list (it's kinda his thing)

Dinner was good, nothing spectacular, but good.

My one problem was the server. We had booked in advanced, a nice large table, full of people ordering a bunch of food, appetizers and drinks. I reminded the server that it was someone's birthday.

SIDE NOTE: I don't expect restaurants to give away food. However, on someone's bday, in a group setting, ordering lots of food-- I don't think it would hurt the restaurant's financial model to send out a scoop of ice cream or *something* 

OK, so I remind the server that its someone's bday and her bitchy reply was "We don't give away desserts, this isn't Chevy's"

OMG - I was SO irritated by that. She could've said that the restaurant doesn't typically send out any desserts on any occasion and even though that sounds awful - at least it's not RUDE.

The food was good, the waitress was a bitch and we all left with a good inside joke about recommending Chevy's for birthday dinners,
author: Austin P.

description: The Paneer and Peas Dosa was not that great,  but their Chicken appetizer and their lamb entree were really good! The service was average. For the price I paid, I expected the food to be better though.
author: Charles Z.

description: Great food regardless of what you order, but beware of SMALL portions.. Order an appetizer or don't. You can always commandeer someone else's table or chew on your fingernails.
author: Nathan O.

description:
The food here is always good.  However, it's not really authentic South Indian food, and it's definitely more expensive than South Indian food should be.

The plan of the night usually goes:

1) decide that a dosa or some utthappam would be a good meal
2) head into the mission
3) discover that the backlog at  Udupi Palace will last as long as the Mayan calendar
4) walk down the street to Dosa and get a table
author: Jay M.

description:
I have checked this place out 3 times now so I can provide a decent review as far as the food is concerned. They definitely make good looking Dosa's, Idli's and other novel southern Indian cuisine which are difficult to find across San Francisco for some reason courtesy of the huge popularity of northern Indian cuisine. Heck I think they have first mover advantage and that holds them in good stead coz they have a novelty in this city.

As far as the food is concerned, I am not a huge fan, it's sub-optimal, watered down a bit as far as the spices are concerned. I grew up in India, and have tasted the best in length and breadth of Indian cuisine. Dosas are regular food fare for us back in India and humble mobile food vendors can prepare a heck of a dosa that used to leave me smacking my lips and with a full belly. With that perspective, Dosa, a mighty restaurant in San Francisco, barely even compares. By no means, the food is bad, it just isn't fantastic or hitting the same standards of high quality food other Indian restaurants in the city have. The other complain I have that there isn't enough quantity , it is reduced. Dramatically reduced. The size of Idli's should definitely be bigger than the little dots they served me today. The masala in my dosa was about a handful, and left me with a feeling of wanting more in my dinner. 

I have heard people complain that is overpriced but I felt it was priced just right, maybe the lack of quantity leaves one feeling that it is over priced. There is a bar inside and that makes drinking and consuming southern Indian cuisine a rare combination so they get a brownie for that. They haven't gone wrong with the ambience at all, sitting pretty on Valencia street with dim lighting, but they aren't really hitting the high notes either. I have had a bad experience with the service once but I am willing to forego that as a human error, so I am not deducting any points from the rating for service. Their service, otherwise, is fine.

Go to Dosa because you can sample southern Indian cuisine here, which is great, just that this should not be your final destination as far as judging southern Indian food is concerned :)
author: Parijat K.

description: Well you defintey need to make reservations as this place is small, and fills up fast. There's a reason for that though, it's amazing! In the running for my food experience. I had the collard greens and mango dosa, and my friend had the white truffle dosa. Flavors were out of this world~delicious. Will go back for my next special event.
author: J P.

description:
Definitely a date spot. We started with Rose brut and Red Beet Croquettes. A flavorful veggie take on a mix between crab cakes and falafel. For our second course we sampled the South Indian Moons. There were a little too many flavors happening at once in my opinion. The uttapam texture was of a soft pancake. Very filling morsels. We then shared the Seasonal Vegetable Korma, a rich curry similar to a Massaman. Finished the meal with a chai and tangerine sorbet. 
Treated like an Indian princess.

Was encouraged to try Dosa's brunch menu. Curried Bloody Mary's? Who knew...
author: Maureen S.

description:
My sister is visiting me and she was craving Indian food so we dropped in here, Monday night. We were seated promptly, but I'm presuming that was because it was a Monday night.

Our waiter was awesome and never once hurried us, even though we were in late. 

The food was authentic and this is where I need to rant a little about ignorance. Indian food does not mean Vegetarian food (even South Indian food) - I am from South India and I can assure you that I grew up eating a lot of meat and fish. So if somebody tells you that Dosa is not authentic for this reason you can confidently ignore their advice on the matter.

Dosa delivers when it comes to South Indian fare. That being said, the food here is a little pricey and if you are not hell bent on getting your fill of meat then there is always Udupi Palace which serves excellent, authentic vegetarian South Indian fare.
author: Job A.

description:
Dosa I think is for someone who likes spicy food! I went with my friend and our food was just okay, our service was good and so was our drinks, the food was just too spicy for us. I also found the Dosa's to be obnoxious, I mean come on, who needs to eat something that big!! 

If your a spicy lover this is the place for you, but if your not then stay clear!
author: T C.

description: Yum!  I ordered the non-traditional paneer dosa and it was HEAVEN.  Just the right about of spice and flavor and it definitively left me craving for some more.   The service was friendly and the prices are not bad.  Recommended!
author: Neelam P.

description:
Why Yelp a restaurant that over a thousand other people have already evaluated?  Because Dosa has now sourced gluten-free asafoetida--a frequently used Indian spice often ground with just enough wheat to sicken people with celiac disease.  

Gluten-free asafoetida means that we can have the sambar that comes with the dosas and enjoy that gorgeous mint-yogurt starter dumpling thingy and all the many other GF offerings made with asafoetida!

For the medically gluten-free among us, Dosa was always a blessing--a restaurant with a clear allergy menu that uses high-quality ingredients to make wonderful food.  Dosa proved to be a reliable restaurant where I could meet friends and *eat* with them.  That may sound facile--but I've drunk gallons of water and tea while watching others eat.  Having celiac disease can mean you'd better limit your hopes to San Pellagrino.  At other places I've also relied on the assurances of well-meaning waitstaff and wound up being temporarily disabled by illness.  Not so at Dosa.

I have fantasized of celiac minority rule since a rakish restaurant server in Barcelona (Sésamo,C/ Sant Antoni Abat, 52, Ciutat Vella) claimed that almost half the population is celiac.   It ain't true, but his comment made me wonder what a gluten-free world would look like.  

Subsidies for alternative grains? ELISA testing for every milled substance?  Mandatory labeling laws with real penalties?  Being able to simply *eat* without interrogating each ingredient?

And Dosa.  My gluten-free dreamland would feature Dosa and its friendly owner and thoughtful staff and delicious food.
author: S.S. S.

description:
Had to wait about 45 Minutes on a Saturday night. Eh, that's normal. It's Saturday. Tables were pushed a little close together. A little too close together. My poor boyfriend kept getting the waiters butt in his face whenever he served the next table over. He even scooted his chair over to make a point and the waiter just took it to mean he had more room to move around. Ack! Okay, so it made me laugh, but fairly uncomfortable for him...

It was very loud in the restaurant, so very hard to carry on a conversation. I wouldn't recomend it for a first date since it was so lound, but there seemed to be more than one there...

As for the food, very yummers. I love spicy and this was mildly so. Very good. Would like to go again when it's not quite so busy to enjoy it a bit better, without the waiters butt in my boyfriends face. Teehee.
author: Danielle L.

description:
We sit in the bar.  She drinks a glass of wine.  I drink a beer.  The glass is cold.  The air is thick with uncertainty.  Filled to the brim with awkward pauses.  We wait too long for a table. 

We sit.  We wait too long for a waitress.  I scratch at my ear.  She checks her IPhone.  Twice.  After too many minutes we order.  Her starter is an organic asparagus soup.  Me, the mung sprouts salad.  

For entrees, she gets paneer and peas, while I order the paper masala.  More waiting.  Waiting.  I want another beer. Can't find the waitress. Damnit.  

So much time passes.  She makes a snide comment about last night.  I remind her of the time at the movies, that comment she made.  I shake my head, grit my teeth.  The appetizers arrive.  Before I get three bites into my salad, the entree arrives.  I sigh, but I am eager to end the evening.  I eat quickly.  The food is good.  The wait too long. 

The check never comes.  I stand and walk to the cash register. I pay the check.  We walk out the door. The hostess says goodbye.  She is beautiful. 

Outside, the air is cold.  We hug.  Silently.  I turn left and begin to walk.  She waits a moment and then turns right to begin hers.
author: P. William G.

description: They don't seat you even if just one member of your party hasn't shown up. I think it is a ridiculous policy. They should at least instruct the staff to make a call based on the case at hand.
author: Prashant P.

description:
Wow, 4 years later and I'm back again! Came here with a friend for Dine About Town - 4 courses for $35. (You only save $5)

I had the lentil dumplings (delicious), the paneer and peas dosa (pretty big portions), the lamb curry (YUM) and then a dessert. I could not believe how full I was...I ate a few bites of the curry and had to wrap the rest to-go. 

Really filling and delicious meal.
author: Carol L.

description: Do no expect traditional food. Just a bit over priced and the atmosphere is a little inauthentic. But the quality of the food is excellent and they do have dishes there that are hella good. They can be inconsistent though. Good bar.
author: Bantu Z.

description:
We had reservation at 9, but weren't seated till much, much later, as there were several parties that were just taking their sweet (ha!) time eating dessert.  The hostess felt bad so she gave us two free appetizers.  She may or may not have known that at the time, but that bribed them an extra star.

Our table was pretty uncreative with the ordering - we all ordered different versions of the dosa, except one, who ordered the South Indian Moons Uttapam sampler.  All were very good.  Basically, a very filling crepe.  They all came with two chutneys.  The consensus at the table was that the coconut chutney was better, but personally, I liked the tomato one.  The soup that comes with is also pretty spicy so don't forget to take your pepcid ac.

Would I come back again? Well, yes if I don't have to wait close to an hour AFTER our reservation time to be seated.
author: jon y.

description:
Great place.  Highlights include:

- Bengali Gimlet (ideal for the Bengali man)
- South Indian Gin & Tonic (ideal for the Telegu woman)
- Fennel & Spinach Dosa (a solid choice)
- Lamb "Keema" Dosa (very tasty and filling)
- White Truffle Dosa (one of the best flavor combos I've ever had)

Service was friendly and fast.  We had a wonderful experience here.
author: Ananda S.

description:
Always wanted to eat here because I heard good things about this place. Made reservations from open table through yelp just 20 minutes before the reservation time. We got there 10 minutes early, checked in and were immediately seated. I was amazed how quickly we were seated even though there were groups of people standing waiting for a table. Perfect example of open table working brilliantly.

We took a look at the menu and ordered the paper masala dosa, lamb curry, tomato and onion uttapam, and the channa bhatura. Was very surprised everything came out so fast. Our little table for two was literally covered with plates of food. There was barely an inch of free space to move dishes around and pick up my glass of water, but that's a good thing!

Usually when things come out and aren't the right size, they are smaller than expected. But when the paper masala dosa came out I was shocked as to how huge this thin wafer crepe style rolled up like a waffle cone thing was! It literally covered almost half of the table and had both ends of it hanging off of the plate it came on. The dish came with spice potatoes and three dipping sauces to use, one green yogurt, and two red ones. I broke a piece of the wafer and topped it with potatoes and some sauce. It has a nice spiced flavor to it with a good balanced texture of crispiness, mushiness and sauciness. I thought this dish was cool and fun but eating it with my hands got my fingers a little oily. But I liked the comfort to the food. 

Next was the uttapam. It looked like a very thin crust mini pizza but the crust was softer and doughier. The uttapam was very Indian spicy but this dish felt pretty oily as well. Next was the channa bhatura and the lamb curry. The curry was perfect, lamb was sweet and juicy tendery swimming in a well seasoned Indian curry. The channa bhatura was what we dipped in the curry with, but I didn't really enjoy this bread, naan looking thing. It was nice and big but this thing was super oily and my hands were sparkling shiny after breaking this bread. It tasted all right but nothing special. It was so oily that we didn't even want to touch it anymore, we gave up and abandoned more than half of this big thing.

Overall the food was okay, had the Indian spice I was expecting but I did not enjoy the oiliness to most of the dishes we ordered. The service was very good though, fast and responsive.
author: Patrick L.

description:
OK.  So this is a little strange, seeing as I just went to Dosa on FIllmore last night with my husband, then this morning, friends called to invite us to join them at Dosa on Valencia.  While we didn't love love the experience at Fillmore, we figured the food will be good so decided to do a direct comparison of the two sister restaurants.

Boy, what a difference!  I had anticipated a long wait for brunch, especially on Father's day, but we had no problems getting in with 5 in our party.  The place was actually still 1/3 empty.  Compared to Fillmore, Valencia felt much warmer and welcoming.  Off to a good start to our meal.

Service was great -- attentive and we did not feel rushed at all.  Food came out at a good pace this time, and the tables were a good 1/3 larger than those at Fillmore.  We tried the Pani Puri (loved this dish! enjoyed playing with my food -- cracking the little crispy bread, which I destroyed on the first try, and filling it and topping it with the two sauces), Dahi Vada (gorgeous presentation), the South Indian Moons Uttapam (a more filling version of the dosa), Spicay Mung Msala and extra sampling of chutneys.  Had a much better time at this more intimate and less pretentious Dosa.  We will return and definitely prefer this location than Fillmore.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I visited Dosa on Valencia after setting up a reservation via Yelp. My reservation was honored as soon as we stepped in the door. Overall, service was very attentive and considerate.

As for the food, if you're looking for a "standard" indian restaurant, this won't be it. This is southern Indian cuisine, which from what I can tell, differs from what you'd normally expect from a typical Indian restaurant. 

I used the tips on Yelp to guide our menu selections. I had the Chennai Chicken (a well spiced dry fried chicken with yogurt sauce and after thought salad), Dahi Vada (fritters submerged in a mixed yogurt sauce which seemed more like soup than a sauce), and Prawn Masala (shrimp in a dark coconut spice sauce) with coconut rice and Bhatura (a giant ball of bread that you deflate and then enjoy, think of naan but slightly sweeter). 

The Chicken was well spiced but the yogurt sauce could have been slightly more special. Dahi Vada was virtually served cold, refreshing but the yogurt sauce was so overwhelming and excessive that you wouldn't even know that there was a fritter below. I had to ask the waitress to clarify what dish it was. The Prawn Masala was the most tasty item I tried and matched especially well with the coconut rice. Even though it was very enjoyable, it was extraordinarily salty, to the point that it left my palate tired. The Bhatura was very soft and enjoyable. 

Service is fast and the fourth star is mostly for that. The food is good, but not as earthy and comforting like most higher end indian restaurants. It's as gourmet as the restaurant is decorated. Good alcohol selection!

I will say that I doubt I'll be returning for some time.
author: Julio E.

description:
The way people portray this place is as if Anna-freaking-purna, the Hindu goddess of food, is going to come down and appear on the plate or cook your dosa herself.  It's not as if the food isn't good, but not mind-blowingly amazing or anything like that.  

Bad news first: 
- I didn't care for the pepper chicken, which was a bit one note in its spiciness for me.  
- the prices. they don't give you much food for the amount of food that you get (er, more like - don't get, I should say).

What I did like:
- pairings - they tell you what goes well with each main entree, such as the rice or bread options.  v. smart. 
- friendly staff 
- constant refill on water, which is also v. smart in an indian restaurant. 

Maybe I'm more used to northern Indian cuisine, but Dosa isn't bad.  Worth a try.
author: S K.

description: Delicious food. We ordered a number of plates and especially loved the Broccolini Dosa.
author: Jaime L.

description:
My GF's been on an Ice Cream kick lately and insisted we make our way to the mission for dinner as an excuse to get Bi-rite for desert.  Being avid Indian food fanatics, we agreed on Dosa and we were both blown away.  

Dosa is not like any other Indian food we've had before.  Almost every Indian restaurant we've had up until now has focused primarily on Tandoori BBQ, Curry, Basmati, Naan, etc. You won't find any of those at Dosa...  They specialize in South Indian cuisine, which centers on Dosa flat breads and Uttapans.  

We started with the Dahi Vada appetizer which was superb.  It was this beautifully presented dish of Lentil dumplings infused with organic yogurt, tamarind, mint, and other spices.  It tasted wonderful; very flavorful and a moderate sized portion for two people.

Next was our Spinach and Paneer Jumbo Prawn curry with coconut rice - the one dish that reminded me of other Indian restaurants I've had before.  Essentially it was an Aloo Palak dish with shrimp.  It was OK, better than fast food Indian places such as Naan & Curry.  However, it wasn't as fresh and tasty as Sultan's spinach Curry.  Out of everything we ordered, I was least impressed with this dish.

Our last dish was a classic Masala Dosa.  We've never had Dosa's before so we didn't know which one to order.  Thus our decision to start with the Classic (apparently the tried and truest).  I was amazed at how large this was.  The plate itself was huge, and our half moon shaped Dosa spilled out at least six inches past either side of the plate.
