It was filled with spiced Potatoes and cashews, similar to what you'd find in a Samosa.  The Dosa's come with 3 dipping sauces, all of which are delectable.  One is a creamy one that tastes pretty garlicky; another is one that reminds me of a vegetable soup.  The third one, my favorite, was a fresh tomato based puree that was cold and reminded me of a blended Salsa.

Our dinner was fantastic and was a pleasant introduction to South Indian Cuisine.  We will definitely be back again and again to try the other Dosa's and Uttapans that all sounded amazing.  I hope Dosa is a catalyst to a new wave of South Indian restaurants; I haven't seen any others around. I'd highly recommend you check this place out.
author: Timothy C.

description:
Not bad.. nothing that great either..
They have a good selection of dosas and other indian things..
the vada pav's were pretty good by america standards i guess..
i personally felt it was too mildly spiced and delicately made to be close to the real thing..
author: Aditya M.

description:
To all the business owners on yelp who have bad reviews about their service, spend a couple of hours in this place to learn about good service. The wait time maybe anywhere from 30 mins to 1 Hr on a weekend, but once you get your table, the service is impeccable. 

Coming to the food, this was the most authentic South Indian food I have had after a long time. I do not mind paying $$$$ as long as the food and service is good like this place.
author: Nirmal S.

description:
I loved the dahi vada we had here. I had a south india plate which was good. I was too full to try anything. It's a small place. 
They need better restrooms, the two small ones were always occupied by parents changing diapers on their kids, while I stood out waiting for 20 mins to wash my hand.
author: Aravind S.

description: The bartender taught me how to say UTTAPAM, what what! So of course I had to order the masala uttapam. It reminded me of a Korean pancake, or a Chinese green onion pancake (that was the consistency of it anywho). It was nice that they told you which sauces were which for dipping and how to eat it (you know, being a n00b and all). Also ordered the chennai chicken as recommended by the bartender (forgot to mention that I sat at the bar for dinner). The dish looks small but it's worth it because it's so good.
author: Lily Z.

description:
came here to celebrate a girl friends bday. we're both craving for Indian food so I found this in Yelp.

parking in Valencia is always a pain.  I used to live around the area so I expected to take a few turns around the block before I found a spot.

The place was clean and very cozy.  I liked the dark lights and the color.

Our server was specially helpful in recommending what to eat and describing the food.  Thank God!
We ordered:
 mango seed for our drinks.  good but needed more booze.
for apps- cochin calamari with phoori (as recommended by the server) and it was good... I was hoping for the regular fried calamari but this one didn't make me miss the old fried ones.

for Entrees: Kerala chicken with lemon rice--really good, Tamil lamb curry - love it! and Rava Masala Dosa --good but too much potatoes.

for dessert:  coconut tapioca with pineapple and passion fruit--really good and rich, also cheesecake -- eh.. it was okay.

their coffee was good too.

All in all our experience was pleasant.
Would love to come back again.
author: Learnee L.

description:
An upscale dosa place! I had dosas in countless number of places not excluding some amazing street food fare. and was slightly skeptical as to how the humble dosa can be turned classier. 

We order the all time fav, classic masala dosa. The sambar that it came with it was exceptional! I mean, having practically grown up on the staple sambar, this version managed to stand out and it still had the authentic South Indian feel to it. Three cheers to that! The dosa and the potato masala were good, nothing remarkable though.

My dining partner was in an adventurous mood and decided to order the harbanero dosa. The hostess tried to warn us and even got a sample of the harbanero sauce so that we can decide before we ordered, but he was hell bent on getting it. Anyway. it turned out to be way too spicy for me and this is coming from a person who is used to a lot of heat in the food, so beware!

We also had the spring vegetable curry and batura to go with it. Some the vegetables listed under the curry description are not typical "curry" veggies but the dish was awesome ! and the batura was the perfect side for it even though batura typically goes with chole curry (hence the name choley bature)

On the whole we enjoyed the experience. This place is of course more than just the dosa and we might order something else the next time.
author: Minu M.

description:
Really cool affordable and trendy indian restaurant!
First time I had a Dosa and Uttapams. The service was great and the waitress was very helpful in recommending the popular dish. I had the Lamb Dosa (heavenly marinated lamb meat) and the South Indian Moons Uttapams (great sample option of different Uttapams). The dish didn't look like they would be filling but little did I know I would come out feeling heavy.
author: Christian P.

description: I love this location..great service,great food, beautiful newly remodeled restaurant! I always get the Masala dosa,and chicken Chennai. Maybe I'm boring, but I crave these!
author: Shelley M.

description:
I went again for dinner at Dosa after three years of doing mostly brunch. I encountered the same hostess that I criticized in my previous review. This time he was very professional and courteous. My dining experience was perfect as it has always been. I finally gave Dosa the five stars for two great vintage items that are back in the menu after several years of absence:

1. The delicious potato crocket. However, it probably has more peas than in the past. 

2. The chai dessert. Although it would be optimal if you could bring the caramel chai cheesecake dessert by itself. 

The new dosas are also outstanding, especially the cauliflower and spinach one. Good job in the new menu!

Brunch as always remains outstanding.
author: Ato B.

description:
Decor: dim lighting, and modern with high ceilings.

Few tables by the window, large bar, and a few more larger tables towards the back.

Service: friendly

We didn't have any reservations and got in during dinner time so we opted to sit at the bar instead of waiting for a table to become available (everyone had reservations).

We ordered:

Tikka masala dosa-delish!

Spinach prawn with paneer-I LOVED the spices in this dish.  This is the second restaurant that I've ever tried that executed this dish perfectly.  This dish won me over.

Bhatura with cholle-it was so good!

Tahari rice (?)-It was refreshing and a good palate cleanser between each dish.

We had a little bit of everything left over and they packed everything up in small little containers for us.  I was pleasantly surprised when I opened the bag up at home :)

My only complaint is the price.  I guess I'm just use to the prices at Viks.  But I guess you're paying for the decor and full service.  It's a great place for a date night, but make sure you have reservations.
author: Michelle S.

description:
I really enjoyed my meal here. The flavors were authentic and the service was efficient. I liked the wine list as well. 

My only complaints are the noise (It was Sat. night), and the prices. Every thing was just a little too pricey for what you get. Since the place was packed with a wait, I guess no one else minds.
author: Robert M.

description:
very cute interior decor (great date ambience) and very friendly and professional service (our waitress spent a while explaining the difference between a dosa and uttapam and how to eat them...haha).

The "chips" served in the beginning (pappa's?) were DELICIOUS and my cilantro mint dosa looked like a giant crepe with two chutney dips and a soupy dip. so good, so filling, so impossible to finish by myself.

I wouldn't recommend taking dosa's to go because they get soggy...breakfast next morn = soggy crepes with cold dips. heh.

bonus: they have a huge selection of drinks! including european beers I've never heard of
author: Serena W.

description: I've been here twice and the food is good.  That said, I think eating here once is enough.  Why?  Because, kind of like Taco Bell, you can order all the different things, but once you get down to it most of it tastes pretty similar to all the other things on the menu.  The tasting menu is a good way to explore a few various dishes and leave feeling like you just ate a house.  Upon a second visit, you realize you can order different varieties of plates, but they all come with the same dipping sauces, flavors and basic preparations.  Lastly, I know this is upscale Indian food, but some of their interpretations of classic dishes just made me end up wanting the classic dish instead.  But that's just me.
author: e w.

description:
M.E.H! First off, the restaurant was way too loud. It was almost impossible to carry on a conversation without yelling into the other person's ear. We went on a Saturday around lunch time, so maybe you would have better luck during the week. Also, the guy at the door called my fiance and his male friend "ladies". I guess because they have long hair? Maybe he corrected himself and I couldn't hear it because the restaurant was so freaking loud...that was truly baffling. 

Me? I like spicy food. No, I love spicy food. No, I have a chemical dependence on spicy food, so naturally I ordered the item on the menu that had  "warning" next to it. It seemed like the waitress was trying to discourage me from ordering the mango-habanero dosa. She kept saying "It's really spicy. Some people [i.e. White people] find it inedible". This, of course, made me want it twice as much. 

It was pretty spicy but I wasn't perspiring and I didn't have the delightful runny nose that lets me know that my endorphins are flowing from all that capsaicin. I mean, I know I'm a dainty little white-lily of a girl but I can eat some pretty spicy stuff. This dosa was not impressive.

Also, I don't enjoy coconut chutney. It's really too sweet for my taste. My friend seemed to really enjoy it so I will say it's a matter of personal taste. I, personally, like my chutney with a little tang and acid in it. I don't want my Indian food to smell like a macaroon. bleh. 

This place was too pricey, not enough food--and I don't even have a very high standard for Indian joints...meh.
author: Stephanie G.

description: This place is on the pricey side for Indian food but the food is delicious. I love the masala dosa, and have a hard time ordering anything else because I enjoy it so much. The ambience is very chic, which makes it a great date destination. On weekends, I definitely recommend reservations to avoid a long wait!
author: Diana G.

description:
Visited from NY. Just loved the food.
The dosa was great but my favorite was Dahi vada
author: Karthik S.

description:
What a wonderful evening!  After meeting an interesting young man at Trigger and waiting for 2 weeks to re-connect, we decided to finally meet up for dinner at Dosa in late March to pop my Dosa cherry. *LOL*

We wandered into the Mission on a Friday night, put our names on the waiting list and only waited about 20 minutes for a table.They gave us a very nice 2 seat tale near the window, which was perfect for people watching and also for conversation.  I've read various reviews that indicate the noise level can be high, but we didn't have any difficulty carrying on a conversation over the rumbling of the interior.  

We shared the Chicken Masala Dosa and Tamil Lamb curry with the lemon rice.  It was a perfect family style type dinner.  The food was adequately spiced and the portion size large enough to share.  Most importantly, the restaurant was clean and the staff were pleasant.  The price range was higher than most Indian restaurants that I've been to, but was worth it.  Would offer the cost of the meal, but he offered to pay for my meal and wouldn't let me see the bill (awww...what a gentleman)... *blush*

I would go back again, soon.

Parking in the area can be hit or miss.  This is close to a BART station and plenty of cabs in the area.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
What $75 will get me:
           
A.  size 2 LBD that makes me look like a heifer
B.  size 6 round toe [5 incher] pumps that almost made me plummet to my grave
C.  10 packs of cigarettes + a handful of colorful lighters
D.  2 course meal @ DOSA + wine

Which one would I gladly refund?

ALL OF THE ABOVE.
author: Lisa W.

description:
After hearing all the raves about this dosa place, i finally tried it during my birthday.

I'll have to say the food was good, the habanero dosa, a good tasty spice. I was rather dissapointed in the staff. Even after having a reservation, still took us 1.5 hours to get our table, and the staff just rushed us through our dinner like no ones business. I was not happy. I may try again, but this time i'll see if the FIllmore is any better.
author: Alnadi P.

description:
I came here for a private UYE put together by Daniel L and Maybelline C. When I showed up I looked around and didn't see people I recognized so I told the hostess that I was there with a big group, she asked, "do you mean the yelp group", so much for anonymity. I've put off writing my review because I have no idea if we got the typical dining experience. 

I was hesitant to come here because I was under the impression that this place was strictly vegetarian, I think it used to be, but when I'm invited to meet some of my favorite yelpers for lunch I get over my aversion to vegetarian food quickly.

I've had lots of Indian and Pakistani food but have never had food like this before. I don't even know what to call most of the things I ate so forgive me for using the wrong terms.

We had two styles of these little empty crust balls filled with stuff. I liked the ones that came filled by the restaurant but the ones we had to fill ourselves were too complicated; this is far too delicate a task to expect your customers to be able to do. We had other appetizers but they didn't really make an impression.

I found the menu baffling. For my entree I asked the waitress to bring me the spiciest thing they have. She said anything could be made spicy so I asked for the chicken curry, which was the only meat dish available. Even though I ordered it spicy it came fairly bland, they gave me a sour tasting chutney to spice it up but I didn't think the flavor complimented the curry. I also tried a giant crepe thing with ground up potatoes in it that Cassie ordered, it was interesting but bland and lacking something, meat would have made it much better.

This might be an excellent crust ball and Indian crepe place for all I know but I didn't particularly like the food and I thought the prices were high for what we got.
author: Manny F.

description: What a find! Excellent service and very authentic, yet CA creative food. Its delicious and comfortable. The decor and environment was also very good.
author: Ashish D.

description:
HAPPY NEW YEAR, Yelpers!!
I'll add here what I said at midnight on January 1st:  "THANK GOD 2009 is OVER!"  That was one rough year (for me).

2010 is already much better!  

On the last evening of 2009, however, I did get a very pleasant surprise by having dinner at Dosa.  For NYE dinner, they had a fixed menu costing $80 per person for four courses.  Our table of four chose wisely to get a taste of virtually everything.

First, it was great that we got there on time and our table was ready for us -- no waiting!  

Second, from the moment you enter the door, service was phenomenal.  A woman, who I later found out was the owner's wife, was naturally fantastic, but the hostess as well as servers were also very pleasant.

Third, the food was all-around terrific.  I was seriously impressed with the escarole (soup), and the first two courses were amazing - including the Dosa dish (I ordered the paneer and peas one - delicious!).  The curry (3rd entree) was very good but I didn't feel it was as "special" as the first two.  The dessert was hit or miss.  The dough bread we ordered was really not good, but the coconut ice cream dessert was out of this world!

They have a green mint (spicy) sauce that I could seriously drink by the bowl. It basically made every dish taste even better.  Spicy as hell - just the way I like it.

It's great food, so I give it 4.5-stars.  It's about the only "Indian" restaurant in SF that I really enjoyed, so thumbs up.  Factor in the service and great wine - and I am rounding up to 5 whole stars for Dosa.  

That said, while it hovers close, it's STILL not the amazing Indian I have come to expect through home-cooked meals or Indian restaurants in Europe.  It's a tiny little step below that - ahhh, I miss Dublin, London, and Amsterdam.  

As a sidenote, I scored parking on NYE at 7:30 in the evening in the Mission, RIGHT in front of the restaurant.  

In any case, I highly recommend Dosa as a dining venue.  It's great for a business dinner, but also nice for a date.  

And pick the Bucklin Zinfandel - - that wine was outstanding.

After all was said and done - the dinner came to $500 including the tip (four people, four courses each, and two bottles of wine).  I suspect it would have been significantly less on a regular night (since we also would most likely not order four courses), but we were all impressed and awfully full as we took off to formally bring in 2010.
author: Grace K.

description: Second visit to Dosa but first time to the Valencia location.  Restaurant is much smaller than Fillmore location. It was very crowded and restaurant had great energy.  The service was very good. The food was excellent. Really enjoyed the pumpkin dosa. The red beet soup was interesting but not sure I would order again. The three course menu is a great option and spice levels are different depending on what you order and our server was very helpful explaining the flavors. Our guests from Texas loved the food so we were very pleased.
author: Greg B.

description:
One for the dosa. 
Two for the host-a (-ess). 
Three for the space. 

Not four for the waitress fallen out of grace. 
Nor five for the "base" that was really just tomato paste. 

Came here for NYE dinner for the posh-y, fun ambiance and great mission location. Hostess was friendly and we were seated promptly at our reservation time (a first here!). As we weren't particularly starved enough to go full-four-frontal prix fixe with the built-in prosecco, we opted to order off the a la carte menu instead, forgoing the dessert and upselling on the bubbly. 

Waitress, assuming we were ordering a la carte for price-point reasons, "Are you sure you don't want to just order the prix fixe? I think it'd be cheaper."

Huh? No, I don't want dessert and it's NYE, I want a distinctive bottle of sparkling shiraz, not something I can find easily at any local Safeway, but "yeah, okay, sure, you can check on that" (knowing full-well that our shared starters, dosa, entree each, and wine would wind up just shy of what the prix fixe would have cost). She doesn't come back.

The starters -- chicken croquettes and halibut pakora -- were solid and the dosa were as fantastic as they've been any other night I've had them. 

The mains, though. Oh, the mains. I know what to expect and you did **not** deliver. Flavors masked by an excessive amount of heat (and yes, I have a high tolerance), skimpy on the meat, and the mango prawns? Two pieces of mango, three shrimpy prawns, and tomato paste, with sugar.

To our waitress walking past, "Excuse me, yeah, hi, hello?! Ummm, we've really enjoyed the starters and dosa, but the mango prawns..." *pointing to untouched plate* "taste like canned Ragu..."

"Oh, well, you see, it's a tomato base." Nada else. No apology. Check please. Full check, apparently. Upscale places normally don't compromise return business in favor of sticking the full bill to a dissatisfied customer. I guess Dosa does.

Needless to say, much like the canned tomatoes, the experience left me with a tinny taste in my mouth.
author: Claire Q.

description:
YUM, paneer and peas.
A little on the loud side.
Very nice service.
author: May T.

description:
I give it a 2 star rating, because truly, I've experienced better! Dosa is for Caucasians. 

Growing up, I don't remember my granny decorating a bowl of sambar like these guys do. Ok, so even if I ignore the fancy, pretentious presentation,the Tapas like ambiance and trendy decor and all that - the food is not tasty. 

Sure, a dosa fills you up - and it should! The dosa batter is made from rice and white lentils, which is protein (that's why so many Hindu vegetarians eat lentils and rice for every meal). But don't be mislead that their dosa is great/good and that's why you're feeling full! 

The only thing Dosa has going is that it's the only (well, if you ignored Udupi) upscale, South Indian place in the city.

It's like this: on a holiday in Nevada, I could go to a Denny's and order eggs and toast, pay them the basic price and leave. OR, I could go to a fancy, upscale diner, order the same stuff, but pay $13.95 - for the fancy plates/flatware, the ambiance and other stuff. 

P.S: Dosa on Fillmore is thriving thanks to your money - you paid him & her that extra money for another fancy Dosa place......that lease is all because of you and your generosity :)
author: Me Iz S.

description:
FOOD & SERVICE:
The dahi papdi chaat was the best dahi papdi chaat I've ever eaten (I'm an Indian, I go to a lot of authentic hole-in-the-wall places).  Also ordered a mango lassi, it was too creamy for me (had the texture of melted ice cream).  

I have to take off three stars for the completely inedible dosa and service response though.  I ordered a habanero chilli dosa.  I'm from Andhra Pradesh, the region of India that's known for chilli dosas (I've had many of them in my life, and I make dosas at home).  Spice is meant to enhance taste, not overpower what you're eating.  They had put so much of habenero chili on the dosa that it became COMPLETELY inedible.  And I have VERY high spice tolerance, I put red pepper flakes and Sriracha hot sauce on everything.  I also got annoyed that when I complained (they said the spice varies depending on the chilli season), they offered raita (yogurt) - but didn't tell us they were going to charge for it!  

The dosa had the correct texture and consistency, so props for that. But everything on their menu should be edible, and the habanero chili dosa most definitely was NOT.  I ended up paying $20+ and barely eating anything.  

If you want the same dosa for a fraction of the price, there's a ton of hole-in-the-wall places I'd rather recommend.  Or ask your token Indian friend to cook you one.  Don't come here for the dosa.

I personally am never coming here again.

AMBIENCE:
It was what you'd expect from a fine-dining place, a tad on the small side.
author: Bee M.

description:
i really don't understand why this place is so popular. Dosa is PRETENTIOUS, totally unauthentic, overpriced, crowded, loud and utterly overrated. It's basically a trendy, expensive American restaurant that happens to serve southern Indian-inspired food. I guess it makes this kind of food accessible to unadventurous Americans .... but do they deserve it? Dosa is like the Medjool of Mission restaurants ... you'll never catch a local here, but it's always packed with people from other parts of the city who don't know any better.  

Well I do know better. There are two MUCH better restaurants on the same block.  Udupi Palace just across the street has basically the same food menu as Dosa, except it's like, actually Indian, 1/3 the price, 3x the flavor, and the waiters don't treat you like you're an ignoramus who can't possibly have had this kind of food before.  Aslam's Rasoi is Pakistani/northern Indian (so, totally different menu) but a way better restaurant.
author: Cassandra W.

description: I love this place. Everyone is so friendly. The service is excellent. The wine and food pairing totally gets the taste buds satisfied. Delicious, fresh and tasty with the delicately balanced spices in all the dishes.
author: Diana M.

description:
Let me start by saying that I have historically not been a fan of Indian food.  In fact, I've only had it once in my life (most likely due to pre-conceived notions I have of this type of food).  All of my former opinions are now out the door, due to the fantastic meal I had at Dosa!  As a vegetarian and someone who loves spicy food, I absolutely loved my meal at Dosa on Valencia.  

We ordered the vegetarian sliders, spicy mung masala dosa and vegetable curry.  The flavors were amazing and I can't wait to go back!  The service was impeccable too.

I highly recommend going with reservations, as the space is not large and you may have to wait otherwise.  I've also now been to Dosa on Fillmore, which I think happens to have a better ambience (and the same menu), but because this one is quite close to where I live - I think this will do just fine :)
author: Rachel G.

description:
This is far from authentic Indian food. Sadly, it's also far from good South Indian food.

We went in for dinner on a Sunday evening and were glad to be seated quickly. We ordered a bunch of different dosas, which came in with the samber burning hot - way too hot to be edible. Unfortunately, that doesn't work well with soggy dosas, as waiting for the samber to cool only makes them soggier. We were famished though, so we ate for the sake of eating.

I'd say skip this place and go next door instead. The only positive - a really great wait staff!
author: Vishal A.

description:
From the people I know, there are three camps when it comes to Dosa:

Camp 1: I think Dosa is delicious and worth the money.

Camp 2: I think Dosa is delicious but South Indian food should not cost this much.

Camp 3: Udupi Palace is better.

I am in Camp 1, I can understand Camp 2, I disagree with Camp 3.  Every time I go to Dosa, I think "Wow, this is pretty delicious."  Every time I go to Udupi Palace, I think "This is better at Dosa, but it's cheaper here."

My good friend from Madras made the comment that the cooks from Dosa are actually from South India, while the cooks from Udupi Palace are not.  She also likes Dosa better.  I trust her (as well as my own taste buds).

As a Korean, I have an aversion to higher priced / fancier Korean places, so I can see why Dosa has its detractors.  But sometimes the fancier places have better food, which is what I think is the case here.
author: David C.

description:
YUM YUM YUM. I'll be back. 
Great service, friendly staff and awesome food.
author: Heather L.

description:
Sorry, not nearly as impressed as most reviewers or so many of my friends.

I don't give stars for trendy decor alone and the food is not too special, aside from its price.

After waiting 20 minutes outside of the joint for my reservation to be available, the two of us spent $50 on preciously small and disappointing dishes.  Finally, we left and had burritos.

Recommended alternatives:
For upscale Indian, try Amber India on Market.
For Southern, try Udupi Palace on Valencia.  On the peninsula, don't miss Annapoorna in San Mateo.
author: Thomas K.

description:
If not for Dosa's sambar and fortunate beer selection, I'd have given the place 2 stars. Unlike 97% of restaurants, the sambar wasn't watery and tasted right (even by my South Indian dinner date's standards). Her food wasn't memorable. My habanero-mango masala dosa was a concoction I hadn't previously tried. The cooks did a good job with it, and my tongue appreciated it. 

One odd observation--Dosa appeared as one of those Indian restaurants where the majority of the patrons are white or otherwise non-Indian. Maybe we caught it at an odd time?
author: Chucky P.

description:
So, I've had family raving to me about how great this restaurant was, and after reading reviews of this place,. I had to try it because I love indian food. 

The chicken chennai is good and the lamb curry was good too but not so much so that I would rave about it for days and tell all my closest friends that they have to eat there. 

The dosa was eh. And for eating a 10 pound sack of potatoes which you will never be able to work off in a gym, you want the dish to be exquisite. and it was okay. Not special. 

Lastly, for however good the food was, we paid for it afterwards. We were not that turned off upon leaving, but my boyfriend and I were bed-ridden for three days afterwards with food poisoning. 

So the foods okay, but eat at your own risk. 


The service was probably the best part of our visit. That's the only positive I could take out of our experience.
author: Naura T.

description: Superb food! Great host. He went out of his way to make my parents comfortable and gave Jain food.
author: Bhavik M.

description:
A solid place for Indian food in the mission, and the interior is nice, but the tables are really close together and the space is pretty cramped.

I think this place is a little too hyped up since I've had better Indian food at a better price, but if you're in the mood for Indian, this is a definite viable option.

We ordered the lamb curry and the masala dosa with coconut rice and a couple of glasses of wine.  The food was tasty and more than enough for two people so I'll probably stick to the smaller plates, if it's just a party of 2 next time.
author: Sarah C.

description:
This is the second time to this restaurant in 3 weeks.  We BART in to see a Broadway show and pick a restaurant accessible to BART.  DOSA is a few blocks away.

I love the paper Dosa's.  For something spicy try the hibernation sauce.  A warning the sauce is very very hot, it literally will ruin your meal if you are not careful.  Order it on the side.  Last night we both offered the Winter vegetarian meatballs.  These probably wont last too much longer on the menu.  Delish!  The coconut rice with the meatballs left me wanting more.  For desert it was the chestnut mousse cake.  As long as that desert will be on the menu we will order it.

Reservations are highly recommended, if you don't have one go when it first opens.  We prefer the DOSA on Valencia it's much more cozy and they have the habernaro  sauc.
author: Kathy N.

description:
Run, don't walk to Dosa.

This is an amazing place with wonderful food and great service.  What I really appreciated were the modern touches to traditional dishes.  Not only is the food yummy but it is served with a sense of flair and service that is all too hard to find at other Indian restaurants.  Bravo team.
author: M V.

description: Very rarely do you come across a joint which gives you honest to goodness authentic food and add their own charm to it....These guys have done it ...Love their shammi's, spicy chutneys, Tried their Kale Dosa, yum.....
author: Arindam B.

description:
Dosa took me deep into the foggy forests of Nilgiri Hills and the sunny Western Ghats today. All with a fried fiddlehead fern appetizer.

Brought my Brazilian "nephew" here after visiting the Museum of African Diaspora's abstract expressionist exhibit. It was a warm day, so we sat up front by the sliding window and enjoyed the breeze and the action on Valencia.

As always, we were warmly greeted and started out with mild fried pappadam. Growing up, our supply was shipped to us my my granny who made them herself. My mom always heated these over a flame and they were charred and uneven. She only ever fried them for company - so when I come here and eat the fried pappadam, I get to be company! They are also a lot milder.

My Rio beer drinking nephew tried a Rasputin beer which came in a tall German style glass, and we took advantage of the Happy Hour prices - $6 for a plateful of batter fried seasonal veggies ( also something we only ever made for company) and bite sized chennai chicken which was spicy and delicious. Two spicy appetizers followed by a third - the cool and tangy sweet artistically presented dahi vada (yes, yes, another company dish), and my belly was filled.

I have never had fiddle head ferns and associate them with upscale restaurants that only cook what grew in the forest that day. So it was a real delight to find them in South Indian food - not South Indian, but very seasonal to NoCalif, and SEASONALITY is a South Indian tradition. My mom's cooking was always varied and depended on what was in season, and that playfulness was a delight to find in something as low priced as Happy Hour. Three large appetizers at $6 apiece and $4 beers is a steal.

I always get the impression that great thought goes into the menu because it stays playful and seasonal. Masala Fiddlehead Ferns? Spice in the forest? The South Indian Forest? It could happen. They were warm, rich, crunchy, soft  and spiral shaped. Fried in masala batter, they are a vast improvement on boring onion pakora. Well done, Dosa!
author: Nan L.

description: I tried their truffle dosa which had a nice distinct truffle flavor. Nothing overpowering, just pleasantly unusual n novel. We also tried the vada pav which was non traditional but absolutely divine. I was a little naively sceptical about how their take on the good ole vada pav would turn out but I was blown away. The menu is slightly different from the menu at the fillmore location. The ambience is very pretty n has Indian artifacts which I adore.
author: Natasha I.

description:
Fabulous food. There are a bunch of other places you can go for just as good of dosas that are much cheaper, but they are in South Bay...not as fun to go to obviously...so location to dollar factor = minus one star.

The place is small and the people are numerous so one does get a pretty good "Am I in India?" experience.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
The extent of my Indian food consumption had been curries and naan so it was great to try something new. I got the dosa and uttapam. Both were flavorful, with good textures, but the three dipping sauces kind of muddled all the flavors together and everything tasted about the same. I liked the texture of the dosa which had more of a crispness, but the uttapam was a little too dense for me. 

The best part - complimentary lentil chips! They are so incredibly light and crispy - mmmm. The waitress was even so nice as to give us a paper bag full to take home! How nice.
author: Elaine L.

description: One of my first Indian experiences that was top notch, from the drinks to the dinners my mouth was never happier and afterwards I felt so full of good food I was sooo relaxed. Even the staff was super nice, this place is my new favorite spot, check it out!
author: sarah m.

description: The place has a very nice ambience. The dosas are yummy! It's a little pricy, but it's worth it!
author: Sathya M.

description: I won a cost savings contest at work, so got a gift certificate from Dosa as a prize.  Thought this was the same restaurant from "Check Please Bay Area," but that was the Fillmore location.  Very convenient parking garage around the corner, in a difficult parking neighborhood.  Ambiance was very cool, and I've heard the Fillmore restaurant is even cooler.  Service was good.  Have to give mad props to the bartender!  I had a peony and ginger ante.  YUM!  Thank god my daughter was double D that night, cos' I was really feeling those cocktails.  Basically we pigged out:  A couple of dosas, uttapam, dahi vada, okra pakora.  Everything tasted really good and fresh.  My family is more into traditional Northern Indian, so wasn't as into this Indian cuisine, but if it's Indian, I love it!  Most definitely want to try the Fillmore street Dosa restaurant the next time!
author: Marie B.

description: Went to this awesome place last Thursday, food was incredible!  While waiting for our table we checked out the drink menu, we found an option to choose "Aareem Se" which translates to relax, and in this instance let our bartenders create you something.  They did not disappoint with any of the creations.    We started with sauteed Cochin calamari, chennal chicken and the chili and onion pakora.  All 3 were awesome, we also sampled 7 different dishes from the menu, everything was fabulous!  Highly recommend Dosa!
author: Megan S.

description: Do not buy Gift Certificates from this restaurant. I submitted a gift certificate request (with my credit card information on it!) on April 2nd. After numerous attempts to reach them to find out when they would process it, I have still not seen or heard from them. This is now 2.5 weeks after I submitted the form. Every time I call, I either am tossed to an automated voice mail or my information is written down, and they still don't call.
author: Katie N.

description: I am an Indian guy and I have never seen an Indian restaurant as awesome as this. Had Mozhi (kerala fish curry) with rice and also ordered a red wine. It was fantabulous. Its cool to hear the american waitress saying indian cuisine (like mozhi) perfectly. Totally loved the ambience. Good place for dating.
author: Venkatesh S.

description:
finally! been starring at this place and hearing about it and walking by it.

asparagus soup is excellent. beet is good, but not as good.

the vegan naan is purti? or something
huge puff ball of fried bread thats hollow. cool!

vegan chick pea curry and vegan veggie curry with coconut rice are excellent

pricey, but typical for nice indian food.
cool cocktails, but no liquor. made with sparkling wines, etc.
author: Samantha S.

description:
My mouth waters just at the thought of this restaurant. I had a date here 2 months back, and I still think about it every week. The Pre Fixe menu is wonderful, I recommend any chicken or seafood dish. The portions are just right, enough to satisfy the taste buds, but leave you wanting the next course. 

The atmosphere is beautiful with candles, lovely modern decor, and very helpful staff. 

Even while sitting at the bar, the place still has an intimate feel.
author: E B.

description:
If one is familiar with this cuisine it is impossible to eat at Dosa without having nagging feelings of being ripped off by a bad value.  The food is fine, but equal to better quality food can be found in quite pleasant settings (e.g., Dasaprakash in Santa Clara) in the Bay Area at one fourth to one third the price of Dosa.  So, if I am going to spend $120 for dinner here, it's impossible not to think that I could be getting just as good of food in a lovely setting back home in Silicon Valley for $30-$40.  
  Other gripes include:
1) the $15 beer flight consisted of three, quite small glasses of beer (seemingly beer "samples" rather than beer, perhaps 6 oz servings).  Really, about $2 worth of beer for $15?? A complete rip off, it would be a bad value at half the price. 
2) Some of the courses are more food art than food, e.g., the seafood Vada first course looked very pretty, but the food was literally two bites (each Vada comes out the size of the 25 cent piece).  
3) the waiters are constantly trying to clear plates regardless of whether everyone one else at our four person table had finished less than half their portion.  Efficiency if fine, but this felt pushy.
   In sum, if value is of absolutely no importance to you, eat here anxiety free.  However, if value is even of some importance, you will experience a meal filled with nagging frustration.
author: William F.

description: I've been to both the Fillmore and Valencia locations and both times I've had a great time. The food is unique and delicious  and since I have gluten and dairy issues they officer a menue that helps me easily navigate safely through my options. I also have to give the service top marks. I was a server for years in the city so I consider myself especially picky but they've given me nothing to pick at since both the bartenders and the servers are friendly and competent.
author: Michael W.

description: Hip scene, great food if this is the region of Indian food you're into.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Went there last night for my moms bday. The food is just incredible. There is a dumpling plate that is just a taste of heaven. The coconut/cardimum gelato is a must have.
It's a little crowded but that SF.
author: Nick T.

description:
For the prices charged, I would really only say that the food I had at Dosa was "OK."   Seems like they could have a MUCH wider variety of sauces or other trimmings instead of just a cup of sambar and the same two chutneys with everything.

The dosa itself (we got the spicy mung masala) was VERY good and worth every penny (all 1100 of them). 

I would be happy to eat here again, but I'm certainly not in any hurry to do so.
author: Mark N.

description: Most Indian restaurants I have been to in the past few years do not serve Southern Indian dishes, especially dosas.  Fortunately after moving here in SF, Dosa on Valencia filled the spot.  That said, they have several varieties of dosas.  Each of them are zesty and plentiful.  They will make vegan dosas upon request, so ask your waiter or waitress.  The atmosphere and decor is less of an Indian restaurant, but more of an upscale bar restaurant.  I tend to go here after work and the place seems to fill up later in the evening, usually with people going for drinks.
author: Archie L.

description:
Despite having lived a block away for close to 3 years now, Mister B and I had never been to Dosa, choosing to walk a few extra feet to a certain other south indian veggie resto.  Well tonight it happened. 

Things were off to a good start when we were seated promptly, yay!  And to be greeted with complimentary papadums was quite delightful!

I enjoyed the romaine and paneer salad with garlic dressing, as well as the dahi papadi chaat, there is a nice bit of spice.  The chennai chicken was flavorful as well.  Mister B and I gotta remember not to order so much, as we both couldn't finish our ginormous dosas - onion rava and masala.  

All in all - good food, relatively high prices.  Nice staff and yummy chai with free refills, which I guzzled to no end.
author: Aimee B.

description:
Food was great! Never had South Indian food before but it was good!!!
Place was small but nice and clean.
author: Winnie B.

description: The dosa's are humongous overflowing the plate and come with very tasty sauces.
author: Karrot L.

description: I've never had a dosa! It was a refreshingly different experience and the staff was very helpful  at walking us through how to eat it.  I really enjoyed the ambiance of the place. Great selection of chutney.  We had the white truffle dosa, watermelon salad, and the jasmine blossoming tea. Very decently priced.
author: Anita C.

description: Definitely try here if you like indian food. It was very authentic compared to others. Food portion was so huge tho
author: Eunice P.

description:
Good place.

Kinda a novelty..... good concept restaurant.... "Dosa".

Good service, good food, but not a place or food I would CRAVE for....
author: Matsuo U.

description: The food was fine but the experience was spoiled by the awful service. The waitress took my menu away without asking what I wanted because they assumed someone else in our party ordered on my behalf, the waiter took my friends cocktail away while he was in the restroom and he was not done drinking it, they kept trying to take my plate away when i was not done eating, a waiter sneered at one of our group because they did not answer quickly enough if he was done with his plate, then the manager basically told us to hurry up and wrap it up because we were not vacating our tables quickly enough. We had a large group and spent a lot of money eating there so its unfortunate when you get treated like cattle as you might expect in a cheaper place. I dont need stuck up stuffy staff when I am trying to enjoy a meal so thanks but no thanks i wont be back
author: Jon R.

description: Customer service has gone down the drain.  I was about to give my name at the front  and was told that I will have to wait for 30 minutes.  And then took another person's name ahead of me even though they came in after me. Left the restaurant right then.
author: Chet M.

description:
I've always meant to go to this place, but it took a visit from my brother to finally try it out.

My brother had the Dosa Masala and I had the Rava Masala version. Each dosa comes with fresh chutneys and a small lentil soup for dipping. The portions were pretty big, and we were pleasantly full by the end of the meal.

I knock off one star because it took them 30 minutes to seat us even though I made a reservation ahead of time. Also, reservations are definitely recommended; however, the bar is first-come-first-serve. The ambience is pretty low-key and on the romantic side. Definitely a great date spot if you don't mind smelling like Indian food by the end of the dinner.
author: Koh K.

description: Slow service but attentive when present.  No frills environs but lofty ceilings and extremely tasty food - best Southern Indian I've ever had stateside!  The bread selections verge on artistic creations not so easy to eat for fear of destroying their beauty.
author: Mr B.

description: I was looking for a restaurant in the Mission District for my wife's birthday.  Saw the great reviews on Yelp for Dosa & we gave it a try.  Super helpful hostess and server.  We ordered a couple of excellent appetizers, a couple of different Dosas (masla)... and a Chicken Currey dish.... everything was beautifully presented and delicious.  The decor and ambiance is wonderful..... worth the trip, even from the East Bay.  Two Thumbs up!
author: Herb S.

description:
Okay, I'm going to have to upgrade this review for Dosa. I decided to give it another try, and this time, my experience was insanely better. 

It was a rainy Saturday night and we missed our reservation by 45 minutes (due to the lack of taxis in my area), but the host was really cool about it and we were seated within 10 minutes. Our server (Ziya?) was great -- very knowledgeable, especially when we asked him for suggestions on what we should order.

We ordered: (1) the samosas, (2) persimmon idiapp salad, (3) kerala chicken curry w/ a side of coconut rice, and the (4) chatni dosa. The samosas were awesome -- huge w/ a good crisp and they were actually a bit spicy. Dip them in some of the cilantro-mint chutney and you're good to go. The persimmon idiapp salad, with fresh sliced persimmon and rice noodles in a coconut sauce, was recommended by our server and I'm so glad he suggested it to us. It had a very unique flavor that I loved -- the textures of the FRESH persimmon and the rice noodles went really well together in the strong coconut milk sauce. The kerala chicken curry was incredible -- good flavor with tender pieces of chicken. It went insanely well with the coconut rice. 

The chatni dosa was good, but still, I don't think it was that GREAT. Personally, I enjoyed the other food much more than the dosas here. Strange that it's named Dosa, because I actually think everything else is way better.

I'm so glad I decided to give Dosa another shot. I'm definitely coming back for more.
author: Roy C.

description:
Went back w/ my family - tried the Caramelized Onion Uttapam - man that thing was dense...and delicious and really kept me full. Reaffirmed my love for their coconut chutney - which after I thought about it was somewhat reminiscent of thai cuisine, but either way, just delicious.

 Dad got the paper dosa which is unbelievably enormous. Brother's Masala Uttapam was also good. I just love finding a place with vegetarian food that's actually beyond merely edible, but delicious. Plus I love Indian Food. If this place were on the Peninsula I'd be here at least once a week.
author: Ross R.

description:
I have absolutely no complaints about the food. The food was awesome. Five-star awesome. Between my two friends and I, we shared the cilantro potato dosa and two vegetable curries, and we were full and happy in no time. The flavors were delicious without being intimidating-spicy, the recommended coconut rice actually did go quite well with the dishes we chose, and the little cumin chips were a delicious palate-cleanser. Even the Taj Mahal beer complemented the meal. All of the tastes were just working in perfect harmony. So why the four stars?

Our waitress was nice, the hostess was nice, the water dude was nice, the dude who cleared our plates was nice... and yet, they came by our table so often and asked if we were finished SO FREQUENTLY that it was obnoxious. It wasn't even a case of hovering, because hovering is impossible in Dosa--there's not enough space between the tables. This was more like really well-timed pouncing. The minute one of us would look up from our plates, our waitress would be there to ask if we'd like the rest of the food to go, and this happened several times. "Nice" at Dosa is code for "We need to turn over this table so get out, you slow eaters."
author: Stefanie L.

description:
Finally made it to Dosa and I was not disappointed. Our table ordered a roti filled with ground lamb, habenero-mango dosa, cilantro-mint dosa, masala uttapam and rasam. Everything was tasty, especially the dosas and to my the surprise the waitress was not lying when she said that the habenero was really spicy, it was burning my mouth in a wonderful way. 

I have never changed by rating before, but after receiving the answer from the owner about why the prices are a little higher than other Indian places I am very satisfied and they totally deserve the extra star. They PAY for HEALTH CARE! They don't add that stupid 4% and hand the responsibility to you. They could simply lower their prices a bit and then take on that 4%, but that to me is shady business. I love this about DOSA that they take the responsibility. They also use mostly organic and that makes me pretty happy. 

I would def. recommend this place to anyone looking for tasty south Indian.
author: Sophia D.

description: The best Rava Onion Dosa I've had in the US! Perfectly crispy without being oily. Had a cheesy dosa appetizer which tasted great with the chutneys that came along. Nice ambience too, ethnic and modern at the same time. I'll definitely be going there again!
author: Priyal M.

description:
Ok, so i went to this place again last night and the vegetable korma with coconut rice  was delicious!! If you like your food spicy get the green cilantro mint chutney on the side.... 

only negative: its a bit pricey (approx  20-22 dollars for a veggie dish and mango lassi - not including tip!).
author: Harvinder K.

description:
Dosa on Valencia is great. It's got a much more homey and casual feel than the one on Fillmore. The menu seems a little smaller too, less expensive entrees, but same good selection of dosas. If Dosa on Fillmore is good for a nice date, Dosa on Valencia is good for a group of friends.

I like this place a lot for a more casual but just as delicious meal.
author: Abbey S.

description: This was my second dining experience at Dosa on Valencia and I was not disappointed. The food quality was consistent (good) and service was excellent. While the dosas are large and seem like they would be filling, the other dishes we ordered (Dahi vada, Idli sambar and a couple desserts) were all meager in offering. Also, I found it really strange that I could not order a Lassi without salt in it! After all, it is just yoghurt blended with water (and without adding salt!) Apart from that, I really like this place and would definitely make it one of my regular haunts. I look forward to trying their other location in the Western Addition.
author: Sue D.

description:
THE FIRST California indian i've been impressed with after moving back to the states from England. 

Indian without naan? No Tiika masala or Vindaloo? Haute Cuisine setting and up-market prices with indian food? 

Yes indeed, Dosa is a different kind of indian experience altogether, but after trying it, I am indeed a believer, and now a big fan of South Indian fare. 

The flavours were both exciting and subtle, rich yet not overwhelming, spicy, but not so much that it drowned out the delicacy of this very very tasty food. 

We had the 'Moons' platter of Uttapam which was amazing (free refills on the lentil 'Dip' that actually eats like a delicious soup! - had a second on the house!) 

Then my wife and i split the paneer and spinich Prawns with coconut rice, which was absolutely delicious - sour, spicy, creamy, cardamommy, mmmm. 

We also tried the tamil lamb curry, pepper chicken and fish pakora (basically super tasty fish fingers) - all of which were very good. 

Overall, I think this place is a bit overpriced, but not horrible - however, if it was 30% less expensive, this would be a 5-star experience. 
you can probably get the same quality food for less cash, but i haven't found it yet - very good meal, would return for sure.
author: Ben B.

description:
SO DELICIOUS! I took my mom here for her birthday and she is a hard woman to please but she absolutely fell in love with Dosa. The food is scrumptious and the ambiance is very classy yet warm and intimate. The vada pav (vegetarian slider) is literally an explosion of taste in your mouth. PLEASE ORDER THE VADA PAV. You'll be the happiest person alive if you do. I promise. It has the perfect combination of flavors. The lamb keema dosa is really good, the paneer peas dosa is not as flavorful and was on the soggy side. The habanero-mango masala dosa is sooo yummy but ridiculously spicy. Even if you're into extremely spicy food, you should definitely ask for a taste of the habanero mango chutney before you order, to make sure you can handle it. The rasamalai is to die for - one of the best I've ever had, and I've had MANY rasamalais. My parents loved the Madras Coffee and deemed it very authentic. Overall, Dosa offers authentic and delicious South Indian food with excellent service. The waiters are very helpful and friendly and one of them was the ideal tall, dark, and handsome type - he looked so brooding and mysterious. Sigh. I swear I'm going to marry him one of these days. I came here with about eight other South Indian people and they all absolutely loved it! And that's saying a lot - let's just say South Indian people are hard to please when it comes to food! 

P.S. I loved Dosa, but honestly it gets five stars instead of four all due to its vada pav. SO YUM. PLEASE ORDER AND DEVOUR. SO GOOD. ORDER LIKE FIVE OF THEM.
author: Vino L.

description:
I tried the 4-course tasting menu: appetizer, mini dosas, small entree, and dessert.  Everything tasted fine, and was nicely presented, but I didn't find it very interesting.  I also ordered a mango lassi, which was a bit warmer than I would have preferred.

My favorite was the calamari starter, which had a little zing.  The paneer and pea dosas were bland, even with the provided dipping sauces.  I did enjoy the lamb curry, but wouldn't necessarily pay full price.  Dessert was tasty, but not something I would normally order.

All in all, it was a filling meal, but nothing special.
author: Cathy Y.

description:
What a great place to go to have a mini, intimate celebration with your boyfriend!

We made reservations were seated promptly (funny that the lady assumed that my last name was LEE because I was Asian. oh well!). Service overall was quick, polite, non-intrusive, and attentive. Just the way I like it!

Free chips: We devoured them. Bad idea given how much we realized we had ordered later on....

Crispy fish pakora: Crispy, hot and tasty. Recommended!

Chennai chicken: Pretty good, but not amazing. Good starter for a large group, so you only have a taste.

Masala dosa: Tasty tasty, great mashed potatoes inside. WOW that sambar was amazing. The more you ate, the more your mouth was on fire, but then the more you wanted to eat because it was so good!

Tamil lamb curry: This dish was absolutely amazing. BEST lamb I've ever eaten. I usually avoid lamb especially in the States because I find it too lamby/gamey. Lamb in China and Australia are less gamey, but still a bit to strong flavored for me. But this lamb curry--omg. It must've been the spices they cooked it in because it was tender and the flavor was soooo good and not a hint of gameyness! The lemon rice was ok to me (not much of a fan of lemon rice in general) but it DID go really well with the lamb.

Be warned that your nose will run if we get a spicy dish. I feel like I can handle spiciness, but for the ones we ordered, it definitely got hotter as we ate.

Our bill came out to $95, which isn't so bad given that we had two starters, booze and two entrees. I highly recommend this place if you're in need of a tastebud booster. We had plenty of leftovers as well.
author: Angela H.

description: Fantastic, deliciously spicy food. Had the Rasam, Hyderabadi Shammi Kebabs, and the Habanero-Mango Masala Dosa. Even my friend from Hyderabad who thought it very strange to eat Dosa for dinner instead of breakfast liked it! Make a reservation since the place gets very busy.
author: Chris R.

description: Hands down one of the best meais I've had this year.  The service was amazing and the cocktails were delicious.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Garrett D.

description:
Over 1000 reviews?! Either Dosa is really all it's hyped up to be or everyone (including myself) is just another sheep in the flock...I think it's a little of both...

- Music: Top 40, definitely nothing "Bollywood" about their choice of music.
- Decor: Dim & romantic. Intimate. Simple elegance- mirrors with gold frames, dark wood, trendy lights. 
- Service- Fantastic- seated within a few minutes of our reservation time, they refilled our water often which was much needed due to their spice level & the waitress made great suggestions. My eyes are bigger than my stomach so the BFF & I went down the dosa list  & hungrily picked out THREE...the waitress said if we weren't *that* hungry to only choose two, as the dosas are quite substantial. I love that she was thinking of our pockets rather than her own.

Here's the food rundown:
- Kerale Chicken with lemon rice- the rice was really fragrant & tart in all the right ways. The chicken portion would have been too small if the BFF & I were starving, but was more than enough since we had other items to munch on. Kudos on serving lean white meat chicken. 
- Spicy Mung dosa- it put my mouth on FI-YAH. I think they went a bit overboard with the spicy chilies, but the chutneys cooled it down enough to be enjoyable.
- Spinach fennel dosa- also a little spicy & very hearty. The texture of the dosa itself is very comforting & is a pleasure to eat; it's crunchy around the edges & soft in the middle. 
- total without tip: $44 (i thought the dosas were well priced but $17 for the chicken dish was outrageous & for that reason, I may not be ordering it again.

Fantastic environment for a first date or anniversary.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Came here for a work dinner. We did family style and shared a bunch of food. The lamb and the prawn dishes were really good. The lamb wasn't too gamey, and the prawns were cooked to perfection. The appetizers and dosas we had were also really good. Definitely would love to come back again.
author: Jenny C.

description: We have dined here a few times with friends when in the area to attend plays at the Marsh, which is just down Valencia. Our group of four found it a solid restaurant with well prepared South Indian food suited to a variety of tastes--spicy, not so spicy, vegetarian, non-vegetarian, etc. Service was fine, food flavorful, ambiance pleasant. Nothing not to like here.
author: Henry S.

description:
Dosa is easily in my top five most overrated places in SF and might be THE most overrated in the Mission.  And in a city where having high price points is practically an aesthetic value in and of itself, I would also call it one of the worst values, especially considering that there is a phenomenally better South Indian place - namely Udupi Palace - not even a full block away.  Although Udupi Palace's lines are already longer than I like, the shred of me that is purely selfless implores you to go there rather than Dosa.

My main issue with Dosa is that it is silly overpriced, seemingly because those who run it believe that they offer something unique.  I infer this from their emphasis on presentation of the food and also the fact that the wait staff addresses patrons as though they never could have had South Indian food before.  Servers tend to be overbearing about making recommendations and the assumption of your ignorance then translates into $11+ dosas, $14 channa bhatura (!!!), $9 vada appetizer, and so on.  

Apparently part of Dosa's draw for its many fans is the idea that eating there is an experience.  To me, the modern decor/atmosphere is tacky and cheesy at the same time, and the (not Indian) music is obnoxious.  How is it that even usually-discerning restaurant patrons miss these obvious issues?

The best thing about Dosa is that it does siphon a good many more potential Udupi Palace customers away from that far superior restaurant, especially those that desire a certain kind of service/experience that I find annoying.
author: Josh C.

description:
I love Dosa.

My first time at an Indian restaurant. And this place far exceeded my expectations.

Our server was very nice and courteous, his recommendations were spot on. 

Dishes our server recommended:
1. Cochin Calamari
2. Spinach and Paneer Prawns
3. Spring 

The food was fresh and vibrant, simple and delicious. 

For the reasonable price, great food and service, I will be definitely coming back.

PS. Mission 24th Bart Station is just 4 blocks away. Great way to walk it off after dinner!
author: Ken C.

description: Came here for a fix on dosa after spending 2 weeks in Bangalore. Hard to compare for authenticity, but it's pretty close. Dosa is super crispy, masala is flavorful, and the chutney got a kick!
author: Stan L.

description: Amazing food! looking forward to going back!
author: Mina D.

description: Delicious, inventive, spicy appetizers. Let them mix you an "Aaraam Se" cocktail. Dosas are very good too. Great for a special occasion.
author: V R.

description:
upudi palace gets another convert

I am devastated. this was one of my favorite places to eat in san francisco. I would consider myself a foodie and I have spent some time is southern india. 

now, the flavors that dosa delivers are still top notch. the problem is it has all gone downhill since they opened the new place on fillmore. 

-chicken appetizer- 
used to be a lovely pile of spicy, crispy chicken bites. now.... 5 little pieces with a mixed green filler. NOT worth 9$$$!!!
so sad. I loved that dish :(

-lamb curry-
used to be a large streaming bowl of amazement with succulent lamb... now, a small bowl with only ok lamb meat balls for the same price. again NOT worth the price.

- paper dosa-
my all time favorite. chunky undercooked potatoes. I am crushed.

I used to love this place. it is so sad when owners get cheap.
author: Jayne M.

description:
I went to Dosa for the first time last week and really enjoyed the experience. I think the best part of it was that we didn't order at all. We asked the waitress to give us whatever she though with a few considerations in mind.

The best part of this approach was that we got dishes we normally would not have ordered (known to order). There is so much more Indian food outside of curry, as I discovered. The food was well prepared with enough attention to the details, sauces, and pairings.

The food was also pretty filling. The highlight was the sweet bread and the dosa.
author: Terry H.

description:
Best indian food I've had - every single dish we tried was amazing, mouth watering, wish there was more so I can keep stuffing my face, good.  Our waitress was very attentive and friendly - and helped us pick what I can only assume was the best stuff on the menu (seriously, so good.)

I do have to warn of the $20 corking fee (not that that is soo unusual)
author: Andrea C.

description:
A gem of a place! Love everything about this place -- the decor, the food and the ambience. We have been here twice so far and we absolutely love it. My hubby ordered a pepper chicken with lemon rice on the side. It reminded us of the authentic chicken recipes from the south of India -- the portion was good size and the chicken was juicy! I ordered a tomato, onion and chilly uthappam -- it came with 2 types of chutneys and samba r. The dosa was good and the sambar was tasty. All in all a great dining experience. The parking garage is also close by, so parking in the city is also not a problem! 

Will definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for a very nice Indian restaurant, especially if you don't mind driving to the city this is a must try!
author: Divya K.

description: I really enjoy the dosas here.  They are full of a wonderful array of flavors, and the chutneys are excellent.  But the food here is just so rich and heavy that I feel like an overstuffed zombie on the verge of collapse for the rest of the night, disoriented and confused, an easy target for mugging as I slump over a curbside and gaze uncomprehendingly at the wheel of some nearby fixy.
author: Moshe Q.

description:
OVERPRICED!
i'm not saying it's not good, b/c it is. 

BUT...

you're paying for some fancy copywriter to write their menu and make stuff sound fancier than it really is.
it's a damn indian breakfast food...like toast and eggs here! 

so the next time you are staring at their menu and the $10+ for a piece of "toast" think about alternatives to this joint. 

i think places like this are great in introducing foods that aren't so popular to the masses...but the real fun is after your experience here, finding places that can give you that same tradition and quality. IMO, that's what makes eating out fun...the hunt for the hidden gem.
author: Mike Skinz Z.

description: Had the dosa masala for a friend's birthday and I was very impressed. The presentation was awesome, and the server went over the different sauces to use, which definitely helped a lot. Great place if you like sharing food with the rest of the table. We were a party of six, this location that's probably as big of a party you can fit in the restaurant, but they easily accommodated us since we had made a reservation. Oh and the drinks are super unique and tasty!
author: Alicia C.

description: its really good Indian food, closest to what I had in Nepal haha.  good quality curry and fresh ingredient. nice decor, good service.   portion is satisfying too.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
Big price for bad Indian food. 

The papadam was great, but who the heck goes to a restaurant for papadam? 

The place's signature dosas were disgusting.

(I've heard a rumor, though, that their biryanis are good.)
author: Kyle M.

description: Outstanding Food - Always Excellent.  Be sure to ask the waiter(tress)  for some useful tips - they always make fantastic recommendations.
author: Annette M.

description:
I love Indian food. I knew coming in this was not typical Indian food but with the high ratings and positive word of mouth, I thought I would try it. My boyfriend made reservations so there was no wait time on a busy Saturday night. This place is tiny! The decor is nice but very dark. One thing that bothered me was the proximity of other tables to ours. There are about ten too many tables in this dining room. The guy at the next table ( who might as well been at our table ) was so close I couldnt even hear the conversation between my BF and I. 
The food was ok. I didnt really enjoy the dosas. We both got a couple different styles to try. To me they were very greasy and the filling in the middle was bland, as were the dipping sauces. Service was just ok. Probably wont come back to find out what all the hype is about.
author: Lauren N.

description:
Yep, Dosa's good.  Yep, you've heard all about it, even way down there in Sunnyview or whatever it's called, and wow, it sure does feel sophisticated to be told you'll wait for an hour (outside! in the dangerous Mission!), and then actually wait an hour and a half.  Well, I outsmarted you tonight, but barely--even at 6:45 we had to wait for a table for two. 

First impressions weren't grand.  A bottle of Kingfisher was $6 and the garbanzo salad recommended by our server was fine but boring, and garnished with pale, crunchy tomatoes.  The veggie korma curry saved the day, with flavors of cinnamon bark and green mango.  The dosa was (shockingly!) the real highlight, especially with the fresh chutneys.  

In short?  Tasty, but hardly worth an hour's wait smooshed up against people who clearly drove in from someplace not-nearby.  Go early, or make a reservation (if your group is big enough), and order heavy on the dosa.
author: Dana S.

description:
My first time at Dosa was completely unplanned... I had heard of the restaurant but never knew where it was exactly. Well just my luck I was taking a long walk that day and happened to pass by just in time to catch their weekend brunch hours.

My friend and I ordered 2 appetizers and 2 entrees... we didn't know how big those Dosas would be so we were definitely stuffed by the end! The appetizer with the crispy rice (like rice crispies) is excellent! I had the basic Paper Dosa and that was excellent as well. At first I thought it was odd to find little meat on the menu - but the flavors of the food that we had could persuade me to be vegetarian.

Oh yeah and on top of that our waiter with the arm  tatoos was great as well!
author: Angelito R.

description: This place is amazing!  I wouldn't attempt trying to decide on the large menu; make it easy on yourself and pick from the tasting menu.  I had the calamari, spicy mung bean, and finished with summer vegetable curry and all were absolutely amazing.  They have a good beer selection so I'd recomend the beer pairing as well.
author: Jason C.

description: I love this place! Everything I have had there is beautiful, flavorful, delicious, and satisfying.  The server each time I have been there is happy to make recommendations to help create a really cohesive meal.  The ambiance is wonderful, although it gets really crowded sometimes.  I would recommend the uttapam sample platter, it is helpful to figure out which one you like the best.  Everything is delicious!
author: Jasmine F.

description: Had such an amazing dinner here!  It was our first time and the waitress was extremely helpful in helping us decide what to order.  The food was to die for, and the drinks were just as good.  This is definitely our new spot for delicious south Indian cuisine.
author: Gaby G.

description: Damn this place is good. I went there with a big group and had a prix fixe menu - everything I had was amazing. So much flavor. So much detail in the food, and well executed. I can personally recommend the spiced fruit salad, the mustard greens dosa, and the tamil lamb. Each of these was a treat unto itself - enjoy!
author: Ben C.

description:
I just went here yesterday around 7.30 and really liked the ambiance of the restaurant. It is located in a nice place and  there is a parking lot nearby to park your car. 

Seating is limiting here and so make sure you make a reservation online. The wait time for food is almost less than 5 minutes. The food tastes  mediocre in comparison to south Indian food i have eaten. The food also isn't spicy enough in comparison to Indian standards. So don't expect the food to be super spicy. At the end of the day if you looking for a restaurant with good ambiance and decent Indian food this is a restaurant. I would give a 2start for the food and 3 start for the ambiance.
author: Kishor K.

description:
I remember leaving with the ever-present scent of fresh-out-of-fryer papadum in my clothes, my hair, my skin *scrunching nose. ick*.

Vada Sambar = super tasty.  My friend compared them to donuts of the un-sweet variety and I cringed at the thought, being ever-health conscious, yet I nearly licked the plate clean.

Surprised to see so much meat on the menu for South Indian cuisine, I went for the Kerala chicken on a recommendation and it did not disappoint, though it was on the heavy side. Save half for later.

My dining companion, who grew up in South India, does his sanity check/quality judgement based on the sambar and he gives Dosa a big thumbs up.

The three spice gelato was beyond refreshing to finish it off. Guessing cardamom, ginger and mystery spice no 3.

The service sort of flaked at the end of the night, a fading presence, with the background music blaring at times - maybe as a sign that it was late and we should get out but it was a little weird.

I'd go back but I'm not running.

*side note - the menu wording is super confusing. it says: "Indicates dishes for which you need to select a side of rice, dosa or uttapam" above the Entrees. you don't NEED to select anything. it's a recommendation. it is NOT included in the entree. it's like ordering a side of rice. it would have been more than enough without a side.
author: Alissa A.

description:
Great service, great food, great ambiance.  Not cheap, but the overall experience is high end, which is never cheap.  The menu features upgraded versions of down home dishes, so there is going to be some trade off.  Viks chaat corner is one thing, great in it's own right, but not a place for a relaxed evening of beautiful dining.  Dosa does an excellent job of presenting chaat style dishes with upper end flair and quality ingredients.  

The masala dosa was delicious, perfectly executed and beautifully presented.  Ditto the Uttapam. My wife got the lamb curry which was too spicy for her, but delicious never the less.  The flavored rice was also great.  The flavors were both more restrained and more refined than the street versions. I'll gladly go again!
author: Jhos S.

description:
I was born and Raised in South India. I lived there for nearly 25 years. So, I know South Indian Food.

This is NOT a traditional south Indian place. Its a Fusion of South India + North India + Western + Some more. I dont say that in a wrong sense, but the true south indian flavor doesn't come out. And, the place is P.A.C.K.E.D!

The Virgin Drink, south Indian Monsson was heavenly and the Mango Panneer Dosa was very nice. The Vegetable of the Day with Bhatura wasn't that great, so, dont go for it. Madras Coffee was mediocre too.

Panneer is not South Indian. Vada Pav is not South Indian. Well, what they served was no where close to a real Vada Paav, but whatever it was, it tasted good. 

Oh btw, if you want to hit someone with a piece of rock, you can try their idlis. That's what they're worth for. Please refrain from those. (That's why removed one star)

Service was ok-types and they were kind of rushing us out as they had to  get the table ready for the next party. We didn't make reservations, but went there at 5.30 when they opened, so, we got lucky. but, that didn't warrant them from "almost" rushing us out. This is why I'm removing yet another star. Other than that, the service was good, the waitress was very responsive.

I will come here again to try other Dosa's, but will make a reservation & NOT order the Idlis & Coffee.
author: Mahadevan V.

description:
My partner and I visited Dosa last night.  Here's what we ordered.
The South Indian Slaw was delicious. It was bursting with flavor and a very nice texture. It was like a modern day waldorf  salad with out all the mayo and raisins.  
Next we had Potatoes & Organic Peas Croquette with a hot mint chutney and a tiny bit of radish clovers with a light dressing on the side to cool ya off. .  This was also very tasty with a bit of heat and more when you used the chutney. It was crisp on the outside and tender on the inside. 
Our main dish was Prawn Masala curry with a side of plain rice and uttapam.  This dish had a nice heat to it with a good amount of sauce for dipping the uttapam (pan cake fried bread) and adding more flavor to the rice.  The presentation was pleasing and kept warm in what I think was a cast iron dish.  
Our waiter was awesome! Since the table was a bit small to have a ton of dishes on it and had a little left over salad which we asked to be wrapped up and it was kept in the back while the rest of our food was served. How nice was that? Fancy service like this needs to be recognized :).  Twice the manager checked on us and helped out the staff with the clean up. The hostess was gracious and smiled while providing polite service. There was a warm inviting ambiance about this restaurant.  I will visit again even if they don't have naan :)
author: Sun M.

description:
I've reviewed Dosa before, as I live in the neighborhood and have been here a few times. I came earlier this week with visiting parents, and have decided I'm not going to go again if I can help it. The food is sub par... samosas are really poor - can get better ones most places. The dosa was meh. Not worth a ton of hype. Barely spicy and just kind of blah. The wait service was surprisingly harsh. The guy made fun of my mom for asking what she could order that wasn't spicy - she's very sensitive to hot stuff (unfortunately - she doesn't pretend it's cool!) and just can't eat it. (Why'd we go to Dosa? Well my stepdad insisted.) Anyway, the waiter proceeded to make fun of her for it, telling her "it's just psychological, you know." And that she needed to power through it. Then he brought her the special, which she still found too spicy. 

At the prices and the crowdedness of the place, I'm just not into it. If there weren't another indian place three doors down that were galaxies better, maybe it wouldn't seem to mediocre. But Udupi Palace is a thousand times better and the food is much more authentic. Do that over Dosa any day.
author: Lili L.

description: Dosa is a purveyor of pretty awesome South Indian food. I highly recommend the Cochin Calamari...yummfreakinee! The Kerala Chicken was a perfect example of a South Indian Curry.  The Dosas and Uttapams are perfectly executed.  The spice level was perfect for me: not too toned down to American standards. I highly recommend this place!
author: P K.

description: Really great south indian restaurant and the food is very authentic to that region..so don't expect to find Naan's or Kulchas..its all about the Dosa. The Winter veg dose was fantastic. Also, my fav item was Dahi Vada..its veg dumplings covered in yogurt sauce..quite delicious!
author: Sergey S.

description:
Hmmmm.....

Hmmmm.....

You know when you go see a comedy show, where everyone else is cracking up but you just kinda missed it (ha, ha...was it funny?)?

You know when everyone thinks that the guy over there is hella fiiiine but you just don't feel it (i mean, I can see he's not ugly)? 

Eating at Dosa was kind of like thaf for me. I just didn't get all the hype. Was I missing something? Like I forgot to put the magic sauce everyone is raving about?

It wasn't so. 

Cute, convenient, clean, affortable, filling, somewhat trendy, "OK" service....the food was alright, so I'm not complaining. I just didn't get all that excited. Can someone sum it up in five sentences or less as to why Dosa is so great? I'll pay more attention next time.
author: Nana N.

description: The food quality has gone significantly down (I've been here many times the past year). You'd be safest with a standard masala dosa.
author: Romita J.

description:
