Eat at Dosa, but ONLY ORDER DOSAs. That may sound obvious given the name of the restaurants, but there are a lot of other appetizers, salads, and drinks that may tempt you. 

I was in a large group so I got to try many dishes. I ordered the mint cilantro dosa which was great. Two of the oh-so-manly guys in my group tried to prove themselves by ordering the mango/habenero dosa, even though one of them said he wasn't good with spicy foods and despite multiple warnings on the menu and from the waiter. The dish delivered as promised, which was awfully fun to watch.

I also ordered a goat cheese salad. It was good, but it was very small and cost $9 (IIRC) - definitely overpriced. Similarly, the drinks are creative and tasty, but they are weak and expensive. I liked my lychee martini and the pomegranate martini (yes, I failed to follow my own advice and ordered a second drink) but they're just not good value.

You should also make reservations in advance if possible. We called ahead at around 6pm on Saturday and were told that the earliest they could seat us would be 9:30pm, but we dropped in at 6:30 and got a table right away. If the wait is too long, there another indian restaurant that serves dosa's right next door that isn't as crowded; I haven't tried it but it looks like a good backup plan.
author: Adam B.

description: Puffffffffffffffffff, the bread, the big fluffy ball bread that deflates when you Pop it! yay, fun, best thing about the joint. The food is so -so, the bread bread breaddddddd is to die.
author: SForiginal T.

description:
The spice .. that smell .. smelled it from the street, and with a recommendation from friends, had to do it.

The restuarant is not large so it does get packed.  I think I lucked out as I showed up with no reservations on a Friday night and only had to wait about 15 minutes for a table for two.  Seeing how lively the place was, reservations are advisable.

The food.  The dosa is great.  My first time trying dosa and I can say that it is definitely good.  We also ordered the spinach and prawn curry.  For my taste, too spicy.  The heat overwhelmed the taste of the spinach and prawn.  Two dishes, two glasses of wine and dessert is plenty for dinner for two.  I'm torn between 3 and 4 stars.  Great service, however pricey, it is still a nice dining experience.
author: A C.

description:
oh... my... god...
i went to dinner at Dosa with a friend to celebrate my birthday.  the tiny space was packed and we waited for about 20-25 minutes for a table (no reservation).  the food was so fantastic, i would have waited an hour.  it was that good.  no joke.  
we split the 3 cheese dosa rolls and avacado peach salad for appetizers and the special for entree (a green curry fish dish).  everything was amazing.  my friend and i looked at each other several times with a mesmerized look in our eyes that said "how can food really be this good?!?"  it all had the perfect balance of spices and heat.  one of the best dinners i've had in a long time.  
if you like good, spiced food and you weren't impressed with dosa, please see your doctor because there has to be something wrong.
author: Anjanette M.

description: Fantastic indian food! Service and decor are great too. The place is pricier than it appears because the portions are smallish (think of the dosas as appetizers), but it's well worth it. The lamb entree was amazing.
author: Laurent L.

description:
Although I'll eat Indian food, its usually not the first, second, or third choice for places to go. But for the future, if someone said we're going to Dosa, I'M THERE!!

I love tasting menus, especially ones that are only $35!! I was expecting tapa-sized plates but WOW!! For a 3-course tasting menu, it easily feeds 2 people. (I can easily turn my leftovers into 2 more meals.) I ordered the Chennai Chicken, White Truffle Masala Dosa, the Seasonal Vegetable Bhatura  and the Mint Lemonade to drink.

Mint Lemonade - Tasted like super sweet lemonade with a handful of mint leaves. It wasn't until I crushed the mint myself did the flavors started gelling together. Not worth the $5 price tag.

Chennai Chicken - Lightly battered with big flavors. Juicy pieces. Has a kick of spice after a few chews.

White Truffle Masala Dosa- SUPER yummy!!! Especially with the white truffle oil. Not your typical Indian flavor but added a different flavor profile that even creeps out of  the to go bag. The Masala was not overpowering with its spices and I think everything worked well together.

Seasonal Vegetable Bhutara - The least spicy of the curries in their tasting menu. Honestly, at this point, I was SO stuffed that I couldn't eat any more and had to take it home. I did eat the Poori (I heart carbs!) and yum!!!

Our waitress explained everything and the wait staff was very attentive. The food did seem to take awhile to come out. The decor itself is modern, albeit in a super small dining space. Overall, I would definitely go back again!!
author: J C.

description: I'll start by saying that while I'm not Indian, I love Indian food. I've been eating it since I was a young child, and at one point spent two months in India, where I had some of the best meals--and certainly the best dosas--of my life. I really wanted to like Dosa, but unfortunately, my recent experience there was anything but positive. I guess if you do go, stick with the dosas, which I've had once or twice, and are tasty and relatively reasonably priced. Otherwise you may be setting yourself up for disappointment both in terms of the quality and the price. My girlfriend and I went this past Sunday evening and got the tasting menu and a "chef's selection" of uttapams. From the tasting menu, we chose a seafood vada (fritter), a "seasonal" fennel and spinach dosa, and a chicken korma dish. The price of the tasting menu was $40 so I figured that the dishes would each be full sized. However, each dish was disappointingly tiny. The vada was a single, round fritter, about the diameter of a water glass--maybe four small bites at the most. However, neither of us minded the size since it was insanely spicy, almost to the point of being inedible. Mind you, we're not shy when it comes to spice--I'll put Tabasco, Tapatio, Cholula, whatever all over any dish, but this was like blazing, eyes tearing up, nose running, breaking out in a cold sweat, sick to your stomach spicy. Furthermore, there was no indication on the menu of how hot this dish would be. It was accompanied by a similarly impossibly spicy dhal, of which we each could only eat a bite or two due to the severe burning in our mouths and the sweat breaking out on our brows. We told our waitress we like spice, but that this was just over the top, and so if she could ask the chef to just tone it down a notch on the subsequent dishes, that would be great. She said she'd let the kitchen know. Then came the fennel and spinach dosa, which was again miniature (not their typical full-sized dosa), and really not that tasty or filling compared to, say, a masala dosa. The small portions of fennel and spinach inside made it seem pretty thin both in terms of actual size and in terms of overall flavor/substance. The final sorry entry from their tasting menu was the chicken korma, which was likewise small, though at least this one wasn't unbearably spicy. However, I think the chef overcompensated after our comment to the waitress, because this dish had the exact opposite problem that the vada had: it was just incredibly bland. I'm sorry to say that it was actually the worst chicken korma I've ever had--it tasted like chicken cooked in pureed, wet cardboard. You could get a tastier chicken korma from any typical, down-the-street type Indian restaurant. Finally came the five uttapams, which each had a different topping chosen by the chef. They were...fine. They didn't have a lot of flavor and were mostly saved by the coconut chutney that they came with. In the end, the bill came to over $70 (including the tip) for just the two of us, and we didn't even order any drinks or dessert. For that price, we could have gotten a feast from almost any other Indian restaurant that would have given us leftovers for days and would have tasted a lot better, or we could have gone to any of the other nearby, moderately high end restaurants in the neighborhood, and eaten much better. Overall, an incredibly disappointing dining experience from start to finish. The only reason I didn't give them one star is because the service was reasonably good, and it has a nice ambiance (though on the particular night we went, the adult son of the family seated next to us was actually playing a video game on his phone at full volume during a significant portion of the meal--way to classy it up, buddy). I'll be giving Dosa a miss in the future, and will instead be going to their nearby, more reasonably priced competitor when I'm in the neighborhood and have a hankering for Indian food. If I must return to Dosa (at gunpoint, for example), I'll be pretty much sticking to the dosas. Based on my experience, I think you'd be wise to do the same.
author: Moses G.

description: Deelicious! I love the sampler uttapam - that way you get a little taste of all of them!
author: k C.

description: This is a review for the manager, not the food. The food is great. We love Dosa, and often take out of town guests to the Dosa on Fillmore because the interior is more impressive than the one on Valencia. The in-laws were in town, so I made a reservation for Fillmore. Turns out that I accidentally made it for Valencia, and they were nice enough to call and let me know that i had made a mistake. (I had requested a downstairs table at Fillmore, which tipped them off.) I called back a bit later, but still several hours before the reservation, to cancel our party of five because we really wanted some place special and Fillmore was booked. The manager proceeded to berate me for several minutes, even though I apologized for my mistake, and had told him earlier exactly why we needed the Fillmore location. He would not let it go, and kept telling me that because of me they were going to lose $400 that night. I can only apologize so much for an honest mistake, and it was appalling to me that he treated a customer so badly.
author: Rachel R.

description:
We were there a bit earlier than the time they open for business, we requested if we could come in as it was cold outside and they did. I would give them 7 stars for that. :-)

The food was so good. I ordered the lamb keema dish with dosa, it was absolutely delicious.
author: anna p.

description:
I went to Dosa for the first time just last week.
I was expecting to see a lot of curry type of dishes and I had my mind set on Cheese and Spinich dish.

But I when i looked at the menu, I didn't recognize any of the things.

I found out that it was some sort of more southern region of Indian food and not the typical Northern Curry style that tastes awesome but makes you stink for days! ( def need to be sleeping on your own if your spouse didn't have Indian food with you.)

As an appitizer, we had organic chicken without bone wings type of dish.  it was a bit spicey.  pretty good.

I couldn't decide what i wanted, so i got the sampler plate which came with 5 different types of pancake looking things.
It wasn't my fav.  I tried my friend's dish and I liked it way more.

His dish was basically a flat bread type with mashed form potatoes which you dip it in sauces.

The only problem I had with the place was it was kinda cramped.
I had asked the waitress for a lemon for my water.  She forgot.  So i asked the busboy.  He forgot.  So i asked my waitress again and she finally brought me one. I hate drinking water without lemon in it.

The bill was pretty decent.  including drinks for 3 people, one appitizer and 4 main dishes, it came out to be around 22$ per person.

However, watch out for homeless people asking for money when you leave the restaurant.

One dude was asking for change, and since i only carry credit cards, i told him sorry.  Then he started to yell "I have cancer in my mouth! you MF!  Why don't you want to help me?"  We walked a way pretty fast the other way.  Good thing he walked with a cane, or he would have been able to catch up to us.

Total I would give it a 3 1/2 stars.  because they forgot my lemon twice.
author: ji K.

description:
Maybe it's because I'm part Indian and have been eating masala dosa's for 30 years, but this place didn't live up to the hype.

The service was great but the food was average.
author: Shez P.

description:
My cousin and his girlfriend took me here for lunch for my birthday. It was about 1-2 pm so it wasn't packed at all. The lady seated us on the stools by the window. This is a cute, very simple restaurant with a bar. 
This was my first time ever trying Indian food, and I was definitely not disappointed! I love the flavorful spices and curry that they use to infuse the sauces and food.
We got the White Truffle Oil Masala Dosa, the South Indian Moons, and Pani Puri. Not only were they super delicious and flavorful, the portions were big and filled all three of us up. The food was ready pretty quick and they were not stingy at all about the amount of sauces they provided for our food. 
The service here is really good. The lady explained how to eat the different foods because it does get quite confusing. They checked up on us frequently, and when we asked questions about the different dishes, they were very clear on what everything was. 

Service was good, food was good, experience was overall a 5 :)
author: Sheila X.

description:
With some 900 reviews, I don't expect my review to make a blip on the yelp radar, but my experience here was of the type where you had to write something about it, just to get it off your chest.

This place is ridiculous.  39 bucks for a tasting menu where you get "to experience a wide range of various southern indian food" sized for a single person.   The food quality is very good, but nothing that any other southern indian restaurant would be able to produce.  Separately, the singular dishes cost 34 bucks but you would get full sized portions, excluding the dessert.

Instead I got a jumbo prawn dish with 2 shrimp.  2.  That's it.

Price performance is terrible.  That's what it comes down to.  I felt cheated, seriously.
author: Michael N.

description:
I've never been schooled in the difference between south and north Indian food, but thanks to Dosa, I now know the difference.

Dosa on Valencia is a smaller property compared to the Dosa on Fillmore, but they were still able to cater to our party of 9. They take reservations, and this is key, if you would like to be seated promptly. 

Service was quick and our waiter was very informative and helpful. All Dosas are worth a try, as well as the different curries. Dosa is a carby-heaven.

Beer and wine bar only, and this is ok since either work well with their food offerings. 

On ambiance - rows and rows of soft candlelights around the bar and tables. 

Dosa is perfect for a dinner for two, or a casual group get-together.
author: Laughlin S.

description: I've been here twice in one week--it's that good!  Great South Indian food and awesome interior decoration.  Our waiter was a bit odd (very standoffish), but otherwise fine.
author: H R.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for Dosa yet. 
I love love love the food and the ambiance is great too (even to go hang out by yourself at the bar on a slow weeknight). The owners and serving staff are great - very friendly. 

So why just 3 stars?
- $4-5 for extra sambhar (that's the lentil soup). Seriously? See, sambhar is key to South Indian food. You eat a lot of sambhar. I don't know what an analogy would be... but it's as much a dip as meat sauce is a dip for spaghetti. Most other South Indian restaurants give free "refills" or just charge $.50-$1 (Udupi next door). I love sambhar and take major offense at this nickel-and-dime attitude (especially when they give very little to begin with). 

- Prices in general. About 30-35%% more expensive than the neighboring Udupi (whose food, I'll admit, I don't like as much - but it's definitely good enough). Drinks are definitely overpriced, but I suppose the ambiance asks for it.

- Quantity of food for the prices. I've been going here for a couple years now, and as far as I can tell, the size of idlis and utthapams (pancakes) has been going down down down. More nickel/dime stuff?

- Not really good for large groups - somewhat cramped, difficult to get a large table.

I'd go more often but for the above reasons. I'm willing to discount all the rest if they deal with the nickel/dime issues...
author: What's in a nam e.

description:
This was fine: delicious food, wonderful server, great drinks. 

The only thing is that delicious dosas and similar cuisine are also available for a fraction of the cost elsewhere (without the fancy drinks to be sure). 

I'm really just as happy elsewhere. But nothing wrong with this place.
author: idrather n.

description:
Way overrated again.
Just because you add crepes to an indian place doesn't mean it is instantly amazing.

almond (?) and cashew shrimp - uh, tasted good i guess.  the shrimp were nice, as was the sauce.  I liked that you could taste the ginger.

coconut rice - nice, but usually i find this hard to mess up.

spinach and fennel dosa - tasted good and savory but WAY TOO SALTY!! wtf.  and I have a high salt tolerance. sauces were nice but I really couldn't find a use for them since everything was way too saucy already.

bread side dish (forgot name) - ordered since we had a really imbalanced sauce to bread ratio.  too greasy.  I kept using my napkin to squeeze all the oil out.

overall, this was interesting since I usually get a larger bread to sauce ratio at other indian restaurants.  over-salted, overpriced, over-greasy :(.  also, no naan.

also, we had a 7pm reservation and were waiting at the bar for a table since the waiter said he would find us a table definitely before 7pm, but another walk-in couple at the bar still got seated first.
author: Xue H.

description:
I've been here twice. The food is nice.

Okay seriously. The last time i went was a Friday night me and a girlfriend didn't have reservations so we opted for the bar instead of a 30 minute wait for a table .It was very tight and I bumped elbows w the chick next to me for the entire meal meanwhile I was being bumped by servers rushing behind me I had no where to put my purse except on the floor under my stool. This wasn't a huge deal for me but I can see how it might be for someone else so I thought I'd let you know. Reservations might be good.

Other than the crowdedness the atmosphere is beautiful. Dim lighting illuminated with supplemental candles,  Indian music in the background, overall a very warm feeling. It was a good place for me and my friend to catch up but would also be a nice date place. the bar would be a good choice for wine (they seem to have a nice selection) and appetizers.

I wasn't super hungry so we decided to split two appetizers and a DOSA. We ordered:

1. Crispy Fish Pakora Sustainably-caught fish, marinated in chile, cumin, ginger & garlic, fried, served w/ spicy chutney

This was supper tasty but a bit smaller than I expected. It was 5 pinky sized fish sticks  for 9$.

2.Dahi Vada Lentil dumplings, topped with cool Straus organic yogurt, piped with tamarind & mint, mildly spiced

These were yummy too. 5 bite sized dumplings, 5 mouthfulls of India. I'm not sure I'd order them again though as the flavors were too muddled.

3. Paneer & Peas Dosa filled with spiced and shredded farmer's cheese, lightly grilled, peas and cilantro

Really delicious. I eat meat but a lot of the time I'm happier without it. This was one of those times. Soft texturally and flavorfully with delicate spices. It was very enjoyable especially with the dipping options (the coconut one was my favorite).

We finished off the meal with 2 Chai teas (one soy and one regular) and Raj Malai. The cardamon and cool creamy pistachio flavor  was the perfect way to end the meal.

In summary this was a great experience. IT is a good place to go if you're not starving as portions are small. This does allow you to try many things on the menu but it can also leave you still hungry once all your food has devoured. There are more substantial items such as the curries but I didn't try them.

Last note - the staff was courteous and pretty attentive considering how busy it was. Every time our order was placed in front of us we were i instructed on how to eat it which was a nice touch.
author: Miya F.

description: We have loved Dosa on Fillmore and finally made it to Valencia and now love, love it too. The baby eggplant kofta is so so good. As always the dosas are superb and the seasonal tasting menu is a great value. We like the ambiance and service was exceptional.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: The atmosphere is cozy and romantic, the food is flavorful and presented nicely, and overall I'd recommend it. Overpriced though, and probably not a good choice for someone on a budget. Would be nice for a date.
author: Stefi P.

description:
OK, I have to admit, I walked in expecting some seriously yuppie shit -- expecting unauthentic, bastardised "fusion" travesties, claiming "dosa" in their name by the slimmest of excuses -- trust me, I've raged at a fair share of wannabe-Indian fusion places that MAKE NO ONE HAPPY. But I stand corrected -- this place was just actually good!

And they did a good job at not only keeping the more traditional dosa varieties tasting dreamy, but also seriously came to bat with their more innovative takes on the dosas and chutneys. Example: they take the classic coconut chutney and herb it up a bit, and ooh is that garlic? I approve!
author: Meena V.

description: My husband and I have been here three times in three months, I love the food.  The 1st time we ordered and asked the waiter to pick a dish. The 2nd time we ordered one dish and asked the waiter to order the rest. The 3rd time we asked the waitress to order the entire meal. Best meal yet!  Good martini for the purist and the "gunpowder" was a winner. Great place for good food.
author: Vera G.

description:
Very good food that's both a gastronomic and visual treat.  Fresh, modern decor.  You get to eat with your hands.  Should have been an easy home run but the service killed it.

Perhaps I had too high expectations for this restaurant because it seems like everyone I know adores it but I was just a touch disappointed, and it was more than just due to the wobbly table.  While the place was still packed at 10 PM, we had plenty of servers - 4 to be exact.  Issue was that they were completely uncoordinated and didn't really care much.  For example, we asked to be explained the menu and our waitress replied by telling us to order drinks first and then walked away without listening to our reply.  When she returned, we ordered drinks but she was still not yet ready to discuss the menu.  Soon afterwards someone else came and asked what we wanted to drink as well...  Who knows?  Maybe it's just the full moon?

In any case, the food is good - I think I'll try the one on Fillmore next.
author: David A.

description: Really really good!  The dosa and bhatura are, of course, awesome.  The vada sliders are also really amazing.  Definitely check this place out!  I still like Madras Cafe in the south bay better, but this place is the best in SF.
author: J R.

description:
This place is f**king amazing!! I came here a little bit ago and was pleasantly surprised with the whole feel and look of this place. We got seated and our server suggested that we not go for the tasting menu because it is "too much food". Well.. we proved her wrong with how much we could eat and at the end of the whole experience I felt pretty comatose, going with the tasting menu was something I never looked back on. Everything, I repeat, EVERYTHING that was put into our mouths that night was fabulous. So much food, so much happiness. Oh and go with the wine pairings if you are looking to get sloshed with those dosas. But on another note, going with the tasting menu and wine pairings may give you some limitations on how much food should be put into your mouth.. 

Another recommendation: They have two bathrooms. I visited both of them that night but if you have a choice use the one farther down the hall. I opened the bathroom door into a room full of orange-ness and mirrors and it was spectacular. The other one is just your standard b-room. 

Damn this place is good, can't wait to head back.
author: Jen K.

description:
Let me say, I'm grateful to a friend's friend who brought me here (thanks Katie!). Very trendy restaurant, friendly staff and, especially, good spicy indian food.  

Their speciality, dosa, is a huge crepe made with lentils with different fillings, mostly vegetarian (mashed potatoes, spices, eggplants, spinach and so on), and served with a delicious (not-too-)hot sauce.  I loved it. 

After all those spices, I couldn't have ended my flavourful experience in a more consistent way than with their excellent three-spice home-made ice-cream (anice, cinnamon and ginger). Highly recommended!
author: Andrea L.

description:
I would not recommend this restaurant to anyone, and especially not to vegans, despite the numerous offerings labeled "vegan".  I was really bothered by the RANCID BUTTER that permeated my dosa.  I was there with a group, and several other people also commented on the heavy butter flavor of the dosas.  It was so bad I couldn't finish my dosa, even though I love dosas.  I finished the filling and gave the rest of the dosa to a friend, who wasn't too excited since she also felt it was too buttery/rancid.

I have a hard time believing the dosa was vegan, given the consensus at my table about the butter flavor.  Although the waitress was quick to warn me about not sampling a friend's dish as it was not vegan, and seemed interested in making my dish vegan, I suspect all the dosas are made on the same grill and they don't clean it well in between, resulting in the super rancid butter flavor.  It was unappealing to vegans and non vegans alike, as it was so greasy and unpleasant, so I would not recommend Dosa, despite other aspects of the food being completely fine.  

If you do decide to go to Dosa, rancid butter dosas aside, my Korean girlfriend strongly warns against the spicy dishes.  She thought that she could take it being Korean and often eating really spicy food, but Dosa takes it to a new level even she couldn't handle.  Being a wimp I didn't need any warning, and found the mild dishes to all be fine spice-wise, as did all my other girlfriends at the table.

Update:  I find the response of the restaurant owner odd, and a further sign this restaurant should definetely be avoided.  I specifically pointed out an issue with butter contamination of vegan food that a large group of diners vegan and non-vegan alike agreed on.  In fact as often happens with large groups the vegan diners chose the restaurant.  Disregarding vegans means losing the future business of large groups of diners that spend many hundreds of dollars in one evening.  I did not say that I thought unfresh ingredients were knowingly used, only that the grill surface likely needed more frequent cleaning as the flavor of the BUTTER was rancid, not the dosa batter.  
Fermented dosa batter does not taste rancid at all, it tastes sort of sourdough like.  Dosa batter does not normally include any oil, oil only is used in the cooking phase.  Rancid is a word that refers to spoiled oil, not fermented lentils and rice.  I do not feel I should have to prove my credentials to describe my meal, or provide definitions for all the words I use, and I find it insulting that the owner has stooped to implying that my lack of knowledge about dosas is the problem not their food.  I have made dosas from scratch many times at home and at others' homes (using ingredients purchased at the Indian grocery and fermenting overnight or longer, not sure how much more dosa study I need to do to meet the owners criteria?) and I've had them at lots of restaurants where they have never tasted like butter, rancid butter, or rancid oil of any kind.  These restaurants include Malabar, Dosa Republic (now Chennai Club) as well as places in Sunnyvale like Madras Cafe.  

***The owner's total disregard of the true issues and customer feedback and insulting condescension means I am now lowering my rating from two stars to one.  ***

It seems like the goal of "Dosa" is to cater to people who want the fancy ambiance and trendy location and are willing to believe this is authentic high quality South Indian food, perhaps because they have never had this genre of food before so the owner's condescension somehow works.  There appear to be enough takers that my large group of friends who now knows better won't be missed.  I suggest if you are in this neighborhood to visit Gracias Madre instead, which we would have done except one group member has a Mexican food aversion.  I guarantee the food will be far superior.  For good dosas I like Malabar but it is a trek out to Santa Cruz and Malabar has its quirks and issues.
author: N T.

description: Had the keema dosa, Expat beverage and tearamisu!  Excellent combo..
author: J S.

description:
BIG OOOPS!

I MEANT UDUPI PALACE ON THIS REVIEW: http://www.yelp.com/biz/udupi-palace-san-francisco

SORRY IF I LEAD ANYONE ASTRAY




The T.D&.H. server brought out this huge stainless steel (county jail) food tray. It had a dosa, a little hot soup and 3 cold dipping sauces. It was so delicious.  It was a lovely surprise. I like it here very much. 

UDUPI does not serve meat AT ALL. I love them even more for this!

I cant wait to go back. I want to take Tao Lin here after his reading at Amnesia September 29th.
author: Sunny Joy B.

description:
I was on my way to a Wednesday night, All-you-can-eat wings in Hayes Valley, when I received a text from the BF to check out Dosa instead. YAY! I love impromptu date nights, especially when I get to check out restaurants I've heard so much about, but have never been to. Those wings will have to wait. 

We popped in a little before 630, and they seated us immediately at the window. Luckily, we arrived before the dinner rush. Apparently, it's busy at Dosa almost every night. 

Toast ordered the Rasam "fire broth" - spicy, tomato, lentil, and tamarind broth, a Bhatura to share, and the Paneer and Peas Dosa. I was debating on what type of Dosa to try, and ended up getting the Mysore Dosa. The waiter was helpful and suggested ordering the sampler of chutney dipping sauces, so that I could try other flavors. (.50 cents per flavor)

We started off with the complimentary Papadum chips. They were very light and crisp, and speckled with cumin. Magically delicious! It was a great way to test out the chutney sampler. The fire broth was lentil-y, spicy and good as well. Next came our Bhatura. Definitely a surprise to see a giant inflated dough ball. It's BIGGER THAN YOUR FACE (and mine combined)! I snapped a photo of it before it started deflating -- and then it was just flat bread and not as exciting. It was a tad on the oily side, but great with the dipping sauces. 

We both agreed that the best dipping sauce, by far, was the Baby Eggplant chutney. I also liked the Cilantro/Mint flavors - both were light and refreshing. The Tamarind definitely has a sour kick to it, so try a little bit first. If you're feeling adventurous, try the Habanero. I tried a dime sized drop - despite the hotness, it also tastes sweet. 

My Mysore Dosa was delicious!! Of course, I do have an unhealthy love for potatoes. The crepe itself was big, slightly chewy, and partially filled with creamy spiced potatoes with onions and cashews. I think I would've preferred less dough because it was folded so a big portion was not filled with anything. I ended up using the Sambar (lentil dipping soup) more than the Tomato and fresh Coconut Chutney. All three came with the Dosa for dipping. The Paneer and Peas Dosa was wrapped like a burrito, and cut so you could see the filling. The cheese looked like scrambled eggs, so I kept thinking I was going to eat eggs and peas. It was also tasty and not too pea-y. 

Overall the service was attentive and very helpful, everything was delicious, but just slightly pricey.  However, with all the food that you get, it's not too bad. We ended up with 6 or 7 ramekins of dipping sauces and half of our Dosas in a doggy bag.

I'll definitely be back to try other things, and mayhaps bump up the rating.
author: Donna H.

description:
We went here last night and we were blown away with how good the food was.  The assortment and shapes of the dosa were very fun & unique.  My eyes, stomach and senses were pleasantly overwhelmed with the spices, decor and delicious food!!!  

Unfortunately, don't have three stomachs so I could've tried EVERYTHING on the menu, but I think I put a good dent so this is what I had and I recommend all of them.

*South Indian Moons  Chef's selection of five different Uttapams - my only complaint is the server did not name each the uttapams on the plate so I can't tell you which we liked best.  However they were still very good.
*Paneer & Peas  Dosa filled with spiced and shredded farmer's cheese, lightly grilled, peas and cilantro
*Coconut & Lemon rice, we liked the lemon better
*Popadom (think I am spelling that wrong) - was the best I've ever had before.
Dahi Vada  Lentil dumplings - This was one of my top choices, its delicate and refreshing.
Also, they have a wide assortment of chutneys and I favored the coconut & mango.

We got there at 6pm on a Friday & it was almost busy, also keep in mind parking can be tough but there is a garage on 21st street.

I left there full & happy...and I didn't feel like crap later which was a definite plus since we ate Indian food.  ;-)
author: Molly M.

description: I would only come to this place for Dosas. The south indian non-vegetarian dishes here were nothing to write home about. In addition they were somewhat pricey. But they do make some interesting and flavorful dosas. I had the masala chutney dosa. Next time i will try the habanero mango dosa. If you're in the mood for curry meat or vegetable dishes I would go to a north Indian restaurant over Dosa however.
author: vishal k.

description:
Everyone hypes up Dosa so we had to go! I was a bit disappointed but it still ended up being okay:
- we made a reservation the day before and were sat immediately which was great
- the service was off from the beginning.. Our waitress had no opinion on the menu and didn't really recommend anything
- the starters were the best part of the dinner. We ordered the calamari dish and chaat. 
- we ordered the paneer and peas dosa & the lamb curry entree. It was recommended with the tomato basmati but we definitely could have done without it. The dosa was great- would definitely go back to try the other types. The lamb curry was chewy and almost inedible. 
- I'm a big fan of gulab jaman and despite being really full, I had to order some. They served it warm in honey and it was perfect!

The ambiance is nice but it is kind of noisy.. Service could definitely use some work. I think we will try the fillmore location next time to compare.
author: Seema M.

description:
Went after reading countless reviews and raves about DOSA and I'm sorry to say, I did not care for DOSA. The curries were watered down and did not have much taste.

The DOSA was a good dining experience, but would rather buy pre-packaged Indian Food from Trader Joe's.
author: April D.

description: Yum, yum. Tiny space, but pretty classy. The service was pretty great and the food was beyond-best South Indian restaurant I've been to and one of the top Indian places in general! The mung bean, paneer and watermelon salad was ahmazing. A little pricey, but the food is so good it's worth it. Definitely going back.
author: J E.

description:
Delicious food, fun to eat, friendly and fast service.  Tasty tasty tasty...the only gripe is that its a bit too expensive for what you get...I mean not to sound cheap, but if you really look at the ingredients and how much you are paying, it feels like a bit of a rip. 
That being said, I would easily come back here since we both really enjoyed everything we ate and had a lovely time.
author: Nilu r.

description:
I do enjoy food but unfortunately as my palate does not tolerate even the mildest dish you can order in most of Indian restaurant I'm usually not a big fan of Indian food. So even if I did survive my Tamil Lamb Curry I will focus this review more of the ambiance and the service than the food itself.

We had a party of 6 on a Friday evening and I made the reservation two days in advance which was enough. Plus it was a smart idea since this place is popular and the wait at the door for a party of that size was of an hour this day.

The atmosphere was nice but not fancy. Very soft lightning that can be great for a date. The do not have any seating outside and probably 30+ seats inside. They do have some nice cushions

The service was nice and our waitress was available for questions. She also gave us time to look at the menu and order. We were never rush, which is great ;)

This place is not cheap for sure, but I think the ratio between quality and price is there. Each of us pay in average of $30 for 2 shared started and each of us took an entree while some of us took some drinks. 

I do not have too much experience with Indian Food but so far I put Dosa on the top of my list because of the atmosphere and the service. Plus it is in my neighborhood ;)

==============================

Pros:
- Soft lightening is a plus for a date. :-)
- Delicious complimentary Pappadum salty and spicy freshly friend chips
- On of the most popular Indian restaurant of San Francisco
- No rush. I really appreciate the fact that we weren't rushed to order and leave. Very nice. Remember me the French way of life when people go out in restaurant ;)
- They focus on organic and sustainable ingredients (and even use Indian spices in their cocktails).

Cons:
- Their does not seems to have a large selection of non-spicy options. The waitress recommends their Tamil Vegetarian Curry as a non-spicy option. Bummer for me, since I definitely wanted some lamb. That should not be a con since people that go for Indian food are looking for dishes that can spice up their meal ;)

Cedric's secret advice:
 - Because of their soft lightning in the evening, bring a camera with flash if you plan to take pictures once inside.
 - best dish or combination of dish to order? I would recommend sharing a starter and then going for an entree. Of course the Dosa are their specialty so you should go for it as well ;)

Good to know:
- They will ask for a credit card number to secure the reservation. A penalty of $50 will apply if you do not show up!
- Dosa is located in two location in SF: Valencia and Filmore. If you would go for a more fancy location, go for the one on Filmore!
author: Cedric L.

description:
During the hour I spent dining here, I was so confused. Why? Probably because I've never had South Indian cuisine before. I'm accustomed to just plain naan and curry which is Indian food but Pakistanian as well. 

All I saw on the menu was dosa, uttapam, dosa, uttapam, dosa, uttapam, etcetcetc. You get the point. 

For the newbies...
- DOSA is a HUGE crepe (like really really big) that is rolled up and filled with whatever you order. For example: masala. So like a potato onion curry ish thing. 
- UTTAPAM is also a crepe as well, which is slightly thicker and the ingredients are rolled into it, so it comes out like a small burrito. 
- Both DOSAS and UTTAPAM are served with three things...
1) Lentil soup 
2) Tomato Chutney and 
3) Coconut Garlickey Chutney

Our server was really helpful and helped us order about 2 dosas, an egg plate and 3 uttapams -- once of which was a sweet one. He then suggested for us to try other chutneys, and subsequently after agreeing to it, he brought out 6 different chutneys for us to try: a lime one, a lemon one, a mango one, a dried tomato one, a spicy habernero one, and something else I cannot remember. I definitely suggest trying the tomato one because it has a bit of spice to it but also a salty kick. Put a dab of this on one of your dosas or uttapams and then load it on with the tomato chutney they give you from the beginning and you're golden. Trust!! 

For newbie diners at Dosa, I highly recommend getting...
1) Masala Dosa
2) Paneer & Peas Uttapam
3) A side of their tomato chutney for 50 cents.

I will be back to dine at Dosa to try their curry that they ran out of when we arrived. I will probably order another Dosa and enjoy it with their tomato chutney. OH and another thing I have to add is that Dosa is VERY vegetarian friendly. All 6 dishes that we order did not have one trace of meat in it. I would come here if I was a vegetarian (who eats eggs, of course).
author: Heidi C.

description: pros: great food, great drinks. cons: pricy, could have more comfy seating, not a fan of their desserts. will be back.
author: R C.

description:
*** READ IF YOU HAVE FOOD ALLERGIES OR KNOW SOMEONE WHO DOES****

I had a terrible time at DOSA on March 18. I loved the chic intimate atmosphere, and for me personally- a non-allergy person, I would have loved DOSA, had I not been with an allergic person, and had I not encountered TERRIBLE customer service.

You need to know that this restaurant does not list common allergic ingredients on their main menu, and items that you would think may not have nuts, ginger, etc may- so you need to ask your server for an allergy menu. My date has a terrible reaction to nuts, and when we saw on the main menu that there was no listing of nuts next to the Kafta Meatballs, he ordered it. He's had several dietary allergies his whole life, and has managed eating Indian food before...

Kafta meatballs are made with cashews. We were going to the restaurant for his birthday AND our 2nd anniversary.

I called the restaurant 5 minutes after we left- as he was throwing up in the gutter - to ask what the hell was in his dinner before I took him to the hospital! The maitre-d rudely asked me why I didn't ask for an allergy menu. I had no idea there was one, as other food items on the DOSA menu had listed there were cashews, and there was no such listing on his Kafta Meatballs- we both thought there was 1 menu.

I called back the next day March 19, to speak with a manager and he pacified me. I told him I am a yelper, so he knows I'm writing this, as he has not fulfilled his promise of gift certificates or even the card he promised when I gave him our address to pass off to the owner. The manager asked for the address, so I feel like this is a double-insult.

I paid $90 for dinner as my date threw it up just out front, and then we had to go to the hospital to get his epinephrine shot. He was sick for 2 days. The manager said he would send such items to as retribution for his ruined his birthday, but hasn't. 

TERRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE. I feel robbed. 

:(
author: Glansande J.

description: Flavors and spices I've never tasted before! Definitely my favorite Indian restaurant in San Francisco. The vegetable sliders are a must-order as an appetizer. Heirloom tomatoes were also great and the Paneer & Peas Dosa was delicious.
author: Steve V.

description:
Dinner here was very tasty. However they or their supplier uses that ingredient in their food (most likely a preservative on their vegetables) that I'm allergic to and requires me to lifetime ban  :(  Too bad! It was a good dinner! Those dosas are pretty incredible.

Wait can be lengthy and you're really crammed in there. Service was good though.
author: Jen D.

description:
this is pretty good indian food but it's probably not the kind of indian food you have in mind when someone says, "hey, let's get some indian food at dosa tonight."

the uttapams and dosas are quite good and the sauces that come with them are tasty, too.  i have not tried any of the curries though i think i ought to head back and sample some.

this place is good but i haven't rushed back.  it felt a little pricey and the lighting is so incredibly dim at night... it was okay for me but my father had a super hard time reading his menu.

the decor is nice but the few times i've been here i've always been seated by the back next to the kitchen which was undesirable.
author: Lauren P.

description:
ok the food wasn't bad, but i've had MUCH better at a 10dollar lunch buffet in wisconsin...

they are also very clear they are ::south:: indian food- no chicken masala! the waiter recommended something with a 'similar taste' and it was nothing like it. the other plate we ordered was closer.

2 entrees, 2 drinks = 70bucks. ouch. nothanks
author: Sara S.

description:
I came here for a friend's birthday dinner, and I should have researched a little before hand to realize that South Indian food doesn't include too much meat. I ordered the Goan Prawns with coconut rice, and it was AOK. It was tasty, and our waitress did tell us it was going to be spicy, but I didn't really believe them because it's rare that "spicy" was actually so. FAIL. It was very very spicy, and we had to get yogurt to cool it down. After a while, I didn't even recognize what I was eating; my mouth was on fire. 

Service: great service until the end when the bus boy spilled water all over the table. Our waitress was very informative and the water was constantly being refilled; it needed to be since everyone was downing it like fish.

Ambiance: Decent place to have a quiet dim dinner w/ a date or to have a group gathering. Not exactly rowdy, a nice side of elegance, but down to earth enough to not feel uncomfortable laughing out loud.

Pricing: $17 for my dish + tax and tip. Not bad seeing as halfway through, I couldn't eat another bite, although I blame that more on the fire that filled up my stomach more so than the amount of food they served. 

Honestly, it would have been better if I didn't spend the first 10 minutes taming the fire. Beware of the spicy stuff because they are not kidding!
author: Camille T.

description: Dosa on Valencia has to be my husband and my favorite restaurant in the city and is our go-to for special occasions and date nights. The atmosphere is amazing, there is a warm glow about the place and the servers are the most attentive  I have ever witnessed. Then there is the food, every time we go we try something different and we are never disappointed, it is the best Indian food we have ever had. If you have brave taste buds and are in the mission you have to go here! Make sure you call ahead or use Open Table to make reservations before you go, it fills up fast!
author: Taylor S.

description: I HIGHLY recommend you try Dosa, the food isn't typical HEAVY indian cuisine, but really flavorful and clean. I had the dosa masala and my boyfriend the garlic chicken. We were both blown away by how much we enjoyed our meals. We both also tried a new cocktail and they now how to mix them JUST right.
author: laura m.

description: Great South Indian cuisine & reasonable prices! A full bar & a decent wine list accompany the delicious food! Staff are up-beat & friendly. Check it out!
author: Jody A.

description: The name says it all. If you like dosa, this place is great. The extensive menu can seem daunting to the uninitiated, but the friendly and efficient staff is only too happy to help out and make suggestions.  Seating varies from window side tall tables,  seats at the bar, to conventional seating toward the interior.  BTW, Dosa On Valencia is "closed" after lunch until dinner.  However, a smaller menu featuring small plates and bar bites is available during this time.  From all appearances, the bartenders on duty are very capable and creative.  My wife had a Mango Mimosa which she pronounced as "simply delicious".
author: Louis H.

description: I feel like a snit for saying this but I just don't get the rave reviews for this place.  The food is average & the customer service lacks authenticity.  It feels like they are trying too hard with the eclectic decor & low lighting..hoping the customers are distracted enough to not notice they are paying way too much for basic indian food served in a hot, loud and cramped space.
author: Amy B.

description:
This is definitely not a hole in the wall Indian place.

 The dim lighting and intimate setting have a very pre-getting-laid-tonight tone. Had the spring dosa, which was good. Not too oily & the sauces were yum. 

Not too sure about the authenticity of the place, though- particularly when I heard country music come on in the background...

Conclusion: Worth trying, but wouldn't consider it as a place I'd go regularly.
author: Veronica G.

description:
Excellent in every way!
Great beer, delicious food, wonderful service, charming atmosphere....thanks Dosa for a perfect dining experience.
author: Eva S.

description:
Seeing that Dosa is Michelin Recommended, I was really excited to try the food. Unfortunately, I wasn't blown away. The dosas are good, but not spectacular. 

I also had the Kerala Chicken, which I do not recommend. Come here for the dosas only. If you want an entree, I highly suggest going to a restaurant which serves North Indian cuisine. 

Also, it is a little pricey for what you get. Nice ambiance and great service though.
author: Sandy K.

description:
Ate at Dosa for the first time tonight and I was definitely pleased.  I decided to eat out alone tonight, so wanted someplace with a good vibe and that I could eat at the bar.  Dosa is warm and inviting, while at the same time having a hip vibe going.  

I sat at the bar and found the bar staff very friendly and helpful - unlike many bars in the Mission.  Even the guy sitting next to me was helpful in my beer selection.  I had a great experience at the bar.  The food had some great flavors - although I'd skip the organic field greens since you're probably there for South Indian flavors.  The salad wasn't bad; it just didn't seem appropriately paired with the rest of the menu.  The garlic soup was out of this world - spicy and flavorful - and was a work of art visually.  The shrimp chili fry had a really great flavor, although the shrimp might have been a little overcooked.  

The downsides?  It took quite a long time for each of my successive dishes to arrive.  At least the vibe kept me entertained during my wait.

I'd definitely recommend trying Dosa, even if you don't consider Indian to be your thing.  If you consider flavor your thing, then Dosa has plenty of that.
author: Scott L.

description:
Ahh, Dosa. The legend that is Dosa.

I wish I could discuss in great length the fantastic flavorful dishes, the outstanding presentation and the stellar service... but the truth of the matter is that I cannot.

Why? I'll tell you.

An interesting thing happens when you dine at Dosa. You sit down and you immediately get lost in the menu. There are so many wonderful unusual sounding dishes listed that you end up deciding on several dishes and then you forget what you've ordered.

As the first few plates start to appear, you might wonder which dish you're about to enjoy and you'll dive in. You'll be 'oohing and ahhing' and telling your friends to 'try this dosa' or 'make SURE you have some of that' that you'll probably forget what it is that you ordered. 

The plates will continue to come out of the kitchen. Like a pack of hungry wolves, you'll practically attack the waitstaff, anxious for what's next. There probably won't be a lot of talking while dining either. What there will be is sounds like, 'Mmmmmm' and 'Oooohgaaaawd.'

I will add the the ambiance and service is spot on- perfectly bustling and busy, yet still cozy and personable. I can tell you that the unusual desserts are tasty and you should most definitely try to save room for one, if not all of them.

I do remember the Dosas (the filled ones in particular) being fantastic.. and the prawn dish is to die for. Everything else is hazy... 

Food Coma is inevitable.
author: Katie A.

description:
I love Indian food (I get samosas and/or parathas from the farmers market almost every week, and am a big fan of naan, among other dishes), but Dosa's South Indian food didn't do much for me overall.

We arrived on a Tuesday night just before the dinner rush.  The decor is modern but warm, and the place has a nice feel to it.  Unfortunately our waitress proved to be somewhat distracted -- she forgot to tell us the specials until after we'd ordered, and otherwise barely delivered the minimum of service.

For a starter we had the Chennai Chicken ($9.50), which was excellent.  The free Papadum chips were also very good.  I had a glass of the Gewürztraminer ($12; good but a bit sweet), which one of the owners delivered to the table himself.  Apparently that wine is a favorite of his.  

For entrees we shared the Masala ($10) and Paneer & Peas ($11) dosas.  The presentation was beautiful and the portions were a good size.  And while the ingredients certainly seemed very fresh, I found both of them to be fairly mediocre as far as flavor.  They just didn't stand out at all, although the Masala was the better of the two.  Similarly, neither the tomato chutney nor the sambar were anything special.  The fresh coconut chutney was better.  However, my girlfriend thought it was all delicious, so YMMV.

We finished with the Gulab Jamoon for desert ("Two soft, lightly-fried milk and dough balls served in a warm, cardamom flavored sugar syrup"), which perhaps predictably tasted like dough and sugar; it did not impress.  Both of us wished we'd had Indian ice cream down the street instead.
author: Andy S.

description:
Two preliminary digressions:

1. Why does hearing rain pound on a windowsill make me sleepy and happy, at all once?

2. Quoth "Knocked Up":

Sadie: Why is everybody so mad at you? 
Ben Stone: I don't know.  Are they mad?  What have they been saying? 
Sadie: They've been saying, like, "Blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, Ben's a prick."
Ben Stone: They said that? 
Sadie: A lot! 
Ben Stone: That sucks!

I can only assume it's the name.

Now, back to the show.

First, the important caveat for those like me who are terminally clueless: Dosa is not really like 99% of the other Indian restaurants you've been to.  Not necessarily better or worse, just different in ways you need to understand.  Like, for example, Google Dosa and find out what it is, then resign yourself to the fact that that's what you're going to eat there.  And it'll be good, so don't worry.  But know what you're getting yourself into.  Hey, BTW, not a bad idea for life in general.  If only it worked that way.....

So, the food was really quite decent, and the service was okayish.  And the price was...well, it was $65 for lunch.  For two.  But, come to think of it, I did have two Pom martinis.  I can feel their healthy antioxident powers scrubbing my insides as we speak, making everything sparklingly pink.  Which, I can only presume, is how your insides are supposed to look.  And I say "presume" because, while I have accidentally unzipped my skin more than a few times, (1) I never really paused to examine the stuff underneath, and (2) at no time did I believe that stuff, at that moment, looked "the way it's supposed to look."  Not freshly Pom martini scrubbed, at any rate.  Which brings us full circle, I think.  Was it as much fun for you as it was for me?

"Blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, Ben's a prick."  Yep, got it.  Thanks!
author: Ben P.

description:
Food was very good - a bit rich, but flavorful, interesting, and good quality (but not worth all the hype in my opinion).

The service was poor -- 5 different wait staff came by to ask "who's going to take the last shrimp?" SO irritating - we'll eat our shrimp in our own time thank you!!

We felt like they wanted to hustle us out of there ASAP which ruined the tone of our meal. 

I can get great food and a relaxed staff elsewhere.
author: Sally V.

description:
I went to this place as a suggestion by a friend since I wanted to have something light.
I had the idli here and the sambhar was very armoatic and tasteful.
The green/cilantro chutney that they offered with pani puri was amzingly spicy.
But I will have to say that I will give 5 on 5 to the Masala Chai that they serve.
The tea was simply amazing and I could say with confidence that its one of the best teas that I have ever had in Indian restaurants in US.
Great flavor of cardomom, ginger.I liked the first cup so much that I had to ask for another one.
author: Kunal J.

description:
We really enjoyed Dosa! Super tasty food, friendly service, and fun atmosphere. It was also really nice that if you ask, they will bring you a menu that lists all the meal options that are gluten-free, vegetarian, etc. 

It gets a little pricey if you order cocktails, but no big surprise there.
author: sara n.

description:
Noted: 

Dosa isn't a place where you go to if you are craving for your mama's southern indian curry. This is defintely a place where you go for dinner with girlfriends, or a date, or even just to eat some good food.

I would say the dosa is delicious!!! and the spicy chicken, and chickpeas,.. my mouth is watering, and their lassi martini!! seriously can they make shitty food? nope they can't it's delicious!! and so beautiful. Just be aware that there is no way in hell you can find parking so find the parking garage around the corner to park, it's only a 1.50 don't be a cheapo and just park there. I hate double parkers and you will get your car keyed if you do that in the mission!!! Oh yeah, try to make reservations, or just be ready to wait a long time for a table.
author: Nina M.

description: Really disappointing service. Slow, disjointed, obviously very bad and they knew it -- so they just added a tip. Hostess was patronizing and rude. I was embarrassed to have brought friends from out of town.
author: Rob L.

description:
I'm updating my 5 year old review. It used to be a positive, yet 3 star review. I had just moved to the bay area from Florida back then and I think I was still recovering from sticker shock - Dosa for $12!! Oh the humanity! 

Now I realize that $12 is reasonable considering the quality is pretty damn amazing. I returned here yesterday and loved everything we ordered. 

White truffle dosa - very good.
Onion rava dosa - yum
utthapam sampler - great if you like utthapams.
Chennai chicken appetizer - delicious!
madras coffee - pretty good (you might have to ask them to heat it up for you)

Desserts:
rasmalai was perfect
coffee pot de creme - really heavy, but delicious.
author: Arjuna R.

description:
I almost gave Dosa a three-star review. I don't want to give every "decent but not amazing" restaurant four or (yikes!) five stars; that will dilute the ratings. But they are open late, so thank you, Dosa, and four it is.

Don't get me wrong. Dosa is good. But in San Francisco, there are many choices for a repast. The crepe-like dosas are interesting, but can be presented a bit pretentiously - our neighbor's was delivered in the shape of a 3" diameter tube, with the fixings on the side. Yum, I guess.

I must also raise an eyebrow at the "mostly organic, sustainable and natural ingredients" claim for their prix fixe menu. Earthlings, it's either organic, sustainable, and natural, or it's not.

But the food was yummy, although the "moist warm sticky balls" were a bit suggestive. That made our evening. The lovely Carolyn was my celebrity dinner companion of the evening, and she was raving about her take-home dosa twenty-four hours hence. So there.
author: Poker M.

description:
Below is a BRUNCH review:

This is the best brunch I have ever had. 

(should I stop there?)

This food feeds my heart. Spicy tangy sweet Fiery Fruit. So good when with friends I order my own and one to share. The south Indian coffee is one of the best things ever in my mouth. Like some magical melted coffee ice cream warm in a cup, just for me.
 
The best way to get your eggy potatoey brunch on is he Egg Poriyal Dosa with a Masala Dosa.  Spicy potatoes in a smooth creamy coconut dipping sauce sound good? Chivey egg in pancake with sweet tomato or spicy lentil sauces? The only thing better is the Cilantro and Tamarind sauces that come with the Pani Puri, which is like a create your own mouth orgasm, TRUST. 
I want to bathe in those sauces. 

Recently I went out of my comfort zone after watching a table next to me giggling while eating the Dahi Batata Puri and tried it. Think: crispy shells with cool yogurt inside with a sweet sauce. A perfect bite of brekkie as far as I am concerned.

Sure sure, atmosphere, excellent service, reasonable price. But the food...sigh....
author: Lizzi M.

description:
Dosa is kinda like a Bong Su of Vietnamese food.  No question, it's delish, nouveau, pricier and more refined than more casual spots that serve very similar food, but in silver tin bowls.  Some days you want ambiance to match the food and presentation.  Like when your best friend since kindergarten flies in from DC and is meeting your b for the first time --- YIKES!  

-Dahi Batata Puri were small hollow crispy breads filled with Strauss organic yogurt, potatoes, mind, tamarind chutneys.  You stuff it in your mouth and the yummy goodness explodes.  On the brunch menu, but they served it for us at dinner.

-Chennai Chicken was good, but the pieces were small, almost shreds.  Flavor was great though.

-FANTASTIC Jumbo Prawn Masala.  Huge and succulent prawns in this amazing coconut milk reduction served with coconut rice and raita.    

-Fave dish at the table.  South Indian Lamb Kofta Natural, free-range lamb meatballs, creamy sauce of tomatoes, spinach spices, lemon basmati rice, and raita. 

-Moons Chef's selection is a great way to try five different Uttapams.  Served with sambar, channa (garbanzo) and chutneys.  Moh moh moh...gimme moh!

-Dessert was kulfi (Indian Ice Cream) in mango.  Served in cubes, creamy, but not too sweet.  Different, but a must try.

3 beers, bottle of wine, 3 chai teas, and one other appeitizer I can't remember.  Total $264 for a table of 6.  It's a great place for a group dinner, casual date, even visiting relatives.  I would definitely return.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Yum, yum and more yum. My husband and I have wanted to try this place for ages but we never plan ahead and the lines are typically way longer than we want to wait. Last week we had friends in town and they wanted Indian food. i am sure they meant Northern Indian but they were not specific so I FINALLY booked reservations for DOSA.

We were not disappointed! The food was fantastic. We all ordered different "dinners" and we all cleaned our plates! The service was okay once we could flag down our waiter. He seemed to be in another world, staring out into no where every time I looked for him. But having reservations and no wait to have such fantastically, yummy food, who really cares about the waiter, I mean he wasn't bad, just not on top of it?
author: Denise L.

description: I had a very bad experience with this restaurant. I went there seeing the yelp reviews.. the dosa was totally soaked in ghee and i don't find any other taste than ghee taste. the thali was bad too - some random set of curries with another ghee soaked dosa. and just 3 table spoons of rice.
author: Siva G.

description: Havent had much Indian food but this seems more traditional. eating with your hands is not common for me but they have a nice variety of foods and sauces you can dip your food in. Soup tastes great but this crepe-like pancake doesnt curb your appetite as portions are small
author: Len A.

description: Decent South Indian food if you have to get it in the mission. However I'd highly recommend you go to Dosa up in Fillmore instead, or better yet, take a drive to the South Bay, so much better South Indian fare down there.
author: Mayur A.

description:
Two things about me:
1. I typically despise "nouveau" or "fusion" versions of ethnic food.  
2. I tend to shy away from hyped-up places in favor of finding my own favorite hole-in-the wall that I don't Yelp about.

I'll be damned if Dosa wasn't some of the best Indian I've had this side of Little India on Pioneer Blvd. in Artesia, CA.  Of the three appetizers and three entrees we selected, all were phenomenal.  Delicious and tantalizing "souped-up" versions of south Indian classics.  The sauces/garnishes were fresh and flavorful and the texture and presentation of everything was perfect.  Our knowledegable but unobtrusive server did a fine job, especially with wine selection.  
The price is more than this White Trash would normally pay but the experience was worth every penny.
author: Eric S.

description:
How have I not reviewed this before?

Dosa is my standby "I need to know I'm getting amazing food and great service restaurant".
I pretty much exclusively come here for weekend brunch, and I think it's more exciting than dinner. Come here with an open mind, but know that everything is good. I order almost everything with a side of spicy mango pickles cause they are delicious. 

Papadum: delicious and crispy
Paper Masala: crispy! Not too spicy. Somehow fresh, even though it's potatoes and nuts.
Rasam fire broth: perfect if you have a cold, not as spicy as they say it is.
Cilantro mint masala: amazing, refreshing, interesting mix of flavors
habanero mango masal: it is seriously spicy. don't order it without a lassi or some raita, cause it will literally make you sweat....but it tastes good. 

They just added an avocado and garbanzo bean salad to the menu that is so fresh and well balanced. 
My less favorite items are roasted garlic and fennel soup (it's a little bland) and the bhel puri, cause I'm just not that adventurous I guess. 

Yeah...Dosa is probably not "traditional" food, but they don't pretend they are traditional.
author: Nadya K.

description:
I came here a few weeks ago with a friend for dinner on a Thursday night. I had heard about Dosa before, so I was excited to finally try it. Between the two of us, we ordered samosas as an appetizer, channa bhatura (her) and habanero-mango masala dosa (me).

Overall, the food was delicious! My habanero-mango masala dosa, despite being spicy as hell, was really yummy. It was served with two types of chutney and sambar. I really like dosa, but will probably pick a less spicy entree next time. I would definitely recommend this place if you want to eat non-pretentious Indian food in the Mission.

-L.
author: Leeann C.

description: I would give a sixth star if possible. I was visiting SF and was treated here on my birthday. This place has awesome cocktails. AaramSe is something you shouldn't miss. Appetizer portions are great for sharing. Go for the lamb kheema dosa if you are a carnivore. I was super impressed by the dessert menu and restaurant overall. This is not your usual Indian fare. Its different and so much better
author: Vihar D.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed and devoured the food at Dosa. First sign that Dosa was going to be a good experience: the majority of the people there were actually of Indian decent.

The three of us ordered three dishes to share, after some general advisement from the nice guy at the table next to us. We ordered the Paper Masala Dosa, the Uttapam (the South Indian Moons dish - which was a chef's sampling of various thicker versions of the dosa), and  Dahi Vada, which had Lentil dumplings, topped with yogurt, piped with tamarind and mint. Everything we had was so delicious. 

Ordering the dosa is an experience in itself. The waiter comes out holding a oversized, paper-thin, crepe-like pancake that is paired with different sauces and fillings on the side. As fun as it was to see, it was just as much fun to eat! 

Dosa was a very good place to bring several friends and have fun over the meal.
author: Amanda D.

description: I want to go back and try this place again. Got the combo thing last time, it was ok. Maybe their other curry stuff will be better.
author: Cindy L.

description:
After hearing so many good things from my roommate and coworkers about Dosa, I finally had to see for myself what all of the fuss was about.  I was not disappointed.  While I'm not the most seasoned connoisseur of South Indian cuisine, I know what tastes good and Dosa definitely fits the bill.

My roommate and I arrived on a Wednesday night without reservations.  There was a wait for a table, but we decided to take a seat at the bar instead.  Really it's an ideal situation for me.  Might as well just the distance between myself and the alcohol down to a minimum, right?  Since it was my first time here, the bartender offered a few friendly suggestions on what and how to order.  Having already had somewhat of an idea of where we were going, we went with the onion pakora, lamb kofka with lemon rice and chutney masala dosa.  While we waited for our order, the bartender brought over a little snack to get us started of pappadums.  These chip-ey things are awesome.  I just could not stop eating them.  They are so light and crispy and cheesy!  Fantastic!

The onion pakora arrived quickly and it was a perfect way to start.  Basically an Indian version of the blooming onion, the perfume of cumin and coriander invaded our senses and whet our appetites.  There was just enough batter to make it crunchy, but not so much so that you forgot what you were eating, it was fantastic.  Granted, it's pretty tough to go wrong with something battered and fried in my book.  

The entrees of the lamb kafka and dosa arrived not much later as our corner of the bar was covered with a massive triangle of dosa and a healthy portion of lamb and rice.  The dosa was light and crispy on the outside, which just a bit of chewiness as you bit into it.  The lamb kafka was terrific as well with six good sized lamb meatballs swimming in a spicy, rich and flavorful sauce.  The lemon rice was a perfect accompaniment to cut through some of the richness of the sauce.  The edges of the dosa also provided a nice substrate with which to soak up the sauce of the kafka.  

I again must commend the service here.  The bartender was very friendly and helpful with out orders and the service was timely.  The atmosphere here is very lively, but I still felt quite comfortable here.  The prices aren't bad here, but I wouldn't necessarily consider it cheap.  However, it's been over 3 hours since we ate here, and I'm still stuffed so that must be a good sign right?
author: Gary L.

description:
I finally visited Udupi Palace just down the way and I still prefer DOSA.  Udupi's portions are super sized and cheaper but Dosa uses better ingredients and the food is more flavorful.  -1 star since the food doesn't blow me away like it used to... something's missing.   

The crowds that used to be at Dosa seem to have wandered to Udupi (and maybe Dosa Fillmore) because the last few times I've visited, there has been no wait and no reservations necessary.
author: Mimi L.

description: food was amazing, so flavorful. I had the vegetable bhatura-a curry and the bhatura is the big fluffy bread. Sooo good. Hip ambiance. Bartenders and servers were very friendly. I can't wait to go back.
author: mel m.

description: We had a nice time there last night thanks to the company we came with and a lively atmosphere of the place, but won't be going back. The food is only average ( I eat a lot of indian food) and priced at least double what others charge.  When I asked my waiter if the bill  could be correct - about $25  for chicken Korma a he called the manager right away - who came and told me her job was to explain prices (apparently a common event) - she went on and on about how they use fresh ingredients and organic stuff and how all the other indian places have their stuff prepared in South San Francisco.  Well sorry, no I don't believe that last part.  And regardless of what ingredients were used,  the food tasted only so so  - I've eaten a lot better in even hole in the wall indian places. Dose comes no where close compared to Amber or Breads of India. This is SF - most cooks here know how to cook meat tender. This was tough - all of it from appetizer to entree.  The calimari appetizer was so tough - like chewing hard rubber.   Even when the brought out the papadum when we fist sat down they didn't bring any mint or other dipping sauce to go with it.  We made the best of it, but the food isn't worth the price or the attitude.
author: Eric H.

description:
As the name suggest, a South Indian place with panache. 'Dosa' is definitely a class apart from the usual south indian places due to its great service, warm hostess, clever ambience and awesome food.
I could smell the aroma as we entered the restaurant, which had a warm atmosphere and was crowded with people, as they were savoring the food. We were promptly seated on a Sunday night. The menu ranged with variety from the dosas to chennai chicken and an interesting wine menu. We delved right into the entrees. The preparation was excellent and surprisingly better than most south indian places in the bay area. I would highly recommend the 'paneer dosa' and their 'gulab jamun' for dessert. The entire experience was splendid and the hostess made our evening even better with her recommendations.
author: Lisa H.

description:
Excellent.
The sambar was rich, the idly was moist, and the lamb was quite savory.
The dosa was just a little too crisp for my liking, but that won't  prevent my return.

Having tried the location on Fillmore, I can throw in a comparison between the two.  This location doesn't suffer from the ultra-modern,  "atmospheric over-kill" the way the other does.  The decor is attractive, but not over done.

Service was great, and the wine list attractive.
author: Ken B.

description: Just trust the waiter, ask for a variety of dishes, go with friends, share, and enjoy a truly unique experience.  It's a bit noisy and crowded...but who cares when the food is so yummy.
author: Greg R.

description:
as good as it gets... i think they serve the best dosa/uttapam in bay area.
really love their food...will visit once again
author: V D.

description: Great food, bad service. Popularity can be rough and some restaurants manage it with grace. Dosa seems to be straining from it. I had a 730 reservation on a Saturday night. While seating us, the hostess told us we had to be gone by 815. Whoa. We then waited 20 minutes for someone to take a drink order. The rest of the meal proceeded at a similarly inattentive pace. At 850 we were politely ejected from our table. I've never been thrown out of anywhere before. To top it off, OpenTable just sent me hate mail wondering why I skipped my reservation.  Lots of other choices.  Moving on from Dosa.
author: Mike M.

description: I was walking by with four friends looking for a place to eat. We were very undecisive about which cuisine and what price range we were in the mood for. Everything stopped when the smells of Dosa caught us dead in our tracks. We didn't have a reservation but they accommodated us in just over ten minutes on a Sunday evening. The staff was very helpful as we tried to figure out the menu. The food was beautiful, in great portions and I still have dreams about it until this day. Sooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo delicious!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Veronica F.

description:
Emily says that excellent service is an ongoing commitment.  You can't pick up some 'service' at your local corner store.  You can't talk to your dealer and ask him to hook you up with some 'service'.  You never say, "I spent every night for the past two months slaving at the workbench in my garage.  It was worth it though, because now I have Excellent Service!!"

I can tell you that Dosa has 'service' in spades recently.  Four of us went to Dosa on a Saturday night.  The place was crowded and bustling.  No more so than usual from what I hear.  But our service was astounding.  The hostess made good eye contact and held a warm tone to her voice.  The bartender was ruthlessly efficient.  Our busser was quick and unobtrusive.  And our waiter was ... magnificent.  He expertly tended to drink orders, offered explanations on the dishes when we looked puzzled, gracefully humored our slightly intoxicated dinner companion who subtly grabbed his ass, and never once approached the table when were in the thick of a good conversation.  Brilliant!  I've rarely had a more delightful dinner and so I was sure to thank the owner before we left.

There's only one thing you must know about the food here: The lamb curry is pure ambrosia.  I've never once in my entire indian food eating life ever tasted anything so blissful and decadent.
author: Christopher K.

description:
I had previously visited Dosa on Fillmore and had loved it. Unfortunately Dosa on Valencia came in much under my expectations. The chutney did not really bring out the coconut flavor, the sambar was a tad sour, the masala in the masala dosa was too dry (may be stale). I ordered the paneer peas dosa and I did not find many peas or the nice cilantro flavor. 

Service was below average as well. 

Will not return to this place.
author: D B.

description:
Good bread, good meat, good Dosa, Let's eat!

I was ready to eat anything after trying to rough the traffic of tourist and the Blue Angel fans on Sunday. 

Fortunately, Dosa provided a feast worthy of a maharaja and for Queen Liz. 
Yes, in my small world (my home), I AM THE QUEEN. Bow down.

Fiery Fruit ($9) - Fruit delivered with a spicy sweet refreshing tingle on the tongue.
Paneer & Romaine ($9) - Creamy Garlic dressing gives a real kick to organic romaine, cubes of farmer's cheese, and organic cherry tomatoes.  
Masala Dosa ($10) - Creamy spiced potatoes with cashews and onions.
Paneer and Peas Dosa ($11) - Peas with spiced farmer's cheese.
Bhatura ($5) - Gigantica, soft, puffy wheat bread.
Chennai Chicken ($14) - Chicken cooked in spices to give a tangy and spicy flavor.
The chutneys are delicious here. Try the habanero-mango sauce if you want an interesting tangy, spicy kick. 

Seriously, HOT DAMN!

OVERALL: Delicious South Indian food in a hip restaurant with excellent service that provides newbies with great details about the food. What a crowd. I feel SOOOO cool.
author: Liz K.

description: very rich food with a great atmosphere. however, if you want a cheaper, more authentic dosa, go to udupi
author: Amin S.

description:
A note on wardrobe: heading directly to Dosa from your workout will not only garner you quizzical looks from the hostess, but also disapproving once-overs from the bourgey yups who apparently form the majority of the customer base.  (Also, hideous forty year old facelift in Seven jeans from five years ago: fuck you. I wear what I want.)

A note on waiting for your table: it's going to be a half hour plus, so you might as well not freeze outside the whole time. The assholes sitting at the bar will do everything they can to prevent you from getting close enough to order a drink, and the bartenders will acknowledge you wistfully, as though they understand your plight but can't permeate the jackass wall enough to actually take your order. But you must persevere. Even if it means getting your shit right up in someone's sambhar, you must persevere. Order more drinks than you need at the moment, and close your tab right away, because it will be the last time you have any face time with that bartender.
