Oh, and get up out of the sambhar as fast as you can, because homey is pissed. I mean, fuck him for not waiting for a table like the rest of us, but still. You don't want to get a beating over a hefeweizen. 

And speaking of the hefeweizen, I recommend the Pinkus Organic. It paired really well with the lightness of the food, and it's a refreshing post-workout beverage.

The menu at Dosa is stupefying. It's lengthy and exquisitely detailed (there is even an addendum spreadsheet for food allergies and vegans). Clearly, a Masala dosa is requisite, just as an archetype. I would also highly recommend you get the "Idli Moons" to share, though "share" will quickly become more like "stab interloper with fork." And despite my professed craving for the "lightness" of the food, I found the bhatura to be my overwhelming favorite. Because no matter my elevated intentions, it always comes back to fried dough with me.  

Order the $35/pp tasting menu; you'll spend more than that anyway.
author: Megan W.

description:
When I found out about this place, I was excited that a South Indian restaurant was finally opening up in San Francisco. North Indian food is tasty and all, but sometimes I hanker for the food of my childhood. I haven't gotten around to learning many of my mom's recipes, so for the moment I search far and wide for a South Indian restaurant to satisfy my comfort food cravings (that doesn't involve driving to the South Bay).

When my friends and I got there, I was impressed by the Mission hipster/modern decor. But things went quickly downhill from there. First they apparently lost the reservation that my friend had made and accused us of not making reservations. Luckily, it was early (6pm) so they could "still seat us." They proceeded to take us to a table for 6 that was directly in front of a weird hanging partition. Combine that with the poor acoustics (I had a hard time hearing people on either side of me, let alone across the table), and I was put off.

Okay, so the physical space wasn't the best. But I'm here for the food right? Yummy, crispy dosa, filled with spicy, flavorful potato curry, and sambar. Salivation. So to keep it simple, I order the most unfancy one off the menu.

I was mystified by the presentation. What any self-respecting dosa maker puts the potatoes on the side? That's the thrill of eating a dosa. Dipping the crispy ends in sambar, working your way to the yummy potato center. Besides, eating dosa is messy as it is. Having to "build my own dosa" didn't help manners. In addition, both the sambar and potato curry were bland, boring and just plain awful.

Think I'll start learning my mom's recipes instead.
author: Madhavi K.

description:
I give Dosa 3.5 stars overall.  Like the paper masala dosa and LOVE the chana bhutura.  I was full by the time chana bhutura came to the table, but couldn't let it go to waste.  The flayor and consistency of the bread is so addicting.  The soy chai was a bit disappointing., it tasted really bland and lacked some spices.

I like the Valencia location vs. the one in the Fillmore.  The Valencia location was a little more cozy and warm where the Fillmore location just felt really upscale.
author: Johannah P.

description:
Whether you are south indian, north indian or non-indian, you should definitely try this atleast once.

It gets all the stars from a great experience. Especially when you have just avoided a dismal experience elsewhere.

The food, the ambience, the service are all excellent. The food is authentic south indian and it tastes just great.

We had Rasam, Garlic soup, Chilli bhajia, Vegetable korma with uthappam and paper masala dosa. Everything was great. The korma had slightly bigger chunks of carrot and the uttappam was a tad too oily. But our waiter very nicely listened to our grievance and suggestion about this.

For dessert we went for Mango lassi and madras filter coffee. Both were good.
author: Suchithra R.

description:
After all the glowing reviews, perhaps I was set up.  Its also possible that I managed to order the two joke dishes on the menu.  

The first moment of cognitive dissonance occured right after I walked in. I'm speaking of course, of the music. I'm  a fan of the bouncy groovy music - but it's quite odd having that as dinner music -- especially in an Indian place.  (In the music's defense, after that CD ended they changed back to the more traditional music that tends to be played in a place serving cuisine of the asian subcontinent.)

(Side note to those looking for a romantic dinner: high ceiling + crowd  = trouble conversing.)

The second moment occured after I sat at the bar and got my first look around.  Is it just me, or does that food runner look just like Quentin Tarantino?  Okay - that's just odd.  Unless he's working on a film about the food industry and just wants some experience. 

The waitstaff were friendly, but it was pretty obvious that they're just about out of steam - apparently they've been busy since they opened on Tuesday.  They brought a little plate of pappadum with my beer, which is a nice touch.

So those joke dishes I mentioned? Potato Croquettes and Tamil Lamb curry.

- Potato Croquettes -- possibly a major ordering mistake.  Served with a splash of arugula and a side of ... ketchup.  I've been to piles of indian places, and the chutney of the "57 varieties" has never before made its apperance as a side dish.  (Or does that still count as a vegetable?)  The Croquettes were decent - could have been more intensely flavored, and crisper.  From the menu description I was more expecting a South Indian variety of Samosa.

- Lamb Curry.  The curry itself was good.  I thought I detected a bit of raisin in the sauce.  Could have been spicier - but those of you who have eaten with me know that I like pretty much everything "just a bit spicier."  

(okay, actually my brother claims that when folks ask me if something is spicy or not, a caption should appear in front of me that reads: "Professional driver. Closed Course. Do not attempt.")

So the curry by itself was fine. They brought out with it a plate of rice - surrounded by more pappadum.  No really, I've still got plenty of pappadum on the other plate, that I was enjoying with my beer.  The basmati rice was ... unfragrant.  No cloves in this rice, no carrots, no saffron  - just a pile of white matter.

With "Misrilou" playing in my head, I walked from dosa disappointed.
author: Stephan W.

description:
I've now been to Dosa -- whether for dinner or for a weekend brunch -- at least twenty times since they opened, probably more. Having just eaten at Udupi Palace's new SF location down the block, I was reminded about just how good Dosa' cuisine is. They continue to take South Indian cuisine in new directions, without veering from tradition too much, and Anjan and Emily (the owners) remain a charismatic fixture of why this place keeps packing them in. 

I can't wait until their Fillmore location opens:  you can count on me stuffing my face both there and at this original location, just don't get too close, I might bite.
author: Nish N.

description:
ok, I'm giving it an extra star - it's in my neighborhood and I love South Indian food. I know I'm in the minority here, but color me "dosappointed". I have visited South India and had great traditional meals both out and at my friend's home. This food was just ok, maybe traditional, but not close to what it could be. The place was loud, our server seemed really kinda out of it, checked with us once in an hour- we had to get her attention-after we were almost done. I can understand- I used to wait tables- but you know fake it a little...or go ahead and be pouty, but ask me if I want another drink or how the food is- cos then I would tell you it's either bland and starchy or hot-spicy, still without much real flavor. Without the long wait and at half the price I would maybe go back just for some quick spicy cheap food, but none of that's happening...so I gots to say nosa to dosa.

owner man: don't bug me. at all. you have plenty o bidniss. let squinka be.
author: Squinka C.

description:
This is my first one star review on Yelp (if I could give you 0 stars I would), but I think this place must be hiring marketing specialists or something because the food was very standard in quality and lacking in atmosphere.

Here are the basics:
Plus two stars for the amazing Mung Bean Salad and the Dahi Vata. 
Plus one star for serving Southern Indian food in the Mission.
Plus one star for the lounge feel inside, its is nice inside but the paintings were pretty tacky

Minus one star for the long wait for a table and the strange acting hostess
Minus one star for the inflated price (normally Dosas are $5 in the SF Bay Area or even cheaper in San Jose)
Minus one star for serving meat at a Southern Indian restaurant
Minus one star for not serving unlimited sambar
Minus one star for the sambar, it gave two of us bad heartburn and stomach pains
Minus stars for the semi-soggy Dosas we ordered, they were not as good as I was hoping. I was embarrass that I choose this restaurant.
Minus one star for the switch of waitstaff in the middle of our meal, we went from the most attentive and friendly waiter I have ever experienced to the rudest waitress that made us wait for the check for over 30 minutes.

This place is way too pretentious. The Dosas are not special here and the atmosphere is severely lacking, it is just HYPE. Try Annapoorna in San Mateo for affordable, good South Indian food, homestyle or Alhamra (on 16th near Valencia) for cheap, Northern Indian food in the Mission.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
I wanted to take my family out to a nice dinner, but i just felt embarrassed after taking them here. 

-This place is just too confident for it's own good. It looks nice and fancy, but is really just a facade of intimidation trying to get you to say to yourself, "Oh, I should really like this place, because it's neat looking."

 - "Have you been to Dosa before?" The waiters and waitresses ask before they didactically try to convey the importance of the menu on metaphysical levels that can only be attained with repeat visits. The staff  is comprised of lame people that probably talk really loud on cell phones in public places and partake in lame fire related hobbies (i.e. twirling fire balls on strings) and they poo poo cool fire hobbies like making instruments and cars that shoot fire. Our waitress spent about 10 minutes trying to explain the menu, which really made me uncomfortable, especially since the menu is really not that hard to understand. 

-I liked the fiery fruit salad (it didn't shoot fire balls), but their signature potato dishes are so bland, and you pretty much just eat sauce for dinner. 

-The push button on the bathroom door does not work, you have to use the dead bolt. I learned this the hard way, as did another poor soul who caught a glimpse of me wiping :( 

Really, my main issue with this place is the staff and ambiance. This place thinks it's way better than it is.
author: Killian E.

description:
The seating was a bit snaggle-esque.  The hostess told us we'd have a table in 45 minutes so we went to Range for a drink.  When we got back to Dosa the hostess was hemming and hawing so I had to firmly but scarily remind her that I'm an awful see you next tuesday (work it out) when hungry and a lil' drunk.  Luckily, she accomodated us immediately and my companions were only a little appalled at my behavior.  Hey, somebody had to do it.  We got a table, right?  

The food was splendid and the vibe was fabulous.  Read other reviews for more helpful food descriptions.
author: Mokirobinson M.

description:
"How many of you think   you are a creative person? Raise your hands." Almost all of us consider   ourselves  creative and we raise our hands and give ourselves 5 stars. 

Being "creative" is not enough. We need to be able to harness our creativity by innovation, convert our creative insights into new mental categories and combine them into coming up with new approaches, create perpetual novelty to the senses and come up with products and services which the customer was not even aware it existed before(like an ipod).

If I were to tell you that I am going to open an Indian restaurant in the Mission, I will be greeted by the yawns of "yet another boring spicy Indian restaurant". One couple did precisely that. Only difference was that they applied their Intelligence and effort in researching the Indian restaurant market and coming up with an unique concept of focusing on the Fine dining South Indian market(south Indian and fine dining, I would have said that it is a contradiction in terms) and DOSA was born(Winner in the Fine Dining Non-Pakistani/North Indian category).

DOSA is the epitome of San Francisco hip where patrons patiently await in a long line savoring the Valencia corridor experience. The chance factor is very important in restaurant business but the owners of DOSA, by following Pasteur's maxim
 " Chance favors a prepared mind" 
are laughing all the way to the Bank.
author: Kaustav C.

description:
3/1/07 Quick update from my earlier review below...one of the owners contacted me to point out the prices reflect the high quality of organic ingredients and their zip code. He also mentioned he was sorry it did not work out for me. I really appreciate that kind of attention to their patrons. 

Not sure what the fuss is all about. Long waiting time and the food is ok at best, but it is definitely not worth the price. It's also very crowded so not a good place for a quiet and intimate night out. Service was friendly, though understaffed. I give it one star because it is just such a bad value. If they cut the prices by 30% to 40%, I'd probably give it three stars.
author: Veggie S.

description:
As review 832, you should already have a decently clear idea that 5-stars isn't unusual for this palace of South Indian naan noshing glory. (Or perhaps a little crêpe spilled the rice, lentils and other juicy deets.)

Whatever the case may be, when Nish N, the guru himself, is selecting, ordering, and buying...you know it's gonna be good. When he lets you pair the wines (with added help from the mix-master sommelier,) the meal is "ruin the rest of your meals for life" good.

Best served with a killer group of community managers from around the country and a bottomless pit of a stomach. 

Quote of the night:
"Dosa? As in Bull-dosa?"
author: Laura N.

description:
I finally got to visit Dosa after hearing countless times about its non-traditional brunch fare. You know you've hit the culinary jackpot when A) the South Indian restaurant you visit is filled with actual Indians *gasp* and B) you spy Nish there with his family. 

JR and I settled into our seats with a sweet mango lassi to study the menu and the somewhat boisterous crowd. With the help of our server, we settled on a few choice items, and before you know it, they arrived in full glory. 

I had forgotten how much fun it is to eat with your hands! The "South Indian Moons," a selection of 5 uttapams (sort of like savory crepes), came with fresh coconut chutney, tomato chutney and sambar, which made for an exotic medley of dipping sauces. Oooh... and the vada sambar was a feast for the eyes and the palate! 

I docked a star because the spicy slaw was nothing special, and the dosas were too similar to the uttapam platter we ordered to fully enjoy them. I can't wait to study up about what to order and go back! I feel like I've just touched the tip of the iceburg.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Dosa probably deserves more than the two stars I'm giving it, but that's just the way I feel about this place...I probably won't be going back and here's why:

1. There's cooked cashews in a heck of a lot of their dishes.  I *hate* cooked cashews, so was frustrated from the get-go (even though I was happy that we were seated right away when our party of four got there on a Sat at 8pm, I had to look at the menu for a very long time to figure out what did and didn't have the dreaded cashews).
2. I ordered the South Indian Moons Uttapam and found the lil' pancakes that came mushy and not all great, depending on what was in them (the onion and peas & onion were good, but the one with peas and red something or other was awful--and, one of them had cooked cashews! ugh!).  However, I did adore the channa (best I've had) and chutneys that came with them (best mixed together!), but hated the sambar (too thick and sour for me).  Overall, I'd say it was worth a try, but not at all worth the $13 price tag.  No way.
3. For starters we had the Vada Sambar (you can probably guess from the comments above that I hated this dish), which comes with gooey dumplings (yuck) in sambar (double yuck), and the Dahi Vada, a lentil dumpling in yogurt and spices.  I have to say, I really enjoyed the Dahi Vada (particularly the presentation--it was beautiful with white and brown striping, you just have to see it) but again the price just wasn't worth it ($7 each).

Other folks in my party ordered the lamb curry, which they said was amazing, the mysore dosa (so-so), and the seafood curry (okay).  Adding in three beers, our bill (including tip) came to about $120.  I think that's waaay too overpriced for what we got.  And, yes, the decor is pretty, but it was noisy, hot, and folks were crowded together (waiters were literally tripping over people). 

So, even though it's good to try new things, I will probably not be going back.
author: Cassidy P.

description:
I went to Dosa once, and that was enough.  I went on the suggestion of a friend who insisted the food was amazing.  The food was good, not the best south indian I've ever had (not like the kind my friend's family fed me!), but the service was really terrible.  See, I'm the kind of person that usually makes reservations for this type of "hip" establishment, because it's the kind of place where you will have to wait eons otherwise.  However, that's exactly what happened anyway.

A group of 5 of us arrived around our reservation time, and were told we had to wait.  About an hour and a half later my friends were more than annoyed, but I insisted we stay.  Once seated, I was so annoyed I couldn't really enjoy my dinner. The service left much to be desired, especially after waiting so damn long on the street.  I have not gone back since.

UPDATE: After writing my review, not 30 minutes later I received an e-mail from one of the owners.  He apologized for the service and then turned around and told me that I was wrong about their reservation policy.  Like I once told a woman whose child kicked the back of my seat for the entirety of a 3 hour flight, don't apologize do something to address the problem.  Perhaps if he spent less time stalking yelpers who didn't rave about his place and more time actively managing the establishment so that these issues are resolved, then Dosa wouldn't have as many angry reviewers complaining about waiting and bad service.
author: Lorraine L.

description:
The worst Indian food i've ever had. No indian in their right mind would eat there. Overpriced, no flavour, the waitstaff spilled red wine on my friend and didn't offer to pay for dry-cleaning.....

And it's such a shame as the lighting/atmosphere is so lovely. Decent wine selection, nice atmosphere (very first-datish), terrible food.  Much rather go next door to Herbivores.
author: shelly p.

description:
The food's fine, but as others have pointed out, the service tends to border on impolite, especially on Saturday nights. Beware!

I, along with 2 friends (one of whom was Indian) went there last saturday. My Indian friend went in to ask about the wait, and was told 1 hour. My (asian) girlfriend went to the restaurant and casually asked about the wait while coming back. She was told 25 minutes. Note that my other friend had just asked about the wait 5 minutes ago and was told 1 hour. Unbelievable. Anyone know of a non-racist explanation to this?
author: Em E.

description:
I just don't get it. 

I live around the corner from this place, and on a damp, downright COLD San Francisco night--last night, for example--warm Indian glop on soft bread sounded good. I was also inside most of the day Fighting the Good Fight with Photoshop CS2 and I couldn't bear to eat one more meal in front of a screen. So, out to Dosa we went...I can practically go there in my bathrobe.

But then, I don't think I'm ever going there again.

The first time I went to DOSA was when it  just opened, and let's say I was pretty unenthusiastic. It was basically a big $10 pancake with some thin, soupy Indian food smeared on it. But one night I ran into some rich friends who were standing outside in line in the icy mist, rosy cheeked, with such anticipatory smiles on their faces I thought maybe I should give it another try. 

They said it was their "favorite Indian restaurant." My current favorite is ROTI, despite the iffy service and the distinct feeling that it's mild Indian food for, uh, whatever the Indian word for gringos is. Gentiles? Goys? Whatever. I love Roti, but I didn't want to give up my parking space and drive to West Portal.

So last night started out a little disappointingly. We walk around the corner from my quiet, impressionist tree-lined street and guess what?Young hipsters! Hipsters with piercings and tattoos--well, yards more piercings and tattoos than colonize me and my boyfriend. Hipsters Out on a Friday Night!! Hipsters standing in line to experience the manna that is DOSA!

That star up there?That's for the Botticelli's Venus that was seating people. She was lovely and sweet and I wondered whether I had such nice curves when *I* was 23. I was bewitched by her. We waited half an hour, and my boyfriend and I shared an $8 glass of wine at the bar. I was thinking about Venus's creamy white shoulders when the bartender poured us extra wine. Which was nice because, well, when exactly did it become customary to only serve half a glass of wine? So I was cheered. But it all went downhill from there.

What can one say about spending $14 on a bowl of sauce with two chicken bones in it? "It looked so good on the menu." They have a great menu copywriter. I thought, "This item here? with the 5 pancakes chosen by the chef? That HAS to be a lot of food!" 

Like as if.

The chicken thigh bone was a bit too spicy for me, so I tried to attract the attention of our waitress to bring some, I dunno, chutney? Raita? Something sweet or cool to offset the hot and spicy and...did I detect bitter? It took quite a hub-bub to get those things. The waitress and the busboy looked appalled. Apparently chutney was only served with the pancake dish, which wasn't out of the kitchen yet. 

I looked down at my droopy little thigh bone (the one on my plate, with the sauce on it) and suggested they bring the chutney a tad early. The waitress sighed. Gringo, she thought. Wimp. I felt distinctly unhipper. How could I tell them I used to eat Indian food for two bucks on sixth street in the East Village before they were even born? ("We used to walk six blocks in the snow to eat Indian food on sixth street! We used to DREAM of eating Indian food in a corridor!")

After the Disappointing Chicken we got six little latke-sized pancakes with a bowl of inedibly hot, meatless, vegetable-less brown glop (Was it soup? Was it sauce?) and a bowl of slightly more edible garbanzo bean stew. The pancakes were tasty. There was, however, a thimble-sized cup of something pale mint-green, that tasted of almonds or something. It had green flecks in it, I think, and it was without question the best thing on the table.

We were so unsatisfied that when the waitress came over to suggest dessert, I said we were looking forward to a pint of Ben and Jerry's in front of a Netflick. She finally smiled and said that sounded good to her, too. So I finally started to like her. After all, I was a waitress for 12 years. 

Let's just say, when you spend $50 for a cheap bite out on a chilly Friday night, you shouldn't be hankering for your pals Ben and Jerry to come over for a nightcap.

The decor is nice, though.
author: Caryn L.

description:
addendum to below review:  i would not be surprised if the owners don't play fair.  After writing my initial bad review, I got a really nice note from the owner apologizing.  I wrote back to him and then he wrote me back saying, more or less, that I probably didn't know good Indian food from bad Indian food and I didn't apply the chutnies correctly, etc. because I was in a big party.  My party was 3 people!  What a jerk!

I was unimpressed.  I love Indian food and the city has such great options.  Dosa was crowded (which isn't a big deal) but the potions were small and the food was not all that great.  It wasn't bad, just not worth all the money we spent.  The service was great and everyone was accomodating and nice.  Very fast - our food came in 10 minutes - just expensive and not that tasty.  I won't be returning.
author: Reggie G.

description:
Update 8/27/06* Came by for a dinner with friends and was stuffed again full of South Indian goodness. The noise levels were a little better it being a Sunday night, although the crowds were still cranking and we had a short wait for our table. Make a reservation, which are now available and plan to have a glass at the bar.  The Leitz riesling is a great wine to pair with any of the dishes and it's only 8% so you can drink up.  My eyes are always too big for my stomach at this joint and I once again am in a serious carb coma.  The Dahi Vada is awesome still and all the dosa's are worth trying. This place is becoming a local staple. End update*

*Update 6/28/06 Returned for an 8o'clock dinner and was pleasantly surprised with my meal again. Especially the Dahi Vada which is a visual and gustatory splendor.  Although the noise issue hasn't been rectified, the food was even better than the last time and our waitress, although Mission hipster extraordinaire, was quite pleasant and knew her south indian cuisine. The Taj tallboy was a necessary addition to our otherwise fantastically spiced dinner.  For anybody who has been frustrated with over oiled indian dishes, I would highly recommend Dosa, to see how it can be done  proper.  My new request is reservations.  *end update*

Original Review: 
Dosa does a good job of re-reintroducing South Indian cuisine to San Francisco. The crowd is a Mission blend of everyone that makes the  hood so special. The food was good quality but not quite outstanding.  The atmosphere is busy cool but the noise levels made me feel like I was a grumpy old man. 

For my personal gustatory pleasures, I prefer driving to  Cupertino or Fremont for my carb happy pleasures of dosas, idly, uttapams and sambhar. There is no bettter guilty pleasure than that warm cocunut chutney feeling when you look around and see that  you're the only white guy in the joint, and the kids are staring at you wondering how you discovered their secret.

Overall, if you're not feeling the scenic 280,  Dosa is a good choice for South Indian,  so enjoy the tighty whitey waiters and the chitter chatter boom box.  FYI, for another version of authentic ethnic cuisine done well in a cool upscale style, check out either Limon down the street on Valencia.

Dosa is new to the scene, so I'll be checking back to watch their progress. As with all new endeavors, it takes time to work out the kinks in the curry.
author: Phil M.

description:
I haven't had such a pleasant dinner in a long time and dosa was able to deliver that to me. The restaurant is small, intimate and dimly lit, perfect for a date. However, the tables are pretty close together, so refrain from speaking dirty or baby talk to your date because the people next to you can hear you very clearly.

The majority of the menu is occupied with a list of dosa and uttapam. I'm too lazy to explain it what they are, so just go directly to their website http://dosasf.com/menu.html
Miss K (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=1Idc35tGsgkB3G2ntig0LA) got one of the dosas... can't remember which one. I got the paneer and peas uttapam, just because I like to be different. Nyah.

Now, I have never had southern indian food before and have never even heard of dosa so I didn't know what to expect. The dosa was pretty big, compared to the uttapam. I was slightly disappointed about that at first because I was hungry and I picked the smaller dish. But by the end of dinner I was actually pretty full. The mango lassi probably had something to do with that because it was really really thick. A bit too sour for my tastes though.

Anyway, the food was really good. all the dosa and uttapam are served with a lentil..something..something... soup (sorry, bad memory) and 2 different kinds of chutney. I couldn't tell which chutney I liked better because I keep mixing everything together. It tastes better that way! Besides, I was just following the "tip for first timers" on the menu. Basically it tells you to put a little bit of each chutney on a piece of dosa/uttapam, dip it in the soup and eat it. It's really good! I think the coconut/white chutney will burn your tongue slower than the red one, but the spiciness doesn't linger.

Lastly, our waitress (Christy?) was really nice and pleasant. And I notice that Dosa is the most diverse indian restaurant I've ever visited. Usually when I go to an indian restaurant, all the employees are indian guys. But Dosa employs all white, yellow and brown people. I thought that was pretty cool.
author: Ari C.

description:
By far, the best Indian food I've had in the States.  I was in Rajasthan earlier this year (Northwest India) and ate in the homes of several Indian families.  And although DOSA is Southern Indian food, the food served here still definitely has that homecooked, authentic vibe to it.

I actually loved all the dishes.  Lentil chicken was oh so tender....the prawn masala was savory and non-fishy....the Dahi Vada (lentil dumplings with yogurt) was hella good and I'm generally not into cold dishes or dumplings to be honest.  The Prawn chile fry appetizer was tasty but the portion was kind of small.  And the bhatura!!  I love this bread.  Big and puffy and slightly sweet.  Yum!

One of the drawbacks to this restaurant is that they don't take reservations.  We had to wait 15-20 minutes on a Thursday night for a table for 3.  I also circled 15-20 minutes looking for a parking spot and ended up finding one on 18th and Valencia. I can't imagine what the weekend wait and parking situation is like.   Next time I will definitely cab it.  And lastly, if spice is not your thing, talk to your waiter before ordering and they will accommodate.
author: LaSha G.

description:
The food is absolutely amazing!  I've grown up eating home cooked Indian food so can tell when the food is crap, but this place definitely passes the test.  I'm not sure I like paying that much money for Indian food, because to me it's like Chinese food - it should be really good but really cheap.

Went there on a Saturday and it was ridiculously crowded so make sure you have a reservation (there wasn't even room at the bar).  Service was great.  It was a little too dim in there for me but I suppose it's all part of the ambiance...
author: Dina B.

description:
Sometimes I think about the habanero mango dosa when I'm doing other things, like sitting at work. I like that, when ordering this, I have to ask for an extra napkin, to wipe my head with. It's not outrageously hot, just some extra heat, but the flavor combination is sensational and when I'm in front of the microwave at work, and it's noon, and my little frozen meal is on minute three, I think back to how happy I am when the cool heat dosa is brought to me.

Naturally, and I realize it is silly to even suggest it, but should they ever open an East Bay branch, I would cry salty tears of pure habanero joy.
author: Ross G.

description:
Burly pal and I go out for dinner to Dosa.  We're not familiar with much on the menu.  "What should we get?"  "Let's get dosas...  if the place is named after them, that must be the thing to get."

We select 2 vegetarian dosas, carefully picked to avoid nuts, which I am deathly allergic to.  I think to confirm with the waitress when we place our order...  "There are no nuts in these, right?"  Turns out ALL of the dosas --every last one of 'em-- have nuts in them.  The potatoes are cooked with nuts, and everything's cooked on the dosa grill.  Even a lot of the meats are cooked with nuts.  Glad I asked!!  They really should say something on the menu about that...  hence the minus one star (generous on my part, I think).

As a nut-free vegetarian, my only option is the curried bowl o' beans (it did have an Indian name).  I am less than thrilled, but go with it.  I have to say, even though it was the last thing I would've ordered, it was amazing.  The spices were complex and interesting, the texture was good, and it came with this great bread for sopping it all up that was bigger than the plate it came on and my own head!

The place feels crowded and noisy, but you should go anyway.  I may not go back, since I've had the one item I can try.  Unless you ask me nicely, in which case I'll go cuz I'm easy like that.
author: Andi T.

description:
I recently went to Dosa with a friend. It's a good looking place but as Jerry Seinfeld once said, "Oh, it's a scene man". First, it's annoying that they don't take reservations. Second, the place is about as loud as a night club. We sat by the front window and it was still hard to hear anything being said. 

As for the food, we split one dish of chicken curry, one uttapam and one dosa, plus we each had a beer. The food was flavorful, but the total tab was like $60.

I don't mind dropping some cash for outstanding food or food that is hard to find, but I'm sorry, but I can get way better Indian food at a way lower price at many other places in the Bay Area.
author: Yogi B.

description:
Went here on a Monday evening at around 7:30.  I could smell curry from three blocks away.  I prayed that there would not be a wait . .  10-15 minute wait for a table, but seating available immediately at the bar.  Not bad.  

Service was super friendly and helpful.  Neither of us had tried South Indian cuisine before, so some explanation was required.  And a good number of check-ins without being annoying.

Tried the bhel puri, paper masala dosa, and kerala chicken. Holy God, that paper masala dosa was huge.  It was about three feet long.  The dosa proved to be a bit challenging to consume because it kept crumbling apart, but it was probably my favorite. The sambar and coconut chutney were delicious.  

Honestly, the paper masala dosa probably is enough food for two.  We hardly touched the kerala chicken, only ate about half the bhel puri and didn't even finish the dosa!
author: Jenny R.

description:
This was my first time having Southern Indian food and it was amazing. I loved everything and from the house specialty the dosas to the heirloom tomatoes and the mango icecream.

The chennai chicken was a great appetizer. And the butterfish dish was delish and savory and filling but not heavy. 

The staff was polite, helpful, and knowledgeable. All in all this is the kind of place where you keep bringing people back to introduce them to what will soon climb the ranks of their favorite cuisines.
author: Maria A.

description:
Overpriced.  Overcrowded.  Overrated.  It's way too much of a hassle to eat here for what it is (hour long wait for a table, anyone?).  You're better off eating at Pakwan on 26th and Valencia.

P.S.  One of Dosa's owners emails people who review this restaurant negatively on Yelp.  As such, I would interpret some of their high ratings with a grain of salt, as some of these positive reviews may have been influenced by a fear of being stalked.  Creepy.
author: Mike M.
A J.

description:
Fairly average Indian food, but great ambiance. Usually Indian restaurants are nasty, smelling, playing Hindi music and have dirty or sticky tables. This was a refreshing change from the USA norm for Indian places.

EDIT: I initially gave Dosa a four star rating. Everything before the word "edit" above is the same as it was before so you can read what I initially had to say. I am adding this because a MANAGER OF DOSA, who goes by the name of Anjan, PATROLS the DOSA page on yelp and messages you!! Insane! 

One yelper who gave Dosa a one star rating was harassed by Dosa owners (maybe it was the same guy??) on Yelp (see the one star ratings) I believe it, and have had it happen with other restaurant reviews on yelp. 

Dosa now gets two stars!  Good job Dosa police!!
author: G J J.

description:
Too crowded.
Too sceney.
Too uptight.
Too loud.
Too expensive.
Too contrived.
We were asked to vacate our table about 5 minutes after we paid our bill...Lame.

But, the food is pretty good, even though its definitely not traditional. Dosa is going to take a big hit when the new traditional and home style South Indian opens up 3 doors down on Valencia and 21st. This new place, Udupi Palace is a third restaurant in a small Bay Area chain of cheap, good, vegetarian South Indian food.

If Dosa just didn't take itself so seriously it would get a much higher rating in my book...
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Total disappointment.

Food: Uninspired - leftovers wrapped in a tortilla and microwaved.
Decor: Stressful - a schizophrenic combination of modern chic and high school cafeteria.
Service: Apathetic - only the requisite order-taking and bill-delivery in very poor time.

Don't be fooled by the creative descriptions. It's just TJs-style frozen-dinners dressed up with (tasty) sauces.
author: Surely I Am C.

description:
I didn't enjoy this place. It's not as authentic as you can get down the peninsula.

I think I was disappointed in the food, and then the service was ridiculous. People should try the indian restaurant down the block. It's much better.
author: doug d.

description:
I've been here a couple of times. The first time with out-of-town friends was good, but not the best South Indian food I've had. There were four of us at a tiny table, so they had trouble fitting the food on the table. Not a comfortable situation. I've had much better dosas, but the uttapam was excellent. I was disappointed with the vegetarian selection since I'm used to much larger or total veg selections at S. Indian restaurants. The chutney situation was weird--they're very stingy with it. 
The second time we went I was not happy with the food at all. The uttapam was too crispy and thin and the vegetable curry was bland. And the prices are much too expensive.
Honestly, once Udupi Palace opens down the street, I'll be able to get my S. Indian fix there, so I'll probably never go back to Dosa.
author: Wan T.

description:
This San Francisco semi-institution has quickly hit its stride.  The concept.  Modern southern Indian cuisine, updated and inventive without being fusiony.  Upscale but informal trendy.  The namesake crepe-like dosa are fun and novel to us San Franciscans. You can have a good time here.  A foodie haven, a winning formula for ethnic food much like Cha Cha Cha,  Slanted Door, or Ti Couz.

The room is often packed to overflowing, couples touching their faces and playing with their hair, lost in each other more than the food.  An enthusiastic staff of unevent professionalism and expertise scurries through like water down a cascade, randomly tending to this or that.

My first visit was slightly disappointing.  The idea works, and a very good chef is at work.  The weakness is execution, particularly service.  The waiter was awkward, the ninja food runner hit-and-run, slapping things down to the point of sloshing on the table then dashing off without explanation or checking or cleaning up.  He kept tugging at our half-finished plates, touching and moving them before asking if we were done.  Eventually he  yanked them away with food still on them without asking.  When done we told the waitress and host we wanted the check, no dessert.  Then we got, you guessed it, dessert menus and one of those strip tease waiter routines to get you to eat sweets.  It's group service, so you get random treatment from a lot of different people.  Overall the service is quite attentive, just  frenetic and unpredictable.

Wine and alcohol is very expensive but food is quite reasonable.   $6 for a bottle of Anchor Steam?  Double no thanks.  But the crowd thinks otherwise, snapping up red wine by the bottle, nothing under $40, because that's what they like.  White wine is $8-11 a glass (they charge far more than the customary 1/4 of the bottle price for an ungenerous pour). 

The "fire broth" was thin and enticing but small, incomplete, it left you wanting to eat other things.  I think that's the purpose.  So that one hit the mark.  Uttapam sampler had five seemingly identical open faced tacos with various sauces.  My dosa was an interesting crispy crepe but the potato filling, a solid hunk of food matter, was not completely satisfying.

Kitchen staff gets slammed with more orders than they can handle so things can come out a little uneven and needing seasoning corrections.  A few things could use a squeeze of lemon (which wasn't offered), a little more or less salt, a different condiment. 

This place has lots of potential.  With better execution, simplifying the menu, a few key signature dishes, it will break out of just being a good times hangout to become a more serious restaurant.

Second visit - upgraded to four stars.  Not all the way there but closer.  Tried some more dishes and hit some jackpots.  A lamb curry, for one, and calamari appetizers.  Some personal attention from the charismatic owner helps - he really loves the food and his customers.
author: Gil S.

description: I had a meal here on a Friday night after ages... Everything was excellent. I can't wait to go back for the calamari appetizer!
author: A T.

description:
I wanted to try this place because of the strong/high marks and since it's been named the best Indian food in SF for a few years (something like that).  

We ordered:
1. Onion pakora - tasted similar to a blooming onion, they just give you an eggplant dipping sauce to make it seem Indian.
2. Chennai chicken - this was okay, nothing to write home about.
3. Veggie curry - again, nothing that great.  I was expecting more zing or zang to the spice.
4. Chatni masalsa dosa - my boyfriend thought it was okay but nothing amazing.

If the menu on Filmore is different, we might give that a shot but we don't see ourselves coming back to this one again.
author: Carol S.

description:
Update: Went here for my birthday and I had the chennai chicken appetizer, the chicken bumped it up to a 5 star. Wow.

As an Indian, albeit a North Indian (and this is a South Indian restaurant), the food was fairly good. I was in the mood for a dosa (hence the restaurant name), but found that I couldn't get the masala dosa because they already had the cashew nuts in the potato mix (I'm allergic). So I got the chicken curry, a little bit on the spicier side, but I liked that it wasn't bland!

Downsides: I wouldn't go here on a romantic date, it's a lively place where you can't really hear your dinner companion. 
Upsides: it's good for some decent Indian food when you are missing good home cooked Indian food!
author: Radha S.

description:
Named for the South Indian crepe made of rice and lentil flours, Dosa is a haven for gluten-free eaters. Although their entire menu is not gluten-free (ask and they'll give you an allergen cheat-sheet that tells which allergens are in which foods), Dosa's focus on South-Indian cuisine reveals just how versatile gluten-free grains are, and how core those grains can be in some cultures. It'll make you feel like other cultures' foods were made for your tummy.

The pungent scent of Indian spices greets you at Dosa's door, and sticks to your clothes when you leave. Their menu focuses on two styles of South Indian pastry, including the dosas -- stuffed with vegetables, curried potatoes or paneer cheese -- and uttapams, which are more like pancakes with a variety of items mixed in. The dosas and uttapams are served with a pair of chutneys, typically coconut and tomato, as well as rich lentil soup that they cook for nearly a full day before bringing it to your table.

Dosa also offers an array of curries and a tasty range of appetizers -- but stay away from the spicy Chennai Chicken, which is unsuspectingly dusted with flour. On top of everything else, the prices here are reasonable, especially for such deliciousness.
author: Beth W.

description:
One of my very favorite places to eat in good ol' SF!

I'm an Indian food fan, but DOSA is Southern Indian food, which is pretty different than anything I'd experienced before.  Your server will ask you if you've been before, and if not they'll give you a rundown on what to expect and some suggestions about what to order.

LISTEN TO YOUR SERVER!  They want to help you.  And they know their shit.

My experiences at DOSA have always been wonderful.  Some favorite dishes are the Masala, the Rava Masala, the Fiery Fruit Salad (super fucking good!), the Cochin Calamari and the Channai Chicken.

Go to Dosa.  Run, don't walk.  You can thank me for it with a b.j. later.  :-)
author: Christopher S.

description:
Yes. Dosa is worth the hype.  Once again, I wanted to hit one of the big hipster havens and write that, really, it was seriously over-rated.  I'm thrilled that Dosa proved me wrong, and provided a delightful dinner adventure.

We arrived, this Saturday evening, right when they opened. There were already 3 or 4 parties waiting but we were seated immediately in a fabulous window table.  It helps that it was a gorgeous July evening in the Mish, which made for great open-window dining.

From the moment we sat down, the service was EXCEPTIONAL.  Our server was charming, attentive, and extremely knowledgeable about the food and wine.  I hate it when I ask a server for a suggestion and they reply with "I dunno. (*giggle*) Everything is good!"  Not at Dosa!  She had useful suggestions, and great explanations about every menu item and the wine to go with it! THANK YOU!

It's been a few years since I've had Southern Indian Food.  I love it.  It's hard to find so I consider it a big treat!  I wasn't sure if Dosa could live up to my hopes but they absolutely delivered -and then some.

We ordered from the prix fixe menu with wine pairings.  As each course was laid out, Steve and I argued over whose choice was better.  (I maintain that all of mine were.)  The food was DIVINE!  Each plate contained a symphony of deliciously spiced treats and just the right amount of cardamom--which to me means cardamom in everything.  

I hate to say it, but I wasn't thrilled with all of the wine I sampled.  I had a pinot noir before dinner that I didn't even finish -and I LOVE pinots!  I also didn't expect the tempranillo that was paired with the 3rd course to be a rose.  If I could knock a half a star, I would, but everything else made up for it in spades.

Four course prix fixe dinner for two with wine pairings and two extra cocktails came to $150.  They aren't cheap eats but there's plenty of bang for the buck.  We went home with full tummies, leftovers, and very happy faces.
author: Amy A.

description: I really like Dosa. Everything I've eaten here has been delicious and service has always been a-okay. The tasting menu is a great way to sample a different dishes. Personally, I prefer to just order a dosa (spicy mung masala is deeeeeeeeeeeelish) and a soup. The crispy fish pakoras are very light and yummy too. I've been to both Valencia and Fillmore locations and the only reason why I kind of like Dosa Fillmore better would be because of the atmosphere and the really cool door in the front entrance.
author: Queenie C.

description:
Totally overrated!!
I felt it was also overpriced for what is essentially street food. The place is very attractive, but it's much more style than substance. The food was decent, but not worth the price tag, especially when you consider that almost the entire menu is vegetarian. 
There are loads of other Southern Indian restaurants in the bay area at much better prices.
author: mary y.

description:
Went here to celebrate hubby's birthday with the family on Saturday night.
Six of us had the Dahi Vada and the paper dosa as a appetizer.  As a entree we had 2 types of dosa, 1 spicy mung masala dosa, vehhie korma with coconut rice, 2 south indian moons Uttapans.
I love carbs so this place was perfect for me.
The entire family enjoyed it very much.
Will definitely go back again.
P.S- I would strong recomend to park on the parking lot .  Its hard to find a parking on mission but is also a much safer choice.
One star less? Small and a little too crowded.
author: Emy B.

description:
This is an update from the first visit in 2008.  There were two greeters at the door who are now, thankfully vanished into outer space and replaced by two guys who were wonderful and very welcoming this last Saturday.
We knew the food and the service would probably be good but the initial impression at the front door truly lasts.
We had a reservation for 8:15 and were seated as soon as we got to the door at 8:10.  The place was booming.  Last time our group of 10 or 12 made our own noise, so I had not remembered that the place plays techno music and was a bit loud, but it seemed to work ok once we were settled in to our food.
The food was fabulous.  
Chennai chicken appetizer was plenty for two.  Delicious and tender.
My friend had a crispy dosa with lamb which she liked and I enjoyed the onion rava dosa thoroughly.  Spice was perfect!
We mingled with the people who are unfortunately too close to each other on the left wall, but they were cool.  I think they could take a few of those tables out and skip the music, or put something authentic Indian softly in the background, but it would not deter me from coming back.
The price was good for what we had.  We did not have dessert because we savored the entree so much.
So convenient to 24th St Bart because parking can be tricky.
Thank you Dosa for ditching the two awful hostesses and placing some customer friendly hosts in their place.  That alone will bring me back and I hope to try the Fillmore location too, based on the pleasant experience this visit.
Looooove the Indian food.
author: Ellen O.

description:
At Dosa, I had my first dosa -- which is a South Indian crepe -- which is really a form of Indian crack.

Their masala dosa was filled with potatoes, onions, cashew nuts, and an unidentified substance that makes me crave it a day after eating it.  

I will return to try everything on their menu.  I am not kidding.
author: Tim G.

description:
For the Spicy Mung Masala and spiked Pomegranate Garnet for my (magic) 28th birthday last night, I am eternally grateful.

For the Shiva Nataraja dancing on the back of the demon dwarf of ignorance behind the bar, I am suddenly pious.

For the wait staff possibly too entranced in meditative states to attend to things like questions and requests, I am not totally impressed.
author: Alex Z.

description:
Good but overpriced.

Came here with a gf for dinner and we ordered two dosas. As it was our first time at Dosa, we immediately scoured the menu for our usual tikka masalas and were aghast to find no curries on the menu!!!! But we ordered vegetarian dosas, which came with several sauces. It basically tasted like a crepe with Indian spices. It was well-done but I wasn't v impressed with the meal overall.

I'd come here again because the ambiance is nice and it's a good date spot, but when I'm really craving Indian grub... to Naan n Curry!!!!!
author: Cheryl F.

description:
Finally made it to Dosa.  Stopped by today after a sunny day strolling around the Mission.  

Two of us arrived at 6pm (Sunday) and the place was already half full.  We were seated immediately after being greeted by the friendly hostess.  

We ordered the Dahi Vada (lentil dumplings) starter which was beautiful in presentation like a painting and it also was the most amazing flavor experience.  We then ordered two dosa's the Rava Masala and the Paper Masala.  Both good but I really think one dosa would have been enough.  Paper thin dosa so you don't think it's a lot but man does it expand in your tummy.  One minute you feel fine and then WAPAH! you're instantly in a dosa food coma.  My dosa food coma was so bad I ihad to walk it off all the way home to the Lower Haight.  

A couple things. . .my dining partner is very familiar with South Indian dosa and says Dosa is pretty good.  However, the Lassi was not good.  It was much too salty and it was made with yogurt instead of buttermilk which he prefers.  

Dosa is good but all the hype had me thinking it was going to be something more.  I don't think I'd go back to Dosa if I did not have a South Indian food lover in my life.
author: James M.

description:
Dosa lives up to all the hype, especially when you get your bill-- their food is reasonably priced considering how deliciously gourmet it is.  Try everything when you're there.

I had never had South Indian wine until Dosa-- it pairs incredibly with the spices and seasonings, but isn't very good standalone.

I think green wines would go wonderfully with South Indian cuisine.
author: Abendigo R.

description: This venue is smaller in size compared to the venue on Filmore street, so I definitely recommend making a reservation if you have a large party.  My friends and I decided to sit near the bar area.  The mixed cocktails are creative and tasty, and the appetizers and entrees are delish!  It also helped that our friends were regulars and knew exactly what to order off the menu for us enjoy a wonderful dining experience.  I would recommend getting the crispy fish pakora and the lamb keema.  Would definitely come back and also try the Dosa on Filmore as well!
author: Janice M.

description:
I love this restaurant. Yes, it's crowded and busy but it is delicious. Not to mention the woman who owns this restaurant is lovely and truly cares about her customers and their experience.  
I choose DOSA to go on a date because I wanted to go there and my date was incapable of figuring out where to take a vegan. Loss of brownie points for him. I choose wisely!
It was a friday night and the place was packed. We waited for an hour or a little more but it was worth the wait. I was in love with everything. Plus, DOSA also offers a vegan/vegetarian ingredients list for needy people like me. The food was excellent, service was perfect! I was dreaming about DOSA fro the next two days that I had to eat there again 2 days later with other friends.

I disagree with people who says the place is overpriced. You could easily get two items and share bringing your bill to no more than $25 without drinks of course. I have yet to do the tasting menu which I want to try sometime. So.. maybe another date with...
author: Eryn L.

description:
I was a bit skeptical when I walked into this place.  Trendy Indian restaurants usually bring out cynical side of me, mainly because they lack the authenticity in the eating experience.   Cloth napkins?  I'll stick to the paper ones thank you very much.  Silverware?  The only eating utensil I need is attached to the end of my right arm.  Ceramic dishes?  What happened to the stainless steel plates with the three compartments?

Despite this skepticism, the food was actually decent.  And entertaining.  One of the waiters came over and offered to show my friends and I how to eat the pani puri dish, but after seeing that there were two brown people at the table to provide assistance, he figured we could manage.  Little did he know, I'm an awful friend.  One of my buddies tried to carefully poke a hole in a puri and ended up shattering the whole thing.  Another poured the pani into his puri only for it to come leaking out all over his arm and the table.  My roommate just said f*** it, ate his puri and then took a swig of the pani.  Needless to say I laughed my ass off.  Almost as funny as watching me eat with chopsticks...

The bhel puri was excellent and the sambar that came with nearly every dish was suspiciously addicting.  I was not too pleased with my paneer utthapam (I guess the place is called "Dosa" for a reason) but liked most of my friends' dishes.  Waiting staff is also courteous and vigilant with the water refills...but we did go on Sunday for brunch when it wasn't too crowded.

Overall, the food was good but seemed to be catered to fit the chic ambiance of the restaurant...in other words, it was overpriced ($8 for a plate of six pani puris?  Aren't Indians supposed to be frugal?)  The taste is more westernized as well, so I probably wouldn't bring my Indian parents here (that would be equivalent to bringing your Asian parents to P.F. Chang's).  Go here if you want to eat some good, semi-authentic south Indian food that won't leave your clothes smelling for weeks after (damn you Naan N' Curry)
author: Satyan P.

description:
Why write the 704th review of Dosa? Because I am perplexed at the high ratings.

Everything started great: cool atmosphere, packed room, great service, great explanation of the Dosas. And the starter, recommended by the waiter, was excellent: Chennai Chicken, boneless chicken marinated in yogurt, spiced and fried, served over greens. So far, I'm liking it.

Problem #1: _Do not_ order the tasting menu. At $39, it's expensive for what you get. My Lamb Kofta had two meatballs the size of nickels. A complete disappointment for what I was paying. My friends who avoided the tasting menu had reasonable servings at reasonable prices.

Problem #2: _Beware_ of going with a party of 6 or more. We had 7 and received a 20% service charge, rather steep, but when Dosa slaps on another 4% surcharge for S.F. Heath Care, you end up with everything on menu really 33% higher with tax, tip, and surcharge.

Paying $85 for one beer, one glass of wine, one tasting menu, where the main is tiny is absurd.

Aside from feeling gouged, I wish Dosa could solve the pricing problem. Some of the food is very good. Some of the Dosas average. It nets out to Decent Indian food in a cool atmosphere for high prices. Pass.

P.S. I too have been emailed by the owner. Although I appreciate his thoroughness in reading these reviews, he needs to take to heart the criticism on price/quality/portion. I agree with Lorraine L's review: http://tinyurl.com/5g5o2k: the owner needs to address the problem, and not write three-page rebuttals. Perhaps the owner could write these rebuttals for the Republican National Committee and spare me.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Atmosphere: GREAT--just right candle light
Service:  PROMPT and ATTENTIVE--lovely hostess
Food:  Mashed potatoes by any other name...are just the same! 

Enroute to my pilates class I drove pass this place and made a mental note to try it out just on its window appeal. Two hours later, the line was out the door and maybe that's why we stuck out our 35-minute wait, despite the rain. (The bar set up so close to the window tables leaves no room for standing inside and enjoying  a drink while waiting.)

Being first timers we relied on our server and the menu to dictate our choices:  masala dosa and the other crepe-like thing (sorry, it was my dates' dish and I don't recall the name.) The menu enthusiastically suggested the first and our server exclaimed about the second, "great combo if you two want to share," she said.

I cannot disagree with her more. They were the same filling--mashed potatoes, mashed peas, and where were those cashews??--just in different wraps. I had to ask for another helping of the chutney to give the food flavor. Mashed potatos by any other name...

Luckily we had also ordered the prawn curry and that was yummy.

I've read the other reviews for DOSA and so just may give it another try...or not.
author: R T.

description:
Stellar service.

Solid food -- very clean for Indian food but still quite heavy. I'm used to the Indian/ Pakistani food that I had in London, and this place was an interesting change. The dosas kind of remind me of Eritrean food, which is always a cool break form your usual dining experience.
Ordered the samosas and the chili bahjia + sweet onion chutney -- the latter was pretty awesome, good balance between the spicy and the sweet.

Had the paper dosa, cilantro/mint dosa, and the spring dosa. All quite different, vegetarian and fairly light on the palette until full consumption. It's not cheap, but the food also feels a lot "cleaner" and the atmosphere a lot more refined for your usual Indian spot. 

Wouldn't say I'd frequent this place but I would definitely come back.
author: Chieh T.

description:
Dosa is certainly one of the more heavily-hyped restaurants I've been to.  Overall, it kind of makes the anticipation of going more stressful than it ought to be.  But what can you do?  

It was actually quite easy to get a table here: we were a party of 5 so I simply made a same-day reservation on OpenTable.  I had heard recommendations of doing the tasting menu, but with 5 people it was really much cheaper to order a la carte.  We ordered two sambars, lamb vindaloo, vegetable korma, channa, a paneer dosa, a masala uttapam, and an extra bhatura.  It turned out to be more than enough.

I guess it's important to note that Dosa is *not* just a typical indian menu plus dosas.  They're serious about doing it south-indian here.  Not that I'm an expert on south indian, but I do know north indian and this is not it--they don't even have naan (but don't worry, fellow naan-lovers: the bhatura will win you over with its oily goodness).  There's also precious little in the way of meat dishes.
  
Ironically, though, we actually found the curry dishes, not the dosa/uttapam, to be the highlights.  My personal favorite was the korma--worlds apart from the rich, buttery stuff you get at Roti--which was loaded with cloves or something, because each bite was like spicy Christmas in your mouth.  Still, the dosas have a subtle, nut-infused deliciousness of their own.

Dosa is well known for doing wine pairing, but my experience is that every indian dish needs a different type of wine, so we just went with Soju cocktails (and by the way, Soju has officially reached hipster saturation at this point--witness Soju & Vitamin Water, the official drink of the Treasure Island festival).  Of course, I still maintain that beer or scotch are the optimal drinks for indian.

All in all, don't let the hype hold you back (or drive you here against your better judgement).  For serious indian food fans looking to explore new territory, Dosa is essential.
author: Wes M.

description:
Good food. The mung bean salad was my favorite. The lamb kofta meatballs were over spiced so you couldn't really tell it was lamb. Overall the food gets 3.75 stars. Consistently tasty, but not as good as Pakwan.

Also, they don't have naan! Naan is possibly the 2nd best food (next to Skittles, of course) and if I had a restaurant (even if it weren't an Indian restaurant), I would serve naan. So I was a little disappointed that a South Indian restaurant wouldn't have naan.

Service was good: polite, helpful and timely. But the tables are too close together. We were getting bumped into from all sides. Two of us by customers seated at adjacent tables and one of us by servers. At one point, my boyfriend had to stand up to let a server go by. It's not like the restaurant is insanely fancy, but at about $35/person, it'd be nice to keep your seat.

The bathrooms are nice and clean. The desert menu is predictably uninteresting. I'd might go back, but Pakwan is so much tastier and cheaper.
author: Ana D.

description:
The entire time I was at Dosa, I kept comparing the cuisine to a more casual South Indian restaurant called Saravana Bhavan in Sunnyvale.  Dosa is okay, not great. The sambar was too thick, the chutney's a bit odd tasting and the masala they used in the sambar tasted like MTR or a brand I don't particularly enjoy.  I would give the mango lassi a second chance...it had a certain zing to it ( yes, I said Zing!) and woke me right up. 

 I will give them props for great service & decor.  They accommodated our group of 15 people around 10:45 ish.. right when the chef's and waitstaff start to get antsy vacuuming around your table ( that did happen to me at another restaurant..it was comical)

As for the decor, there were two striking paintings, one of ganapathy & another of a pink lotus that I wish I could have taken home with me.
author: Amruta G.

description:
Everyone loves Dosa.  Yeah, yeah, yeah.

Let me break it down for you.  Maybe you can understand why my Dosa love is unenthusiastic, and more like a "Dosa?.....Don't-sa sound so good unless we are going on a date."

First the BAD:
Dosa = Not great for large parties.  Read: parties over 5 people.  Who don't travel together.  In packs.  Tied at the hip.  Admittedly we had a party of 8.  Two of which were stuck behind a car accident they could do nothing about.  Yet, they refused to seat us,  and despite having reservations (AT 5:30, when no one was there), we amicably bellied up to the bar to wait. Which leads us to my next two observations...

Dosa = Kinda small, and one hell of a dinky walkway between the bar and the dining area.

DOSA = Bar-tendress was a totally unfriendly, unhelpful, and downright rude.  We were all dressed to the 9's, being delightfully polite,  and ordering many wondrous, not-so-cheap foo-foo drinks.  Go figure.  Next time I will sit there, taking up space, swearing like a sailor in my gym clothes, while sticking out my tongue.  And I will be ordering many, many, mixed virgin cocktails. 

Hell hath no fury like a birthday girl scorned by a crabby bar-tendress.

So here's what I don't get, Dosa.  You know we're a large party, with 6 nicely dressed, polite people, obviously drinking/spending a crap-load of money for a birthday dinner...Why not just seat us in the table you've set aside for us anyway, let us order a bottle of champagne and some appetizers and kick it for the 20 minutes we have to wait (while getting the hell out of your walkway...)?

The GOOD =
Dosa= Finally sat us, after some finagling, and didn't blink an eye when the 2 late-comers hopped in our table, prior to our ordering.  Our waitress handled it oh-so-amazingly well (yay, things start looking up!), and was super helpful in aiding us in our culinary choices. 

Dosa= Waitstaff is extremely knowledgeable about their cuisine, and make excellent recommendations.  They posses the key to de-mystifying the wonder that is the food of Dosa.  

Dosa= As everyone says, delicious food and drinks.  I had the lamb curry, and for my first baby sheep experience, it was quite a heavenly de-virginizing. We passed around our various dishes and each one of them was presented beautifully, and tasted great.


CONCLUSION = Dosa good for dates.  Dosa BAAAD for big birthday.  Dosa likes you when you're eating, and likes picking out good things for you to eat.  Dosa bartendress does not like you (or anyone else for that matter, it seems).  

If I rated Dosa on food and drink alone, it would easily be a 4-5 star shot.  But half of the experience rests on the customer service..and that ranged from absurd, to great, and back to bizarre at the end.  

Thanks for the mediocre customer service experience...with the great food...I guess.
author: Christy B.

description: Mm, the uttapams (pancake-esque take on the dosa) are so tasty here. I got the "South Indian Moons," which means the chef picks five different uttapams for you. Carmelized onion, paneer & peas, masala were the ones that stood out, but carmelized onion was definitely the best. For an appetizer, we got a salad of fruit spiced with hot pepper. Interesting flavor blast, but not sure I would get that salad again. The place was gorgeous: pale orange and candles up the wazoo.
author: Kevin L.

description:
The first thing you'll notice is the irresistible tastiness of the crispy herbed crackers; I can't remember what they are called now, but you only get one serving of them for free, unless you ask nicely, and perhaps a bit pathetically.

Then you might be thinking it's time for a proper appetizer: while you can't go wrong with anything on the menu (as it all generally has an appealing, hearty spiciness to its flavor) the chicken chennai will blow your mind if you have any sort of appreciation for chicken nuggets. They have been redefined by the kind people at Dosa, and come highly recommended, by me.

Then you have to make your way through the rest of the menu; if you've never eaten at a South Indian restaurant before, you'll be all, "What?" So just get the masala dosa, like the menu says. It's the tastiest weird-thin-pancake-filled-with-spiced-mashed-vegetables you will ever have in your life. Just note that this place is mostly vegetarian, as that's the predominant diet in South India, apparently.

And be forewarned: you will stuff yourself mad at this place, and then on the walk home you will notice your stomach swelling. That's the way this food works, for better or worse, so mind your greedy, ravenous belly.

I've never managed to save room for dessert, but from what I remember they have some sort of "cheeseballs in cheese sauce, with cheese" dish that sounds wonderful to these cheese-loving ears. And I can highly recommend the coriander beer, based on how much my girlfriend savors its "don't call me cilantro" flavor.

In the high school of restaurants within walking distance of my home, Dosa would be the cool exchange student that made friends with everyone quicker than you ever did. Delicious!
author: Max H.

description:
Yep I know this place is too popular. But I'd post my review here nonetheless. I do this because this restaurant deserves it.

I only wish Dosa would become less attractive to people so I wouldn't have to wait. :)
author: Kenn E.

description:
yes this is a great new place.
I was also lucky to go to the pre-opening and everything was amazing.
Service is excellent and the food is so damn good.

Go and check it out.
author: Gianmaria C.

description:
Wanted to check out Dosa to see if it's possible for any restaurant to survive in this seemingly cursed location.  We got there early and were seated right away, but by 7:30, the place was packed with a line out the door.

I'll admit from the start, I'm a fan of northern Indian food over Southern so my tastebuds created an argument against this place long before I unfolded my napkin. In the end, I found the food rather average. The Masala Dosa was slightly bland and the accompanying sauces, though filled with potential, lacked punch. The lamb dish was decent, but not impressive. The sauce was fairly bland, the meat a little tough and the rice sparse.

Fortunately, the chai and the service were great.
author: sara s.

description:
The waiter made my night. Alex was his name and without him I'd be ticked because it was pricey and not as good as a hundred places in the East Bay. What was so great about Alex? He walked us through the differences between North and South Indian food in a way that, despite that he must have to acclimate to the hipster population to work there, wasn't bored and condescending. He was pleasent and competant and made up for the so-so food and pretentious people everywhere. So-so food because you have higher standards the more of the hard-earned that you're dropping.

**Beware that the owner is a little unclear on how to make folks like his place better. Rather than offer free things he tries to argue with you about your review. My experience is my own and no jackass comment showing up in my inbox will change that. There goes a star.
author: Mer S.

description:
What can I offer that hasn't already been said? A.M.A.Z.I.N.G.

While I tend to favor Northern Indian cuisine to Southern, Dosa didn't disappoint. But I would have been surprised if it had since Nish N. was our host that evening, and you just know he's going to show you some of his fav places in the city. 

The heirloom tomato risotto and heirloom tomato coconut salad were both delicious, and I was happy to have one last chance to savor these delicacies before the season ended. 

The butter fish (aka black cod) special was tender, and the dosas (my favorite being the paneer and pea) were light. One of my favorites was the Chennai chicken appetizer. 

In general, Im a condiment sucker, and Doza is heaven for those who love to dip.
author: sarah p.

description:
Thinking about eating Indian food makes my stomach do somersaults.  Generally speaking Indian spice and my GI system don't get on too well.  But I had a feeling I would do OK at Dosa.  Yelp definitely turned me on to this place, though I had noticed its enticing orange interior and styling storefront before.  It seemed worth a try.

It. Was. All. Delicious.

Now, does someone who knows very little about Indian culture and who generally avoids Indian food loving your restaurant speak in its favor or to its detriment?  I'll let you decide.

The Dahi Vada (lentil dumplings drowned in - like, literally hidden underneath a flood of - Strauss Organic Yogurt (not sure why the brand is so important as to be on the menu, but whatever) )was a delightful mix of spicy, crunchy, cool, refreshing, minty, salty, sweet YUM.  Leftover yogurt made a great dip for Papadums.  

We had a curry with prawns and tomatoes, the name of which is escaping me (ie, it's not on their online menu, which I am obviously consulting because I have a total mental block for non-Latin-based languages - and French, incidentally).  It was another spicy salty sweet sensation of flavor which encouraged me to eat way beyond my comfort level of fullness.  Delicate, savory basmati rice accompanied.

We split a Dosa as a main entree.  My dining partner pulled some kind o f two-Dosa hibrid with the waitress.  As it was already stuffed with farmer's cheese and peas and spices, it was not much for dipping in the overabundance of unidentifiable chutneys, plus the lentil/eggplant soup thing (internet says: "Mysore" - which they served on the side instead of spread).  I used a spoon.  The combination sent me into a place of isolated deep contentment, from which it was hard to hold a conversation.  I was sad we could not finish it, that we once again ordered too much food.

I like the innovative menu, nevermind my need to be coached by a professional through the ordering process.  There is much of intrigue to try here, and that encourages me to come back.  Everything was exectued well and the space was intimate and not too noisy.  This place is a winner.

Did I just write winner?
author: Jennifer B.

description:
What an interesting food experience!!  Wonderful flavors delivered to the table in forms I had not yet encountered.   When eating the dipping sauces with our dosa and uttapam we played the game where you identify a new ingredient with each bite.   The ingredients were not complicated, but their pairings were ingenious.  Mmmmm!!  For a deliciously dramatic dish, try the Chana Bhatura - hot air is rarely put to such good use.

The wait for a table for four was a tad long but we had not made reservations for our Monday evening dinner and the place was nearly full.   Couples were seated almost immediately.  Make reservations for weekend nights.
author: Mike B.

description:
An interesting Indian restaurant! But there are definitely tons of better places for the prices they charge. The food tastes okay but it is not authentic. 

The place is also jammed with tables that it feels like you are in a tight fitting jigsaw puzzle.
author: Rajan P.

description:
Dang dude, 800 Yelpers already told you it was good... what are you waiting for? My favorite dosa was the one made out of corn meal. The curries were all fantastic. But I was most happy that we ended our meal with a chai that wasn't presweetened. 

Go with a small group so you can try everything!
author: L. M.

description:
I love the idea of serving good authentic ethnic food in a modern atmosphere!!  For some reason, it makes the food less scary to people who are intimidated by foreign waiters and lace doilies on a table.   So, I was excited to try DOSA after hearing good things.

By the look that our waitress gave us, we seemed to have ordered a lot.  We started with the DOSA version of chicken fingers - tasty but nothng spectacular.  Then came our lentil dumpling appetizer that was smothered in an artistic display of mint puree, yogurt, and some kind of plum sauce....there was a lot of sauce.  I like to be saucy, but not to eat food that is super saucy!  Good sauce, but still we decided that it was a classic case of "diminishing marginal value." 

The lamb stew was delicious with just the right amount of spice...and oh so tender.  But the "DOSA" wasn't that great.  We had the flat crepe-like one, but we should have chosen the fluffier, thicker one.

It was interesting to try a new side of Indian cuisine, but I don't know that I'd ever "crave" DOSA.  There is also a great quaint, trendy, Mission atmosphere and great DOSA drinks.
author: Annie C.

description:
Good Indian food and excellent service...

But really overpriced. Meal for 2, which was 2 Dosas and 1 shared curry, was $50. That's not including drinks or dessert.
author: Andy A.

description:
So Dosa is consistently packed.  We showed up around 7:45 and were told there was a 20 minute wait so we headed up to The Make-Out Room for a drink. When we returned (I think we missed our spot) we were informed that it would be another ten to fifteen.  I have zero patience and contemplated trying someplace less crowded. Luckily we decided to stick it out. The hostess came out side to let us know that our table had opened up ...and it was on. It was extraordinarily loud in the restaurant but I didn't really feel like it hindered our conversation at all and I'm the soft spoken type. 

We started with the Organic Greens, Mango & Sheep's Feta Salad. Those flavors accompanied by red onion, toasted walnuts and topped with an understated (didn't overpower the other flavors) yet amazing cilantro dressing definitely made for a great beginning. I had the Spring Marsala dosa and my dinner companion had the Paper
Masala. Both were excellent and I'm a meat mouth.

A new word has been added to my lexicon. That word is Sambar. The menu describes it as "a flavorful lentil dipping soup made with vegetables". Flavorful is the understatement of the century. Soooo Gooood! I think our server mentioned something about 31 different spices but I was slightly distracted by the little voice in my  head repeating "Go Gene, Go Gene, Get busy, Its your birthday" and the dull roar of a packed restaurant as I savored this delectable (There's crack in it) soup.

Dosa gets five stars for excellent food and the fact even though they are doing well (I've got to  assume) yet haven't forgotten what hospitality is all about. I've lived on Valencia for over 6 years and I have seen quite a few establishments open at this location and then quickly disappear into hazy memories. From the look of it Dosa will be around for a while. Sweeet!
author: Mingus R.

description:
When you walk into this place, you feel like you need to be some well-dressed, super rich snob to fit in. But don't let the contemporary, trendy atmosphere fool you- this is really good food. We start with the Dahi Vada, and I always have Dosa or Uttapam. I love it.
