The boyfriend had lamb curry last time we went, and he said it was delish (I don't eat meat, so I just got to watch and wonder). One time I also had the Mango Seed cocktail, which is pretty much an alcoholic version of Mango Lassi. This place gets busy on the weekends, so I'd recommend either making a reservation or showing up before the dinner rush. In all, even during the rush hours, the service is great and so is the food.

UPDATE: My boyfriend and I returned to Dosa last night, for the first time in a while. The last few visits we have noticed the slow-down in service relative to our first few visits about a year ago. The food is still on par, absolutely excellent. And, in general, the wait staff is friendly and kind. However, I'm close to taking off a star just for the extremely slow service. Don't tell me I have a 20 minute wait and seat me an hour later...
author: Erin M.

description:
It's easy to think that Dosa would be a place you would like. You take one look and you can tell it's a charming place. The signage is nice, the decor looks fabulous, the music is cool and the crowd waiting outside looks hip and hungry.

I was warned the wait would be long. I just didn't think I'd spend the whole night starving.

I anticipated it being crowded so I showed up there around 8ish to put my name on a list for a large group. The hostess said the wait would be 1hr 20mins. I gulped but accepted it.

Came back with crew 1hr 30 mins later. No luck. This is where starvation beings.

The hostess just sucked. Granted, it's a hard job dealing with a bunch of hungry people who want to sit and eat. But you can't just ignore them. Part of the job is working with customers, the more proactive, the better. 

We constantly had to go to the hostess instead of her coming to us to find out what the hell was going on. How much longer would we wait? At one point she said that they stop seating at 11pm and we'd surely eat before then. I couldn't believe my ears. 

After a while, I had the distinct feeling that the hostess wasn't being genuine with me or the other patrons. I often heard her using the same excuses like, "Oh the people at your table are about to leave.." or "the people at your table are eating dessert" or "the people at your table are just sitting there and we're waiting for them to leave." While the hostess was civil, her concerns for the patrons was definitely not genuine. 

At hearing this, people with baited breath would wait another 20-30 mins while the people at the tables they were waiting for were supposedly "done and just sitting there." Please. We saw people come and go and be seated and it didn't make sense that a group took 30-45 mins to order dessert and pay.

We ended up waiting a total of 2 hours (2 HOURS!) and sat around 10ish. I heard no apologies from the hostess when we sat. 

I can understand if patrons are lingering, ordering dessert, whatever. But keeping customers waiting indefinitely is just wrong. Giving them really bad time estimates is just wrong. If I knew we'd be eating at 10:15 instead of 9:30, I surely would've gone elsewhere and come back to Dosa another time. 

Foodwise: The spring dosa was decent, the vegetable korma wasn't. Maybe it was my fault ordering korma at a south Indian restaurant. The spring dosa was good but not any better than one could find at any other decent dosa place for much cheaper. 

The only reason why I'm not giving 0 stars is a person who seemed to be the owner/manager came to us and sincerely apologized for us waiting so long. He was very kind and removed the obligatory tip from our bill. He also explained that it was an especially busy night. 

Unfortunately, our whole group was brewing angrily outside for the extra 45 minutes we waited (on top of the 1hr 20 mins we were told) and the damage was done. 

(In all fairness, we still tipped a fair amount because we did not want to blame the waiter for our unpleasant experience as our waiter did a decent job.) 

So, patrons, consider yourself warned. Dosa, the food was good but not worth the wait. Personally, I'll be looking for other South Indian restaurants next time I get my craving for dosas.

Here' my breakdown:
Hostess: 0 stars.
Waitress: 4 stars. 
Owner/Manager: 5 stars.
Food: 4 stars. (3 stars if you take into account price)
Food worth waiting? NO.
author: Pete C.

description:
OK... So we returned on the evening of Monday, March 23rd.  Honestly, we were so incredibly disappointed, I've been tossing up giving a two star rating.  However my other visits do not justify two stars, so I am going with a three... for now.  

First of all, to make a reservation for 5, they request a credit card number.  What?!  This isn't a white table cloth, high end restaurant... what the heck?  Someone please explain this logic, because I just don't get it.

The food was decent.  We started with an order of Pani Puri.  We've been for Sunday Brunch, so we knew what these were all about and were very much looking forward to it.  However, these came out stale.  Possibly day old from Sunday brunch?  They weren't crisp, and it wasn't easy breaking through them with a spoon.  Incredibly disappointing.  The Fiery Fruit was great as always.  There were five of us, so we ordered several dosas and uttapams.  They were great, however two of them were so similar we couldn't tell them apart.  Wish our server would have enlightened us about this fact when we placed our order.  

While our server was pleasant (blond with glasses), and competent, nothing particularly shined.  Another server came and brought out some of our dishes, she was incredibly unpleasant.  (medium brown hair) Her attitude was horrible, and it was noticeable in her tone, and her body language.  She even seemed to purposely run into one of the bus boys because he was in her way.  Another turn off.   

I should also mention, the gentleman filling my water spilled some in my dipping sauces and on the table without apologies or acknowledgement.  Not a droplet, but a decent amount spilled and landed in my sauces.  My boyfriend sitting across the table from me, chuckled a bit when he saw the whole thing, and the guy heard him, and slammed the water down on the other side of our table.  Um, yeah.  What do I really say to that?  I'm typically pretty darn easy going when it comes to service, and dining, but this was straight out of control.   

I should mention one more good and bad experience for the evening...  When we paid the bill, we didn't notice the automatic 20% added for gratuity.  Apparently that's their policy, a party of 5 or more automatically receives 20% gratuity.  Doesn't that seem a bit excessive?  A 5 top is considered a large party?  I don't know.  We didn't notice it, and someone, possibly the floor manager, brought it to our attention.  That was one of the very few redeeming qualities of the night.  So thank you for bringing this to our attention.   

Ugh, I just don't know if this experience is deserving of three stars, but I'm going with it based on my past experiences there.  Maybe this was a severely off night.  Again, our food was mostly decent, but we left feeling like we paid a lot for what... some decent but not outstanding food, and mediocre to sub-par service.  What happened???  Dosa used to be a favorite of mine.  I'm afraid it will be some time before we return to this neighborhood spot.
author: Kelly K.

description:
I absolutely love Indian food, although most of the Indian cuisine I have had has been from the northern part of India. Dosa is strictly South Indian fare and is out of this world. When you walk in, the colors of the walls and the smell of the spices will warm you instantly. The small bar offers a small collection of Indian beers and a longer list of wines and mixed drinks. Once we were seated, I ordered one of the dosas and loved it. It was a perfect balance of seasonings....the spices were distinct but were not overpowering. The pleasant surprise was that the meal was very reasonably priced--$9 for a very filling dosa and $7 for a beer. 

I will definitely be back again!
author: Jenn G.

description:
Yes this place is really good and yes its been reviewed 2 million times.... but there are a couple of things you should keep in mind:

* Stick with the south indian food - the curries are overpriced and overrated

* you must get the idli sambar - it kicks major ass

* make sure to arrive with your entire party - or you will sit hopelessly at the bar while other peeps steal that great table with a view

* alcoholic drinks are really good

* you can get the exact same food in fremont/san jose.... for about 1/3 the price
author: D S.

description:
I just want to mention that this is actually good South Indian food - this is not a trendy place that's just getting away with a butchered version of a lesser known cuisine. In case anyone was worried about that. 

IT IS SO GOOD. The lines outside at all hours are not good, so I just wind up eating an early bird dinner to avoid the chaos. It's worth it and I'm old anyway.
author: Shal J.

description:
Before I start: My mother makes the BEST dosas in the world...just thought i should put it out there.
Now,  I never thought I would come to this place, just because I know how much a "good" dosa costs, but a friend of mine wanted to try this place; so we strolled in around 7:00pm on a Thursday. The place was packed. we sat at the bar, my friend ordered a glass of rose, and I ordered a glass of malbec(reminded me of my trip to Mendoza, Argentina), it was really good wine. 
For food, we ordered a plate of idli, it came soaked in sambhar, and side of two types of chutney. So here is my one issue, I do not like my idli swimming in the sambhar, I would like it to come seperate, just because idli can get mushy...but having said that I loved the sambhar, LOVED it!!!, I would pay $7 for the sambhar alone(even though I thought it was on the expensive side).
We also got masala dosa(which is my personal fav), I loved the texture of the dosa, it was really soft,  with well spiced aloo(potatoes) inside. The cost was $10, again on the expensive side, but worth it...because of the sambhar...
Overall: if  you go, i would say sit on the bar, it is a much better experience, and order idli(if you have not tried it yet), but make sure to ask for the sambhar on the side
author: BOSHIKA T.

description:
If half stars were an option, I'd give 3.5.  I've chosen to round up on this occasion.

I've been to Dosa twice, and neither time have I left particularly impressed or disappointed.  I should say that Vik's is my Bay Area Indian food standard.  I know that Dosa serves southern Indian fare, whereas Vik's is northern, but I'm an idiot, so...

We had the Samosa's for starters (totally decent) and I had the Paper Masala which was okay, but not fantastic.  Look, it's a nice place with decent ambiance.  It's a great place to take a date, but it's just not what I look for when I go out for Indian. 

Ambiance: 4 stars, small place, a little noisy, a good blend of classy and casual though.
Price: 3 stars, not great not bad, totally average
Service: 3.5 stars, We had about a 10 minute wait even with our reservation (which I consider to be acceptable).  Servers were relatively friendly and attentive, but not exceptionally so.
Food: 3.5 stars, if you're in to southern Indian food, my understanding is that this place is pretty decent.  For a neophyte (like me) I think most people are better off going with a Uttapam instead of a Dosa...just my thoughts.

Again, totally not bad, but I won't choose to go here again.  If someone I'm with is dying to go, I'm there, but it's definitely not my first choice.
author: Thomas K.

description:
The ambience- more packed than the Filmore locale but has a hip, happening vibe in keeping with the Mission location. nice bar upfront with some interesting cocktails. Warholesque collages with Indian themes adorn the walls.

The food- the small plates were excellent and nicely presented- the pakoras and samosas perfect. Dosas and uthappams are simple South Indian breakfast food although getting increasingly getting complex and sometimes overly so. Dosa has the basics you cannot go wrong with- the simple masala, paper, and rava. Others are questionable-like the truffle one or the three-cheese one. The chutneys and sambhar accompaniments were tasty as was the rasam.  If you are a spicy food buff, don't miss the habanero-mango masala dosa. The chutney burns but is worth it. The selection of other curry dishes were a bit limited for a vegetarian but this is a dosa place and you go there to get,  umm, dosas (see note on service below). The dessert menu was tempting but other than the rasa malai which was well done, others were a bit disappointing and not worth the price tag. Just go to bi-rite.

Which brings me to service which in this occasion was a little wanting. The waitress was trying to change everything people were ordering to the point where I was going ask her to pay the bill as well. She was over blowing the habanero chutney (which she insisted be on the side instead of inside the dosa) to be some sort of Krakatoa in a cup which turned out to be fiery but not volcanic as she made it out. She also questioned our choice of too many dosas claiming that they will taste the same but once again this is a dosa place and in food savvy sf, even the non-indian locals know a thing or two about Indian food and how to order. 

Overall a bit pricy but worth the experience. Udupi down the street used to have good dosas a few years ago at half the price but not any more so I will be making more trips here.
author: Manoj S.

description:
I've wished for years that someone would open a South Indian place in my neighborhood. They finally did, and the food is unquestionably good, but I really feel that the place doesn't address my demographic as a long-time resident of the Mission.

Lets put it this way: the first thing that happened when we went to be seated is that we were scowled at for wearing thrift-store clothes, then seated as far in the back of the place as they could put us. Then, during our meal, the guy at the table next to us was complaining about the tenants that he'd had to Ellis-act evict from a building he owned. (I'd hate to use phraseology as unseemly as 'yuppy toilet' or 'douche' in an article such as this, but, well, I guess I just did.)

The place is not even that expensive, comparitively, it's just that you could feed an extra person or two on the same money at, say Udupi Palace in the East Bay.

The food is neither the best nor the worst South Indian food that I've eaten, it's just presented very artfully.

I'd call it an ok place to eat if you can stomach the 'New Valencia Street' types that crowd in there. Do they prepare food to go?
author: David M.

description:
I visited Dosa a few weeks ago with my family and was wholly underwhelmed by the experience.

An overview of my complaints: very bland/mediocre food, high prices given the quality of the food, and non-Indian wait-staff.

So, the food. If you've ever had high-quality, authentic Indian food, this place will severely disappoint. The spices have no zing to them and taste as if they've been in the freezer for a year or two. Both our dosas and udapam were quite bland. The dahl was the one redeeming element of the meal, being quite tasty.

Second, high prices... Maybe these prices are normal for the city (I'm from the peninsula and so don't eat in SF all that often), but this place really seemed overpriced to me. The decor was classy--they were going from a contemporary Indian look from what I could tell--so maybe that hiked up the price a bit. However, it seems to me that if you're going for contemporary, then the food as well as the decor should be so, and this was definitely not the case. In any case, fabulous Indian food is definitely available elsewhere at this price.

Finally, the non-Indian wait-staff. First of all, it is just a little strange to be eating Indian food and being served by a 100% white wait staff. yes, perhaps I should be open to new concepts, but it just feels rather non-authentic. Additionally, this fact makes me think that perhaps the whole venture is not even owned or operated by an Indian family. Hmm.

In sum, skip this place and go try out one of the city's million other fabulous restaurants.
author: Chelsea H.

description: The food here is good, but not as good as (much cheaper) places like Vik's Chaat in the East Bay.  Once in a while, though, I do appreciate the more unusual options at Dosa -- think kale or broccoli rabe.  And the little mung bean salad they have is spicy and delicious.  Dosa is also a nice place to take friends who are vegan or have celiac disease, since it has a "special needs" menu with everything clearly marked.
author: B. R.

description:
Great balance in this cuisine and a nice place for Sunday brunch.

I was delighted when my Paneer dosa arrived; light and stuffed with a variety of vegetables. The grilled cheese was not dripping from it but chopped finely and in concert with the delicate spices and vegetables.

I never had a dosa until today and was expecting a crepe. Again, a dosa has a balance of crispiness and softness and not at all greasy.

Try dipping the dosa in the different sauces. Each sauce affords a different taste. My favorite was the coconut chutney with mustard seeds. I didn't care for the sambar (thought it was a cup of soup until I asked).
author: Adam W.

description:
I'm not an expert on south indian cuisine. Chances are that unless you're from there, you haven't eaten much of it either; South indian restaurants are few and far between. After dining at Dosa I was able to put together a short guide so that you won't feel so lost while looking at the menu.

Chennai chicken - Think of buffalo wings or strips, only with the most tender chicken you've ever tasted, and seasoned with a spicy  rub (I think there's a little coriander in it) instead of wing sauce.

Uttapam - It looks a lot like a latke, only depending on what kind you order, it will have all sorts of different vegetables mixed in, and are served with a bean dip like sauce, one that closely resembles tikka masala sauce, and another that is a little bit like hummus. Also it isn't Haunakkah yet.

Dosas - savory crepes, more or less. served with the same trio of sauces as the Uttapam.

Lamb Curry - Imagine a fantastic spicy lamb stew with rice. Much darker and heartier than what you usually think of as curry.

Their wine menu is about 3 pages long; they've got pretty much everything. Just don't try to leave the bar without closing out; The hostess will tackle you and wrestle you to the ground, I'll bet. They're pretty serious about not seating people that haven't closed their tabs. 

AK said that the service had been spotty in the past, but we were blessed with one of the most professional, attentive servers I've had in recent memory. Water glasses sat empty for less than a minute before being refilled; Amir steps outside for a minute and leaves his napkin on his chair, and someone comes by and folds it. They're completely out of mind until the moment you need something, and then they're gone again, like The Others on Lost except they refill your water glasses instead of stealing your children. 

The place itself packs a crowd without inducing claustrophobia, it's warm but not stuffy, tasteful and trendy but not pretentious. And the owners are nice. I'll be back next time I'm craving latkes, stew, crepes, and wings but don't want to hit four different restaurants.
author: matthew r.

description:
You know a restaurant is good when you are trying to figure out when your next visit will be as you are exiting from your first visit. Dosa is one of those places. I am not super familiar with South Indian fare, but I know Nish (my friend on Yelp) loves Dosa and so do some of the people I know in the real world, so I have really been wanting to check it out. Friday night I was finally able to team up with my partner in crime Jen O. for an early dinner and we both agreed on Dosa.

We decided we would try the 4 course tasting menu, because the portions are a bit smaller and since there was two of us we ordered two things from each course and shared. Plus, at $30 per person, this is pretty reasonable. 

We also did the wine pairing and shared, so for $16 each we got to sample six wines. I don't recommend the wine pairing though, because though the wines are actually quite good and so is the food, The wine does not enhance the flavor of the food because the spice wipes out the wine. Honestly, Jen and I both agreed that a nice cold glass of beer would have been better with our meals. 

So here is what we had. My favorites are marked by an *.

1. Starter Course 

* Cochin Calamari -Tender calamari, sautéed with a mildly-spiced coconut milk sauce, served with mixed greens. (Incredible)

Dahi Vada - Lentil dumplings, topped with cool Strauss organic yogurt, piped with tamarind & mint, mildly spiced (Too beautiful to eat - but we managed.)

2. Mini Dosa

Paneer Dosa - Dosa filled with spiced, grilled farmer's cheese, peas and cilantro. (Excellent)

* Chatni Masala Dosa - Our signature South Indian savory crepe filled with creamy, spiced Indian potatoes, onions, cashew nuts with a spiced chutney spread of blended baby eggplant (Excellent x2)

3. South Indian Curry

** South Indian Lamb Kofta - Spiced natural & free-range lamb meatballs in a creamy sauce of tomatoes & spinach served with lemon basmati rice and raita (Yes, it is as good as it sounds).

* Kerala Chicken & Cauliflower - Tender free-range chicken in a grated coconut sauce with green beans and tomatoes, with basmati rice and raita made with Strauss organic yogurt (Delicious)

4. Dessert 

* Kulfi (Indian Ice Cream) -Pistachio

Gulab Jamoon -Two soft, lightly-fried milk and dough balls served in a warm, cardamom flavored sugar syrup (Almost identical in taste and texture as pancakes soaked in syrup, except no maple taste. Too sweet for me).

Ambiance - We were seated in a roomy corner next to an open window on a warm night in the Mission district - Bitchin'

Service - It was great. Our server was really cool and whenever she was too busy to get to us, she sent her crew to make sure we were comfortable and cared for.
author: J F.

description:
I'm not sure what I could possibly add to the reviews on here that someone already hasn't noted.

Yeah, it's loud...
It's small...
It's a bit pricey...

But damnit...it's GOOD!!!
author: Christy L.

description:
Brrrrunch!  A great way to eat at Dosa without the bustle of the dinner rush.  We had one of the egg dosas, which was delicious and came with the best bowl of dahl I've ever tasted.  They also have some chaat entree dishes that they don't have in the evening, which were excellent.  We had two chaats and one egg dosa split between two people and we were full and happy.

Service was super friendly and attentive.   Fresh plates and a cleanly-wiped table between the starters and the main course, which even some fancy restaurants neglect to do.  We were there right at opening, 11:30, so they weren't very busy yet, but I was still impressed with the service.

My only gripe is the coffee, which was some kind of Indian sweetened coffee with milk that I didn't like.  I'm sorry, but I just really need three thumping strong cups of black, rich, coffee at brunch.  I know this was Indian brunch, but if you can have a Bloody Mary or Champagne at Indian Brunch, I don't see why you can't have a gut-eroding cup of Ritual or something like that.   Nor was the tea selection extensive.  If you like black tea but don't like Earl Grey, you're out of luck.

We were out of there for under $50 with a big tip, and will be back, though I might BYO coffee next time.
author: Vince D.

description:
I personally feel this place is good but a little over rated. The ambiance is great though. A HUGE negative is the wait time. Granted, it reflects the popularity but that doesn't help if you're in a rush.

I do like the creative fusion Dosa options etc. If you want authentic Dosa though, you do not come here.

UPDATE:

I got this message from the owner. Apparently he does not take feedback well because in conversation with a friend I discovered he tends to respond to Yelp posts in a very defensive manner. I got this response 8 months ago and, although I thought it was foolish to do as a business owner, I had forgotten about it. My friend encouaraged me to post it. I also lowered my rating by 1 star.

Since when was fuison an insult? Anyway here's what he sent me:

Hey Ajit - I'm sorry about the wait at Dosa.  We tried taking reservations when we first opened but people did *not* respect them.  Dosa is certainly not the place to visit if you're in a rush and I'm certainly very grateful when people chose to wait.   

If you grew up in India, like I did, a few minutes here and there is just part of life and you learn to take it in stride.  :-) 

I'm not sure where you've had dosas before but I imagine even though you're of Indian origin (judging from your name) you neither grew up in India nor are you Southern Indian.   On the other, I and three of my chefs grew up in India with authentic Southern Indian fare.   

I'm okay if you don't like our food (I don't expect everyone to), however, there is  *nothing* "fusion" about our recipes.   Our biggest fans happen to be folks who've grown up in Southern India and who appreciate our emphasis on traditional preparations. 

Kind regards, 

Anjan 
(one of the owners)
author: A J.

description:
Reading over the recent 1 star (or -3 star review) I want to laugh -- Or hunt down the poster.

I went to Dosa this past weekend and it was an incredible experience. I ended up waiting over an hour for my table, but the hostess was amazing. When the 20 minute wait turned longer, she brought fresh pappadam ONTO THE STREET for me and my 3 friends to munch on. When 10 more minutes passed, she came out herself to apologize that the party before us was lingering so long, and comp us a free appetizer. Menu in hand, she had us choose a selection there, and sure enough, it was delivered to us (with more pappadam) the moment we sat.

The food from there was spectacular, the waiters wonderful, and after the meal they were friendly and let US linger, even when we asked if we were holding up another table. (They said we were not and assured us they would let us know so we didn't shaft another party like we'd been.)

This place is fantastic. Great food, great service, the whole deal. If you are looking for cheap Indian food, don't come here. If you are looking to be seated immediately, don't come here. (It only seats 49 people in the entire place.) But if you are looking for an amazing meal.... This is your place.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Dosa is sanskrit word meaning "ridiculously awesome and unique Indian restaurant with great wine list and a long wait".  They cook with top-quality ingredients... I particularly love the Strauss Family yogurt found in many of their dishes

Be sure to try a dosa or an uttapam, but they have great curries and very interesting starters too.  Try the dahi vada, pepper chicken curry, and the "south Indian moons" - a selection of five mini-uttapams

Order a bottle of German riesling to complement the spicy food.  The selection is excellent and well-priced
author: Dave K.

description: The food was fresh and tasted very good. Its different from the traditional south indian food. The dosa fillings are creative. The curry that we ordered was also very good . The only thing that i didnt like was the Rasam soup that we ordered in the appetiser. It was extremely spicy with too much of rasam powder. The chutneys were also very good. The ambiance was ok, except that it was very noisy. If you only care for food then thats a non issue.
author: Shubhi T.

description: Because of the majority of nice reviews, I made a trip with a friend to visit Dosa on a Saturday during their brunch menu. The dark interior and electronic music they had on was very distracting and created a club like atmosphere, which was a little strange for brunch, imo. I had the Masala Dosa and the Mango Lassi for a drink. The Masala Dosa was good ( the potato filling along with the crepe and the two dips were pretty tasty ) but the the Mango Lassi was a little too thick for a drink. They service was ok. But I wouldn't make a special trip to go to DOSA again. Even though its a pretty place where you can get drinks that happens to serve South Indian food, its nothing special.
author: Theresa D.

description:
4 stars for the food and drinks... the lassi soju is pretty yummy. Food wise the dosa's (food not the place) are pretty  tasty. I went for the masala (thats a staple) and of course it was crispy. The potato filling was delicious. The owners are a cool couple - Anjan (bengali yeahh) and his wife. Say Hi to them when you stop by. BUTTT - make sure you keep an hr or 2 handy as service is super slow being the place always crowded.

Update - Added one more star as service was way faster the second  time and after.
author: Sav B.

description:
For my 100th review *sighs exaggeratedly, tosses hair over shoulder, smirks knowingly* I thought to myself, "what better place to review than one that every single person on Yelp has already reviewed beyond exhaustion!?"  Genius, I am, I know.

Let's make this quick, then, shall we?

Dosa has really good food.  Slightly pushy staff.  Below par restrooms.  Surprisingly good wine.  Cramped seating.  And did I say really good food?
author: Christine M.

description:
I would like to dedicate this review to a soon to be fellow yelper, Scott (you know you want to make this place your first review....).

Wow, okay, fan -freaking tastic!!!  I am so glad I went here and will definitely come back.  The company also helped :)

For an appetizer we ordered the Dahi Vada.  Lentil balls immersed in a yogurt sauce.  This one totally blew my mind.  I loved it!

I am sorry, I can't remember the name of the Dosa ordered but I do remember it having peas.  Super delicious as well.  

Also ordered the Prawn Coconut Masala, curry dish (again super, super good) and the coconut sorbet (who doesn't like coconut?).

All in all, it was an excellent meal, reasonably priced and worth it.
author: Inga B.

description:
I did give it 5 stars. I have been many places where they serve south indian dishes. Surprisingly Dosa has a number of varieties  based on the face which state of india the dish belongs to. 

Amazing dosas. I haven't had such in a long time. Their Sambar was just awesome. It was nice, thick and in Gee (Butter) which is rare to find in Bay Area. I did like to go to their Filmore branch as well. 

anyone who likes south indian food must definitely try this restaurant. The quantity of food is also good. Service is good (peak hours it could slow down a little), friendly people. :-)
author: blogme c.

description:
It's way too expensive for what it is, but the food is really good.  Stick to the dosas, the other dishes are not so great.   The coconut gelato in a coconut shell was delicious.  Not the friendliest service I've encountered.  

Can't wait for Udupi Palace! (thanks Jennifer C. for the 411)
author: Ashkan J.

description:
I loved the spices of the food and the environment.  We went in the early part of the afternoon for a "brunch".  They overcharged on the appetizer but fixed it when cheapo me had to complain about it.  The main downfall of this place is the price and here's my main point ...

The cheapest 12 ounce bottle of beer was $6 = I am not going to recommend it on principle because of this.  That's highway robbery.  It made me so angry I had to just drink water and sulk.

I joined Yelp to try and stop this beer rape of Valencia Street.  This place is the highest I have seen however.
author: David L.

description: Great depth and complexity to the flavors - one bite of the coconut rice and I new everything's gonna be alright.  Every dish was solid,
author: David R.

description: The Ambiance is one of a kind.  Must order the bhatura, it's slightly sweet, chewy, and ridiculously delicious.  Only offered during dinner which is disappointing.
author: Alias A.

description:
Decent food, but if you like to take your time, I would suggest not going on a busy night. 

While we had a drink (the mojito-like drink with fresh ginger was refreshing & tasty), some appetizers, maybe another drink and talked, our server very kindly tried to get our full order several times, then a guy who seemed like he may have been a manager came over and not-so-subtly demanded, "Are you gonna order your main course or what?" 

Maybe we were clueless for just sort of taking our time and not scarfing everything down so they could turn their tables more quickly, but I'm a little confused: I thought Dosa wasn't just another fast food place. 

I agree with my dinner companion that the Lamb was pretty good, and the Vegetable Dosa was pretty tasty--neither of us had tried a dosa before. 

I'd give them another try--maybe, but definitely not on a busy night.
author: N B.

description:
Dosa... Soft, spongie crepe-like dough...  Coupled with some interesting sauces and a mashed potato thing.  Very Nice, I like!.  Paper Masala was the name of the dish.

Sat at the Bar...  Had the Lychee Soju infused martini.  Very nice and smooth until I chomped on the Lychee...  STRONG!  Awesome!

Kudo's to the Calamari and the Fire chicken ( I know that's not the name of the dish but it should be!).

Service at the bar should have been better.   I asked for water twice, and it took at least 10 minutes to fill our first drink order.

The owner is very cool, especially when he started pouring the wine! His heavy hand was much appreciated.

Keep it up!
author: Scott S.

description:
What can I say that has not been said already.....YUM!!!  I could eat here EVERY DAY, it is that good.  If I was stranded on a deserted island and could choose one person to be stuck there with me I would want Dosa's chef and an unlimited supply of German Riesling Kabinett...no joke.

I might even choose him over Brooke Burke.....




...well that might be going too far but the food is seriously the bomb and so is the owner, Anjan.
author: Ben D.

description:
WOW this place rocks!!!
What a great place to have breakfast brunch. 
All dishes are so new to me I can hardly explain southern Indian cuisine .
They are spicy and so yummy.
The egg dish rocked my world call Uttapam and I hear the Dosa rocks as well. It filled me up and the Mango Lassi. Very tempting to order more but the food was filling and the prices are reasonable. 
A date took me here and was the most impressive cuisine that was new and refreshing i have seen in over a year!

The decor is relaxed casual and modern colors. There is a counterto eat solo as a choice as well.
author: Joe R.

description:
"No way! This cannot be a dosa place!" I tell myself this the entire time I'm waiting for a table, getting seated, ordering, eating and leaving the restaurant. Dosa restaurants generally do not have romantic lighting, a full bar with amazing mixed drinks/wines, tables of well-dressed customers and waitstaff that fawn over you. It was a welcome surprise...although I did feel slightly under-dressed since I thought I was coming to a regular Dosa place. 

We started with the Chili Bhajia. Not sure what kind of peppers they use but this was really really good. Fried to the perfect amount, tasty, not overpoweringly spicy and just all round deelish. The plate was cleaned out in about 4 seconds. I ordered the Bhattura for my dinner. A huge, round fluffy piece of fried dough (yes...I threw any healthy notions out the door) served with a side of channa masala (garbanzo beans in an onion-tomato gravy). The Bhattura was sweet. I've never had a sweet Bhattura ever and I have to say it was not a welcome change. The Channa was fresh and tasted rather good but the Bhattura just ruined my meal. The rest of my table ordered various types of Dosas. The plain dosa tasted good as it was super crispy. Getting that consistency and crispiness is a feat and I applaud the chef. My husband ordered the Dosa with the Spinach/Cauliflower Curry. The dosa (plain) was of course amazing. The curry...wow...overpowering with garam masala and it tasted like someone had emptied many curry powders over the veggies. Not good. Props to them for creating very interesting chutneys such as harbanero which made my husband cry (literally) with happiness. 
We ended the meal with Yogurt Rice...these guys use Strauss Yogurt which is my favorite brand to use when eating Yogurt Rice...so they id their research and came up with the perfect end to the meal. 

You are paying solely for the ambiance and location when here. A dosa at excellent dosa places (Saravana Bhavan for example) would run about 5-6 dollars. A Dosa here at "Dosa" costs about 13-15 dollars. My Batthura cost me around $13. At any other Indian restaurant, it would have run me about $5 (including the Channa Curry). For these prices, I better get myself some amazing food. In fact the next day, I went to Saravana Bhavan and Dasaprakash in the San Jose area and had a much superior meal - taste-wise. 

Don't think I will be back again because I know how good South Indian food tastes having eaten it everyday growing up. This is not it. The decor and service is great but the food needs some serious work.

UPDATE ON SEP, 21 2010

I received a message from Dosa's owner mentioning that their higher prices are due to the fact that they use local, sustainable ingredients and that all employees get healthcare and are paid well. Great...I applaud that attitude. 

I still think that the entire experience (primarily due to the lackluster food) is a 2 star review. 

Also, the owner added this in the message that I thought I should call out: "We generally don't compare ourselves to the South Indian restaurants in the South Bay but rather to the home-cooked food and the cuisine we grew up with in India.  :-)"
I am comparing this meal with my childhood meals growing up in a South Indian household with my parents and grandparents and eating such food every single day. I'm also comparing Dosa's food to that of other South Indian Restaurants in the Bay area.
author: Sing V.

description:
I'm a bit of a rasam snob.  For four years one of my dot-com partners was an Indian from Bangalore.  While a US citizen, he returned at least once a year and came back with a suitcase full of his mother's own ground spices including the only rasam powder I had ever known.  His wife, impressed that I knew and liked south Indian food given we were in Philadelphia, gave me powder from their private stash, taught me to make rasam and introduced me to other ingredients I hadn't used before like jagary and fresh curry leaves.  The resulting rasam was not a fiery-hot in your mouth concoction but body-warming with a really satisfying finish.  So I'm spoiled for life on that account.

That said, I really liked everything else I've tried here so far.  I was glad to see cachumber salad on my first visit but sorry to see it re-named chopped salad on my second.  It is a pretty confetti of diced cucumber, red onion, tomato, carrot, red and green bell papper with a chili/lemon dressing over four romaine leaves that serve as nice scoops.  An excellent salad with just enough spice.

The tomato and onion uttapam served with coconut chutney and excellent sambar was nicely browned on both sides but could have been a touch crisper - but was still really great.

They have a nicely thought out list of wines - the 2004 Penalolen Savignon Blanc from Chile's Limari Valley stood up beautifully to the spices and was fairly priced a $7 a glass but a bargain at $26 a bottle.  

I am glad have south Indian in the City - not that there aren't plenty of good reasons to go to Berkeley - but I can walk to Dosa.    I'll definitely be back.  

Oh - one more thing - I hope they start opening for lunch!
author: Jon R.

description:
I would give dosa 4 stars because I have a hard time understanding the menu (how are all these things different from each other...I still don't get it).  BUT that's my fault for being ignorant, and the wait staff is more than amenable to helping me understand and providing excellent recommendations for both food and wine.  On one visit they even had an "expert" bring me a taste of a wine, and he discussed with me how it would pair with my meal, etc.... (way above and beyond my expectations).  Then the waitress was so cool she wrote down not only the name of the wine but a local place that for some insane reason has it at a super affordable price.  That little tip definitely made paying $11 for a single glass worth it! :)

I've always enjoyed everything I've eaten here: salads, dosas, and the chip-like things that they bring out to start.....they don't last 5 seconds in front of me!  so good!

The decor is lovely.  It has a tendency to get loud but somehow I can still manage to have a quiet conversation and maintain a chill vibe.  It might be the acoustics that keep the noise to a tolerable level, or the calming warm colors .... or the fact that they seem to set me up with an awesome table every time!  I've always been here with just one other person...which I think is how I like it best.  I can see group conversations and ordering getting difficult for sure.

When I want to do fancy (never pretentious) this is where I go.  Prepare to wait, but maybe you'll be lucky enough to get a seat at the bar while you do so.  I typically see a line but I definitely feel like I've been lucky to hit it at just the right time...never had to wait more than 10 minutes.

This place is an experience for all senses:  good food, good people, good decor... I leave smiling every time!
author: miranda caroligne ..

description:
Went with 10 people last weekend.  Based on our server's suggestion we all did the tasting menu.  It's $32 for 4 courses. 
 
I didn't make it to the final course (dessert).  WAY. TOO. FULL.

Good food.  

Loud. Fun. Yummy.
author: T M.

description: Authentic and tasty south indian food. Just like my mom's preparation. Try Lamb pepper fry. Serves two.
author: Sathya K.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmm.  
Get there early to avoid the lines. 5:30 pm should work.
Deliciously varied Indian food served on light crispy crepes called dosas.
We enjoyed the paper masala dosa, an appetizer of yummy organic greens, mango and cheese, the jumbo prawn masala and some coconut ice cream for dessert.  A wonderful dinner for date night.

Tip: Watch out for the spicy curry!
author: Barbara P.

description:
The bf and I went to Dosa tonight for the first time, and I was nearly overwhlemed by the spicy scent coming from within--seriously, if you're not into spice, do not come here. We went at 6:30 (on a Sat.) to avoid a long wait time and were seated immediately at the very last 2 person table--shortly after, the bar filled up and the wait began (IOW, if you don't want to wait, go early). 

Service was great--our waitress was friendly and attentive, immediately filling our first drink order.  I ordered the Spring dosa, and bf ordered the Pepper Chicken (very hot-spicy, he tells me...I was too ful to try it). The Spring dosa was phenomenal--full of fresh, yummy veggies and just hot enough with the lentil dipping sauce, which I found hot enough to make me glisten (b/c girls don't sweat, right), but not too hot to eat. Had a great sauvignon blanc (forget the name, but it was the chilean one, not either of the indian varieties), and bf enjoyed the maharaja beer.

My bf particularly appreciates efficiency serivce and excellent food, and he gave the experience a 10. Came to ~$70 total (including tax and tip) for two with two drinks per person. Four stars for now, but if it's consistent, the rating could go up.
author: Jasmine F.

description:
Visited Dosa 9/8/06 at 930pm. It was a friday.
there was a 15 minute wait for a party of 4.

Food: 4 stars
Decor: 5 stars Very trendy, not very indian oriented. you wouldnt know it was indian by looking at the decor. there are cool divider panels at the back of the room disquising the kitchen, bathrooms, and whatnot. Sooo loud. we had to lean in at our table and still could only make out 1/2 of what the person was saying.
Service: 5 stars They were attentive and removed plates properly.
Cost: 5 stars. entrees were $10-$12 

Ordered: Potato Croquet $7- Ordered in an attempt to dublicate the samosa lovin'. they were prety mushy with no potato chunks, not so crunchy on the outside.
Spring Masala dosa combined with fresh vegetables including peas, carrots, cabbage and red onion... 11 this was very good. it didnt not have that warm coherent taste of the Paneer Dosa. I would order the Paneer Dosa next time instead of this item.
Paneer & Peas
Uttapam topped with farmers cheese and peas... 10 this was tasty as well. It was an open faced dosa which was very pancake like. The Paneer Dosa that my cousin ordered was way better than my dish IMO.
Pros: Good paneer dosa, tasty  "lentil dipping soup" =daal
Cons: too loud to talk, and we made the mistake of eating there with cousins that we hadn't seen for a year. :(

Overall: will return for the paneer dosa, and the good beer
author: Mango D.

description:
meh.

We shared 5 dishes between the 3 of us.  There were only two that I truly loved: the mixed green, mango goat cheese salad. and a potato dosa dish.  

Our server was nice, but the food came out before the drinks.  It was uncomfortably warm inside and I returned home feeling nauseous.  

Maybe it was an off night.  I feel no need to go back.
author: Shayna N.

description:
These are probably the best dosas I have had. Ever. However, the only ones I've tried on the west coast, so it's entirely possible that there's better out there, but you'll have to convince me. I had the paneer...and it was amazing. We also got some calamari...wow...so good. The tomato soup is great, definitely get it spicy if you can handle it.

Yum. I'm still drooling today!
author: Irene F.

description:
Dosa is one of my favorite restaurants in the city!  Amazing food, great crowd, good service, delicous drinks...I could go on and on.  

I am dying to go back here again.  Pleeeeease, sweetie?  Take me back to Dosa?
author: Alyssa W.

description:
Great food and great Service !

We were in on Sunday night and had a great dinner.  The Tamil lamb curry was the highlight ( I can't get enough of that stuff).  We also had the Kerala Chicken curry and spinach and fennel dosa and they were both delicious too.  Our server, Cheri, was friendly and knowledgeable.  

We made a reservation and the friendly hostess with the beautiful flowing red hair made sure we were sat immediately.  

Overall, a great experience.  If you haven't already checked this place out, you're missing out.
author: Kent C.

description: I need to find a place that serves amazing dosa in Houston. I'm hooked.
author: Lonny Y.

description:
After seeing the average rating for Dosa to be 4 stars on Yelp, we decided to try this restaurant for weekend brunch.  The food was ok.  We ordered 2 masala dosas and a chaat as an appetizer.  The chaat was very flavorful and unique, but the dosas were meh.  Nothing really special...  I also ordered a chai, which was very watery and disappointing.  Overall, the food is ok, but I knocked another star off for the prices.  It's a bit pricey, as compared to other similar restaurants.  Our bill came to $42 for the above.

They also seemed understaffed.  There was only 1 waitress for about 7 or 8 tables, and it took a while for her to come around.
author: Mon L.

description:
I went here with coworkers on a Saturday night.  We waited for over an hour.

I don't claim to be any expert on this cuisine, but we had one expert at the table--she was in charge of ordering. The waiters kept bringing us dishes, our expert would explain what they were, and I would, quite happily, eat them.

The food was fantastic. The service was fantastic. The decor was fantastic.

At the end of the meal, I was stuffed and could hardly eat another bite. Then they brought out the desert menu. I had a fantastic pistachio ice cream to finish.

Total bill, with a bottle of wine for the six of us, came to $37 each (including tip). I thought it was a great meal.
author: Nathan N.

description: I recently began exploring Indian cuisine. I read great reviews about Dosa online and decided to try it. One of the worst things about trying new food is not knowing a.) how to pronounce it and b.) not knowing how to consume it. The staff at Dosa just explained everything assuming that most diners are unaware of south Indian cuisine which made it all much more comfortable. The food was delicious and there was plenty of it, I couldn't finish mine. Try any of the dosa plates- they are really yummy.
author: Russell Allen E.

description:
I went here on my birthday with a bunch of my friends. 
They were so accomadating of our growing numbers and our indeciciveness. 

I love Southern Indian food- and have never found anywhere as good as the Diwanna Bhel Poori House in London- until now, 
this place was delish!!! 
I can't wait to go back.
author: Suzanne D.

description:
Mmmmm...Dosa. This place was recommended to me by a waiter at Millennium, so I knew it had to be good. But oh, was I in for a treat. Their brunch is so wonderful, their portions are so big, and their staff and atmosphere so pleasing. 

The owner came by to check on us while we were at dinner; he was great. The food was spicy, honest, warm food that makes me crave it everyday.
author: Carol S.

description:
A more diverse menu than Udupi Palace (in Berkeley and South Bay) that goes beyond the core Dosa/Uttapam selections.  Where I could compare directly with Udupi, they were close, but not necessarily better.  The less standard choices seem to be the stronger options.  

Given the pent up demand for South Indian, they probably should have chosen a larger venue, but even so, I'm grateful that they're here in San Francisco.

The atmosphere is loud and lively -- a first for this location which has proven to be death for several restaurants over the last few years.
author: Robert C.

description:
I like South Indian food.  Most Indian places in the City are actually North Indian/Pakistani, so I was excited to go here when it first opened.  It wasn't good.  The food was bland, unexciting and overpriced.  I thought I'd give it another chance, now that it's been a couple of years since I first went here.  The food was still bland, unexciting and overpriced.  

If you want to experience some really good South Indian food, drive yourself down to Saravana Bhavan in Sunnyvale.  It's the real thing, and you just might get to eat sooner than if you had to wait for a table at Dosa.
author: Alexander K.

description: I always recommend this spot to friends! Make sure you get a reservation because they pack out even on weeknights. Parking is tricky but that's just the Mission. Prices are reasonable for the quality of food and service.
author: Kimberly Y.

description:
with the huge number of REVIEWS already, i'll use this space to RAAAAVE instead!

wowwie wow wow! a restaurant that beats to the rhythm of my heart and the yearnings of my tummy! as i cleaned my plate of the last piece of chatni masala dosa, i actually felt sad that it was over. it was one of those tasty, scrumptious dishes that i know i'll be craving - must-have-it-now-or-else type craving.

the food and drink were brilliant - we ordered separate tasting menus for a reasonable price of $35 per. each serving was perfectly portioned in my opinion, and it gave me the chance to try a variety from their abundant selections as a first time diner here. i happily ordered: the South Indian Mung Sprouts Salad to start, the Chatni Masala Dosa to follow, Veggie Korma with basmati rice to top my tummy off, and lastly, a small serving of the Coconut Sorbet to temper my palate! everything was incredibly tasty, well-timed, hot, and just bursting with spicy surprises! the wine list is superb, with many non-Californian wines to choose from. we went with a new zealand gewertz (DELICIOUS) and a rose of pinot noir to start (DIVINE). he then went with a viognier, and i the australian cab. all of them were luscious and perfect for this type of cuisine. 

the atmosphere and service were outstanding for us as well - one of the unbeatable things about dining in the Mission is the energy from all of the restaurants. the warm colored walls. the mix of ethnic, popular, and house music. the charged flurry of conversations about the small dining room. food runners zipping around with giant aromas  tailing. sensation teasers that had me giddy. our server was super patient and very attentive - we never felt neglected or over-served - thank you for that! 

and at the end of it all, i realized that Dosa in Indonesian (my original culture), means SIN. well no wonder i am hooked then...
author: Diana L.

description:
I went during the first couple of weeks, after reading a torrent of build-up on Tribe.net. I certainly was excited to find out why this was so distinctive and so much anticipated/lauded upon opening.

I have to admit that even though I certainly would be happy to go back, I am going to stick to my favorite neighborhood Indian restaurant, Rasoi's, for the time being.

The renovation in Dosa is very attractive. But the huge crowds, cramped space, bad acoustics, and distracting music were all a bit too much too handle.

Our waitress was superb, friendly, helpful, and very professional.

Yet we found the menu and actual meal somewhat uninspired. I guess in part I have gotten spoiled on all the different types of crepes you can get in this city, and on the substantial portions that usually accompany them. If it weren't for the sauces that came with the Dosas, the night probably would have been a huge disappointment. I sense that the fact that I am a carnivore also set me up for a let-down, as there are virtually no non-meat/poulty/sea food appetizers available.

I hope they expand the menu and the hype dies down so I can try it again and, hopefully, have a more satisfying experience.
author: Eric P.

description:
Shit Goddamn is this place good.
Start by sharing the Masal Dosa and a glass of Lillet over ice.  I tried their soju, which is fine, but, for some reason, Korean liquor doesn't go well with Indian food. Then get the Chennai Chicken thingy, a bathura and a mango lassi. You'll be dreaming about that daymn bathura for weeks afterwards. It's so chewy and doughy and greasy. And their sambar is the best I've ever tried next to homemade.  And I used to eat in Little India down in Artesia.
I immediately told all my Malayali friends about this place.  You'll never believe that some Velekai's are behind this restaurant.  Wait....the owners ARE South Indian. Awesome!
author: Joyhan S.

description:
Sigh.

We walked in and I was immediately pleased by the demeanor of the hostesses - they were so nice.  When we were seated, the one who seated us asked me if I wanted her to hang up my jacket.  

Quite unfamiliar with South Indian food, Ari C and I studied the menu a bit, and then concluded we were both confused.  Still though, we settled on our choices until our waitress came over to explain things...at which time we both changed our orders.  (If this is your first time, listen to what your wait person has to say....)  I got the rava masala dosa, which was yummy, although I ate too much of the crepe part before I got to the middle, so by the time I finished the insides, I was too full to think.  I just wanted to lie down.  The dipping things were good, the red chutney and the lentil "soup" were better than the coconut chutney, which to me was just hot without much other taste.  

As I have alluded to in various parts of this review, the wait staff was exceptional.  From the hostesses to our waitress, Christy, everyone was so nice and helpful.  Attentive.  Pleasant.  The ambience was also awesome...halfway through dinner I realized the bar area looked really inviting, spacious and nicely lit by the sunlight.  

I would definitely come back.  I want to try the tasting menu and the fiery fruit.
author: Kerrie L.

description:
Tonight, after watching Dosa being built and then finally opening just weeks ago, we decided to stop in for a quick dinner. 

Dosa is a special sort of restaurant for San Francisco - instead of focusing on the common tandoori dishes of northern India and Pakistan, it focuses on the crepes and chickpea dishes of southern India - the wonderful dishes of cities such as Chennai, Goa and Tamil Nadu. Here, you'll find mostly vegetarian with a single chicken appetizer and a few meat based curries. The main courses revolve around dosa and uttapam - vegetable filled crepes and pancake like chickpea breads with added in vegetables and spices.

Arriving at 7pm, we were lucky to be able to get a table - a single two-seater that had just become available. Considering that a group of four that had arrived just before us had been quoted a 1.5 hour wait for a table, we felt  that this was a good omen.

The food? Wonderful. I started with the Chicken Chennai - spicy chickpea battered chicken served over mixed greens and garnished with slivered red onion - which was fantastic, possibly the second best Indian chicken dish I have had, surpassed solely by Mehfil's Chicken Laccha. Following that was the Coriander and Chili Uttayam - perfect on its own and magically made better by dipping it in the wonderful coconut chutney.

Dosa's decor was also quite nice - using deep salmon colors accented by brown wood and frosted glass partitions. From a restaurant flow perspective, the bar was too crowded, making it difficult to follow the maitre d' to our table. The bathrooms were clean and the service seemed to lack any noticable defects aside from the fact that our main courses came a little too quickly after our appetizers.

Two appetizers, two main courses, three beers and a "chai russian" - a variant of a white russian using chai and soju instead of Kahlua and vodka came to $61 without tax. We'll certainly return here - next time saving room to try one of the tempting desserts.

No reservations for parties of 4 or less and no hard alcohol. Beer, wine and soju "cocktails" available. Credit cards accepted.
author: Avery G.

description:
Good.  But Spendy!!!

Maybe I'm spoiled by amazing Indian food at Hemas Kitchen and Bhabis Kitchen off Devon St. in Chicago.  Very tasty, good flavors, fast service. Actually scary fast service.  No REAL complaints, but this just made me miss the amazing love care and spices of indian/pakistani food of my yesteryear.

The menu has SO MANY words on it...really.  When you are hungry, do you really want to tackle a menu that is the equivalent to trying to cram some chapter of accounting or russian literature in before an exam?  Its like it needs color coding or some other kind of categorization...something!!  It makes you spin.  And I'm not saying this because I know absolutely nothing about Indian food, but some grouping by flavor or general palette would be helpful.

Oh and I like how they bring Papadums to your table to snack on.

I know, I'm being a bit of a hater,
author: Vivian T.

description: Great food and an unusual menu.  Very different from your standard Indian fare.  Most dishes I've never seen anywhere else.  Plus, good service and well-run.  Just wish it was easier to get into.
author: Ric S.

description:
I've been hit with a "dosa" reality lately.  Besides bad puns, I have a problem with eating Indian food in that it will make me sweat uncontrollably (even when the food isn't all that spicy).   It's especially embarrassing when I am the ONLY person in the restaurant pouring out of my pores.  

Food:  3 stars.  Dosa and Amber India are the only places that my friends from Bangalore, India were impressed with.  That's a good indicator of the authenticity of the food.  However, I would skip the appetizers.  The medu vada, served with sambar and chutney, tasted quite bland.  The South Indian Tomato soup, described as delicately flavored with spices, could have been the "fire broth" as far as I was concerned.  There was nothing delicate about it.  Thankfully, the dosas and curries hit the spot, especially the paneer dosa (highlight of the night), chatni masala dosa and lentil chicken, which was so tender.  I didn't care so much for the South Indian Moon Uttapam, which felt like a waste of money and came with the same damn chutneys and sambar we got with the appetizer.  For dessert, we had the cheesecake, the most non-Indian dessert on the menu, and it wasn't half bad.

Service:  2 stars.  Our server was clueless.  We ordered everything family style and all the dishes came out at once.  There was absolutely no room on our table to fit all of the dishes.  As we were trying to maneuver the plates around and clear up space, he even came by and asked us how the food was - before we even had a bite!

Atmosphere:  4 stars.  The space is modern and cool, with a mixed crowd that mostly skews towards the younger side.  A couple of issues I had was the heat in the dining room, which was another catalyst for my sweat, and the lack of a reservation policy for tables under 5. 

Hits:   Lentil chicken, dosas (especially the paneer dosa).

Misses:  Medu vada, South Indian tomato soup, South Indian Moons uttapam.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Amber India, Vik's Chaat Corner, Pakwan, Shalimar
author: Keith C.

description:
As someone who goes to Dosa all the time you'd think I'd give it a better review.

The Dosa, Uttapan's, and appetizers are good, the curry is rather unexceptional. Either way it's expensive, but this doesn't seem to bother me so much when it's three blocks away at 11am on a Saturday and I'm with Laura Holden who has now moved to Oregon...so well..

And then there's that server I love, I love him, but I do not like some of the other people. Fortunately I usually don't deal with them, I deal with Mr. nice tall guy. 

In any case, there is one thing I still crave and can't find anywhere else: The Dahi Vada. Yeah you don't know what that is, but I'm here to tell you. It's a yogurt lover's god, and a heart burner's savior made with nothing but the best, Stauss organic yogurt (how much better could you get?). Lentil dumplings live in this bunch of orgasmic holy land mildly spiced and piped with mint and tamarind. The sour taste mixed with the slightly crunchy exterior of the dumplings is comforting and full bodied in flavor. I savor each moment for sure.

I regularly order the South Indian Moons (my server tells me I never fail with this one) which consists of five uttapams (I find them better than Dosa) which are served with the sambar, channa, and chutneys. Basically one of these dipping sauces is spicy and brothy. The other two are pasty one coconut flavored, the other with a tomato bisque flavor. 

I don't think the Moons are anything worth crying over, but they're definitely tasty, with their spiciness taking full reign over their fat appeal. They are def. much better than the curries though.

In any case, I like South Indian food, I do, so I go here, but I don't like their curries. For that I'll go to my secret spot which I'll never tell you about.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
Dosa = De-licious. I have been here several times now.  First time was a couple years ago when they first opened, had a huge group for my birthday there.  (which would be unheard of nowadays, it's always super packed and not that big inside).

but there is a good reason!  food is excellent, fresh, inventive.  south indian is where it's at baby!  i never got sick of it when i was traveling there. and i like how Dosa uses a bit of their own style and flair to keep their menu interesting.  my most recent visit was a week ago or so...ordered take-out with my friends (who have triplets and live up the street).  we each got a masala chatni dosa and shared the cochin calamari (freakin' fan-tastic).  the babies are too small yet to eat dosas, but i think they were drooling watching us.  felt a little bad.

so what if it's a little pricey compared to south indian hotspots in berkeley....Dosa is a full service restaurant, using mainly organic ingredients and always freshly prepared....AND you don't have to leave the city, right?
author: Isabel C.

description:
Oh yeah, this place is good. Our friends Chamath and Bridgette took us here - they told us it is the third time they've been there that week! We've eyed this place for a couple of years but always end up going elsewhere because it is hard to park in the mission, and the lines extend way out the door when we walk past.

We ended up going on a Sunday night when parking was relatively easy, and the line, although long, still had us seated in 10 minutes. We opted for the 4 course tasting menu so that we could try more things - the courses are smaller sized than usual. The dosas were good; I especially liked the coconut based dipping sauce. But the lamb curry was just outrageously flavorful and delicious. We will be back for sure.
author: jeremy l.

description:
We are long time devotees of both locations, particularly Valencia St. I love Dosa but felt it's starting to slip (both locations). I've had many brunches (& a birthday!) there. The food is Excellent. Fantastic wine list. The ambiance used to be more relaxed, but the renovation made it just gorgeous! Bonus points for putting the Kleenex dispenser in the loo; spicy food makes my nose run.
However, I have some critiques this go 'round.
I'd like to give them 3 & 1/2 stars, but Yelp does only whole numbers- so 3 it is. 
 -1/2 * for being too hip (it's cool you got a dj when you remodeled but please turn down the volume during luncheon, I'd like to hear my tablemates- this isn't a disco)
-1/2 * for being kind of arrogant- please don't keep raising the prices. $13 for a vodka martini? That's LA prices! *Please, Don't get greedy on us- dosas and chaat are inexpensive foods.
PS Also, it kind of sucked that you wouldn't give our friend (a renowned SF food blogger) a Paper menu to take home (?!)
He's in the chron today and again later this week- someone I'm sure you'd like to have say good things about you. 
Please don't make me regret my loyalty in your attempts to go upmarket. Remember the little people as your success continues.
author: Rachel D.

description: The food is great but they won't substitute alcohol on the cocktail menu. It's pretty small so make a reservation. Definitely going back.
author: Jeff R.

description:
This place came highly recommended from friends and media sources alike so my expectations were high. As you can guess from my rating it didn't live up to the hype. I went as a party of 3 and shared the food with both the people with me.

Ordered the following:

Starters:
Potato Croquet
Channa

Main Course:
Masala Dosa
Chatni Masala Dosa
Paneer Dosa

Total Bill with tax & tip (18%) = $75  (*note - no alcohol was ordered)


The only dish that any of us really thought had good flavour was the Chana starter. The others were simply not interesting, lacked any encouraging spices that would would expect from Indian food, and frankly tasted like reheated mashed potatoes with veg, ala Bubble & Squeak (an English leftover hodge-podge of mashies and veg you fry up the next day in a skillet).

I am honestly quite puzzled by the overwhelming glee for this place but maybe it is all in what you order.

For the hype and the money i'd expect more. 

I think the SF Chronicle needs to hire a new food critic.

- neil
author: neil c.

description:
I am from Chennai (heart of south India) and a pretty good cook, so guess I can say with some amount of credibility that Dosa is Great!

6:15pm: Entered Dosa asked for a table for three, sipped Cosmopolitan till the third friend arrived.
6:30pm: Friend arrived & three of us moved to a cozy table and ordered Rava Dosa, Paneer & Peas Utthappam, Chennai Lamb Curry with Rice. Also some lillet & Soju with lime. If you have never had Dosa before, try the Rava not the regular Dosa. Rava is coarse wheat flour and the regular is rice flour.
7:20pm: Ready for dessert, we ordered Coconut cream gelato, Rasmalai & Madras Tea - which was not really great.
7:40pm: We left pretty happy that finally there is a decent Indian restaurant in our hood.
author: Divya R.

description:
I'm sorry, but I was disappointed.  I was so ready to have a great time at Dosa, and was so looking forward to a real, chic, South Indian meal, but...

The dosa was not crispy and the chutneys had no flavor.  I was expecting a spicy, tangy, tomato chutney, but instead found it bland and boring.

Tamarind or Coconut chutney with the fritters?  Nope.  Nothing sweet, sour, and pungent to cut the fried croquettes.  So much better this food would be if they didn't hold back on giving some true South Indian tastes and flavors!  Come-on guys, this is San Francisco, give us a chance!

Anyone interested in knowing what a good dosa tastes like, visit V.I.K. at 4th and Allston in Berkeley.  For $4.50, you'll have a moment of bliss.  Then come back to Dosa and ask them to open up thier spice purse a bit, they have so much potential.  

Not all negative, though, the restaurant looks great!  colors, lighting, the bar... I give them high marks for the off-dry wines that pair well with the cuisine.  If you're entertaining guests who know nothing of Indian food, and have sensitive palettes, this could be fun.

Granted, I've only been to Dosa once.  I'll willing to try it again, but am skeptical.
author: Greg H.

description:
Fantastic food. Horrible experience. Just loud as freakin' Cal-Train filled with Giants fans. And the heat in the place - holy hotness - I must have been there on Bikram yoga night! I felt like I was in the Great Indian Desert  -  shedding clothes and dripping sweat. The place was packed and you could hardly navigate to the restrooms. The service was a bit rushed.

The food was good, but I won't eat it there again.

A Dosa owner sweetly responded to this review and said I may have a better experience on a weeknight before 6:30 or after 9pm. Good  advice - I will certainly take a closer look before I step inside again.
author: michelle b.

description:
YUM! 

My friend and I walked in a little drunk, a lot hungry, and clueless about how to navigate the menu (this plays to Amol's review, but it's SF. mixed crowd, yes.).. we ended up sitting at the bar and throwing ourselves at the mercy of the bartendress. She suggested wine and 3 courses, based on our basic needs (um, delicious? some salad?), and made us fall in love with her:

Everything was delicious, perfectly timed, fresh, excellent. That charming owner made sure we were having a good time, that everything was just right...just enough checking by the staff that if there were a problem it would have been solved, but not so much that we didn't feel safe talking about totally inappropriate topics (quietly, to each other only, of course).

Marvelous. We finished with port and didn't spend a fortune. I can't wait for the new one in the new neighborhood. Or is that just a rumor??
author: rebecca g.

description: I've been wanting to try Dosa for awhile, and when I finally made it there for a late dinner it did not disappoint.  The standout star was the Channa Bhatura, which is a chickpea masala served with a delicious puffy bread.  The paper dosa was quite good as well.  The paneer and pea uttapam was good but not as strong.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Extremely delicious and interesting Indian food! I love going to Dosa. It's a great date place because the seating is a little tight. But the lighting makes it quite romantic. 

Get the firebroth - or at least that's what we call it. It's amazing and really opens up your sinuses! HA!

Be prepared to wait for a table though!
author: Elizabeth Z.

description:
Why is eating with your hands so much fun?  I don't know if it was the two Kingfishers in my belly, but DOSA had me giggling with delight, like the day I got my first "My Little Pony".  Something about ripping off my little dosa piece and choosing my next chutney gives my brain the stimuli that it craves.  
Step 1:  Tear perfect 3X3 dosa square.  
Step 2:  Scoop perfect spoonful of sambar onto perfect 3X3 square.
Step 3:  Top perfect 3X3 sambar dosa square with perfect dollop of chutney.
Step 4:  Shove perfect 3X3 chutney-sambar-dosa square into mouth before perfection falls into my lap.  
Step 5:  Cut the fiery goodness with swig of Kingfisher lager.
Step 6:  See how many times you can repeat steps before intoxicated fingers fumble each crucial step.

And so on and so forth.  Was I just having a good time playing with my food, or did it actually taste that good?  Or had I just downed too many beers?  I don't know.  I guess I should come back again and find out when I'm sober.  Nah.
 
All silliness aside, DOSA is inventive, creative, and daring.  And that means that they miss a few beats here and there, but hey, at least they're trying.  I absolutely adore Indian cuisine, but rarely does it stray from the usual suspects -  chicken tikka masala, saag paneer, blah, blah, blah.  I was delighted not to understand half the menu at Dosa.  

I have never raved about pappadam before, but dang, this stuff melted in my mouth!  I had to order a second basket.  And a second beer...

To start was the "Five Indian Moons", a sampler of five uttapams.  To be fair, I only loved the "Paneer &Peas" uttapam, but I still think it's worth ordering the sampler, if it's your first time.

Of course, order dosa; it is their namesake, if you haven't noticed.  I prefer plain, so I can scoop chutney to oblivion.  I tried the three-cheese dosa, and I never thought I'd ever say such a thing, but there was actually too much cheese, and it overpowered the delicate dosa.  I can't believe I just said that.

Service is OK.  A bit too professional and sterile, if you ask me.  And they can never keep my damn water glass full.  Maybe I should order my food less spicy; perhaps I should take some accountability here...

I have been to both locations, and I'm torn as to which I prefer.  If you're lookin' for a chic night out with a beautiful chandeliered bar and beautiful manicured people, go to Fillmore.  If you're feelin' low-key, and just want to eat goddammit, go to the Mission.  

Either way, just go.  I have not yet seen another Indian restaurant break away from the norm as successfully as Dosa has.  I'll certainly be back soon.
author: Monique B.

description: I got their dosa stuffed with a habenero filling.  It was spicy and delicious.  Space is small, but this SF and I'm not going to fault them for that.  They are a part of the currently ongoing Dine About Town, so I may go again.
author: AJ K.

description:
I'm not a big fan of Indian food, or rather, my stomach isn't a big fan of Indian food.  On the other hand, it is one of hubby's favorite cuisines (he is English and Indian food is their national cuisine, right?).  

Being such a good wife, I took hubby to Dosa's on Valencia for his birthday last year.  I didn't even realize Dosa was an Indian dish!  I was pleasantly surprised with the dosa.  The taste was more subtle than other Indian foods I have eaten.  Of course, I'm a big fan of crepes in general so that probably helped too.  Hubby couldn't stop talking about how much he enjoyed his dish and just mentioned it again today (that's how I remember to write this review).  My stomach reacted similarly to all the other times I eat Indian food though.
author: Amy Y.

description:
OK, my now third update to this review:

The place looks great and is a great value for your money.  Seems that they'be worked out almost all the kinks with the service.  It's still very busy (good for them) but that translates into a long wait for you so plan ahead for the wait.

The food is really good, but isin't quite up to 'Udipi Palace' (the gold standard in my opinion for south indian).  The paper masala dosa had the masala served separately, which isin't traditional.  The mysore masala dosa needs to be crispier (obviously, still walking the fine line between the paper dosa and a non-paper dosa).  The drinks were very innovative and delicious.  Tried some of the curries on the menu recently and they were great.  The 'pepper chicken' is an excellent choice if you're not in the mood for a dosa.
author: Rudro S.

description: We tried the Avocado & Peach Salad, Egg Dosa and Tamil Lamb Curry as take-out.  All good, but not as spectacular as the meal we had before.  Would order the Watermelon over the Peach Salad and other Dosas over the Egg one.  We'd order the Lamb Curry again.
author: marcie v.

description:
Even though I've eaten my share of 10 rupee dosas in South India, I'm happily jumping on the Dosa bandwagon.

I love the vibe.  It's elegant and fun without being frou-frou.  And everything I've had has been superb (particular favorites are the paneer salad and the paneer and pea uttapam).

A lot of people were surprised that a relatively inexpensive restaurant like Dosa could be named one of the 10 best restaurants in San Francisco, but I'm not.  Besides fantastic food and great service they have something else that just can't be faked or bought: they put a lot of love into what they're doing.  Who wouldn't want that?
author: Tara M.

description:
The paper dosa I had last week was soggy... hopefully a one-off mishap.   I'm keeping the 5-star rating, though, b/c I've been utterly impressed every other time.  I went to Dosa a few Sundays ago for brunch and was bloooown away... really great salads & chaat dishes, along with the more traditional South Indian fare.  I had the egg poriyal with uttapam... a great deal at only $10-11.  Madras coffee is also a must.
--

I finally gave Dosa another shot (at FIllmore), and as promised, I'm updating my review.  This is truly authentic (with the exception of some "fusion" dishes that they call out), fresh, and mouth-watering south indian cuisine.  Possibly my new favorite Indian restaurant in the bay area.  Even the complimentary papad was notably better than what I've had in the past.  (I think you guys should add a masala papad appetizer... not sure if that's customary in south india, though).

Anyway, you've earned the 5-star rating in my book.
author: seema s.

description:
Let me start by saying that I don't like Indian curry.  Why would I go to a place with Indian cuisine if I don't like curry?  Well, not everything is a curry dish and my friends love this place so I wanted to be a sport and try it out.

This place is obviously very popular as can be seen by the number of people dining here right up until closing time.  My group had a wait of about 20 minutes which is really a short wait compared to many places I've eaten.  Waiting for good food is just something you have to learn to accept.  While waiting I had a lychee infused soju.  The soju flavor was actually pretty strong which threw me off because most soju I have had didn't have a strong flavor.  It tasted a lot like the overly syrupy lychee martinis that my roommate makes, bu this wasn't at all syrupy.  If you like soju though I think this is a definite must try, but probably not for someone who has never had soju or is very picky about their alcohol.
