For my meal I had the Paneer and Peas.  I was very happy with this dish.  It was cheesy and the peas were not all mushy.  The chutneys they give you with this dish is a great accompaniment.  I had a bite of a shrimp dish that was good and a bite of something with eggplant that was wonderful.  The mango lassie that I drank was so refreshing.  I loved it.  I would order a pitcher of it if I could.

I didn't have any problems with the service.  We got our table as soon as the space became available.  We didn't have to sit and stare at a dirty table hoping that someone will clean it for us to be able to sit down.  Our drink orders were taken promptly and we weren't pushed to order until we were ready.

If you do like Indian cuisine, not just curry dishes I would highly recommend this place.  It's more accurate of my experience to say that Dosa deserves at least 3.5 stars.
author: Luis M.

description:
I went there Friday night with a couple girl friends and we loved it! I didnt mind the 40minute wait, it is a friday night after all, and once seated service was prompt, friendly, and informative. I was the only one at my table with prior experience eating south indian cuisine (check out my Indian food list), but the menu was appetizing enough, and encouraged by the delicious aromas around us, my companions had no difficulty picking out their choices. I selected the uttapam sampler (moon something or another), Issy had the peas and paneer uttampa, and Jess had the Mysore Masala Dosa. Everything was de-lusious! Im looking foward to a return visit (hopefully soon) with a bigger appetite so i can try some of their apps, salads, and desserts.

Update:
Ive been back since and have expanded beyond the uttapams and dosas. The curries are divine! Had a mung been app salad that was beautiful. Soups and desserts were fine. Only disappointment was the uttapam sampler, ordered by me for a second time: just not as good... almost tasted undercooked.
author: Mollie M.

description:
I rarely give five stars to any place but I'll have to give it to Dosa they deserved it. Being that i only tried Indian food one other time in my life(and i didn't like it) i may not be able to judge the food as well as the next. 
I do know the customer service was amazing! Being that I've worked in the customer service business for years, i can honestly say that place made me want to go back. 

The hostess was delightful, and she called my dad when i our table was ready so i could take him on a little stroll through my new "hood". I'm sure other place may do that but I'm never experienced it.

Our server was awesome, i think she could tell this was our first time in an Indian restaurant, i think it was the clueless looks on our faces as we explored the menu with dishes we could not pronounce but we tried. She recommended some dishes we would like and also this lightly fried wheat bread..just to die for..i may just go back to order that.

I decided to get the Keralab Chicken and Cauliflower with coconut rice, it was great..but it was so spicy! I'm not one for spicy food but it was great, especially with that bread.

I also had a very good glass of white wine, which made the meal delicious.

As i stated before I've never really been to any Indian restaurants but for me Dosa(currently) is as good as it gets!
author: Nia W.

description: Randomly selected this restaurant one night. Absolutely wonderful Dosa, sambhar and coconut chutney. Great curd rice and coconut rice. Overwhelmingly spiced Goan prawn curry. Have to say was a little wary at first -walking into a almost full South Indian restaurant with practically zero Indian diners, but at the end was very satisfied with the quality of food. A little pricey, but will certainly come back here again.
author: R C.

description:
I tend to judge the authenticity of a restaurant based on the number people at the establishment who are native to the food being served. For example Ebisu, thumbs down vs. South Sea Seafood Village, thumbs up. Dosa definitely gets five stars on that gauge.

Previous to eating here, I was basing Indian fare mostly on cheap, b.y.o.b. places like Naan and Curry and some of the big ones in Berkeley, so maybe Dosa is only better relatively, but it changed my whole outlook on Indian food.
author: Sophia G.

description:
After an evening of some amazing indian classical music at the Sangati Center a few blocks away (ever heard carnatic music played on an alto sax?) i was craving some indian food. Dosa wrapped up the evening very nicely. We got a table in about 15 min, not bad for a saturday night, and the staff was super efficient and friendly.

The spring dosa was good, though the accompanying sambar was too sour - but the heavenly coconut and tomato chutneys more than made up for it. Portions were good size (i could have sworn the server said their special for the day was Fish Barramundi, coz i was a little taken aback when i got something as big as a Barracuda), but if you're one of those people with a mind-bogglingly large appetite, then add an appetizer or two and dessert and you should be in good shape.

Overall, the food was above average (note to indians: if you're expecting down-home indian cooking just like your amma makes, you will be disappointed). There's definitely more authentic south indian food to be had, but it involves a drive to the south bay and not-so-fine dining.
So if it's a nice evening out you're looking for, Dosa fits the bill well, not to mention the perfectly reasonable prices for the ambience and service.
Will definitely be going back.
author: Miki N.

description:
I've been here several times and the food is excellent. All of the curries and Dosa's taste fantastic with great mixes of spices to tantalize the tastebuds. 

The innovative drinks are also really good, especially the specialty martinis and cocktails. 

I only give Dosa three stars because of the price. There is plenty of cheap good Indian food in the city. It just seems like you are paying for the hipness factor when you are in here.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Mmmmmmm....I love the huge dosa crepes that fold over -- makes me want to sleep in a giant sleeping bag made out of dosa, so that I can have it for a midnight snack and breakfast in bed.

Favorite?  The curried cauliflower dosa -- mysteriously only available at the Mission Dosa and not the Fillmore location.  I've also had the paneer & peas dosa, and the eggplant masala dosa -- also yummy. 

As a vegetarian, I love that I can eat 99% of things on the menu.  Yay :)
author: Lisa C.

description: Open late. Great food, pretty spicy and certainly spendy but worth every penny.
author: K B.

description:
Just amazing service! 
The bartender spent at least 20 min giving my friends tastes of different wines. Then after waiting 30min total for a table - they were fantastic because we were a group and they had to scootch together a few little tables. 

We were finally seated. Our waiter helped us with the order. What was even better was that they were closing the kitchen and were waiting for us. It was really nice of them to do that. And then our food was fantastic! Just delicious. A great way to break into south-indian cuisine. I love it and will most def go back.

I must recommend though that you go in small groups of 2 or 4 and not 6 or 8 as that is a little difficult to handle in the small dining area. But otherwise just delicious!
author: Chiah C.

description: This place was a great Sunday night treat. I bike by this place all the time, and now I've been inside and experienced the great cuisine. It's obvious that they exercise the utmost care in preparing all their food. Try the dumpling appetizers, they come out hidden in a swirl of yogurt and are fantastic!
author: Eric R.

description: Isn't dosa supposed to be a cheap variety of Indian food? This place definitely wasn't cheap and all you're really paying for is the ambiance. I've had hole-in-the-wall Indian food that was comparable to this place.
author: Eric L.

description:
I've been meaning to go here FOREVER.  I never had dosa prior to Dosa (heh), but I love Indian food and I love crepes -- so I figured it would be a perfect union.  My peeps and I finally made it last weekend and were happily greeted with a menu offering every kind of dosa known to man....and it was indeed love & marriage.

Wine selection gets an A+ also.  The options paired very well with the spices in the food.

Didn't give it 5 stars only because I wanted my portion to be a little bigger.  I can't exactly blame Dosa though for my overly-voracious appetite!
author: Sid D.

description:
The food is really good.  Unfortunately, it takes more than just food to satisfy me.

There is a wait.  There is a wait of epic proportions.  I might as well have brought the latest Harry Potter book, but luckily I had many good friends around to chat-up with.  From my estimates we were waiting a total of 2+ hours to be seated.  That's ridiculous.  Even for a Friday night.

Looking over the menu, I spotted the first page, which contains a fixed-price ($35 at time of this writing) that allows you to choose a soup/salad, mini-dosa, curry, and dessert.  I always like to choose from this menu because it allows for a great variety of sampling at a moderate cost...and it reminds me of Europe.  Unfortunately, after selected all of my dishes, the waitress comes up and tells me that if the majority of our table (of 8) does not order from the fixed-price selection then I cannot either.  This made me actually angry.  If I was alone I would have left right then and there.

So, hurriedly I selected some other options from the base of the menu.

Here's what I chose:
Organic Greens, Mango & Goat's Feta - $9
Rava Masala Dosa - $11
Ice Water - $0 (Thankfully!)

Sticker shock?  Yeah...that's a bit high, especially for a dosa.  San Francisco eating ain't cheap.  Dosas in the South Bay can be found easily for $5 or less.

The salad was decent, but nothing spectacular.  Good balance of flavors and portion size was as expected.  Just nothing stood out on this dish.  You can make this one at home.  Buy one of those goat cheese and walnut salads in the prepackaged salad aisle of the grocery store plus a mango and Whalaaa!

The dosa was...awesome.  Possibly the best Dosa I've ever had.  Granted, I've never had this type (Rava) of Dosa before.  Maybe that was the factor that swayed me so much.  Also, I think I've had maybe 10-15 dosas in my entire life...so not a huge pool we're sampling from.  Oh, and some were buffet dosas.  Anyways, I'll give Dosa credit to their name.  This was the highlight of my visit.

Dosa might be better as a street stand selling delicious dosas - allowing easier access and concentrating on their craft.  I think the only time I will ever return is if I can be assured that the wait time is not more than 1 hour and they allow me to order whatever I want from the menu.  The disappointment was greater than the flavors this time.
author: Bryan T.

description:
wowza-

This place was incredibly good- with a capital G. I didn't give it five stars because, well, it was pricey and as a starving newly non-student. I need my budget- but for a splurge, and eventually for a casual dinning experience (when I'm not so broke ass) this is where it is at. Dosas are a type of crepe-type thingy filled with yummy veggie goodness that you dip in a pea soup sauce with coconut chutney and tomato chutney. Me and my friend got two and split them between us. OOOOOH WEEEEE... it was YUM. mmmmmm... I'm remembering the experience as I type. It was very busy in there, filled with happy shiny families, and hipster kids murmuring over candles. Our waitress was so cute and was more than happy to explain how to eat a dosa and which fruity soju drink to get. We stumbled out on to the street pleasantly filled and pleasantly surprised to find a new enjoyable place to eat.
author: Nnekay F.

description:
Giamma's review is succint and correct. food is excellent just about everything on the menu is truly authentic tasting. which was surprising to me until I heard that they have South Indian chef working the kitchen.

something unusual - the egg scramble Dosa, new to my taste buds but darn tasty, and same goes for paneer dosa. Don't know if egg Dosa work better as dinner or as a kick-ass breakfast entree.

Methu Vada were excellent and so was the Sambar (the lentil and vegetable soup) accompanying all the dishes.

Wine list is remarkable, but am I going to be drinking a bordeaux or other full body reds with my dosa? probably not. I think Champagne, and other sparkling wine from New Zealand works great with it, just get the bottle, its only $25, and great value for it.

and the solo entree for desert (ras-malai) which although is common across the board in indian restaurants, was done beautifully. Nice and light and very fragrant heavy cream sauce, the cottage cheese patties themselves were of superior quality than most other indian restaurants.

I think the place works as a great dinner date spot as well.

so give it a shot if you have never had South Indian food before. Remember, this is a just a sliver of the cuisine, for some of the more hard-core and fiery dishes of the south, you may have to visit the south bay. Though some of the dishes served their are bit adventurous for even my tastebuds.

peace
author: An u.

description:
update 8/17/2006.  
I finally made it back to dosa last night to give it another try.  i liked what i ordered a lot better this time and have increased my original two stars to three.  i had the chile and coriander uttapam.  it was very spicy which i like and was filling.  i did however, think the sambar to be to thick.  i also thought the coconut chutney was watered down and not flavorful enough.

my dinner partners both had a dosa.  they dosa's looked like a crepe from ti couz.  they were weird.  i didn't think they were big enough either (by typical dosa standards) especially for the cost. i did really enjoy the mung bean salad for an appetizer. i highly recommend getting it and splitting it between two or three people.

with all of this said, i wish dosa would introduce more south indian curries to their menu.  they have a few curries but only one is vegetarian, the channa masala, and it's considered a north indian cuisine.  i would like to see more okra dishes and more south indian dals featured at dosa and then i might consider giving it another try.  there are so many different vegetarian south indian dishes that i just think it's a shame to not feature more.

for now i will stick with my favorite dosas at viks and udupi - i think they are better tastings, cheaper, and an overall better deal for your money. 

old review:
i was so incredibly excited to finally get a south indian restaurant in the city that of course i went to dosa a week after it opened.  however, i quickly  found it very disappointing.  two of us ordered two appetizers (vada and idli) and they came out as very small portions only one pice of each (give me a break) - not much at all compared to great indian restaurants in the east and south bay.  then i got annoyed because a damn dosa was more than 10 dollars.  come on now and give me a break, a dosa should not cost that much!  a dosa at Udupi in berkeley will only run you about 5-6 dollars and kicks Dosa's ass. Of course I don't want to leave off better dosas at Viks and Saravana Bhavan in the South Bay. I would never even think to wait 2 hours for Dosa's food.
author: Kristie P.

description:
Second time here and the experience was a treat. The place gets crowded quickly and the noise levels are high. They wouldn't take a reservation for 3 - so was glad we were there at 6 on a Thursday!

The Channa bhatura and lamb curries were excellent. Very home style food. We also chewed up the masala uttapas and the Paneer Dosa. 

A bit pricey at about $45 a person, but we did leave with a satisfied belly and a bit of food for later

Would definitely go back .
author: Ron W.

description:
This is a strong 3-star rating, likely a 3.5 if I could do half stars. I'm not the biggest fan of Indian food but this was pretty good. 

Dosas - honestly I didn't think the dosas themselves were anything to write home about; I much prefer naan or roti. But the saving grace was the tasty  selection of the three sauces that accompany each order - all very unique & pretty yummy. 

Uttapam - don't get these. Ours was really soggy; the texture was so limp I couldn't enjoy the flavors. Stick to the dosas.

Dahi Vada  - these are described as fried lentil dumplings topped with yogurt. But in reality it is more like yogurt soup with three dumplings buried in it. I'm not kidding; you can't see the dumplings under the bowl of yogurt. It was good, but I never understood why you would fry something just to completely immerse it in a sauce; isn't the crispy texture the key objective in fried foods? 

Curries -  it was the curry dishes that will probably have me come back here - we ordered two, the lamb curry & the prawn mango curry, and I must say they were both pretty memorable. The lamb curry was rich, intense & robust, one of the most flavorful dishes I've had recently. The prawn mango curry  was equally satisfying - a perfect balance of spicy & sweet, a dish I will surely want to have again.

So the next time I come here I'll know what to get, and it might be closer to a 4-star experience.
author: Kathy Y.

description:
As someone whose mother was called the "Sambar" queen, and has been known to eat over 10 dosa's at a sitting. I have very high expectations when it comes to dosa. Suffice it to say Dosa is the feel good movie of the year for south indian restaurants. There are two key parts for a good dosa. 1. A crisp, buttery but not too oily dosa with a faint sourdough aroma and 2. Spicy sambar with tamarind's sour bite and lots of fresh vegetables and savory onions. Dosa delivers on both key ingredients to a great south indian meal and adds its own blend of friendly classiness and a modern sexy vibe that makes the other "Denny's" type south indian restaurants run home to Madras in their dirty lunghies.

A great date/people watching/stuff yourself silly without breaking the bank/ place. Some people complain about the wait but that's like saying a hot chick/cute boy is high maintenance. Comes with the territory baby!

But Dosa could do with some sound damping, it's very hard to impress your date with your intricate knowledge of south indian chutneys if all she can hear is the 4 other tables around her. 


Oh and my mom likes it too so there!

P.S. If you want reach the highest order of food indulgence order the fricking lamb curry already! You might just die from the pleasure!
author: Ketan A.

description:
edit: One of the co-owners messaged me thanking me for the 4 stars and asked what the restaurant could do for the 5th. That in itself deserves 5 stars - amazing customer service (don't worry, you get it in the restaurant itself too!)
****************************

One of my new favorite places. I can't believe I've found an Indian restaurant where I can leave feeling light and comfortably satiated, and not too smelly.
author: serena l.

description:
Wow! This place is amazing! My meal definitely lived up to all the hype. My husband and I made a spontaneous visit to Dosa at 8:30 on a Wednesday night and were seated almost immediately - which was a miracle, I think. 

The food was spectacular and unlike anything I've ever had before. Simultaneously rich and subtle and so so yummy!  We ordered 3 starters and one dosa, which was more than enough food for 2 people. 

I would highly recommend the Dosa we ordered - the Chatni Masala. It was filled with baby eggplant and creamy, spiced potatoes. Hmmm... so good! I also loved the Chennai Chicken - so tender and light. And the Dahi Vada - lentil dumplings topped with a yogurt sauce. And all of the chutneys on the side are to die for. 

I can't wait to go back, but I'm afraid of the lines. Having to wait amidst all of those delicious smells might just kill me. Maybe we'll get lucky with another spontaneous visit in the future.
author: Caitlin L.

description:
Dosa is fusion food done well ~ it's South Indian favorites with an American twist.  It's got a nicely unified decor (something that is usually lacking in Indian restaurants) with the crowded feel of midtown Manhattan hot spot.  

Yeah, some people might look at you funny if you eat with your hands.  That's right woman sitting across from me at the neighboring table, I saw you glaring at me - but hey, isn't that what the fusion experience is about?  A controlled amount of cultural dissonance!  Even the Amish-to-SF transplant Liz G. was eating with her hands!
author: Vikash G.

description:
LOVE Dosa. Adorable wait staff, nice atmosphere, chill music, right ambiance and, of course, South Indian Heaven on a Plate. 

The mango seed cocktail is the perfect dessert. Actually, all their specialty cocktails are awesome. (Dangerous, because you just want MORE!, but awesome.)
author: Cary M.

description:
Awesome experience! Great service... very informed and coherent waitstaff that provided us w/ proper ettiquette for eating dosas w/fingers ( not w/ a fork....which I didn't really follow for the entire meal ;)  ) . 

Betsy & I made it there around 6pm for dinner. It was quiet and there was a table available immediately by the window. We started w/ the Dahi Vada which was almost too aesthetic to destroy. That's dumplings hidden under a fantastic light organic yogurt w/tamarind and mint. Man... it was awesome.

Betsy got the Spicy Mango Shrimp and I chose the Spring Dosa, which we shared. It was a lot of food for just the two of us. I really wanted to try the Rasam Fire Broth but that'll have to wait 'til next time. 

Again, service was great, although at one point in time I thought it was almost TOO great and TOO attentive but I think that's just because we were having a pretty great discussion.... and so the southern indian cuisine was awesome. Cool Indian music & warm decor... a 5-star no less.

Definitely a next time! Try it if you haven't already....

P.S. Their website refers you to the parking garage on 21st between Mission & Valencia. I didn't even know there was a parking garage there... which made me happy, of course, because living in the Mission I'll definitely put this to good use. And it only cost $3.50 for the 2 hours we were there. Not bad, not bad at'all....
author: Ash G.

description:
Unlike some other reviewers, I don't have a whole lot of experience with South Indian cuisine. I do, however, have a lot of experience with restaurants and this is a very good one. I love it when the owners (Emily and Anjan) are on the floor working...you can be sure that quality will be insured and that's always the case here. Its no surprise that Michael Bauer (SF Chronicle) named this one of the 10 best restaurants in the Bay Area.

I've rarely been to Dosa when there wasn't a line at the door. Since I usually come here alone I wind up having dinner at the bar. The wine list is small but well chosen (although I wish there was a full bar). Having eaten here 20 or so times I've had most of what the menu offers and don't recall having been disappointed with anything. They offer two soups, a tomato and a "fire broth" and both are actually served hot (a pet peeve of mine is warm soup). Both are flavorful and light. I usually order the Chopped Salad or the Fiery Fruit. I do like spicy.

There are very few non-vegetarian dishes on the menu so being a non-vegetarian I welcome the Chennai Chicken appetizer. Again, just a bit on the spicy side the portion is large and the chicken, marinated in yogurt before frying, is moist and tender. One of my faves. I've had most of the Dosas but tend toward the Uttapams, an open-face version of Dosas. I love the Tomato/Onion Uttapam and the Chili/Coriander version as well. By the time I've finished all this I rarely have room for desert (although I always hear the siren call of the Valrhona chocolate gelato).

The prices are very reasonable, the service is excellent, the decor is warm and soothing and inexpensive garage parking is right around the corner. How can you beat it?
author: Gary C.

description:
I freakin love Dosa!!!

Spicy explosions of flavor in every bite. Delicious and satisfying textures to delight your mouth. Just go there!

For appetizers, try the idli. They're little dumplings made out of lentil flour and come with sambar, a super flavorful lentil stew with coconut (I think). They also come with two little condiment sauces, one is spicy-tomatoey, and the other one is creamy and coconutty. Seriously delicious. It's the kind of food where you're making little comments like, "Oh. Yeah! Mmmm. Oh my God, this is so good," with every bite, and you start to wonder if people around you will think you're doing a Meg Ryan in "When Harry Met Sally" impression.

I had the Spring Dosa, which was a dosa filled with potatoes, peas, carrots, and I can't remember what other stuff, but it was steaming hot, and had such amazing fresh flavor, and was cooked to perfection, with the potatoes done but still firm, peas still bright green and popping gamely in your mouth, really just so lively and fresh and definitely Spring-y. Again served with sambar (fine by me as I can't get enough) and the two condiment sauces.

We also had the chicken curry, which was really interesting to me and unique in it's denseness of spices and heavy use of chili and cardomom. It kind of reminded me more of an Indonesian curry, but then I'm no expert...I just know it was fabulous!

For dessert I had the mango kulfi, which was really good, but not all that different from gelato or regular ice cream, or maybe my taste buds were just exhausted from such an exciting meal!

My first introduction to Indian food was at Pasand in the South Bay when I was 18, and that's what I thought Indian food was for a few years. When I first tasted North Indian food, I was like, "Wha...?" I quickly grew to love it for it's own charms, but my true love will always be the Southern (Madras?) cuisine. Even the names of Indian dishes have such a wonderfully whimsical sound. How can you not love something called idli? Or sambar? Or pappadum? Or dosa? Or gulab jamun??? I dare you not to smile as you order your food!

Fantastic music, lighting, and decor add to the experience at Dosa. I can't wait to try the Fillmore Street location...and I hope they consider opening an East Bay location!!!
author: Marcianne A.

description:
Until recently, this was the only upscale Indian restaurant in San Francisco. I give it three and half stars. Mainly because while the food is good and tasty, and the decor very nice, it's overhyped. It's a trendy Mission restaurant in a city that does not have much to offer in good, authentic Indian food.

For a restaurant that is named dosa, their dosa is average - it was a bit more limp and soggy than I expected it to be. I've had better dosa from a cart in Washington Square Park in downtown Manhattan. And Vik's in Berkeley serves better dosa too. Except that Vik's is not an upscale trendy restaurant.

Some of their other dishes are quite good. Others not as good. The service is fine. The waits can be ridiculous.

While my review might seem a tad harsh, it is to be taken only in context of my standards for Indian food. Dosa is one of the best Indian restaurants in the Bay Area for food, decor, atmosphere, and service and I will be back, but I am keeping to my stance that there are no options for good, authentic, regional Indian food in the Bay Area. What do you say Restaurateurs, I think San Francisco is ready for the real, local Indian cuisine.
author: Adrian L.

description: The food is good, but the atmosphere is a bit pretentious. We much prefer Udupi Palace, just a block away, which is less expensive and has great food and service.
author: Veg V.

description:
For the value, the ambiance, the food quality and service?
4 stars.  The dosas are crispy, plenty of dahl for filling, and it was just the right amount of spicy.  The food is cheap, the service is great.  

I had the dahl vada, which is this lentil dumplings... my friend and I had 0 expectations and ended up licking the plate clean.  What's in that sauce man!?  I also had the spring uttapam.  It was slightly fluffy, packed with fresh vegetable ingredients.  The food itself alone?  I'd give 5 stars.  I've had the famous dosa cart in nyc, and that cart does not come close to the quality of this restaurant
author: Deanna L.

description:
When you are trying to find something besides a burrito then this is an option.  I've heard about this place and went here last minute after having ice cream at Bi-Rite.

25 minute wait.  OK lets head back to my place.  Two blocks later, ring ring, oh you can seat us now?  Scrrrrreeeeccccchh!  VROOOOM!

Naming yourself after one of the food items means it's  must to order it.  I"ll get into that in a minute.  We ordered: 
Cochin Calamari = good
Jumbo Prawn Masala = good but the coconut rice wasn't very flavorful
South Indian Moons = good especially the lentil spicy dipping sauce
Spicy Mung Masala = OK but I expected more since the name on the store front is Dosa.  I say this because having Indian food in San Jose area cannot compare.  

However this place is one of the better Indian places in the city. 
Total $72 for a party of three.
author: Po L.

description:
I've only been here once and was not impressed. I may have just ordered the wrong dish and should go back to give it another shot. However, I do think there is too much hype for just average food. 

The decor is nice - very fancy (not like more traditional Indian joints). The food seems more catered to a Western palate. I ordered the Spring Dosa which was basically a salad with a paper dosa around it and with very little flavor. For better dosas, I reccomend going to Udupi palace down the street.
author: Amanda W.

description:
Went to Dosa for the first time last night and was very impressed with both service and food.  We were a large group so we were able to walk right in with a reservation - I would not want to wait in the lines waiting for the smaller tables.  One note - our table was a bit crowded for the reservation for 8.  Be very,  very good friends if you come as a large group.

The waitstaff was friendly, and very busy.  That was fine because the menu explains everything - which is great if you're trying (like we were) new foods.  

Best part - a very nicely balanced wine list.  The mark-ups on bottles seem reasonable and the selections match the food very well.  I could come back, sit down with dosa or two and happily work my way through the by-the-glass selections.

Worst part - incredibly noisy!  We shouted across the very small table and still didn't hear all the conversations.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
A friend of mine had been raving about this place for a few months now, and I decided that it was time to try it out. Overall the food was good, but not as fantastic as my friend made it sound. This could've just been the case of him setting my expectations too high...

To start, we had the Chennai chicken and the paneer & romaine salad, and the salad was great! The chicken, while good, definitely played second fiddle.  The salad was just so refreshing, and ended up being the perfect compliment to the spicy chicken.

For our main course we had the masala dosa and the lamb curry, and both dishes were tasty. It was my first time trying dosa (which is obviously this restaurant's signature dish) and it did not disappoint, The lamb was very tender, and the curry in which it was served was quite good.

They have an interesting array of beverages available on the menu which includes some nice Indian wines and lillet cocktails, which I had not had before.

The staff was friendly and made great recommendations, but I have to admit that we felt a bit rushed while enjoying our dining experience. I assume that this was because we were there on a Friday night and the restaurant was packed.

I will definitely visit Dosa again in the future...just maybe on a slower night!
author: Art D.

description:
I have been a South Indian food fan for several years now.  After Udupi Palace opened in Berkeley, my wife and I go there more consistently than any other restaurant. We have also had decent dosas at Priya in Berkeley, India Curry House across from Bimbo's 365 in SF, and Saravana Bhavan in Mountain View.

We have been intrigued by Dosa since we found out about it here on Yelp and finally got a chance to try it last night. We showed up around 7pm on a Saturday, and surprisingly, it only took around 15 minutes to get a seat. We ordered a Taj Mahal and Pelegrino at the bar while we waited, examining our menu options.

We started with the romaine and paneer salad, which was good, except the paneer didn't really add much flavor. Crumbling up and sprinkling our remaining papadum over the salad was actually a good idea.

The baseline South Indian dishes for us are the masala dosa and sambar. We were not disappointed by these.  The dosa was nicely done with crispy on the edges, stuffed with delicious potato masala curry. We were not at all impressed by the coconut or tomato chutney. The coconut chutney in particular was comparable to a dull sweet hummus.  Luckily, the complexly spiced sambar provided ample dippage. I would also like to recommend a side of the mango pickle.

We also tried the only vegetarian curry, chana bhatura, which is a chick pea curry served with a large bhatura, which is a fried bread similar to poori or even sopapilla (fry bread of the southwest).  The combo is noteworthy. I just wish there were at least one more vegetarian curry to choose from...

The atmosphere is nice and decor is pretty trendy. Our bill for all of the above was $60 including tip. So, that was pretty expensive, but worth it for the experience.  We will likely try Dosa again, but with a little more self control on the ordering. More than likely, you'll find us at the completely vegetarian Udupi Palace in Berkeley.
author: Ron L.

description:
Very solid food, yummy tasty sauces, super-friendly service. 

FANTASTIC FANTASTIC FANTASTIC wine list. I mean, seriously. Someone understands both the flavors of food and loads of wine styles. I haven't been led wrong yet.

Yes, it's super-trendy, but the owner's around and looking and listening; he's in for the long haul. And is extra good to 'hood locals.

Only downside is all those hard surfaces bounce sound around and around and man, oh, man does it get loud. Solution? Carpet on the underside of the table surfaces would do a lot to mitigate this.

Get your ass here and eat some food. The curries are quite possibly even better than the dosas or uttapams.
author: Glen M.

description:
Wow!  Even though another review of Dosa is clearly unnecessary, I must write something because of how much I love it.  

The food is spectacular!  If you are looking for something to wow your palate, this is definitely it.  And everything I've tried has been very good.  But you must like food with strong flavors!  Even if you don't, my partner was extremely content with his salad.  The mangos on the salad were incredibly ripe and sweet.  

I just have to mention, because everyone seems to rave about the service, a couple of things.  This is not the place to sit down for a relaxing meal.  The bussers are practically watching you eat until they can come and clear your plate.  On numerous occasions at this restaurant I have told three different people that I am not done with my food and then finally give in because I am tired of fighting to keep it on the table.  The food comes out immediately.  I feel like they are just trying to get you out of there as soon as possible because they are trying to make more money from the next customer.  That being said, if you are trying to make it to a movie or show, this could be a good thing.  Although, as other reviews indicate, your wait will probably be longer than the amount of time you end up sitting at your table.  

Nevertheless, the food is more than worth it.  I actually give it a 4 1/2
author: Nellie M.

description:
went last night for their first Monday night.  Yeah I know the owners.  I am writing this review because in the recent past I recall hearing a handful of friends(fickle) comment on the lack of authenticity or spiciness(hot peppers).  

Does one need an off the chart scoville rating to consider food tasty? Taste buds overwhelmed with heat?  I think the food is very delicious/authentic.  I mean the chef moved from India, what more do you want.  Had the sprouted mung bean salad, cause I'm sorta on a health kick.  Quite tasty.  Cutting down on the meat even though we had the lamb and the chicken curry.  Had a really nice glass of a New Zealand Brut, and I think it was a Austrian bubbly, and a great albarino too.  one of the better wine lists in the city as I am a fan of whites...

Oh and my morning BM was not painful.  ahem Pakwan...

Dosa #1:  The Mission
Dosa #2:  __________________
author: Greg M.

description:
I was excited when I heard of an Indian restaurant that specializes in dosas. When I arrived here my excitement almost instantly turned into apprehension. This place was way too swanky for a restaurant aimed at serving what is essentially a breakfast dish or light lunch. I almost felt like more attention was paid to the lighting, fixtures, design, and bar area than anything else in the restaurant.

Once I saw the menu and its prices I grew even more wary. $10 for a dosa? OK, I'm willing to bite, but this better damn well be a fucking incredible dosa.

We ordered dahi vadas (little crispy dumpling like things immersed in yogurt and sauces) and onion pocadas. While the taste wasn't bad, it certainly wasn't super authentic or confidence inspiring. The dahi vadas had way too much yogurt in the mixture and the spice/taste was far too reserved. 

Once the dosas cames out (we got the panner cheese filled and 'authentic'  spiced potato varieties) I was impressed with the size. The dosas themselves seemed to be executed well in terms of texture and crispiness. However, taste failed for authenticity on all accounts. The dosa wasn't too bad, but the potato filling was certainly way to tame for me. Seemed 'americanized' to me...maybe I need to try the spicier versions.

Oh also, we waited over an hr for what ended up being bar seating...and I don't think they take reservations. The place is pretty small, with maybe 15-25 tables total, and unfortunately most of the space is wasted on the over sized bar.

For a place that is supposed to specialize on one dish, is this crowded, and is on the higher side for prices, you would expect something really authentic and to have your socks knocked off. My socks are still on...

Maybe I have to give it another try and order something else?
author: Varun ..

description:
The restaurant is outstanding for its service. The staff is trained to be experts about their dishes: origin, flavors, cooking techniques, and wine parings. Recommendations fly off their tongue without any effort and they always emit accessibility, grace and confidence.  Like in other big cities, it's a relief to encounter a little bit of down-to-earthiness. 

When I went, I just couldn't stop eating as if a metronome was commanding me to place scrumptious bites into my mouth from the Prawn  Chili Fry to the Rasmalai. Like a fellow reviewer, I too went from a food trance into a food coma. I hurried home, changed into my least restrictive pj's and kicked back on the sofa for an hour, until I resurfaced from that same euphoria and went with my gf and friend over to Little Baobabs.

For entrees: the Tamil Vegetable Curry has texture and seasonings like nothing else, Paneer and Peas Dosa will satisfy the Paneer fiend, and the Chile and Cilantro Uttapam had a great crunch to it.  Unfortunately, the Chutney Masala Dosa had a filling too thin and slippery to top my list. 

I was considering giving the place 4 stars because it's a little pricey, but I think the food and the atmosphere speak for themselves. My Indian friend with whom we had dinner recognized the owner from a family wedding. This made me eye him curiously throughout the night and I have to say that I liked the way he seemed to stay calm, aware and active- not that I know anything about restaurant management. 

Dosa is for rare occasions, since the price tops similar formidable taste establishments: Udupi for Indian food or Osha for Thai. Better to make it an occasional or even rare indulgence.
author: Masha R.

description:
One of the best Indian restaurants I've ever had...Overall ambiance, food, service was all A+

We arrived early around 6 to avoid having to wait as they don't take reservations.. Started out with a Mango lassi soju martini... It was soooooooo good.. Like an Indian version of the soju-yogurt Korean cocktails I like so much...

The food was too fabulous...had a lamb vindaloo.. the uttampan sampler, Masala Dosa and the calamari starter..

I think South Indian food is my new favorite.. It's light, spicy and refreshing with spices galore and a hint of citris here and there... None of this overpowering cocunut milk curries at the other places... While I do a like a good chicken korma and tandoori... given the choice, I would pick Dosa over any other Indian place... plus the cool loungy atmosphere and cocktails makes it the hands down winner!
author: Doris M.

description:
I'm a fan of this pretty restaurant. First of all, of the vast vegetarian variety of their menu. Went here for brunch on a Saturday afternoon during when they were serving "Chaats". At first, I thought it's a really interesting starter, and our waitress seemed to recommend it so much to us (and other tables), but after it got to our table, we thought that the portion is not really worth the price. If it's $6-$7 it's still reasonable. We're talking $9 here for 6 pieces of chaats. 

The dosas on the other hand are delicious. We had the masala dosa and it was really tasty. The pappadums they served earlier was great too. I thought the pappadums were the best among other pappadums Ive tried. And also, go for the Chai or Soy Chai. Not only they are deliciously creamy and thick, they are refillables! yummy
author: Rika P.

description:
Let's cut to the chase here. The problem with this place is the intense cognitive dissonance you get if you've ever eaten at a proper dosa restaurant. Stuff like dosas and channa bhatura are Indian street foods. A dosa is normally like $5, if even, and eaten off a tin plate. These guys only get away with charging $10 for a basic dosa or $13 for a channa bhatura because the they're the only game in town, so the food is new to many people.

Basically eating here feels like it would if you went to a pupusa place, and the sommelier recommended a wine for your pupusa. Or if you ate at a place that bills itself as a trendy, sit-down hot dog restaurant. You're sitting in front of food made of chickpeas and potatoes, eating with your hands, smudging your cocktail glass with greasy fingerprints. It just doesn't feel right.

That being said, I relented on the stars because the food isn't bad. It wasn't spectacular (my bhatura was deflated and a little cool, the dosa was good, but not the best I've had), but again, it's the only place in the area I can get south Indian, and it's pretty good. The food was definitely low on the heat level; ask explicitly if you want it spicy. Indian coffee was okay (it has some nice chicory flavor).

My experience with the service was very positive. The host and the bartenders were laid back but attentive and quick. The decor was very nice, all flickering candles and warm colors. And, true to trendy Mission form, the place was filled with good looking people.

I can't wait until we get a real south Indian food shack in San Francisco someday with cheap thalis and Indian sweets!
author: Andrew H.

description:
Dosa? Yes PLEASE!

We went about 5:30 last Saturday night with no reservation and were seated immedaitely.  The server was very friendly and helpful with explaining the menu items to us, and since we had never eaten here before that took some time.  She was a perfect guide and navigated us to several GREAT tasting items including the right beer.  

About 15 minutes after we were seated it seemed like the crowd hit Dosa hard (it was a good thing to get there when we did).  

There are 332 reviews before mine and virtually all of them rave about the food at Dosa.  I agree with all of them.  You could taste the freshness of the ingredients and it was truely fantastic!!

We left happy and stuffed and took a 20 mintue walk aorund the Misison just to feel somewhat less full before leaving the Mission.

I can imagine there is quite a wait for seats here so I would recommend and reservation or coming very early.

I cant say enough great things about our experience at Dosa and we will definitely be back very soon!!!!
author: Chris G.

description: Truly unique and delicious. Paperdosa is my go-to and I just learned you could add cheese to the potato filling:)
author: Nisha M.

description: Overall a fine night with friends at Dosa.  We had a big enough group that we just ordered a whole bunch of different stuff and shared it all, even the small plates.  The place was packed to the gills and we were all enjoying ourselves enough that I wasn't aware of any problems at all with service or the flow of the dishes that arrived.  I don't even want to list all the things we tried, but it must have been half the menu or so.  I don't recall anything being disappointing, but then again nothing was so over the top delish that I would need to rave on it.  The different dosa dishes provided nice visual variety for the table, though some of the sauces provided in the ramekins got a bit monotonous.  The coconut rice was new to me and was tasty.  It helped offset a few of the hot chile sauces. The lamb curry I recall had a nice medley of spices but was overly salted for my taste.  We had so many dishes that when dessert was offered, nobody bit.  I don't know if it was the variety of food or the multiple glasses of King Fisher but later that night I was awoken by multiple sheet rumblers.  When the sun finally rose, my body smelled spicy and I was still blasting 'em on through my morning coffee.  It was a fine night to be with friends in the city and Dosa was a fine host.
author: Ho H.

description:
WAITING FOR DOSA.  If you have more than a party of 4, make a reservation and do it before that afternoon.  We called in the afternoon to make a reservation for 6 people and were told that they couldn't make a reservation this late, so to just walk in. We did and had to wait 2 HOURS! At first they told us 45 minutes to an hour. Okay, fine. We had drinks and waited. Then were told that their computer went down and they couldn't tell us how much longer until they figured out seating manually.  So, we waited. Then we were told that a table of 6 was leaving and we could have their table.  But instead, they ended up giving the table to people who had a reservation. At this point, we said if we don't get seated in 5 minutes, we were walking. As luck or time would have it---it's now 9:15pm---another table opened up and we got seated.  

Once seated, they gave us 3 appetizers on the house, which was nice.  We just wanted to eat.  Of course, the food was yummy.  Just wished they were better organized with the reservations and seating....if we knew we would have to wait that long...we would have tried somewhere else.
author: dgirl a.

description:
Absolutely Marvelous Food. Great Ambiance. Good Selection of Appetizers and Entrees. Very Authentic South Indian Food.

Must try appetizers:
Dahi Vada
Mushroom.....
author: Chandrashekar G.

description:
My friends and I stumbled upon this gem on a Saturday night, eyes widened, looking into a crowded and bustling restaurant. Never having heard of this place (I was visiting from out of town), I thought, we HAVE to try this place. Did I mention that we were starving for food??? Everything looked so good-the decor, the lighting, even the people! The hostess there was great and since the wait was long, she recommended that we eat at the bar since a few spaces opened up. I just have to say that I am so glad that I ate there that night. We ordered the calamari which was a little exotic (too many spices), the paper dosa (YUM) and the chatna something. Can't remember the rest of the name, but it was the BEST part of the meal!!! I just remember that it had a lot of garbanzo beans in it. 

The prices are fair and I would definitely make a trek back to Dosa. I would probably  make a reservation next time. This place gets so busy. Can't wait to go back...
author: boody p.

description:
Holy Moly this was good!

My cousin asked me if I have had southern Indian food before.  My response?  Yes, of course.

The reality?  Not like this.  Everything was amazing.  I did not even understand what I was dipping into - an array of chickpeas, spicy sauces, eggplant, yogurt, everything under the sun. 

Even the desserts were superb.

One caveat: my tummy was doing flipflops the next day.  But it was worth it.
author: Jill D.

description: One of our regular spots.  Love the egg dosa and the south indian slaw appetizer and nice but casual atmosphere.  Also great drinks and bartenders are good at creating new ones if you give them some inspiration.
author: C S.

description: Yummy food, great atmosphere, nice service! Finally checked out this place and it's great. Staff were friendly and helpful making recommendations.
author: Claire R.

description:
I'm not a fan of most Indian food, especially Mughlai cuisine which is what all "Indian" restaurants in the States really serve. There's a lot of South Indian food I love, and thank God for Dosa!

There's two reasons I love Dosa: 1) it's very San Francisco Mission; it caters to the San Francisco crowd, not the Indian-missing-home-food crowd -- makes a world of difference, seriously. 2) it's South Indian food: the menu's a potpourri of dishes from Chettinad, northern Tamil Nadu, northern Kerala And central/southern Kerala.

If you're new to South Indian food in general, I suggest you go in a group so you can sample a lot of different food. I highly recommend the Cochin Calamari, Dahi Vada, Heirloom & Idiappam, Mysore Masala Dosa, Rava Masala Dosa and Chennai Chicken (curry). You might want to order some bhatura (puffy wheat bread; it's North Indian) for the curries.

They do have some North Indian items in the menu, like samosas, baingan bharta, onion pakora, etc., if you care.

End with a cup of nice Indian tea (not pre-sweetened!).

I've always had a good experience here. And the wait staff is pretty knowledgeable so don't feel like you'd be lost here. Alternately, if you're having a tough time deciding, get the four-course tasting menu.

Bon Appétit.
author: Premshree P.

description:
-- Heads up, I went last night with a group of eight and if you have a group of five or more you need to make reservations a few days in advance. 
This place made me want t cry... the food was so good, everything was so absolutely fantastically good. I actually have to go back again today. I bought extra food just to take home.. it was like being on Girard street in Toronto except it was clean, and there are more choices of food to eat.  
The lighting was great, the whole scene was perfect.. hell I even loved the art. Its sorta loud for an intimate dinner for two, but being nestled in next to your date at one of the booths will more than make up for it.
author: Zee B.

description:
We had dinner here on a Saturday night. There were 7 of us and we hadn't made reservations prior - for some reason we were unable to do so using their online reservation system which links directly to Opentable. In any case, we waited for a little over an hour to be seated and boy was the wait worth it!

There was a huge selection of items to choose from and everything we tried was absolutely delicious. I grew up eating lots of South Indian cuisine in Malaysia so I am definitely picky about my dosas and uttapams. The wait staff was friendly and when they brought out one extra item that we hadn't ordered, they didn't charge us for it.

We were certainly stuffed by the time we were done and much to our delight the tab wasn't astronomical. That's 2 bottles of wine and plenty of food for $35 per person (including tip!).

Highly recommend the place!
author: N K.

description:
I dont usually like indian cuisine, but I always recommend this place. I take all out of town friends there because I know that Dosa is sure to please every time.

Always a long wait because it is so %$#@*& good.

Paper Masala=Yum
Lassi Drinks=Yum
Dahi Vada= YUM!!! Definitely try this one

Love the food. Love the ambiance. Love the service. Love the prices.
author: Rosie M.

description: I'm a little skeptical of primarily vegetarian food...  We went with the Chennai chicken, the Masala dosa and the uttapatam with paneer and peas.  Everything was great and incredibly filling.  There was also an Indian wine on the menu which went perfectly with the meal.  The staff, especially the owner, is really friendly and nice.
author: Wendy L.

description: If you are comparing to inexpensive Indian food, as most of these reviews do, you will gripe about the price and portion size.  But it was delicious, and the waitress was an all-star, complete professional.  So comparing Dosa to high-end restaurants, it had a great atmosphere, terrific service, and tasty food (small portions).  $100 for plenty of food and a delicious Sancerre for two.
author: Robin W.

description: Spicy, spicy, spicy - and usually when something is this spicy, it loses in flavor, but this food had a lot of flavor. Little restaurant, so either make reservations or get there early. Parking is available in a parking structure 2 blocks away.
author: Alldaron K.

description:
Although I had much higher expectations, it could be said that there was really no telling what I could expect since my exposure to Indian food is limited to a few mild curries, tikka masala, mango lassi, and various iterations of naan.

Cochin Calamari Calamari, sauted with a sumptuous spicy sauce... 8
Spring Dosa Masala dosa combined with fresh vegetables including peas, carrots, cabbage and red onion... 9.5
Pepper Chicken Tender fall-of-the-bone chicken prepared in a sauce of crushed peppercorns, ginger and an assortment of spices, served with Basmati (Indian long-grained) rice... 15
Tamil Lamb Curry Niman Ranch Lamb steeped in a sauce of fennel, tomatoes, poppy seeds, caramelized onions and a blend of other spices, served with Basmati (Indian long-grained) rice... 16

The common theme at Dosa was "my mouth is on fire." My recent infatuation with non-breaded calamari was satiated at Dosa, where we were served some of the smallest calamari sections I've had to date and although I liked it, it kind of took away from the chewiness factor that I'm so fond of. The preparation was similar to a calamari salsa, with diced tomatoes, cardamom pods, and the coconut chutney as a dressing. Our dosas were the Indian-equivalent of burritos where the tortlla was replaced with an thin, egg-based pancake and stuffed with the corresponding vegetables. I thoroughly enjoyed the lamb current, but my taste buds were burned out by the time I reached the chicken. I could tell, though, that the chicken was disappointingly dry for a slow-cooked curry preparation. Although the food was good, I probably won't be back since the service was less than fruitful.
author: Monica T.

description:
This was one of the places I want to try before I moved back to LA but never got a chance. I was back in town for a day on a business trip, so I gathered some friends, made reservations and pushed my flight back a few hours.

It was good and unique Indian food. Their main entrees are Dosas, surprisingly enough. They are delicious thin and crispy crepes filled with various and familiar Indian dishes and ingredients. The starters were good too as well as the salad we shared.

If you are a first timer, try the marsala dosa, that's what I had and I recommend it.
author: Scott M.

description:
What's left to say?
I think their mango lassis are a bit small, I guess, but I'm still on board to become a regular.
author: Sean S.

description:
My new favorite Indian restaurant! Dosa opened when I lived in the mission years ago and after attempting to go 3 times in the first year it opened (I don't like to wait), I gave up and Dosa dropped down to my B list. Fast forward 7 years, I was searching for a new vegan friendly restaurant and finally tried Dosa. I love going to an omnivore restaurant and having a variety of options besides salads. The paper masala was super fun to eat - the pictures don't do it justice - this is a huge mammer jammer! And I loved the South Indian Moons - The mini uttapams were deliciously chewy with crisp edges. The soy chai was also fantastic. We also tried the potato and mushroom curry with the coconut rice. It was good, and not greasy like Indian curries tend to be, but not as great as the other dishes. The decor and music were both chic and hip - the perfect ambiance for a date. The hubby and I sat in the window and people watched as I became nostalgic for my days living in the mish. After dinner, I didn't feel weighed down like I usually do after Indian food, and the best part was that my hair and clothes didn't smell like the food. 

P.S. Sunday night is a great night to eat at Dosa - we had a 6:30p reservation and most of the restaurant was empty.
author: Vivian A.

description:
I'm usually skeptical about trying out Indian restaurants in the bay area, as i have found most of them to be highly overrated. With my usual skeptical exuberance, i tagged along with my friends to Dosa. We didn't have a reservation, but the line wasn't too bad. After a 10 minute wait, we got a table. The decor is pretty nice, a welcome change from the usual garish ambiance of most Indian restaurants. 

They have a pretty extensive menu, although everything is overpriced. We ordered Idli sambhar as an appetizer. The service is prompt and the idli was brought out in under 5 minutes. It is pretty easy to screw up an idli, but the idli was super soft and the sambhar was pretty kickass! with just the right amount of flavor. 

We all decided to go with dosa's. We ordered the Rava Masala, Paneer, and a regular masala Dosa. The dosa's are pretty awesome! super moist. For the first time in my life i have actually liked south indian food. The spice was just right and the chutneys and sambhar are some of the best i have had. 

I would highly recommend this place, you won't be disappointed!
author: Tushar V.

description:
I've only been once, but I plan to head back soon. A friend and I decided to head over one night and had only a brief wait at the bar before being seated at a cute little table right by the front window. It gave me a great ledge to rest my giant beer on as we dove into some seriously yummy food. 

We started with the lentil dumplings which were a little too dense for my taste, but the sauces that accompanied it were delicious. 

Then we split a Paneer and Masala dosa. While the descriptions of the dosas may sound a little plain, be advised that the dishes come with two chutneys (coconut and tomato) and a sambar so you can pick and choose which flavors you want to create. 

That all said, I found it a very reasonable meal, a great dining atmosphere (warm colored walls and friendly waitstaff), and seriously tasty food.
author: Emily L.

description:
You know what is one good way to judge a restaurant?
How do you feel after you're done eating there?

Does you stomach feel happy?
Do you feel relaxed and not rushed?
Are your ears calm or ringing painfully?
Is your wallet still about the same size it was, or 17 pounds lighter (or with smoke coming out of pieces of plastic)?

If your answered affirmatively to most of the above questions (first part), then it's probably a nice find of an eatery.

That's how I feel about Dosa.  All the dishes my friends and I shared were flavorful and *not* greasy.  The sauces, quite distinct, with most packing a pretty good punch :).  And speaking of spice:  whoa, try the fire fruit.  They're not kidding when they say fire :D.

My lassi, as with most lassis in America, was a bit too sweet for my tastes (compared to the more authentic creamy-but-not-sugary lassis), but I give a hearty thumbs up to everything else.

Even the server was friendly and helpful.

Out of respect for one of our friends who is a vegetarian, my other friend and I (avowed omnivores) ordered only veggie dishes.  And we didn't miss the meat one bit.  Now THAT is saying something :)
author: Adam L.

description:
Love the food. 

Updating my review**

After getting a personal email from the owner I'm revising my review, not many businesses these days will follow up so quickly when a customer voices an opinion. A little customer service goes a long way in my book and is worthy of revisiting what I initially wrote here. 

We had a mishap when we arrived, having a reservation for 6 people, which changed to 5 then 6 again. One of my friends wasn't on time for our reservation and we were told we couldn't be seated until she arrived, so our table wasn't held. After speaking with the owner and getting flustered about the thought of having a long wait before we were seated (there's always a long line) a table opened for us. We didn't have to wait as long as I'd feared. The owner graciously offered to buy our table a round of appetizers, more good customer service to make up for the mishap at the hostess desk. 

Our dinner was excellent however it felt a bit rushed by our server and the bus staff. It made me feel like the main concern was to turn tables quickly. 

While I most likely won't go back with a group, it just didn't work well for our party of 6, I would return with a smaller party. 

The food is done well, decor is lovely, crowd is interesting and the price is reasonable.
author: stephanie h.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy! My Indian friend and I came here for lunch last Sunday and the 1st thing we noticed is that all the employees were so nice and friendly! Apparently, they were serve brunch over the weekends, but we were still able to order what we wanted (well, what he wanted - I put my friend in charge of ordering!).

We started our meal with Bhel Puri (puffed rice, diced green mango, potatoes, tomatoes, onions & coriander). This dish came with spicy & sweet chutneys, but it was so good, it didn't need them!

Then we shared their Non-Vegetarian Curry of the day (paneer, spinach, cauliflower, carrots, chicken). It was sooo good! The chicken was so moist and tender and slightly fatty - yum - but it wasn't overcooked. The veggies weren't mushy. It was perfect! I just wish they gave more rice so I could make dish last longer!

We also shared the Masala Dosa (dosa filled with creamy, spiced potatoes, onions, and cashew nuts). The dosa was nice and crispy on the edges and soft in the center and the filling was wonderful. The three dipping sauces (coconut chutney, tomato chutney and sambar) were all so good and they didn't taste the same.

Great food, great service, and affordable too!
author: Sharon W.

description: This place was good. Keep in mind that this is southern Indian cuisine. You will not get tikki masala or naan here. So go somewhere else if that is what you are craving. I would recommend the Chennai chicken and the chaat.
author: Lina M.

description: Got the plate recommended by our server, to try a variety of southern Indian foods.  It was rather confusing as to what was what and what to pair with what, was not able to remember after they quickly told me.  It seemed tasty, but I think my lack of experience with Indian food does not allow me a to be a fair judge.
author: Kristin S.

description:
Okay - I've just changed my mind on this place. I went here several months ago and wasn't overly impressed (perhaps it was because our party was smushed into too small of a space and we were turned off). Last night we went back to try it again and we were all quite pleased. 

They have an interesting wine dish, and it's quite yummy. Dosas are tasty, but the appetizers were even more delish. Try the madras coffee.  It's a bit on the pricy side, but since it's an unique change from the standard Northern Indian cuisine, it's worth treading yourself now and then.  

Try to get their early to get a table - this place gets packed.
author: Julie L.

description:
Good, well presented dishes that are definitely NOT your typical steam buffet all-you-can-eat Indian meal deals.

Had the Dahi Vada, a lovely presentation with the mint and tamarind making a beautiful pattern with the cool yogurt.

Tamil Lamb Curry was nice too. Nice balance of spices cooked with tender chunks of lamb that went well with the Basmati rice.

The Spring dosa was good as well, a variation on the Masala dosa.

The beer selection was good, way beyond your typical American macrobrews and the token Kingfisher found in typical Indian joints. I'm  not much of a wine drinker, so the variety of beers was a thoughtful touch. I actually got a kick out of getting my SO a bottle of Lindemans Framboise, which she really enjoyed with the food.

Overall, a nice place to dine with friends, or perhaps your date if you don't mind shouting your sweet nothings to him/her over the loud din of hipsters that fill the restaurant during peak dinner hours.

My only small gripe is the prices for some of the dishes. A Chana Bhatura runs $13 here, where you can get  something similar (granted, minus the presentation, service, wine selection, and atmosphere) at Vik's in Berkeley for about 2/3 the price, or even some of the offerings at Udupi Palace which are equally interesting and tasty.

On balance, Dosa fills a need for smart, upscale Indian cuisine in the Bay Area.
author: Bono B.

description:
Where I liked the ambiance, decore, and had excellent service, I am simply not prepared to pay so much money for Indain food and to leave hungry!

The style of Dosa is Southern Indian food, reminding me of the fare served up at Vik's in Berkeley.  And where I found everything flavorful and tasty, it was 3 to 4 times the price of Vik's, and the portions were about half the size!

For specifics:  Not being super-hungry, four of us split 2 tasting menus for the sake of variety.  We had lentil dumplings and the chicken appetizer, a chatni masala dosa, a tomato and onion uttapam, the shrimp curry, the lamb curry, the cheese cake and the rasmalai.  I really enjoyed everything I tried, but the portions seemed to be about 1/3 the size of a normal entree.  So the 3 plates seemed more like the equivalent of 1 dish - for $35.  With wine and beer, the bill was about $70/couple, yet I was still hungry.

Our server was excellent and patiently explained the whole menu to us.  The place was packed, and we had waited 45 minutes for a table.  But she was so nicely accomodating to newcomers who may not understand the menu.  I did like the feel of the restaurants.  I'm just not used to paying so much for Indian food.  Too bad.  It's a good concept.  I can see paying a little less but leaving full and being very satisfied.
author: Stephanie R.

description:
I stumbled across this tiny restaurant, while with a friend from New York. We decided, what the hell and gave it a shot. The ambiance was alluring and balanced. During a week night with were seated rather quickly and commenced of family style meal. All in all it was quite tasty, filling, reasonably priced and friendly.  We had a great experience and meal. 

I have been there since, to my chagrin on a weekend.  Our party of 4 waited over 1 hour to be seated. Just at the end of my rope and ready to get pizza instead, the hostess apologized for the exorbitantly long wait and did her best to seat us promptly there after. When seated they comped the appetizers and the meal began. We all walked out satisfied and delighted.

I will have to poopoo the naysayers about this restaurant. Obviously, they know little to nothing about the variations in flavoring of  regional cuisines.  My only advice, educate your pallet. Take a trip to Indian Row if your ever in New York near Saint Marks Pl and truly discover and learn the differences in Indian fare. 

Overall, the experience is warm and inviting. Well educated and prompt staff. There are better Indian restaurants but you will need a plane ticket, toll for the bridge, or BART ticket in hand.
author: Devon D.

description:
FOOD: Married to someone whose family background is South Indian (Chennai), I have to say the food is just plain fine.  We were jumping for joy when we realized that a dosa/idli/vada place opened up right here in SF but the food does not compare to the dosas found in Berkeley, Sunnyvale, and Santa Clara or my in-laws house of course ....unfortunately, those are not a 5 min ride from our place!

I had the spring dosa the last time and the filling was bland with no depth of flavor. The dosa itself was not quite the right combo of crisp and soft. And, to my utter surprise I think I detected garlic (?) in the coconut chutney that accompanies the dosa....that is not authentic and a bit weird for me but maybe it was an attempt at innovation?  I don't remember the taste of the sambhar though it left me happy that day but the portion was small!  Also had the pakora which was good.

The lassi was too salty and had to send it back to tone it down. 

Will update this section with hubby's comments on his food.

SERVICE: Maybe this has changed since we were last there but it's odd to eat at an Indian place (no matter how damn hip) with no Indian servers/hosts in sight.  I gather that the owner makes the rounds talking to customers now, which is nice. Our servers, the two times we've gone there, have been nice enough but they seemed to neglect our table...maybe they thought we knew the food already and didn't want to waste their time.  But c'mon, re-fill our water glasses at the least!  And, it's not cool having food "dropped" on your table instead of being "placed" on it.

PRICE: Pricey for South Indian food.  It's pretty much double what you would pay outside of SF. But hey, they're the only ones around here serving this type of food so I shouldn't be complaining.  SIGH, what I would pay for Gujarati (Western Indian) thali food if only they had that cuisine in the city.

AMBIANCE: Loud and crowded but I like that it's clean and some thought has been given to the interior color and decor.  It would be better if the tables were moved apart a bit more so you're not jutting your elbow into people walking by or the person at the next table.

Will go back again to satisfy South Indian food cravings if we're not able to get to the East or South Bay. Next time though, I'll try other main course items on the menu besides the name sake. Perhaps one of the uttapams or curries...
author: Abha K.

description:
Eh.

The food gets four stars.  The dosa and uttapam and accompanying chutneys and sambar are quite good, and much different from normal Indian fare.  As my dining partner commented, it's almost too much flavor.  The prices are reasonable and the portions are good.

But the atmosphere and wait staff get two stars.  Both times I've been here, the experience as a whole has really rubbed me the wrong way.  

There are far too many tables crammed into the small space, and you're sitting right on top of the people next to you. (Literally -- I couldn't help but have my butt touch the table of the people next to me when I walked past to sit down at my table. That's just gross.)  It's loud, everyone is crashing into each other (staff and patrons), and it's just uncomfortable.

The wait staff is creepy nice -- that sort of saccharine, fake smiles, sucking their teeth when you don't order wine and appetizers and dessert kind of attitude.  They act far too uppity for the price and fanciness of the restaurant.

Don't get me wrong, the food won't disappoint and I'd take home a tub of the coconut chutney if I could.  But overall, I don't think this place lives up to all the hype.  I'd rather go to Aslam's or Cafe Ethiopia or probably even Herbivore and have an overall better dining experience.
author: Megan D.

description:
I don't really even know why they bother to offer the 5 or 6 "South Indian entrees." - they taste about the same as you'd get at a very good Indian restaurant, except you're paying more for the organic ingredients. The Dosas (and uttapams) are unique and set them apart from the other Indian.

That being said (that was describing the lamb that I got), both of my friends' Dosas were delicious - I don't know why I didn't get one. Great service, and the drinks looked good.
author: Mark A.

description:
We finally ate at Dosa tonight and man, what a treat!  I love the place.  Real flavor.  Fresh.  Bests my previous favorite Indian restaurant (Indian Oven in lower Haight).  

Definitely worth a go if you dig really good Indian or other South Asian food.
author: Scott M.

description: Dosa is one of my favorite places for interesting south-Indian food. The corn and curry leaf soup is my current favorite.  All their dosas are well done, and the Sambar is one of the more flavorful ones I've had. The only downside is that it can get a little noisy and cramped when it is busy (which seems to be all the time).
author: Sandeep T.

description:
Upon arriving at Dosa on a Thursday at 6 pm, we were seated at the bar until the rest of our party arrived.  The bartender casually introduced some of his favorite dishes to us while we waited.  As folks trickled in, our party became complete and we sat down to a half-full restaurant around 6:30.  By the time we ordered, the restaurant was full and pleasantly noisy with spirited conversations around appetizers and entrees.

Dosa specializes in southern Indian food, which is a fairly dramatic departure to what most of us are more familiar with.  That being said, there are some recognizable items on the menu -- things that read "curry" or "lamb" or "masala".  However, the stars of the menu are the namesake of the restaurant: the dosa (and its cousin, the uttapam).  Our server was very enthusiastic in explaining just exactly what these were -- the dosa is a thin rice crepe, while the uttapam is a thicker pancake, both of which can be ordered with a variety of fillings or toppings.

But first, the appetizers.  We started off with the Chennai Chicken (fried boneless organic chicken marinated in organic yogurt with coriander and cumin).  Boneless buffalo wings from India?  Perhaps, but the mild spices were a surprise, which I appreciated since I could actually taste the chicken, which was tender, moist, and flavorful.  We also had the Dahi Vada, which confused us a bit when it arrived at the table.  The bowl of yogurt we saw actually contained the small lentil dumplings underneath the tamarind and mint design along the top surface.  Not only were the lentil dumplings great, but the leftover yogurt went very well with our entrees also.

I am a huge fan of paneer, so I was immediately drawn to the Peas and Paneer Dosa.  My rice crepe came filled with shredded farmer's cheese, peas ,and cilantro.  While the portion size was relatively small, there was just enough food to satisfy me without making me feel bloated -- as I often do at Indian restaurants!  The peas and paneer were also very subtly spiced, allowing all of the main ingredients to shine for themselves.  The dosa and uttapam dishes come with sambar (a lenti dipping soup) and two chutneys (tomato and coconut).  The tomato chutney was a particularly good accompaniment to my peas and paneer lentil.

We also ordered an uttapam topped with a masala containing potatoes, onions, and cashews.  The uttapam was a more substantial pancake, which made it more integral to the taste and texture of the dish.  If I were to return to this restaurant, I would definitely order the uttapam over the dosa.  Another masala we tried was the Channa Bhatura, which contained garbonzo beans witha choice of  an oversized puffy wheat bread or a vegan poori (fried bread made from whole grain durum wheat).  We assumed that the non-vegan wheat bread would not be fried, since it wasn't mentioned specifically in the menu, but it came to the table glistening with oil.  A bread was definitely required for the masalas, but perhaps a baked option would have been more appreciated here.  Nonetheless, both of these masalas were great dishes with an obvious taste departure from the more commonly known northern Indian cuisine -- I suppose everything simply tasted milder.

To round things out, we also ordered a more familiar Tamil vegetable curry with cauliflower, green beans, potatoes, and cherry tomatoes over coconut rice.  This dish was unoffensive and rather plain -- it was, once again, very subtle in spicing, but the vegetables by themselves weren't particularly punchy in flavor, leaving a bit of a vacuum of taste with each bite.  The subtlety of spices in the other dishes were to their advantage, but not so well here.  Then again, this vegetable curry isn't terribly adventurous when it comes to southern Indian cuisine, so I'm not surprised that I wasn't terribly impressed by it.

I suppose the lesson here is to understand the motivation for this restaurant.  Do not treat it like your local lunch buffet Indian restaurant where your tandoori chicken is haphazardly perched over a bed of biryani.  Instead, embrace the individual flavors of the dosas and the uttapams and let the ingredients speak loudly with undertones of Indian spices.
author: Jim W.

description: No, it's not authentic, if you mean what would have passed for contemporary back in your grandmother's day. Yes, it's innovative, though not gratuitous. Yes, it's very good.
author: Bib G.

description: very affordable rate for the nice food and well decorated environment.
author: Paiyu G.

description:
Go early to avoid the wait and volume bomb!   Very tasty and I love the texture of the dosas themselves.  Crispy outside but just slightly chewy or is it gummy inside..  Really good.  The wine list (apparently chosen by the sommelier of Michael Mina) had several slightly sweet whites that went oh-so-sublimely with the spicy, spiced dishes.  Mmmm.  Can't beat it. Just bring some gum for the garlic..

2/3: Whoah, just went back there, and the food was great, but the service!! One star.  Appetizers came out and sat on the table for 2 minutes while we waited for our plates.  Our wine finally came out after we were done with our appetizers.  Water came out 1 minute earlier. Dirty dishes piled up and up..and up.  I know you're busy, but c'mon. You're understaffed!
author: Melanie C.

description: Great spot to grab Indian food in the Mission.   Dosas are yummy.
author: Heather R.

description:
Every review I've written lately has been five stars, and its not due to being easy to please- the streak of restaurants I have gone to lately really have been phenomenal.

Dosa is crowded, and noisy, but adorable nonetheless.  I would get a reservation next time, we waited about 30 minutes for a party of 2.

Once we got in though, and the dosas came, all the waiting was suddenly worth it.  Dosas are various types of Indian crepes with fillings that range from peas & paneer to potatoes, onions or meat.
