They were delicious and a great new twist on the usual family style Naan 'n' Something Indian places.

I could get used to these dosas, and Dosa is definitely too close to my house for my own good...
author: Jessica P.

description:
I have to admit that I wanted to dislike Dosa.  I have tried to get in there numerous times without a reservation, only to be turned away at 7:00 p.m. with the notion that there are no tables available until 10:00 p.m.  They won't make a reservation if there is table of less than 5, which I consider to be pretty snotty, especially considering they are in the Mission, but sure, whatever.  Go right on, ahead.  

I tried Dosa last night....finally.  We were sat pretty much in the middle of the restaurant, which was a little too loud for my taste, and my ears were ringing after we left the restaurant.  I got the Masala Dosa, which I thought was really good.  I had a non-spicy chutney that I kept dipping my food into.  The manager also brought us an extra dosa, because he felt that my boyfriend's dosa was a bit too crispy.  Now that is good service.  :) 

I will give Dosa 5 stars for service when you are actually in the restaurant, 4 stars for the food, 3 stars for ambiance, and 2 stars for having to wait for too long and try too many times to get in.  This averages out to about 3.5 stars, but they don't let you do that on Yelp, so I will go 4 stars, because I liked the wine.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Since there are so many reviews, I will add only what I think is missing: if you don't like spicy food, this is not for you.

Dosa is wonderful, the flavors of the few things I tried were stunning. It deserves its ever-present line of salivating potential diners waiting to be admitted. But even the "mild" food I ordered nearly burned my mouth off.
author: Amy T.

description:
i hate it when i read a review that starts like this but: 

3.5 starts.

or actually, maybe more like 3.45, since i would totally round up if it was closer to 4. but it's not. 

3.45

i avoid the gluten and i live in the hood so it was great to find this place and know that i could eat bread-like things with impunity (made with chick pea flour) but it's not a 4 because:

1. pricey pricey. am i paying $2 extra for the innovation of "air-chilled tomatoes"?

2. very limited meat selection. like one chicken dish. which was a good dish, mind you, but i need more variety in my life. that doesn't involve goat or lamb.

hey you guys i just had a thought. the plain dosa is kinda like a thin version of ethiopian injera. i think one of these nights i'm gonna get a dosa to go and take it across the street to the ethiopian place (since the ethiopian place serves rice for the gluten-challenged and that's not nearly as fun).
author: Will R.

description:
I kind of assumed this place was busy with people waiting outside only because it is chic and trendy, but after eating there i can say that the food warrants a 30 minute wait.  Usually i hate to wait, and i will not do it, but i've been wanting to try this place for some time now.

The waiter was very knowledgeable about the food he was serving.  The flavors were intricate and complex, and left me very satisfied.  

I can recommend this place to all vegetarians and vegans.  The vegan dosa's were just as excellent as the "regular" ones, which are all vegetarian btw.
author: flip it up u.

description:
Fantastic... food, prices, service, atmosphere!

I love this restaurant for all of the above reasons.   And I ate here right after becoming engaged to my husband.  All nostalgia aside, you cannot go wrong by eating here.  I'd be surprised to hear anyone say that they were not satisfied with their experience here!
author: Jen M.

description:
There is now one (but only one) place to get good indian food in SF.  We wanted to hug the staff for a meal that reminded us of London.  It's not as good as the best of London... But far better than the rest of SF. 
Service was also very good.  From the crowd at the door we expected quite a wait, but were seated before we could decide on a drink.  Once seated, we ordered and were served within 15 or 20 minutes.  I usually expect slower service at a new-ish restaurant and was pleasantly surprised.  Oh and it was very inexpensive.
author: adam m.

description:
Decent, overpriced South Indian food. The only reason this gets three stars instead of two is because it's the only South Indian place close by.

- In terms of value, this doesn't hold a candle to Saravana Bhavan in Sunnyvale. Or any other South Indian place I've ever been to. :-P

- The most ghee I've ever had in my sambhar. Questionable. Not bad at all, though.

- We were caught off guard by the pathetic level of heat in the food. Yeah, I guess we should have asked, but really, it's South Indian food.

- We came here early in the evening in the middle of the week. The place was packed, but no wait. Slow-ish service.
author: R E.

description:
I never could understand why there was a line outside of this little South Indian Dosa spot.  However, I had the pleasure of finding out for myself whether the wait was worth it.

On a random Sunday afternoon a friend and I decided to walk over and take a chance on getting post brunch time seating.  It worked! No wait (yay!!).  

The dosa's were quite good, however the price was not.  Imagine paying $13 for a burrito???  Well, that's how I felt paying $13 for a dosa.  

Having just come back from India and devouring some of the yummiest home made dosa's on the planet, I find it difficult to understand why these folks would rip off innocent (read: dumb city "foodies" of non ethnic origin) by offering really good (not great) tasting dosa's at high prices.

Let's remember people, the food is from India....which means it's supposed to be CHEAP!!

I'm glad that there is a place like Dosa in the Mish.  Now.....if we could just get them to fall in line with Mish-like  and India-like prices, that would be awesome!
author: DJ N.

description:
I had been craving for real South Indian food. I had been eating my fist at night thinking it an idli. 

I'd been through loads of Indian restaurants, only to concede to the usual vegetable masala.

Needless to say, Dosa really hit the spot for me. I ordered a Mysore dosa, as well as some idli to start. The sambar was perfect and thick. The staff was nice. The wait was alright (10 minutes). I got to eat with my hands. I missed South India a teeny bit less.

It is a bit pricey, but worth it. I was a bit skeptical because something with the interior was telling me "uh-oh, there is no way they can do it properly", but I was pleasantly surprised.

Hooray! I will be back really soon.
author: Base M.

description: Absolutely love this place!  The food is great and the service is awesome.  Service is always friendly, never pushy or uptight when you come by right before they close for lunch or when they're busy for dinner.  I'm a fan of the Paneer & Peas Dosa, as well as the Tamil Lamb Curry.  Both are absolutely delish with the roti or uttapam!
author: Reb R.

description: HOT yup thats right HOT. Good food and good environment and bonus good drink. Should give it a try.
author: Anuj K.

description: I finally made it over to this restaurant on uber hip Valencia.  It has been packed the past few months and I was psyched to see what all hype was about.  Sad to report that while the ambiance is nice and the people pretty, the food is just average.  The best doas to be had are still in Sunnyvale.  I had the masala dosa which was just okay.  Plus some of the stuff did not look too legit...paneer caesar salad? Pass.  Service is prompt and friendly...that always gets half a star from me!
author: Kamael S.

description: I loved Dosa in the Fillmore and finally had a chance to swing by the one closer to me, on Valencia.  It was packed so we sat at the bar, on the corner, and enjoyed every minute.  Food is delicious.  Because of how the bar is situated, unlike the Fillmore location, your view of other patrons is a bit obstructed- this will be a plus for many diners that want a little more seclusion.  Either way, bravo to the creators for taking Indian food beyond street foods and hole in the wall dining.
author: Andre S.

description:
I must say SPICY HOT! :)  
So my mouth fell off eating here...but it's worth falling off a bagillion times...because regardless of the spicy...it was delish! 

I loved this place, and will definitely return. 
I never knew about this place, but wandering on a Friday night with a friend to figure out what to eat...my nose KNOWS best ....hardy har. 

I smelled this place walking by and HAD to eat there. Friday nights must get busy...so a 45 minute wait was well worth it. I must say  though the best part was that they actually take down your phone number and call you about 10 mins before the table is ready..which is a GREAT idea, because you can wander the neighborhood until your table is ready. 

The ambiance was very nice and a nicely designed restaurant. A lil crowded if you go on a Friday night, so I may opt to choose another night next time. 

So indulging a little my friend and I chose the 4 course meal which was roughly $40 each...oh I think it was a little more because it's an extra $15 for the half glass of wine, that you get per course. They weren't horrible wines, but wasn't the best ever...but definitely good :)   There is only one course where you can get red wine, the rest are white. 

With so many dish selections, I can't say which exactly I ordered...but everything in the course was very savory and delicious. Calamari was pretty good, along with the curry prawns. The dessert was even delicious as well. The donut like ball (which was pretty sweet), and pistachio ice cream was yummy in my tummy! 

If you are a fan of super spicy food...this is the place to go. 
The service wasn't bad as well, and they were pretty friendly. 

I look forward to returning!
author: Catherine O.

description:
So we finally made it here after two prior attempts where we were discouraged because of the large line and huge crowd outside of the restaurant waiting on tables. I think on our first attempt, we were told that they had no tables at all. No wait time was offered. The second time, we were told an hour. My belly couldn't take the wait. Plus, they wouldn't let us up the number in our group when a couple of friends made an inpromptu decision to join us for dinner. This third time I came prepared. So I wasn't the least bit shocked when they said 45 minutes. The minute that door flies open, the smells from the kitchen are overwhelming. The air is so thick with wonderful aromas that, as hungry as I was, I thought I could taste the air. 

We ordered the lentil patties with yogurt sauce as a starter. I like yogurt but I thought the amount of yogurt on this dish was a bit excessive unless you love you some yogurt. But I found that it overwhelmed the lentil patties, which I would've liked to have tasted more of. When they first put the dish down in front of us, I thought it was dip and didn't get that there were lentil patties hidden underneath. (Sorry, I'm a novice.) For our meal, we ordered the Meysore Masala Dosa (dosa stuffed with potato, served with lentil soup) and the lamb curry. Both were absolutely delicious. Spicy enough to give it just the right amount of kick, but without leaving you sweating like a hog. Perfection! 

Good service + great atmosphere (but a wee bit too crowded) + good food + good prices - long wait -  no waiting area - no reservations for parties less than five = I give my first Dosa experience 4 stars.....
author: Marie M.

description:
When I hear the words "Indian food" I usually go running, which explains why it took two attempts from a friend before I agreed to give Dosa a try. I guess I'm just not all that adventurous when it comes to food - one of my rules is no cuisine that is eaten primarily with one's hands. However, Meagan M. gave this place a glowing review and said that even Indian food novices would like it.

Upon walking through the door, I was immediately impressed by the amazingly appetizing smell. It was a bit warm and crowded, but luckily the noise level didn't overwhelm normal conversation. Atmosphere is lovely - nice for a date or a group of friends.

We ordered three things, none of which I can pronounce. I felt like a lot of the ingredients in the uttapams and dosas were a bit redundant, but nonetheless everything I tried was delicious. My favorite was the dahi vada (lentil dumplings with yogurt and mint sauce) - not only beautiful, but very tasty.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
I had such high expectations. And they were obliterated. Nothing I ate sang in my mouth. And they stupidly had to move us during our meal, which I found kind of annoying:

My friend Dave and I came in at 5:30 on a Thursday night (they had just opened for dinner) and told them that another friend may be joining us later, so please give us a seat with the capability to sit three people. They sat us at a four-top (which was two 2-tops pushed together) table in the middle of the restaurant. 

After ordering, and while eating appetizers, a different host-person sat a group of three at the 2-top next to us, now making it impossible for us to expand to that table, should our friend show up. 

And our friend did indeed show up.

So what did they do? Instead of moving the threesome who had not even received their food yet, and who came after us, they moved us! I was in the middle of eating! I could not believe it. It was lame. The right hand was clearly not talking to the left hand. Had they been super busy perhaps I would have excused it, but they weren't

And then the food, was not amazing, as I expected. I ordered the South Indian Moons Uttapam. It was fine but not *that* tasty. And the channa was almost too spicy to enjoy.   I also ordered the Chopped salad. A simple dish that I have had at other indian restaurants. This one was almost flavorless. I've had better. For 8 bucks I should get some flavor. 

Even the pappadam that they give you for free when you sit down was kinda oily. I've had much tastier pappadam at other fine indian restaurants.
author: Andie J.

description:
Okay, the good, the bad and the ugly 
The positive
+ Hip atmosphere
+ Great service

The Bad
+ Some of the food was pretty good, some not so good.  Generally  the dosas were mediocre.    

The Ugly
+ Way overpriced tasting menu - omigod!  Shocking.  Don't do it.
+ Waiter said we under ordered, but we *way* over ordered.
+ They added a 20% tip for 5 people or more plus a 4% SF service fee.  Just a little over the top. 

Warning - long wait if you don't do a reservation.  Need 5 people to make a reservation though.

My guess is they can improve these things, but they are a hot restaurant right now, so not sure if they will.  Would I go again, no.  Was it a horrible experience.  No, it was fine.

UPDATE
I had a good e-mail exchange with one of the owners after my posting - I think its nice when they respond in an open way to reviews.  I should note that the we pay the 4% SF health fee, regardless of whether its an additional fee, or whether its imbedded in the cost of the food.

The 20% was still a source of disagreement between us.  But heh, we both said our thing.

Anjan mentioned they increased the lamb portion, so they are listening to feedback.  Always a good sign.  Might I try them again - well, maybe.  If Anjan makes my dinner selection:~)
author: Jessy B.

description:
Super friendly service and nice, homely vibe.  The food was okay - the prawns in the appetizer were over cooked and the two other dishes we got tasted very similar, because they both came with the same sauce and soup.  

Still, they went down very easy and I think I had one of my best post-meal experiences ever.  For stuffing myself the way I did that night, I did not feel sick at all.  All the ingredients were well-balanced and there weren't too much of anything -- not too much salt or grease or whatever it is in food that makes you want to die if you eat too much of.  That's pretty awesome.
author: Andrew P.

description:
Delicious food! I absolutely love Indian food and the cuisines here were just packed with flavor and spices.

If you haven't had South Indian cooking before, definitely talk to the waiter (ours was very helpful and friendly, bit of a dry humor sort of guy, but I liked him and he was very helpful). They'll do a great job explaining the menu. Its definitely family style dining, I would not recommend eating one dish alone, it'd be an overload of one flavor.

My friends and I went with the Peppercorn Chicken, Paneer & Peas Dosa,  Paper Masala Dosa, and Chile and Cilantro Uttapam. The peppercorn chicken was very nicely spiced and served in a delicious curry, however, I was a bit disappointed in the description as fall off the bone as it required a bit of cutting. The Dosas were just great. The paper masala - I think - is probably the most basic as its just a crepe dough and you dip in the various sauces, which I thought were great. The Paneer and peas, also very good. But my favorite was the Chile and Cilantro, so much flavor in that one. A bit small serving for that dish, but it just explodes with flavor in your mouth. I love spice and cilantro is - wait for it - awesome!

The restaurant itself is a bit cozy but not so small you're inadvertently joining your neighbors conversation. The ambiance is very contemporary but not so cutting edge it freaks you out. Colors are earthy and comforting.

I feel this is a good place for a small group (no more than 6) or less. If you're into ethnic food with a modern twist, definitely recommended. I was warned about the service here, but didn't personally have a problem our waiter was very courteous and helpful. So hopefully the seasons of change are coming about.
author: Quan D.

description: simple elegance.  Good times, great food.  The food speaks for itself...it's delicious and light, but feeling enough.  Definitely will come back!
author: Jac T.

description: Wonderfully delicious South Indian cuisine, served by professional and attentive staff.
author: Kathy K.

description: Pretty good Indian food in a nice environment. But Aslam's and Udupi Palace on the same street serve very good Indian food at a lower price. Service was very good though.
author: Prague G.

description:
LOVED it! 

All our dishes were outstanding and included the Dosa Masala, chopped salad, lamb curry, pepper chicken, prawn masala... wasn't terribly crazy about the Cosmopolitan cocktail I ordered... it tasted like they forgot to put vodka, either that or my taste buds were shot as I had been out day drinking since 1PM. 

Service was friendly, although I must say I felt somewhat reprimanded by the host because 2 members of our party were 10 minutes late for our reservations and we couldn't be seated without all members of our party there... totally fine, I understand... we didn't make a big deal about it at all and I felt bad we weren't all there in time, but all told our 2 friends were only 10 min. late, so it wasn't *that* bad to warrant a wrist slap, yes?

Other than that and the weak cocktail (maybe I just got unlucky with a weak pour, but next time I'll probably just stick to beer) everything was fabulous. 

Dosa is modern/hip, so a definite change of pace from the traditional Indian restaurants we're used to... recommended and I will return with the boyfriend.

**UPDATE** 4/30/07

I just learned that the cocktails are made with Soju because DOSA does not have a liquor license... now it makes sense why the cosmo I ordered tasted different...have plans to return but will sneak in my flask of vodka. 

KIDDING. ;)
author: Nenette Y.

description:
It looks like all the other reviews have already summed this place up pretty accurately. BUT: let me give you a quick run down of our evening and you can be the judge.

We showed up at 7:30 (reservationless as they don't do reservations for parties smaller than five) and were told the wait would be about twenty minutes. There's not really any waiting room so we told her we were going to walk down the street to the Phoenix for a quick predinner beer and would be back in 15. "Would you like me to give you a call when your tables almost ready?" the hostess asked. "Why yes that would be fantastic!" I replied. So we walk down the street and have a couple of pints at the Phoenix. Admittedly the wait was more like 45 minutes than 20, but I was sitting at the pub having a pint so I didn't really give a pakora! The hostess finally called and we walked back to the restaurant where our table was waiting for us. 

We get to the restaurant and sit down. Jennifer was our waitress and she was simply fantastic. Even though she was relatively new to the restaurant she knew the menu inside and out and capably guided us through our options and helped us decide what would work best for us. The appetizers came out quickly, and were amazing. The food came out quickly, and was amazing. All the while Jennifer stopped by to top of our wine and make sure everything was as good as it looked (it was!). We finished the meal with the Gulab Jamoon (Two soft, lightly- fried milk balls served in a warm, cardamom flavored sugar syrup) and the Kesar (saffron) Pistachio Kulfi (Indian Ice Cream). Definitely interesting but still good..

All in all it was a great meal: Good food, good service, good atmosphere, just good. Be sure to check it out some time!
author: Jeff S.

description:
Can you hear me chanting "DOSA, DOSA, DOSA!"? My husband & I  finally booked a sitter and got out of the house with a group of friends last night to check out Dosa.  As other parents can attest - the perceived value of a night out is compounded further by the fact that you're paying someone $15 an hour to watch your kids so you can escape the house to go out and spend even more money on dinner, drinks, parking & entertainment.   It had better be good.  Well Dosa didn't disappoint!

The owners, Emily & Anjan, were so incredibly accommodating and gracious to our large party - and even squoze in 1 more with an unexpected last minute arrival into town. 

We all did the $35 4-course menu (a deal!) and we all tasted bites of each others plates.  You just couldn't go wrong.  The staff was also friendly and genuine.  

We will be back for sure!
author: Kristin S.

description:
The wait was super long! It took us over an hour to get a table.  The wait was so long in fact that I was over the point of being hungry and I couldn't enjoy the food as much.  The service was top notch, and everyone was really friendly and helpful.  The dosas were okay, but sort of disappointing, partly because there was so much hype about them, and partly because we waited so long for them.  

What was really good though, were the veggie chips which were so crisp and had such a rich wheat flavor infused with vegetables.  Dip them in the chutney and the cream sauce and it's on.  

I probably wouldn't go back unless the wait was less than 20 minutes, but overall, I'm glad I went. 

Happy birthday ZACK!
author: James C.

description:
Very different than your standard Indian food.  But encouraging that there are large groups of Indian families here for their special dinners.  LOVE the dosa's.  You need a reservation on most nights, but might get lucky and get a seat at the bar. 

Note to self: need to go back.
author: Angela T.

description:
One day I saw the paper dosa as it stomped through downtown New York City, crushing cars beneath it, smashing buildings, until it eventually climbed the Empire State Building, fine broad in silk nightgown in hand...  RAAAAHHHHHHHH!

OK, maybe not.  But it certainly was big enough.  And kind of phallic looking.  Perfect for the silly 8th grade boy humor that lurks inside me and likes to make awkward jokes on first dates.
author: Sarah J.

description:
A very interesting take on Indian food. Genuinely authentic, almost traditional Indian.... yet has a unique twist, bringing the taste into the new age.

Getting the tasting menu is a good idea: exposes you to the spread Dosa has to offer. HIghly recommend the White Truffle Masala Dosa and the Sunchoke and Sweet Peppers Uttappam.

Cocktails: Ginger Ante is a modified Dark and Stormy... the ginger beer pairs well with the Indian flavors.
author: Aditi K.

description: My friends and I and one of my friend's dad were looking for an authentic Indian place (you tend to take visiting parents to authentic Indian places). We were browsing through some restaurants on yelp and after failing to find anything open for lunch buffet after 3 pm, we figured out that we will hit a restaurant on valencia. We did not find this place until we were actually on valencia. I was taken aback to see staff of white and african american origin in an Indian restaurant. This was kind of an Americanized  - South Indian restaurant. The waiter was very friendly. He did pronounce the names of the dishes in correct manner and I was smiling happily. They have a huge selection of dosa and it is fresh. Don't forget to try rasam (South Indian soup :) ). The chef's name is Murthy and he is from Chennai. I would love to try the other two dosa restaurants too.
author: Anand R.

description:
I heard about Dosa from a few friends and had always wanted to try it.  As a recent NYC to SF transplant (15 months) I had experienced quite a bit of disappointment when it came to Indian cuisine in San Francisco.  After my third try I decided to give up on it all together, until I came across Dosa's name again when planning out my valentine day dinner and decided to finally go for it.

Because of my last minute reservation the only table I could get was for a 9:30 seating, much later than I had become accustom to in the city.  My date and I were almost 40 minutes early and our host was happy to seat us right away.

We both ordered the prefix menu;a 4 course meal with 4 or 5 options to select from at each course. We also went with the wine pairings for the prefix; a generous 1/2 glass of wine with the first three courses.  Between the two of us we were able to enjoy 8 different items and 6 wines.

The waiter was friendly and warm, personable, and knowledgeable of the food and the ingredients as well as the wines.  The food was a bit hotter in flavor than I was used to for Indian (I was certainly feeling it the next day), but the quality was excellent.  The atmosphere was decent; the wall colors were as spicy as the food, the light fixtures were a bit unattractive (I'm a lighting snob, so I'm a bit harsh).  The seats were comfortable, especially after having all that wine, but I thought it was a little tightly packed (I could follow my neighbors conversations too closely).  

A highlight of the meal was the Dahi Vada, which I thought was one of the most attractive dishes I've ever seen at an Indian restaurant.

Dosa was by far the best Indian restaurant that I have come across in San Francisco and I would certainly dine there again.
author: Mister G.

description:
Nice finale to a perfect San Fran day coming from the De Young impressionist show, we showed up at Dosa on a Saturday night at 8:00 pm, no reservations. After a short wait we took our seats at the bar, again another unexpected bit of perfection or masterpiece in both our food and the service. 

The food appeared within minutes. The sauce were rich and well seasoned and obviously made from scratch. A wonderfully creative cocktail list included a Lillet cocktail with a provocative name spiked with fresh ginger and mint served by undoubtedly the best looking bartender we'd ever seen. We seriously thought about returning for brunch, though it was likely he wouldn't be working the morning shift.

Would return in a heartbeat!
author: Lisa B.

description:
I declare this place... a must-see!

Food-- Spicy and Delicious
Ambiance-- Loud, but tastefully decorated
Service-- Usually quite good-- Occasionally bad

This place gets 5 stars for the food alone.

It is a little noisy, but the food is so good, you'll put up with it.

Try this place.  The food is fantastic.  Unlike all the other Indian Restaurants, this place serves Southern Indian food, so you won't find your regular Indian menu.  If the menu overwhelms you, ask, your waiter to help you decide.

I've been here about 5 times and I have the waiter/waitress choose for me and my party every time and we haven't had a bum meal yet. 

Definitely get the yogurt rice.
author: Tahd F.

description:
Update: I always want to eat here.   It feels like it should be a part of my Perfect Sunday Day where I top the activity and excercise off with some warming comfort food.

Never occurred to me that there was a distinction between South Indian food and...other Indian food (Is there an East Indian, West Indian or is it just a North/South distinction??) 
My friends and I were wandering around in the mission and were lured in by the spicy, savory scent wafting down an entire block.  
I was a little unsure of how to eat it (do you really eat it with your hands?  like Ethiopian?) but managed to do a fork/hand combo that allowed for maximum sauce piling. 
Service was great - very timely and appropriately attentive - we were promptly seated, but then again, we were fairly early and the crowds came in just about when we were wrapping up.
author: Maria C.

description:
Until Sunday, I had never had a dosa before. 

My friend and I had a drink at the bar and only waited about 20 minutes for a table.  Since I hadn't been there before, my date a self-proclaimed dosa lover (NIN) convinced me to go for the 4-course tasting menu.  Caution:  only go for the 4 courses if you are hungry since it is a fair amount of food.

At the end of the meal the only thing to say is "Wow - what a treat!
  I chose the potato croquettes that were served hot and perfect with dipping sauces.  Next came the spring vegetable dosa that was light and flavorful, then the lamb curry which was some of the most tasty morsel i have had in a while.  And last but not least was the fantastic banana gelato for dessert.  

Thanks NIN for making me go in for dinner.  Can't wait to try some more tasty dosa on my next visit!
author: Annabel G.

description:
With all the positive reviews of Dosa I suppose it doesn't need another one--so I'll keep it short.  

On second thought--seeing as how Dosa can get so crowded--take your sorry ass somewhere else so the next time I eat there I can get seated quicker!  ;)
author: Nobody M.

description:
We stumbled upon Dosa as we were strolling the Mission looking for a fun new place to try. The menu looked tasty and there were a ton of people seated inside - even though it was a random week day - always a good sign. 

The food was delicious (especially the soup). It was my first time having dosas and I'll definitely be coming back for a 2nd try. 

Great ambiance, fun finger foods, and the service was on the better side of average. Good stuff!
author: Han C.

description:
This place is the perfect combo of what I enjoy in a dinner spot:
- tasty menu
- good wine list
- correct energy
- consistently helpful and friendly staff
- equally appealing bar and seated dining
I have been here numerous times and have not once been disappointed.
Tough for parking sometimes, but it's the Mission, so of course we plan ahead.
author: Isa L.

description:
Can anyone say: San Francisco's hottest new brunchoen spot for the weekends? I almost hesitate to spread the love for fear of not getting a table the next time I go there! 

The mung sprout salad and non-vegetarian curry specials [weekends only :-( ] are absurdly delicious, and I can hear the "ooohs and aahhs" around me from people enjoying other fare. I can only imagine how delightful this must be if you're a vegetarian [most of the food is] - if not, it's still a whole new way to eat Indian. The cocktails are light but fun and appropriate for the food. A must-do restaurant for the savy eater in the Mission district!
author: Little P.

description: this place gets crowded. I wasn't much of the fan of the dosas.
author: Tannaz G.

description:
I had heard good things about Dosa but living in the Tandoor-loin gives me my fill of good Indian food for bargain basement prices so I never made a point to go...until last night when my partner and I were walking through the Mission looking for a place to eat.

Everything was amazing from the wines to the dosas to the very attentive service!  We went on a Friday night without a reservation so we sat at the bar and had a couple glasses of wine each before dinner since there was a 30 min. wait time.  The bartender, Karine, was SO sweet and really knew the wines.  She really took an interest in what we ordered and suggested a bottle that she thought we would like to accompany dinner.  We did order the suggested bottle and loved it.

We debated whether to order the tasting menu or go ala carte and realized that we could get twice the amount of the same food that was on the tasting menu for the same price or less and get a second meal out of it.

The coconut and red pepper soup was AMAZING!  I could have made a meal out of that alone.  My partner ordered the fire water soup which was spicy but not overwhelmingly so.  We both got dosas - mine the regular masala dosa and his the mung bean dosa.  The dosas were tasty on their own but the real stars were the accompanying sauces!  They added so much flavor to the light, crispy dosas.

For entrees we ordered the eggplant dish and the prawn curry.  Both were amazing, although the eggplant dish was SPICY!  My partner ordered the cheese curd dessert which was tasty and just the right serving size to be shared at the end of a (self-imposed) heavy meal.

The food was done well but lots of places have good food.  What made me give Dosa 5 stars is the service.  From the friendly and attentive bartenders to the gracious hosts to the napkin folding every time we visited the restroom to the fact that my beverage glasses never emptied, this was a real dining experience, not just a meal out.  Our waiter Gabe was knowledgeable and present but not annoyingly doting.

The night we went to Dosa I had just received my first paycheck from a new job and we really wanted to have a lovely meal to celebrate.  Dosa did not let us down.
author: Jon B.

description:
dosa OH-sa.

HERE is another reason to eat in the Mission.  Of all places to endure an often guaranteed 30-45 minute wait, Dosa is worth it!  While the bar doesn't serve hard liquor, it does make great soju cocktails like the Lychee Lush and Pomegranate Garnet that'll occupy you during your wait (or at least a third off it).

With red walls that illuminate from the lamps hung from the great high ceilings and the mirrors that cover the whole restaurant, you can't help but get excited for the food.  It's a great place for both vegetarians and those other eaters. There's SO much to choose from, so grab a handful of friends to eat at Dosa.  Even non-eggplant lovers will enjoy the chatni masala dosa.  All I have to say is don't forget to order the raita for the spicy dishes. 

Unless you're departing with an empty stomach, you'll never leave Dosa unhappy.  Book ahead - book even if you don't know if you'll be in town.


(if it's extremely busy, they'll offer you a free drink at the bar to clear you out of your table...at least that's what happened to me.)
author: Eszter K.

description:
Dosa: So-Sosa

I think too much hype gave this place an amazing reputation that is really hard to live up to. 

Upon our Saturday night 6pm arrival we were seated promptly. 
Our waitress was very helpful and friendly. She had answers to all of our questions and she was able to highlight a few of her recommendations.  She sounded like she's worked there for months, but we found out she just started. She was cool- knew her stuff (or was just really good at pretending she did).  Overall the service was great- we always had everything we needed. 

The food was good, but nothing we had was exceptionally amazing. We had calamari (tasty, small portion), a veggie korma curry (a lot of cinnamon flavor, not very hearty, a lot of sauce) and the dosa with eggplant (Eh, mushy..sauces were good, but also not hearty or very exciting).  I like a little more *crunch* or other texture in my meals other than these that are only soft, spongy and saucy.  Our wine was really good- Curtis Heritage Cuvee' (blend of Grenache, Syrah, Mourvdre, and Cinsaut) ($29/bottle). 

I am glad I went because I have been curious about the food for so long, but I am not feeling the desire to go back.
author: Amy J.

description:
When I had to meet and hang out with yet another of my sweetie's exes, I nearly lost it. Who wants to be friends with that many ex girlfriends?! My motto is "we broke up for a reason, now get lost". 

So my evil plan to discourage  future dinners in a really messed up, passive aggressive way is to encourage the ex to lobby for going to an expensive and/or annoying restaurant. If I have to put up with giggles, meaningful nostalgic gazes, and strolls down memory lane  I am getting a damn fine meal out of it hopefully where it will be too loud to hear very well. 

So Dosa was the latest victim. But in spite of there always being a line out front and a bazillion people waiting, we got right in. Drat! And they sat us toward the front that didn't have the din of an airplane hangar like the back part of the restaurant. Drat drat! The service was exceptional and the food was super tasty too! My evil plan was foiled.

I scarfed down the masala dosa like a starved dog and could have had three more. The squid was tender and succulent, but not calamari. I repeat- do not expect calamari. Great wine selection. I loved it.

Then when we left the ex started complaining that it wasn't as good as the places in the East Bay. And the Honey started complaining that it was expensive for fancy Indian street food. Ha HA! The evil plan worked after all.

Thank you Dosa- I think you rock! Even if you are a little pricey and would it kill ya to throw some chicken in a crepe?
author: Krismet C.

description:
It's a very cozy restaurant with a warm glow and energetic vibe. I've never had South Indian food before, but this was truly delicious. I started with a blood orange martini, which was on special...sweet yet sour and strong but not overpowering.

Got the Dahi Vada to start, which was a cold dish...lentil dumplings topped with a mint-yogurt sauce...very tasty and unlike anything I've ever had before. We then moved onto the signature Dosa...we went with the Masala and were not disappointed. Very flavorful, especially when dipped in the spicy sambar. (I love spicy things, and thought this was the perfect amount of spice). We also shared the shrimp-mango curry with a side of coconut rice, and it was equally tasty.

I'm hungry just thinking about it again, and can't wait to go back!!
author: Jaymee S.

description:
I really wish I could give 1/2 stars. I'd give it 3 and a half if I could. Ok, it's a four. I'll give it a four. 

Ambiance: super duper, just like a trendy spot in the city should be

People: Good for watching people. Nice people. (Why did I write that?) Feels like a new age Indian restaurant - white people with nose rings, etc. No offense white people. I love ya.

Service: Service was very good. Is this really an Indian restaurant? It's uncharacteristically efficient for an Indian restaurant.

Food: The food here is good. The starter of medu vada was really nice. They hit the nail on the head with spice combo. The dahi vada was also kick ass. Good job on that!

The main dish, a dosa in my case, was really nice. It was as good as any dosa I've had in Fremont, Newark, or even dare I say, Berkeley. The thing is that this is not a trendy upscale type of food, but it's being served in such an atmosphere. I'm giving the stars based on the food. If I were giving it stars for a whole "experience", I guess, well, I'd give it 3 and a 1/2. Wait, didn't I already say that? 

Four stars for the delicious cardamom gelato. Wow, that was yummy. 

And FIVE STARS for excellent service. Really.
author: Dyuti S.

description: This was our first time and we were very happy with Dosa.  I took my wife for her birthday and the food was great, nice and spicy.  We will definitely be going back for more.
author: Norman C.

description:
Went there last night and got a taste of true down home southern Indian cooking in a cool atmosphere.   The food is definitely the real deal and reminds me of trips to Bangalore and Goa.  Try not to load up on the papadam though - big mistake. 

The chana masala is great.   It is not over oily or lacking in flavor which is really common in other places that serve that dish.   It comes with a big puri that really compliments the dish.   

We felt obligated to get the masala dosa and thought is was good.   A little bland for my taste, but the dosa was crispy and delicious.   The side chutneys were good, but the coconut one was also a little bland. 

The wine list was pretty affordable and had a decent selection in the $30-$40 range.   Wine and Indian food is not always my first pick, but their selection does the food justice.  

They really need to take reservations though as the wait is a little much.  However, being late or waiting a long time for something does seem to be a tradition in India, so I will chalk it up to authenticity.
author: Jim Z.

description:
UPDATE:  finally made it back, and it was even better (and just as packed!) as our last visit.  the staff is so attentive & friendly, and handles the crowd seamlessly....  never have i so enjoyed a meal having really no idea what in fact i'm eating.  5 big huge stars!

wow.  so pleased to finally make it out to this spot!

we phoned up around 6ish on a tuesday nite asking if we needed a reservation...???  very friendly voice says, 'nope... come on in!"  f-forward two hours later, and this place was BUZZING.  so busy, with everyone packed sardine-style into the tiny entry area.

we were told, friendly-style - it'd now be a half hour wait or so for a table for our pair & have a seat at the bar.  there were TWO remaining seats at the packed bar, and i hurled myself through the crowd semi-obnoxiously to grab 'em...

there seemed to be a terrific mix of small groups and couples --- the interior is very bright, welcoming and open-feeling, which is good because otherwise one would feel cramped among a bigger crowd.

the food??  YES!   so good.  i was pining for a curry, and the prawn curry i ordered was perfecto'... superhuge portion made me wish i'd settled for a small-plate/app order instead - tons to choose from.  my dining partner had the lamb curry - also yum - but hers was HOT. whereas mine was NOTSOHOT.  why??  instead of pondering this too deeply we ordered a raita to mix-in/balance-out... and that was delish, too.

the wines by the glass were fun & interesting, and we're really looking forward to coming back for the "set menu" or "samplers" with a group.  v. well done!
author: Kayse G.

description:
Four stars cos i have heard a lot 
will revisit this review after i have had food there.... 
the following things make a south Indian restaurant
- Good Crisp Dosa 
- Mysore Masala Dosa 
- Bottomless Sambar 
- Chutneys esp the red one  
- Rasam 
Will check in post dinner

Update......
.... Three stars because i cant figure out how to make three and a half ... dosa loses points for not having bottomless sambar... but for the record the sambar was awesome and i think we ordered three sides of it over what they gave us with the food
author: Puneet k.

description:
I just popped in, around 6 PM, to try it out. Got seated immedietly (though it did fill up around me after). 
The waiters were all really, really nice and helped me pick out what to have. I got the Chatni Dosa and a mango lassi.
the mango lassi was OK.
But the chatni dosa blew. my. mind. 
the dips/suaces were delicate but flavorful, totally unlike anything i had before. 
the bread was delicious, the filling perfectly cooked and spiced.
It's like...well, it's not like all the same chicken tikka masala i know you have been ordering for years. 
This tastes different. The spices are unique. It was excelent. can't wait to go back.
author: meredith b.

description:
Flavor was a bit lacking, but the taste was okay overall.  Not worth the price.  But I'm giving it an "A-OK" because the waiter was trying to be helpful with ordering suggestions.  In fact, all the staff were nice and with no eye rolling when my straw-challenged one year old dripped Mango Lhasi on the table.  

One thing I have to note:  I usually wipe down a table before I give my son food because, as I've learned , food will often end up dropping on the table before it ends up in his mouth.  Well, I forgot to wipe our table down before I gave him the piece of french bread I brought from home.  As soon as I gave him the bread, he dropped it on the table.  This triggered my "Oh Sh*!" reflex, and I quickly picked up his bread and wiped the table with one of his baby wipes.  That wipe was so brown afterward that my first reaction was to hide it from embarrassment!  Maybe it was just the spot I wiped?  Not sure, but the sight of that dirty, grimy baby wipe from our "clean" table may have colored my overall opinion.  I feel bad about writing this, but also feel it has to be said.
author: Ani M.

description:
Tried Dosa for dinner with a reservation on a Friday night.  Highly recommend making reservations and if there's just two of you, ask for a table by the windows.  The restaurant is noisier towards the larger tables in the back and the restaurant always feels warm in temperature to me.

We enjoyed a bottle of champagne and the $39 tasting menu for food.  The food was very good for a spin on Indian food.  The dosas were good, the chicken chenna, as well as the lamb.

The prices are slightly high, would return more often if they were just a tick lower, but good service and food.
author: K V.

description:
Went to Dosa last night for the second time. The second time was even better than the first!

We started with the mung sprout salad. I'm normally not a fan of sprouts (the sandwich kind), but these were different and really great. A definite must.

The service level was great and the woman who waited on us was nice and helpful. The wine she suggested was great, and very reasonably priced. We were pleasantly surprised by how fast our food came to the table.

The restaurant doesn't take reservations for parties under 5, but when you arrive and check in, they will take your cell phone number and call you when your table is ready. This cool system means that you can go down the street for a drink and then come back right when your table is ready. Genius!
author: Sara Z.

description:
I kind of don't want to write this review, since I live a few blocks away and don't want the wait to get any longer than it already is at this tastiest of Indian spots in the City...but it's only fair to the folks at Dosa to give them their just reward for serving some seriously delicious stuff.  This is good, honest, fresh, kick-ass Southern Indian food like you've probably never been lucky enough to have it.   

Check out their wine list, too--I've never been disappointed.
author: Marie S.

description:
To please all members of a diverse party of 7 is an accomplishment, and one that Dosa fulfilled hands down!  2 sets of 40 somethings out with our discerning teen and 20 something offspring. We left satisfied, happy and wanting to return for more. Chalk one up for experience!

We loved everything. No reservations - time to people watch. Non alcohol drinkers - creamy lovely lassi more than satisfied. Vegetarian and non veg diners - plenty of choices, more so than most South Indian restaurants. The vibe was great and somehow energizing. The staff is working hard and did all they could to please, but it was easy to see how it could come apart given the quick turn over, and tight space. Ready to return...and next time will eat dessert here rather than at the disastrous Bombay Ice Cream, 5 blocks up.
author: Ash A.

description:
I came here with friends about a month ago.  We heard a lot of buzz about the place recently, so decided to try it ourselves.  I got there early and decided to have a drink at the bar with my other friend who was also early.   Evidentally, they had called my  gf who made the reservation about 10 minutes beforehand to make sure that she was still coming.  I guess they didn't know that half the party was already in the restaurant ...FYI they never asked. us  (but then again we didn't give our names either).  But did it really matter since it was still empty around 6pm?? 

 The food was good, not your standard southern indian flavors.   As I've seen others postings, there's no naan because hey there's Dosa!!!  

My coworkers warned me about it being pricey but in actuality it seemed reasonable for the place/crowd/environment (a lil pricey for you typical indian though, which is what I think my coworker was comparing it to).
author: Stacey L.

description:
Dosa choose me. I was walking towards Herbivore with a friend and passed Dosa on the way. We both turned our heads to the lovely spicy smells coming out from the place we were standing right in front of... DOSA.

We managed to strike it at a really good time (about 6:30pm), just after we had gotten settled, there was a line out the front door.

The food was top notch from the Potato Croquet and fresh Mango Lassi to the spicy south indian pepper chicken curry and the Chatni Masala Dosa.

Admittedly, the service could have been better. The waitress seemed VERY put out by serving us our meal, water, etc., however, I'd be willing to write it off in favor of the deliciously spicy/complex fare...
author: noelle m.

description:
Very mixed experience. Saturday night 7:30. Prime time. We had to wait an hour to be seated. That wasn't the problem. The problem was being told it was a 20 minute wait. Fine. 30 minutes later we were told it would be another 20. Fine. Not fine: They seat 2 other parties who came after us and were THE SAME SIZE as ours. Those guys didn't have reservations either, which we knew since we spent 45 minutes talking to them outside. Dosa was off to bad start.
 
Once inside, one of our party was seated in a broken chair. Its condition was previously known to the staff since, without prompting, a waiter came over with a new one... Which begs the question: if they knew about it why was it left at a table to begin with?
 
Next we were nearly served the wrong drinks. Then they attempted to serve us someone else's appetizers. Then, when they finally succeeded in serving us the wrong starters, we couldn't get a server to take them away (we would have eaten them, but no doubt we would have been charged for them + our own). Our waitress seemed everywhere but no where near us, and all the other servers we made eye contact with, and motioned to, ignored us. I finally had to physically walk the incorrect plates over to the hostess. That was not acceptable.
 
Now, when we finally did get our food, starting with the Chennai Chicken and the Medu Vada, it was wonderful. Our entrees, devoured family style, were the Rava Masala, Egg Dosa, and the Spring Dosa: all excellent. Very filling. None of us left the table hungry. However, given the runaround we got with the wrong plates, not to mention the problems being seated in the first place, they could of earned their tip by comping us a starter or two- even an apology would have been appreciated. But we got nothing of the sort, which by then, wasn't surprising.
 
As for the space itself, crowded and noisy. I know that the space is limited, and they want to accommodate as many wallets- excuse me, I mean "patrons" as possible, but there is no room to gesture while talking without smacking someone at the next table. Consequently the noise is an issue if you normally enjoy talking (as opposed to shouting) to you dinner companions.
 
Take away this: the food is delicious, the service is amateur. I don't know if they do to-go orders, but that seems the best way to experience the food (eg without the weak service).
author: Ogdred W.

description:
I love Indian food!  Love, love, love.  This is a bit different than any kind of Indian food I'd had before, but it was a good different.  It's definitely worth trying.  I had the Mysore Dosa, which was delicious!  The dipping sauces that come with the Dosas and the Uttapam are so good.  There's a tomato chutney, a coconut chutney, and a kind of lentil broth/soup stuff.  Oh my goodness, talk about all kinds of yummy-ness in my mouth.  The service was great.  We had a nice waitress who made really good recommendations.  The place is pretty trendy, which can be both a good thing and a bad thing.  I'll leave that part up to you.

One thing we didn't know before we went was that the Dosas and the Uttapam are all vegetarian.  I don't mind that, but the boyfriend was a little disappointed.  It was like that scene in My Big Fat Greek Wedding, "What do you mean you don't have no meat?!"  Luckily, he got over it and thoroughly enjoyed his Masala Dosa.
author: TK B.

description: Wonderful Chennai Chicken.  Servers were attentive, friendly, and happy to see us.  Great music selection during happy hour.
author: Jo S.

description: Great food - just terrific, and different from any I've had.  Seated at the bar, service was great, the bartenders actually genuinely seemed happy to chat with us.  Friendliest place I've been in San Francisco (OK, the only friendly place), but it was just a nice time, and very good price.  Only thing keeping me from five stars is, it was very loud.  Did I mention the food was great??  Am already planning to go back.
author: Steve S.

description: Based on all the high Yelp reviews I really had high expectations for Dosa. We made reservations for a Sat. night during Dine About Town. For my four courses I had the Lentil dumplings (Dahi Vada), Spring Dosa, Pepper chicken and Gelato for dessert. I was most disappointed by the Dahi Vada as I didn't realize this dish was served cold. The dumplings are basically served in a bowl under a heap of yogurt. The Pepper chicken also wasn't anything to rave about. There were two pieces of chicken and one of them was a drumstick. It's nearly impossible to eat a drumstick without picking it up, which means there's no "cute" way to eat it. The flavor of the chicken was good, but I've had better for a fraction of the price. At the end of the night we walked out with a $90 bill, which is definitely on the high end for what we got.
author: Krystal C.

description:
This is a great restaurant (and this is coming from a brown girl!).  

Service: awesome
Decor: drop dead stunning.
Food: tasty!

We ordered a Vada/Sambhar, an onion uttapam and I had the moong dosa...all were tasty and fabulous.  

The dosa was crisp, filled with the daal, and sprinkled with chopped onions and green chilies, which was awesome... the chutneys were tasty, and the food satisfied the gastric cravings.

It's a great date spot.  We went right before the kitchen closed for the afternoon on a Sunday....otherwise you may need to snag reservations.
author: garbanzo b.

description: The best dosa I ever had in the bay area is at Dosa. I had ordered Lamb meat balls for a party at my place. They were spicy and tasted so good that it was an instant hit. A great place to hang out with friends on a rainy evening and enjoy great food and cocktails.
author: Anbu A.

description:
It might help to start this review with the fact that I have been eating at Dosa at an average of twice a week since it opened. That itself is testimony enough that I love the food there, not to mention the staff.

The core South Indian dishes are the best I have eaten anywhere, including many places in India where I grew up. The salads (mung sprouts), soups (beet) and variations (spring Dosa, Soy Uttappam) are creatively refreshing.

Although the prices seem high for people who eat at the dive Indian/Paki places, there is no comparison in quality, food or service; the dishes are all prepared fresh, the produce is organic and ingredients are high quality. At the end of the day...you get what you pay for.

Try the place if you haven't yet.
Remember, it gets pretty crowded during peak times.
author: Ra ..

description:
The food was enjoyable -- at least the fraction of it we got to actually eat.

When we were about 3/4 of the way through the meal, a staff member jumped on the table, scooped up all of our dishes and left us staring at an empty table in shock.  I know what your thinking, we should have just told him we weren't done -- but there really was no notice what-so-ever.  He just reached in and grabbed stuff.  Not a word was said, no "Are you finished?" or opportunity to take the food with us.

Its not like we were holding up the table.  We were actually eating fairly quickly because we had just waited a very long time to get food.  In fact, there was at least a 35 minute wait between being seated and the next time anyone talked to us. 

So the food is good, a little pricey, and you must be ready to defend your meal like an angry dog.
author: Robb K.

description:
***The (owner?) from Dosa emailed me personally after reading my snarky Yelp review and let me know that their coconut chutney is homemade and made me realize that I might be eating grossed out prepackaged stuff at other Indian restaurants and not knowing it. Guess Katherine B. got schooled! Also, he employs a lot of chefs from south India, so there goes it. 

My 4* review stays, since I just can't get the same dosa and ras malai as in India, but I will write a few more positive things:

1. EXCELLENT customer service
2. Amazing fish curry (had at Fillmore Dosa)
3. Great date spot
4. Amazing cocktails 
5. Wait staff is always friendly and informative
6. Nice decor 
7. Sure it is crowded, but this is SF people, there is not much space. And people want to eat here, so it is busy, that is usually a GOOD thing.......

I still can't fathom paying that much for Indian beer. . . 

I have been here with quite a few Indian gentleman who love the food but agree it is not the same as their mother's, but then again, what restaurant is???

Either way, it is nice to have a more upscale place to drink Gimlets and hash out the daily grind over some good south Indian food.
author: Katherine B.

description:
I was looking for a place to eat on Sunday night and feeling a bit adventurous. So I fired up Yelp and it led me here to the Mission.

The space was intimate but we were seated quickly. The service was helpful and friendly. And the food was very very good. The chicken curry and and the paper masala were excellent. I found both to be full of awesome Indian flavors. One of my favorite things about Dosa were the various chutneys and sauces they brought out. I heard they have a new location in j-town so I'll have to drop in the next time I'm in the area.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
Pricey and busy, but get the COCONUT RICE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

went to this place on my bday and it was small and crowded, but I loved it. The food was tasty and the portions were generous. They look small but are filling. Watch out for the $38 four course meal. It can be confusing because the way it is written on the menu it looks as if it means $15 for a four course meal. Again, not a big deal and we just overlooked it. I would def. suggest this place!!
author: Michael B.

description:
We did Sunday brunch at Dosa. .. never been. It was fantastic!
Our server, however, was not especially helpful in taking our order. But still good.
author: Vanessa T.

description:
So good.  Ambiance is great as is the service.  I wish it were a little cheaper, but you can't get everything you want.
- Rava Masala Dosa - delicious.  Best dosa I've ever eaten (although I am not an expert by any means)
- Peppercorn chicken - tender, easily pulled off the bone
- Dessert: sweet uttapam with fresh strawberries.  Heaven.
author: Melinda C.

description: I love this place. I made online reservations for some out of town friends and they were able to accomodate us earlier once a cancellation was made. A treat for any special occassion.
author: Diana O.

description:
Tasty Tasty!  It's a very warm-seeming space (especially when it's 75 in SF) with all orange walls, but nicely done with neat hanging vertical lamps all through the back.  Moderate size bar up front, serving wine, beer (of an interesting selection), and soju cocktails.
The food is wonderful.  The onion pakora (Indian onion rings, essentially) are unique with the addition of curry leaves to the mix.  The uttapam and dosas are all very good, and the dipping choices are, well, choice.  The orange one is especially good and unique in flavor.
A word of warning: dinner is much more filling than it looks!
author: Don H.

description:
GREAT indian food here--well spiced and balanced.  We got two tasty curries--one shrimp, and one lamb (well marinated/stewed, a little heavy on the cinnamon, but great choice of spices nonetheless).  And the rest was mostly vegetarian.  The chennai chicken was awesome... perfect beer food.  perfectly marinated and stirfried (Read: very moist and flavorful).  The rest of the things we got were variations of pancakes/crepes.  I can't remember what everything was called, but we got two dosas, one eggplant dosa, one spring dosa, both tasty.  ANd we got this paneer and pea in a pancake thing, and this other pancake-like thing.  All of these came with a soup to dip in and two little sauces.  THere was this awesome fried puffy bread called Bhutara I think, that was oily and flaky, kinda like a roti, but more puffy.  It soaked up the leftover curries very well ;)

The highlights of the evening, I think, were actually the chennai chicken, and the lentil dumplings (I think they were called vada sambar).  The "dumplings" were amazing--the dish was like a shallow soup of yogurt, and the balance of textures, and flavors was simply amazing.  the lentil "dumplings" were basically a loose chewy cake of lentils, and were drenched in a chilled sauce of yogurt and some other stuff.  For presentation, the chef made concentric rings of brown and white, and then dashed them radially towards the center to make a beautiful floral pattern.  Outstanding.

The food was awesome.  5 stars.

But... the place itself was extremely loud--they need some soundproofing.  we were right in the middle of the room, by the wall, and only a table of 8 yelpers.  Yet, I could barely hear Serena, who was talking about an arm and a half's length away diagonally from me.   

And I left hungry, and in need of some meat.  So if you're a meat lover like me, you might want to get a taco or two at El Farolito ahead of time.  In fact, as I write this, I'm jonesing for a taco de lengua or pastor...  sigh.  Anyway, the meat selection was not so good, given its southern indian, which is much more vegetarian than your typical pakistani restaurants that you find in SF.  But the meats they had were excellent.  I need to go back and get some of their meat-filled dosas...
author: Fong L.

description:
I went with a couple of friends at 2pm on a Sunday.  We had to wait almost an hour for our food when the place was not even crowded.  The salad was one of the best I'd ever had, we got it to share thinking that a $9 salad would be a good size, but it was the size of a side salad.  

I'm also allergic to onions, and since they have to pre-make many of their fillings (it takes a long time) they told me they could not special make one without onions.  That's ok, I''ve had to deal with worse.  The sauces were great, but there was something I ate that gave me an allergic reaction - one I've never felt.  Maybe a new strange spice or something.  I got the chills and a light head (a pepper reaction?)

I love Indian food, and I would say definitely give this a try, but it is so different don't go in expecting "indian" food if all you've had is N Indian. 
I'm giving a 3 star because there wasn't much I could eat and for the slow service.
author: Candace B.

description:
I love this place. Consistently good quality and attentive staff! They have this amazing jacobite beer which is flavored with coriander. I recommend ordering one prawn chili fry apiece to go with the beer to start with. I always order the Masala Dosa, because It is perfect already why mess with it? Spicy Spicy and watch out because the Jacobite is better than Guinness and can add up on your bill pretty quickly if you are with a group!!!
I always sit at the bar and have always been glad that I never opted to wait for a table!
Oh! Oh! Wait there is more! The other night when I was in we also ordered a raita and poori which the staff inteligently brought us to cool and cleanse our palates after the intense heat of the chili prawns and before the next course Dosa. 

Very nicely done by the kitchen or whomever executed the command...

My friend's chicken and eggplant curry was also delicious but we were mostly full by the time we finished the dosas that we had ordered.
author: Kimberley M.

description:
Currently, this is my favorite restaurant because of the food. I enjoy the dosa's and uttapam's while my husband enjoys the curries. The chutneys are amazing as well. 

The main reason I didn't give this restaurant 5 stars is because of the wine menu. There are not many choices. But  I have found that this is the case in most Indian restaurants in San Francisco. I don't know if it's different elsewhere. However, wine is not the reason why you go to Dosa. You go there for food. ****Okay, I went back to Dosa and tried the riesling kabinett which the owner suggested. It was fabulous! So I've changed my review to 5 stars. :-)


Be prepared to wait for a table up to 30 or 45 minutes.
author: Cindy K.

description:
I've been here twice now and really enjoy the place.  It's hard to get a table, but the tantalizing smells coming from the kitchen convince you it's worth the wait.  

While I'm certainly no expert on Indian cuisine, they seemed to do the flavors a great deal of justice.  There might be other Indian restaurants in the city that deserve four stars as well, but frankly I don't know them.
author: Mitchell F.

description:
Been wanting to check this place out for a while, and finally had a chance to do so last night.

Arrived around 6:30pm on a Tuesday night, which was perfect because there were plenty of open tables.

The service was great, our waitress was very friendly.  They are a bit pushy with trying to take away your finished plates to the point where they want to take something that still has a little food left on it.  It's not a big deal though, just tell them "no, still working on it" and they won't bug you about that plate until it's finished.

The best thing we had by far was the Dahi Vada appetizer.  It is "lentil dumplings, topped with cool Strauss organic yogurt, piped with tamarind and mint and gently spiced."  Delicious.

The actual Dosa was good, but not substantially better than the cheap ones I get at this place in the south bay.  

Overall, it was a great dining experience.
author: Chris Q.

description:
Review for BRUNCH only.

My friends and I stopped by DOSA yesterday.  I didn't know this, but they now have a brunch menu.  Indian brunch?   I was definitely curious to find out.  For a split second, I did wonder if they would be serving bacon and eggs or even pancakes?  Ok, just kidding about the bacon!

In fact, they did have Indian versions of the traditional omelets, pancakes, and crepes.  I had the South India Omelet which was more of a frittata.  The eggs were well cooked; fluffy, but not runny.  Unexpected was the spicy "kick" from the chilies.   My friends tried the Sunny Side Uttapam, which I would compare it to having eggs and pancakes, and the Egg Poriyal Dosa, a crepe in disguise.  Of course, each dish came with sides of  tomato chutney, coconut chutney, and sambar.  All seemed to match well with our dishes.

In the end, I think we all agreed that the OMELET was the BEST, with the uttapam a close second.  The dosa was good, but seemed much more plain when compared to the others.

Before we get to the STAR rating, one thing of importance to note, weekend brunch doesn't start until 11:30am.  We all wondered if this still counts as brunch.  You?

The STAR rating:

-1 STAR for the waitress.  Not sure why, but she was so damn persistent about having us order Chaat.  I think she asked about 3 times.  My friend finally relented and we got the Dahi Batata Puri.  I would describe it as a heart stopping, explosion of flavors!  DELICIOUS!
author: James C.

description:
I like it just fine, but come on, folks!  It's basically an Indian crepes place.  And frankly, how can ANYONE get excited about crepes?  It's a CREPE for god's sake!!  (Which must tell you how much I like Ti Couz, but that's another Yelp for another day...)

Anywho, I asked one of my dining companions has traveled extensively to India and lived in Pakistan for years if I was "just not getting it."  He replied, that in fact, he thought that other than the lamb curry, the other dishes we tried were pretty "meh."  Nothing "fantastic" but certainly not bad.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
So, the wait here was kinda long. luckily, i was late and my vegetarian super club handled it!

The dinner was really good. I had no idea what a dosa was, but it turned out to be a crepe with mashed potatos inside. Can't go wrong with that!

Super good!

#3
author: Tasha R.

description:
Talk about a popular place. We arrived on a Sunday at 6 p.m and the place was packed! Considering they had only been open for a half an hour, I'd say that their business model is quite successful. 

Thankfully, we were seated right away, at a teeny tiny table between two larger tables. (That's called foreshadowing).

We ordered an appetizer, which came quickly. Unfortunately, so did our main entrees. They arrived a couple minutes after the appetizer. Now, here comes the problem: Since the table was teeny tiny, we hardly had room to move, what with the appetizer, those little chip things they give you, our drinks, a candle, and our entress (comprising three plates because puffy bread came with one entree).

I'm taking away a star for all of that. I felt cramped, so I really couldn't enjoy my experience as I so wanted to. Damn, I need stretching room if I'm going to eat. 

I'm impressed with their swiftness, yet I need to recommend that they time their food properly. I felt a bit rushed because the food came out so quick. 

Here's my plan for this place:
(1) Make reservations (HIGHLY RECOMMENDED)
(2) Eat here once more.
(3) If I get a repeat of my first experience, I'm taking a couple of stars away.
author: Mark G.

description:
The only reason for not giving this place five stars is the friggin line out the door and nearing the corner.  Otherwise, superb.

Our hostess was really nice and super helpful when ordering.  Imagine, four prissy gay boys wondering what might be good on the palate and not too strong afterwards in the club trying to be all cute.  Well... lesson learned with spicy food... you just don't go out afterwards to a club and expect to be approachable.

Back to the food...  they served us a small bowl of soup and DANG, GINA! was it good.  Spicy, salty and chewy... mm mm good.

The "pancakes" were soft and full of flavor.  One thing I do have to recommend for those wine lovers out there (personally I'm a red kinda guy) stick with white and it'll all be fine.

The ambiance is nice but busy.  I'll definately be going back soon with those that know how to handle their spices.  ;-)
author: Sas C.

description:
Finally made it to DOSA last night! We planed on going here, but got very hungry and didnt want to stand and wait in the line outside. My "friend" convinced me that it wouldnt be too long, so we went. We walked right in at 8pm and were seated at the bar. Sevice was nice, even the waiters not helping us were nice. It was a little dark in there for me since I have so so eyesight and never wear glasses or contacts. 

We had the ... ummm.... Something with something. I just know that it was really tasty, not heavy at all and we left there feeling good. 
2 thumbs up.

A
author: A W.

description:
Before thinking of making the trek to Dosa, if it's a Thursday, Friday or Saturday night, forget about it. Heck, forget about hitting any restaurant you've heard of in the Mission. We're overrun with tourists and bridge-and-tunnel kids, hipsters who actually live in the Richmond because it's cheap but party in the Mission, and all those dang Marina clones who come to the Mission to drink and drive.

My advice, which I hope you don't take, because then I will have a hard time getting a table at Dosa, is to go for brunch on the weekends, when idli and dosa and uttapam should be eaten. There's a few too many babies and their parents from up in Noe Valley sharing Dosa's sunny space with you, but they're much better behaved (and the babies are quieter) than the weekend Marina crowd.

The food is fairly authentic South Indian breakfast food, even if at 8 times the price - but if you factor in the price of the plane ticket to India, you're coming out ahead so stop your bitchin'.

Someone should Dosa's chef though that cilantro is not in every South Indian dish - it makes an appearance in almost every dish at Dosa. In three weeks in Inda, I only had cilantro once, and that was with dinner, and it was little side dish of cilantro-packed chutney. Other than that, always tasty and very consistent quality.

I wonder what Dosa will do once Udipi Palace opens their new location down the street, in Firecracker's space...the competition may bring the prices down and may ease up the wait for a table. One can only dream...
author: Lauren G.

description:
I just had to find out what all the fuss is about since I am a fan of south Indian cuisine. I've passed by this restaurant many, many times and it seems to be always packed.
One Easter Sunday, we decided to take a gamble and try it out. We were seated after a 10 minute wait - not bad. I guess the key is to get there early, that is, before the dinner rush hour.

The beverage menu was thoughtful, offering a variety of wine, cocktail,and beer selection well suited to the menu. To my surprise, they had Lillet! What a perfect aperitif to a warm evening in the Mission. 

For starters, we had the The Chennai Chicken (good but no outstanding characteristic ) and the Idli Sambar (flavourful). The main course, Masala Dosa and Rava Masala - our favorite of the two. We also ordered  the Prawn Coconut Masala - rich, tasty, great flavours, along with the 2005 Albarino.. For desert, we shared the Gulab Jamoon - my favorite, paired with a nice Tawny port. Made to perfection, not too dense not too spongy - just right in my opinion.

Did I say that it had a really nice atmosphere, knowledgeable and friendly staff, and a great crowd. Overall, Dosa made a great impression and I will definitely comeback. Yummmy!

Why only 4 stars? It's my first time.
author: Sam H.

description:
I finally tried Dosa and let me tell you, it was worth the wait.  

A little pricy for Indian but the food was delicious and the service was great.  The food reminded me of a friend and her cooking style.  Too bad she lives in L.A. and I've moved back to S.F.  :(

I tried the Spinach & Cauliflower Vadas, Dahi Vada, Chatni Masala Dosa, and the Rasmalai.  So good.  So much food.  So full.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Pros: The food is very tasty and the wine list is extensive. 

Cons: Not being able to make a reservation for parties under 5.  The annoying waitress I've had each time I've been - she is condescending and unhelpful. Our entire table cringed every time she came by.

(Update: the owner contacted me regarding my review and told me the reason they don't have reservations under five is due to the months of no-shows when they opened. He also cared deeply about our service and apologized to me for our experience. Looking forward to coming back to see if the service will match the fantastic food!)
author: Chris I.

description:
well, after weeks of building up my indian food utils, i finally got to try Dosa tonight.  it totally lives up to the hype.  most of the indian food i have had has been more northern indian, so this was a nice change of pace.  when i walked in the door, the smells were amazing.  i went from not hungry to starving in 2 seconds!  the atmosphere is lively and the service is friendly and prompt.  now onto the important stuff...the food:

- samosas - incredibly delicious.  i liked the northern and southern samosa almost equally but the northern samosas i thought were a little more delectable.  both the tamarind sauce and cilantro sauce were very refined.

- Prawn chili fry - beautiful presentation and excellent spicy flavors.  loved it with the microgreens.

- south indian moons - this was the chefs selection of five different uttapams.  all were delicious.

- spicy mung dosa - first of all it was huge!  excellent flavor compositions going on in there.  there is definitely A LOT of heat!  we were are pretty blown away by the spiciness and we like our food hot.  come to find out they but jalapenos and thai chilis in there...that explains it.

- peppercorn chicken - arguably my favorite dish of the night.  the meat really does fall of the bone and the sauce is this thick, dark red smokey/sweet/spice-laden indian goodness!  we had this with coconut rice and were all very pleased

- cardamom gelato - this was the icing on the cake...two full scoops of this stuff.  i love cardomom, but you have to be careful with it.  it was well balanced in this dish and finished off the meal well

if you like good indian food, go to Dosa.  prices aren't horrendous, and trust me, it is worth it.
author: Christian C.

description: Vegetarian pani puri delights that explode in your mouth in mini-bursts of tamarind and cilantro-green chile pleasure. And paneer and pea uttapam stuffed pancakes with sauces on the side. That pretty much sums up the sublime and slightly spicy South Asian fare we consumed during a recent Yelp-related soiree here in the Mission. The company made for a lot of fun, and the staff were incredibly accommodating as they catered to our party of 11 patrons and explained the fine intricacies of the vegetarian offerings on the menu. We loved the first courses (chaat) including a very elegantly-displayed dumpling dish using yogurt, tamarind, and cilantro sauces. The main dishes were also good, and the crowds here were also eagerly intent on consuming their meals. Prices are fair esp. given the high quality of the food. We each paid around $20 per person for an excellent meal and were happy to do so. This is great place to come when you are part of medium or large-sized group! Multigenerational families, couples on dates, groups having fun ... all seemed welcome here. Thanks to Daniel L. and May C. for helping to organize this unofficial Yelp gathering. Great desert as well!
author: Bradley N.

description:
Indian crepes and soju cocktails, all yummy.  Watery eyes from the spices, cozied up to the bar (where quite a few others were eating their meals, too), just letting the high orange walls and soft lights fill my head, it's nice.  We got the traditional chatni dosa and a crispy one, both great.  The girls next to us had a puffy dosa, looked fabulous.  It was busy, but i will be back for more.
