*update* ... ok, was back for more and it was even better the second time around!  calimari appetizer was a FABulous dish in and of itself!!
author: Today Y.

description:
The interior for Dosa is very warm and inviting. The pallet chosen is not your typical metal, glass, and cool toned paint. Instead, the interior manages to blend modern, minimal and comforting. This is the balance I am constantly looking for, whether in restaurant/retail or residence. 

All of the people working here seem to be happy and genuinely amicable. Great service, not rehearsed "niceness".

My friend and I sat and the bar and proceeded and stay there for the meal itself. The bartender without hesitation recommended the Cabernet Franc. Great choice (although I know crap about wine).

For starters we ordered an Idli Vada Sambar. To be honest, I don't know which one was which but one was pleasing while the other was rather bland. The both were served in a broth concoction and either the idli or vada ended up being too mushy as a result.

Next, we ordered the Masala Dosa which lived up to the restaurant's namesake. Perfectly crisp, light, and perfect amount of filling (as if I really knew what the hell a dosa is supposed to taste like),

We shared a main of lamb curry and this is the justification for only 3 stars. This is the one dish my friend insisted we order due to her past 
Dosa outing. Although done well, there was nothing to justify my friend's enthusiastic recommendation. It only tasted like lamb curry with a bit of spice. That's all. 

Dessert was Gulab Jamoon, eaten solely by me. My only reason for ordering these was to compare them to their ubiquitous Indian buffet cousins. Ehh, a little better but not my much. However, our server comped these b/c they were the bottom of the barrel...literally. We ate late and these were all that were left at the end of the night. Only aesthetically could you tell though.

I will definitely return and do a proper update if warranted.
author: Shawn T.

description:
I went to this restaurant with my parents about a month ago. Saturday night, mighty busy. lots of couples on romantic dates, and not much room for a party of three, but that's usually an indication that the food is yummy. and it was!! prices are on the higher side, but the decor, music, waitstaff, and presentation for all the dishes is such that they can charge what they do. if you want to have an in-depth conversation, the noise level might not be great. the parents had a hard time hearing [and, truth be told, my little bass-lovin ears did, too!] 

said parents and I had also just had a home-cooked Southern Indian feast, so we had something delicious to compare this meal with, and it really was spot on.

all things considered, food is great. service is really fast. there's a wide enough selection that everyone in your party will be happy, even the Souther Indian-loving experts! 

if you want traditional, no frills Southern Indian food and are willing to drive, take a trip down to San Mateo [right off of 92] and try Annapoorna - it's really cheap, vegetarian, and you can watch Indian TV... no liquor license [which is a bummer when you're eating spices] but for four people, the bill is rarely more than $35.
author: Rachel W.

description:
Sooooo, I'm INDIAN.  And damn proud of it.

I moved to SF almost two years ago, and have eaten nothing but shitty-shit-shit Indian food.  Until Dosa.

Granted, I have high, no, VERY high standards for what I think good Indian food should be, and this place really surprised me.

I went on a Wednesday night at about 7 and waited about 2 minutes for a table for two.  I think we got there just before the rush because just after we sat down the place started to fill up and get REALLY loud (minus half a star because I couldn't hear my own voice and came out of the restaurant horse after dinner).

I had a masala dosa and a mango lassi, which are two things I have ALL the time.  I figured that if the place couldn't make their most basic things decent, it wouldn't be worth me coming back.

The mango lassi was a bit too thick for my taste, but otherwise flavorful. Check.

The dosa was tasty!  Just enough spice, just enough potato, just enough sambar.  Check.  

Minus a quarter of a star for WAY too much grease on my fingers after my meal (I don't even have that much after eating at a mom-and-pop Indo place) and minus another quarter of a star for a very bland sambar.  

The rus-malai was yummy, but again, a little on the thick side.

The owner was nice enough to come and introduce himself to us and ask us how the food was.  I think it was cause we were one of  the only brown people in that joint (not uncommon in San Francisco) and he maybe thought he'd get an honest opinion of the food (or maybe he asks everyone, who knows?).  I told him I didn't expect much and that I was pleasantly surprised, especially because I heard so much about Dosa.  

Service was great.  Water always got refilled.  Orders didn't get messed up.  I'm easy to please in this area.

I'll be back, Mr. Owner.  And I've been raving about this place to everyone I know.
author: avisha c.

description:
I debated giving this a five star and it was close but I'm not sure it earns the fifth star.  But it is really good.  Anything that comes with dipping sauces are cool.  Food costs a little above $30 a person without alcohol(i.e. If you drink water) which is a good price for really good food.

Definitely would recommend the Curry Lamb Kofta.  My friend from work recommended it and she was on the money.  Kofta rocks.  This is basically a lamb meatball in a nice curry sauce.

We also tried the Paneer and Peas Dosa (which came with all the dipping sauces).  My friend got really protective over one of the dipping sauces.  "Go away!  Mine!"  That means it's good.

The appetizers were good but not super excellent which is why it gets only four stars.  We had the chennai chicken and the grilled chile prawns.  Prawns were spicy. 

Ambience is nice.  It's a cute little spot but it can get busy on popular nights (like Fridays) and therefore you need to wait in line but it's worth the wait.

Oh, and apparently they are opening a new one in the Fillmore near Yoshi's soon.  Some free kinda helpful advertising for the Dosa people.

Woot.
author: Aron L.

description:
First time there.  Very impressed.  The Chicken & Cauliflower curry I had was amazing and distinct. Drinks were very pleasant as well.

I'm giving this 5 stars because I believe it to be a top notch Indian restaurant.
author: Oren F.

description:
Date night last night at Dosa was pretty amazing. It's probably safe to say that most expat Brits accross the globe contest to being big curry fans - the food is pretty much a staple dish back home. That said, finding a good spot in the city has been challenging which is why after hearing about it's many awards and accoloades Dosa was high on our list of new places to try in SF. 

Dosa did not dissapoint. Far from it. This is without a doubt one of the best places you can go for an Indian, especially if you are vegetarian and more so if you like authentic cuisine and not the heavy, creamy, over seasoned mixes you often get served at most joints. The mini popadoms didn't need sauces they were so flavorsome and the Spicy Mung Masala was tasty enough to satisfy any carnivores who say vegetable treats are bland and boring. Also highly recommended is the Channa Bhatura - the dishes are prepared with virtually no wheat and natural ingredients meaning you can eat lots and don't come away feeling stuffed and bloated. All in all awesome food for a very reasonable amount - great for dates, small groups of friends and even solo trips as the bar is lively and inviting. I have a feeling we could be back in mumbers on a very regular basis.
author: Nadia G.

description:
Super great San-Francisco take on South-Indian food. The wait can be a bit long sometimes, but the staff are great, the prices are good and the food is awesometacular.

The cheddar + mozzarella Dosa, as sacreligious as it sounds, is devine, and goes quite well with your neighbour's paper masala. 

It's so good that it frequently makes me forget that I've developed a recent inability to consume certain Indian spices without cramping up and dying a few hours later. mmmm, worth iiiit.
author: Glen M.

description:
Without doubt, one of the best! I've never had a bad meal here, and the service is always good. My parents just visited from the east coast, and we took them there for dinner. they were blown away, and my father said it was the best indian food he'd ever had. This coming from an ex-South African says a lot.

My only complaint is that they dont take reservations for parties less than 6. As a result, we always have to wait.
author: Lori G.

description:
Updated:
Came here last Saturday at 8.  Told wait could be an hour.  Gave them my cell and went to Ritual City Roasters.  A little after 9, we got the call that it would be 10 minutes.  Waited outside Dosa for another 30 minutes.  

2 visits
2 quotes of 1 hour wait
1 visit: 10 minute wait
1 visit: 1 hr 40 minute wait
Average wait: 55 minutes

Well, if I haven't learned anything else from my research, the wait at Dosa is the ensemble average.

At least the food is still good...
*************************

I came here after drinking at Elixir.  We were trying to find a place in the Mission on a Saturday night that didn't have too long of a wait, haha.  Finally, after getting tired of hearing 1.5 hours, we agreed that the quoted 1 hour wait at Dosa was agreeable.  We left them a cell number and decided to walk to a nearby wine bar for a drink.  No sooner had we walked in the door of the wine bar, did Dosa call saying that our table was ready!  

I had a paper dosa, and it was delicious!!!  The multiple dipping sauces only made me happier, cause I love to dip my food.  The flavors were complimentary.  The service was efficient and the atmosphere was lively.

I'll definitely be returning to Dosa for some South Indian food.
author: Jory R.

description:
Quick Summary: AMAZING & not cheap!

Me and a few friends checked the place out about 3 weeks ago. It's close to the CCSF Mission campus so i had walked past it quite a bit and it was always (read: ALWAYS) crowded. Roommate & another friend recommended it to me, and that was reason enough to give it a try.

We arrived at 9pm on a wednesday night and had a wait of about 20-25 mins, the place was packed. Thought they have a big bar, it's not fully stocked, keep that in mind (it's a restaurant after all).

Once we were seated, we ordered a bunch of different dishes and all of them without exception were ... wait for it ... AMAZING. Not necessarily authentic indian cuisine, but man who cares!

I have to give a lot of props to the staff. They were very nice, my glass of water was not once empty. The recommendations they gave were spot on.

The only bad thing i can think of is that it's quite popular, so ... make reservations or be mentally prepared to wait a bit. Also, it's not cheap by any means. That's be the only reason i'm not there once a week!
author: Ali A.

description:
I was looking for a restaurant with good vegetarian options in the Mission to entertain a friend from out-of-town.  My peeps have always had warm words for Dosa, so I thought I'd check it out.  It was a wonderul, smooth experience.  We rolled in about 7pm expecting a wait and were told our table would be ready in 45-50 mins.  Lo, 45 minutes later, we are being seated at our table.

Until I looked at the menu, I didn't quite realize how different South Indian food is from North Indian food.  All of the Dosas and Uttapams looked great, but I really was out-of-my depth in terms of being able to make smart menu choices.  As if she read my mind, our server glided to the table and asked, "Have you guys been to Dosa before?  Have you eaten South-Indian food before?"  When she saw our bewildered and blank faces staring back at her , she chuckled and gave us a crash course in the menu, asking a lot of questions to provide us with recommendations.

There wasn't a false step in the recommendations she gave us.  Every morsel was tasty, beautifully seasoned and lip-smacking good.  The food euphoria Dosa elevated us to made this a stellar evening.

I have to give a special mention to our server.  I only wish I knew her name.  She had black and white polka-dot nails...She was phenomenal!  Not only did she know the menu inside out and give great recommendations, but when she heard my friend Sarah coughing, she brought her a special broth on the house.  How nice was that?!
author: Ciara M.

description: I really liked this restaurant. It just made me feel very elegant. First class! The food was nice and had great presentation. Impressive and not too expensive.
author: Sandra W.

description: Whats going on in this town? Showed up at 9:30 im a late dine. We wanted to get the tasting menu. Was told it was to late. What kinda restaurant does that. To be honest I bet it was just the server saying so. The dosa was good. Everything else was sub par. The manager was really nice. That boosted it a star. Otherwise for the price and the rude service not worth it. There are lots of other restaurants in the mission I would rather try. I could be wrong but I believe they close at 10:00.
author: Numa R.

description: I hesitated between 2 and 3 stars. The food definitely isn't bad, but seriously guys, go to any South Indian restaurant proper for cheap, filling, yummy dosa and sambar. This place is not worth the wait, and I generally dislike being served by hipsters. For coffee is one thing, but for Indian food? No thank you.
author: Richa A.

description:
This place is a great place for South Indian food. I tried it after reading the reviews here on Yelp, and I was pleasantly surprised to find the food and service was great. We chatted with the owner who often takes the order and ordered Paper Masala Dosa which was great! The sambar (lentil soup) was great - very authentic South Indian style!

The service is slow and definitely expect a wait time of atleast 30 mins. But definitely worth a visit!
author: Hetav S.

description:
The long wait trick figured out. 
Sign in, give them your cell, go to Latin American club around the corner for a drink. They call you, bust it back to Dosa. Sit and eat. 
The food was great. We had a curry and dosa. I love the sambars. We had a nice wine with our meal also.
Would come back and take the same approach to the wait issue.
author: shannon t.

description:
Dosa is another small, upscale SF restaurant. The waiters are great and very helpful with suggestions when ordering. I had heard good things about both this Dosa and the one in Japantown so I was excited to try it.

Unfortunately, I don't think that Southern Indian food is something that I like. Our entrees both had a lot of egg in them and even the soup (Rasam "Fire Broth"), which most people love, wasn't that great. My favorite thing was probably the Chennai Chicken appetizer. We ordered dosa and uttapam but neither of them were nearly as good as the northern Indian food I usually order.

If you like Southern Indian food then you will probably like this restaurant. It's just not my thing.
author: Jackie G.

description:
Dosa is a savoury South Indian crpe. I do not enjoy South Indian cuisine or crpes ... but I am bored and this is the second place that came to mind so I will write about it.

Herbivore was the first place by the way.

I enjoy the Punjabi sort of Indian. I love that stuff. It all tastes like yummy to me but this I do not enjoy so much. It was really loud there. It was like one of those Latino parties I grew up going to where they play the music louder then it needs to be so the twenty people there each can only talk to one other person and that is only by yelling.

The service is a bit stuffy but that does not take away from the food which I personally only sort of enjoyed but everyone I was with loved it so perhaps I was having a poor food day?

I think it is actually a rather decent place and despite the overly hipster vibe I got [probably from all the hipsters] I would say if this region of food is your thing, go for it.

Okay... in addition, if you want to be a bit of a bit of a pretentious frak, it will suit you too. It is pricey [not too pricey], ambient [but not too ambient] and you can rock the blazer/jeans/ironic moustache without looking out of place.

If this is too middling a review, I am sorry. I just cannot muster up the passion to love or hate this place. It is a three out of five for me because it is good food but not my favourite.
author: Jonathan JayLando D.

description:
Great Brunch place in the Mission!

We decided to come here since we always pass it on Valencia.  What drew our attention is that is was a South Indian Restaurant which is hard to find since most Indian restaurants are North Indian.  

We were seated right away next to the window. BTW I love a nice view when i go to restaurants, especially one right next to the window outlooking the street. 

My husband and I started off with some mimosa's.  Then, we basically asked the waiter what he recommended since it was our first time.  

We had their special chata or dosa (forgot the name) and it was filled with potatoes and indian spices. This was definitely different from any indian dish i have ever had.

Also, we shared an meal of their special which was fish (since south Indian's eat a lot of seafood) in a great curry sauce.  This was amazing! 

For dessert we had gulab jamin (it is a little ball made of dough dipped in a syrup) so sweet and well worth getting. And a rasmali.  I don't know how to describe it, but its their special cheese dipped in condensed milky thing....Soooo good!
author: richelle p.

description:
Gosh...I really want to like this place.  The food IS very good.  But, noisey, crowded, rushed service, and finally...KILL the House music, for god's sake, it's an Indian restaurant.  Play some Indian classical or modern Indian, anything but House.  The wine list is way over priced for the selections available and our waitress was intent on keeping my wine glass full.  Felt like a hustle.

As much as I like south Indian cuisine, I doubt I'll be returning to Dosa
author: Steve H.

description:
This restaurant is pretty busy and popular among SF people. However i found the food to be OK for the price. I had papedum, masala Dosa and idli. I could barely walk after such a big feast. The place is cramped. i felt as if people sitting on the next table were actually sitting with me :( 
Finding street parking in this area is difficult so save the hassel and park in the garage on 21st St.
I found this place to be equally good as Udupi.
author: Hasham Y.

description: I've had plenty of dosa's in my time, but this one takes the buscuit!! just the right amount of crispiness on the outside and flavorful inside. Not to mention the appetizers which were off the hook!! Excellent service too by the owner and his crew! Lovely place to dine, romantic ambience.
author: Rak P.

description: The food was average, one of those fancy Valencia St. restaurant. We ordered one apetizer and I ordered dosa. It was just ok. I made it to Viks in Berkeley and the food was much better and less expensive.
author: Yoko S.

description: I finally made it here and yup, it's really good.  I loved the northern samosa, the lentil dumplings in yogurt, pappdum, and the sambar that's served w/ the dosas.  i ordered the peppercorn chicken (very tasty, but i think i'll stick with dosas next time), and the bf had the paper masala (A+).
author: Priscilla T.

description:
Good food, good atmosphere for large groups (not the best first date place...it's a bit too loud), and good location for parking. The overall experience is definitely catered to hipsters - nothing's overly flavored or spiced. Those who love dosas may want to stick to the classics: masala or mysore, which are well complemented by the tasty sambar. Those who are new to the dosa experience and don't like spicy food may like paneer or spring. Dosa's desserts and cocktails weren't to my taste, but they do main courses very well, and I dug the wine selection. Try the white wine from India, you'll be pleasantly surprised! 

It's definitely on the pricey side, but worth a try - you may love it. Plus you can go across the street for a post-dinner coffee and dessert at Ritual!
author: Anika K.

description:
YOU FED NUTS TO MY FRIEND WITH THE DEADLY NUT ALLERGY. After he told you, "Hey, I'm really really allergic to nuts. Can I eat this?"

A bunch of us met up at Dosa to celebrate a friend's birthday. Unbeknownst to our organizer until maybe an hour before, we had to order the prix fixe menu. Um, ok. That kind of sucks that we can't choose anything on the regular menu because we were 12 people large. They then kept us waiting so that we would order more drinks (where the margin is much higher) - we couldn't even order. 
On to the finally ordering...I'm a celiac, and they gave me a meal that didn't have gluten in it. Which is impressive! I recognize that it's an easy thing to mess up. A friend sitting next to me is horribly, terribly allergic to nuts. He told the waitress this. SHE GAVE HIM A SALAD WITH NUTS IN IT. He had a horrible reaction, and had to leave the restaurant. He had split his order with another friend - they said they comped it (um, seeing as he had to leave and couldn't actually eat it? That's the least you could do.) but charged her for the meal. And they made sure to charge his drinks to the rest of the table. Keep it classy Dosa. 
The food was amazing - I had the truffle dosa and mmmmm was it good. But Dosa, you handled everything else TERRIBLY. It was appalling. My friends and I still mention it every once in a while..."Hey, remember that time we went to Dosa and they almost killed [friend]? Yeah, that was horrible."
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Came here with other yelpers in a Daniel L. and May C. event.  This was such a good pick for us because we all had a chance to share our delicious food and be able to eat with our fingers.  We shared the Pani Puri (recommended to pop the whole thing in your mouth otherwise it will burst and become a total mess; it was quite a mouthful, but worth it).  We also shared the Dahi Batata Puri (with good strauss yogurt to cool your tongue) and Dahi Vada (was ok).  I ordered the Egg Poriyal Dosa (dosa was kind of soggy compared to other people's really crunchy dosa).  I tried another yelper's Masala Dosa, which was really good and I will order that next time.  I also tried the chicken curry with coconut basmati rice (so aromatic and flavorful).  My spice tolerance always depends on the flavor of the food and halfway through my meal I was sweating but didn't notice because it was so delicious.  Overall, it was a delicious meal.  Highly recommended! 

Pros: great service, great food, and great company.

Cons: hassle looking for parking, try public transit?
author: Amy C.

description:
Judging by the throngs of people who stand waiting outside even on a Sunday night, this relatively new South Indian restaurant is already a hit. I recently visited for the second time, and although the food isn't necessarily life-changing, it's very tasty, and I'm keeping Dosa on my list of restaurants to regularly patronize.

I wasn't very impressed by the chopped salad, although it is one of the few sources on the menu for fresh veggies. The idli (steamed rice and lentil patties) and vada (fried lentil dumplings) and their accompanying sauces are more interesting, if a bit heavy. Dosas are a must; I love these lentil crepes. The uttapam, or open-faced dosas, are also good, although I recommend the tomato and onion variety over the chile and coriander version (too spicy, and not in a good way). And I actually think the curries stand out among the other items on the menu -- I really enjoyed the pepper chicken and tamil lamb curries, both of which featured incredibly tender meat and complex, tasty sauces. Also be sure to get the delish channa masala with a giant piece of bhatura (fried bread). Last but not least, I love mango lassis, and the one I had here measured up.

This is a loud place, but I didn't find it any noisier than a lot of other places, but YMMV. Service is generally quick and efficient.
author: Tara M.

description:
My south Indian roommate says, "I want to hate this place, but I can't because it's really good."  In order to appreciate the positive nature of that comment, you have to understand that my roommate wantonly declares his dislike for so many food items with little or no basis in reality.  For example, he has expressed his dislike of pizza while actively eating a slice of pizza that wasn't intended for his consumption.

Anyway, the dosas and uttapams are very good, accompanied by great dipping sauces (that's really what you're eating in the first place).  The service is friendly, though it's quite likely that you'll be waiting for 45 minutes -- they don't take reservations for parties under 5.

One nit is that although they have an interesting selection of wines, they practically freeze their whites so you have to warm it for a while.  Other than that, it's good.

UPDATE: Anjan kindly responded that on busy nights sometimes wine by the glass come straight from the fridge, but mostly bottles are kept on ice.  Thanks!
author: John H.

description:
So far, the best Indian cuisine experience in SF. No longer will I have to travel to the South Bay for Dosas and drool-worthy curry. When you line-up the short list of sub-par hole-in-the-walls and buffets in the City, the high quality of  foods found at Dosa are a delight. Bite after bite, I was pleasantly surprised and I would go back for more.

If you want to avoid the weekend wait, then be sure to arrive on the earlier side.
author: Be N.

description:
Sometimes it's easier for me to be impressed by excellent service than amazing food.  I will toss around 4-5 star reviews for places with good vibes and excellent staff, but with so-so food.

The people can make a place more than the food can.

I don't like restaurants with this kind of wait list.  Nor do I like them with these kind of bartenders.  Everything took too long.  Bartenders were slow in general, but exceptionally slow when it came to closing out your tab.

It's so small, and for the amount of business they get it's just insane to attempt going here on a Friday or Saturday night.  You feel cramped inside and psychologically rushed.  I can't relax and eat in such closed quarters with waitresses and people wizzing by me nonstop.  It's just not comfortable, all you want to do is eat and move onto your next location as soon as you can.

The food was excellent.  The lamb curry was exceptionally delicious...literally melted in your mouth.

But I don't like waiting so long to eat.  It's freezing outside and there isn't even enough room at the bar to fit inside comfortably while you wait.

It's not worth the wait.  That's just my opinion.  Nicer places to go on a Friday or Saturday without the constant waiting.  I've been, now I know, and I don't forsee myself going again.  (At least not on a weekend that's for sure.)
author: Mary R.

description:
Not the best Indian food in San Francisco, but a tasty variation of typical fare at a reasonable price.

The service was attentive and friendly. The colorful and vibrant neighborhood is a great place to walk off your meal.

It's definitely on my return-to list.

For Indian cuisine alternatives, I like Amber off Market, Roti in West Portal and Masala on 9th Ave. Each is pricier, but more refined also.
author: christopher r.

description: Hmmm .... this place used to be incredible. Not sure what happened.  The food (dosa) was super greasy.  Maybe I caught them on an off night? Or I've been spoiled from Annapoorna in San Mateo http://www.yelp.com/biz/annapoorna-san-mateo#hrid:atyxlYghJ2AVF7uNabSyIQ ?
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Let me just say someone is making $$$.  This place is a goldmine.

We had a 1.5 hour wait for party of four on a Friday night, which was expected. It is not bad as we just headed up the street to Amnesia. Many other Dosa patrons had the same idea.

We did the tasting menu, which was pretty good.  Next time I would just do the straight up dosa though.  The staff was great and the service excellent.  I will try the brunch sometime I think.
author: Matt T.

description:
Had a decent experience at Dosa last Sunday - quite a scene, fantastic food, okay service. I'm not all that familiar with South Indian cuisine so I let my friends do most of the ordering - everything was delicious. 

However, the drinks took too long and the food came out way too fast. And judging from the other reviews, it looks like I'm not the only one. However, I'd go back again - and just request that the kitchen takes their time with my order. 

Definitely order the lentil dumplings with the cilantro/mint chutney and tamarind sauce - not only is it the most beautiful dish ever (order it and you'll see why) but it was delish! Dosas and uttapams were good...meat dishes not so much. And I LOVE meat. And I almost didn't come here because of such a limited meat menu. Sigh. So take my advice and stick with the vegetarian dishes and you'll be happy.

***UPDATE***
About 5 minutes after posting this, I received a message thru Yelp from the owner apologizing for the service. Turns out three employees were sick and one was training - which would explain the issue. I'm impressed with the effort and will now definitely give them a second chance. Nice work Anjan. :)
author: Kate S.

description:
Nice chic to modern atmosphere for a South Indian restaurant.  I had Dosa's special/ main/ original dosa, which is the "dosa masala."  It was nice.

Be sure to prepare your stomach for the wait at the line.  I would say on a Thursday to Saturday night, plan on waiting for 30-40 minutes.  And this place doesn't take reservations.

Have fun.
author: Alan T.

description:
I've been looking for a dosa place since I ate my first one in LA. I was not disappointed. I had the Masala dosa and it was just how I like it. Spicy. 

Most Indian restaurants in the city are pretty much hole-in-the-wall type places, but this place is more hip and elegant. The only complaint is the noise. It is very loud due to all the hard surfaces.
author: Robert C.

description:
Pretty good brunch.

We finally got around to trying this place after several unsuccessful attempts to find parking and without a huge wait. Sunday seems to be the best place to walk right in for bruch. The food is really good and flavorful, we enjoyed every bite. I can imagine that it's pretty lively and loud in the evening and on the weekends so, if you're not into that I would recommend and early lunch or brunch.

I'd like to try the dinner menu so hopeful the parking gods will be with us the next time we're in the hood and want to eat here.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
This place really is fantastic. My friend and I planned on sharing potato croquets, a side of rice and some bathura to eat with our dosas, but the waitress warned that it would be too starchy. We ended up getting the dahi vada instead of the rice, and it turned out to be a great accompaniment for the bathura. The dahi vada was presented beautifully.

I ordered the chatni masala dosa, which I *thought* was flavorful until I tried my friend's paneer and peas dosa, which I thought had a delicious and comforting spice flavor, whatever it was.

My main complaint, though, is that the place is expensive -- for $8 we received two potato croquets -- though otherwise not overpriced. I was impressed with most aspects of my meal (service, presentation, flavor, etc.), and I thought our experience was worth the $55 tab. It's not somewhere I can afford to eat regularly, but I intend to bring my family here sometime soon. Also, the ceiling fans made the place quite chilly. I had to wear my scarf by the time we finished our dinner.
author: Amy Z.

description:
I'm going to admit right now: I am biased towards Indian restaurants.

I literally think it is the food of the gods. They must've dropped some god-sized crumbs, which landed in India and thus -- the best cuisine on the face of the earth was born.

And Dosa is pretty damn good. Does it get the bonus star-of-the-gods? Well, no... it's no Little Delhi (see review). But I thoroughly enjoy a nice uttapam, and that is some GOOD coconut rice. I recommend the paneer and peas, and ask for spicy if you're feeling daring. Muahaha. Can't wait to try the brunch here! A little spice in the morning before a beer and some Bi-Rite at the park? That's my kinda Sunday.

One thing though - I really don't mind sitting my grubbin self at the bar, but I do wish they took reservations. Because sometimes a girl's gotta wear heels. And that girl does NOT feel like standing around while you mop up the last drop of your curry.
author: Megan B.

description:
Ahh. One year later. Dinner is still the reigning meal here at Dosa. There was not a single misstep in the house, as we sampled soups (the lovely coconut cauliflower comes to mind), starters (the chennai chicken got rave reviews) and sundry other items - prawn curry and channa bhatura being among them. Every one tasted just as they should. That is, the way they would at any self-respecting, authentic South Indian establishment. 
The only thing that elevated this experience even further were the wine pairings. Our server, god bless her alcohol-loving soul, made some fantastic suggestions. Could not have been more appropriate. 
Years go by, and still I love Dosa. Can't wait for their Fillmore location...
author: Purnima M.

description:
My friends and I came here for brunch because it sounded interesting and we were really needing to try something new. I had never had dosa's before, nor have I ever had this type of Indian food before, so we didn't really know what to order once we saw the menu (especially since there was practically no meat to be found.) The waitress was nice enough to make suggestions and everything turned out to be pretty good. 

We ordered the egg dosa with cheese which was served with coconut and tomato chutney and sambar. The coconut chutney was GOOOOD. We also ordered the chicken briyani, which wasn't featured on the menu but was a special that day. Pretty delicious...love the yogurt stuff you pour on top of everything. The third dish we ordered was the dahi batata puri appetizer, which was an experience in itself. Its like a fried bread shell filled with yogurt, potatoes, and chutney. When you stick it in your mouth, it explodes   and you're left with a mouth full of something (thats what she said). Wasn't my favorite dish, but it was interesting. 

I would definitely come back to try more of the different kinds of dosa's. Also, do not try the little bowl of mixed crap at the front that looks like birdseed. I think its a mix of fennel and various candies, which is supposed to act as a breath freshener...we got talked into it and it tasted like rotten jager.
author: Mel P.

description:
Decided to try the Dosa on Valencia since it is the original one & we did not feel like dressing up (I needed somewhere where I could wear those cutoff jeans shorts....ha, totally kidding). Pretty small restaurant, nothing unordinary about the atmosphere, pretty average (not fancy, but not divy) and pretty small.

We ordered the Paper Masala Dosa, the Channa Bhatura & The caramelized onion Uttapam. All three were DELICIOUS. The paper masala dosa was a HUGE roll of bread that is served with curried potatoes, two different sauces & lentil soup. The Channa Bhatura was my favorite thing, garbanzo beans cooked in a delicious sauce & was served with sweet puffy fried bread. The Uttapam looked kind of like a pizza and was very good too, was a thick & pancake like with vegetables on it.

All of the food was delicious, the service was great and we were out the door for $40 (with tip), although we didn't order any drinks. I would go back to Dosa anytime!
author: Elaine S.

description: I thought all the food we had was delicious and with nice ambiance! My boyfriend is South Indian with a mom that is an amazing cook, and even he agreed it was legit. Just be warned- it is definitely NOT $$ signs. We ordered two drinks, just enough food- a dosa, some sides, but only one entree (I picked at his) and the bill came to about $40 each. It was well worth it but just be prepared when you go there, this is not an inexpensive destination.
author: Amanda M.

description: I am giving Dosa 5 stars because of the service. There were some complications with my reservation and the manager went above and beyond to contact the owners to find a solution. I threw a get together party and some of my friends were skeptical about going out to indian before a night on the town, but it turned out perfect! There were enough choices to fill everyones tastes and dietary restrictions.
author: Ahna B.

description:
Pretty damn good.  I couldn't help but try this place after seeing almost 900 Yelp reviews.  The Dosa was phenomenal and the dipping sauce it came with was just perfect.  We ordered the first Paper Dosa which comes with potatoes, two dipping sauces, and this delicious lentil based dipping broth.  The waitress claimed it was their "holy grail".  It takes 38 ingredients to make it and takes a full day to prepare.  That's the kind of love you like to see put into your food.  We also ordered the Jumbo Prawn Curry & Lamb Kofta, both of which were great.  The mango lassi was also good but nothing spectacular; definitely not worthy of the $4.50 price tag it came with.  

Like everyone else, I feel this place doesn't deserve that five star review because of their overpriced menu.  It would have been nice to see more things on the menu other than Dosa, but I guess that's what they specialize in.  If it weren't for that, it would have earned a 5 star based on the food and the service which were both great.
author: Mike L.

description:
Came here last night with a friend. The waiter was very friendly and helpful. We started with a very good ch*** (bread) which had mint and a cream and green salsa type sauce which I really enjoyed. Its a Monday special they have.

I ordered the dosa-masala and my friend ordered the panner dosa and they were both very good. 

We also had the Indian Pilsner beer which was pretty good! 

The dishes are plentiful and good. The atmosphere is great and the staff is very helpful.

I had a couple beers before dinner at the Pilsner and when I have a couple beers before dinner it tends to distract from my taste buds and compromises the taste of the food, but it was still very good.
author: Art A.

description:
I found myself here on a Friday evening.  A friend and I wandered in unexpectedly, and were seated immediately.  Not bad for a nice restaurant on a Friday night.

The server was quite nice.  He asked if it was our first time here, which it was, and he proceeded to break down the menu for us in terms that we'd be able to understand.  I felt way more prepared to be able to pick out something I'd really enjoy.

I would like to warn you, if you are used to Naan n Curry, Chutney, and the like, this is quite different.  You will definitely recognize some of the same ingredients, but how it is prepared is completely different, and they don't serve naan.

Back to business.

We were served quickly.  We put in our order, I went to the bathroom, talked on the phone for 3 minutes, and when I came out, the food was on the table.

The Mango Lassi was made out of yogurt and delicious.  I got the Paper Masala Dosa, and my friend got the Peas and Paneer Uttapam.  Both were delicious.  Mine was definitely a hands-on type meal.  Rip apart the dosa and get your hands dirty!!!  The way Indian food should be.  His was a little bit more refined, needing a knife and fork.

The service wasn't bad at all until the end of the evening when we were waiting for our check.  It got to the point where my date put his credit card on the table and another waiter picked it up and got us on our way.

Other than that speed bump, I enjoyed myself.  I'd definitely return.
author: Jess R.

description:
This is my first south indian food restaurant.  We had the Cochin Calamari, the Masala Dosa and the prawn coconut masala.  The Cochin Calamari was extremely fresh and flavourful.  As for the Masala Dosa, was delicious, judging from the ingredients used, it will be more suitable for vegans.  I will not get the Dosa dishes again because the cost of making them is low and its actually hawker food back home (Singapore).  

I strongly recommend the prawn coconut masala, the prawns are fresh and not overcooked.  The prawns took 'soaked' up all the curry and made it good.  

Another must try is the Mango Lassi (Mango Yogurt drink) its not too thick and blended with a nice dose of mint leaves which made it even more refreshing!  

Overall, I enjoyed this place and its not too spicy for the locals.  (Though I would have preferred it to be at least 50% more spicy).  Try to get in early as people starts strolling in from 5.30pm onwards and by 6pm you will have to stand in a line if not, make a reservation.
author: Xiuf L.

description:
i will start this review by stating Ive never liked Indian food .

With that said, I will say I had a pretty good meal here. My friend and I shared the Fire Broth soup , that was beyond excellent and I'd come get that for take out sometime. For our main meals I had the Dosa Masala. Pretty darn good but the presentation is way too big , it looks weird having this big thing hanging off the plate, and he had this fire chicken thing ...the chicken was tender and very good but the sauce paired with it threw me off. I'd come back I think...it wasnt amazing to me but like I said Ive never really enjoyed indian food so maybe im biased
author: Lauren V.

description:
like the atmosphere and liked sambhar but hated 1hr wait.

Now i realized that i can get much better dosa in south bay.
author: chess t.

description:
I've had a lot of indian food in my time, but I was shocked to find out that there was a whole range of flavors I had never experienced below.  So for its unique and quality dishes, I give them props.

The atmosphere was semi-upscale for an indian restaurant and the service was very attentive and friendly. Of course with the white linens come a higher price tag on your meal, but its all part of the experience they're trying to sell to you. 

I can't remember what I ate, it was rather foreign for Indian food, must be from a different part of India. I think it was worth trying but there are many other cheaper places in the city that match this little jewel, so I'd say give it a shot if you're looking for upscale indian.

Update: one of the owners responded to my review and mentioned that they do go out of their way to use free range and organic material in their food. That is a huge plus for me, compared to other indian restaurants, so that ups the prices but  for a very good reason! Rock on Dosa.
author: Venatius P.

description: They serve the best vada Pav in the bay area as it taste very same to what we get in India. I will go to this place again. They has good dosa. And the customer service was also nice.
author: SS S.

description:
Certainly some of the most interesting Indian food I've ever had, and the most tasty. Most Indian places in town are N. Indian and Pakistani and are either way overpriced or kind of divey. Either could work depending on your tastes, but Dosa brings something wholly different to the party. Since it serves S. Indian, Dosa's regional specialty is also its namesake: flat, spongy rice pancakes of bread that conceal a collage of spices, flavors and ingredients (reminiscent of Ethiopian food in its composition and textures, if not its flavors). The spicy mung masala dosa is fantastic (green chiles, spicy potatoes and lentils), as are the somosas and the peppercorn chicken (comes in a thick sauce that mixes heavenly with a side of rice).

What you won't find here are the tika masalas, naans and tandoori dishes served by about 90% of all Indian restaurants in town. 

Finally, while I didn't have dessert, an after dinner spiced Indian coffee was without question the best coffee drink I've ever had. 

The wine list is substantial and the servers are skilled at recommending wines. Personally, I like white when eating spicy foods, and the Greek Assyrtiko we chose was fantastic. 

The restaurant itself is a stylish and modern foodie paradise, painted in warm earth tones and decorated all over with technicolored paintings in Indian motifs. The service is prompt, although I felt like they were rushing us a little and going for turnover (at 6:45 on a Friday, the place was already filled up). Finally, I have to say that the prices here are very reasonable and the room's casual elegance makes dining at Dosa a treat.
author: Andrew K.

description:
One word - wow.  Next time friends are visiting SF, I'll take them here for sure.  Go for brunch, it's not crazy packed and a great way to start the weekend.  Fantastically friendly service, and the food in addition to being delicious is FUN.  You get to dip your steaming flavorful pancakes into lentil sauce first, then two types of chutney, and top it all off with garbanzo bean curry.  Yummy!  

I wasn't as impressed with the mixed drinks - they were seriously weak (I guess I should've expected it since they were you using soju), but for $8-9/pop I guess I was hoping for something better.  Next time I am sticking with wine - the place has a seriously awesome extensive wine menu!
author: N. S.

description: there's a world of difference between the quality of food at the Dosa on fillmore and this one. This one - service was decent, but the food was pretty ordinary.. I had the paneer peas dosa and it was like the batter was old or something, it tasted mealy. Anyway we only went here because the good Dosa was booked for the day. Take my advice - dosa on fillmore, if you couldnt get  a reservation there head straight to south bay for the best south indian restaurants in the US
author: divya c.

description:
Great South Indian food + nice ambience! Rare combo out here :)
Brought my parents to Dosa when they first opened and we all agreed it was very yummy food. The dahi vada was delicious and very well-presented and the dosas were nice and crispy. Good service too - none of the waiters are Indian, but the owner is. I've been back a couple times since then and haven't been disappointed. I've heard their new location on Fillmore is even better.
author: Sushmita S.

description:
I grant the possibility that Dosa's food may not be the best example of South Indian cuisine in the Bay Area; I certainly would not consider myself an expert. But after eating there last night with two friends from out of town, one a vegetarian, I can say that we thoroughly enjoyed the experience. Our server, who was Indian, was extremely helpful, courteous, and not rushed even though the place was packed. We ordered tasting menu and shared 3 of the 4 courses. Standouts included the fiery broth soup, the mushroom masala, and the coconut gelato. The drink selections were plentiful and both of my girlfrend's soju cocktails -- the sinful crush and the lychee soju homebrew -- were divine.

Although it was packed, we had no problem hearing each other at the intimate tables. Definitely a place to recommend for something out of the ordinary, even for those who frequent Indian restaurants.
author: Michael B.

description:
Good ambience, decent food, very good service but pricey food. Thats why I am rating it 4 instead of 5 stars. 

This place is located in the mission, the one place I wouldnt expect to find a decent indian restaurant but i was surprised to see how clean and well maintained this place was. I have visited this place 3-4 times in the last 2 years and it still is the same. 

The food is decent. The sambar had an overkill of spices and is not as good as I was expecting it to be. The idlis are not fresh and fluffy. I liked the Dosas and would recommend them instead of  idlis.  Try the Madras Coffee which is a mix of coffee with chicory and is a staple drink in southern India. 

The service has always been very good but I find this place pricey.  This is a good place to take your date if you want to have Indian food and it has a good collection of wine and Indian beers too. 


Very good service
author: Rahul P.

description:
This weekend, I went on a culinary expeditions to Dosa and The Slanted Door. My conclusion: both are the eptiome of stylish, but (somewhat) overpriced ethnic cuisine. 

Here at Dosa, I was very underwhelmed by their basmati rice. Not flavorful, not aromatic, and was rather overcooked, in my opinion, with too much water. This is in comparison to some very nice basmati that I cook at home in a plain ol' rice cooker. 

The dosa itself was pretty good, as was the lamb curry, but on the other hand, as with The Slanted Door, not so much different from restaurants of the "lower scale" variety.

So if you want an upscale experience, then this place is pretty happening, but if you're interested for the food only, it's pretty good, but not worth a long wait.

ADDENDUM: I got a nice reply from one of the owners, reminding me that they use the highest quality ingredients, free-range, organic, etc, and this is indeed a big plus compared to the "lower scale" establishments, and contributes to their cost structure.

Also, I forgot to add (and ok, I'll raise a star because of it, because it's so rare to find) that their ras malai is absolutely fantastic. I have made ras malai myself from scratch, so I know what a fresh version tastes like, and what the texture is supposed to be, and Dosa's version is very, very good.
author: Bruce C.

description:
somethings will just never be the same without her.  i came up on a work trip...and i only knew the city from her eyes, she always had the most endearing taste.  i wanted to relive every moment and try to forget the amazing times i had but it was too hard...so i went to what i knew and i ended up here.  

i sat in the corner of the bar by myself, ordered the same things i had from before (samosas, paneer dosa, vada pav)...i even recognized the bartender from the other Dosa restaurant, food was still mediocre but i never told her that....it was her (my) birthday and the fact she went to the length to bring me here was enough for me.....
author: Saga D.

description:
First trip:  good but not great.  Cocktails are a definite plus:  we started with the chai russians while waiting, and both that and the lychee lush were yummy.  After we were seated, my friend tried the mango lassi and that was good too.

Food-wise, we tried the cheese dosa and the lamb curry, the curry was unexpectedley spicy and interesting.  My co-diner reported that it isn't always that spicy.  The cheese dosa was... OK but not worth coming to Dosa's for.

I'll try it again though, the curry was enjoyable and I probably should have ordered something more traditional than the cheese dosa.  The cocktails certainly helped deal with the wait!
author: Leo H.

description:
You are in a state of panic! your cool composed self turned into a mere dusty memory and you are about to lose it - you ex is visiting from out of town and she wants to have south indian food! 
Worry not my friends, smile and tell her you have it covered and then call Dosa to make reservations! now breathe!

The place is well laid out, with attention to ambiance and comfort. It breaks away from the general perception - good indian food is only served at run down hole in the wall places!. wait! is that really the general perception!

The food is good, but not the best i have had. Agreed, there are more authentic south indian eateries in south bay but this place is not bad at all, no sir! on the contrary, i found the food flavorful and well presented.  i had my usual, mysore dosa, and i was not disappointed. 

The place gets pretty crowded so make reservations ( they don't take reservations for fewer than 6 people per party) or check it out on a lazy weeknight. 

i would write more but now i want sambar rice!
author: Nabil B.

description:
Cool spot, good service, poor beer selection, lousy food, totally unimpressed. Sunday brunch for two consisted of two drinks two small plates & two entrees total $85 with tip left us choking that food back down and it was not very good the first time down. 

One of the plates was a chicken plate; come on $15 for three very small drummettes & rice or something like it is ridiculous.

I wanted to try DOSA for a little different presentation than the usual Indian food, but broke my own rule, that any place with that many reviews most likely is not all that good, since most people do not have especially good taste.
author: Bill K.

description:
Adding two cents-

they brought us an extra dish by mistake- paneer dosa- really yummy and even better that they didn't charge us for it!

The uttapam was really good and the special they had- a mustard fish- really spicy mustard and spices were flavorful.

Nice treat- for me, I think it was pricy compared to others I have been to - and while sometimes it's nice to pay for atmosphere and touches like the carafe of water on your table, normally I'll go elsewhere and support the mom and pops!
author: Keri B.

description: My friend and I ordered the Dahi Vada, Chennai Chicken, and the Mango Salad.  The dishes were delicious and the waiter was very attentive to our needs.  We really liked the complementary papadums :-) I would definitely come back here the next time I'm in San Fran.
author: Laura P.

description: This place is unlike any other Indian restaurant I've ever been to! The dosas and the uttapams are always fantastic.
author: Ben E.

description: Oh man!! This place was incredible! I'm used to Northern Indian but this (Southern) was an unexpected treat. The server was very informative and gave great explanation/recommendations without being overbearing or condescending. I had a whole branzino special, while the other people I was with opted for items off the menu. Everything was delicious! Well worth return visits.
author: Hank D.

description:
#64 of 100 on 7x7's The Big Eat SF 2009: Paper masala dosa at Dosa
http://bit.ly/1VmqYA

#67 of 100 on 7x7's The Big Eat SF 2010: Paper masala dosa at Dosa
http://bit.ly/a1POhh

Having been to India three times and having had a fair share of India food around the Bay Area, I can't say that DOSA is top of the line Indian food, and by my standards, I'm not sure I would recommend this place to friends looking to dine in the Mission.

7x7 recommended the paper masala DOSA, so we dutifully obliged. The Dosa itself was massive (this seems mostly for show around here), and the India potatoes, onions, and cashews were quite tasty. The tomato and coconut chutney were also a nice complement. Did it stand out to me? Not really - and halfway through the meal, the Dosa lost its warmth so it was kinda soggy in the middle.

Other dishes we had included:
- Idli Sambar -- great starter, idli itself was a bit tough but the dish was good on a rainy SF evening
- Kerala chicken -- this was pretty awesome, including the coconut rice. I'd probably get this again.

So yeah, 3 stars. The waiter we had was really nice and was attentive with the water.

Behind us was an Asian couple with a girl who talked really loud. The guy was trying to be tough and ordered the spicy masala dosa. The waiter warned him that it was really spicy, but he went ahead and got it, but then had to ask for yogurt to cool it down. So much for impressing the girl. So for all the guys out there -- don't try an Indian restaurant for a date. You might embarrass yourself with spicy food.
author: Reid Y.

description: I was not at all impressed by this restaurant!! I was extremely disappointed. My sister and I was so hungry and looking forward to our meal. The food looked good but once I tasted it I was not happy at all. It was also pricey! For one dish is about $16 and all it is is mashed up beans, potatoes, and flour to make the bread. There is hardly any parking on the street and you have to pay for parking at a garage nearby. It was located in a crappy neighborhood. I will not waste my money on this place. Terrible!!!!
author: Jennyfer M.

description:
Went with 2 friends on Friday night, had to wait for 30 odd minutes as we didn't have reservation. The interior seems a bit crowded but ambience is pretty nice and prices are pretty reasonable too.

A decent selection of Dosas, we tried 3 varieties of Dosas and all were pretty good.(and I guess my rating bar for Indian food is a bit high..so it was definitely good). The best was Paneer and peas Dosa. Was presented in a unique way !

Also the accompanying chutney and sambhar were pretty good. 

The only eyesore was the nearby locality isn't particularly upscale and you don't feel much comfortable walking around while waiting for being seated.
author: S G.

description:
Only "south" indian place to eat in San Francisco. 
decent food, nice atmosphere. Kind of small,be prepared to wait get a seat.
author: Hash K.

description: Amazing food, great ambiance, just the right amount of "buzz." Waitress seemed just a little rushed. Prices are right. Will go again.
author: Mike V.

description:
Oh my life was revolutionized the first time I ate at dosa. South Indian cuisine is just as tasty as North Indian but less well known and harder to find. So like many people, I'd never had it! 

Now I know the delights of dosa and uttapam. Yum!
author: Claire G.

description:
Dosa is an authentic inexpensive Indian restaurant with great atmosphere. The food was great, particularly given the price. I'll definitely go back. 

However, we went at around 7:30 on a Saturday and had to wait 1.5 hours for a table. Now, they took our number so we could go down the street to a bar and wait, which is a plus, but 1.5 hours is a LONG time to wait. Be prepared or go early.
author: Jennifer C.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF.  A tad expensive but well worth it.  Great drinks that'll have you singing in no time.  Recommend the habanero dosa for the adventurous.  All that I've had here has been great.
author: Martin S.

description:
Great food - 4-5 stars
Service - 1-2 stars

After making a reservation on Opentable for 5 people at 7pm - I had to give me credit card and they called to confirm my time the day before. We have been to Dosa a few times, but been about 5 months since our last time.  I don't know what management has done, but we arrived at 6:45pm, pretty quiet and waited at the bar..and waited and waited..soon it was 1 hr!! We checked in for the 3rd time and they apologized and said it would be another 20 mins or so. I couldn't believe that with a reservation and arriving early we STILL were not seated.  Finally someone offered an appetizer while we waited at the bar, but it was just the free chips - gee thanks! 
Finally, got seated about 1hr 20 minutes later.  We ordered and food came slowly, but as I remember the food was awesome!

The check arrived..the waitress says gratuity was included. I always thought that was for 6 people or more?  We took a closer look at the check and they made us pay gratuity on all of our DRINKS too - huh???  We would never have left such a tip for this kind of service..how annoying!  Think that may be our last time going to Dosa.
author: E k.

description:
I know, I am a horrible person, but I just didn't LOVE Dosa. The service was pretty good, but we did have to wait 30 minutes before sitting down at a table that we had on reserve for a week. And even then we were crammed into a corner too close to the kitchen and bathrooms. 

The food came out entirely too fast (I hate being rushed) and maybe I am biased because I have traveled to India, but I just wasn't impressed. I was less impressed when I saw the bill. 

However, their Dosa was pretty good, and I don't know of anywhere else to find them. And their sauces were like 8 out of 10 stars or whatever. I am willing to give them a second chance, but as for now, I don't buy the hype.
author: Delilah S.

description: I am not an adventurous eater, and thus don't like trying new things, but the food here was fabulous.  I didn't get a chance to order a drink (driving) but it seemed like they had amazing cocktails as well.  Wait staff was very good as well... my friend dropped her fork, and the waitress appeared within seconds with a new one before we even asked.
author: Eliza K.

description:
Back when Dosa first opened I was stood up by the girl I was pretty sure was "the one".  I sat there for 20 minutes alternately worried, angry, and starving.  I never ate.  I broke up with the girl soon after.  I hadn't gone back to Dosa until yesterday.

Holey Moley it's good food!  It's wiped away any associations with my failed love life, and in their place is the memory of one of the best South Asian meals I've ever had in San Francisco.  Love is fleeting, masala dosa is forever.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Ah the dirty South...India that is.  I'm not talking about this somewhat backwater swampland I live in called Jacksonville.
It may very well be that my neglected taste buds were overstimulated here, but I truly enjoyed the dosas and uttapams we had here.  We shared the Paneer Dosa, the South Indian Moons (5 assorted small uttapams) and the Shrimp Masala.
The shrimp was the highlight for me.  Well spiced with a satisfying fresh, crunch.  Uttapams, not really worth 13.50, nor was the dosa worth 11.  I think you can find dosas just as good for 3-4 dollars cheaper.  Go to Vic's in Berekeley if you don't care about the ambiance at all and just want to stuff your face.  I guess you're paying to be in SF and all that.  Don't get me wrong, I liked the food a lot, just not the prices.

I had a mango lassi/soju drink that looked good on paper but really failed in execution.  Actually, I didn't like their lassi either.  

The ambience was nice.  A smallish place with a dark orange color scheme.  They have a small bar as well.

Service was ok...we waited about 1 hour for a "45 minute" table.  I guess you'd have to blame the other customers though.

I liked it, but I don't think I'll go back.  There's too much competition in the Bay.
author: Jay L.

description:
What to say? I'm another big fan of this delicious food. 
Can't wait to go back!
author: Sergio D.

description: It is not what you think of when you want indian food. It is completely different and I didn't like it. I know a lot of people who do though. I just think there are better indian places out there; you just have to look outside the city. Plus the lady at the front was crappy. I have to say the veggie sliders were pretty good though if not a little weird.
author: Chris S.

description: Delicious. Paper masala dosa won't steer you wrong here. Probably better with a larger group so you can have a variety of dosas and curries, etc., to dip and share. Chaat was just average.
author: Brian C.

description:
Wow! We showed up at 7:30 on a Friday and were told the wait would be 1hr 15min. We tried to wait by the bar, but felt like we must be violating some fire code, so we stayed outside. Then the fire truck showed up and we were sure this was going to close down the restaurant for the night. Alas, Firepeople have to eat, too. We finally found a spot at the bar and had appetizers and drinks. The food actually tastes like the smells coming from the kitchen. Strong Curry flavors, which were great. 
Finally, we got the table and ordered two dosas to split between the two of us. This was a significant portion. The Peas and Cheese (Matar Paneer) was out of this world! The dipping sauces are delicious as well. The Masala dosa was half filled with potatoes, peas etc... It could have had more inside. 
Definitely a great tasting experience, but the wait times are a hassle. 
Wine list was full and the waitress had good knowledge of how to pair wines with the food. 
Not strictly vegan food. (See cheese review above.) Though, they do have vegan options.
author: Kat T.

description: The service was good. I ordered Dosa Masala and for apetizer the Vadha. But the vadha came inside a bun. I have never seen this in India but maybe is something new this restaurant is doing. The only Indian eating here was my husband. The chicken chili was very tasty.
author: Mw C.

description:
Busy place - expect a long wait, unless you go at the right time. I was thoroughly satisfied with the different vegetarian dishes and dosas. They were flavorful, had nice texture (saucy, chunky), and ingredients were fresh. I had an assortment of different curry sauces of unique, varied spices, which provided an experience for my palate. 

Nice decor (classy, but simple) - the lighting made an enormous difference in creating a pleasant ambiance.. A bit more expensive than many Indian restaurants...(I have to thank my generous friend who treated me out)
author: Audrey L.

description:
We tried to go here many times, but were always turned away at the door (Dosa doesn't take reservations for parties smaller than 6). Finally, we had a Friday night where we had no real plans, so we decided to stick it out. Fortunately, the wait was only about half an hour.

I really enjoyed the papadum - this is actually the first time I have ever had a papadum that I liked.

We had cocktails - they serve wine, beer, and soju cocktails. I ordered the chai russian, which just wasn't my thing.

I ordered a curry with a dosa instead of the side of rice. It was very good - I would recommend doing it this way.

In the middle of the meal, we had an extra Dosa delivered to our table. From what we were told, the owner had decided that my Dosa was too crispy, so they sent us another. I thought that the second Dosa was significantly better than the first.

The bill came to about 50 for 2 people (dinner and 1 drink a piece), which seemed about right for what we got. I thought that the service was very good. Overall, my only "complaint" could be that it was loud, but to be fair, this was a Friday night and we were sitting in the middle of the room.
author: Dana L.

description:
I was at Dosa for my birthday and had a great time.  The restaurant was very cozy, service was good and food was excellent!  

Just beware, when ordering a spicy dish ask the server HOW spicy it will be.  I love spicy but hot damn one of the dosas I got was flaming hot.  It may have been the spicy mung masala dosa.

I will definitely be back.
author: H K.

description: We came here on Valentine's Day and I was pleasantly surprised with the ambience of this Indian restaurant. Most of the diners were non-Indian which is a good sign of their diverse attraction. The dosas of course were really good. We got the calamari which was a nice touch and the shrimp special for dinner. I liked that they did well in all types of indian food not just dosas and south indian cuisine. We got something similar to a virgin mojito which was really refreshing and good ole homemade ras malai for dessert. We met the owner because it was a high frequency day and he was really nice and interested in our thoughts on our experience. I look forward to trying the Fillmore location which I hear has an even better location/ambience.
author: Sheena S.

description:
After a failed attempt last month (who knew they were closed on monday?) ;-) I finally made it to Dosa last night. As many other peope have said - the no reservations policy is a little frustrating but we waited at the bar and had a glass of wine so it wasn't too bad. Our wait was probably about 30 minutes for a table of two around 7:30-8pm.
The food was excellent! The dosa's were by far my favorite part of the night. I thought all the dipping sauces were excellent - all had a little kick which was nice. Enjoyed the wine, and the dessert. Pistachio ice cream was very nice. Good portion too. Overall great experience and will def. go back again!
author: Emily L.

description:
We waited for an hour outside before getting a table. The aroma made the wait torture-- I'm pretty sure that I was drooling by the time we made it in. The interior is quite stunning, although crowded and, though others have commented that their service was sub-par, we had no problems.

As Indian food goes, I've certainly had better. Our lentil dumplings were decent (although I give an A+ for beautiful presentation) and I second the soggy dosa sentiments expressed in earlier reviews.  My dosa was alright but not thrilling, only the variety of sauces made it somewhat worthwhile. And, after trying companions' dosas I was left unimpressed.  I expected to be treating my taste buds. Mostly I think my taste buds were pretty bored.

Next time I'll look elsewhere for good Indian food.
author: Mariah K.

description:
I love this restaurant  because there are never any ugly people in it.  Ever.  

And the food is top-notch, as has been mentioned by the previous 800 reviewers.
author: Paul B.

description:
We took my dad here last year when he was visiting.  I was skeptical that:

1. There could be good dosa outside of India (and/or outside of my mom's kitchen).
2. There could be good Indian food in San Francisco. It just didn't compute.

Boy, was I wrong.  My masala dosa was flaky goodness, although my main beef (haha, no pun intended) with masala dosa is that the masala is never evenly distributed. That held true at Dosa too.

My father pronounced their sambar the best he has had outside of India. That's high praise indeed.
author: hima s.

description:
YUM.  went here last night with 4 friends - we were told we'd be seated in 30 minutes but it only took 10.

We ordered the 4 course tasting menu, and although it was a bit too much food for our girly appetites, everything was delicious.

I had an organic greens, goat cheese, walnut and mango salad with an awesome cilantro dressing.  fresh, tasty and the mango was delicious

then had a spring dosa - the dosas here were excellent and this one came with some veggies.  dipping sauces were interesting and flavorful

next was the prawn coconut curry - what an awesome choice i made here!

had some mango kulfi ice cream for dessert and went home stuffed and happy.

really enjoyed the atmosphere and open setting.  

only complaint was a slight lack of service - i kept having to ask for water refills and we asked several people for the check before we got it.
author: Lauren V.

description:
This was a great experience.  I went here, never having had southern indian cuisine.  The staff was very helpful and patient with the ordering process.  The manager even came over when our food arrived to explain to us how to eat the food.  This may sound lame, but I never want to look ignorant when it comes to eating!!!  Show me how the locals do it...
The food was really tasty and well made.
author: sara b.

description:
Stupidly trendy and priced to be laughed at.

Dosa, I'm south indian, you're kinda-sorta south indian, I've been willfully ignoring you for a while now, knowing that I can get a tasty fix of the mother cuisine from Udupi Palace, the South Bay, or when I go home to Cleveland.

Still, I decided to mark the passage of my first year in the city by getting you over with.  Please understand, I'm not trying to be an authenticity douchebag.  It's just that I used the mother cuisine filter on yelp (oh wait - yelp - you don't have that? please implement! i'd prefer advice on indian restaurants from a Venkat than from a Victor) and that told me what I needed to know - I still see no reason to pay your prices for food that gets it about 80% right when I can do better in at UP down the road, or in freaking Cleveland.

The rundown:

1. Mung Salad - nine dollars.  nine dollars? for that?  about 2/3 a cup of mung sprouts that tasted pretty much only of lemon despite the advertised spices.  Concept has lots of potential.
2. Rasam - good.  You got one of the basics right.
3. Chile cilantro Uttapam.  Weak sauce.  Weak freaking sauce.  No evidence of chile or cilantro.  Didn't hold up very well to being eaten by hand, which is why you play the game in the first place.  And are you guys pureeing some portion of the sambhar before it comes out to make it pass for soup? Sambhar is not supposed to have a uniform mouth feel guys. Uttapam was the low point and the sambhar was the low point of the low point.


4. Dahi Rice w / Achaar.  The space above is to indicate that I waited about 1/2 hr. after the uttapam for the dahi rice to show up.  I'm glad your kitchen knows the appropriate order of things (yogurt rice always last) but I don't recall asking for extra time after the uttapam to smoke a cigarette, use the restroom, and order tamarind rice from UP while I waited.

By the way, if you're going to be a south indian restaurant, how bout using a south indian word for yogurt instead of the Hindi.  Ok, now I am being an authenticity douchebag. 

Service was fine, and I thought your staff did a respectable job of shepherding newbies through the menu.  But please inform them that Shrikhand is not just "sweet yogurt."  Gogurt is sweet yogurt.  Shrikhand and gogurt are completely different things.  Therefore Shrikhand must not be sweet yogurt, right?

EDIT
 .
I see dedicated pain in the ass Anjan M. has decided to comment on my review.  

Here's an idea: why don't you convene your legendary 14 south indians to find some recipes that actually celebrate the gastronomic diversity of the south?

No?

You're still going to serve up the same old pablum?

And you're still the same condescending bore you were yesterday?

OK.
author: Srikanth S.

description: Excellent south Indian, and unlike most, has non- veg entrees as well. Dosas, idles and sambar were all first rate. Highly recommended.
author: Salil D.

description:
My wife and I have been here twice for Brunch.  Both times were good but the second was definately the best since I opted for their signature dish, the Dosa Marsala.  Is was fabulous.  As and appetizer we shared something called the Dahl Vada.  They are lentil dumplings that are served in a yogurt/tamarind/mint mixture.  It was beautiful to look at, not at all what we expected, and was REALLY interesting to eat.  That's my thing, I should probably say.  Food should be fun to eat.  So much food is just consumeable.  Fuel to dump in your gas tank.  How dull is that?

Dosa serves up a brunch that is both interesting to look at, very pleasureable to eat, and not horribly expensive for what you get.  I suggest you do what my wife and I did, split a salad, a starter and a Dosa.  it was the perfect amount of food and damn entertaining to boot.  We will soon be trying them for dinner with a party.
author: Torbin B.

description:
I am not a big fan of Indian food.  It is a long story why I decided to visit this place.  One of my friends who lives just a block away from Dosa highly recommended this place many many times.  My boyfriend who seems to live in the floating dog house ever since we started dating happens to LOVE Indian food.  The odd thing is that we never had Indian food together.  Anyway, I decided that it is time for us to give Dosa a try since my BF loves Indian food and my friend is so crazy about this place.

Since Dosa does not accept reservations, we decided to arrive at the restaurant early.  We arrived at about 6:00pm on Saturday evening.  It took us 1 hour and 30 minutes to get a table!!!    Luckily we secured a spot on the corner of the bar so we could at least had our appetizer first.  The calamari salad was delicious!  The calamari was so tender and full of flavors with different spices.  The lychee cocktail was not as good as what I had expected.  The lassis cocktail was so tasty that I drank 2 glasses before we were seated.  We ordered lamb curry, chicken curry and a plain crepe.  The crepe was paper thin and was great to dip with our curry dishes.  The curry dishes were spicy but not too hot.  The chicken was juicy and tender.  I love the fact that they put both the breast meat and thigh in the dish.  I am the dark meat eater!

My conclusion is that people go to Dosa because they are food lovers.    That's why most people are willing to wait for hours for a table.  Will I come back to Dosa again?  I will under one condition: Next time I am gathering 6-8 people so we can get a reservation.  I am totally turned off if I have to wait for a table for more than 30 minutes.  I survived this time because it was a special day.  It was worth of waiting because my BF really enjoyed the dinner!
author: Michelle H.

description:
We've been trying to get a reservation here forever but have always had been told they were booked up 2 to 3 weeks out. Could it be THAT good or just another over-hip destination? Then one Saturday night we decided forget it, let's just put our names in and saunter over to a nearby bar for the inevitable hour & half wait. And we were seated in 20 minutes -- so what that reservation thing is all about I don't know.  UPDATE: now I *do* know what the reservation thing was all about. One of the owners just let me in on the fact that they are primarily a walk-in restaurant, so take few reservations and only for larger parties. This is why I love Yelp! Thanks for the info, Anjan. I'll be back, because ...

What I DO know is I have found my new favorite food. I can't believe the reviewers who said the dosas were flat and chewy -- I guess a total difference in tastes because I found the dosas to be yummy with an interesting blend of flavors, I loved the sauces, and I can't wait to go back to sample all the different kind of dosas on the menu. The server was also helpful in directing us through the menu as first timers, and the service was incredibly prompt. I'm a fan!
author: Phoebe H.

description:
The food was great, 5 stars for Indian food.  No sick, oily feeling later because the food was really, really good.

I ordered a *nice* glass of wine and received a very small pour-- half a normal pour.  My choice was more expensive than the others at our table and no one else had this "problem" with their lesser wines.  

This doesn't seem like good practice to me.  At first I thought my judgment was wrong but later in our long meal I ordered a second.  It too, was very small.

As I held it up and really looked at it skeptically, one of my dining companions asked if I ordered a half glass.  At that moment, a waitress retrieved the glass "If we could just take that back and finish pouring...."    

I appreciated that with my stink eye they corrected this mistake but I still paid full price for that first half pour.  i was with a large group of work people & did not feel comfortable bringing this up with the waitstaff-- "Hey, do you remember that first glass I asked for?  That one was small too!!!"  I left feeling nonplussed although the food was fabulous.
author: Megan G.

description: "Spring Masala Dosa" is the BEST indian meal I have ever had. Period.
author: Petka C.

description: I was pleased with my first DOSA experience, but subsequent dinners have brought me to the conclusion that the quality is not consistent.
author: Raven K.

description:
I thought Dosa was just OKAY. 
Here are my thoughts: 
*We were told the wait would be 1/2 hour, but we waited for over an hour. Which is excusable since it was a Friday. 
*More important than the wait, I was just a little disappointed with the food itself. I guess it was over-hyped and under-delivered for me. 
Apps
