Samosas- nothing special, but not badly made either. 
Prawn chile fry -wasn't horrific, but a little too salty. 
Dinner 
spring dosa with sambar- the potatoes in the dosa were lacking on spice for my taste. The sambar was pretty good though- a little thicker than others I have tried. 
-the best part of the meal was when I asked the waiter for something spicy to put in my food, he brought out a mango habanero chutney. It was SUPER spicy and I loved it, even though I was sweating.
author: Jodi S.

description: Yumyumyumyumyum with a little bit of yum. Try the sinful trish drink. Lamb curry. Tomato chili uttapam any dosa.... creepy manager kept staring at me tho... whatev.
author: Miranda L.

description: Dosa offers interesting, tasty cuisine in a pleasant atmosphere, with attentive help staff for a reasonable price. Fun for Sunday brunch.
author: Nicky D.

description: This is my favourite Indian restaurant in the city! Awesome for Sunday brunch.
author: Elcin E.

description: When my friend said vegan restaurant, a bunch of images crossed through my mind- lil frou frou servings, salad w/ a drizzle of vinagrette. But INDIAN vegan is a completely different. Its full of potatoes, carrots, curry sauce, and a HUGE dosa (equivalent to a giant tortilla). With different dipping sauces ranging from tangy to hearty, each bite is a new flavor. Mango mimosa was awesome. Service is friendly and they refill your water constantly as if you're in NYC. Food was brought out w/in 10 minutes of ordering. Pricey for lunch but worth every dollar.
author: Thomas L.

description: Tried Habenaro Masala Dosa here. It is insanely hot, but exciting if you have the guts to take it on.
author: Mak J.

description:
Don't underestimate how hard it is to get a table at Dosa: Four of us tried to walk in and eat here a couple of weeks ago, and gave up. Trying to work within the system, we gathered up 2 more friends -- Dosa takes reservations for groups of 5 or more -- and emailed early the next week to get a table. After 3 days without a response, I called and left voicemail. A very sweet woman called me back and apologized for the problem, and found us a table at the time we wanted. 

Needless to say, my expectations ran pretty high after all of this rigamarole. Largely, I think they were met. The food is interesting, tasty, flavorful without being incendiary, and thoughtfully presented. Service was crisp but a little stand-offish, and our server was very helful when it came time to figure out what (and how much) to order -- once we asked. 

I was really pleased with how reasonable the prices were. For less than $45 per person, including tax and tip, we had 2 bottles of wine and a handful of beers, plus a ton of food. Our order included a refreshing chickpea salad, a pair of appetizers -- crispy-spicy potato croquets and lush lentil dumplings -- three dosai (paneer, egg, and rava masala), and two of the curries: a deeply spiced Tamil lamb, and a prawn coconut masala... oh, and a giant bathura. Each dosa came with its own bowl of sambar, plus two smooth chutneys: a gingery coconut one and a spicy tomato version. Needless to say, we didn't have room for dessert, although I was tempted by the cardamom ice cream.

On the downside: The tables are awfully close together, the noise level is out of hand, the decor is warm but a tad bit stark -- some art on the walls would help. Worst of all, the hordes of drooling, hovering patrons (staring daggers while you try to enjoy dinner) is really, really annoying. The hosts were letting people hang out in the dining area, not just the bar, and I found that extremely inappropriate.

If I could make a reservation for a party of 2 or 4, or better yet, walk in on a weeknight with a reasonable expectation of a table becoming available within the space of a leisurely cocktail, I'd become a regular. But given the hassle factor, I can't imagine it being more than an occasional thing. I hope that once things calm down a bit, the owners might consider opening at least a few tables to reservations, while leaving the majority open for walk-ins.
author: anita c.

description:
The food was very good and the service wasn't bad, the experience is a good deal richer than one might typically be used to from your average 'do-it-yourself' Indian restaurant.

Dishes are elegantly presented and use high quality ingredients.  If you want tasty Indian food in a real restaurant presentation, stop by Dosa.
author: Eric M.

description:
I wouldn't go so far to say this is the best South Indian food that's out there.  As a South Indian, born in Mysore, I know first-hand how good a Mysore masala dosa, made in Mysore, tastes, BUT, DOSA does a pretty good job of creating a wonderful space to introduce some pretty delicious entrees.

The restaurant:  Love the design.  For a small venue, they've done a great job of making the atmosphere inviting and warm.  I think the earthy paint color is gorgeous.

The staff:  Very friendly and attentive.

The food:  Looks like art.  It's not one of those restaurants where presentation outshines palatability, the food in DOSA actually looks and tastes good.  I would recommend the South Indian Moons uttapam or the rava dosa, both are fantastic.

Wait:  I think for dinner it's harder to find a table.  For lunch it's great.  We were a party of 3 on a Sunday afternoon and had no problem getting seated.  I've dined at DOSA for dinner twice before and had to wait about half an hour.  If you have to wait, it's worth the wait.
author: Swetha G.

description: Paneer and peas is my favorite.  We also had:  paper masala - nice presentation; pepper chicken - didn't know peppercorn could be so spicy; mushroom and fingerling potato curry.
author: Elsie D.

description:
Lots of hype, the food is disappointing, bland baby food like although dosa itself was ok.  No coconut chutney with dosa.  Wha??????? 

I love Indian food especially southern indian food and have eaten at many places.  This is the least impressive Indian cooking and it's just unjust this place probably makes tons of money serving painfully mediocre food because they like to light up couple of candles and some people are sucker for that sort of stuff. 

Very over priced.  Yuppi Indian place. BORING!!!!  You have to order / pay for the rice separately.  That is just lame and annoying. I will never go back the
author: Suze W.

description: The food here is consistently really good. But, I'm giving a low rating because of the horribly rude service. I know this place is popular. It's been popular for a long time. So popular, for so long, in fact, that they've made enough money to open a fabulous space on Fillmore Street. Great. Good for them. Congratulations!!! But, that doesn't mean customers don't matter anymore. We (customers) are still people. We're humans. And, we matter. Its through us that they achieved such prosperity and it's through us that they will either flourish or perish in the future. No business deserves to exist when they treat customers with contempt, arrogance, and outright hostility as has become the norm at this place.
author: Eater S.

description:
We went there on a Saturday night without reservation and had to wait 30 mins. I love the bar area and the music they played.However, the seating area is very crowded. 
I would give the food here a 4 star. The dosa's were done very creatively. My mom had the chola bautura which was great as well.
author: S S.

description:
I should have "borrowed" a menu because I have no idea what I ordered now, but everything was so flavorful and tasty.  My friend and I went on a Monday night, which means that they have a selection of tapas-like dishes.  The one that we ordered was so light, lovely, and refreshing with the yogurt and dill.

Otherwise, we had an incredible vegetable curry, served up with puffed up poori.  We also ordered this crepelike dish filled with onions, which came with some tasty and spicy condiments.  

I will definitely have to hit this restaurant again and pay attention to what I was eating...I loved the food (which wasn't too heavy compared to a lot of Indian restaurants), the ambiance was simple & elegant, the service was attentive, and I thoroughly enjoyed my dining experience!
author: Evelyn K.

description:
Hells yes we will pull up some chairs at this bar and grub!  My Sister and I had just left a benefit for La Cocina and after being suffocated by the crowds and squeezed out of tasty small bites we were HUNGRY! 

We walked the neighborhood trying to find a place to nosh.  Berretta, always a favorite, was packed to the gills and the girls hadda eat stat.  We cruised up past Dosa and even though it too was packed, we spied two people leaving the bar.  After some quick karate type moves we were seated and sipping beer and some white wine.  

We loved the atmosphere of the restaurant. Somehow they have managed to make it seem lively and full without making you feel like you were jammed in like sardines.  The lighting was perfect, just low enough to disguise all blemishes.  

We started with the jicima salad with chili dressing and pecans, very tasty but also VERY SPICY. Make sure you have an alcoholic beverage with this.  Then we moved onto the prawn curry and the masala dosa, very very yummy!  I was particularly moved by the coconut rice that accompanied the prawns. Also, there was no skimping here, we each were STUFFED by the end of the meal.  

I found the Dosa to be interesting but not quite as stellar as the curry dish.  Perhaps I need to return and try one of the dosa's with different ingredients inside....

All in all a very pleasant experience, super food coma afterwards but not quite as severe as your standard indian experience. I will definitely be back, and next time with a bigger appetite!
author: Claire C.

description:
Yuuuuuummmmm! 

A love of Indian food, I prefer it homemade so don't eat it out at all. This place is a winner. Will go back.

1) Specialty drinks
2) Fresh ingredients, nothing soaked for days
3) Vegetarian
4) Great, great service
author: Michelle S.

description:
I've enjoyed NYE dinner at Dosa twice now and visited on various other occasions. The food here is as beautiful as it is delicious, although you'll enjoy it lots more if you have a decent tolerance for spice.

The chutneys are amazing across the board, although the habanero-mango one is pretty lethal (yet somehow still tastes great). The sambar that comes with each dosa is flavorful and fresh, as are the dosas themselves; I've never had anything bland or boring-tasting here. There's always a number of vegetarian options, although if you're vegan or lactose-intolerant, watch out for cheese or cream in many of them. The servers are generally fabulous and happy to offer (good) advice if you're unsure what to get. The restaurant is lovely, if smallish, and with the high ceilings, it does get noisy and a tad claustrophobic when it's full. So it's probably better suited for groups of 4 or fewer - if you bring your entire extended family, you won't be able to hear anyone. Then again, there are worse things than eating amazing food while prentending not to hear your aunt Bertha's complaints.
author: Xenia L.

description:
I'm updating my original review. I was here on Saturday night with a friend visiting from DC. Super fast service, friendly waitress, and although I wasn't that hungry and just ordered the Rasam, I'm aware the anything I've ever ordered here has been fantastic - South Indian Moons, Onion Pakora and that dosa with the eggplant paste is to die for! 

Owner is super friendly and our waitress helped us pick a killer wine to go with our food.  Cheers Anjuman for getting me to add another star!

10/26/2008 - My fiance took me here for my birthday, and we ordered the Vegetarian curry with coconut rice...the rice was something to write home about, we took one to go! =)
author: Bhumika K.

description:
First, I'm not a fan of Indian food.  I try and keep an open mind, but I just accept it now.  I just find the food a little heavy for me, and it induces a post-meal food-coma on par with the annual turkey induced tryptophan slumber.

We had a dosa, soup, curry.  All was yummy.  After the meal, I tried to resist the oncoming coma with a trip across the street to ritual coffee roasters.  Didn't help.

I liked Dosa.  It was good.  But I could not keep from comparing it to so many of the Indian places in the south bay, which I think are just as good,  but without all the trendy atmosphere and hype.
author: Ken and Yuri Q.

description:
I am always seeking South Indian food--dosa and such.  Yum.
This place was good and I loved my dosa.  But, the drinks are overpriced and I find it hard to justify waiting over an hour for a table when there are so many other good Indian places in the city, South Indian or not.
Plus, there's the hipster factor, which gets old....fast.
author: Jessica L.

description:
This place really deserves 3.5 stars from me.  My wife and I came early one evening, without reservations, in the middle of the week.  We were seated promptly.  But by the time we left the place was packed.  

The ambiance was really nice.  Definitely a great date place.

The service was really good.  Our waiter was quite knowledgeable about the wines and paired them well with our meal.  When I glanced over and saw him also working the bar, I guess it made total sense.

The food was tasty, though I have to say the dosa itself was a little on the dry side.

And there lies the rub.  We could go to the East Bay and get a better dosa for literally 1/5th to 1/8th the price.  The two of us spent about $100.  What you're paying for is the better service and atmosphere.

There's nothing wrong with that.  Like I said, if you're looking for a good date spot, go here.  The food is great, but you can find just as good dosa's elsewhere.
author: Ben C.

description:
Went there for the first time on Friday with a friend.  We had to wait 25 minutes to get a table, but it was worth it.  Our waitress was excellent...  Though we had problems hearing her cause of all the noise in the restaurant.

But I had probably the most delicious soup I ever had...  Spicy Soup I think is what it was called.  And exactly what I was looking for.  I was a touched underwhelmed by the main course...  But still very good.

You are paying for the great service and atmosphere.  So with that, I don't think the food is overly priced.  It's definitely someplace you go for a nice night out.
author: R G.

description:
Went here for the first time Sunday night, lured in by the delicious aromas and the promise of South Indian food, which is sorely absent in San francisco.  

Yum.  The boy and I split the paneer and romaine salad, which was seriously one of the tastiest salads ever.  Very simple, but ooh, I want one right now: grilled cubes of paneer, slivers of incredibly flavorful, tart tomato, and a perfectly balanced garlic dressing.    He got the South Indian Moons (5 different uttapam), I got the basic Masala Dosa.  So good.  A crispy, flavorful crepe and lovely chutneys in which to dip it.  I got a glass of  the Malbec, which went really well with the spicy lentil soup/dip.  

All in all: good service, good atmosphere, super-tasty food.
author: claire l.

description:
Everything is AWESOME: the food, the drinks, the service, the ambiance. Fabulous!
____________________________

A "regular" brought me there the first time. VIP access to a table, warm and efficient service, great food, good wine... 

For my second visit I unfortunately had to wait (and freeze) on the sidewalk. The service was still friendly, but with that little "pushy" twist as if to say "hurry up, other clients are waiting on the sidewalk...". 

The curried lamb is awesome (I loved it so much the first time, I couldn't help but order it again), the dosa is so big you could wrap yourself in it and the wine selection is more than OK.

Bottom line: Better go there with a VIP, but if you can't you'll get a great dinner.
author: Lili G.

description:
Math:
1 dosa + 1 appetizer = 2 satisfied stomachs
1 dosa + 1 dosa = 2 full stomachs
(2 x dosa) + 1 appetizer = 2 full stomachs + 1 doggie bag

Better:
Mysore Masala Dosa (Get this one! You're welcome.)

Good:
Paneer & Peas Dosa (not as tasty as above. Creamier, but above's creamy enough)

OK:
Cochin Calamari (soft, need to order bread for dipping)
author: David G.

description:
One severely under dressed day last spring, Alice and stumbled upon this place while looking for some other place to brunch that we couldn't find.

Over $60 dollars and two hours later, we emerged still really under dressed, but very impressed and delighted with the spicy fruit salad, the Sula Indian Chenin Blanc (a first for me), and an awakened respect for the crepe-like dosa.  Yummy.
author: Dee I.

description:
I was excited to try Dosa, I love Indian food and I was looking forward to trying the southern style - and nice change from the usual tikka masala and naan. But, to state the truth - I walked away feeling underwhelmed. 

Service: 4
For my party of two we had a short wait (about 10 minutes on a Wednesday night). Our waiter was pleasant and fairly attentive - no complaints here. 

Space: 2
The restaurant itself is "cozy" - you can't get out of your bench seat without moving your table to one side or the other to create more space (read: fat people can't sit on the bench side) and the music consisted of pop tunes. I have no idea why the music bothered me. I guess it just made everything seem more Americanized - I prefer a more "ethnic" experience beyond Gwen Stefani perhaps?

Food: 3
The organic greens, mango and goat cheese salad blew my socks off. It was crazy good. Maybe a tad bit too sweet to have for your whole meal but as a shared dish it was simply divine. The rest of the food was blah - we tried the dosa, which basically seemed like samosa filling with a thin, crispy crepe around it it was ok but generally flavorless. Next we had the South Indian Moons, the chef's pick of five different Uttapams (a Indian pancake with food baked in). Of all five, we only liked one. I felt like I could make these at home just like pancakes with tomatoes or cheese thrown in, sauce on the side. My "Lychee Lush" cocktail was decent but the piece of lychee in it looked like a butt and made me feel just sick for drinking it. 

Conclusion: I'd go back if I had friends that wanted to go but I wouldn't suggest it myself.
author: Allison B.

description:
I took a vegitarian friend of mine to this restaurant. This place is very cute, and has good service and atomosphere. Although I am not vegitarian, it was very filling. Uttapan (pancake dosa thing) sampler plate was great, but one of them was really spicy. Vegitable curry had great flavor and not too spicy. 
You can get as great food at a restaurant on 16th (Packwan?) for1/2 the price, but I like this place better.
author: Mika G.

description:
I love that I love Indian food.  I feel so bad for the people who are missing out on these amazing flavor combinations, heats, and textures.  THANKS, TASTE BUDS!

A group of 10 of us wanted to make reservations for a Friday night dinner (reservations only for large parties) and had to settle for a 9:30 time slot.  Thankfully it was early September and was crazy warm while we waited outside for an extra..... 45 minutes.... boo.  This place is really small and really crowded and really loud.  Good thing we were all sitting so close together!  The food was EXCELLENT and left me very satisfied (that's what she said.  (the Office comes back this week - yay!))  

I ordered the paneer and peas dosa - yum yum.  Nice amount of heat and great flavor.  It was a really big serving and came with like a lentil dipping soup and some other chutneys... I remember liking the mango one best.  We also split a bottle of white that our waitress suggested - something from India... quite refreshing and went very well with all the food.  The other half of the table split a bunch of apps and other dishes and were moaning all over themselves about how good the food was.  

Service was a little spotty - so minus one star.  It was so freakin packed in there, though.... wow.
author: Laura B.

description: I wasn't a big fan...the tables are all squished together making you feel cramped and uncomfortable, the service was bad and they made us feel inferior somehow...very weird feeling at a restaurant.  I've eaten in many nice restaurants and never felt so awkward with stuck up servers that weren't very attentive.  The food was not that great either; we won't go back.
author: GranolaGorilla Z.

description:
It was a weekend and busy but the service was fast. I loved all of the food ordered on our table. Very tasty and on the spicy side which i enjoyed.

It would have been more helpful if our server informed us the level of spiciness on what we ordered coz most of my friends didn't enjoy their meals due to the fact that they had to drink sips of water in between bites - they didnt expect the level of heat in their dishes. Had the waiter explained this, it would have been avoided. 

The dessert we ordered was so-so, i just dont see myself eating "rose flavored" treats. I would still give the other stuff on the menu a chance.
author: duane a.

description:
Maybe I'm easily impressed, but this place was fantastic!  The food was exceptionally delicious, the service was top-notch, and the ambience lovely.  It could just be that I'm a sucker for Southern Indian food, which I'd never had before, It could be because there was cilantro (which I despise) in the food, but the flavors were so well balanced that I couldn't taste it.  It could be that every aspect of the service was pleasing.  It could be that the great table we had, right by the open window (on an evening with perfect weather) made me giddy with love for San Francisco in the Spring.

Whatever it was, I'm going with it, and anointing Dosa one of my top-ten favorite restaurants.
author: Freeman F.

description:
Tasty, competently prepared Indian food at reasonable prices in a sleek space, but an utter mob scene.

The lamb curry was good, as was the prawn coconut dish, and a lentil dumpling appetizer was the star of the night. But the signature dosas blended together -- we had three at our table and I couldn't tell one from the next.

It seems unfair to criticize a restaurant for being popular, but I can't see returning until the buzz dies down. Waiting an hour for a table in an overcrowded room that is so loud I have to yell to carry on a conversation isn't my idea of fun. Kudos to the friendly and polite table staff, considering the working environment -- I can't imagine trying to explain a new cuisine 10 or 15 times a night in that din.
author: Cameron C.

description:
The South Indian version of Slanted Door.

I really enjoy the dosas, breads, and the crepe-like dishes like the uttapam.  In case you did not know, a dosa is a south indian crepe that you eat with your hands.  It's nothing like the crepes at Ti Couz or Magic Pan.

The meat dishes (which are probably not South Indian dishes anyway) are only slightly above average.  Fun atmosphere and a good place to sit back, drink, and experience a different type of cuisine.

By far, the coolest and slickest Indian restaurant in SF.
author: Zk K.

description:
I've been here twice and on the first visit I'd give two stars, and the second four. 

The first time the wait was horrible, I had a chai at the bar which wasn't so good, the food was just okay, the noise level was crazy high because I'm sure there were more people here than the bus during rush hour. I suppose I was let down due to some of the hype, but frankly because I've had much better dosas elsewhere. 

The second time the food was better (some of the dips were less watery), the service was more attentive given less people there, but it still didn't do it for me. I like that they have a broad selection of food, that has a good price tag, but I wouldn't write home about it.
author: Emily A.

description:
This place is definitely trendy.. .and the service is pretty good. we went with a group of 10 and it took us FOREVER to figure out what we want.. should we share, should we not share..  they told us that u probably shouldnt share.. who knows.. 

The food is Southern Indian, and consists of Dosa's which are traditional crepes..   I had the Mysore Dosa.. and  by the way, there are NO samosa's here and NO naan. so don't go there asking for that. 

;)

I'm not sure I would go back, but it's an interesting difference from the Northern style.
author: j d.

description:
EDIT: i forgot to mention that on another occasion i got a glass of white wine from the bar and it was delish! the bartender was very nice too. 

on a random tuesday night after yoga i was there and it was packed. the crowd was loud and the food was good.

our server was super nice and made some thoughtful, if not to my liking, recommendations. those big pieces of flat bread are salty salty salty.

great to go to with 2-3 friends. not sure if it would be the best option for a group.
author: Kenna T.

description:
No wait for two on a Monday night after we cruised by Maverick and got denied (40% off wine Mondays, who'd guess?).

The food was very well done.  We had two dosas between us, the paneer and peas dosa and the spring dosa.  Before we could both wash our hands, the food appeared on the table.  Presto!  Which leads me to my next point.. without the masala sauce and chutneys, there was something missing.  I couldn't place my finger on it until it was pointed out that the fillings were a bit cool and mushed together.  "Homogeneous" is a charitable word to use.  I felt like the $11 dosas had been sitting under a heat lamp just waiting for us, and that's not enjoyable.

The service was prompt and subtle, and the beer/wine selections were extensive and appropriate.  Perhaps we got a bum batch of dosa, and perhaps I'm spoiled, but I think they missed the mark a bit given the market Dosa aims for.
author: K M.

description:
We were brought there by our Indian friend and her Indian-in-heart boyfriend, so this place must be totally legit.   I must admit I know nothing about Indian food and I don't remember when last time I had it.  But like I said, we had guidance to the menu.  

For starters, we had Cochin Calamari.  It was really tasty and I like when calamari is grilled, not fried.  They also shared Onion Pakora, which I didn't try because I don't like onions.

For entrees, I had a South Indian Moon Uttapam.  Uttapam is basically like your naan, but more sophisticated.  I loved mine.  I love anything that's naan-like, and my dish came with uttapam of different flavors.  I wasn't sure if the two rather large bowls on the plate were dipping sauce or meant to be eaten as independent dishes.  For dipping sauce, there is far too much of it for the 5 pieces of uttapam you get.  And as an independent dish, I just couldn't take it as a wussy for spicy food.  I tried to spoon it into my mouth, but my eyes-watering, coughing reaction was way too embarrassing to share with even close friends. 

The Indian friend had the same dish as I did, which gave me even more confidence in my choice. The two guys had dosa.  If you like thin, crispy dough, I suggest dosa.  Different style, equally tasty. 

The portion isn't large.  But I have developed a new philosophy in 2008 on restaurants: I think it's better to leave a little hungry and wanting more than to go home feeling stuffed and uncomfortable. 

And it was surprisingly easy to get a table on a Friday night despite the location and popularity of the place.  We walked in and got a table.  But that was probably just luck.  Oh, and try to sit in the back because in these brutal SF winter nights, we were freezing every time the door opened because we sat next to the bar.
author: Candice B.

description:
We came here with my husband's coworkers. I have never had anything quite like it. The dosa is delicious. We had a pretty large table so we got to try a variety of things. I wish my stomach could have fit more, but I tried my best. I'm going have to come back for the rest!

Updated: I went there last night with some friends. We had: 
Chennai Chicken - moist and tender but a bit pricey for the amount
Prawn Chile Fry - spicy and delish
Dahi Vada - I liked the creamy lentil dumplings and the sauce. I could go for more dumpling and less sauce though.
Tamil Lamb Curry - tender, flavorful, and delicious
Paper Masala - I wasn't that impressed with this dish. It's somewhat like a thin crepe with a side of curry potato salad. The other dosas I've had here are better.
South Indian Moons - The mini pancakes were not that impressive but I really liked the chutneys that they came with. I wish there were more pancakes to scoop up the rest of the chutney.
Rasmalai  - This and the lamb curry were my favorite. I love the flavor and texture of this cheese. It's kind of like pieces of fresh mozzarella soaked in this sweet creamy sauce. I loved it!
author: Diana S.

description:
Never had dosa before, but now that I have (and twice!), I'll never be the same.  All I knew was Dosa was an uber-trendy Mission Indian restaurant - possibly overrated.

For me, it's now still pretty trendy, but right on the money with the food too.  You have to understand that I'm so totally over crepes as creative cuisine - everyone's been there and done that (plus pesto and artichokes), but THESE are crepes I can still respect.  Mmm...you tasty little thin crepes filled with gooey, spiced goodness.  You're so delicious...yes, you are!  Yes, you are!

One dosa's a great portion-size for me - huge but fairly thin, and it comes with the best sambar I've ever had.  I LOVE LENTILS.  Very odd quirk of mine, but it's true.  And I could slurp the sambar here for daaays.

As for other food, I've tasted a really wonderfully-spiced veggie curry here, and probably the only near-miss for me has been the rack of lamb curry (nice with the lemon rice but nothing to write home about since the lamb was a little too tough).  Service is great and personal, especially for such a cramped, crowded space.  Great place to enjoy good food and pretend to be cool.
author: Christina H.

description:
I've been here twice and now and wow, i'm a fan.  We had the dosa's of course. They all came with all these great dipping sauces and chutneys. All soooo tasty, some spicy, some creamy......Not too many meat dishes, but we had the Chennai Chicken, totally moist morsels. Who knew that a menu with extremely mininal meat dishes could be so amazing??!! 
One thing though, we had the Organic Greens, Mango & Goat's Feta salad. I could've made this at home.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Very good food and excellent service. We started with the South Indian Mung Sprouts ($9). Basically a lentil salad - very refreshing but watch out for the chilis. My first bite was a big one and I didn't look for chilis. My tongue was on fire until I doused it with the Sinful Crush ($8), sort of like a Mohito.

I was more concerned about my drink so my husband ordered the Mysore Dosa ($10.50) and some sort of curry with chicken. Both dishes were delicious but make sure you wash those hands because you'll be getting into the dosa with your fingers.

Our friends both got an order each of the Paper Masala ($11). Man was that dosa humoungous! It was about as long as the table if not longer rolled into a tube. First time I saw or ate anything like it. 

I think what I like most is that you can get a unique dish (dosa) in a cool atmosphere. Even at the end when we were coveting a much wanted table and were lingering 15 minutes after we paid our check, no one was rude about getting the us out of there.
author: Wendy B.

description:
After reading glowing reviews about this place, I was excited to finally try it with hubby this weekend. Since this place only takes reservations for parties of 5 or more, hubby and I went for an early dinner (esp. after reading about the ridiculous long waits here). 

The waitress recommended the tasting course, which runs $40 a pop and gets you an appetizer, dosa, entree, and desert. Being first-timers to South Indian cuisine, hubby and I opted for this option. 

While the food was above average, the portions that come with the prefixe menu were paltry. The dinner definitely was not worth the total bill of over $100 we paid for our meals (and from what I can tell, not worth the crazy wait some people are willing to put up with to have some dosa).
author: Sandy Y.

description:
The food was pretty tasty, but the service was really pretty bad.  We showed up and they told us it would be 20 minutes until we'd be seated.  40 minutes later, we were still waiting for a table...no apologies, nothing.  When they finally seated us, I was expecting a little something to compensate, nope.  Instead they forgot to bring me my Lassie (oddly enough something I had read about from another Yelp reviewer literally just before we ate there!)  I had to ask for it three times before it finally arrived!

Our waitress was really nice and helpful in navigating the menu, but the main host/manager guy was really rude.  He actually came over and condescendingly explained that I was eating my dosa incorrectly!

I would recommend going on Monday nights when they're serving Chaat. That was the highlight of our meal by far.  Oh, and dessert was pretty nasty...tasted like pure corn syrup.
author: Kimberly G.

description:
Good food, a good wine list and overall a good dining experience. Also, they use fresh and organic produce, free range chicken and lamb and sustainably-caught fish. Ofcourse, all this comes for a price (including the long wait). 

If you are looking for a quick (and cheap) south indian bite, go to Udupi next door. Stay here if you want to eat like the French...a nice long meal with high quality ingredients.
author: Paawan K.

description:
It's been exciting to watch various foods come into their own in San Francisco in recent years, two prime among them being pizza and Southern Indian cooking. Dosa is a prime local for the latter. Aside from the quality of the produce, it's not clear why the dishes here cost two to three times what they would at any other Indian joint, but everything we've had has been excellent, and the dosa-dipping instructions on the menu are appreciated. The wait staff doesn't always know what's in a given dish, and rather than ask back in the kitchen has just done the smug "I'm enlightened, you're not" thing, but hey, at least the food's really good. 

Worth the wait, as there's always a line. 

Chaat only on weekends and, I think, Monday night?
author: OuterLands X.

description:
Fusion South Indian food.  Why fuse?  Ah, to fuse, or not to fuse.  

Sometimes fusion takes two different things and combines them to make something better.  The whole is more than the sum of its parts.  Or so they say.

Sometimes fusing two things makes things worse.  That's the way the cookie crumbles.  As the saying goes.

In this case, Dosa does an ok job of the fusing.  Here is how Dosa does the fuse: they start with authentic dishes, and (sometimes) add random little fusies in there.  Fusies may be cheese, or spring vegetables.  The results are mixed.  Sometimes the fused food tastes good, sometimes not good.  Such is life.

But there is hope: the core, the heart, the meat and the flesh of the menu is authentic; and good.  Who would have thought!  Authenticity can be fancy.  And it can be good.  The masala dosa, mysore masala dosa, the uttapams (try the 5 moons to get a sampling), the sambar or channa that come with.  

These things are good.  Hence the goodness of the rating.
author: Vishal K.

description:
To make the long story shot...... Amazingly courteous and very fast service that had us out of there in 15 minutes after a tasty and satisfying meal.

Now for the long story.......

This was my first visit to Dosa on Valencia. The place was full at 1:30 PM on Saturday July 24, 2010 and so my daughter and I came back at 3:00 PM when the crowd had thinned. We were seated promptly but after waiting a while with no one paying any attention we decided to head out as we were in a hurry.

On the way out the Manager of the restaurant request the reason for us leaving and I explained to him that we were in a hurry and since they seem to be busy we needed to go. 

He was extremely polite and apologized for the delay in services. His words were, "Give me a second chance... I hate seeing a customer leave without being served", and promised a quick meal if we knew exactly what we wanted. Being South Indian that was easy. 

One plate of Medhu Vada
One plate of Paper Masala Dosa
One Sweet Mango Lassi

He promised the Vada would be on our table in 2 mins and the Dosa would be another 2 mins. He was true to his promise and we were out of there by 3:30 PM

The food was the best I have tasted in a long time!!!! Kudos to the manager and staff of the restaurant for not giving up and delivering on their promise. 

You have a Dosa fan!!!!
author: Laks S.

description: There is something so soothing about eating at Dosa.  They  focus on fresh, local and organic ingredients. I love the panner and peas dosa served with tomato and coconut chutney as well as dhal.  Unlike most Indian restaurnts you leave feeling satisified not stuffed.
author: Danielle M.

description: Ehh, I'd rather eat at Udupi or Kasa.  I don't know what all of the chatter is about.
author: M M.

description: Particularly good place to introduce people to Southern Indian Food. Order a mix of curries and creative dosas.
author: Laela S.

description:
So anybody that knows me knows that when I'm really really hungry I am not a force to be reckoned with. I will tear you apart. So Dosa may be suffering from "Tara's lack of food" Syndrome. It's an epidemic. 

Granted, we got there pretty late on a Friday night, so I should have brought a snack with me in anticipation. We waited sooo long, and when we finally sat, it wasn't even our "table", we lucked out and got seats at the bar (about an hour and a quarter in). Who knows how much longer the table would have taken. Happy camper I was not. 

But generally long lines just mean grrrreat food. I went with the boy, who is South Indian (Bangalore what!) and he was excited to see other Indians waiting for tables with us. But we were both surprised that when the food came he was underwhelmed (I thought it was pretty tasty, but I've never had dosas before, so I'm a horrible judge) We were also weirded out to see that nobody working there had a hint of Indian descent, which I think made the boy feel even weirder about the food.

The ambiance of this place is awesome though, and sitting at the bar was fun. I thought the food was good, so if you're not a dosa aficionado (and don't have a grandma's recipe to compare to) then you probably won't be disappointed. Just bring a preemptive long wait snack.
author: Tara O.

description:
Dosa is by far my favorite Indian restaurant in the city. They make the most yummy South Indian food, its spicy and innovative, and the place has great ambiance (especially for a south indian place - If you've been to one - you'll know what I'm talking about). 
 I love their spicy mung dal dosa, corriander and chillie uttapam, onion rava masala dosa and their chennai chicken is to die for. 
 The only con about the place is the long wait times. I've had a couple of bad experiences there with waits, but the owner's been wonderful about buying us free drinks the next time to make it up to us. What can I say - Dosa rocks!
author: Namita G.

description: i've been there once....the wait on a tuesday nite was pretty long.....alothough that place is pretty small.....we ordered some dishes and it was pretty good, but pricey.  Overall the atmosphere is pretty good, but it might be difficult to look for parking around that area.  I wouldn't want to go there again because there's not much special about that place
author: C L.

description:
Went to Dosa last night after hearing about all the hype about how 'wonderful' it was how it was a 'top restaurant' etc. etc. etc.

If you can judge a restaurant by its service, then the reviews are true.  Although I'm not behind this 'no reservations' policy (look, man, I can plan where I'm going to be and what time, even if other people can't) I do think the staff do everything possible to make the process as painless as possible.  The bartender looked like he was scanning for snipers, he was so on top of everyone's drink needs.  People would just turn towards the bar, and he'd have a drinks menu in their hand!  If you got low on a glass, he'd ask you if you wanted more.  None of that 'excuse me, bartender' nonsense you get from 'hip' places.  (NB. When did it become 'hip' to be rude?)

So having finally gotten our seats, (and yes, we're so close to everyone, I can hear the guy at the next table explaining to his date why he and his Dad don't see each other much, even though his Dad lives 10 miles away), we made the critical mistake of not ordering our food when the waitress took our drinks order.  Apparently, this is a major faux pas at Dosa, for which we were punished by her taking the order of four other tables, ignoring our efforts to gain eye contact, to reel her back in.  She never forgave us for that indiscretion either, I would note.

So we do order. The drinks arrived.  The drinks are spilled.  This happens.  The server was very nice about it, offered to pay for cleaning (red wine, light colored shirt) but hey, that does happen, the shirt is a few years old, don't worry about it, and we were comped for our drinks.  Nothing beyond what I would have expected, but nothing less either.

Within minutes (less than 5, mind you) of ordering, the lentil doughnut as my husband calls it (Vada Sambar to the rest of us) arrives at the table.  Yummy, hearty, better suited for a colder day (my mistake, not theirs) but delicious.  We also ordered the Masala Dosa, which was very tasty, and the South Indian Moons.  This one is a little sample plate of each of the different types of Uttapam (the chile and corriander was the best) and this dish was the bomb.  Fantastic channa dal to go with it, spicy, but tasty.  Ummm, so yummy.

So overall, four stars.  Really terrific service (even with the red wine spilage), fantastic food, well chosen beverage list to accompany the food.  Now, if you could just arrange reservations, I might be willing to go up to 4 and a half....
author: Christina R.

description:
This trendy Indian/Pakistani restaurant in the heart of the Mission is certainly busy for a reason.  The food is as spicy as it gets, and served to share with the whole table. Spicey shrimp are to die for!! Lots of sauces for dipping, and every kind of flat bread you can think of. 

Don't show up between 7-8pm though because getting a table is nearly impossible, and the hostess will tell you 15 minutes, when that really means an hour.

If you like hot and spicey food with a fun and trendy ambiance, this is the place for you...just make sure you show up at 8:30pm.
author: Jessica W.

description:
A lot of people on Yelp really seem to love this place, and I can understand why, especailly if you're into what they do best- Idili, Sambar and Dosas.

I had never tried any South Indian fare of any sort.  But I don't discriminate, especially when it comes to food, so I made a reservation for 8:45 last night.

Too bad the only purpose my reservation served was basically their walk-in wait time cut in half, as opposed to the standard 45-60, we waited about 20 minutes for our table upon arrival. Boo. 

It's really cool that they have a bar, because most indian places in the city don't offer a really great cocktail selection with their naan and curry (another fine establishment). I had a glass of the Sula white wine, and it was really quite wonderful and not like any other white wine i'd tasted previously.

When we finally were seated, our service was efficient (check was a little slow though but it's cool), and our waitress was helpful and friendly. 

Now for the food- I don't really have anything to compare it to, seeing as this was my first brush with south indian fare. My friend that is into south indian fare  dug what she got, but it didn't 'blow her out of the water'.  We both order the masala dosa. I didn't hate it, but I definitely felt the same way- it wasn't the best thing I'd ever put in my mouth. 

I think the best thing we had were these crispy-crackery things that they give you instead of bread. Yum. My friends who got the Idili really enjoyed that as well.

So ultimately- it's a little pricey, you gotta wait despite reservations, but if you really wanna try it-- I'd say definitely go. At least once.
author: Amanda D.

description:
I love paper masala dosas.  I mean, I love Indian food in general, but I really love paper masala dosas.  And here, just for my benefit, is a whole restaurant devoted to making good dosas.

I must admit, I was a bit skeptical at first because the decor is so fancy/american (and there are pictures of Frida & Diego on the bathroom doors?), but Dosa does not disappoint.

Our dinner: we shared a paper masala dosa, some amazing mango curry with prawns over coconut rice, a citrusy white wine, and chai. 

Wow.  The paper masala dosa was not quite as crispy as I prefer, but still good.  And the mango curry was just the perfect amount of spiciness.  It's pricey, but oh so worth it - I'm heading back soon!
author: Maia B.

description:
First of all, go early as this place fills up quickly and it's on the cozy side for seating. 

Recommended Dishes:

Starter: (portion is small only comes with one idli and one vada), Flavor was good but not over the top I have to Yelp about this as soon as I get home type of good.  Eat it with the coconut chutney to balance out the spices.  
Idli Vada Sambar  
A combination of idli and vada served with Sambar and coconut chutney... 7 

Main Course I recommend:
South Indian Moons
The chef's selection of five different Uttapams served with sambar, channa (garbanzo beans) and chutney... 13.5
Very very NICE!  Thin, flavorful and a great way to sample the different Uttapams. Great side curries with this dish.

I didn't order the Dosa but I think you get a more authentic Dosa at Udupi in Sunnyvale for like half the price.  

Service: Great Waiter, very attentive and he explained how to eat everything even though I don' t think one needs much direction.
author: Mel S.

description:
The best thing about Southern Indian food is that it is not just overpowering curry but more delicate spices.  Dosa successfully accomplishes the subtle spices of Southern cuisine.

I have tried the dosas as well as appetizers, curries, desserts and coffee.  The entire dining experience here is superb.  Every dish is a little surprising.  Take, for example, the ice cream.  It is this super cold super frozen desert - and the texture and consistency is different from traditional ice cream.  This, like the overall Dosa experience, it is a step above, and surprises your pallet and expectations. The servers are generally very helpful and attentive.  Its a smaller and the seating is intimate.  The portions are not huge, so you can taste a few different dishes each time you go.

Don't expect your typical Indian restaurant experience at Dosa.  Instead, expect a surprising, delicate and delicious meal.  It is subtly different and intriguing amidst so many generic Indian restaurants.
author: Morgen N.

description:
The best thing about Dosa, minus the er-dosas, is the coffee. Thick, sweet, perhaps a dash of coconut milk, try it, the bloody mary, not so much... but unique.  

The hostess, I think Rebecca was her name, was professional, kind and got us to our table in no time. 

The Mysore Masala Dosa is great for a newbie, that or the Paper Dosa which may sound a little less exciting but believe me, is worth it. 

It is also worth it to check out Brunch because they have these little yogurt appetizer things that are great and the Uttapam sample platter is delicious. Oh also the coconut red sauce that they give you is awesome on... pretty much everything. 

NEWBIE NOTE: To save from oh-so-faux-pas Southern India embarrassment, the large brownish/red "sauce" they give you is actually soup, not for dipping.
author: Alex M.

description:
The Mission District is comparable to Williamsburg, Brooklyn - full of thrift shops and cafés, a pleasant mix of hipsters, artists, ethnic groups, and pretty much anyone who's up for some kind of "alternative" lifestyle, however you want to interpret that.  The neighborhood is slowly being referred to as "The Gourmet Ghetto" (the original Gourmet Ghetto is in Berkeley, CA), because of the surge of notable restaurants that have settled in the past few years; Bar Tartine, Tartine Bakery, Balompie Café, Delfina, Foreign Cinema, and Bi-Rite Creamery are just some of the restaurants I'm interested in.  I've already eaten at Range (see my blog entitled "Not so free Range"), Papalote, and Café Gratitude (blog entries in the works).  

Walking distance from my new apartment is Dosa, a south Indian restaurant that was recommended by at least half a dozen locals.  But when making plans to eat at Dosa, I was warned of the long wait for a table on any given night from the moment doors open.  Luckily, dining alone at 5:30pm on a Monday night is a surefire guarantee for a seat at the bar.  I'm not a huge fan of dining alone, but a good bartender can usually enhance the experience for single diners and offer some good conversation.  Planning to eat a lot of spice, I selected a glass of crisp Grüner Veltliner to round out the heat.

As one would expect with the name, dosa's make up a major part of the menu.  Typical South Indian fare, dosa's are thin, crispy crêpes made of rice and lentil batter and stuffed with various fillings.  My favorite is the traditional Masala dosa, filled with curried potatoes, fried onions and occasionally peas.  I opted to try something new and ordered an Uttapam, a slightly thicker version of a dosa, mixed with green chilies, onions and fresh cilantro.  The accompanying sauces and chutneys make the experience delightful because you can diversify each bite with spoonfuls of fresh coconut chutney, tomato chutney and sambar.  

Indian desserts are a far cry from Western desserts.  Ras Malai - a Pakistani and Indian dessert made of patties of paneer, a mild farmers cheese, which have been soaked in sweet cream and flavored with rosewater and crushed pistachios - was a refreshing and elating end to a light and flavorful meal.  On my next visit I will return with friends and try the tasting menu, a bargain at $39 for a four course meal, and hardly more expensive than my meal.
author: T. L.

description:
OK, the food here is amazing.  My favorites are the Dahi Vada, Chennai Chicken, and the Channa Bhutura.  I'm a hard core meat-eater, so I was shocked when I found out the Channa Bhutura was a vegan dish.  I mean, I really had to do some soul searching after that one.  

My only critique of this restaurant is that there is no central air, so on really hot days, if you sit in the back, you will sweat.  It gets really warm in there.  Trust me, and wear a t-shirt.  You have been warned!
author: Julie B.

description:
Definitely the place to try for South Indian food.  Dosas obviously are the things to try, and what makes this Indian restaurant different from others.

If you don't know, dosas are like large, light crepes, which are filled with different things, usually curries, and eaten with various kinds of sauces (or chutneys).  I've tried a few different kinds, and they've all been good.

The lamb curry is to die for.  Very tender, and quite spicy too.  So is the chicken curry.

Go with some friends, and order a bunch of things; appetizers, and some entrees, to really get a good selection of what Dosa has to offer.

The one minus is because the restaurant is so popular, it can be hard to get a table (even if you try to make a reservation) during normal dining hours (6-9pm).  I've usually gone for an early dinner, at 5:30, to avoid the crowds.
author: Ramon C.

description:
There really seems to be a dearth of south indian places in SF given its size.  Somebody told me about dosa but I remember the first time I walked by this place my instant reaction was - "There is way too many white people in there, this place can't be authentic!". Bigotted view, I know, but I still stood by it.

The only reason I finally ended up going was the fact that my folks were in town and my mother basically only eats indain cuisine. So, I took them there fully expecting to get basterdized versions of south indian dishes with hefty price tags.

To my surprise it turned out way better than I expected. The service may have been a bit slow but the masala dosa that I ordered was pretty good. The masala wasn't great but the dosa was really quite moist which I liked. The sambar was pretty good though I wasn't too impressed with the chutneys that came with the dosa (unfortunately not spicy enough for my palatte). 

My mother got the onion rava dosa which was one of the better dosas that I've had anywhere really. Normally the rava has way too much pepper in it but over here it was right on. 

We also ordered the dahi rice (rice with yogurt) and its nothing complicated to make but they had a nice touch with the onions and carrots which really rounded off the meal well. In addition, the whole thing didn't end up being that expensive. This place was much better than the only other south indian place I know in SF - Udupi which is just a block down on Valencia.

I'll go there again... I'd still like to find that cheap and grubby south indian place in SF but this will do as a substitute.
author: Krishnan S.

description: Mind you, my last visit was probably a year ago, but I'm still hankering to go back. Yum!
author: Amy R.

description: They are definitely one of the better Indian places in the city.  Idli Sambar is really good here and also I like the dosas of course.  It's a fun place with a cool atmosphere.  It can get kind of busy sometimes but they do have spaces on the bar which can open up.
author: Helga B.

description:
Update 7/21/06:  I've been back to Dosa twice since my initial visit.  Slowly Anjan and the yummy food have won me over.  The noise level is still a distraction so don't come for a romantic evening.  But I have tried a few other thing on the menu that are not so starch specific and I think balancing things out definitely made a difference.  Try the calamari or the chicken cube starters.  GREAT flavor and spice without making you choke down water.  And the Sambar.  All I can say is.. I would be perfectly happy to sit with a bowl of that and a dosa all by myself.  Dip away!

My girlfriend and I knew going in on a Friday night that a table would require a wait.  We occupied ourselves with a glass of wine at the bar and let time pass. No harm, no foul.

Once seated, we looked forward to our food. We started with the lentil dumplings, good.  But a bit heavy on sauce.  Moving on to their specialty dish, the Masala Dosa.  IMPRESSIVE.  It's huge!  And quite tasty. The accompanying chutneys were good but could have used a little more flavor.  We also had the chicken curry.  This is pretty basic and actually kind of low on sauce.  Overall I would've liked the Dosa more, but I was kinda lentiled out.

As it was our first visit, of course we had to try dessert.  Balls.  Milk Balls.  Stay away.  I almost had to spit it out cuz the syrup they came in was just toooo sweet.

Overall, it's a good neighborhood place, not too pricey. We even got a $27 bottle of Lindauer and the bill came to just $60.  I'm glad it's walking distance for me cuz I will probably go back. I wouldn't make a special trip across town for it.
author: Row M.

description:
I came here a few months ago and I had to admit I had a pleasant experience. The restaurant has a nice atmosphere. It's not too bright or too loud. The food was excellent. It tasted just right, so did the portion. The only thing, we ordered Palak Paneer and it wasn't what I expected. They came wrapped in crepes. A little bit different than what I used to, but I guess it was their specialty.

The customer service was good and I absolutely recommend to make a reservation to come to this place. We had one and we still had to wait quite a bit. 

Though I had a pleasant experience, I doubt that I will go back. There are many other cheaper good Indian restaurants.
author: Perry S.

description:
I've been obsessed with dosas lately, so it just seemed natural to gravitate towards this place. I went on a Sunday afternoon and expected to wait in line, which is what I always see at dinner time outside this place, but was pleasantly suprised by being able to walk right in and take a seat.

I ordered a Masala Dosa, which was amazing. I have been eating at several different restaurants that serve dosas, and the filling was by far the best I've had. The potato filling was heavily scented with aromatic spice and had been mashed to delectable moist perfection. It was, however, much smaller than I am used to and came with a pitifully small amount of coconut and tomato chutneys, especially for the price. The sambar was flavorful, but watery and lacked the addition of any vegetables. 
 
I probably would have left feeling satisfied, but a little cheated, except that the staff was apparently just not busy enough and decided that meant being aggressively over-helpful. I understand good service, but if I'm not engaging the staff in conversation, they usually get it that I want to eat in peace. 

The host that seated me might as well have just sat down at my table the entire time critiquing how I ate. He actually did make himself comfortable in the seat across from me when my food arrived.

Apparently he thought I need to be schooled in Indian food because I asked my list of questions at every new restaurant I go to about the ingredients of the food I'm interested in ordering. I have allergies to wheat, gluten, and eggs so have to be cautious that way. First he over explained what a dosa is, then he actually sat down at my table when my food arrived and started telling me what the "correct" procedure was for eating my dosa! 

Apparently he made my actual waiter nervous, because after that it was impossible to get the waiter's attention for things like water. I really didn't want to interact with the host after that, but he was the one who kept noticing me looking for the waiter and getting me things.

My taste buds where happy and my belly full when I left, but this place made me feel cheap and anti-social.  I like to get more for what I pay and I like to feel relaxed rather than harrassed during my meal.

The 4 stars are for decent food,minus non-relaxing atmosphere.
author: Wendy B.

description:
SUNDAY BRUNCH

Service=Very attentive and attractive...helllooo hot girls...and boys

Food=Pani Puri were little crispy taste explosion pockets...A MUST ORDER

Atmoshere= Very tasteful and inviting.  Music a bit too loud for Sunday morning if you are slightly hungover....

Homo factor= not an issue

Price= $$$ but well worth the experience

Parking= mission parking... not so fun.

Bathrooms= Should have been a bit cleaner considering it was early in the day.
author: Annmarie K.

description:
Until tonight I was a south indian food virgin.  No longer.  I joined the crowd in the mission at 5:30.  Minutes later the place was packed.  Nice crowd.  Good vibe.  Typical mission.

I started my meal off on a high note.  Mung sprouts.   Actually a spicey lentil salad.  Very nice.  Complex flavors.  My tongue used taste buds not exercised for decades.  A slow heat that builds slowly but doesn't overwhelm the food.  Why aren't lentils (and barley for that matter, but barley is another story) used more often?

Next, chennal chicken. It's described as fried marinated chicken.  It comes to the table and is tempura like, but more spicey.  In fact in this plate of food, the oil the small pieces of bird were fried in and the spices overwhelm the meat.  The plate tastes of everything but chicken.  

I finish with moons uttapam.  Five different discs of carbohydrate. Supposedly differentiated from one another by various toppings.  My aged taste buds cannot distinguish one from the other.  Dip each into a somewhat spicey sauce, cool it off with another sauce, and you know what?  Its still nothing more than a pancake with some stuff in or on it.  

Well, each to his own.  I had a nice time.  Southern Indian is OK for me but nothing more.  Food being such a subjective thing, well, try for yourself.  Even if you only like it as well as I did, you may also learn something.  I did.  And the crowd and mission are both nice.
author: David D.

description:
Aaah... south Indian food in the city. And what a treat. The hour-long wait made me so hungry that I'm pretty sure anything would have tasted delicious at that point - but Dosa was still a delight. 

My 2 peeps and I shared an awful lot of food - dahi vada, idli vada sambhar, paper masala dosa, mysore masala dosa, paneer peas dosa, mango lassi, madras coffee, and almond pistachio kulfi. Everything was very good and very authentic. The dahi vada was served in such an aesthetically pleasing manner that I hardly had the heart to dig into it. (But I did. And it was awesome). The accompanying sambar and chutnies tasted like they were homemade. I would say the only less-than-perfect item was the filter coffee - the taste of chicory was a bit strong, and it had no foam on top (which means it wasn't made quite the right way). 

I live almost exactly midway between Dosa and the south Indian places down in the south bay (Saravana Bhavan, Madras Cafe) - but if I'd like to have my food in a classier setting, I'm so heading north.
author: Abha R.

description:
So went here.. FINALLY.. yesterday..   
L-O-V-E-D their ....
  - Service (they were so attentive.  they knew exactly what each one of us ordered, they were even proactive about asking me if I wanted anything for my 1 year old to snack on while we eat our meals...  Service was just fantastic..  can't say enough!!)
  
- Food..  OH MY GOD...  do they know how to present there food... !!!   What delicate details to decorate the food..   Felt like a queen each the food there..   I am a south Indian and I must say.. the food was as authentic tasting as it can get...   .

  - Atmosphere --  Fantastic...    


Only negative thing about this place is that it is tooo small for the kind of crowd it attracts...      

Also, not sure if they allow smoking inside...  but I kept getting strong odors of smoke from time to time..  so not sure if it was just folks sitting around us...  or the wind from outside bring that smoke in.. (since they keep their front door open)...     being a non smoker..  i hate to have to smell cigarettes

But overall, EXCELLENTO!
author: S J.

description:
Dosa was quite an experience.  Amazing Indian food.  Who knew that Indian food could be fantastic.  This place is just beyond.  It's open late.  It's warm and full of laughter.  On weekends they have a special dish (I think it is just on Sundays) where you get to fill these little pockets with meat, veggies and spices... out of this world.

Not to be missed.
author: Down Dog Y.

description: YUMMY!  I love this place.  We dropped by on a Saturday afternoon between furniture shopping.  They have amazing options for vegetarians!
author: K O.

description: Wow, rarely do I ever disagree w/ the mass on Yelp...  But I will for Dosa:  The food here is not unlike other South Indian restaurants - there's nothing to write home about.  But you'll pay more for the ambience - the food is over priced.  But if you're wanting a nicer joint and don't feel like slumming it in our many beloved Indian dives, Dosa is for you.
author: FoodJunkie S.

description: Excellent meal - soooo flavorful!! luved every bite!
author: Kayla P.

description:
Just got back from Dosa. We walked in at ~6:15 and sat at the bar straight away. (would have been 25 min or a table). About 20 min later, the line was out the door. Keep the long lines in mind when thinking about going here.

Each of us had the tasting menu. We started with the marinated calamari, which wasn't great, a bit bland and marinated, not fried. The Dahi Vada was very hefty and filling, and heavily sauced, I liked it, she not so much.

We then had mini-Dosas, the Chatni Masal Dosa and the spicy Mung Masala. Honestly, we could not tell the difference between the two, but they were good, particularly with the chutneys.

We moved on to the curry. We had the Baingan Bharta and the lamb. both were great.

by this time we were stuffed, we had gone from famished to stuffed very quickly.

But there was still dessert...We had the mango Kulfi (tastes like a frozen mango lassi) and coconut sorbet. Each was good by itself, but eaten together was even better.

Biggest knock is the price, $140 for two, feels steep for indian food, even though it was tasty and filling.
author: GreyGhost G.

description:
Good but make sure you like Southern Indian food. No naan, no saag paneer. BUT it is very tasty. I had the pepper chicken with a side of rice which was just the right amount of spicyness. My husband had the spinach and prawn paneer which was too spicy for him with a side of the uttapam. My dish was delightful, my husband did not like his so much. The uttapam was VERY buttery and not flavorful. We both agreed we like Zante's better on 30th and Mission.
 Ambiance and service was great and we will go back now that we know what to order! Price ok $50 for dinner two main dishes with the obligate sides and a coke for my hubby.
author: julie q.

description: Really nice service for upscale indian. When you crave indian but need a place that's kind of fancy.
author: Alex A.

description: Udupi is much better but Dosa does it right too. My masala was a touch too salty but wasn't too bad. Solid food. I'll go back.
author: Kat L.

description:
Not really a huge fan of Indian cuisine but thought I'd give in to all the hype.  Well what do ya know, not hype afterall!? Delightful, yes it was.  

Went there on a friday, packed house. Quite a long wait, an hour or so but perfect for grabbing a drink at the bar. Aside from the long wait, service was friendly and efficient. Loved the orange and the space, though its pretty small with tables arranged very closely together. 

Got the spring dosa, nice balance of flavors. Spices worked well together, not overpowering. Totally a fan. Heard they have a tasty brunch as well on sundays I'm ready to try! See ya there....
author: ursy t.

description: Dosa is just fantastic.   The decor is chic enough for New Years' and birthday celebrations, the bar is sexy but not too dark, and the food is very very good.  I would pay more than $12 for their curry and pancake dishes.  Order a drink and, yes, your bill will probably double, but $24 for dinner anywhere in SF is not too shabby.  And at Dosa it is quite a bargain.
author: Jane B.

description: I got food poisoning eating @ Dosa on Valencia.  It looks so pleasant, but being sick for 24 hours isn't worth it.
author: Anya R.

description: Great dosa, nice coconut flan, ok Trichy Swizzle. All in all, a good time.
author: P K.

description: Very good authentic items like vada pav, rava masala dosa, paper masala dosa. Okra pakora waaay overpriced for literally about four okras thinly sliced and besan-fried. Overall great food tho.
author: Tom H.

description:
Thursday, 7pm.  We walk in and are told that it is over an hour wait for a table.  OK, we'll just hang out at the bar.  Luckily 3 seats opened up.  So we're sitting there and the bartender tells us that we can order our dinner right there at the bar... no waiting.  Well, that seemed like a great idea, but when rude patrons are ordering drinks over your meal and spilling all over your back and talking through you it simply ruins the experience.

The food was really quite good, but my favorite item was the mango martini.  Wow, I could subsist on those alone!  The dosas were huge and the sauces they came with had great flavor.

I would recommend making a reservation and being prepared for very a loud dinner.  There isn't a quiet section in this restaurant.
author: Doug A.

description:
I really liked our experience at Dosa this past Wednesday night.  The place was hoppin' and the food was a refreshing twist on what I have come to expect at an Indian restaurant.  At the end of the meal I considered ordering this chicken appetizer dish AGAIN but my wife reminded me that I had truly had plenty to eat...  its true...  I had.
Dosa is a new restaurant with surprisingly few kinks to work out.  Their service was very friendly and the ambiance was 
warm and rich.
We will definately be back with friends!
author: David N.

description:
I have to admit, this is the first time I've tried south indian cuisine.  I would say overall, this place is pretty good and I liked all the dishes, but just didn't find anything outstanding.  

With a small group of friends (4), we ordered take out for a little dinner and movie at our friends' place.  I was impressed at the timing (20-25min.) for a Sun. night, and a really nice hostess taking our order as well as welcoming you into the restaurant (thank you Jessica).. 4-5 stars for take out service (This is the closest I've ever been to giving out a perfect score)

As for the food, I guess I just love my meats and there's not many of those options in a south indian cuisine.  We tried their paneer and masala dosas (what they're known for),a chicken curry and lentil dumplings.  The dumplings look like fried doughnuts and are mediocre but I liked everything else.  I agree with their recommendation that putting both sauces on the dosas increases the taste palette and I should also warn against those non-spice lovers that at a minimum, most of the food (esp. the curry) has at least a little kick to it.  

That being said, we only spent $15 a pop but I guess in the end, a place has to meet expectations.  I suppose I'm not being really fair since it is a lot better than most, but when you're consider one of the top indian restaurants in the city, I expect to be somewhat delirious with delight at the end of a good meal.

Update (9/4/07): +1 star for one of the owners sending me a personal e-mail to discuss other options that I might enjoy besides the one I tried in the statements above.  I think I still prefer my North Indian butter chicken, but I can appreciate good customer relationship and service.
author: Ken S.

description:
Wow, I never knew Indian food could be so diverse and delicious! Went with a group of five and we ordered a good mix of about everything to share. Each dish was unique and tasteful. It was hard to pick a favorite or leave leftovers on the table because we couldn't take them to our next stop. Loved every bit of it!
Classy interior as well!
author: Jen T.

description:
Indian eatery with a bit of ambience? What a concept! 

Food is delicious and thankfully un-americanized (read spicy). Yes, there are plenty of non-spicy Indian dishes, just ask. Do not miss the dahi-vada. (writing this review makes me hungry!)

Wine selection is very good. Energy in the restaurant is good.

Best South Indian restaurant in SF/Bay Area.
author: Sai M.

description: Good for the lack of having to wait on a Saturday night. However, I was disappointed with the food, I was expecting a lot more. Had the paneer and peas uttapam, and it was a bit more oily than I would like. Perhaps I just am not very fond of uttapams. However, tried the dosa masala and it was just okay. Liked the pancake part, but the inside filling was jush meh. Samosas were good, but not standouts. Good service and nice atmosphere. However, I just didn't see enough on the taste end to go back.
author: Glaciala A.

description: I had brunch here for the second time and it's always tasty and the service is friendly and very good. This time I enjoyed Paneer and Peas Uttapam and my partner had Mesala Uttapam and we shared Dahi Vada for an appetizer. Our meal was a great combination of tastes and textures and with a great presentation. Tasty and filling and a great choice for a place to eat on Valencia Street.
author: Dean J.

description: Not been to Dosa on Valencia for a while - after forays into recommended peninsula Indian restaurants and several visits to the other Dosa - it was so good to be back, hauntingly good. Busy and vibrant, nice mix of Indians and the usual Mission crowd - we squeezed into the bar, great service, cool music and a sensational lamb baida roti to get started. Perfectly balanced dry spicy Italian gerwurztraminer. Caved in and just went with my favourite main dish, Tamil vegetable curry with coconut rice. "This must be it, what else is there?"
author: Vera N.

description: In an odd turn of events, I ended up at Dosa most unexpectedly after working in San Ramon for the day. Without reservation on a Thursday evening, I waited for less than 5 minutes before being seated and less than 10 minutes before enjoying my meal. I will definitely be back to try all the other dosas that I missed this first time!
author: Charles B.

description:
Excellent authentic Indian food, even for north Indians! This is as good as it gets. Their salt Lassi was very good and being from Rajasthan I know a good Chaach(Lassi) when I have one. We ended up having 3 of those. The masala chai was excellent too. I had their Non Veg Lamb Entree with Coconut rice on Sunday brunch and the masala was exquisite. We also tried the Chili and Coriander Uttapam but that was not upto par. I bet their Masala Dosas are best in town though. Have to give that a try another day. 
Mung Salad is also very healthy and good. I would say its a bit pricey for Indian food but it would be hard to keep up the quality of this place without those prices. Authentic food even tough the place looks like its fusion.
author: Chef M.

description:
Amazing. 

I thought this place was great. I went there for brunch and thought to myself while i was eating, "this is what good food is about". It reminded why I started cooking in the first place. Clean, good, simple with well rounded flavors and textures that complimented each other well.

The service was good and relatively seamless and the atmosphere is pleasant as well.

It's a little bit more expensive than your average diner or cafe spot but for the extra few dollars it's definitely worth it.

 I haven't tried their dinner but if it's as good as brunch I'm sold.
author: Jacob Z.

description:
+ Fiery Fruit salad
+ Dahl Vada
+ Prawn Chile Fry
+ Masala Dosa
+ Crisps
+ Charming owners
+ Good service

De-lish!
author: Tulip F.

description:
Went there last night. Figured it wouldn't be so busy on a weeknight between Xmas and NYE. Parked a block away, waited 8-10 mins. Not bad at all. 

Each course arrived lightning fast. If it's always like this, why is there always such a wait?

Nothing was oily, greasy, or had too much ghee. Dry papadum, very excellent. I ate too much. 

Our appetizer, fried lentil donuts with chutneys, was good but had flavors too similar to our dosa entree. I hate it when the exact flavors repeat in courses. The dosa was good and crisp, perfectly cooked. We used to get dosas at Indian places back in the 80's and this one had less filling than those but was a notch better. 

The shrimp curry was good with deep flavors. Kind of pricey at $16 though. Almost everything seemed pricey for what it is. Indian food in the US is way overpriced except at Nann n Curry!

Loved that there are Lillet cocktails. Creative touch with the translucent glass separating the kitchen/restroom corridor from the restroom. Loved the low-key Euro beats. A very diverse crowd in terms of age, dress, and upscale/downscale tastes. Service was very attentive. In all my years of going to Indian restaurants and experiencing horribly slow service (our running joke about Indian restaurants), this place had the best service. Course it looked to me like the staff wasn't very Indian. 

Had a smile over there being a Mysore style dosa on the menu. Very fitting for the Mission.
author: Paris E.

description:
We were tempted by the tasting menu but opted to go in a different direction as the customary looksie confirmed our suspicious that this place served it up. Not that I'm not one for "serving it up" but I'm not a fiend for Indian food. Was never into the curry-infused food thing. 

Honestly, it was my first time trying Indian food and it was alright. I wasn't too pleased with the dipping sauces that accompanied almost every dish.  I didn't really know what to use them so it may have spoiled my experience. 

I would give it another try if it weren't so busy. We got lucky as they were able to accomodate us with a table on a rainy Tuesday evening.
author: S L.

description:
Authentic south indian food coupled with a stellar wine list (I'd recommend Lucy rose or Selbach-Oster riesling).  The menu includes some lip snackin goodness like Channa Bhatura and chaat on weekends+mondays.

Love the Spring Dosa and the recently added Spinach Cauliflower Vada, Eggplant Curry + Coconut Rice. Along with my back home favorites: idli/vada sambhar and masala dosa.

Major props to the Dosa team for setting the bar on an up-market Indian restaurant. Pakwan is good for a dhabha style meal, but Dosa is its classy cousin.
author: el b.

description:
Had a great dinner at Dosa last night. They don't seem to take reservations for parties of less than five people, and when we got there a line was out the door. But, it turned out that we were able to sit at the bar and have the whole menu available to us there. A table opened up shortly thereafter, but we stayed where we were.

We each got the fixed-price four-course dinner. Started with the Chennai Chicken and Dahl Vada, went on to the Chatni Masala Dosa and the Tomato, Onion & Green Chile Uttapam, then the South Indian Lamb KoftaTamil Vegetable Curry. We finished with the Rasmalai and the Gulab Jamoon.

The ladies behind the bar were friendly and helpful with what to get (with both food and drink). All of the food was really good. I love Indian food, and this was probably the best I've had since I've lived here (three years). We each had a couple of cocktails. Both of mine had Soju in them, which was kinda light and refreshing.

This is a pretty small restaurant, and every table was taken the whole time we were there. The decor is attractive, and the place is in a great part of the Mission.

If you like Indian, go. Great stuff here. Good times.
author: Steve R.

description:
India has a diverse cuisine. Thank you Dosa for breaking out of the thick curry Punjab mold.

Dosas, oh yes. Shrimp curry. Channa Bhutura rocked my world.

Only complaint, $8 beer. $8 Kingfisher?! Come on.
author: Mikel M.

description: I tried this place about 2 years ago. The food was on point, very flavorful. The servers were extremely professional, attentive, and quite knowledgeable about the cuisine. They have a large selection of dosas along with other signature south Indian dishes. Give it a shot, you won't be disappointed.
author: Ms B.

description: We made a reservation for my Husband's birthday 2 weeks in advance, and were still forced to wait 25 minutes by the front door.  The maitre d' had a 4-top open during the entire wait and did not offer to seat us, despite the wait and the occasion.  The food was ok, but by no means blew my socks off.
