Again, this is why I would rather pay $20-$30 more a head for better service and extraordinary food.
author: Hannah A.

description: We went here for brunch. The food was excellent, and I would come back here just for that part of it! It is not close to one of my favorite places to go though.  The waiter service was awful and disappointing. We had to hunt down our waiter for the check and he never once came back to check on us once our food was served.  The other wait staff, the guy that brought out our food, was nice and showed us how to eat the Pani Puri appetizer.
author: Brooke N.

description:
Food - average
Service - ok
Ambiance - nice
Wanted to try this place because a friend mentioned it.  The food was only ok.  Not a place I would go back to.
author: J S.

description: Decent but I actually felt their dosas weren't as good as they should be. This is sort of a let down for a place called dosa, no? I also feel it's too expensive.
author: Kristin S.

description: AMAZING FOOD! We visited the Valencia location only later to find out that there was a second location on Fillmore.  The location on Fillmore is larger and fancier, where as the Valencia location is smaller and cozier.  The food regardless is delicious, and worth every penny. We had the lamb dishes that were by far the best we have ever had. Would definetly visit this place again!  Staff was attentive and helpful when ordering.
author: A O.

description:
I'd never had a Dosa before. The name of the restaurant refers to their specialty. This thin soft bread thing filled with different things. 80% of the menu is vegetarian. All the dosas and the fluffier alternative (whose name escapes me) are fully vegetarian. As a meatatarian this had me concerned.

We ordered the habanero dosa and the lamb curry with coconut rice. The dosa was relatively spicy. For those who find it too spicy when you start it, dig into the deep end and eat it with the filling. The filling does a great job at cutting the spice level down while keeping the tingle at the end.

The lamb curry was delicious. It was more delicious when i still was eating it with the habanero dosa. Makes me think that if i go back Ill ask for it spicier than normal. It was a thick, gray, gravy-like curry, just as it should be.

My only disappointment was that they didnt have Naan or Goat on the menu. But i cant blame them for that, its a different type of indian food then what i normally go for.

Go early! The line builds fast. When we arrived at 630 on Saturday there was no line, at 730 when we left there was a 30 minute wait (for 2 people). A very intimate restaurant, perfect for a date (even a first one).
author: H B.

description: VERY popular and VERY busy ALL the time. That didn't ruin the experience though as the food and service were very good. No complaints whatsoever, and would gladly recommend to anyone. Probably one of the best dosa experiences I've had.
author: Royce R.

description:
My bf and I tried Dosa (on Valencia) for the very first time on Saturday. It was suuuper packed... so much so that we overheard an angry man in front of say that he waited over 30 minutes for his table and he had a reservation! We only waited 15 minutes after our reservation time to be seated. So, I guess this is a warning to all that reservations are more than recommended if you want to eat here on a busy weekend night!

We ordered the following:

Cochin Calamari --- really tender calamari rings in a curry sauce with a side of greens.
Paneer and Peas Dosa --- looked like a cheese and peas burrito!
Tamil Lamb Curry with Coconut Rice --- exactly what the name says.

I think the best parts of the meal were the calamari appetizer because the calamari was tender and the sauce was delicious! And also the coconut rice because it was light and had a hint of coconut that went really well with the spice of the curry. The dosa itself was just ok. I don't know if there was supposed to be a really spicy chili pepper in it because I ate it and my mouth/throat/stomach lining was on FIRE for at least 10 minutes. I even teared up a bit which really scared my bf. Ha! The lamb curry was good, but nothing out of the ordinary.

Given all the hype (and the ridiculous wait) for this place, we were sadly underwhelmed. I would return to try other dishes on the menu, but I'd rather try something else.
author: Cecilia W.

description: We got the chennai chicken, dahi vada, and Tamil lamb curry based on glowing yelp reviews.  While they were all fairly good, nothing was exceptional.  The service was good to say the least.   The chennai chicken was tender for being fried and the yogurt sauce was a good complement to the dish.  The dahi vada was pretty but it was covered in sauce that was very rich.  We also got the lamb which was not too gamey and well seasoned.  Overall, a decent experience but not sure i'd go back again.
author: Kristie G.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in SF.  When I was in college at Berkeley I had a roommate from Southern India and her mom made idli sambar for us .  I've never had it anywhere else that tasted as good...until Dosa!

The owners remember us when we come in and recommend dishes...they're obviously imbuing the experience with so much heart.  The flavors are fantastic and I love the ambiance....very warm and lively.

Highly recommend!  apparently now they have brunch too, which we've been meaning to check out.
author: Darla W.

description:
Place is boom. Great food along with a Great services. very friendly people.

The best Dosa's i every eaten out side India. Must Go Place if you are in the area.
author: Vijay M.

description:
Not bad.  Not great.

Bit disappointed by the selection to be honest as I would have preferred more choice other than dosa after dosa after bread dish after dosa...

It was very tasty although left me with a bit of a dodgy stomach today...
author: Michael R.

description: Very authentic tamil food. Sambar was delicious. But its a little too pricey
author: Archana S.

description: The mango lassi was great, as was the squid appetizer, and the food was tasty but not exceptional. The service was only mediocre. We were seated without being given a menu, and it took them 15 minutes just to bring us one, even though the place was not full. I asked for non-spicy food for my 2 year old, and what they recommended was definitely spicy. They kept taking away plates and utensils literally as I was chewing my last bite, very rushed.
author: Viola T.

description: Came here the other day for Ladies bday. Wanted to take her to Frances but she insisted on this place. Heard a lot of great things about it so was excited. Food was just ok, either lacked seasoning or had too much acid, in my opinion. Service was a little lack luster considering dining room was a bit empty. Were given dessert menus before entrees came, twice. Odd. Then desserts ,which were not even ordered, were brought out before entrees. Go figure.
author: I D.

description:
I have to say- I've been to Dosa three times, each roughly a year apart, and each time was at least "pretty good"

I brought my mother here a few weeks ago and honestly had the most amazing dinner. Yogurt appetizer + like south Indian chicken wings with cucumber goo. YUM. The dosa, of course, was amazing. But the real surprise was the curry. I normally hate curries but the lamb curry here was out of this world.

One of the things I love about this restaurant is the food's ability to showcase a huge array of flavors without a dominant/ boring "seller" taste or texture. That's why eating here is an experience.

Two small quibbles: don't get the like curds cheese dessert as it tastes exactly like Lysol, and the the food runners need to be trained to say what they're putting on the table before leaving.

Thanks Dosa I'll be back!
author: Matt T.

description: The Dosas (specifically the masala) was very good, and it was well priced. We got the samosas too and I wasn used to having the potatoes mashed, which was a bit different than chunky potatoes. I really liked this place. One issue though is the wait, I personally think there are other Indian restaurants that don't get this type of hype that have really good dosas
author: Eric A.

description:
Wow! Dosa is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  Eating there is such a joy. The food is delicious, you can really tell that the chef's put love and care in to the food, which is so very important. Not to mention it is very healthy and healing food. I get a euphoric rush after eating there... soo good! And totally affordable!
Thank you Dosa!
ox!
author: leah p.

description:
I have just came back from Dosa and am really disappointed . I ordered Mango Seed which was half the size of regular martini with just few drops of alcohol.Dosa was soggy and tasteless. Meal at this place will make a huge hole in you pocket as it's overpriced with below average food.

After reading my review owner of the Place Mr. Anjan sent me a very rude message saying are you sure you visited us......Yes Mr Anjan I am sure I dinned at your Restaurant I was avoiding not to write name of the drink and dish but now you have asked for It I had Mango seed, guys its a horrible drink with a very small portion priced at around $6. 

I really wish I can knock off this one start too.
author: Nycgrl a.

description: This was recommended by our Hiking Yoga instructor (and her husband). It was excellent - Southern Indian cuisine is different from what we normally think of as Indian food, but check this place out if you like Indian at all. So many interesting things to try, you'll have to go several times. And everything we had tonight was delicious.  The only negative is that we were a little rushed because we got there later and weren't eating particularly quickly. But once the servers realized, they slowed down to a more leisurely pace, and were very pleasant throughout the meal.
author: Keith M.

description:
As someone who has lived in south of India for a while, I can attest to the fact that the food here is superb! They get the Sambhar so right! Dosas are brilliant - Uttapas too. The curry of the day has always been  good.

Try the egg poriyal dosa for brunch - its brilliant. If I had to critique this place, it would be on the idlis and the chai they serve. Idlis are a bit too hard and chai is really too mild to be authentic. Oh also, the wait is a killer and its too frustating most times - they don't take reservations for 4 - and on a couple of occasions I had to wait for more than 30 mins even after having a reservation. They ought to correct that. The place is too small so it can't seat a lot of people - it always fills up pretty fast.

Also, the Ras Malai is a must have for desert!
author: some g.

description:
Huge portions and the crepes are really, really, really oily. I'm not used to heavy food but it was fun to taste all of the different curries. 

The ambiance was a little on the loud side and I wasn't that fond of our hyper waiter who tried to get us to order more and more alcohol just to get a bigger tip on the final bill. 

I would recommend it to people who like indian food but not for the health-conscious.
author: Lauren E.

description: It's a small place on a holiday weekend, so I forgave that they were 20 minutes late on our reservation seating. Plus, they were very apologetic and were nice enough to comp an appetizer while we waited.  The food was all wonderful.  The calamari appetizer was amazing -- I was tempted to just get two more of those and call it a night.  But I went for a DOSA with a side lamb & peas -- the DOSA itself was irresistable, and the lamb mixture complemented it well.  I've been there before and found that many of the dishes are quite spicy (and I'm no lightweight), so I chose the ones I did based on the very helpful waiter's recommendation on the less spicy dishes.  It is a bit noisy, but not so it was impossible to talk... it just took a little more effort.
author: Dana D.

description: I honestly don't understand what all the fuss is about.  The service and decor were fine and the food was, well, fine.  Nothing to write home about.  I had better Indian food for a third of the price two days earlier in the tenderloin.  A friend of mine and I split two entrees and each had one drink, and our bill (including tax and tip) was around $34 each.  Pretty ridiculous for Indian food.
author: Debra C.

description: Good quality food but tastes average.
author: Alex M.

description: It was very good. The waitress was quite nice. My family really enjoyed it as well. It's just that I am allergic to peanuts and cashews and this was not really a nut friendly place. A lot of their foods have cashews in them, which kinda sucked just because I wanted to try different foods. It's also very rich food, so we got full very fast. The food we ordered was still great. if you want, get the dosa with peas. That was the best thing I had all night.
author: Huitzi H.

description:
an outstanding place to be a veggie or a vegan.  also...if you're a veggie/vegan and are not big on fake meat (get away from me, i hate you.  fake meat is the BEST!) then this place is for you.  southern indian food is delicious and the food at dosa is the best i've had in the bay area (the masala dosa is FUCKING MASHED POTATOES IN A PANCAKE.  the only thing that could make it any better is if it performed oral sex on my person.  okay sorry ew.).  also, nice location.  good for a group or a date.  love the lighting.  

i actually don't have anything else to add.  that dude making fun of me on yelp has pretty much zapped all the creative energy that i had left and now i am dead on the inside.  please mark this review as funny, useful and cool and then do the same with all my other reviews.  i am yelp royalty, after all.  don't you all just do what i say?  so yes, mark this review as funny, useful and cool and then fan me and write me a million compliments.  why are you still sitting there reading this?!  DO IT NOW!!!

(or just unfan me, ignore this review and call the psych ward at UCSF.  i might not be coming out of this one alive, folks.)
author: Laura B.

description:
Dear totally hot international guy sitting next to me at the bar at Dosa,

I know I worked it into the conversation 3 times, but he's my roommate. I mean, we have separate bedrooms and everything. I tried to give him eye signals to get lost, but he's a straight boy and can't read my intricate series of winks and nods. As soon as I sat next to you, I was overwhelmed by your crisp white shirt, rolled sleeves and Tag Heuer, not to mention your incredibly hot Ivy League, young Deepak Chopra vibe dining alone at an upscale Indian restaurant. I just wanted to cover myself in marigolds and red dots when we discussed restaurants, us both frequenting the same fabulous and oft-reviewed hot spots. I was practically beside myself when my made-up excuse to talk to you resulted in you offering me food, and died and went to heaven when you ordered a single glass of champagne with your bizarre, foreign dessert. I hope I wasn't obvious with my four blatant arm touches and one bold back pat. I simply wanted to experience the feel of what I can only assume was custom made in Delhi or Hong Kong. When we were finally seated away from the bar, my roommate (again, ROOMMATE) pointed out that you were obviously flirting with me. He encouraged me to go back to the bar and talk to you, to leave you my business card or ask you out for chai. But I was too chicken, and too busy enjoying your recommendation of the onion bhaji with the Chenin Blanc. But if you read this, and you probably will, I hope very much to go on lots of dates with you to the marvelous restaurants we discussed and so look forward to your building me my very own Taj Mahal.

You are hot, guy at the bar at Dosa, and I think I love you.


Most Sincerely,
Beth

PS. Seriously. He's my roommate...
author: Beth S.

description:
So everyone knows that this place is fabulous, and no one needs MY review to tell them that it's fabulous.  But I had dinner at Dosa last night and just felt moved to share my thoughts.

Since their menu is SO packed with tantalizing options, there are a lot of dishes that even loyal customers might not have had the opportunity to try.  Take the Coconut & Roasted Pepper Soup, for example....probably one of the most divine dishes I have ever tasted!!

The service was also excellent -- all the staff were really friendly and attentive.  Dining out here is consistently a wonderful experience.  Dosa is a restaurant that richly deserves its excellent reputation.
author: Holly P.

description:
Again, if I could I would give this place a 0 but I do appreciate the opportunity to laugh my ass off when I leave a place like this for the absurdity of it all.  My party waited for an hour to sit which which was fine.  Two of the three decide to order off the tasting menu while the third wasn't as hungry so she was getting just one other dish for herself.  OK.  Oh first we find out that the corkage fee is $20, a little pricey but whatever.  Anyway, back to my story.  So we tell the waitress and she looks very pained and says "oh sorry we can't split tasting menus".  Uh, what does that mean?  Two of us are ordering off the tasting menu and one isn't, we aren't splitting?  Waitress: "oh actually in most SF restaurants including ours, we like to time the dishes so we can't have two of you order the tasting menu and one not".  Uh, again, what???  Its a timing thing?  How elitist and fabulous do you think you are?  btw, loved my friend's comment "yeah I understand that at a fine dining establishment, but, uh, okay give us a minute".  So we either had to promise that our third friend wouldn't order anything else and not eat off our dishes and we could order the tasting menus (that was ok for some ridiculous reason, btw, you are losing money by her not ordering but whatever) or the two of us couldn't order off the tasting menu.  (again, you are losing 70 bucks (tasting menu is 35 dollars) which doesn't make any freaking sense to me if you are trying to make money, aren't you a business?).  So, guess what, we left.  Yes we left your wonderful, top 10 restaurant because guess what, we like to order what we want to, that is why we have money to spend here and our free will.  I don't appreciate being told what I can and can't order if the item is available and you can physically bring it to my table.  Your loss Dosa.

btw, I have eaten there before and liked the food but it certainly isn't the best thing I have ever had in my life so Dosa please don't be under any illusions that you can treat customers that way and get away with it because the food is so unforgettable.

***I do have to add that the management at Dosa emailed me pretty much right away apologizing for what happened so I might have to give the restaurant another chance at some point soon.***
author: Lindsay P.

description:
Went to dinner at Dosa on Friday night on July 3rd. 

Overall, I think the food at the restaurant was good, but the service was barely passable for "good", and the food portions were terrible.

We tried a wide variety of their options:
1) Samosas- which came as a surprise to me that they were only 2 per order, this was strange since our server only mentioned we should get "two orders of that". My expectation was that there were 3 per order, since there was 6 of us at the table.
2) Spinach and Paneer Jumbo shrimp- great spinach, but 3 "jumbo"shrimp.  Again, a laughable portion for 6 adults.
3) Bagara Baingan- also was very good.  My favorite dish of them all.
4) Lamb Kofta- a very well spiced dish, and had a great curry sauce with it.
5) Tomato and Onion Uttapam- spicy and delicious.
6) Spicy Mung Masala- this was the reason we were there, to actually try their dosa. It was very good, and very flavourful.

Plus $8.50 in various rice sides, which were practically non-existent.

So the food was good, and I commend them for making great Indian food with local and organic ingredients (which they should maybe flaunt on their menu, if this was my menu I would be excited to share with the diners where their food came from).

But there was simply not enough of it.  After costing $50 per person, we left practically hungry.
author: Danian P.

description:
I am a huge fan of Indian food, but I am weary of some Indian restaurants.  My first exposure to Indian cuisine was my best friend's mother's cooking and she was a damn good cook, so I compare everybody's cooking to hers.

Anyway, I hang out on Valencia a lot at night, and this place is crowded every time so I could tell that they got some good food here.  I finally booked a reservation with my best friend to eat here and the food did not disappoint.

Both my friend and I are vegan, so we were really happy that the restaurant offered a chart to show what dishes contain popular allergens, such as gluten, or dairy, or meat.  It made ordering much easier for us.

I ordered just 1 dosa and it was so delicious and flavorful that I couldn't even finish it, no matter how much I wanted to.  It came with a coconut chutney that was so good, I want to steal the recipe but I dont think the cook would give it to me.

I give it 4 stars because the service wasn't bad at all, but it wasn't outstanding.
author: Jolene L.

description: The BEST coconut rice on the planet earth.  The watermelon & mung sprout salad and the baby eggplant kofta... heaven.
author: Michele L.

description:
Sure, it was a Saturday night.  We put our name in at 8, expecting a long wait.  We were told 35 to 45 minutes.  8:35 we came back.  Were told we were the next table.  9pm.  5 more minutes, we're informed. 9:30.  Assured we're the next table. 9:45, would we like to have a drink at the bar? 10pm, we're finally seated and informed that they're out of glasses.  And plates.  They bring us food, but then quickly take it away claiming that it was intended for another table.  Once we got our forks into the food and growled our displeasure things went a bit smoother.  We were so hungry by the time we got our food that I barely tasted it as we shoveled it down.  It may have been pretty good, but the abysmal service. One round of comp drinks for two hours of waiting just doesn't cut it.
It's understandable to have service issues at a popular new restaurant.  But jerking your customer's chain isn't doing anyone any favors.  If they had said two hours when we arrived, we obviously would have gone elsewhere.  But telling us that we're the next table for an hour and a half is just bad customer service.  For now, the food isn't worth the hassle.
author: Gabriel S.

description: Lousy excuse for South Indian food. The service was completely disappointing to begin with (35 min to see the waiter return with drinks, after having been moved from the wannabe bar area to our table). Basic items on the menu like the Idly (rice dumpling) were undercooked and "pastey", the dosa was grease laden (no, Indian food is not fried twice and served in oil!) and the prices were off the charts. For an excellent South Indian meal for under $10 visit Tirupathi Bheema's or Saravanan Bhavan in the south bay!
author: Nishant J.

description: Dosa is like the boy you had the perfect date with who then waits 5 days to call you. You eat that coconut rice and you obsess. And obsess some more. And remember how good each bite was. And wish you could spend more time with Dosa. But NO, Dosa is aloof. He is too busy to see you again for a very long time. He's in high demand... But he's always on my mind. And I know that one day I'll fight my way through his gaggle of admirers to spend time with him once again, because he's THAT GOOD!!
author: Michelle D.

description:
It's been almost a month since I visited Dosa, and I have been endlessly debating with myself whether I should even add my $0.02 to the $8.28 already in the Yelp pot - especially when my impression is so discrepant from the general opinion. I thought maybe I should visit again, but then I realized that I have way too many restaurants left on my list to hit up before I leave SF...and that I am, in fact, narcissistic enough to think that my review might serve some use in this Yelp world. So here you go:

"Congratulations, Dosa! You have just made it into the Overrated Club!" I wanted so much to like Dosa - hip Mission locale, cool decor, vibrant energy, courteous and down-to-earth service (both while waiting for our table for four and during the meal). However, there was a lot of the experience that just seemed a little bit "off." Our server was very enthusiastic about telling us his favorites within each section of the *overwhelmingly* large menu. Since he seemed so friendly and we were so indecisive, my friend and I got into our "assault the waiter with questions" mode. He handled it well, but when we asked what the difference between fresh corriander and cilantro was, he seemed flustered and was unable to find an answer for us. I think that we scared him because after that we never saw him again. The service thereafter was moderately good, though it took some effort to flag down more water.

Oh well, it's probably best because some of his suggestions were real disappointments, and I am a terrible liar. Our starter, the Dahi Vada (lentil dumplings topped with yogurt, tamarind, and mint) sounded intriguing and unique to Dosa. Unfortunately, the presentation and the texture of the dish elicited a unanimous verdict, "It's like 7 layer bean dip." Not appetizing unless it is Super Bowl Sunday. For our entrees, I had the Chatni Masala dosa, which we all agreed was the best pick of the table; it would have been nice though if the waiter had confirmed whether it would be made with the eggplant or the ridge gourd. The dosa was very large (~12 inches across), with an ample serving of a creamy baby eggplant chutney spread encased in a wonderfully crisp crepe. The other entrees included the Channa Bhatura (a flat-tasting chick pea masala served with an awesome puffy wheat bread), some vegetable curry that was so inspirational and muddled in flavor that I can't remember anything else worth mentioning, and the South Indian Moons. The South Indian Moons (chef's choice of five uttapams - aka open faced dosas), in particular, sounded too good to be true - and it was. It's a classic case of sacrificing quality for quantity - the half-dollar sized uttapams were all dry and none of their toppings was able to stand out (I enjoyed the paneer & peas most, probably because I am a cheesehound like that).

Despite how terribly loud it was, we were able to carry on a lively discussion about NYC vs. Bay Area lifestyle and dining (p.s. I'm always up for this conversation...). While the food was not offensive, the overall experience was unimpressive, especially given the attention and high praise Dosa has received.

3.5 stars for ambiance + 3.5 stars for service + 3 stars for food  = an induction into the Bay Area Chapter of the Overrated Club.
author: Steph P.

description: Sucks.  I can't believe how popular this place is.  Do you people hate your tastebuds?  Have they pissed you off in some way?  Seriously, I want an explanation.
author: Coco D.

description: After reading the various reviews, I was nervous about eating at Dosa. Turns out, the place isn't all it's cracked up to be, so at least I was appropriately forewarned! We had an appetizer, dosa, and pappadam, and all were pretty bland. As most have mentioned, everything's served with the same dipping sauces and soupy soup (what else can I call it?). The tables are way to close together, and we felt like we were eating in the bathroom (or at least in the hallway, which connected to another hallway, which led to the bathroom).
author: Bee H.

description: nom nom nom ... just ate here about two hours ago .... would definitely do this again.  not only were there tasty surprises, but it's nice to eat in an indian restaurant that isn't a hole in the wall.
author: Henry M.

description:
This place has THE worst customer service I have ever experienced in a restaurant, bar none.  Two friends and I arrived late (apparently, after closing) to meet up with a group that had already ordered and received their food.  We were told that the kitchen had closed so we weren't going to be able to order.  Fine.  But then when we tried to order drinks (beers, etc.), we were told that the kitchen was closed and so was the bar. !!  It was only just after 10pm (closing time) and I just couldn't believe that the bar would shut down that quickly. My friend went next door and bought some beers from a convenience store and brought them into the restaurant for us.  Meanwhile, one of the guys in the group who had arrived earlier and was eating also tried to order another beer and was given the "we're closed" line.  He went up to the bar and made a big stink about it and a few minutes later, the manager came over and apologized to him saying that there was a miscommunication and that he could indeed order another beer.  The server who'd been so incredibly rude to us and had told us we could *not* order drinks also came by to apologize *to that guy but not to us on the other side of the table.* To add insult to injury, she came around to our side of the table and asked someone else BUT NOT US if she wanted another drink. Talk about a slap in the face.  First tell us we can't have food. Okay. But then tell us we can't have drinks. Then tell us we *can* have drinks but don't even offer us any. After the completely uppity way they treated us, I wouldn't have bought a drink from them anyway, but still. It's hard to believe that the proprietors would have so little sense of customer service that they would 1) turn away the chance to make high margin $ on alcohol, and 2) not try harder to mend the bad feelings caused by the "miscommunication" among their staff in the hopes of getting repeat customers in the future. Btw, the food that our friends shared with us was good, but I would NEVER go back to this place due to this extremely upsetting experience. I would give it 0 zero stars if that were possible.
---------------------------------
I got an email from one of the owners letting me know that he's addressing the problem and attempting to extend some goodwill. I have to say, I'm surprised (but pleasantly so) that business managers are so closely monitoring this site, but that just means that it's doing what it's supposed to. Bravo!
author: sylvia c.

description: A mouthful of hot, sweet and tang rolled into one. A bite of surprise. Flavors like tamarind water and spicy-sour mint compliment each delicacy.  The pani puri is a starter I order every time I go. The dosas are incredible. After all, it's in the name. From start to finish, each meal at Dosa is a journey you'll want to experience again and again.
author: Alex H.

description:
I am scared of these people. They are scary. 

They have lots of rules. I don't do well with rules... 

I busted in here last Tuesday night all pissed off because I was having a hard time parking my car for the first time since moving to the Mission, and my friend and I were trying to squeeze a hurried dinner into planned-out nights, and said friend was calling me asking me over and over where was this place? He was standing on the corner of 22nd and Valencia! And I was calling him back repeatedly while trying to find a parking spot, and park, and walk, downhill, with my big work bag, and my computer bag... "It's not right ON the corner. It's ON Valencia." And then he's calling me back saying he doesn't see it... "Well walk farther down then. It might be closer to 21st." And then -- THE HORROR! I see it. And it's actually between 20TH AND 21ST. And I have to call him back AGAIN. Only I can't get through because he's calling me at exactly the same time to tell ME where it is... And I'm like, "I KNOW where it is. I'm committing this cell-phone-suicide FOR YOU." And by the time I get in he's having a chai at the bar and I drop all my bags on the ground and he's like, to the maitre'd, "Can we get a table now? (Aside to me) They wouldn't seat me without you..." And scary maitre'd is like, "Actually, why don't you settle with the bartender first..." And we're like, um, oookay... And he was really kinda snotty. But whatever, we really just want to sit down. And HOLY SHIT was it hot in there. Like, I know you're a "Southern Indian" place, and you're very proud of the fact that your food is DISTINCTLY southern Indian and not northern, but your CLIMATE doen't need to be... And we finally get our table, and then we realize we know NOTHING about said cuisine of southern India. So we ask the waitress for help. And she's like, WAY INTENSE. She's like, there every second. Are we ready yet? Do we want dosas or uttapams? Why don't we get one curry, and one dosa, and share everything? Okay, well, WHY DON'T WE MAKE UP OUR OWN MINDS? But whatever, she was trying to be helpful, and she was, for the most part... And then the food comes. And it's good. I mean, really good. In a weird, I'm-not-really-familiar-with-this, I-still-don't-quite-understand-what-I'm-eating, or why-I-ordered-it, I-think-it-was-just-because-you-were-freakin'-me-out, but-oh-well kind of way... But of course we can't finish it. And oh good Lord, we have to ask for to-go containers. So some mystery man comes out from the kitchen, and I don't know what happens. It's like that carni act, where the guy puts a quarter under a card and then shuffles it around on a table with other cards and makes you guess which one the quarter is under... DUDE, WHAT ARE YOU DOING WITH OUR FOOD? Just put it all in boxes and give it all back to us! Lord! Then evil maitre'd man comes back with our check, because once again, he REALLY wants us to settle up, because by now the place is PACKED. Packed, I tell you! On a Tuesday at 7:30. And I realize that I am sweating really bad and want to pass out from the heat. And I come to the conclusion that I am slightly freaked out by Dosa, even though I am a little bit hooked on dosas...
author: Lisa T.

description: Dosa gets by on reputation and the fact that it's rare to find southern Indian food anywhere.  In reality, the food is only so so.  People seem to like it because they have nothing else to compare it to, I guess.  Restaurants like this also seem to attract the surliest of staff.  From the minute you walk in the door, you're made to feel like you're being done a favor by getting a seat, getting served, etc.  I don't know much about southern Indian food but I'm pretty sure this can't be the cream of the crop.
author: M M.

description:
My boyfriend and I used to avoid this place like the plague... Err, well we'd at least cross the street so we wouldn't have to wade through the over-perfumed, loud, "yes, I like to stand in the middle of the sidewalk, so what?" yuppie crowd that usually gathers outside this place every night between 6:30 and 8... But with the dwindling number of acceptable vegan-friendly (non-new age) restaurants that my boyfriend and I can go to in this city, we decided to pop in there just to give it a try (and because my boyfriend loves him some uttapam).
The first time we went there, which was a little over 7 months ago?, we  were famished and it was pretty late (9:45pm -- 15 min before closing). We were very glad that they seated us, even though it was so close to closing. Everything we ordered was amazing, well spiced, super delicious, and it all made us feel good. We finished every little bit of food they brought out to us, from every little crumb of the papdum, to the last drop of that oh, so scrumptious sambar, to even the bed of greens on which they laid the onion pakoras (well, what can I say? We were hungry!!).

The service there is always attentive, helpful, and friendly. =)

Well, since our first time there was so great, we've become regulars. We usually find ourselves going to Dosa more when we don't feel like doing dishes, but it's really just because my boyfriend or I want those pakoras! Sometimes we even end up going twice a week... You can say we're addicted. It's gotten so bad that I've had to remind my boyfriend that we'd already been their two nights in a row and the staff there will make us join DA (Dosaholics Anonymous).

Oh, and as a bonus for Mondays and brunch on Saturdays and Sundays, they serve these yummy chaat dishes... because you know that anything fried has to taste good... =)
author: Miss C.

description: Don't waste your time . .   it looks all cute and warm inside but stay away!!  There is fantastic Indian food to be had in SF . . . try India Clay Oven or Raja or of you want something a little different then go Himalayan - just don't go here.
author: Valerie D.

description: I went to Dosa under some duress with my eyebrows raised and my palate somewhat biased. I am a diasporic South Indian and dosas are a a staple in my house. My instincts did not lie!! $11.00 for a slightly large paper dosa? Highway robbery! They don't even give you enough palya (the potatoes in the center) if you get a masala dosa, and they skimp on chutney in general. In addition, their chutney isn't even CARA aka SPICY! Don't go to a restaurant to pay $11.00 for what you can get for $3.00 (or in my case free at my mom's house..) at a better, smaller, less snobby restaurant. My favorite part? Exchanging looks of pure incredulity with the other Indos at the restaurant...
author: Yaamini R.

description: We arrived at Dosa at 6:30 on a Friday evening. The hostess sat us at the bar (which I prefer as opposed to going straight to the table, an extra libation never hurt anyone) and told us it would be about 10 mins for a table. It wasn't that crowded yet, but the tables were full. Sure enough, 10 mins later our table was ready and a people bomb had exploded in the restaurant. There were people everywhere and it stayed that way all night long. After having the food, I understand why. The spectrum of spices and tastes we encountered over dinner was phenomenal. Lentil dumplings, Indian crepes (or dosas, which is what the restaurant is named after), curries, gulab jamoon (fried milk balls)... Wow, thinking back on dinner makes my mouth water.
author: Bucky K.

description: Don't believe the hype! Spendy,  trendy, and lackluster food. After all the hype and wonderful reviews that I read I had extremely high hopes for Dosa. Unfortunately those high hopes were dashed upon the rock of discontent as I took my first bite of my dosa...not nice. I will not go back and I highly recommend a visit to Amma Cafe in Vienna Virginia. It's 1/3 the price and kicks some major Dosa ass.
author: Robert J.

description: You better be able to handle HOT, spicy food...ask about each dish.  The concept of what is "hot" is definitely subjective.  Had to send my dish back...beautifully prepared, but made my nose run.  They were gracious and did not charge me...brought me something else.  Service is excellent. Peach and avocado is ambrosia...but I doubt authentic.  Deserts are very good. Dosas are very good.  A little expensive.  Not too noisy.  Once again, great staff.
author: Felice K.

description: I like this location a bite more than the one in my hood.  Service was much friendlier and overall it just had a much more comfortable vibe. Great, bold flavors. Good service. Endless options of dosa are great to try!
author: Danielle R.

description:
UPDATE 3: New tasting menu! Try all your favorites in one meal without bustin your pants! You get your choice of two perfectly paired wines with each of the three courses, and each person gets to order their own dishes, so if you are over family style or small plates, this is your best option (though you could obviously each order different things for each course and share). My companion also noted that with the tasting menu, you don't have to negotiate several plates of large overhanging dosas at a smal table. 

I had the uber-fresh mung bean salad starter, and the reduced-serving portions of paneer dosa and lamb curry. Dessert: their perfect unsweetened chai and creamy saffron ice cream, all with impeccable service. They can easily do the tasting menu for vegans and veggies. And it's a great value--about $32 without wine and $50ish a person with.

Now I can get my Dosa on and still not be too full to go dancing afterward!!

UPDATE 2: The best brunch I've had in the City to date!! Can you say "Organic egg Uttpatam"?!!  Holy Shiva, Shakti, and Hanuman, I will faithfully be back to your door again very soon! 

UPDATE 1: Been back many times now and keep trying new, amazing things--try the pepper chicken curry and the lamb curry. I licked the bowl when they weren't looking. Dosa also just made Michael Bauer's Top 100 Restaurant list! They are here to stay. 
______________________________________________________
Went to the pre-opening of this amazing new south indian restaurant last night. I had never had dosas, so I don't have anything to compare it to, but I do recognize delicious. Dosas are large South Indian crepes made from rice flour and fermented lentil flour batter. Fillings are customarily vegetarian and include potatoes, vegetables, and chiles. We started our meal with a lentil tomato soup that was light and spicy enough to ward off colds for the rest of the season. The paneer cesar salad was also perfect--the cheese not too fried and the dressing not overpowering. The boyfriend loved the fresh-tasting cucumber salad. Then the dosas! We had a lacey Rava dosa with blended potato and cashew nut filling as well as a traditional dosa with paneer that was surprisingly delectable for something so seemingly simple. The chutneys that accompanied them (cilantro and mint, tomato, and a spicy, gravyesque one) were all perfection. The wine list was short but well chosen (the cab franc went especially well with the richer chicken dishes), and lambic beer and soju cocktails (including a "russian chai" which is a delicious twist on a white russian) round out the beverage selection. Don't wear a belt so you can enjoy the dessert--the paneer with sweet cream is rich but worth it. The owners Anjan and Emily are sure to succeed with this well-thought out menu, warm yet modern atmosphere, and cheerful, attentive service.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
I've become a fan.  We had to wait about half an hour to get a table for two (they only take reservations for parties of 5 or more), but it was truly worth the wait.  I had the paper masala dosa (thin, crispy long rolled crepe-type deal with a potato filling), served with truly tasty sambar (soup, basically) and chutneys (dipping sauces).  For some reason, the masala aspect (meaning the potato mixture) of my paper masala dosa was served up in a separate bowl rather than stuffed within it, whereas the regular masala dosa came stuffed.  Either way, the taste was great!  The pappadum (salty fried chips-type things) they provided before taking the order was good too, and they have a nice, extensive list of drinks.

You have the option of getting a 4-course meal for $35 (meaning a soup, starter, entree, and dessert), but honestly unless you're like SUPER hungry, I think just going straight to the dosa will work just fine.  I am a total hulk, and this satiated me.  I'm a little disappointed that I, unlike other reviewers, did not receive a cultural lesson on the cuisines of India! :\ Oh well. Maybe because we were both brown.

Note that this is not a good place for you if you prefer your Indian restaurants and the people within them to be a living, breathing museum of ethnic stereotypes.  There are no servers dressed in maharaja uniforms, bowing politely to the backdrop of melodious flute and sitar music. Also, don't ASSume that this isn't real Indian food because there is no nan, tandoori chicken, or samosas; we are by no means a monolithic people, and each region has its own cuisine.  Contrary to what some reviews have stated, the dosas look and taste pretty like the ones actually found in South India (not that cross-cultural culinary experimentation would be a problem anyway).  It's just the very trendy decor and hipster-Mission look of the restaurant (including the staff) and the music (er, don't know what the genre is called, but it wasn't Indian) that give it the feeling of "fusion." And what's wrong with that?
author: Leena K.

description: What's the point? Don't believe what I say, read the reviews. It's all true?!! Why, oh why, do i live in LA when there are places like dosa, oh so far away???
author: Deidre H.

description: Hip crowd, packed, and nice to see South Indian in the Mission, but personally thought the dosas and uttapams were not as good as at places like Udupi Palace in Sunnyvale.  Food seemed a bit americanized, but maybe that was intentional given the target audience.  caveat: I've only been to Dosa once and I'm not Indian or an Indian food expert but I do love Indian food.
author: Chris P.

description:
review number: 423
number of stars: 4.5
number of dosas ordered: 4
number of minutes waiting for dosas: 3
number of minutes waiting for desserts: 2
number of people waiting in line to get into this place: 56156048953

Just go. It's good. It's a different Indian food experience. The service is fast.

Tips: 
*go before 6pm to avoid the crowds. 
*soju cocktails are pretty good
*dosas are HUGE, order one per person if hungry, one per 2 people if you're not so hungry
*reservations accepted for 5 or more people
author: Caroline C.

description: Me and my best friend went here because we both wanted Indian food and had never been there before. Let me tell you, we won't be going back. There were no samosas on the menu (what kind of Indian restaurant doesn't have samosas?!?!!!!!!!) and the food was WAY overpriced. It never even said "organic" or "local" to justify the pricing. The food took way too long to come out and the restaurant was stuffy and crowded. The servers were very nice, but they were so busy that they were slow. It was interesting having an Indian crepe but the best thing in the restaurant was the complimentary lentil bread.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Our first and last trip to Dosa. What a disaster! My husband and I love south Indian food and do not mind driving to Berkeley or the South Bay for it. But I am seven months pregnant and wanted to try south indian food close to home. We were told that it would be a forty minute wait. We waited an hour 30 minutes!! I almost fainted by the end of the wait. To their credit, the service staff was polite and gave me a chair to sit on. but twice they gave a table to people who walked in half hour after us. Granted, it was a table for four but there were plenty of couples who had been waiting a while and would have been happy to share a table for four. We were pretty mad and exhausted when we finally got to sit. They got the starters out right away but the food took a really long time to come. We started with the Rasam and the calamari. The rasam tasted like it was out of a box but the calamari was actually good. For entrees, we ordered the Rava Dosa and the pepper chicken. Both were extremely mediocre and nothing to write home about.  
So if you have to wait more than 20 minutes to get a table, just drive to berkeley and eat at either Priya or Udipi, both offering wonderful no-frills south indian food that is far more authentic. 
A message for those who just keep sitting there once they are done eating while the line outside just keeps getting longer (the owner finally had to hint to a group of 3 who were all to happy to just sit their half hour after their check had arrived. They started with a group of 5 and two left while the other three just kept talking for half hour )-shame on you!! One evening, you will be  waiting outside and the talk will just not seem that pleasant.
author: ash s.

description: The food was delicious and the service was amazing. Thanks Z. I've never had dosa before this and I'm a convert. The only thing that kept this from being a 5 star was their desserts. Not like they were ok they were inedible. One was this cottage cheese thing in what tasted like simple syrup and the other... Just avoid em. But other than that it was amazing.
author: Josh F.

description: One of the best curries i've had in the US, this is food so good that you just want people to stop talking as you chew because your sure the flavors are harmonized to the point where they must be audible. I went with a friend and we split a dosa and lamb curry and it was brilliant. It was a tuesday evening around 8pm and we didn't have to wait more than 5 minutes, but the place was buzzing, I would hate to try and get in here on a friday or a saturday. The service was great and  as we identified ourselves as Dosa newbs our waitress provided some good advice and didn't try to sell us.  Even with a couple of drinks the meal came to $45 excluding tip and considering the quality of the food i consider that a great deal.
author: Karl L.

description:
I've been trying to get into Dosa for over a year now.  Every time I go I never have a reservation, only a desperate hope and prayer that a table for two might be opening up sometime in the next hour for me and my dining partner.  Alas, my prayer goes unanswered as I'm turned away time and time again by a line of people outside and a hostess who is unable to accommodate my hunger pangs and desire for that large South Indian crepe craving that can only be cured by a whopping dosa.  Tonight, however, God looked kindly upon me and my friend as we were told a table would be available in 15 minutes.  I was about to get my dosa fix!  I haven't had a dosa since I visited India four years ago, but I distinctly remember how much I enjoyed it.  I've been hearing great things about Dosa and the excellent South Indian cuisine since it opened on Valencia.  Needless to say, after this many attempts and all the hype, I was ready to be disappointed.  I was not.

The meal started off right with the friendly and courteous owner himself, Anjan taking our order and making some helpful recommendations (I was so hungry and eager that I was about to order food for the next three days and he held me back).  We started off with the Chennai Chicken which was a delicious mix of spicy kick calmed by the cool yogurt dipping sauce.   We then proceeded to share the Masala Dosa which was deliciously paired with the flavorful chutneys and superbly prepared sambar.  We also ordered the Prawn Coconut Curry and the Tamil Lamb Curry which were both extraordinary.  I expected that they would be too spicy, salty or sweet.  They were both perfectly seasoned and the not overpowering at all.  Every bite of the curries mixed with the basmati rice or Uttapam was a pleasure to consume.  The portions were very reasonable and we had plenty of food leftover to take home.  The prices were very very reasonable and the portions very generous for any Indian restaurant, much less one of this caliber.  The service was excellent and the waitstaff very attentive.   

If you haven't had South Indian food, I highly recommend trying it out.  This ain't your momma's Chicken Tikka Masala and Naan we're talking about here.  It's totally different from the mainstream Indian fare.  Anjan and his wife know how to run a restaurant.  He must have come over to our table 3 or 4 times to talk to us about the food and our experience.   That level of attention always stands out to me because an owner who cares that much about his food and patrons demonstrates how much he loves his restaurant.  We were around when things were slowing down and chatted with him for a bit.  I'm happy that a guy that nice is having this type of success with his first restaurant.  I can't wait to try out the new Dosa when it opens in Lower Pac Heights!!!
author: Dave L.

description:
the only thing that differentiates dosa from udupi place down the street is fresh ingredients.  to some this is what differentiates a good restaurant from a bad one.  for dosa, it's only a slight difference.

w/ a more modern indian/american look, dosa makes itself more presentable and therefore attract more of the hip trendy crowd.  the food is just a notch above udupi but the prices are a few dollars higher.  for the same dinner we had, i think we would've paid at least $10 less.

this place is crowded and they don't accept reservations for 2 people.  so get their early and consider the bar, which is what we did.  you can order anything off of the menu but your space is quite limited so hold back from ordering the paper dosa.  the bartender that waited on us was quite indifferent and wasn't too enthused, either.

we started w/ the north/south samosa and puri.  the samosas were decent but a bit too salty.  thankfully the tamarind sauce was there to counteract that.  my wife felt the tamarind and mint sauces were both store bought rather than made in house.  the puri was nice and light and not oily at all so that was a nice surprise.

for the main dish, i had gotten the mysore masala dosa and she got the plain masala dosa.  the mysore dosa is made w/ a different batter and has a nicer flavor to it.  the masala inside is a combo of peas, onions and potatoes.  we liked each of our dishes but didn't think that they were incredible.  the dosa itself was nice and crisp though mine had spots where it became soggy and stuck to the bottom of my plate.  the sambar that came w/ our dosas was very good.

we were so full that we had no room for dessert and opted for the check (which comes to you right away at the bar).  i don't see a pressing need to go back to dosa.  i feel any udupi palace would satisfy me equally if not more.
author: Swarup B.

description: The wait probably isn't worth it (sometimes you can bart to berekely in just about the same amount of time), but if you catch them during a lull, the food is good, if you can stand the crowds and get over paying Rs. 500 for a mediocre dosa. That said, I'm not aware of anywhere else in the city that serves uttapam.
author: Blaine C.

description:
4.75 (no oinky, this does not make it to a 5) =D

Ok, one thing you should know once in for all - I am not a Mission gal, ok, well excoosy moi, i haven't fully indulged myself in the foodie section but the bars, please, don't even bother converting my "district views" - been there, done that.... It's just not me, it's just not my style, nor is it my scene, and speaking of which, I am also not a Marina gal, thank you very much...

and yet,
Dosa -- *pause* -- is a different story. Dosa is fantastic! One very delicious S. Indian fare located right in the Mission...

Vibe, presentation, food quality, service, everything was great - paying less than $100 for dinner, minus the drinks w/5 solid dishes was well worth it, but of course, let me just say the downfalls before I get to the foodie part. Parking was slightly a bitch and the place can get a bit too squishy but the food - delicious! The red/orangey walls and the paintings throughout definitely made it cozy. It can get a bit loud, so enjoy it!

*Cochin calamari ($9.50) definitely not your ordinary crispy, battered calamari. had quite this funky spicy punch, but it was well balanced and tasty!
*Rava Masala Dosa ($11) - good...
*Spicy Mung Dosa ($11)-- tasty...
*Tamil Lamb Curry ($16.50) - my favorite! mmm *must get w/the coconut rice*
*Baby Eggplant Curry ($12) - so so, but yum
*Coconut Rice w/Curry ($2.50) - yummy
*Rice Side w/curry ($2.50)--fair. Just rice w/curry. what do you expect?

Everything was perfectly marinated! I can't remember what each and one of them tasted like now because I'm sick *AGAIN?* and my head is a bit foggy, so...  I'm wondering if this fog is having to be in SF a bit too long... Anyways, just think of the dosa like a crepe... 

Drinks - average $9 and up.

TIP: sure, I'd HIGHLY recommend you in making a ressie, but do prepare to wait approx 30 mins.. I don't get that, but minus that, I recommend this place. 

It is and was, --indeed-- quite, a DELIGHTFUL treat!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
UPDATE 4/21/06:  I'm giving Dosa 5 duckets. Since going I continuously dream about the place. No other Indian place will do.  Also DJ Hardkaur has confirmed that this place is, to quote JJ Walker, "DYNOMITE!!"  Sorry Big V! You can have your South Bay, but weez keepin' to DOSA. 
_______________________________________________________

So there we were, out in "The Mish." The plan was to hook up at Dosa to try the new "off-da-hook," South Indian restaurant in the Ci-tay. Big V was waiting for us out front. "It's going to be 40 minutes man" he says when I pull up. I double checked with the hostess, but when Big V's right he's right.  The joint was jumpin'. Got the brush off, "Already told you it was going to be an hour. It's only been 20 minutes."  We were at a cross roads. Big V felt it was worth the wait, so we headed over to The Latin American for a couple of pre-dinner cocktails until din din. Well my fine peeps, it was worth the wait. Interior is done up in warm and festive colors. The lady of the crew had a Lychee Lush (Lychee infused Soju)  while Big V and I split some Taj Mahals. We gobbled up the Chennai Chicken (lightly deep fried madras spiced chicken bits drizzled with squeezed lemon) Followed perfection with perfection: Paneer Dosa was amazing; Idli Vada Sambar; Onion Rava Dosa, Mysor Dosa (thick onion pancake sort of) that we dipped in a spicy soup .... The entire event an entirely spice and taste joy ride. We walked away satisfied, forgetting that we waited an hour for dinner.  4 duckets for the fantabulous food. Minus 1/2 a ducket for the long wait, and another 1/2 for what Big V said, "Yes man, it was good, but it's just as good in the south bay man...and less expensive."  I'll gladly forgo paying the price of gas to the S. Bay and eat at Dosa.
author: Johnny C.

description:
I make a lot of mistakes. I mean who doesn't? 
But I like to make this one mistake over and over again I think I am trying to get it just right. It goes something like this. Open mouth pour as much liquor in as you can. Swallow. Repeat until you can no longer stand. The problem though comes the next day. Then after a few hours of agony I resume the repeat portion. 
That one mistake leads me to other mistakes like going to a very crowded Dosa inebriated with my vegetarian best friend and my carnivorous cilantro phobic boyfriend for the first time. 
The menu at Dosa is large and pretty complicated. I did not understand this until it was too late. 
And by too late I mean when we are seated and have asked for more liquor at which point the BF gives up on deciphering through his vodka haze and puts me and the vegetarian in charge. 
When I am drunk I want to grunt and point at pictures of food. 
Somehow we manage to pick some things and the waitress gives her approval for our choices. This is the part where I am supposed to say to her "Uh did we order anything that doesn't have cilantro in it?" I forget that step. 
Apparently my BF also forgets this step. BC when food starts showing up and I ask the other waitress the important question she laughs at me. Of course there is cilantro in everything. I know this. 
Oh well. BF eats the pepper chicken and deems it quite good while the veg and I get down with the paper Dosa which was really good, especially the dipping soup, I can't remember what that was called but it was great. The one thing that we had which I would not recommend was some kind of lentil patty covered in this major sauce pool which none of us really understood or liked. 
So i guess the important lesson here is have your wits about you when you go here. You will need your brain.
Learn from my mistakes people because one of us has to and it is certainly not gonna be me!
author: Melissa H.

description: The food at Dosa is all delicious! I chose Dosa as a dinner spoke for a ladies night out - it was easy to get a reservation using their online system and when we were a little late they graciously accommodated us. Thank you for a great dinning experience!
author: Sadie W.

description: I loves me some Indian food and I thought this was a nice change from what I'm used to.  I'm not craving this stuff...yet but I'd come back and try it again!  No ring of fire...hoooray!
author: Ramon L.

description: Really good, slightly expensive South Indian food. My Indian friends tell me that the food is perfectly spiced. A good wine and beer list and friendly servers, in a lovely setting.
author: Cyrelle D.

description:
Update: I have since returned about five times and have upgraded Dosa from 4 to 5 stars.  Its just always really really great.  I have never once had anything on the menu that I didn't point to about every third bite and say "this is good, really f#$%ing good" to my dining companions.  The paper dosa is to die for.  and the dehi vada (sp?) is unbelievable - a order it every time and wish I had twice as much kinda dish.  The only downside is that with the new "top ten of 2006" rating, and being so unbelievably tasty on its own, it is really really busy most nights - but I am willing to wait... you won't be disappointed.
Stumbled in a bit drunk after some backyard party last saturday night...sat at the bar and was really impressed.  I had walked by last Mother's Day and saw a ton of Indian families waiting for tables, which i took as a good sign.  I can't believe it took us months to get in here.   Had a really amazing lentil cake thing with these mint, coriander and other great sauces.  The dosa was great, the curry was really nicely spiced and the leftovers ended up being a creative scramble breakfast the next morning.
author: amy b.

description: Dosa is the hands down the best Indian food I have ever had. The food is  fantastic and the atmosphere is beautiful. The service is excellent as well. Favorite dish: Dahi Vada (Lentil dumplings, organic yogurt, tamarind and mint). The unique blend of flavors created a taste that i dream about.
author: Tam C.

description: I visited Dosa with some coworkers and friends last night, and we had a wonderful time. They accomodated our party of nine with no problems, and since it was the first time most of us had tried South Indian cuisine, the server was helpful in providing some great recommendations. The dosa and curries (especially the veggie curry)  were incredible, and I cannot wait to go back. The Lychee Lush (homemade lychee-infused soju) was dangerously good as well.  The bill for dinner for the nine of us (which included about one drink each, six appetizers, two dosa, one uttapam sampler plate, three curries, tax and tip) came out to less than $30/person.
author: Naomi F.

description: The food at Dosa is decent, but unfortunately the service is  not. I have eaten there 3 times now and every time it is the service I have been disappointed with. This last time, my husband asked to take the remainder of his meal to go, and I kid you not- the waitress rolled her eyes at him! Then, just after that, she was rude to the table next to us and we overheard them discussing how unhappy they were with the service. Although this restaurant is only a block from me and I love Indian food, I won't be returning.
author: Terry M.

description:
I have to laugh at the people who think this is such a great restaurant.  I went there with a party of eight last night and we ordered quite a few different things.  None of them were particularly memorable.  Decent but very overpriced relative to much tastier Indian food.  One of things that i enjoy at indian restaurants are the condiments and the sauces.  The condiments were minimal, less tasty than at the cheaper Nan and Curry style places, and the sauces were also less exciting.  Certainly nothing memorable.  The waiters were attentive, but a bit patronizing, acting like we had never tried Indian food before.... please.

This place would get a three as the food was decent, if the prices were even close to reasonable.  It is not good value and the higher-end experience they are attempting to provide is mostly to get you to enjoy their wine list and the specials.  I love Indian food but have no interest in going back.
author: Reginald F.

description: Over rated, over priced, not worth with the wait.  Food is mediocre at best, bland, inauthentic and uninspired.  Would be a largely inoffensive restaurant, but the crowds push it over the edge into bad.
author: kellan e.

description: The Fare was great, the service was less than par. The waitress messed up our order several times. She may just have been having a bad night, but she wasn't very accommodating about it. She left out 2 main dishes, 2 drinks , and got one order wrong for a party of 6. This all just as the kitchen was closing.. she replaced the main dishes with more Dosa and rice.. but still not enough to fill us. I was annoyed. The food was good, the service was something less.
author: Danielle A.

description:
I had twice eaten very well at Dosa, so when my parents wanted to try a new restaurant, I suggested going there on a recent Tuesday night. Unfortunately, while the food was good, we had a very unpleasant incident with our waitress, who made it very clear how little she cared about what kind of  experience we had. I will not be going back.

We were a very friendly party, relaxed and in the mood to have a good time, and everything started out fine. We were early for our reservation, but were seated within five minutes. We ordered two bottles of wine, and four appetizers for the table to share, and seemed to have a nice rapport with our waitress. The wine and appetizers were served in good time, and we were all enjoying ourselves. Things were off to a great start.

Then, three of us were served our entrees. No problem -- we waited a few minutes, expecting the rest of the food to come out shortly, or for the waitress to notice and tell us what was going on. (I think they have food runners, because our food was served by a combination of different people, none of whom would speak to us). When nothing happened after a reasonable amount of time (maybe 10 minutes?), we flagged down our waitress to let her know we were still waiting on four dishes. She said she would check with the kitchen, and came by again shortly to say there was a mistake and they were doing what they could to fix it.  

At this point, she started to get a little aggressive - like we had been giving her a hard time or something. Which we had not be doing at all - we were all still very nice. "No problem," we said. She walked away, without giving any indication of how long we'd have to wait, or offering to bring those waiting on dishes anything to tide them over.

Five minutes later, or so, a fourth dish came out. Then, nothing. After another ten minutes, we thought we had better let our waitress know we were still waiting - she had not come by to check on us. Again, we caught her attention and politely let her know that we still needed three dishes. 

At this point, she snapped at us, saying that "the kitchen is already aware of it!!!" And stalking off. We were stunned! Many of us at the table have worked in food service, and it did not seem unreasonable to inquire politely about food that was taking a very long time - we just wanted to make sure it hadn't been overlooked - she's the one who can talk to the kitchen staff, not us. By the time the last dish had been served, those of us who had been served first had been done eating for quite some time. 

Again, we ate well, and had a nice time. The only real problem with the meal was the waitress's attitude. I am sure she was stressed, it was busy, but she was very unpleasant with us. I might be paranoid, but I had the feeling that she felt she could brush us off because, as a large table, our 20 percent tip was going to be added to the tab no matter what happened.

Eventually, the waitress came over with four dishes of ice cream (not enought for the whole table) and offered what I suppose was an apology (she never actually said, we are so sorry, and I'm sorry I snapped at you) for the food arriving at all different times. She ended with an aggressive, "You're night isn't ruined, right?" 

Well, of course not, but we thought for sure she would not add the compulsory 20 percent tip and let us decide for ourselves how much her service was worth. But, she did indeed add the service charge. (The manager did come by to offer us a more heartfelt apology for the mix up, which we appreciated. By then, however, it was too late.)

In the end, our objection was NOT that there was a kitchen mix up. As frequent restaurant diners, and former restaurant workers, we understand that can and does happen, and that it's nobody's fault, especially (usually) not the wait staff's. 

However, what we did object to was her prickly behavior when we asked about our meals. The message she gave us was that she didn't really care if we had a good experience at Dosa. 

The food at Dosa is very good, so it's sad for me to say this, but because of the poor treatment we experienced, I will not be going back.
author: A O.

description:
only if you arrive in a large group can you really experience this place fully (careful with the reservation number, they are sticklers).  south indian cuisine can be harder to come by sometimes, since a lot of places typically focus on north indian.

everything we had was flavorful and delicious
if you order the following, I can guarantee a good meal:
Fiery Fruit -- good
Chennai Chicken -- intense flavor
Spinach vadas --probably the weakest
Chatni Masala Dosa -- scrumptious
Paper Masala -- sometimes the flavors start merging
Paneer & Peas Uttapam
Prawn Coconut Masala -- don't forget the rice
Channa Bhatura -- probably the best thing
Raita -- balance the spice
Mango Lassi, of course
would pass on the dessert next time
author: Rob C.

description: I really want to like this place but I always seem to order at least one thing I don't like. The dosa themselves are a bit overwhelming in size and made me gassy. There is also only beer and wine so I suggest sticking to one of those, they make some sake cocktails but they aren't so good.  Coconut curry was good and I really like the soup.
author: betsy P.

description: The food was worth 4 starts, but the pretentious waiter/manager kicks it down a notch. I can enjoy my food without having to "manage dynamic flavor profiles". I love food, but man...just calm down
author: Dave B.

description:
Good food but be prepared to wait (and wait and wait).  There are two hostesses at this small place but they were apparently hired for some reason other than competency (maybe the owner is into rainbow hair).  Their MO seems to be to tell everyone that the wait is 20 or 30 minutes, though 60 to 90 minutes is more typical.  If you have a group of 5 or more you can make a reservation; that reduces waiting to 30 or 40 minutes.

If you get tired of waiting the Indian/Pakistani place just a block south on Valencia street is quite good and the service is much better.
author: Peter H.

description: I am deathly allergic to cashews. We told the wait staff at Dosa who promptly provided us with a list of food with and without specific nuts. However, even though we were extremely careful about what we ordered, I still went into anaphylactic shock.  Something  we ordered must have touched a cashew in the kitchen. I won't be eating at Dosa again. Be very careful if you have nut allergies there.
author: Victoria Z.

description:
There's nothing new left to say really..

We spent about $150 (including tip) for one appetizer, 4 entrees, 4 drinks and one dessert.

Even if you go on an off night, you'll probably want to make a reservation as it took more than 40 mins for us to be seated even though, after we got in, it didn't look like every table was full (and they originally said it'd only be a 20 min wait).  In terms of service, we had two waitresses, one nice and one a bit gruff.  One oddity about this place is that all the tables are really quite close together, so close that you can easily overhear another table's conversation because you're sitting thisclose to them.

The food is pretty good and nicely spicy, although it's trendy South Indian for a western palate (as evinced by their menu descriptions).  I thought the dosa portions were pretty big and reasonably priced.  It's the alcohol and appetizers that are pricey.  They serve (complimentary) pappadam at the beginning but no chutney, unlike most other Indian restaurants.  It's also weird to charge extra for stuff like achar/condiments.. which is typically part and parcel of a traditional Indian meal..
author: Bees S.

description: Terrific addition to the Valencia strip! The food is delicious, mostly vegetarian, and a good value. Our group of 7 made a reservation for a Tuesday night and it was packed-- we did have to wait for about 15 minutes. (One should note that only parties of 5 or more can make reservations.) Not a problem and the hostess was very sweet. Unfortunately the rest of the service was a bit spotty. We had to ask for items a couple of times and one server really wanted to regulate our wine choices. He was slightly condescending. Still, I have faith that with time the service will improve and I will definitely return. Who knew I was such a fan of South Indian cuisine?
author: Michie L.

description:
i have no idea what all the fuss is about when it comes to dosa.  sorry, but the food here just isn't that good, in my experience.  i've been here 4 - 5 times and the food and service has always been mediocre at best.

there was also that one special time when THEIR DOSA GRILL BROKE, so their namesake meal was, um, missing from the menu that night. lame.

there are much tastier indian options in the mission, like aslam's rasoi.
author: Elle B.

description:
So, we went to Dosa on the opening night and go back a couple times a month now. I've tried a lot of things on the menu, my previous experience with South Indian foods being in Bangalore and the South Bay. The dosas are excellent. I even like the non-traditional cheddar cheese dosa. It's like a quesadilla and it's fantastic. I'm in favor of evolving cuisines, afterall, if noone experimented, we would eat the same boring shiite all the time. I love the channa bhatura, but the portion is enormous. It's kind of daunting to feel like you have to finish that enormous bowl of channa and even more enormous piece of deep-fried bread. For idlis, no one makes them as tender as mom does, so I recommend getting vada or dosa if you like sambar. The chennai chicken is sooo delicious it's guilt inducing. The curries are all excellent. My favorite chutney is the tomato chutney. I'd like to see the other chutney be a green chutney with cilantro in it. That fresh green taste would really round out the flavors. Now the ambiance at Dosa is pretty good. It's loud inside, but wonderfully decorated in a non-tacky fashion. It's not cafeteria style like all those places in the Peninsula. The crowd is distinctly good-looking, and it's a great place for people watching. You will do this because the wait is long, even if you're a friend of the owners or did the art on the walls (that was me) the hostess will still make you wait. The busboys are really sweet though, and the barpeople are pretty good. The Mango Seed cocktail of mango lassi and soju is super yummy and the wine list is thoughtful and increasing all the time. Well to sum it up, the food is really quite good, very nice ambiance that is a little loud, and the waitstaff is hit or miss. The portions are way too big, so don't go there alone if you want to try out more than one dish.  When the owners are on site, as they often are, they go out of their way to say hello and try to seat us. More often than not, we eat at the bar, which is a good option if you don't want to wait for a table. Five stars!

By the way, this is a "hello"  for all the morons who wonder why they don't serve naans at Dosa.  I don't even know why you bother reviewing it. South Indian food is a completely different cuisine! And the little "sticks" in the sambar are a very yummy vegetable called "drumstick". You actually strip away the flesh with your teeth. They add an essential flavor to the sambar.  ANyway, please take your $7 and go back to Naan and Curry because the line is long and I don't want to wait in it for an hour only to hear you gripe about there being no Chicken Tikka Masala. F-you.
author: Darcy V.

description: This restaurant has quickly jumped up to the top of my list.  The Mysora Masala Dosa is divine!  It's one of my favorite dishes anywhere.  The wine list is great and the service is perfect.  Very comforting ambiance.  This is one of those types of restaurants that you once again have to thank goodness you live in San Francisco (as if you don't already have enough reasons).  And for us Vegans, they even bring out an info sheet of each of the dishes and whether they are Vegan or if they can be made Vegan!   Thank you!
author: Roy J.

description: This restaurant made me wish I lived in San Francisco . . . well, that among many other things, but this is significant nonetheless.  Fancy-but-not-too-fancy ambiance and mood, DELICIOUS food, great drinks, and wonderful service.  Our waitress was really patient and friendly as we bombarded her with various drink and food recommendations, and she brought my friend an unbelievable bowl of gelato with a candle in it for his birthday.  We went on a Saturday and had over an hour wait, but it was totally worth it.  Come, put your names down, then take a walk around Valencia St. and work up a good appetite while you wait.
author: Anna G.

description:
went with a friend after reading a review somewhere that said dosa was good and...romantic, i think? best new romantic mission restaurant? or best romantic new ...restaurant? well, in any event, after several unsuccessful attempts to get said friend to put out, i cut my losses and decided to just enjoy the food and the atmosphere instead. boy were we in for a treat. 

my dining companion had spent time in southern india living with a host family, so she actually had somewhat of a point of reference in terms of the food at dosa. she told me about dosas, which are sort of like pancakes or crepes that you can dip into a variety of mind-blowing chutneys, lentils, sauces, etc. the best thing about this meal is that we always had at least four things to dip the dosa into at any given moment, and they all somehow worked in concert with one another flavor-wise; it's like some sort of complicated chemistry of flavors that i fear i will never understand, but that's all right--let the professionals at dosa understand it for me, and i will continue to come back, perhaps even when i have someone to romance... 

the food is very affordably priced--my friend and i got soy chais, an appetizer (idli, which she said she hadn't had since her time in india, which made her very excited--they were bready dumpling-like things that are apparently made from lentils and were swimming in delicious seasoned vegetables/broth), and two meals, and the total bill was under $30. maybe it's because the server, either intentionally or unintentionally, omitted the 2 chais from our bill. in any event, that saved us $6. by arriving early (around 5:45 on a saturday), we beat the evening rush and snagged one of two window tables without a reservation. the place quickly filled up after we were seated.
