try the paper dosa if you want them to bring out a HUGE piece of crispy dosa that, from afar, looks like a ginormous hollow baguette. try the spring dosa for fresh veggies wrapped in a softer dosa. overall, dosa is very affordable, savory, swank, and yes--romantical.
author: Marla W.

description: Dosa is an upscale Indian restaurant with a nice atmosphere.  With a party of five, we ordered all different types of dosas to try. I was impressed with how they were each presented in such a different style.  All were yummy, though I found the meal to be a little greasy and starchy overall.  Since I'm sensitive to greasy food, I probably should have asked for them to go light on the oil, but now I'll know for next time!  I love the salad with mango in it.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Not pretending to know the difference between uttapam and dosa, I ordered both the caramelized onion uttapam and the spring dosa at Dosa. 

I'll be damned if I still can't tell one from the other, but I can tell you that they were equally good.  My date was also highly approving of the papadum; before we'd been served, he declared himself anti-papadum, but tasting it, he changed his tune.

I also appreciate this message on the Dosa Web site: "We'll be glad to serve you as long as you walk in before closing!"  That seems fair.  (Unless you're Oprah, and you're paying a visit to Hermes.)
author: Hannah J.

description: Unlike other diners, I seemed to have a horrid experience.  First my mango lassi gave me food poisoning!  My friend had the salt lassi and had the same experience. So maybe the yogurt was simply off...but serious the restaurant should check the freshness of their dairy products.  Second, my masala dosa filling was not cooked properly.  The potatoes were still hard and undercooked.  Masala dosa is a staple and it's made a specific way in Kerala...this simply was not it.  I give it the second star just for the decor...the glass panels towards the kitchen and restroom reminded me of patty fields (rice fields for those who have never traveled to Kerala).  Good use of colour and texture.  But the food needs examining.  I may be overly critical b/c I am South Indian and this simply was not up to par, but seriously this was not good.
author: Jolsna J.

description: I swear the only reason I am obsessed with this place is because I want to introduce the best of South Indian cuisine to all my friends. It's a good thing. The only shame is I don't roll here with a larger group so we can try more dishes. I hear everything is amazing but I can't seem to expand past the app of lentil dumplings and yougurt, chile & corriander dosa, shrimp curry, and the incredible beer selection. And they bring you these chips... I want a 10 lb bag of those chips. But only as a present to a special friend. It's a good thing. Once you try these dishes you might stick with them too! It's really a beautiful spot, feels like the real deal and has incredible service. The staff must be getting at those chips.
author: Jean W.

description: This place was fun as a group and it is a blast to share the Indian Dosa and unique rustic southern indian food.  If you want traditional northern fare pick some place else.  This place has big hype but they do take reservations.  Keep your group to 6 or less because it is crowded and they can't accomodate extra chairs pulled up to the table.  Don't forget to have a mango lassi to drink as it is a nice complement to the earthy flavors.  Nice ambiance...if a little noisy
author: Nadia B.

description: love most of the dishes here.  i usually get the chennai chicken for appetizers.  go-to dosas are the spring, paneer and peas, or masala chutney.  the restaurant offers a nice, unpretentious ambience.  i prefer this one to its sister restaurant on fillmore.
author: Helen T.

description:
I like this restaurant and I would MAYBE go back only to bring someone who hasnt been and is really in the mood for indian and the mission experience. But would I go out of my way to go again, NO.

We had a reservation for 3 but showed up with 5, they got us a table in 30 minutes. Great service, really nice host and staff. We chilled at the bar before: great drinks, cool people around, and a good vibe meeting up with friends here.

Food: Samosas were amazing and lentils in the yogurt fantastic as appetizers. Really good stuff. Entrees- the paneer Dosa was great as well as a chicken dish, but the other two things just ok. Our server recommended this onion thing (it was just fried bread) it was such a letdown. Hello: look at your table, 5 health-conscious gay men, do you really think we want to eat a plate of fried bread? NO. It didnt have any ingredients in it like the other Dosa's did. NOT IMPRESSED.

Overall, I think a unique great place, just order carefully and dont order yourself a $10 plate of fried bread that tastes like..

We had drinks at the bar, some more drinks, and good amount of food. Came to $40 a person with tip (bar drinks included too). Not bad.
author: Jared B.

description: I've never had this type of indian food before with the dosa crepe. However, I was pleasantly surprised. the place was really cute and nice, really good service and the meal was really creative and delicious and somewhat light. I left feeling nourished and not weighed down like I usually do after a typical indian meal. I'll enjoy another meal here soon!
author: Liz S.

description: I'm sorry, but this place is over-priced. Yes the food is pretty good, but $17 for a chicken dish?  It only had about 4 pieces of chicken. The paper thin dosa was good but not great. The beer and wine were pretty good.  You spend for money for the ambiance here.
author: H. A.

description:
About a month ago, my friends and I wanted to come here, but there was a line out the door, and people was willing to subjugate them selves to what felt like below 40 degree F temperatures to get in here and dine. Woah, it must be that good huh? We didn't wait to find out.
We decided back then to find a place where we could get a table immediately and out of the cold pronto.
Now, I was back in the bay this weekend to visit friends and have fun, and to get back to civilization for a bit, and wanted to meet up with JC and have dinner. She was game.
As always, she gave me the lead and after a couple minutes of name tossing, we remembered this place. Dosa.
This time, we walk in and talk to the hostess. The place was already crowded, but they said they had a table already available, but would seat us when our 3rd would arrive. Cool.
I had a smoke while we waited and then, right on time, JC show up. Great.
We tell the hostess that we are all here, and she walk us through the dining room.
Wow. Very nice. Warm and elegant.
We sat and ordered some tea to shake the chill from our bones and to look over the menus.

Some one brought us these chips to munch on.
My friend T made a comment about the chips which confused and stopped JC and I from reading the menu.
T: It taste like crab, you know crab chips?
JC: I though you said it taste like crack.
Me: I thought you said it taste like crap.
hahah.....
JC: Haha, crack. Huh? What you been smoking? Hahah...
Back to the menu.

Uh, what the hell? I don't know what any of this is? JC was explaining some of the dishes and even pointing to a couple items that some of the other patrons were receiving letting us know what they were.
Ah..ok. I was still confused.
We got our tea and the server asked if we wanted any other drinks or to start with apps. I jumped on the app order.

Prawn Chili Fry: Prawns rubbed in lentil flour, chili powder & other spices and fried, served with shredded romaine.
Paneer & Romaine: Romaine leaves topped with pieces of lightly fried farmer's cheese, organic cherry tomatoes, and thinly sliced cucumber served in a creamy garlic dressing.
"Sound alright?" I asked my friends. "Sure, what ever."
We like to be random and we like to share in the randomness.

A couple minute later the server came back and my friends finished our ordering with 2 dishes or their choice.
Tamil Lamb Curry: Free-range natural lamb in a sauce of fennel, tomatoes, poppy seeds, caramelized onions and a blend of other spices.
and, an order of
Masala: Uttapam topped with spiced Indian potatoes, onions and cashew nuts.
We chat, laugh, cap and joke and have a great time. And our food begins to arrive, really fast.
Wow.
Since I have no experience in the field of South Indian cuisine, I won't attempt to describe the flavors, textures, colors and aromas of our dishes to you the reader. I feel that it would do it great injustice. But, I will say that it was incredible.
Incredibly delicious and gorgeous. Exotic and spiritual.

On the down side. I feel that out server was over extended. Once we got our orders in and received our meals, we didn't see her. We wanted to order some wine. I kept trying to get her attention, but no luck. Just as we were about to say "fuckit", a person I figured out to be the floor manager asked us about our meal and if we needed anything.
"Yeah, can we get a wine menu please?"

He returned very quickly and gave us a couple minutes to decide before taking our orders.
JC decided on a velvety and spicy Spanish red, and I ordered a soft and sweet Chilean red. Both went well with all out dishes. Very very nice.
As we were finishing up our meal and sitting back and sipping wine, our server finally returns to ask our status. Despite the lack of attention, we were ALL good.
author: Kione E.

description: So in all fairness.... I'll start off by saying I don't think I like Indian food...Once again this was part of the weekend of food with my BF's fam. Beet soup was pretty tasty, I also had a plain dosa with some of the dipping sauces.... It was okay.... I had a few bites of the BF's salad and that was pretty good, but a bit garlicky.... Meh.... Just okay.....
author: Jennifer B.

description: I am not the biggest fan of south indian food but this place changed my mind...the chefs are truly creative and talented!  This food is not fusion but it is definitely a delicious new spin on the traditional menu items.  presentation is lovely all around
author: monana c.

description: I absolutely love this place.  When you see that many Indian people inside an Indian restaurant you better believe it's good.
author: Deepti B.

description: I'm not sure why this place is so popular and why people are willing to wait so long for a table. I've eaten here twice in the past year (gave it a second chance). The uttapams are a little soggy and all the sauces taste the same. I think it's basically the same sauce and they throw in some coconut or an onion or something for different dishes. Also, it's incredibly loud and the music is a bit off, which just adds noise instead of ambiance.
author: Lin N.

description:
Food was alright, but the service was sub-par.

I thank the reviewer who put on there that we should ask for an allergy menu, because you wouldn't know they had one.... they didn't tell me they had one, and it doesn't say anywhere on the regular menu that you can ask for an allergy menu.

Too expensive for mediocre food and bad service. I'll have to try Indian Oven of the Fillmore next time I crave Indian food.
author: Maziar B.

description: Sing it with me now...Ov-er-ra-ted! The fiancée and I like to think of ourselves as connoisseurs of the cheap and dirty Bay Area Indian-Pakistani dives ever since that down-and-dirty gem, Kabana, near our former University Ave and San Pablo pad, won over our hearts and taste buds. From that first fateful evening when we stopped by for some Saag, Kabana became a firmly-entrenched weekly tradition. Fast-forward three years and we are driven to Dosa by the 1000+ positive Yelp reviews on a warm, hungry night out in the Mission. Once inside the famed Dosa, we were similarly  drawn to the Dahi Vada and Chennai Chicken by the fanatical Yelp reviews in their favor. The former was relatively tasteless while the latter was good, but like any fried chicken tenders are good (i.e. not worth 10 bucks). Yes, 'Chennai Chicken' is a fancy name for chicken tenders that couldn't hold a candle to anything you'd get at your local Chick-fil-A. I ordered a glass of gewurztraminer, which rarely disappoints, but managed to do so, and even more so at $12 the glass (d'oh!). The finacée had a significantly more drinkable Spanish red. We ordered the Masala Dosa for our main dish and were left longing for the piping hot Garlic N'aan and  greasy, soupy Masala from Kabana or the literally finger-licking good food of the Ethopian Cafe Colucci in Berkeley. It's not often that a night out in the City has us dreaming of our old digs in Berkeley, but Dosa managed to do the trick. We tried to salvage the meal with dessert, but the Rasmalai, while tastier than the rest of our sub-par supper, was of a funky texture that left us less than impressed. The portions were such that on the way back to our car we almost bought a delicious-smelling sausage from a street-vender on the corner of Capp and 22nd. Needless to say, we won't be back. In short, if you're looking for a stylish venue (which Dosa is), go somewhere with better food (Andalú, Foreign Cinema and Limón are nearby)...and if you're hunkering for good Indian food, even N'aan and Curry will better satisfy your urge and for about $60 less...
author: Matthew Z.

description:
Pretentious way-overpriced Indian food for yuppies who've never been near India.

Okay, the food isn't terrible - not outstanding, but not inedible either.  But the prices - especially for South Indian food - are ridiculous. This is a typically wannabe SF eatery, more about the fake ambience than the actual meal on your plate.  And the ambience isn't even that good - the service wasn't great, and the tables were much too close together, allowing no privacy at all.

Count how many Indians are at Dosa on a typical evening.  Then walk down the block and count how many are at Udupi.  I rest my case.

---

I got a very polite response from the owners, who claim (among other things) that a direct comparison to lower end restaurants is unfair because Dosa uses natural ingredients and observes good business practices.  All of which I greatly respect, actually.  So I added one star.  

But ... the fact remains that when I'm paying a good chunk of my hard earned money for a meal, I have high expectations (about the food, most of all), and Dosa did not meet those expectations.  And although the comparison to much lower priced Indian restaurants may be unfair, it still lurks in the back of my mind.  And I do NOT see a lot of Indians at Dosa, except maybe the i-banking Marina-dwelling kind.  Not that there's anything wrong with that, but it's not my demographic.  Sorry.
author: Michael J.

description: Amazing food!   If you want to plan a great dinner for two or an event, Leonard is the person to call.  Kudos and a great big thank you to the fantastic Manager, Leonard Hughet at the Valencia Street Dosa!!  Leonards is wonderful! Personable, great ideas, attention to detail and he wants you to have a great time!! Amazing personal attention......... So call Leonard!!! Patti L
author: Patti L.

description: Dosa is truly an amazing taste experience.  It's a little tight, a little hot and the food makes your mind pop open like you've never eaten before.
author: Stephen P.

description:
good indian wine
bad burps
hour wait
author: Tabatha Y.

description: OOoOOo I loved the lemon rice, slightly tart and aromatic, excellent when paired with the with Lamb Koftka. The 2 appetizers we ordered were equally amazing--the chicken pieces and prawns, tender pieces smothered in spices. As for the dosa's, I ordered a Mung Masala which was quite yummy. I liked the thin paperie crepe but if you let it sit too long it becomes soft. We ordered several glasses of different whites and for the most part they were all nice wines and paired well with the food. So to top it all off, the prices are fantastic, very affordable. Dosa's my new fav. Indian rest :)
author: Royce L.

description: Insanely, insanely, insanely good. Addictive, even. The spring dosa is my favorite. But the lamb curry is amazing too. AND, bonus, there's this scottish beer they carry that costs $8 a bottle but it has coriander in it, which gives it this incredible chocolatey-ness. That sounds weird but it works. It is almost as addictive as the food. Not cheap, but so very worth it. Eat at the bar if the wait is too long.
author: Luxxury L.

description: Sunday night I got taken out to a belated birthday dinner at Dosa. We didn't make a reservation because we weren't sure what time we'd get there. We arrived around 6:30 and were told it was a 30 min wait for 2 people but we could have an appetizer at the bar. We only had time to order our mango lassis (super thick but tasty)before we already had a table, less than 10 minutes. I almost left when they said the 30 min wait so it's a good thing I didn't!! Both of us had the seasonal tasting menu, which is $35 per person I think, for three courses. Local, organic, seasonal food! Our waitress was very sweet and friendly. For the first course, roomie had the chicken, sort of an Indian chicken nuggets, and I had the pear avocado salad. Both good. For the second course, roomie had the special hot pepper uttapam and I had the sweet pepper sunchoke uttapam. They were both really good, and I think these were the best of the whole meal. Two options on the second course had nuts, but the waitress was able to steer us away from them. For the last course, we both chose the veggie bhatura, which came with a poffy bread. It was good, but lacking in real veggies. I love squash and I had one, maybe two pieces, just one cauliflower bite and one green bean. But mostly potatoes. I'm ok on potatoes but not a super duper fan, I would have liked more veggies. Roomie concurred. Still, really tasty, good sauce and bread. The dessert menu is nut-heavy. We ordered one cool looking carrot dessert that didn't say it had nuts, but when it came, it did. Only the chocolate cake doesn't, and I wasn't in a chocolate cake mood, but the waitress was super nice and apologetic. We both had chai tea soo good and a great way to finish off a nice meal. This is listed as $$ here on yelp but it should be $$$. For 2 chais, 2 lassis, and 2 dinners, it came out to $100 and change, which was worth it, but just note that if you're coming here expecting to pay $11-30, odds are, you'll really be paying more. Go anyway, nice ambiance, friendly staff, good food. YAY.
author: Merredith L.

description: I always go here sundays for brunch and we always go like right before they close but theyre always very good about seating us and treating us well. Foods always good (who doesnt love lots of potatoes with spices?) My friends and I tend to scandalize this place, since its a couple and me and then we alternate, making the servers think that we're like swingers or something. :p
author: Nancy P.

description: I really, really wanted to love Dosa. Really, I did. It is THE Indian restaurant everyone in the Mission talks about. But the only thing that I tried worthy of talking about was the Dahi Vada, a tasty starter with lentils and Strauss yogurt. Everything else I we ordered was forgettable. The most memorable thing about Dosa was the terrible service. Although there were only four or five parties in the place, it took forever to get our server to take our order and when our meal finally came our server never checked on us again. Everyone was friendly, but I was bummed that the wait staff in particular was not more attentive.
author: annie s.

description: I love this place.  Def a place to take those peeps in from out of town.  Looks fancy-pants at first sight, but also has lots of character.  A+.
author: Madeline D.

description: We waited for 1.5 hours (!) for a table on a Friday night. But it was well worth it. The food was absolutely amazing and the service was great. During our wait, we sipped nice drinks at the bar so the time flew by. No complaints whatsoever.
author: Krista S.

description: This place was good, but not as good as Vik's or Udupi in Berkeley.  I would only go here for the atmosphere and location.  Otherwise, why not just go to Viks?  or Udupi?  Point are lost because my dosa came sliced up and was totally soggy!!  My favorite part is breaking off the crispy ends and dipping it in the sambar.  The sambar was great by the way, as were the chutneys.
author: Bucky M.

description:
This place is excellent!!! Minus one star for one rude person of the wait staff (if you are interested in story, see below).

The food:

I don't think I've ever had Southern Indian food and Dosa is probably the best Indian food I've had in awhile.  I don't mind paying a little extra, especially when it's as good as Dosa is.

There is only one non-vegetarian option from what I could tell from the menu.  It changes daily.  Sunday's daily special was a lamb dish.  It was soft pieces of lamb with a firecracker spicy sauce.  Excellent and addicting.  Our second item was a traditional Paneer dosa with farm cheese and vegetables.  Very very good. And the chutneys that accompany the dosas are excellent.  

Our server:

In Jennifer's defense, I did bring my one year old to a packed restaurant on a Sunday.  And he was a little cranky because he was hungry.  Had she checked on us, I would have asked if there was anything kid friendly (not in a heavy sauce) on the menu, as he was not interested in the dosa I ordered for him.  Or I might have ordered a second mango lassi to bribe him.  But to my relief, he made it through without any real scandals.

The reason I feel offended is because my older boy order a mango lassi with the original meal order.  Jennifer, our server asked if I wanted to try one also.  I responded, that I would sample his and if I liked it, I too would order a second.  We finished our meal before we ever saw the mango lassi or our server again.  With fire coming from our mouths, we'd finished our waters and I could not get her attention.  When we finally did get her attention she argued with me and said that she had already served us with a mango lassi earlier.  She left and returned twice asking me again and again if I was sure that she had not given us the lassi.  At this point I was ready to snap, it was extremely rude.  The lassi costs a measly $4 and if my son wanted to drink 3 on our lunch date, I would buy them for him.  I would not lie and try to weasel a second from the server for free.   When she finally returned with the mango lassi she made a comment about how she remembers giving the drink to us and she also remembers saying how much we were going to enjoy it.  Then she retreated to the back of the restaurant and kept watch on us, like as if the mysterious glass was going to reappear and she would catch us.  Now how were we supposed to enjoy the remainder of our meal and the lassi after we were repeatedly insulted?  I wanted to get up and leave, but I did not want to spoil lunch for my boys.  It's too bad that the server did not have the same consideration for us.   

= MINUS ONE STAR
author: Jessica R.

description: Good food, good vibe if you will.  Smaller place typical of many of the mission spots.  Flavors are pretty good, portions are a little slim.  keep hearing how it is a "fusion" place, but the food seemed fairly authentic indian... not that I would know squat about "authentic" food.  service was good on a wednesday and they have a bar you can eat at, but, alas, no draft beer.  beer selection could catch up to the wine selection.  first time eating dosa, have to say it was pretty good.
author: Cole M.

description:
The only southern Indian place in SF that I know of.  Their dosa's are really flavorful.  There is usually always a line also especially on weekends.  The owner actually wrote me a message after I rated it which I thought was actually a nice touch.  I will go back again
--- Update 3/25/06
Bumping up to 4 stars.  I went back and had a great meal.  We ordered a dish with a swirl of colors and was very tasty.  What was the name of it?  We also had a Chutney Dosa which was excellent.  The service was great and also the wine.  Oh my BeJesus, you have to try the Cheesecake Indian dessert.  The person I was with is Indian and she said it's even better then you get in India.  I just wish it wasn't so popular, open late night and delivered ;)  The owner asked us how everything was when we were there and was very friendly.
--- Update 10/23/07
I had the Dahi Vada last night and it wasn't as good as before.  It wasn't as sweet and the sauce was more bitter on top.  The cleaning guys asked us about 5 times if we were done before we finished and the waitress we had seemed like she was in a rush all the time.  The Shrimp curry dish was awesome though.  We were seated right away on a tuesday night which was nice.
author: Mitch A.

description: Wow this place really lived up to the hype.  The food was great and service attentive.  The place was a little loud and hard to carry on a conversation without using hand signals.  I would definitely go back.
author: A P.

description: Just really good Indian! Love their paneer and peas and lamb dosas. Very friendly service as well. A neighborhood gem.
author: Celine C.

description: I'm still a little new to Indian food but imo Dosa's was a great dinner. Just the right amount of heat and good service. The dining area was a little tight but I know a good restaurant has to turn tables. Reasonsably priced for SF.
author: Matt F.

description: With 131 reviews, I hoped someone mentioned that this was a vegetarian place. I was walking around the mission and the smells pouring from the venue beckoned me. I failed to read the menu, there was like one meat dish, chicken curry I believe. The staff was unbelievablely nice and didn't make me feel like a dofus for missing the whole non-meat thing. The server brought me out a sample of something that was divine, but lacked meat. I tried to get chicken added to the dish she had me sample, but all of the chicken was pre-cooked in the curry. A little on the pricey side, but it is SF. I enjoyed my brief stay and have recommended it to my friend that are less fanatical about "carne" pleasures.
author: Jocelyn F.

description:
one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  not because it's incredibly crowded and you can hardly ever get a seat right away, no matter what day of the week, and not because you're practically sitting on top of the next table.  but i love them because they are so vegan friendly but don't make a big deal out of it. the paper masala dosa is my favorite but all of the dosas seem to taste pretty similar--which means divine.  plus who doesn't love to dip?  and you get lots of dipping (in various chutneys and sambar, a lentil soup) at dosa.  last but soooo not least, i love dosa for their lychee lush drinks, that come with an alcohol-soaked lychee at the bottom.  the perfect dessert!

edit:  we came here for new year's eve 2007 and i had the vegan prix fixe menu--cauliflower vadas, mysore masala dosa, coconut veggie curry and blood orange sorbet for dessert.  it was all divine.  plus a woman came around and painted our hands with henna for free.  what a great way to ring in the new year--stuffed and decorated!

edit again: i came for dinner on a monday night and was surprised by their CHAAT menu, which is only available mondays and sundays (brunch).  we had the pani puri, which were not only delicious, but totally fun to assemble.  damn, i love this place.
author: kate s.

description:
So
The food was spectacular. The food was just the right amount of spicy. It was very flavorful and on par with other Southern Indian food I have tried. I mean I have never been to India but from what I have heard it is fairly authentic. There were a lot of white people working there though. So is it just run by a bunch of culture appropriating white people? I mean if it is that's fine , my favorite Japanese restaurant growing up was owned by Koreans so it is not really a big deal. Anyway, I think the prices were fair. I mean really I get tired of people complaining that food is expensive. Seriously folks it nourishes your body. Lots of things go into food production. Growing it for instance, people who pick it, transportation, the cooks, the wait staff, the clean up crew. So you really have to take that into consideration when food is expensive. Food production is expensive.......People have to grow it!
I did have a tiny tiny tiny problem with the staff. The were very "rushing". The wanted to know our ordered as soon as we sat down pretty much. they hovered because we couldn't decide.  They were slightly snobby. They did act like we had never had Indian food before "Channa means chickpeas basically" and "a curry is a spicy dish". Eh really I never knew that. We also brought our own drinks from the whole foods store next door. In less than 30secs 4 waiters stormed our table and made us feel super ashamed about it. I understand bringing outside food and it was a mistake but not that big of a deal  but seriously 4 waiters!! They gave us a lecture like we were 4th graders and even poured our drinks into glasses they brought. I made the mistake of pouring my own drink into my own empty water glass and got reprimanded. I mean really. The next thing that happened is they hovered after that incident. Then they were all about us leaving, we wanted dessert though they began to clear our table before the last bite of food was even in my mouth. I guess because this pretentious upper class San Francisco status symbol unique for the mission cultural experience for nob hill Noe valley north beach families is apparently so popular they cant have 3 non-hipster san francisco college-y kids mess with their image. I am not sure.
But I cant just give it one star because  the food was good. So this is for the chefs. Go you!! You Rock!! Im giving you 5 stars. You cant share them with the wait staff though.
author: cole s.

description:
I was here for brunch today.
If you've read my other reviews, you KNOW I'm all about fatty, traditional breakfasts/brunchs, ie, tons of hollandaise sauce, bacon, French fries, etc.  So when my brunchmate suggested Dosa for breakfast, I was a bit wary.  This place is down the block from where I live so I walk down it ALL THE TIME, but today was the first time I've tried it.
I'm very happy that I did!  The food was DELICIOUS.  We ordered the following:
-  Madras coffee
-  Dahi Vada:  lentil dumplings
-  Spicy mung masala:  lentil dosa filled with spicy potatoes
-  South Indian Moons:  this was the chef's choice of five Uttapams; we ended up with the masala, paneer and peas, tomato and onions, chile and cilantro, and the caramelized onion.  
Of these, the paneer and peas and the tomato and onion were the best.
Everything was very tasty and definitely worth the price.  I will definitely be back!
And kudos to the staff.  They could clearly see that my brunchmate and I were amateurs when it came to South Indian cuisine, and they were very helpful when it came to explaining the dishes and what to pair together.  Bravo!
author: Meh M.

description:
well, i'll have to disagree with rudro s. in a previous review but we all have different opinions huh?

i feel like dosa surpasses udupi in tastyness (& spicyness) and the sambar is far better at dosa...however, i will not trash udupi...it's tasty there, just a little dumbed down i think for the population they serve.   i hope this doesn't happen at dosa but you can ask for spicy(er) food.

everything i've tried here has been really good and the paper dosai has been my favorite.  the fire soup was very spicy and tasty and worth trying.  

:: on the down-side :: 

this place is much pricier than udupi though and is somewhat of  'a scene' for the yuppies but you know it's good too when you see desi folks bringing their whole family there on a sunday night.  you just gotta work around the kinks...can't do anything about the price though.

::in sum::

get there early if like an early dinner and put your name on the list to try to avoid the wait and scene, eat with your hands (it's way you're supposed to eat it, and it really tastes better =), and don't be afraid to ask to make everything SpiceyER if that's your pleasure.
author: craig m.

description:
My friend and I have tried eating here a few times but were unable to.  There is such a buzz about this place that we HAD to try it.  We finally were able to go when we went here not as hungry as the previous times.  I need to highlight this, but the staff was very friendly; especially the wine guy and the bartender who's recommendations we used to select our dishes.  There was actual conversation and not just rote pleasantries with a smile.  Having said that, I understand one of the main principles of running a restaurant is having a high customer turnover, I felt a little rushed when I was slapped with a menu before I even took my first sip waiting for a spot at the bar.  

It was one of those rare warm SF evenings and I wanted a good cold beer, unfortunately, I couldn't find one on the menu, so I settled for a mango mimosa and a mango seed for my friend.  The mango seed which is mango lassi and soju was pretty good but a bit a little bit heavier than what I was craving for at that moment.  Ahhh, but you can't go wrong with mimosa right?  Wrong!  I think the fresh mango that they used was out of season or was not ripe enough, because the mango mimosa was really tart; the combination  evaporated the natural sweetness that usually comes with mango and champagne.  It tasted like I was drinking a really bad champagne bottle; I didn't know Charles Shaw made champagne.  Although, the "Tank Girl(?)" wine that the bartender recommended was really really good.

I'm a calamari-holic and order calamari at every restaurant I go to.  It's definitely made my bill much more expensive most of the time, but I'm willing to pay for it to find those rare instances when I find a definite winner.  This calamari was not one of them.  While the actual calamari was very fresh, the sauce it came with overwhelmed the squid and made the dish literally taste like regular pasta......and it was the pasta that an old friend's mom used to make that made him not my friend anymore.  How can you mess up pasta?

The Lamb Kofta was excellent and was a bit peeved that my friend liked it as well; damn her.  I really liked the various Uttapams and the paneer and peas really surprised me; I'm not a big cheese guy and I actual enjoy this.  In conclusion, my friend thought the dishes were really salty, I thought they were very tasty and I was able to taste most of the ingredients used.  We both felt that the uttapams and the paneer was better on their own, adding the chutneys and the sambar to them really confused the palate.  I'm used to dallop chutney on my dishes, but had to restrain myself with these dishes.  Weird right?  I think this is what my friend meant when she said the food was salty.  I just thought that the chutneys were so flavorful that they should have been served with a plainer dish (or even just rice), instead of the subtle flavored and enjoyable paneer and uttapams.  The food is decent south indian but overpriced.
author: Don B.

description:
finally checked this place out and was not disappointed in the slightest.

great ambiance, good service and the food.....simply put was a cathartic experience. 

we had a chicken appetizer that had a really good yogurt style dipping sauce. we split a dosa- pretty big serving and soup......if you like Indian food you'll fall in love with Dosa.
author: Ax L.

description:
i'll take a dose-a of dosa!!  i tried my first dosa at dosa the other nite....and loved em.  these are ginormous crepes (but kinda crispy - as a good crepe often is) - i mean they don't even fit on the plate!  and the ones we got (i forget the names - but one had farmers cheese - which looked like chicken and lots of fresh salsa-ish vegetables and the other is the top of the menu - the country fave) were d-lish.  we also enjoyed the lamb curry (very flavorful and warm and chunky) and for an appetizer we got the chicken something or rathers - which looked basic but had dynamite taste.

for desert -(my indian friend ordered, so i don't know what they were called or how they're spelled) we got these little dough balls that sit in a honey rose bath.  so freaking good-and the size of a donut hole - so the perfect little sweet taste to end a meal where i stuffed myself silly.
author: Kate F.

description:
If you are new to South Indian fare, Dosa is as good an introduction as any.  The dosas are okay, often nicely crispy.  My choices are the masala dosa and the paper dosa, as I think they taste the most authentic.  The uttapams are okay as well, but their temperature sometimes suggests they are heated under a lamp.  The same goes for the lamb curry, which on a good day, is nicely piquant and zesty, but when tepid, tastes like just another curry with some lamb.  The chickpea salad is lovely, but honestly, to call it South Indian-inspired would even be a stretch.  My South Indian friends simply shake their heads at the idea that Dosa has the chutzpah to claim authenticity.  They all grew up on South Indian food courtesy of Mom, so I turn to them for precise judgment, as I would turn to Koreans who have had food in Seoul or Los Angeles' Koreatown when it comes to authentic, great-tasting Korean.  Their opinions notwithstanding, everything tastes fine so long as you do not expect the rich tapestry of spices that comes from undiluted South Indian home-cooking.  For the latter, the choices are endless if you go to the South Bay or Berkeley, which is a stone's throw away.  And everything is ridiculously overpriced, especially the trademark dosas.

The decor is very nice--warm with earthy, clay tones, the lighting and furniture add a smooth, modern touch.  There is a full bar and the bartenders are eager to help.  The wine list is interesting.  I had syrah from India and that was... interesting.  Service is fine.  They are always busy bees and the tables are too close together.  Still, Dosa is here to stay and I am curious to try the new one on Fillmore.
author: Dee C.

description: This place is amazing.  Cheap prices and great food.  Highly recommended for people that like spicy food.  The mysore dosa is my favorite and definitely punches a kick.  The little soup that accompanies the dosa packs heat as well.  A good non-spicy dish is the prawn coconut masala curry .  Be prepared to wait during dinner time though because there is always a line on the street.
author: Jason M.

description: Eh.... I'll go elsewhere, especially for the money.
author: B K.

description: Took my girlfriend here on Valentines. It's a pretty nice place... I'm from New Delhi, and am not used to eating South Indian at a nice/posh place... They're usually hole in the walls. It's not super posh or anything, but compared to most Indian places, it's pretty nice. And yes they do recommend their wines based on what you order to eat, matches very nicely. We got the 4-5 meal deal kinda thing, where it's a 4-5 course meal. It was pretty nice, and not super pricey either. Definitely recommend going there if you're with a gf/bf and want to go somewhere romantic. Definitely not the best South Indian I've eaten... but was very good.
author: Anish B.

description: I honestly went to this place simply because it had so many reviews. Dosa's smelled so good, the food was pretty tasty and flavorful as well. I can best describe it as Ethiopian food with a small posh twist on it, not that there's anything wrong with that. A great date would include taking someone to Dosa's bar on a weekday night about half an hour before the restaurant closes . The crowds will clear and you will get a great ambiance with amazing smells. Sitting at the bar will also give you a perfect opportunity to sit a little close to that special person ;)
author: Ramy H.

description: Dosa is pretty good.  That's about it.  I'm a little surprised at how difficult it is to get in to (and how brusque they are about reservations, as a result), but it's an institution of sorts in the area.  I found it a little pricey for what it was worth.  The dishes that contained cheese were a little heavy-handed.  Yeah, I'm not being very coherent here, but our dinner wasn't really either.
author: Brad S.

description: Egg Poriyal dosa and Mango Mimosa....bliss!
author: Shweta V.

description:
so here's my deal. i was out for dinner w/ some friends. our 1st choice was inexplicably closed so we meandered down the street and one of them said "oh! dosa!" the hostess said our wait would be 30-min. it was actually 15 (love that). but the real secret is - instead of floundering around the menu, let the wait staff do it for you. we closed our menus, said to our waitress (dead ringer for dorothy hamill, by the way) go ahead and order for us. it was FANTASTIC. i don't remember everything we had (probably because of the copius taj mahal's) but it was tasty. nice amount of spice (the lamb curry was exceptionally memorable,)

go - don't have enormous expectations, but let yourself be surprised.

for people who don't like noise - good luck. it seems like every restauranteur in this city has knocked themselves out with the whole "i can't hear you because of the vaulted ceilings" ambiance. which totally sucks.
author: RT G.

description: Yum. We sailed into Dosa tonight at 6pm and got seated immediately. My prawn curry was yummy and generous on the prawns, and my girlfriend's Mysore Masala dosa was equally scrumptious. Oh...and the mixed greens, mango and goat cheese salad and chennai chicken were both great starters. Amazing food, an excellent selection of Indian beers and great service, however I wish I could take away a half star for the boy band pop music that was playing when we first sat down.
author: Chris R.

description: Good, but not great.  Nice clean space with a huge menu and lots to choose from.  The no reservations policy sucks.  There are better places to have Indian food, maybe not as nice looking, but you don't eat the decor.
author: Tony A.

description: Went on a Tuesday night, had no problem getting a table for 4 at 8. Our server was extremely friendly and helpful in making suggestions, I greatly appreciate when servers actually know about the food they serve and can answer all my questions, which she did. Fun drink menu with Soju and Lillet, great wine list too. The food was delicious, although I tend to think most Indian dishes taste the same. As a vegetarian, the options were endless and it was fun to eat the dosas...like quesadillas with fun dipping sauces. Worth a visit for sure.
author: summer r.

description:
My friends and I have been going to this restaurant ever since it opened. We've  always noticed how quickly the wait staff turns over, always new wait staff and hostess. That didn't seem detrimental until after dining there last time. The credit card we used appears to have been "skimmed".  Approximately a thousand dollars worth of fraudulent purchases were made on the card immediately the day after.

To make matters worse, when the owner was contacted , in order  to warn her about this, she just screamed and threatened.   We do not have definitive proof that the card was "skimmed" there.  However, it is highly suspicious since it has not left the owner of the crediit card's sight (while paying at other merchants) for a  while  until at that juncture.(paying for the dinner).

Because of the unpleasant interaction with the owner, we will not ever go there again since "fun" dining also means good ambience.

We suggest that you pay "cash" if you go.
author: priya k.

description:
The food is excellent, but we ate here on the warmest night of the year and it was easily 90 degrees in the restaurant.  I was visibly sweating because of the warmth in the restaurant, and the spiciness of the food.

There are no knocks on the service or food.  Excellent.  Minus one star b/c of how warm it was in there and not very good circulation.
author: P C.

description:
3.5

Although the meal my boyfriend and I had at Dosa was tasty and filled us up, I still like northern Indian food better than southern after getting a taste of the cuisine at Dosa.

We came in on a Monday night at 9pm, and the place was packed.  So packed that we had to wait 25 minutes for a table-a sign that the food is good.  

Maybe my slight disappointment in the food had to do with the fact that I wasn't really in the mood for Indian food to begin with, but nevertheless I still feel like northern Indian food is tastier and appeals to more people than the type of food offered at Dosa.  We ordered the lamb meatball curry, the spiced fried boneless chicken appetizer (i forget the proper names for all these dishes), the puffy fry bread, a side of coconut rice and the pea, cilantro and farmers cheese uttapan.  The curry was good, although I would have appreciated it more if it had chunks of lamb meat instead of lamb meatballs.  The uttapan was so-so; it was not what we were expecting.  We thought it was going to be a type of thick bread similar to naan-except it was more like an omelette or something.  It was a bit heavy and didn't stick together well.  But, the veggies inside were tasty and the occasional burst of texture from the peas was a nice touch.  The puffy fry bread was AWESOME!  Definitely get it-who doesn't like fried dough?!?  Lastly, we ordered the honey rice ball things for dessert, which were OK.  I'm used to those being served in a rice pudding type soup, but these were soaking in basically a hot simple syrup liquid-and they were HOTT as hell.  My bf burned his mouth on them so watch out for that.  And also, they only gave us two honeyballs-for $5 I feel like they should be giving 4.  Most people share dessert nowadays, and two measly little balls seemed like a rip off in my opinion.

Moving on to the service.  Although our server was friendly and polite, I felt like she was just totally not on the same page as we were.  Every time I asked a question, I felt like she didn't understand what I was inquiring about and the answer I received was confusing and strange.  It was weird.  And, I felt like she could have been slightly more attentive-the other waitress on duty seemed to be on the floor a lot more than our server was...I found myself wishing we had her as a server instead of the one assigned to us.  Sorry, but true. 

All in all, it was a decent meal but the next time I'm craving Indian I will most likely opt for the northern Indian food I am more accustomed to.
author: Genevieve M.

description: We went here for New Year's Eve dinner. The prix fix menu was generous- huge portions. We barely had space to eat by the third course. Only quibbles were weird tasting sambhar - almost burnt? - and the dessert. It was cold and not that appetizing. Paneer and mango dosa was different and interesting - also love the chicken kabobs appetizer.
author: k c.

description: Indian for brunch.....wasn't my favorite idea...sounded like I would be burping up curry all day....Was I pleasantly surprised or what!  Dosa was great....I remember the deliciousness of south Indian food...its been awhile.  The dosa's were flavorful and not too heavy, the chutneys delicious and not overpowering, the chai...as authentic as I have tasted...yummy diddly um...can't wait to go back.  I am still shocked, organic free range Indian eggs in a dosa...
author: Tracy M.

description: What else can you add to a place that has over 650 reviews? The food is great. Their Dosa's are awesome and the pakora's are nice and spicy. We got there a bit early (around 6:30) and found a couple seats at the bar no problem. by the time we left it was packed and people just kind of hanging around waiting for people to get up from the bar. The only real complaint i had was that the bartender that was serving us wasn't that good. A lot of people sit at the bar to eat so i didn't feel like we were putting him out but that was the attitude he gave.
author: Stephen K.

description: Went here for the BF's bday. Don't be fooled by the lines and the wait list. Nice decor, killer drinks, but the food was lackluster and you have to enjoy it rubbing elbows with strangers.
author: ZacKandMeL M.

description: Pricey and really really average. Plus they did what i think is the tackiest for any restaurant...they keep the tails on prawns in their curries. There is no dignified way to eat that other than use your hands or just slice what you can. Service was good which is why it gets two stars.
author: Sylvia S.

description:
um...meh...that's my review:  meh

overpriced dosa in a nice atmosphere.  go to berkeley for good cheap south indian food.
author: Christine R.

description:
Like wow man

I didn't expect to like this restaurant!  I'm indian afterall, and superpicky about my indian food, and...I digress.  I really liked Dosa!  My dosa and the sambar were fabulous!  Plus I had a lychee martini which was fabulous too.

Only cons: really really busy on weekends, and quite pricey for dosa.
author: Michele Y.

description: This place is great!  Good food, fairly attentive wait staff.  Great wine list!  They don't take resies for small parties, but I have never waited longer than 30 mins to get in.
author: Stephanie J.

description: MMM.... we came here for the first time on a Sunday for lunch and was seated immediately without reservations.  It wasn't too busy and service was spot on.  Their "brunch" menu didn't look any different than what you would expect on a regular menu except that they offered alcoholic brunch drinks and egg-related dishes.  Of course, I wanted to try their infamous dosas so I ordered the spicy mung masala dosa, which is filled with curried-flavor mung bean and potato with chopped up onions and bell peppers.  My man ordered the paneer and peas dosa, which was served very differently than my dosa (see my photos).  While mine was the dramatically large rolled crepe with filling loosely placed in the middle, his was wrapped into a tight, burrito-like structure.  Both were very tasty, and a bit spicy, but not too spicy.  I liked the crispy "chips" that they give in the beginning of the meal (like tortilla chips in Mexican places). and also the fact that the dosas came with two different chuneys (a tomato based one and a bean based one, I think) to dip, and also a small bowl of lentil/veggie soup called sambar.  Two dosas for the two of us was $25 w/o tip and we were stuffed silly.  Still had room for a Humphrey Slocombe ice cream after a short walk there ;)
author: Grace M.

description: Delicious food & cocktails, and very good for a gluten-free diet --- a ton of options.
author: R F.

description: Chennai chicken was a nice start - nicely seasoned boneless bites of chicken with (essentially) a Tandoori marinade. The papadum, unfortunately, was a salt lick, as if someone simply paid no attention to how much salt was added. The chile and onion pakora was nice, but mucking up a chickpea-batter fritter is nearly impossible. Is it too heavy? No. Is it too greasy? No. Done. The classic masala dosa (filled with potatoes, onions, cashew nuts) was just fine too. Was there any applause from my cells? Not even a chirp, but it was just fine. The Vada Pav, a vegetarian slider with a spiced-potato patty, chutneys, onions, etc., was nice, if uninspiring - and it still eludes me why you are asked to mix the "gunpowder" and ghee to apply to the slider yourself. The Tamil lamb curry, which they serve with the lemon rice, was good enough; and that, in the end, was the 'flaw' with everything - all was good, nothing great, and I'd rather eat at Vik's Chaat (Berkeley) any day of the week. Dosa's 'organic' sourcing and product pride is well and fine, but better flavor is better flavor. The 'Southern' influence of Dosa's cuisine is not much of an inducement (I thought it would be); it's not especially distinguished in its spicing from what you find in other Indian restaurants. I'll be honest with you - next time I'm in the area looking for an Indian meal, I'll try Udupi Palace instead, and I'm no vegetarian, so take that as you will, yeah? In sum: fine service, enjoyable space, good food, a nice wine and liquor selection; but if the brilliant originality and power of Indian cuisine is your one true thing, there is better to be had without the frills or extra bills.
author: Brski B.

description: Loved it!  Rava masala dosa, masala dosa, and rasmalai were delicious and authentic. Great atmosphere too.
author: shoba d.

description: Really, really, really good South Indian food in a tastefully decorated restaurant.  I had egg dosa (fusion cuisine, I guess) and my friend had cheese dosa --- both were excellent and the sambar and chutneys were right on the spot taste wise.
author: ITesh J.

description:
Hmmm.... Well based on my past review of Dosa, I got a message back from one of the supposed owers of Dosa. So I will do my best to be fair to the resturant  
Good things about this place :
a) Great atmosphere inside.
b) You dont stink like an indian kitchen after you done eating here.

What I did not like:
a) The sambar was weakkkkk... ( I still feel the sambar was off. I realize there might be various ways of preparing it but it just didnt work for me.) 
b) The coconut Chutney ( As per the owner this was an home made recepie. I felt personally this was not what i had quite expected.  )
b) The dosa's were like crepe rolls !!!!  Far from orginal dosa's. ( the owner mentioned that if you want something more authentic try the Masala Dosa or the Paper Masala. I guess i will have to try it out next time. ) 
c) Tamil Lamb ( thanks for the correction ) , i thought this one was funny. Lot of Tamils I know are vege eaters, and some are not. ( So i found the name funny.The owner mentions this is a dish from the Nilgiri Hills. I do stand corrected on this. I have to admit i never tried this dish before. )  
d) One last thing, Papad needs to be crispy when served. the ones we got were quite soft.

In all its a great place but, in my subjective opinion the food didnt quite appeal to me.  In all fairness try it out and see what you think.
author: Amlan S.

description:
Dosa is delicious.  Rumor has it that the owners are considering adding Flying Horse lager to the beer list (yum)!

I recommend ordering the curries spicy.  The calamari is wonderful, the shrimp curry is amazing, and the channa masala is out of this world!  

I'd like to see a few more vegetarian curries on the menu, but everything that is on the menu that I've tried has been fantastic.
author: Matt M.

description: D for Delish - you're in for a treat at  Dosa.  It's a fun, off the beaten path kinda place-so eat here when you're feeling like something different.  It's fun to pick and choose as all the dishes on their menu are good - share them -- like, family style.  Mmm...their wine list is quite good as well.
author: Leslie G.

description: Why is this categorized as Pakistani when it's straight up, South Indian.  I've always wonderend why it is so hard to find sounth indain food in SF. Luckily, there is DOSA, a cheap and chic eatery in the Mission. I always get the channa bhatura: spicy chick peas with fried puffy bread the size of a full moon. Despite always being crowded, we've never waited more than 5 minutes to get a seat since there are always a few empty chairs at the bar where you can also eat and venture into the world of Indian wine. Yes, I said Indain wine!!
author: Angela C.

description: This is one of the best south indian food I've ever had in US! The place is small & cozy, and not one of those typical Indian restaurant (not stinky or dirty!) but the best authentic food ever!! I crave for dosa every week, i am taking away one star because of long wait! There's always 20-30 mins wait and bar is always crowded, so it gets tough and they dont take reservations. Get there early! Also there is a cheap parking lot so u dont have to go around for hrs looking for a spot. I love their masala dosa, never been a big fan of Dahi Vada but you have to try it, this place has it down..oh and their amazing mohito (while ur waiting)!! The price is pretty decent especially for the quality of the food!! I likeeey
author: Natasha R.

description: Went there for brunch this past Sunday and had a great time. I had never had dosai before so this was a first for me.  I love trying new things so was really excited.  I was not let down.  There were about 15 of us and we had reservations so there was no wait.  The decor is beautiful and the atmosphere relaxing.  Our waitress was very helpful and attentive.  And the food was excellent.  We ordered a little bit of everything and tried a bit of each.  There are plenty of veggie/vegan options for your veggie/vegan friends and family members as well as egg options.  So, something for everyone.  And do try some of the desserts.  Ohh soo good.  My favorite was the cardammon gelato.  (My favorite spice.)  What more could I ask for really?  I would highly recommend it.  I'll be going back.
author: Magdalena ..

description: Fun and friendly place.  The food was fantastic, very eclectic menu and reasonably priced.  Lots of tasty veggie options.  The place fills up early, but eating at the bar is fun and the service is very attentive.
author: Nicole G.

description: Came here with friends and had the whole tasting menu which was disappointing because the flavors were surprisingly similar -- it simply wasn't worth the price.  However, the chai was the best I've had in the city.
author: Adam Z.

description: Dosa has me star struck.  I had to go back  last night just to make sure that it was in fact as rediculously good as I thought.  I put my name in at 7:15 and we did not get seated until 9:00.  If the food and service were not the 5 star rating that I gave, I would have been irritated beyond belief.  I had no idea that Indian food could taste this good.  We ordered the lamb, the pepper chicken, the coconut prawns and a number of other starters and entrees.  The food is priced amasingly low for the quality of presentation, the upscale atmosphere, and taste-bud-baffling flavors.  I'm seduced.
author: Cameron Y.

description:
You see 2 stars and wonder why. Let me tell you. 
1. Food
2. Ambiance
3. Service
4. Price

Let me add color:

Food - So, apparently people are just not getting the memo: if you open a restaurant, the food has to be good. And even if you decorate your little locale to be the "hot spot," I don't give 2 shits. The food needs to be good. Sorry, I like food. Now, I admit I am not as familiar w/ south indian cuisine. Although i did have south indian in india...well, the northern part of india, and it was good. Now, with this restaurant, we were all overwhelmed by the menu. The veggie crepe thing I got was ok, but I kept combining like 4 different sauces over it to give it flavor...and there was so much crepe. I don't really know what the deal is - if this is a very western version or what, but it was just not  quite working for me or my party. 
2. Ambiance - ok, it's a nice setting. however, the music was elevator music which i asked the manager to change. she did to mellow indian beats...but nothing inspiring. the bar is cute. lighting is nice. But we were seated at a table in the front and it was so awkward. 
3. Servie -- if you have read any of my reviews, you know this is a biggie for me. First, the people I dealt with were awkward. Except for the bartender - I was a huge fan of her. She was cool. Had I known, I would have spent my night at the bar instead of at an awkward table. The manager was ok. The hostess had some major attitude. The waitresses were ok, but not very smooth. Maybe they lacked experience? Also, there was no place to hang my coat. It was dragging on the ground and it took them forever to figure out a solution - that is, to figure out to hang it up on the hangers they had on the wall. They sat us at an awkward table and were just generally awkward. I guess the theme here is awkward and not smooth. And then when we left the restaurant, the waitress didn't even say thank you or give us a nice farewell like a proper waitress. Really did not sit well.....all in all, what a total disappointment.
I guess if I had lowered my expectations the price and experience would have been different. It's just so hard to say, hey, go to this restaurant where you're going to pay significantly more money, not like the food that much, and be around awkward displeasing service, when I could say, head to Naan and Curry, pay $7 a person and enjoy some seriously amazing food, drink free chai, listen to bollywood beats, and hang out w/ Rashad..... and i like chic places, but good places are good places....and this does not even come close to the top 1%....but Naan and Curry.....now that's a great place.
author: Jess P.

description: I think this is a pretty awesome place. Its south indian food, which has some great vegetarian dishes, but unlike most south indian places this place has a pretty impressive selection of non-veg dishes as well. it also gets 5 stars for the ambience, nice and cosy, not cramped. they dont have mojitos, but they have something that looks like it, its good, try it. wait can be a bitch, but overall a great place..
author: Kumar S.

description: Everything is to die for here.  This was one of the best meals I have had in a long time.  The chips that they serve before the meal were amazing...I could have eaten them for dinner.  This is a MUST try.  I can't wait to go back.  The fact they don't take reservations is no bueno...
author: Lori M.

description: I came here for brunch with my dad and we were both very impressed.  I believe I had a cheese Chaat and some kind of mixed appetizers. The mango mimosa are tres yum! Expect to pay about $50 for two people if you get  dosas, appetizers, and mimosas. Food portions were just right and I had leftovers. The only reason I give 4 instead of 5 stars is that it gets quite crowded and the seats can be a bit too close for comfort. 5 for the food and service, 4 for the ambience. All in all, definitely recommended!
author: Kristi D.

description: Never had to wait more than a few minutes for a table which is good because I usually come ravenous and make every attempt to devour all food in sight...actually a tough job because their portions are generous and the food is delicious.  My favorite is the Rava Masala, but everything I've had here has been wonderful.  I highly recommend a mango lassi, smooth, flavorful and easy on the sugar makes this drink the perfect accompaniment to a spicy meal.  On that note, don't come here if you can't handle a little heat, this is Indian food after all.  The coconut chutney cools things off nicely though should you find your ears whistling and/or emitting steam.  Service has been consistently outstanding.
author: Celeste A.

description: 6/24/07 We have stayed away from Indian restaurants because of our bad experiences in the past. Over 15 years ago we had a wonderful experience in Chicago, IL. We love spicy food and we use to enjoy Thai restaurants. So for spicy food we decided to try Dosa, the newspaper reviews highly praised Dosa. Well the newspapers were right, we had an excellent meal and Jillian our waitress was amazing. She is an incredible asset to the restaurant. I took all of her suggestions and she was right on target. We look forward to going there again and we hope to bring other friends. Enjoy!
author: Jose A I.

description: If you like excellent Indian food and cozy atmosphere than Dosa is the place for you.  Yes, it can get crowded and is a bit loud but hte food is simply amazing!  This is a definite stop and if you don't like to wait you can always get a to go dinner!
author: Jim E.

description:
PROS:  Food was good.  Service was attentive.
CONS:  Tables jammed together.  Too loud to talk - patrons and music.  Too expen$$$ive.  You are paying filet prices for grains.  Charge for beer was excessive.  Our waitperson pushed an unnecessary and not-very-good appetizer on us.
TIP: tables in the back are impacted by constant traffic in/out of the bathroom - and the occasional reek of disinfectant.  But given the line of people when we left, you'll probably take whatever is available.
TIP:  This cuisine is better with beer.  Wine would be overpowered by the strong flavors.
We wouldn't go back there under any circumstances.  One of those trendy-for-no-good-reason places.
author: J C.

description: Yummy vegetarian and vegan indian food, with spicy kick!  It's a great place for a nicer-than-usual dinner out, I loved their fire broth!
author: Jenni S.

description: I love dosas (the food).  Sure the dosas you get here are like 8 times the price they are in India.  But we aren't in India and these things taste pretty damn authentic.  Get a giant paper dosa and eat the hell out of it.  Damn its good.  I love dosas!!!!
author: Jake A.

description: This is probably my 10th time at Dosa in the last 6 months. I never even heard of south indian food until I was at Dosa. Its Basala Dosa had me licking to my fingers! They also serve Brunch on weekends and make sure you try its curry dish (if you are a non-vegan).
author: Cathy Y.

description: Excellent, unique, Southern Indian cuisine like none I've never had before. For apps start with the calamari (I know it sounds weird at an Indian place but trust me it's awesome) and the lentil dumpling thing. The chickpea salad and mung bean salad were also good (healthy tasting). Next we had an uttapam (like a pancakey thing with stuff mixed in), of course a dosa and lamb curry. The lamb curry was fabulous! The uttapam was yummy too. The dosa was surprisingly mediocre. The only downside to this place is you have to go at like 6PM if you want a table and with the names of the items on the menu all in Indian it's very difficult to figure out what's what.
author: lani P.

description: Ate lunch here yesterday. Host was very sweet and friendly. Waiter was very attentive. Food was extremely flavorful, I could not even begin to tell you everything I tasted. The music was a bit castro street, but that did not bother me. Love the colors and the lamps. A great experience!
author: January B.

description:
Unbelievably, i had a bevy of gleeful sing-songy repartees amongst the unknowing killjoy's. I mean, honestly, from the outside, the bellowing atmospherics made me want to ballistically pierce the cellulite of every FM radio "new-country" advocate: the "bacardi ad" walls, people, chairs, tables, napkins. Overcharging us for desserts. Having ".5" on the menu order amounts dealing with essentially standard south indian fare. You want to squeal obtrusively into the ceaseless, constantly forming void in front of you, knowing they are charging an extra three dollars for above par Vada that you get in sunnyvale 5 1/2 times over financially. There it is though: i am trapped in this gatronomic wonderland, and its essentially the only south indian in town. So, uber-sleuth, what we have here is a matter of logistics and salient curiousity. Everything, food wise, was as tasty as you fucking wanted it to be. I kept hearing about this distinguishable spice factor: Revealing enough, it didnt inseminate my uvula with blatant and brash authority that my trivial buxom laden oral cavity clasped at for immaculate zen, a notable task i fiscally endured. Man, the sambar just wasn't the bulbous fireball heat blanket we optioned to digest, but it's flavor was a monolith of dancing herb-laden specilization. The mysore dosa was like a convivial legume mortar shell that burrowed into my memory bank instantaneously, innovating a declarative ruckus, ensnaring the "trust fund circus" happenstance all hovering above your "desirables". The chile and coriander uttapam a clever sensate apocalypse that boded impeccably with the numerous dunks of coconut chutney, exemplifying the iradescent struggle of the quality-quantity variety. I came, i saw, i judged on superficial whim and prodding esteem based inadequacies concerning the clientele, and i ate until my pancreas cheated on the math test. Now, i ask you, amnesia or aquarius? Where do pulse burps go to die?


p.s. The owners have won!
author: Christopher J.

description:
Food was delicious.  Decor nice.  Their menu said large prawns and that's exactly what I got - big juicy ass prawns.  Everything was great food and decor wise.  Here's why they didn't get 5 stars:

The owner via a waitress asked if my friends and I would mind moving to the bar to talk after we finished our meals because there were patrons waiting for a table.  Not a bueno move.  I think the waitress was a newbie, so she didn't ask in a tactful way.  Anyhoo, I didn't appreciate it because I've been a regular and we didn't idle for that long.  This was the first time I went with friends (usually it's with my boyfriend and we like to eat, pay and leave).  I've never been asked to leave a restaurant before.  The owner did come to say we can stay as long as we wanted after seeing our displeased faces.  Regardless, it was rude.  Don't know if I'll go back.
author: Lisa F.

description: As many others note, Dosa is delicious.  An Indian friend of mine claims it's overpriced for what you get, but we were full for under $20 each. Any dosa-type dish is good - the key is the sauces.  Loved each of them.  The high quality foreign beers are a nice bonus.
author: Brian D.

description: Reasonably good quality. but slightly overpriced. I must say though that their staff was very knowledgeable about their products. Excellent ambience for a couple and for a bunch of friends. Very laid back attitude, very Californian. I had the Onion Rava dosa, which was excellent. Went with my family, including baby, which I would definitely avoid if I went there again. The place is very children-unfriendly - layout, music, atmosphere, etc.
author: Keyur S.

description: Delicious. Well priced ($10 - $12 for entrees). Well decorated. Courteous service. The standard Masala dosa is great.
author: Saquib P.

description:
Lively restaurant. I've been here 3 times now. I got a different variety of dosa each time and just munch away onto dosa heaven--I haven't been disappointed yet. The staff is nice and attentive. The downside to this place is it's popularity! Seating can take an hour or more if it's a weekend night. 

Oh and a warning to those who cannot handle spicey-ness: this food can be quite mouth warming--and I'm not referring to the temperature. :)
author: Tara C.

description: No complaints, except I don't turn out to be the hugest fan of dosa (the actual type of food which the restaurant is named after). Too much potato and a little bit too spicy. Definitely recommend having some tea at the end of the meal to settle your stomach (and the gelato!)
author: Ryan H.

description:
As the name suggests, the dosas are really good, i tried the peas and paneer, tasty homemade cheese.

also tried the vegetable korma.  while it was good, i seriously have made the exact recipe off allrecipes.com.  so i guess that is where they found their recipe too.

this place is overpriced, from the beer/wine to the rice to the entrees.  the dosa was a fair value.
author: Carla K.

description:
yay, i finally got to eat here the other night!!  on thurs (a rainy) night, the place was packed at 8 pm.  we were able to snag 2 seats at the bar and eat there.  they don't have a full liquor license, so we had the mango lassi cocktail and the lychee cocktail, which are both made w/ soju.

for food, we had the chopped salad, the spring dosa (which is filled w/ veggies), a side of raita, and the channa batura.  i like the channa batura, but i hear the one at vik's is even better.  

they play loud music here, and the vibe is pretty good.  if you have a large group, be sure to come on time, b/c they don't seat you until your whole party arrives.  i want to come here for brunch next time!!
author: Helen T.

description: In the mood for something different? Grab a taxi (dont' drive, just don't do it) to 22nd and Valencia for some darn good eats. And I love that they serve Kingfisher beer. Enjoy!
author: Jennifer B.

description: Happen to stumble upon this cute little restaurant in the Mission....we saw a line outside the restaurant so it must be good, then we started reading the menu which consists of dosai, it reminds me of dosai from Malaysia. Was reading the writeup at the window and this is a southern indian restaurant...hmm interesting, it must be spicy then. We sat down after 5 mins of waiting time and our friendly server showed up. We were given a plate of papadam on the house, nicely done. We ordered appetizer - Chennai Chickeu Boneless chicken cubes marinated in Strauss organic yogurt and spiced with cilantro, coriander, cumin and curry leaves, lightly fried, served with mixed greens which came in a jiffy. Then for entrees, we had the Masala - classic Dosa filled with creamy, spiced potatoes, onions, and cashew nuts and sampler of uttapam - South Indian Moons the chef's selection of five different uttapams served with sambar, channa (gurbanzo beans) and chutney. Was slightly disappointed with the Dosa Masala since it was rolled into a burrito-styled serving with lots of stuffing, not the way I know of Dosa. I was really hoping for the paper thin dosa, should have ordered the crispy paper dosa served without the filling. Alright next time maybe...it was still packed when we left at 8:30 and patrons were still waiting for their table. Decent but slightly more pricey due to ambience, wine list, etc compared to the smaller joints in South Bay. Bf thought the food was too spicy, he bit on a tiny red chilli, poor thing....
author: Yan M.

description: Love this place!  Usually we just let the manager order for us, and he has never steered us wrong.  Creative cocktails, amazing service and a wide variety of vegetarian options.  Try the brunch :)
author: Tracy B.

description: First off let me just say that I love dosas as an Indian genre, but my experience at Dosa's missed the mark. Maybe it was just our orders, but the dosas that we had just weren't that good and the experience was made worse by the fact that I didn't have the elbow room to manuver the friggin thing because we were basically sharing a table with the couple seated next to us. I'm willing to give it another try but I would go for a lunch or on off hours.
author: M L.

description: The only good thing about this place is its decor. Usually this is one of those trendy places which are overrated. The sambar is watery and expensive. Frankly there are hundreds of better Indian eats in the bay area. I am an Indian so I know good South Indian food when I eat it and this place is both over priced and not tasty.
author: Nikil M.

description: Vik's is still the best thing going for South Indian cuisine, but if you can't make it across the bridge, Dosa will more than do. I highly recommend the fire broth as a starter. Stay awayb from the Indian wines, though - they're poison!
author: Eric G.

description:
Dosa

So I went to brunch at Dosa today.  Admittedly, it's not your traditional brunch fair, but I was pleasantly surprised at how delicious it was.  My friend and I started with one of the best, most creamy soy chais that either of us had ever had... with refills!  We then moved on to these little do-it-yourself pockets of delight called chaat.  They're little crispy hollow pastry thingees that you break a hole into the top of and fill with delicious things like chickpeas, potatoes and mung beans.  Then tamarind and cilantro "waters" are poured into the cups so that they're full.  Then you just pop them into your mouth.  Wonderful!   (They only serve them at brunch and Monday nights... check them out!).  I never knew I loved tamarind so much!  We then shared the rava dosa and a fruit uttapam that was more like a stack of mini pancakes than an India dish.  And it was all delicious.  AND... almost everything on the Dosa menu either is, or can be made, vegan.  

Oh happy, happy, deliciously happy day!
author: LeSLiE W.

description: This place gets my ultimate south indian approval. As a South Injun who grew up eating dosas, vadas, sambar, and uttapams every weekend, this place stays true to the real thing that I'm used to at home. It was like being in my sweet lil' mom's kitchen only I was in the Mission and I was sipping a lovely lechee cocktail to go along with my meal. I made sure to avoid the crowd by going in on a rainy Wed night. We were seated immediately by the window and our food came out promptly.  I recommend the onion rava dosa and the idlee/vada/sambar appetizer. The presentation of the food was excellent and the spicy factor was perfect! The tomato chutney was the perfect accompaniment to pretty much everything in the meal. Get your dosa on NOW people.
author: Roopa D.

description: At good suggestion by my infamous Yelper friend constantly spreading the Yelp gospel, we arrived early and didn't have to wait for a table despite being a Sat night.  Table of 4, seated quickly, ordered a bunch of food family style.  Each dish came out like a separate course.  Portion size is moderate.  Each very tasty.  Beverage was free flowing and they were very attentive to filling water and keeping our table organized and clean.
author: Emery C.

description: I'm into Dosa because it's authentic, yummy, and not too pricey. Best of all, it's FAST, which means we can take our toddler here. The waiters are cheerful, accommodating, and good with the kid too.
author: Bronwyn X.

description:
I'm knocking my review down a star. The food is really delicious, seriously we had an heirloom tomato salad dish last night that nearly made me cry! The problem is, that though the staff are extremely polite but the service pretty much sucks.  We made a reservation for 6  people at 7:30pm. We were there early, but waited nearly 20 minutes past 7:30 to be seated, while they were seating people right off the street with smaller parties. Ok, I understand big parties are hard to seat. The icing on the cake was that we never saw our server after we ordered, period. We only got 1 round of drinks, not the 2 or 3 that we would have preferred and when the manager checked in on us because our server was MIA, he took our order for a second round of drinks (after we were done eating our main course) and never brought it to the table. The bill would have been nearly double if we would have had a chance to order more drinks... too bad for them! Unfortunately the last few times I've been here the service was lack-luster as well.

*****Upate: I should have done this a long time ago. The owner of Dosa contacted me to follow up about my post above. He was concerned and thorough and I felt taken care of. They recently opened a DOSA on Fillmore, near my work and I love it!
author: Erika D.

description: Hard to say something new with so many reviews but this place is great and worth the extra monday.
author: ari s.

description:
Straight up excellent.

Complex, penetrating flavors that warm you from the inside out. Went in a group, and we all shared everything... every single bite was delicious. 

Also: Traquair Jacobite beer. So good.
author: Nicole A.

description: I came here for a Sunday night dinner and by 6pm, the place was crowded. I like the decor and ambience but it can get a little loud in this small restaurant.
