For appetizer, I had the calamari dish. The calamari was fresh but the sauce was slightly on the heavy side. I also had the lamb curry and that was tasty, though cumin-heavy. Being a little thirsty, I tried both the mango lassi and the chai. I really liked both and maybe they were a little more authenic than what I'm used to. Expect to pay $30-40/person  for appetizer, main dish, drinks. Overall, a very nice neighborhood restaurant.
author: Prista C.

description: Dosa rocks!!!! The food is sooo good! And both times I've been the waitstaff have been very helpful in suggesting what order to eat the dishes I wanted, or what dish will go well with another dish. I love this place! They are quite busy though, but luckily they'll take down you phone number and call you cell when you're table is ready (for the nights when the bar is kind of full, or if you just want a change of scenery while you wait) so you can go down the street and have a drink somewhere else. Both times I've eaten there I've gone early and singed myself up planning to leave and have a glass of wine somewhere else first. Both times its worked out perfectly. If you're going on a weekend I highly recommend this method. Trust me--the food at Dosa is worth the extra effort!
author: Amanda D.

description: Went with 4 friends for dinner. I had made reservations on opentable.com and was surprised to see that a credit card was required to hold the reservation. Seemed a bit pretentious for a place like this. The food pretty good though, as were the drinks. We got the samosas (note: only comes with two), spinach & paneer jumbo prawn curry with coconut rice (was a bit spicy for my taste), paneer & peas dosa (my fave! reminded me of a quesadilla since it had cheese and was grilled), chutney masala dosa (this was only okay), and south indian moons uttapam (pretty good, similar to a Chinese green onion pancake). All the dishes came with various dipping sauces and a lentil-based soup. Overall, pretty decent but not one of my absolute faves.
author: T L.

description: I have no idea if this is how southern indian food is supposed to taste--all I know is that it tasted delicious.  All ingredients were incredibly fresh and flavorful and the presentation couldn't have been nicer.  My only complaint (and the reason for 4 stars) is that the table are way too close together (yes, yes I know that it is SF and hip and places in SF that are hip are itty bitty, but seriously.  We were practically sitting on top of our neighbors).  Plus, it was a warm evening and there was little to no air circulation.  Despite all of that though, would go back in a heartbeat to try everything else on the menu.
author: Janet G.

description:
don't bother waiting.  it's all about the take out.  the food is overpriced, yes, but you have no other s.i. option in the city, so suck it up and be grateful anything involving yogurt- i.e .dahi vada, raita, lassi- is heavenly.  
they lie about the quote times, and the service is inconsistent at best, so save your saturday night for somewhere special, and get dosa takeout on a tuesday.
author: Ariane R.

description: Awesome!!  We went on a Monday which is special Chata (sp?) day.  We got some little air filled crispy breads and a man (who looks like he should be on tv, I'm thinking HGTV or the Food Network) showed us how to break a hole in them and fill it with potatoes, chickpeas, sprouts, spicy mint sauce and tamarind water.  Oh my god they were great.  As was my dosa, I never had such a concoction, yummy.  I was very sad that they forgot to bring my salad, cause I need at least a little bit of cheese with every meal, but oh well I was well fed.  The chocolate gelato is more like cold flourless torte (SOOOOOOO rich).  My stupid friend :P couldn't even finish hers!!! WHATEVER!!!
author: Louise A.

description:
i finally got to check out this place after hearing constantly about it. since there was only 2 of us, and there were so many different options on the menu, we went for the tasting menu. i was quite surprised as we didn't have to wait more than 5 min for a table, but this could have been due to it being a 8pm on a weeknight.

their curries were just ok, but the dosa's were delicious! they come served with dipping sauces that are heavily spiced and very flavorful. dessert was interesting as well. i tried the mango lassi, kind of like a very rich mango ice cream that you can cut into cubes.

as we were leaving, the server mentioned them serving brunch. i'm looking forward to trying an egg dosa one of these days.
author: helen l.

description: Great food, but being from Po-Dunk Davis I found the atmosphere to be pretty overwhelming(loud). But the service was great and the food was a delight. Would recommend to anyone who likes Indian Food.
author: Gabe R.

description:
For a year now I've been hearing about Dosa... I finally went tonight and was disappointed.  The food was sub-par.  In fact we ordered Samosas and had to have them sent back because they were still frozen in the middle!  The service was atrocious!  Our server was extremely passive aggressive and the food runner would literally just throw the plates on the table, knocking stuff all over the place and wouldn't even blink an eye at it.  The dosa's were SO disappointing.  First off, a good dosa is supposed to be slightly crispy not soggy such as the ones we had at Dosa.

The only reason I would give them 2 stars is because of the ambiance and the hostess and bartenders were extremely friendly! Their desserts are also good. If you want great Indian Food walk half a block up and you will run into Udapai Palace- that place is awesome!
author: A T.

description: Best Sambar I've had outside of India. Everything I've had has been delicious, traditional, and consistent. Just wish the atmosphere was more casual. It's strange to eat dosa with a knife and fork. Am I alone on this one?
author: Libby T.

description: High quality ingredients very well prepared, although a bit pricey. Staff were attentive and the place has nice modern decor.. I would guess that my Indian friends would say that the flavors were modified for the American palate. I thought it was very good, especially the dosa with chutney. There are cheaper dosa places, but this place is pretty good given the quality and execution.
author: Margot N.

description: I'd say this is place is good, "fancy" atmosphere and expensive (thus maybe good for a date ??), but  overrated. Other neighborhood indian restaurants are cheaper and better.
author: Augusto H.

description: Awesome south indian food! I myself being a south indian, I can confidently say that the food is very close to being authentic (I tried only the vegetarian dishes though). I really liked the ambiance and the service too!
author: Anu V.

description: Dosa is fantastic - even if you think you might not like Indian food - I swear, give this place a chance and you might decide that you were wrong. Their menu and their servers are very informative, and they help to teach you all you need to now about what you're about to partake in. I had a sample of everything and I think that's the way to go - you get a little taste of each course. The only think I'd advise against getting is the Gulab Jamoon for dessert - it's a fried dough ball in a sugar syrup....not very good. If I go back, I'd go for the gelato or sorbet instead.
author: meagan m.

description: 4.5 - Yum, yum, yum.  I had never had dosas before and they are darn tasty.  The salsas, chutney, dipping sauces for them were amazing as well.  The wait was longer than what they told us though and from what I heard that happens a lot but it was worth the wait.  I could have eaten like 3 more dosas though because there aren't much to them, so I wouldn't just get a single dosa again for my entire meal.  The suggested Malbec was also very good.
author: Rise G.

description: The food and the ambiance are really good.  I'm not too familiar with Indian food, so I don't know if it's traditional or not.  The servers were great and explained everything on the menu, and I enjoyed a really nice dinner here....it is a tad on the expensive side, but at least you know you're getting something good to eat.
author: Kristine C.

description:
**ADDENDUM** 
I got a personal message from one of the owners explaining their seating policy and why it was recently instated, and also addressing the issue with the check. It's a rare occasion that one receives service like this and I will happily return to Dosa knowing that the owners will take the time to reach out to individual patrons and address their grievances, esp. on the VERY DAY that the review was posted. If only more businesses here on Yelp did the same...was enough to change my 3-stars back to the 4 I had originally wanted to give them.***
---------------
It pains me to write anything less than an optimal review, but I've been frustrated lately by their seating policies. They require everyone to be there before seating us, which - in the case of last night - meant that six people waited for 10 minutes at the bar while our assigned table sat vacant. Frustrated, esp. when we'd been on our feet all day...would have liked to sit and relax.

The only other frustration came with a mix-up with the check - took us over 15 minutes to get out of there, and they still mis-charged the ONE credit card we had. They remedied this by giving us the difference in cash, but it was still a bit annoying.

That said.

The food here is consistently tasty; for those who aren't familiar with South Indian, it's mainly vegetarian and quite different from your "traditional" Indian (Naan 'n Chutney-esque restaurants that you see on every corner.) Their Uttapam and Dosa are both fantastic, whichever variety you choose, and I tried the calamari appetizer which tasted like Christmas. (Must have been the cloves, and note I *LIKE* things that taste like Christmas!) We always get the beautifully presented Dahi Vada and literally have to get more papadom  to scoop out the last morsels of this tastiness.

I will certainly return to Dosa and hope that they reconsider their seating policy for large groups (or are more willing to make an exception for "regular" customers like ourselves) as this restaurant would clearly earn at least 4 stars if not for that service snafu.
author: Aubrey S.

description: Dosa is great. Everytime we walk by, the aroma that wafts out when lucky patrons enter always makes me wish we'd go there instead. If only my wallet would allow such transgressions. Some of the folks that go there are a little annoying and who the hell drinks wine with Indian food. Send the sommelier to the unemployment office and mandate Kingfishers or Taj Mahals.
author: Andy L.

description: FINALLY made it here! And, was lucky enough to go with a regular and, smart enough to go during Labor Day weekend when everyone was out of town so no wait at all. Emily was wonderful, suggested a fantastic South African wine to compliment our food as well as this amazing tomato app which will be out of season in a few weeks.  Loved everything we ordered...and ATE IT ALL!!!!  Plus dessert.   The staff is very attentive and I cannot wait to go back.  I do recommend asking for a side of yogurt if you tend to have a sensitive palette...but it is so worth it to taste all those wonderful flavors.  Simply addictive.
author: Angela N.

description: I think this is the best Indian food I've ever had. Great service. We sat at the bar, tender was slammed but he still took care of us.
author: Ryan M.

description:
This place has great food.  I'd say, however there are few draw backs that are probably just plain inevitable for the location and quality: (1) it's expensive and (2) it's crowded on every night of the week (60+ minute waits sometimes) and (3) it's cramped (too many people, too little space; can get hot and stuffy, like you're back in India again).  

I stick to a few favorites when I go here.  The masala dosa is good though not necessarily the best I've had.  The sambar is pretty good too.  What I like best there is the rasam (the 'fire broth') it had a good deal or fire in it when I had it and I wouldn't recommend sipping it out of the bowl as the menu suggests... might be too much fire.  The chole bhatura (uhm, chane, or in english, I guess it's curried garbanzo beans and deep-fried leavened flat bread) is pretty good too.  I'd say besides home, there's been only one other place in the bay area where I've enjoyed it when eating out.  Finally, I had their mango kulfi once.  I'd give the kulfi a four, but the size of their portion is a definite thumbs down.

The service is also pretty good.  Every waiter/waitress we've ever gotten there has been easy going and attentive, but not overbearingly so.

I'd recommend going out with a group of friends to this place (preferably for a special occasion since it's a bit too pricey), but I wouldn't recommend it if you are just trying to relax and kick back or were just trying to get a quick bite.  

Ultimately, I'm sure there are other places where you can get comparable (equal or better) quality South Indian food for half the price and twice the leg room with almost no wait. (Not sure where they are in the city, but there's at least a couple of South Indian places in Berkeley that should do it).
author: Anx R.

description: Namaste!   I have not been to Dosa recently, but I have gone there several times... and everytime I go there, I enjoy my meal.  I will admit it gets a little crowded and noisy, but that's expected when a restaurant becomes iconic in San Francisco.  I lived in India off and on over a course of 20 years.  When I had my first dosa in Madras in the 70's, I thought - what a delicious way to have a crepe.  I couldn't get enough of the light crepe filled with potatoes and savory curry sauce.  So, coming from someone that has had authentic dosa from the South of India, when Dosa opened up - I was ecstatic!!! Dosa on Valencia is as close to home for me.  It's the real thing.
author: Lizzie L.

description:
Well. The idli sambar has gotten progressively worse. The sambar quality has remained the same but the Idlis are now hard after about 30 minutes. 

The takeout process is very good. They ask for your credit card and it is charged when you get there, just sign and pick up the food. Good if you are double parked. 

I am sure I would have given 4 stars about 6 months back
author: Venkat N.

description:
Loved it.  L-O-V-E-D I-T.  The bartender woman was soooo friendly, brought me poppadam while i was waiting for my friends to show, the pani puri and dahi vada were amazing.  Like "heaven in your mouth" amazing.   

it's slightly more pricey than some other indian places (approx the same prices as my other favorite place, indian oven on fillmore/haight), but worth it.
author: Charmaine Y.

description:
Went there on a Saturday mid morning - the place was not very busy, got seated right away. Nice place too. The food is really realy good. Most places seem to make a mess (e.g.Udupi/Sarvabhavan in Sunnyvale) of the uttappa - but these guys got it just right. A tad expensive perhaps - but well worth it.
Try the Dahi Vada - look and tastes great!
author: Vinayak S.

description:
This place is tasty, and has a fun atmosphere. The staff is very friendly, and it is about as trendy as it gets (not sure if this last thing is good or bad, but let's count it as a positive for now). 

The problem is (and here's where the trendiness comes in) that a part of me just rejects the idea of waiting around and paying this amount of money for a stylized version of South Indian food -a very tasty, but pretty simple and cheap type of comfort food, in my humble opinion. This is even more of a problem now that you can easily get more food and more authenticity for about a third of the price next door, at Udupi Palace. Not to mention that Udupi palace also has a pretty decent selection of wine...  If you must, I suggest just hitting a super-trendy lounge afterwards with the leftover cash... that way you can get better food, better drinks, and better people-watching for the same $!
author: Victoria K.

description: My friend's mom used to always talk about throwing a dosa party, but I never knew what the hell dosa was and figured I should know what it was and was too embarassed to ask.  Thanks to Dosa, the new South Indian restaurant in the Mission, now I know what dosa is - it's damn good.  As is everything else on the menu.  The decor is stylish without being overdone, and the servers were friendly and helpful (which is great when you have no idea what you're ordering).  I don't really remember the name of anything we ate except for the dosa.  But it was all good.  Now all I want to know is when is the next dosa party?
author: Erica G.

description: Really enjoyed the food, loved the Channa Bhatura (a chickpea stew and flaky soft amazing bread) and the wait staff was very kind when things weren't going too smooth (very long time to take order, 3 of the 4 meals appeared, very long time to get check). The acoustics were terrible, I couldn't hear my friends sitting directly next to me. We didn't have a wait, but if I had to wait an hour to get a table, probably be very hesitant to hang around. But food was still good.
author: Alyssa C.

description: I'm not sure if I've ever eaten at a Michelin-rated place before.  I've had South Indian many times before, but I think this is the first time things have been explained to me properly.  The coconut chutney that is the raita substitute was amazing.  I also really liked how the sambar wasn't super watery like it is everywhere else.  It was pretty thick with big chunks of carrots and stuff.  Prices are a little high but I thought worth it for a once-in-a-while treat.
author: Nessie V.

description: Great location, excellent ambiance, very friendly and helpful staff. Excellent excellent food. The wait is very long, so get a reservation or eat at the bar (full menu just like a table). Folks who were waiting for 45+ minutes were looking really really unhappy.
author: Jamie F.

description: My initial review of Dosa indicated that I thought the food was not particularly authentic South Indian.  I must correct myself: I just received the most thoughtful e-mail from one of the owners of Dosa (yes, owners & managers DO read these reviews!), and he assured me that the food is, in fact, quite authentic.  I am so impressed with the fact that he reached out to me in this way that I have to RE-review the place, and up my rating.  South Indian is all too rare in the Mission, and you can be sure that the owners & managers of this restaurant care a great deal about the quality of food they present (and what we all think of it).  You can't get that kind of attention everywhere, so I would say that Dosa is certainly worth a try.
author: Eric H.

description: damn tasty place, always friendly, a little over priced for indian breakfast food, but i guess we're a little far from india. The dosas are always top notch, Idli are just right (get the sambar on the side, no one wants a squishy Idli) And speaking of sambar, its so good, just spicy enough.
author: Jared Z.

description: Yes it's good. A tad shi-shi and noisy for my taste; however, if you want a fun place with slick ambience, fascinating/tasty food - you gotta go. The dosa is like taking classic stuff out of Hyderabad and putting a haute cuisine spin to it. The dosa is as delightful to eat as it is to look at, and I could say the same thing about the decor and the wait staff.
author: Thighmaster M.

description:
Dosa had been recommended to us, but I was a bit hesitant. I had eaten Indian food one time before and the experience was pretty bad. But my boyfriend loves Indian food and I agreed.

I am glad we went to Dosa! The menu has a lot of variety and the staff is friendly and helpful. My boyfriend loves spice, I can't eat any spice, and we both had dished that fit our taste. We also had a nice Riesling that complimented the food. Get the lamb meatballs!

One problem - they don't take reservations. We arrived at 6 and were seated right away. When we left at 7:15, there were at least 15 people standing outside waiting to get in.
author: Rachelle P.

description: Fantastic. Awesome food; Awesome service. A bit expensive tho. Best to bring your own wine and pay the $20 corkage.
author: Tuppence D.

description: MMMmmmm...Dosa.  Yum.  My mouth still burns but in a happy, feed me more Dosa's kind of way.  I actually don't like spicy food but somehow I still order their spicy dishes.  In other places I'd probably say hold the spice!  but here I don't want to mess with the perfection of herbs and spices in their dishes.  I get the Masala Dosa (spicey) and the Chennai chicken (not).  The white and orange sauces are great but I pass on the brown bean soup tasting one.  I think their salads are good too.  Oh and if you're not into spicy avoid the chips they give you in the beginning.  I think it just intensifies it.
author: Ann F.

description:
I had a lovely experience here, but reading about other people getting ghee when they ordered vegan entrees scares me a bit!! Anyway, I went here, because I heard it had good vegan Indian food, which is hard to find in this city! When I was vegetarian I would stuff myself with Indian food all the time until I was in pain. Now, I'm having trouble finding a place that understands what vegan is (one place in the marina served me up a big chunk o paneer, yuck!, btw, on a side track what is the point of paneer, it tastes like tofu anyway, couldn't they just replace it with tofu?) Anyway, I do believe and hope that we found that holy grail: yummy vegan Indian food at this place. We told our server we were vegan and asked if we could do the tasting menu, and she said yes, they could make anything that wasn't already vegan, vegan. We started with lentil soup and a sprouted chick pea salad. The sprouted lentil salad was fresh but not amazing. The soup was very spicy and yummy.  Then we got our dosas, which turned out to be very crepe-like (of course now my suspicions of egg are creeping up). They were filled with yummy veggies and potatoes and came with three orgasmically good sauces. I almost licked out the rest of the coconut sauce. Then came our curries. I got a vegetable masala that was pretty good, not amazing. My boyfriend got a chana masala that was freakin delicious (she had them leave out the cream she said), and we ended with a coconut sorbet, which was yummy and fresh, but nothing to write home about. It was a pricey night, but our server was nice, and, at least I hope, it was my first good vegan Indian food experience in the city!

***update***
I've been assured by one of the owners that the food I ate here was, in fact,  vegan, and the dosas are made with fermented rice and lentils, and can easily be made without ghee. So, vegan kiddies, be careful, but I think you are safe here.
author: Jeani H.

description: Distinctive South Indian food. Enjoyed the Chopped Salad (which is a lot of fresh vegetables)  which was flavorful and healthy. The dosas are incredible; I liked the mixture that was in them and the chutneys and sauces that accompanied. Great place to grab a bite before going to Osento.
author: Shannon R.

description: This is a great place to eat. The food is very well presented and still authentic south Indian. The staff is very courteous and friendly. They have a good selection of dosas and other south indian dishes, including some interesting drinks. I went there with my friends on New Years' eve and had a wonderful time. Will definitely go there again.
author: Matheen R.

description: I ventured out to Dosa last night and it was DELICIOUS! I tried their tasting menu as it was my first time there and was very impressed with all of my dishes. I had the mango salad to start, the signature dosa, the lamb curry and the gulab for dessert. Pretty safe bets on my part but all delicious. I can't wait to go back for a Dosa!
author: Susana M.

description: Delicious, different, unique flavors, great wine list, classy interior, friendly service, great prices.  So, whatcha waiting for?  Just go here, it's definitely worth it.
author: Piper B.

description: OK, I visited Dosa again and had to up my review.  The sambar is really really good. My uttapam was very tasty (though a little underdone, I thought, a little mushy in the middle). My date's rava dosa was tasty tasty, and I thought the chutneys were much improved from last time i was there. We ate at the bar and it was overall a great experience, and we left satisfied. I wish It were less noisy, though.
author: Heather R.

description:
hands down, one of the best indian restaurant i've been. been there few times. great vegi menu. nice bartenders and host. talked to the owner, Anja (spelling), i believe. very nice. no wonder why this place is packed. good place for larger parties (6-12 people)

go after 10pm. more space, less wait, better service. great lychee drink. unfortunately they don't have full alcohol menu. but still, it's one of the best in the city. 2 thumbs up.
author: Parham A.

description: This was my first experience with South Indian food and I LOVED it.  I got the Sping Dosa and it was so good, even the dipping sauces were amazing by themselves.  I wish it wasn't out of the way for me because I would love to go back soon.
author: Jenna M.

description: I came here for the second time last night. My date and I sat at the bar because on a Monday night, we neglected to make reservations and it was very busy! In general I prefer Northern Indian food to Southern Indian food so if you're craving butter chicken or briyani, this place isn't for you. However, if you're a vegetarian this place is heaven. We started with these dahl pani (sp?) little chaat appetizers they only serve Saturday - Monday and ordered a wonderful lentil stew whose name I can't recall and Masala Dosa. Everything was very flavorful and FILLING. What made the night even better was that our bartender was informative and had the best selections of wine to pair with S. Indian cuisine. I'll definitely be back again.
author: Leslie T.

description: Anjan and Emily have struck gold their first time out of the gate. Dosa is great food and service, in a warm friendly environment, consistent from your second visit through your 20th. This restaurant is a testament to their business savvy, understanding of what the market wants, and an uncanny  ability to make each and every customer feel wanted and welcome. I love this food and recommend it to each and every person that happenstance decides to talk food with me. Run, don't walk to Dosa.
author: damir z.

description:
To start with, I've eaten at a fair number of South Indian restaurants. The dosas here are pretty good though I think they use a bit too much ghee (clarified butter) in their dishes. The dosas themselves are VERY nice and crispy -- just the way I like 'em. The potatoes inside the masala dosa were well spiced as well. The bottom line here, though, is that this place is WAAAY overpriced. I grant you that people come here for the experience. If that's what you are going for, go for it. But there are a ton of places in the South Bay AND Berkeley that serve dosas just as good as these (if not better on the "on" days) and at literally half the price.

By the way, I'd say skip the meat or at least the Chennai Chicken. They were like fried chicken fritters and they weren't served with any mint or cilantro chutney.. what gives guys?!?

EDIT: I was notified that the restaurant uses high quality organic ingredients and to be fair, has to pay wages and rent in SF as compared to other parts of the Bay. Something to consider when paying the bill...
author: Salil A.

description:
Amazing!  And I don't even normally like Indian food!  While the decor is stylish, the service and prices are down-to-earth.  We enjoyed the complimentary papadums, thin and crisp lentil chips.  

The dahi vada appetizer was phenomenal.  Although the menu says that they are "dumplings", the dish can more accurately be described as packed breadcrumbs (almost like graham cracker crust) topped with a colorful variety of sauces, including yogurt.  Okay, I have obviously not described it in a very appetizing way, but mark my words, it is DELICIOUS!

We also had the chatni masala dosa (huge, enough to feed two people) and the South Indian Moons uttapam (a sampler platter).  The coconut chutney that came with both dishes was just the right sauce to offset the savory and spicy dishes.

For dessert, we had the rasmalai, cheese patties soaked in cream and flavored with rose, cardamom, and crushed pistachios.  The rose flavor was completely infused into the dish.  It was the best Indian dessert I have ever had.  It tasted so light and refreshing, but I'm sure it was packed with calories!
author: Ana L.

description: this place is yummy.  Food was interesting, i had never had the southern style and was pleasantly surprised.  I can't wait to go back.  Our waitress was amazing as well.
author: Jocie H.

description:
I absolutely love this place. The food, ambiance, service, great prices... everything is so well executed. Be prepared to wait up to an hour on busy nights but luckily they will call your cellphone to let you know your table is ready.

Whenever I have friends come into town and I want to take them somewhere great, Dosa is always my first suggestion.
author: Matt N.

description: We had a wonderful dinner at Dosa, and the service was great. All the portions are generous enough to share, and we did just that. We had the romaine-fried paneer salad, the Chennai chicken appetizer, and a Masala Dosa, sharing all between two people. It was plenty of food. Service was attentive and well timed. We will return to this place, as it was the best Indian food we have had in the Bay Area.
author: Barbara A.

description:
This place has been fantastic since it opened. There's always a wait if you arrive after 6pm, but it's always worth it -- a unique Indian dining experience thanks to the southern Indian perspective (e.g., dosas) and consistantly excellent, freshly prepared, high-quality food across the board. The challenge is figuring out how to fit it all in. Great wine list that compliments the food particularly well, excellent lassies (that tasty non-alcoholic yogurt drink), good service every time, and I really like all the dosa varieties I've had there -- ravi, paper, classic. Don't bother with the curries unless you have a serious appetite because the dosas will fill you up. My favorite curry is the lamb but plan to be taking some home with you. The romaine salad with the fried paneer is a delicious first course, and lighter than some of the other starters. The theme here: save room for as much dosa as you can -- it's going to fill you up and you're going to love it!!!

I could become a vegetarian again at this place . . .
author: Emmabelle S.

description: Mmmmm. Dosa. Their paneer and romaine salad...oh lord. I'm sitting here in New York seriously missing SF, and the food at Dosa being one. The paneer and romaine consists of romaine salad leaves, toast farmer's cheese cubs, tiny cherry tomatoes and a garlic dressing which made me want to forget about my entree after I had it. It was a delicious blending of crispy, creamy, and crunchy- perfect for summer and seasons year round. The papadum (lentil flatbread) had a spicy crispy bite and the cheese dosa reminded me of an enchilada, but thats okay because it was delicious nonetheless. All around delicious!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I've never had  a negative experience at Dosa. In fact they've all been stellar.

If it's a cold San Francisco summer evening head here for a glass of red and some of the best curries I've ever had. Anywhere. I found myself in the middle of Delhi craving their channa.

Dosa will continue to thrive because of the ingredients they choose to employ, their effort in continually evolving their menu, and an understanding of what their particular clientele craves.

And for the constant reviews attacking what's authentic and legit: did you ever stop to think that maybe your mama's uttapam sucks?
author: Rummy T.

description:
This place deserves nothing less than 5 stars. It's my fave place in SF to go to when the dosa cravings hit. And being south-indian, I can say with some authority that this place is 100% authentic. The variety of dosas is commendable, they do not skimp on the spices (not in the sense of chilli hot, but just the indian spices which make indian food taste, smell and look like indian food) and that is why they deserve full marks. 

The ambience is WOW. Love the lighting and wall decor and cozy seats. The place gets quite crowded on weekends, so we always arrive at opening time to get in quick and stay longer, savoring our dishes. The cocktails are very good, they have some new ones which I tried last time - the Indian Monsoon - amazing flavors of ginger, lime and mint along with some I don't know what, but I ordered two of these all for myself :D It was THAT good!

The food always blows me away. It's prepared with so much care, it's evident from the first bite that the chef knows what he's doing. I always get the 5-indian-moons - chef's choice of 5 uttappams, with sambar and chutney accompaniments. This dish is hands down my fave. It's like a stellar course of 5 different mouth-watering uttampams, each small enough to tantalize your tastebuds and have you craving for more. We also get the chilli chicken, which is delicately flavored and seriously good. Hubby usually gets a dosa, they rock at the potato filling, the sambar with ghee smells oh so good, and they are very very attentive at refilling water, but leaving you with good privacy especially for couples. 

Have been to Dosa 10+ times now and never had anything to complain about. Always leave the place raving happy, on how good the food was, the service, how happy and content I am etc etc. Their desserts are yum too - try the gulab jamun for sure! 

Am so craving some hot dosas and coffee now. Wish they would open another branch in the Peninsula!
author: Foodie F.

description: Dosa is my favorite Indian restaurant.  I love the udapams.  A date took me to what was supposed to be a better cheaper place a few doors down and it didn't compare at all.  I'll gladly pay more at Dosa.
author: Meliza M.

description: I went to Dosa on the opening weekend and am in love with the food.  The atmosphere was really fun and enticing, and the food was a welcome change to typical Indian cuisine.  The only downside was that our waitress was a little strange, but the hostess was great.  Be sure to make a reservation though, because we got there and the wait was 3 hours!  Luckily we had a reservation.
author: Jill W.

description: Absolutely loved it here and the service was great.  I never had South Indian food before and it was a real treat.  Would definitely recommend!
author: Candice M.

description:
Simply put, if you like Indian food or are open to a rewarding adventure into Indian food. Go here. Go early. Good service, good atmosphere, great food. YES, it is a hot spot but it doesn't yet feel like the Marina is spawning here.

Update: (March '07) I'm upgrading to 4.5 stars - because the food IS THAT GOOD, their wine list has improved since I was last there and I had dessert this past time - GOOD.  If they would just start taking reservations this would easily be a 5.

Here is my argument for the (all size party) reservation policy:
 
1) You done good. LOTS OF PEOPLE know about you, talk about you, want to eat at you. Mission "generate buzz" accomplished.
2) I'm not conducting surveys but I'd still guess that the majority of your patrons are local-ish (Mission, Noe, Bernal, Castro) and if I may say so, when the options are a) wait for 45-hour or b) eat dinner at 4:30 in the afternoon: the hassle factor starts to drive us elsewhere.  (and I can't imagine this helps with the audiences for whom the mission location is not a plus). You are unique enough that sometimes I'll brave this, but there's many a night when I end up elsewhere even though you were my first choice. (later weekend hours would remedy this as well)
3) Though you are an excellent romantic but not too romantic dinner spot, I can never plan such dinners at you because of aforementioned unromantic things like 45minute waits and 4:30 in the afternoon.
4) The people standing outside are like the evening version of the Boogaloo morning crowd - not in appearance,mind you, but in annoying-blocking the sidewalk factor.
5) The current reservation policy (5 or more, 4 or more?) encourages patronage by the kind of people who move in herds, who are, in general - how do I say this delicately?-  tacky (I do not extend this criticism to family groups, who tend to make me smile and I enjoy eavesdropping on) Now, tacky people are entitled to your goodness too. . .but a herd of them is a bit much.  Alternatively, it encourages the rest of us to accumulate a herd which encourages us to drink more and get loud and disturb those lucky diners who have persevered with the romantic dinner thing.  

Now, since you have proved yourself to be quite deliberate in most of your decisions I don't expect that the current policy is merely thoughtless . . . but this is one diner who would  consider you perfect if I could just make a reservation for 2 on a Thurs-Fri-Sat night between 8-10.
author: Jen A.

description:
I loved the food, the atmosphere and the service has been fantastic both times that I've been. The wait seems scary at first when you arrive, but it seemed to move really quickly when we were there. Try the Dahi Vada appetizer (unreal dumplings in amazing sauce - served chilled), and we also loved the Mysore masala and the lamb curry was fantastic. 

The owner was incredibly friendly, stopping by our table n both occasions to check in and find out how our meal was and it's always nice to have that kind of hands on attention. Great guy, great food, right on!!
author: Eric D.

description:
WOW!  My husband and I came here when it was recommended by a store clerk.  There was already a wait when we arrived and even when we left at around 9pm, there were still people waiting to eat at Dosa.  

We went with the 4 course meal and we're glad we did.  When the food was first coming out, my first impression was that we weren't going to be full because the portions seemed a bit small.  By the 2nd course, we were already getting pretty full!  Every dish was so packed with flavor and I loved every course and every dish we had.  My husband and I both went with the 4 course meals and got different items, so we were able to try different things.  

This would have received a 5 star for it's food, but in the end it only received 4 stars because of the noise level in the restaurant and the way the service seemed rushed.  For a 4 course meal, I would have liked to enjoy it more, but it seemed after every course, even before we were finished, a waiter would come by and say "well, the next course is coming up" and would almost rush us to finish to make room for the next thing.  But the service was still good, just not what I would have hoped for.  It is a must try for those that love flavor and spice!
author: Kathy L.

description: This is a really hard restaurant to get into especially as they do not take reservation for small parties. My friend and I went there and waited at the bar for around 45 minutes before we were seated. We ordered the dahi vada which loked great and was delicious. Then we went on to order the famous Dosa and prawn curry. Everything was absolutely wonderful. Our drinks were excellent as well. Well worth the wait!
author: Sandy p.

description:
A "dosa" is kind of like an Indian crepe.  I am sure that they let you know this on their website, but my friends and I were not privy to this information, so I thought it would be helpful to to write it here since the theme of my dining experience was dipping an assortment of tasty crepes in an assorment of yummy dips.
Anyway, Dosa was a great eating experience: the decor is very orange, yet subtle, the servers informed and helpful, the food delicious.  But, seriously watch out for the habanero dosa.  (They say "watch out" on the menu and I just want to let you know that they mean business!)  After tasting it my body went through a couple reactions: 1.  HOT, as in spicy in my mouth  2.  oh wow, my my ears and nasal passages just cleared up  3. tears in my eyes, i hope nobody's looking.  
ps. We did have reservations (4 ppl)  and were seated in a timely manner.    
pps. I thought that the next day my clothing and hair would smell like Indian food, but that was not the case.  Yay!
author: Torey H.

description: I live real close to Dosa, but have only been there once.  For lunch.  So why review it?  Because they were so sweet.  I honestly kind of did not like the Dosa's we had to eat.  Just not my thing.  But it is a cool atmosphere and the service was attentive and they brought a special unordered baby dish for my baby and cooed over him and it made the whole day special.  So yea Dosa, I may never brave the lines and return but you live on in my heart for being so nice and friendly on an endless baby strolling Saturday.
author: steven g.

description:
I love this place! My favorite is the paneer and peas dosa. The green salad with mango is also very good. As with most Indian, there are options for vegetarians and vegans (ask about which things can be brought vegan). 

There can be a long wait for a table on the weekend, since they only take reservations for parties of five or more. I have waited anywhere from 30 minutes to an hour and 45 minutes. The good thing is they will take your cell number and call you, so you can go to a bar elsewhere. I like the bar at Dosa but it is so crowded with other people waiting that sometimes it makes more sense to go someplace else for the wait.
author: L W.

description:
had a really nice time and great food here!
i got a traditional masala dosa and it was so delicious!  filled with traditional masala flavors, potatoes and cashews, this was a flavor sensation.  the dipping sauces were all tasty but especially the one spicier one.  mmm!
not inexpensive by any means but not as pricey as i would have expected.  good value for food.
also, anything on the menu can be made vegan and most is already vegetarian for those of you that swing that way.
all in all, excellent experience and i would love to go back!
author: Lily B.

description:
updated 12/29 (and added another star).
Compliments to the staff for making sure our 2nd experience was not a duplicate of the first. We arrived and were seated right away. Our server was great and tolerant (we were a teeny bit annoying, i'll admit.. someone thought happy hour before dinner was a good idea :)

The food was quick and good. One dish was outstanding -- the Dahi Vada -- this was the first thing we got and it was fabulous.
I also was fond of the paper dosa -- it was slightly sweet. But everything else? was fine but had very similar flavors. The shrimp curry had a smoky flavor so was a bit of a standout.

Here's the thing -- if I was walking by and saw no crowd  would I stop in? maybe. The food was decent but only that first dish was "special". I don't think it'd be a destination spot for me, tho I thought it was decent. And yes, we over-ate.

Updated 12/26 (and upgraded a star) because we received a message/apology from the owner and an invitation to return. Will update again after we give it another shot.

So we called dosa before we went (they no longer take reservations for under 5 people) and asked how long the wait was for a table of 3. About a half hour.
we figured we'd give it a shot; see how it progressed and had backup plans in mind of where else to go.
We got there and they said 25 minutes so we asked how many people were ahead of us. 7. We got drinks and watched people get seated. After 40 minutes we checked in and it was down to 2 ahead of us. Seemed reasonable; sure it wasn't the 25 minutes we thought but that was OK. 10 minutes later they told us there were a few tables of 3 leaving and we should be seated soon. We watched many 4 tops get seated (which was frustrating because we would clearly order as much as any 4 top and had already consumed more at the bar than those tables would in food). We check in again and they were not the least bit apologetic. We told them we were leaving (after an hour wait) and they said OK. Bye. 
UGH. We'd read the reviews ahead of time about how bad the wait was. Tempting to go back when we have 5 for reservations, but I think we'd have to wait  then, too.
Not worth it. We walked down the block to Range. Was curious to try the food but the staff were just so disinterested. Wouldn't recommend unless you had plenty of free time and patience.
author: Margie L.

description: Excellent food!!!!  The Lamb curry, Rasam" Fire Broth" soup, Potato Croquet, and Cochin Calamari are all very very good.  I wasn't super impressed with the potato croquet though, the chuntney makes up what it lacks.  Service was sub par.  The bus boy was more attentive to our needs than our waitress.  Plus, when the main course came, she brought out the wrong dish for me. How do you confuse "Tamil Lamb Curry" with "Pepper Chicken?" Anyway, the food and ambiance is so well put together, I will leave it with 4 stars and I still plan to go back
author: Marco M.

description:
wasn't blown away by any means, but it was pretty good and i would go back to give it another shot. our starter of fried spinach and cauliflower patties was good, and had a really nice kick to it. but they only give you two, which seems a bit small, esp since the patties were small in size. 

we also shared two uttapam--one masala and one with tomatoes and onions. both were good and the lentil soup and spreads they came with were delish. next time i think i'd like to try one of the meatier dishes just for a lil more diversity in my meal. for dessert we shared these lil milk balls in a sweet syrup. very yummy. 

i didn't find it pretentious at all. our server was nice and always there when we needed her. she didn't try to oversell us on food, and each of our glasses of wine had good pours. tho at $8 a glass, i know that malbec is a bit overpriced. so it goes with wine in SF tho.

i still think i'd rather have a hearty yummy meal at my local flavors of india on college ave in rockridge. you can get so much more food and drink there and it's def cheaper.
author: rachel p.

description: Good service, great food, fun cocktails!  This is not the typical Indian food you may be normally used to.  I am talking the heavy sauces-type Indian food.  Dosa has clean flavors and I end up feeling very full when I leave, and not due to heavy sauces but because we couldn't control ourselves and just kept ordering.  I have also been to Dosa on Fillmore.  Also a very good place but a bigger venue and just a different vibe.  Dosa on Valencia is smaller, more intimate, and more of a neighborhood restaurant.
author: Bay Area G.

description:
As someone who has recently traversed around Karnataka sampling all kinds of dosas and stuffing my face with idli and sambar every morning (or any chance I could get...lets be honest), I can attest that Dosa does a fine job with the classics. 

I had the standard masala dosa while at Dosa and was pretty satisfied with the chutneys provided as well. In general, Indian restaurants in the States don't quite measure up with the "spicy" factor as their geographically Indian counterparts....but TRUST me. This is not necessarily a bad thing. I was basically dying in one of the "local" restaurants in Bangalore from spicy tongue disease. Food can be untolerably spicy in India and there's no sympathy for a wimp....so I'm ok with medium spicy.

While veggie and vegan options were copious in Bangalore and Mysore, their exclusiveness in restaurants was not the norm. Things seem to be changing in the more urban environments, so the authenticity of a South Indian restaurant being judged solely on whether they serve meat or not seems to be a relic of the past. I guess what I'm trying to say is that the fact that Dosa serves meat doesn't negate it's "South Indian" restaurant-ness....at least not anymore....for better or worse.

Hell, I had freaking Chinese food in India...on the streets. Of course it was untolerably spicy and had curry powder in it...but whatev.
author: bloopie s.

description: I love this place. We had a reservation but got there a little early so we waited near the bar. I ordered one of their mixed drinks and asked the bartender if it was very sweet. He said it would be well balanced and I could have my money back if I didn't like it. He was right and it was delicious and he was just super friendly. We had to wait a little past our reservation time but we didn't care because we were enjoying our drinks and chatting with our friends. The lovely waitress kept checking in with us and was much more concerned about our wait than we were. Once we were seated they brought us a DELICIOUS fresh tomato dish on the house to compensate for us having to wait. So nice and unnecessary. We then ordered the tasting menu and just asked for one of everything and it was super fun and super delicious. The food is great and the service is even better! Not inexpensive but I'm happy to pay for great food and great service!
author: Nina R.

description: Great place, great ambiance, can't complain about the food.... This is my favorite Indian place:-). I took one star b'cos of the dumb waitress who screwed up our check, no smiles, no politeness.....that definitely dampens a good night out ;-(
author: Justyna R.

description:
Good service, nice ambience and hands down the best sambar. 
Tried 3 different dosa- the rava dose is great. 
The habenero mango- is very spicy- be careful. 
Also had the lamb special- was excellent. 
will go back for sure
author: zara k.

description:
I think it was maybe the hype that made me so disappointed.
The staff was nice and we were seated within twenty minutes without a reservation.  The food I thought was over priced for what we got and average, but not great!  I went to Dosa (NOT affiliated, but also serves Southern Indian cuisine) in Madrid and comparatively I think the food is about the same quality if not a little better (portions were a good size larger) and the restaurant in Madrid was actually more reasonably priced.

I have been informed that all the ingredients are organic.  This being said, I still believe the mediocre portions where overpriced.   There were only about three bites worth of food in my entree.

They did however accommodate me be letting me know which dishes where wheat free as I am allergic.
author: Jaden V.

description: Dosa has the best dosas that i have had since being back from spending 1 year in south india studying abroad. Their rava dosa is amazing and crunchy and delicious. Their chutneys are incredible, and the dahi vada as an appetizer does wonders to my tastebuds. corny but it's true. good luck getting a seat for dinner, but the coffee shop down the street is a nice place to wait it out. It's super classy in that SF style. It's quite a different experience from say, Sarava na bhavan in SanJo, but i guess that all comes with the pricey-ness of their dishes. Go figure SF. Definitely try it out if you live in the bay are or are visiting the Mission, and especially if you have never had south indian food before. all of it is amazing.
author: Sylvia F.

description: After hearing a fair amount of recommendations from some foodie friends we went by for dinner.   My first shock was that a glass of Torrontes, an Argentinian everyday quaffing wine was $10 by the glass. Those wines usually retail for $7-8 bucks a bottle and charging that amount for this kind of wine is really unreasonable.   If it had been $7 or $8 a glass that would be acceptable in a restaurant situation but in a tough economy and with fewer people dining out, it really upsets me to see this kind of price gauging.    The dinner was satisfying, we had the samosas, a dosa and one curry which were tasty but truly not distinctive enough to merit the prices we paid.   I realize the dosa itself is a speciality, but to me it would be better served as a street cart food for a reasonable price rather than a white tablecloth restaurant where you leave feeling a much lighter wallet.   Our total tab for one app, two entrees, 1 beer and 2 glasses of wine was $72 without tip, come on guys, only one dish had meat in it...how can you justify that?    We won't be back.
author: Kimberly C.

description: This was a cute little place that my friend suggested. The food was pretty flavorful, but the portions were quite small considering what they were charging. The ambiance was good though, and the staff was really friendly, so I guess one would be paying more for service than anything else. Overall, I'd say it was an okay experience, but certainly nothing I'd highly recommend to friends.
author: Ty L.

description: I had a f ing cold when I came here, so I had my guards up...but I needed to get out of the house (being the hottest day of the year) and I didn't want to cook myself. Being brown...I know what's up. I know dosas are generally huge and usually serves 2. My boyfriend got a chicken appetizer that he really liked and we got the rava masala dosa...excellent! The only other amazing dosa place I know of is in Queens, NY...so this was a wonderful treat. I LOVED the artwork and I want one now...or try and create on like that myself. The crowd wasn't overbearing and service was prompt and attentive.
author: Anita C.

description: Wow!  Really enjoyed this place, everything was excellent!  Had the calamari, the paneer salad, the country curry, the lamb and the cheese dessert.  Everything was really good, service great and I liked the wine list too.  Will def be back for another trip.
author: caroline b.

description: I came here for brunch with a friend and chose to skip the line at Cafe Boogaloo.  I'm so happy we made that decision.  We started with small crispy breads with yougurt.  Delish!!!  I really enjoyed my Sunnyside Eggs Uttapam.  This was a great alternative to eggs bendict.  My friend ate a Dosa with eggs and cheese...equally delish.  The Madras coffee was also incredible - rich and creamy.  I'll definitely be coming back for more.
author: Ro L.

description: Really nice, clean, modern look for the restaurant I love the glass panels.  The food though was disappointing.  The sauces were not very good or tasty and dosas themselves lacked flavor and interest.  Two of the dosas we could not tell the difference except that one was folded in half and the other was rolled.  The only reason I would ever come back is that the owner seemed VERY nice.   I thought the food was not very good, because of his sweet nature, I will chalk it up to that we ordered the wrong things.
author: Dana C.

description:
It's great to have a south indian restaurant in the city. Great decor, really cozy.. etc etc.
However can they please make learn to make better Mysore dosas? I went there on Sunday night and ordered the mysore dosa, it was soft, soggy ... tasted like it had been made a few hours ago and reheated in the microwave. Dosas are supposed to be hot, fresh and a little crispy. I've been told that the curries @ Dosa are really good. I really like the restaurant, just wish their Dosas were better.
Another weird thing about the service.. when we got there the place was full. We told the host that we'd sit at the bar and order and get our appetizers there and move over to the table when it was free. Finally when a table opened up the host (who was really sweet) said "Sorry since you have placed your order here I cannot move you to the table, as the server will have nothing to do" (Seriously.. if she hadnt been so nice, I would have argued about it.. decided to suck it up and move on). What kind of a policy is that anyway?!

If you are craving dosas and can make a trip up to the peninsula then drop by Tabla (foster city)- their dosas are AMAZING and much cheaper! (While there try out there samosas - I honestly think they have the best samosas in the bay area).
author: Kin J.

description:
Dosa, a lively Southern Indian Cuisine restaurant in the Mission. I will not pretend to know squat about this specific food, but it was different, in a good way. Usually go to Indian and get the standard Tandoori Chicken and Naan bread, and probably spell it and say it wrong too!

All the menu items were new to me, so I was excited to ask the wait staff about the dishes and what to order. Steered in the right direction and our party ordered a few Dosas, a traditional something or other with stuff inside. For the sake of me I cannot explain them! Anyways, Dosas were great and the prawn curry was my favorite dish.

I would steer away from the larger, next time will order wine. I ordered it because it was a big bottle and I could get two glasses out of it. Wine menu is impressive, and there seems to be a better pairing between the wines and the food.

Order a few dishes and share, there is also a price fixe menu, but that is being selfish :0. The servers are par for the course, but the hostess made us feel very welcomed, guess that is like judging a book by its cover. Put your name down, give them your cell number and hit one of hundreds of divey bars around town come back and dive in.
author: David B.

description: So here's the thing about DOSA: Dosa is a crepe, from the southern part of India where people are very religious and very vegetarian. (I've done my research) Traditional south Indian food does not entail any sort of meat and yet ,DOSA has meat dishes. Of course this is to cater to those who just can't manage to have ONE meal without meat. Don't get me wrong, I love meat to death...but a south Indian restaurant is no place for it. With that said, all the veggie dishes on the menu are mouth watering. Literally and figuratively. They are delicious but spicy at the same time. I feel like most Indian places in the city make food mild for the non-Indian folk but not DOSA. Oh, you must get their Paper dosa, it's the size of a carpet. If you're looking for authentic south Indian vegetarian fare, this is the place for it. If you want chicken- go to Chutney.
author: S K.

description: The best Indian restaurant i have eaten in the Bay Area. Coming from Dallas region and being fed with authentic indian food in all the desi places, I was a little dissapointed with the indian food in San Diego. During the recent visit to the Bay Area, I was lucky to end  up at this place for Lunch and I have to say I was very impressed with the Food and the overall experience. I can recommend it to any one interested in Indian food, this is the place to go in Bay Area.
author: Srikanth V.

description: Had a great meal here last week.  I love that they can make most uttapans and dosas gluten-free!  Yum!  Now if only there were some meat options in the dosas!  (You can get meats just not in a dosa.)  Nice decor.
author: laura g.

description: I was excited when Dosa opened in SF and thought it would be a nice alternative to either going to Annapoorna in San Mateo (where the food is good but ambiance zero) or driving down all the way to Sunnyvale for our dosa fix. I would have to say I was disappointed. The dosas were pretty bland and so were most of the other dishes. I understand it's a fusion place and caters to a wider palate but the food still needs to taste good! The only item I liked from the menu was Chennai Chicken. Additionally, the place can get really crowded and has a long wait on the weekends. In fact, the last time we went, the wait was so long that we were about to give up and leave when we finally got seated. We were a little rushed with the dinner too. It also gets really noisy, so not an ideal place for a relaxed dinner or a first date.
author: Shari A.

description:
Great vibe, great service and the food was good.  The prices were OK.  If you break it down, you're eating a bunch of bread....if you're ok with that this place is a treat, but if you are into veggies and protein maybe not the best choice.  I don't know enough about S. Indian food to comment on authenticity, but I have had better Indian food - not sure of the region.

Our waitress was really cool and the host was pleasant and accommodating.
author: anderson g.

description:
We drove to SF and went to Dosa today at an off hour - around 3:00, so it was not packed.  Parking right outside - yaay!   My very first experience with Indian food, years and years ago, before the dawn of time, was a south Indian restaurant, so I am somewhat familiar with dosas.  Plus I have traveled to India.  Unfortunately, I was not overly impressed with the dosas at Dosa on Valencia....whine....maybe it was an off day?  Maybe the time?  The filling just seemed a little...bland.  I know dosas aren't spicy - but I mean it seemed just like potatoes and tumeric - I could not detect any cumin seeds, which I just love, and isn't there usually some onion sauteed in butter?.  The coconut chutney was okay, but honestly I've had somewhat better.  In fact I've made coconut chutney (and it did take a lot of experimentation to get it right) and mine is better (although it's so much work - I used a fresh coconut  and toasted chana dal - that I don't make it often)..  But I'm not saying that it was bad at all - just not spectacular.  So obviously I'm giving the place a good review anyway.  We started with the pani puri, which I have never had and thought it was really fun.  We really liked the mint cilantro water.  My husband ordered the South Indian Moon Uttapam - a selection of them.  I thought they were just great.  As for Rob - well, he liked them, but I think he prefers Northern Indian food.  Actually, I think he needs to try more South Indian items.  We also ordered raita (we just love the stuff and have to try it everywhere).  It was just fantastic.  That yogurt!  Where did they find it?  maybe they made it?  It was soooooo rich and tangy and great (especially after last week's debacle at the DREADED Amber India).

The service was really good.  We were offered a choice of sitting at the bar or at a table by a really nice guy - and then our server was really great - she had a way of being helpful without every being overbearing. For example, she asked us whether we had ever had pani puri before (no) and then showed us how to put it together.  She did this without being condescending in the least.  Later she asked whether we were familiar with the sauces (we were) and she said "oh, great" and left us to enjoy them.  Service was quick and attentive without being overbearing in the slightest - everyone who works there seems very personable.  Prices, of course, are reasonable.  I would come back.  Husband - oh, come on now - does he really have a choice? :)
author: Pam P.

description: Moved to the OC about a year ago and have been deprived of good Indian food so when my friends Val & Toby dragged me to the Mission for some good eats, this was #1 on their list. Service was good, food yummy...i wish this place was closer to me!
author: Deidre C.

description: I just love all the different spices and flavors at this restaurant.  Very different than any other Indian restaurant that I've been to.  A+ for originality and creativity with the food.  The owner did also come to our table and was very gracious.  For those of you who want to try it but don't want to wait at night, she informed us that they serve lunch on Saturday and Sunday and that there is never a wait.  She also said that the chef does some special curry for lunch that he does not do for dinner time.  Check it out.  Not for those who can't handle spicy food.
author: Princess P.

description: Limited but good. They have a range of really good dosas, including excellent massala dosas. The sauce these come with is very flavoursome. but they all seem to come with almost the same sauce, and most are accompanied by the same soft potato, so there isn't much variety.
author: Nick O.

description: Total bill was sort of pricey. But their DOSAs are sooo good!!
author: Kerry W.

description: I went there a couple of weeks ago. We shared a few dishes so I got to try several items on the menu. Their heirloom tomato w/ noodle salad was yummy. Dahi vada and cheese and chili uttapam were okay. Channa bhatura was really nice and best of all, they had good selection of wines. The waitress was really helpful and she helped us pick most of the dishes. The place is small and got really noisy and hot on Friday night but it was in Oct, hottest month of the year in SF.
author: Maya G.

description: Like the food. Similar to the dosa on fillmore. But a bit more congested and smaller place. Costly/nice food/less food for the dollars. but again its located in a nice place. good for parties once in a while and meet people!
author: Sri R.

description: What can I say that hasn't been said by the 450+ other yelpers. Not much. But I still have to write something about this place because it has to be my favorite indian place in the city. The dosas are sooo tasty, the curries are delish, and even the salads (the mango one is my favorite!) are so good...! Granted, the place is crowded and they don't take reservations (hence the loss of one star), but people, it's packed for a reason!  Now just waiting to try their brunch.....
author: SL N.

description:
I feel about this place kind of like I feel about Ti Couz--once you are no longer enamored by the constructed exoticness of the place, there really isn't much substance left to keep bringing you back.

The food ranges from a decent rendition of South Indian food to just plain weird. I have sympathy for the chef--when you actually go to South India, most of the food there is not made with especially fresh, healthy ingredients. To make the kind of food that health-conscious San Franciscians are expecting, you need to be creative and move beyond that cuisine. All that is fine (I'm not an "authenticity" Nazi)--but in my opinion you should warn people what you're doing rather than surprise them with it.

So, for example, if you order a paneer dosa, you'd expect to get a dosa with a bunch of paneer and maybe some spicy potatoes (or other traditional dosa fillings) to complement the paneer. You would not expect to get a dosa filled mostly with peas (alone, not in a sauce, and "fresh" tasting rather than well-cooked), which, in addition to having three times the volume of the actual paneer, overwhelm the taste of the paneer. This would be fine if this were described on the menu, but it wasn't--we actually asked the waiter if we had been served the correct dish, and were surprised to find that we had ("oh wait, maybe I taste a little paneer, behind all those peas").

The second complaint I have is the cost--South Indian cuisine is based on very cheap ingredients, including potatoes, sometimes chickpeas, sometimes a few peas (usually well-cooked and _always_ in moderation), spices you can buy very cheaply in bulk in an Indian grocery store, etc. How they can justify charging $11 for a bunch of spiced potatoes in a crepe is beyond me. The food doesn't seem to be sufficiently refined to justify that kind of cost. Maybe it's also because the quality is generally only a small step above the run-of-the-mill dosas I've eaten in South India, where you can get one of them for something between $0.25-$1. Again--cheap ingredients.


Three stars because, except for the surprises, the food was decent and occasionally quite flavorful. I may eventually go back simply because there aren't many South Indian options around.
author: Jared B.

description:
Would NOT go back.  The food is not worth the other drawbacks even after several drinks!

Service was very poor.  We waited over an hour for a table when we were promised one in 25 minutes.

Seating was very over crowded, we were four people put at a table meant for 2 people.  We were bumped and pushed throughout our entire dinner.  The table wasn't big enough to hold our dishes.  

The cocktails were great and the food was good but not outstanding.
author: Keith P.

description: The wait was over an hour on a Saturday night, which is typical for a popular place, so I had high expectations.  I ordered the dosa and some masala sauce.  It was way too spiced up.  I couldn't drink water fast enough.  It's kind of expensive, but I'm paying for the decor also. The service is fast and attentive; the waitress was very helpful with explaining the menu.  I liked the apps: beet soup, chicken chanii and the dumplings better the entrees.  Way too expensive for indian food.  I like Rotee better. The chai at Rotee is better, plus it's free.
author: H G.

description: This was my first time trying South Indian food so I didn't really know what to expect.  But WOW, the food is delicious.  I had the Chutney Masala Dosa and truly enjoyed it!  The crepe was yummy and tasted very similar to a French crepe, but crunchier.   It's a nice combination with the flavors of the masala blend of potatoes, cashews and eggplant.  Sooo good and didn't feel too heavy after gobbling up the entire Dosa!
author: AB T.

description:
Since there's no other South Indian in the city, this will have to do.  South Indian cuisine is wonderful, but at this price, I rarely go here.  

If you're on the peninsula much, go to Udupi Palace/Karaikudi/anywhere.   They're at least as good if not better, and half as expensive.   If you're stuck in the city, though, this place has some nice innovations and tasty food.  I'd trade it for a hole in the wall South Indian joint in a heartbeat, though.
author: Matt F.

description: Went to dinner there last night for the first time - loves all the dishes, especially the 5 moons- highly recommended. The wait wasn't too bad considering they don't take reservations for parties under 5.
author: courtney W.

description: Dosa has such poor service and an attitude.  If you ask any of the service people for something, they refuse you.  It think it is overrated, the food is not greasy for Indian food but overpriced and you have to deal with the bad attitude.
author: Chris K.

description: Really long wait for dinner, waitresses who forget to bring you water, uber spicy dishes, and expensive menu.  Not the ideal dinner out for someone who can't handle spice and who's on a budget.  Though I will say, their samosa dumplings are pretty good.
author: K N.

description: The chicken appetizer was pretty good but thought the restaurant is over rated.  I did not think it was anything extraordinary.
author: Mary L.

description: love this place. If you like indian food, great atmosphere, good service. you gotta come thru...
author: Henry V.

description:
One the places I can recommend for good Indian food. This is how Indian food should taste.

I have been there 2-3 times for dinner and food has been always a treat !!!...

Service is excellent too !!!
author: Sumit B.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in the city. The first time I went there I had their Sada paper dosa and as soon as I tasted their Sambar I had a flashback to my mom's kitchen in Kerala where I grew up. Their curries taste so good and home made. I have taken a lot of my friends and family to this place and each and every one of them just loved Dosa. They have an awesome variety of drinks that you should definitely try since they are different. I had their Lassi martini which blew my mind away. I am a big fan of Indian sweets and I always have their Rasmalai before I leave. I met the owner of this restaurant and he is very charming and friendly. If you come to San Francisco definitely try this restaurant,
author: Rejina S.

description:
My husband and I liked the food, but we felt that it is not good to think of it as an Indian food.... especially from an Indian person's perspective.  Well, food is great.  Nice, but pricy.  You are paying for the decor and nice service.
You can get better Dosa down south (not inside SF, but Sunnyvale, San Jose etc) with fraction of cost.  Of course, you won't get fancy plates, fancy service.... but for some paying for such things are.... sometimes not worth.
I would call this fusion.
author: Miinno N.

description: Great Restaurant but SOUTHERN Indian is like a different country to the more popular North Indian Cuisine. Dont expact Nan or Bhuna or lime pickle or any kind of Balti dishes. Interesting but not the Indian Food you might be accustomed to which is a minus for me. Well run restaurant though.
author: Mark W.

description:
If I was in India - I would go to a place like this. The other Indian places I have eaten at in various cities in USA have been stuck in the 70s-80s ambience and the food has become very "Americanized".

Ambience - trendy though a wee bit loud - but great. If I was in India - I wouldn't go to most places that we have to go to here in USA. If it was a place like DOSA - HELL YEAH I would go. The wait was acceptable too even though we showed up without a reservation.

Price - very reasonable.... 

FOOD -- thats what everyone would be reading this --- GREAT !! FANTASTIC !!!  Everything actually tasted the way it would be if I was having it in India... 

I have been highly recommending Dosa to everyone I know who is going to San Francisco... 

Have fun
author: Rahul H.

description: Yet another Valencia Corridor place for trendoids. The kind of Indian food served here is pretty pedestrian, so why pay four times as much? I guess so you can say you went and were probably seen by other people just as cool if not cooler than you. Spend the time and the bridge toll to go to Vik's in Berkeley for some no-frills, down home chaat. Or if you need ambiance, Roti in West Portal.
author: Chili Bill E.

description: The food is good, but I've had food of equivalent quality for far less.  Dinner for two came out to $80 (no drinks).  For that price I expect something a little more mind-blowing.
author: Matthew K.

description: Visiting from LA with my husband and two kids. They were so nice. My husband and I had a lovely grown up meal and they were able to serve the kids yummy food as well. The chicken curry had an incredible sauce. The potatoes were incredible too. Our waitress gave us good info about the neighborhood so we could walk around and have fun after our meal. I would definitely go back.
author: Madeleine M.

description: The food was ok, the service was good, the cost was pricey, and the restroom was not completely clean.
author: Fair Rating D.

description:
We had a group of 6.  3 vegetarians, and 3 carnivores.

The dosas were good.  The Mysore Dosa's filling was nicely spiced and not just a bunch of mush.  The Paneer Dosa was also very tasty.

We also had the peppercorn chicken, the sauce was a little thick and clumpy, but very tasty and the chicken fell right off the bone.

They also had a specials of prawn cashew curry which was very tasty.

I agree with the other reviews that its a bit pricey for what you get, but the food is good as is the atmosphere and service.

Would return.
author: John D.

description:
Perhaps I was just that much a fan of the whole DOSA thing as i didn't actually like dosas a ton. Very strange how much bread they'd give in ratio. I didn't like the Dosa concept that much, but the rest of the restaurant was good. hahah

Pro's
- Some Unique options when you've been a billion indian places
- Tasty food
- good atmosphere
- Very good staff, professional and friendly. I sat a the bar and ate, cool bartender that night

Con's
- Seating can be tough, but common with any good place in the mission
- Probably a little too expensive for the quality.
- Terrible beer selection. I think even Indian food needs good beer selection! or some on draft, there wasn't when i went about 5 months ago or so. Sometimes I don't go to a place if they don't have draft beer, it is that important to me.
author: Brian E.

description: While I can't comment on the authenticity of Dosa, for this gringo, the food was fantastic.  Out waitress was super helpful when picking out a sampling of deliciousness for my party. Went without reservations at prime time on a Saturday night and had a 30 minute wait (after being rejected by Cha Cha Cha). Started with this really interesting lentil dumpling dish with yogurt and mint and ended up splitting the Chatni Masala and lamb curry which were both excellent. Finish off with the chai tea to settle everything down.
author: Graham A.

description:
yummy food.  not as much bang for the buck as you'll get in south bay divey dosa places, but you're paying for location and atmosphere.  went kinda late on a monday night and the two of us were sat immediately.  that was pretty cool considering how hyped it is.  maybe things are dying down.

we were maybe too casually dressed and look young so they seemed to think we'd never had dosas or indian food before and so the staff was a little heavy on the instructions.

all in all, would try again.
author: Katherine R.

description: If you have any issues with sinus blockage, come here!!!  Your nose will be cleared out within seconds.  Came here for brunch and had the delicious fish curry special with basmati rice.  Oh my god, I love those chips, they're so addicting.  And by some miracle of god I was able to have dessert... some sweet milkballs in syrup, forget what they're called.  Definitely worth it to come for brunch than dinner I think.
author: Emily C.

description:
Got the Masala Dosa, Paneer & Peas Uttapam and the Prawn Coconut Masala. Topped it off with a cheesecake.

Had to unload a huge deuce after I got home.

Food was good though, worth the 30 minute wait.
author: Hode L.

description:
Very good food, unique Indian experience that sets it apart from the Naan N Curry's out there.  Gotta have a dosa.  Great food presentation and atmosphere.  The big downer is that it doesnt take reservations for a party less than 5.  You have to wait outside and there's this bum outside that giggles and paces back and forth which can lead to a very uncomfortable pre-dinner experience.  The first time I attempted to go, a Saturday night, the hostess told me it would be about a 20 minute wait.  After an hour of watching the bum like a ping pong tournament, we got so hungry that we ended up going to the Pakistani restaurant half a block up who's name escapes me.  The second attempt on a Friday was more successful.  The bum paced for about 25 minutes before we got seated.  The Dahi Vada was beautiful and a unique dish - lentil dumplings topped with swirls of yogurt and sauces.  Lamb curry was very flavorful and different.  

The only thing that would prevent me from going there is that I don't want to have to wait an indefinite amount of time for my meal.  So maybe I'll save this for when I'm with a big group.
author: C. L.

description: If you have the money this spot is perfect for nursing a hangover on sundays.  It's the only good south Indian food I've had in the U.S.  The waiters are friendly and help you out if your not familiar with south Indian fare.  The drinks are really good too and perfect for the afternoon, but expect to break the bank.
author: Nate W.

description:
good for those who don't generally like indian places but go because your friends like it and you don't want to be a tool.  it wasn't the plan to come here; we actually didn't have a plan, just a small group of hungry people winging it for dinner.
