its little differences definitely sold me- the setting inside, the menu options, drinks, people... it's quite nice, and 5 stars for the cinnamon stick smelling bathrooms!  the waitresses are pretty helpful.  i liked my friend's food better than my own (somehow i got spicy when i aimed for the opposite), but it was interestingly fun- i got this big paper roll thing to eat.  yeah, we took a picture.
author: Monk R.

description: I have been twice now to my neighbor restaurant. Service is great, food very traditional and consistently good. The atmosphere is hip not stuffy. I love the Dosas, the Prawn Curry, and the lychee martini. Just do not drink the Indian Shiraz. It has a horrible after taste!
author: Lindsey S.

description: Great place. Just went there with a good friend of mine and her soon to be fiancee. The aroma that wafts out the door was so fragrant that my mouth was watering already.  I was a dosa virgin, but not a virgin to Indian food which I already love. Flavors were great, drinks were fun. Only thing that gave it 4 instead of 5 stars is that with sharing the meat items on the menu, there was not enough meat to go around for the 4 of us. I had to take a bit of chicken from my husband's plate to try. But-I did leave full and happy.
author: Wendy K.

description: Save yourselves the line and hassle, and go to Udupi Palace! It's right around the corner, and the food is much better. Dosa is overpriced and pretentious.
author: L T.

description: This place is a little pricey and busy for me, but the spicy food is some of the best flavorful South Indian food I've had.
author: Raina M.

description: In the middle of the metro-mission with good food and great cocktails. Heard they just reopened after a remodle. Can't wait see see what they've done with the place.
author: BARI P.

description:
This place saved me from having to eat dinner at some pinko-commy cafe with the worst "political 'artwork'" I have ever seen.  It is a debt I can never fully repay, and a positive yelp review is the least I can do.

Dosa is the only non-fusion Indian fine dining experience I have had, so I have nothing except sketchy take-out to compare it to, but I must say I absolutely love this place.  I've liked everything I've tried on their menu, and while I think it, like everything in San Francisco, is a bit overpriced, you can definitely satisfy yourself on a modest budget here.  I recommend the lamb curry, but make sure they don't treat you like a white person and take out all the wonderful spiciness.  I've always had good servers, and I love the almost nightclub-like atmosphere.  Drinks are good and in the usual $6-9 price range, and they have some fantastic wines to choose from.  Only downside is no reservations so the wait is typically long, even on weeknights, but it is right in the middle of many varied restaurants so if the wait is too long you can check out the other options: french, afghani, moroccan, mexican, american, etc.
author: Katrina R.

description: the food here is great! the tables are kinda crowded! love the puri, dosa, and curries! not too spicy, but great w/raita! didn't try the desserts, but this place gots pretty good indian food!!!
author: Rita L.

description: Dosa is my favorite Indian restaurant in SF.  I love their fiery fruit salad as an appetizer- it's sooo spicy.  I always get their spring masala dosa, and they also have a great wine list.  The only problem is that it is very crowded and their is always a long wait.  I recommend going for an early dinner because they don't take reservations.
author: Sky B.

description: My friend and I ordered dosas and mango lassis. They were both really delicious. They are a bit pricey but the dishes are tasty. I would say try it once, especially if you are only used to Indian found at lunch buffets.
author: j p.

description: I had my birthday dinner here with some friends and it was packed! Luckily somone in my party knew "someone" who worked there and even though our reservation was pushed back, he gave me and my friend complimentary lychee martini's!! How nice. The food was very good and plentiful. We did the tasting menu and were completely stuffed! My recommendation - don't wear too much cuz you will be taking it off cuz it's really hot inside!
author: Natalie S.

description:
First time in my life having South Indian FINE DINING.  Fabulous.  

FOOD:  Delectable.  But be selective!  True to the restaurant's name, Dosas are the specialty here.  The Masala Dosa was HUGE  and we had to play musical plates with the other dishes to get the damn thing to fit on the table.  And the flavor?  Nothing short of luscious.  Really.  Make sure you dip pieces of your dosa in coconut sauce (the hummus-looking thing on the side) - it's ORGASMIC.  My friend insisted on ordering the eggplant curry, which I initially resisted because I always thought I could make it better myself, but tonight I ate my words - and yes, lots of YUMMY eggplant curry that I could never duplicate at home.  Also had their Paneer and Peas Uttampam, which was delicious as well; tasted like a cheesy Jewish latke (potato pancakes) with peas.  My only complaint was that it was a little too small for the price ($13 and it was only about the size of the dinner plate - but then again EVERYTHING looked small compared to that dosa!)  Speaking of small for the price, I would avoid the appetizers.  Unfortunately the fact that our spinach and cauliflower fritters came in a painfully small, tea-saucer size portion was enough to bring my rating of this place to 4 stars only (would include another 1/2 star if Yelp let me)

SERVICE:  Superb.  Waiters are very friendly and knowledgable about the cuisine, and are helpful, NOT pushy, when making recommendations.  Water glasses were always filled in a timely manner, dishes were removed from the table almost once the food was finished from them. Dosa has a good team that's VERY on top of it here. Bravo!

AMBIENCE: Classy.  As I said, this is fine dining.  Lighting is sexily dimmed, but the modern lights hanging from the ceiling give it a very warm glow that reflects nicely off the orangy-earth toned walls.  There's a full bar if you want to catch a drink while waiting for your table or after your meal.  Admittedly a little crowded as the restaurant is small, but at least there are high ceilings so that it's not stuffy.  DEFINITELY a hot date spot.

PRICES: Well this ain't Naan n' Curry, so for the full experience, you should probably expect to spend about $25 - $30/person, including drinks and dessert, which is fairly reasonable for a classy restaurant.  If you're on the budget like me, however, you probably want to save this place for special occasions only. 

PARKING: I always recommend taking the bus in San Francisco.  However, if you have a date you need to impress with a full pick-up service and everything, you're in luck; there's a lot on 21st Street between Valencia and Mission, and there seems to usually be ample parking in there.
author: Catherine C.

description: 30-40 minute wait on a sunday night!  I couldn't believe how packed it was but it made me feel like I was in for something special and it really was.  My dining buddy was a cool cat too which made the night even better.  I love trying new things and I love variety and I definitely got my share of that.  We ordered 2 really tasty dishes that really filled us up and left us very satisfied.  The first dish was the Masala dosa which the menu convinced us we should try and it was right, it was really good and the chutneys(coconut and sambar) were delicious.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Great restaurant - staff, food, drinks, everything! It's always busy though, so make reservations if you can. If you go on the weekend or Monday nights, they have special starters. I highly recommend the Bhel Puri. Went with a group with discriminating taste buds, and everyone left complimenting me on the choice.
author: Hannah C.

description: If you like Indian food, Dosa is a must! I'm used to chowing down on my favorite Indian meal at hole-in-the-wall spots, but Dosa is no hole. It's nice without trying too hard. I would call it a good first date spot. They're only open for dinner, and they don't take reservations for parties smaller than five, so be prepared to wait. Savor some wine at the bar; the wine list was carefully chosen to accompany the cuisine. Service was friendly, and everyone was knowledgeable. If you eat lamb, don't miss the curry! And of course, share a dosa for the table.
author: jenn h.

description: The second dish we ordered was the South inidan moons uttapam. it came w/ a variety of flat cakish bread: Potato, peas(or green onion), tomato and cheese, spinach, and white onion. came w/ the same dips and soups. this was absolutley delightful. its true, the flavors are tantalizing to the tongue. i preferred this one to the dosa. much more flavorful and fun. i loved dipping it in the chutneys! espcially the coconut one. i didn't like the big and heavy candle holders....they just take up table room but my dining buddy was a diggity dog which made the experience crazy cool.
author: Janelle H.

description:
If you are looking for Chicken Tikka Masala and Naan, this is not the place for you!

Which was actually a surprise to me because I had never had South Indian food before. Pretty much everything on the menu I had never heard of before despite Indian being my favorite food.

I had the Tamil Lamb Curry which was amazing with a really unique spice. The Dosa was excellent as well.

The wine director was very knowledgeable and explained everything possible about our chosen selection.

The only negative (hence 4 stars instead of 5) was they told us it was going to be a 30-35 minute wait and it was an 60 minutes before they called us. Our table for TWO was ready...but I had clearly told her we needed a table for THREE. Which meant we had to wait 15 minutes longer. Not cool...but the food really was that good.
author: Mike T.

description: If you LOVE indian food, this isn't the place for you.  This place doesn't serve up the typical fare most dives carry around town.  In fact this hip spot makes some gourmet dishes to brag about, and the native beer ain't bad.  Like the name says, order up a dose of dosas and you'll be good to go.
author: Lane K.

description: My family and I were pleasantly surprised after coming here. We are used to being disappointed when we go to Indian restaurants, but we enjoyed the food so much. It wasn't overly greasy, the dosas were good, and the sambar was fantastic (and every Indian knows how hard it is to get sambar right). It' s just too bad the table was too small for us four and it was crowded and loud, but it won't stop us from coming back.
author: S. P.

description:
i got a lovely e-mail from one of the owners in response to my original review, and i felt so bad for my rudeness that i thought i would amend my review to say that i just personally am not a sour-thing lover--i don't like sourdough, sushi rice, and i guess dosas--so with that in mind...  but we did have this yummy thing in the beginning (my friends ordered while i was in the bathroom, so i don't know what it was) that was these little air-filled crunchy pillows that you crack open at the top and put the mung beans/potato/(?) in with sauce...to eat.  that was a very messy sentence.  anyways, i just had to mention that the owners seem to put a lot of emphasis on personal attention to customers, so for that i might just go back.

- - - - - - - 

original review: 2 stars

it wasn't awful, and the hostess was actually pretty attentive, but i don't get it--why was there a 45-minute wait?  i wanted to conduct a survey of all the happy diners: Why do you love this place and why do you keep coming back?  oh, and dosas are sour   :[   in case you didn't already know.
author: Janice C.

description: Decent, but overrated, and lacking the robust flavors that are prominent in most authentic indian restaurants that I've been to.  Kudos for being a dosa/south indian restaurant, though.  I'm still heading to the south bay for my dosas!
author: Jolene T.

description:
I was out in the misson to meet up with my buddy and we decided to be adventurous and try something new. Udupi Palace it was! The wait was long and it was hotter than a whorehouse in hell! No way were we going to subject ourselves to eating hot Indian food in 90 degree heat, so we wandered over to Dosa which we had also heard a lot about. The ambiance was much better and it was about 15 degrees cooler in there! 
The service was phenomenal! Our waitress was very informative and offered up some great suggestions. We opted to try the curry lamb kofta and the paneer and peas dosa. The lamb was really tasty albeit for only 5 tiny meatballs! The spices and quality of meat was definitely noted, but I had wished there were more red onion action. Don't get me wrong, the dish was filling and delightfully spicy, but not big enough to share! 
I gulped down at least 4 glasses of water, so I can attest to the service. My glass was constantly refilled without me having to wave someone over, which was much appreciated since my mouth was pretty much on fire! As for the dosa...maybe its just me, but I didn't think it was particularly spectacular....at least not to the point of being this places namesake. The crepe didn't have much flavor and the peas still had quite a bit of bite to them as if they were slightly undercooked. The sambar however was very hearty and contained big chunks of veggies which were tasty. 
All in all this place wasn't a bust, but I doubt I'll be heading there again soon. At $60 bucks for two people, there are plenty of other Indian places to try.
author: Stacy T.

description: Ordered Masala Dosa. Enjoyed my meal, ambience, and service. The sambar (small soupy thing they give you with dosa) used to be more spicy, but I think they made it mild for the clientelle. I don't like it when restaurants dumb down food for the masses -- I prefer spicy and was a little disappointed.
author: Sun K.

description: I really like Indian food, I really really enjoyed Dosa. I was delighted  to find many Indian wines on the list and received a great reccomendation from Vanessa.
author: Helen J.

description: Southern Indian food at Dosa's is amazing. The decor of the restaurant matches the food: Spicy! The blood-orange walls and warm candle light compliment the hot Masala and lamb curry. Ask for a side of yogurt, it just tastes so good with the Basmati rice.
author: Rana A.

description: Delish!   I loved everything I had. We got pancake like things that you dip in sauses.  They had different toppings on them- really good starter.   We had a potato dosa which was really yummy.  We also got a chicken curry that was very good.   So all and all the dinner satified my craving for spicy and tasty food. the mango lassi was really creamy...really thick.
author: Julia H.

description: I'll jump on the Dosa bandwagon. Lots of praise for my first Southern Indian meal. The service was friendly, the food had a nice amount of spice and was very flavorful. Our server was surprised at the massive amount of food we ate so we got to try a lot of stuff and it was all delicious. I'm sure I'll be back to try some more flavorful doughy goodness.
author: Keith R.

description: Tasty treats in a much cooler atmosphere than most local Indian joints.  But why oh why won't they take reservations?  Stick to their namesakes, the dosas.  My husband had the lamb curry which was tasty, but not as good as my DOSA!
author: Alison C.

description:
i think this place is fabulous, although i have friends who think it is less than authentic south indian food.  i have been to southern india too, but i don't care - this place is tasty, spicy and fun!!! the dosas are delish, and the breads are excellent.

check it out.  the lines are long, so go early or before you are hungry
author: Erika Y.

description: Loved the food here...went with a large group and we decided the price-fixed option didn't make any sense - better to order exactly what we wanted and pass everything around the table.  I have to say that the actual "dosas" were my least favorite part.  The curries, on the other hand, were amazing.  So was the white wine/mint cocktail (don't remember what it was called.)
author: Nancy H.

description:
nice, mellow, hip ambiance.  definitely need a reservation!!!
fun place to go with a group of 4 or more so you can order a variety of things & share the experience.

our server was very knowledgeable with the menu & gave us good suggestions:  with starters, paper masala, uttapam &  curry.    don't remember this particular appetizer we had but it was beautiful, looked like a dessert.  had the mango lassi alcoholic drink -- too thick as an alcoholic drink & lychee drink (nice & refreshing, but not special).  

my favorite is their chemnai chicken -- lightly fried boneless chicken cubes w/ yogurt, cilantro, coriander, cumin.............

would love to go back with my girlfriends........
author: Cindi N.

description: The reason I have not reviewed this sooner is simple, 432 reviews so far here at Yelp... I could not get in. But the food is great, the service was a bit spotty, our food took forever to come out, but it was well worth the wait. So now that this is not the "hot new" place and you can get a table on a Thursday night, I will definitely come back.
author: Seamus M.

description: I like Indian food, but I'm the kinda person who can only eat it about once per year.  Well, I'm glad my choice for this year was Dosa.  I decided to go with the three course meal with wine pairings (great deal!) to try a bit of everything.  It was all delicious, lots of fresh vegetables and interesting flavors.  The service was really great too, very attentive and informative!
author: Michelle L.

description: The appetizers were different and good, while the dosa was decent, but nothing too spectacular. Service was great though as he helped us choose several dishes that I probably wouldn't have tried otherwise...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Very cozy but spacious location (how's that for an oxymoron?).  

The waitress did a good job recommending several dishes, all of which we tried.  The mung bean sprout salad was actually surprisingly tasty, and possibly one of the most memorable items I tried (the sprouts are opened in the restaurant).
author: Catherine Y.

description: Probably the only place in the bay area where you can get a cocktail with your dosa! The ambience - excellent, service - cheerful and the food  - unauthentic, not the makings of your typical South Indian restaurant. Nevertheless, a good introduction for first-timers to the dosa cuisine.
author: Maneesh S.

description: Really enjoyed our meal here with friends.  We sort of had a bit of everything off the menu it seemed, and really liked it all!  I lived in London for a year, and since then have been unable to eat Indian food anywhere else (ok so that's not true, but I do complain a lot while I eat it), but being that this is Southern Indian, I found it very unusual and tasty!
author: Jenn K.

description: The dosas are awesome. Masala, mung, the sauces and the soup that come with them are just intense. The chile shrimps are hot... Cool vibe, cool atmosphere, good music... Like Ahnold said, I'll be back.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Great Southern Indian food with lots of variety, especially of the vegetarian fare - that is pretty common with Indian food though.
author: Jerry S.

description: Having lived in Bangalore, India for a year I can tell you this is as close as you'll ever get to authentic.  The food is mind blowing, try the dahi vada for the love of god!  Not cheap though, we save it for special occasions.
author: rani s.

description:
after moving back from london, it has been difficult finding good standard indian fare in this city (in london indian is as common as mexican in sf- it is a good standard on every corner). AND although southern indian food is more of a novelty or rare find- DOSA ROCKS!!

we take out-of-towners here all the time, and they always write us dreaming of dosa on their next visit. we have had about everything on the menu- and the worthy mentions are the lamb curry and mung dosa. 

A+ Dosa!!

also, good for a date. a bit pricey and a bit sceney.
author: SF U.

description: I've tried a few of their menu items, and it's ok.  It's not my favorite spot but none of my other spots serve dosa's. I guess I'm not familiar with south indian food. But the flavors were kind of blended together with nothing really ringing out.  The service was fine and my beer was cold.  Maybe I'm only giving it three stars cause I had to wait an hour for just ok food.
author: Bruce B.

description: I'm south indian, and these guys may have my mom's masala dosa beat. I'm impressed. The idlis were just okay, but oh my god is their masala dosa amazing. It was a little absurd when the non-indian waitress corrected me and my (indian) friend's pronunciation of various dishes. Also, the mango lassi isn't so great. That stuff aside, it's the best indian food in town.
author: Anonymous F.

description: Very good but I'm not sure I'd trade in my so-called lower end dosas for the ones offered here.
author: OKAY O.

description: Just went here for the first time last night with a small group of friends. The food was pretty good, the wine was excellent, and was a great experience overall. I have not yet to compare it to the other place down the street, but I will give an updated review once I eat there and make the comparison. Overall, a decent dining experience.
author: Hans H.

description: Having spent a decent amount of time in S. India, I was pumped to find this jem of a restaurant in SF.  While perhaps not as authentic as the other S. Indian food around the bay, I appreciate the style and their dosas really are excellent.  Certainly more expensive than other food of its type in the area, but you pay for the nice atmosphere... which I'm willing to do every once in awhile.  Definitely somewhere I'll return, although less frequently than I'd like due to the cost.
author: trevor j.

description: great food, awesome hosts, groovy atmosphere, gorgeous interior... but temper that with loud crowds and lots of valencia corridor hipsters. Go early in the week or early in the evening. the dosa's really are super tastay (as was every menu item we tried), and the beer/wine selection is wonderful.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
i LOVE dosas, so was excited (though skeptical) about this restaurant.

finally tried it last night, and was pleased. the dosas and uttapams were delicious, but no more delish than when i've ordered them at indian restaurants (where the clientele isn't necessarily the mission hipster/white uninitiated). the drink menu was fun and tempting. the homemade chai was lovely and hit the spot. 

i know this isn't a fair comparison to make, but if i'm lusting strictly for the delectability of this particular palette of flavors and textures, i'd much rather just go to vik's. it's cheaper and feels more downhome.

still, i understand why dosa has a certain appeal - the ambiance is nice and new.
author: jennifer y.

description:
authentic, trendy, impossible to get in, cute, great, amazing, not authentic, unusal...all things i had heard about Dosa. i can't even believe, actually, that it took me a year and a half to come here. i read about it when it first opened (naturally, if you knew me you'd know that i'm up on these things) and have been meaning to come for hella long. finally, after some mixed reviews (see adjectives above, and 350+ reviews below!) i heard from a friend that her south indian husband's PARENTS (read: from southern india) ate here several times when they were visiting, and LOVED it. done. i am so there. 

went last sunday night, group of 6. waited awhile to be seated but i didn't mind: not too crowded at bar, good company, had lillet (rocks, orange)...actually, ok, if it had been any longer i would have started to mind, but what do you expect...want to see and be seen? deal with the crowds, loser. 

we ordered tons of food and it was all amazing. i love dosas. the curry was fantastic also, especially the pepper chicken and the shrimp. ended with chai tea. 

overall experience: great, can't wait to return.
author: rachel l.

description: DOSA is so good! They have a sampler style menu that makes trying a lot of dishes easy. Plus, if you haven't tried Southern Indian food, you have to go here!
author: Julie K.

description:
damn i forgot to review this while i still remembered what i wanted to remember. i'm told i liked it, but that i felt that the wait is totally unjustified.

thank you yelp for replacing my private text file of restaurant reviews [have i been there before? let me check my yelp...]
author: Clover Dan ..

description: I wanted to like this place more than I actually did.  I had heard really good things about it.  Good atmosphere, but wasn't super excited about the food.  It was good, but not great.
author: TR P.

description: A friend from out of town wanted to try a new indian place with a good wine selection. The dinner last nite was amazing. We got there a little before 6pm , so seating wasn't bad at all. Our server was really nice and helpful. I will definitely put this on the list of restaurants to return to.
author: Jenniflava R.

description: Excellent South Indian dishes.  Numerous tasty dishes for vegetarians! (I chose iddly/sambar, rava masala dosa, and madras coffee) While on the pricey side,  it was worth it.
author: Rupesh D.

description: Overall, much better than Aslam Rasoi down the street. The vada and idli were too dense to properly absorb the sauces (although the sauces were very delicious). The dosa was great. The lamb curry was also great. Waitstaff is also great.
author: Rob T.

description: Tries to do for Indian food what Slanted Door has done for Vietnamese food, and does a pretty good job.  But it's something about Indian food, probably the intense spices, that fails to integrate with other cuisine.  Thus, at Dosa, the vibe and presentation and the extensive wine and cocktail list gives you the hip Mission feel, but the food is nuthin' but Indian food, no matter how creative the presentation.  But you gotta give credit to places like this, that makes SF an diverse, exciting dining city.
author: Passdatanqueray M.

description:
I love Dosa because they are my favorite South Indian restaurant. The food is amazing and authentic presented with a chic and modern flair.  I am sad that they got rid of the Spinach and Cauliflower Vadas.  The Medu Vadas are good.  I looooooooooooove their Masala Dosa, sambar, and chutneys.  

I would have loved to give Dosa five stars for their food alone, however, they lose a star for two reasons.  First, they would be better off having no reservation system at all.  It is one thing that they refuse to give reservations for less than a party of 5.  Okay.  It is another thing when they refused to give me a reservation a week earlier for a party of 8 for my birthday when they had no existing reservations for that day.  The hostess said that we had to come in person to give our name and party number on that day.  So, on my birthday, my hubby got home earlier than usual to put his name on the list and then came to pick us up. When we got to the restaurant we still had more time to wait.  What bothered me was that they were sitting a party of 8 from a reservation that did not exist when I tried unsuccessfully to make a reservation.  Also, I think the restaurant setup is really nice but they could maybe update the bathroom to match the high-scale setting of the place.
author: C L.

description: Pretty flipping good but will have to do an update once we take our Indian friends there to see how truly authentic it is!
author: Nichole H.

description:
went with a party of seven and was stoked that we were actually seated within ten minutes of our reservation (especially after reading all the posts about problems w/ reservations). 

everything we ordered was very good (and very spicy). pretty good wine selection for an indian restaurant. service was good & fast. all in all it was a nice experience. 

the only downside:  the tables in the middle of the dining room are waaaaaay to close to each other.
author: jon w.

description: Not bad.  If your a vegetarian, I bet you will love it.  It was an interesting experience as we had never had a Dosa before and was very different, but I don't think we will be going back.
author: Pele N.

description: Not much to say except for this is the first time I tried a dosa and I love it! I got the Chatni Masala. My friends who had some meat dishes said they loved theirs as well. Not sure if they take reservations but if they do, i definitely recommend you getting one. We waited 1.5 hours to get seated. But you know what, there are bars near Dosa so just go have a drink and check up on your table every so often. It'll be worth it. Service is great and atmosphere welcoming as well. Only thing though, the restaurant is small and jam packed so it may not be great for large parties. The next time I visit SF, this will be a for sure stop.
author: Trendy W.

description: This was my first time trying Southern Indian food; the most popular entree is a dosa, a thin crepe-like dish with spicy potatoes and other veggies inside. Amazingly popular place, super chic with main courses in the $9-$15 price range. Don't come super hungry - this is one of those quality-not-quantity places.
author: Debby C.

description: Wow, almost 700 reviews.  Well, let me just add to the raves.  Went for Saturday lunch and had the chicken coconut lime cilantro curry special plus the non-traditional cheese dosa, which was like a crepe and a quesadilla all in one.  Mmmm, cheesy goodness.  Had the rice puff starter where you put potato, lentil and sauce in there and it was definitely a well rounded impressive meal.  Would certainly return.  Also must say that our waitress was fantastic.
author: George K.

description: Really good food.  very creative and inventive indian. It was a bit greasy for my taste thought and it took forever for a table.  I also feel like there was so much good stuff on the menu i couldnt try it all and was totally overwhelmed.
author: S M.

description: The food is delectable.   Perfectly made uttapams and dosas.  I enjoyed the onion pakora, and drinks were excellent.   I had the chai russian.   The only drag is the wait, but if you get a seat at the bar, the bartender (Carolyn) will take care of you.
author: Asit P.

description: The wait can be long.  But I think it's worth it.  The jumbo prawn masala was tasty.  The dosa was really like a huge crepe, but the chutney was what makes it taste great!  Also really like the lamb curry, I love the creamy sauce infused with spices.  You may be paying a bit more compare to the typical Curry N' Naan but the food is wonderful.  Try it!
author: Candy C.

description: Dosas, who knew they could be this good!  If there's a line out the door, you know its good.  You can literally smell the spices down the block!  They don't take reservations for smaller groups, but the wait is worthwhile.  I'd recommend going with a group to share different dishes, the dosa can actually be pretty large and very filling.  Great noisy ambience and the smells drive you crazy.  Delicious and well priced!
author: SF Diner A.

description: I've never had south Indian food so this was a first and boy, was it a great experience!!!!! We had something called Dosa which was wonderful. You dip it in a variety of sauces. Then we had something that looked like pancakes. We tried the vegetarian curry dish which was wonderful and the lamb meatball. I am not a fan of lamb but everyone else loved it. It's my new favorite restaurant.
author: Jay S.

description:
Wanted to go to Vik's earlier in the day, but didn't have the time, or knowledge of public transport to get there.   

Turns out this wasn't so bad, because we had a lovely time at Dosa (late summer 2008).

Dahi Vada, Paper Masala Dosa, and Paneer and Peas Uttapam.   All were good, and the presentation on the DV was notable.  The sambar was kinda boring, if I wanted to complain, and the coconut sorbet was way too sweet for my taste, but not bad.

Regarding some common criticisms:

First of all, you can count your alternatives for S. Indian on one hand.  Yes, one of the those is a hop away, but none of them fill the niche that this does.   You could go here without worrying that your date would be overdressed, and as someone who is perfectly happy eating off a thali and even appreciates something Bollywood playing up on the wall, and generally prefers typical "ethnic" joints for being relatively casual (and cheap) as well as relatively tasty, I very much enjoyed a more upscale, polished environment for a change.  Going here felt like a special occasion, but it was still comfortable.

Second, the food is actually pretty good.   That it is more expensive to eat here than the alternatives is no surprise.  You are paying for more than food.   And really, it isn't expensive when you consider that.  And it isn't like you are eating something from Chat Cafe, prettied up, either.  The food just wasn't mind blowing or anything.  Maybe if I'd made it to Vik's or Udupi, I'd be less forgiving, but it isn't like I haven't had better elsewhere.  It just is the case that sometimes more than the food matters, and the food was good enough.
author: A. W.

description: The food and service was absolutely fantastic!  Dosas are crisp and tasty.  Good wine/drink selection.  A bit pricey for my budget these days but worth every penny.  Only downside are the long lineups....just make sure to get there early.
author: natalie g.

description: excellent flavors with intoxicating aromas! The staff seems consistently good-spirited. I enjoy when my local restaurants keep a personal warmth in service.
author: James-Jimm P.

description: The service is friendly, not quite swift. The food ingredients are high quality and flavor is above average. The masala dosa and sambar were fairly authentic, with a tone-down for Western tastes. Papadums a little oily, as mentioned in other reviews. I think this is a very reasonable approach to running a South Indian restuarant in the Mission. I will return and recommend to friends.
author: Frank B.

description: In addition to being a delicious meal, DOSA turned out to be something of a mini-experience in a new culture, which was both unexpected and delightful. The wait staff does a great job of addressing that casual diners might not know about the differences between cuisines in north and south India [this could certainly have been annoying or overbearing, but was instead unforced and pleasant]. As a result, I ordered just what I wanted and had a great meal in a new restaurant eating new food without having to guess anything or ask lots of questions.
author: Jon W.

description: I loved this place because it has every imaginable kind of dosa I can name but it still gets three points because we had to wait for 20 min at the bar after showing up on time for a reserved table and its dosa's are not as crispy as Dasprakash in sunnyvale. I would still go there again.
author: Meghna S.

description: My guy brought me here for my birthday recently.  We found that sitting at the bar meant no waiting and the best light and view.
author: Mark S.

description:
I love Indian food, and when it's prepared well and with quality ingredients, there's nothing else quite like it.  So I've been thrilled the three times that I've visited Dosa - well, about the food, anyway.

The service at Dosa was very sorely lacking.  During our meal this evening, servers and hosts alike were pushy and apparently unconcerned about being obvious about their need for us to eat quickly and get the hell out, despite the fact that we were (trying to) enjoy their tasting menu, ordered two bottles of wine, and weren't being particularly slow about our food & wine consumption.  They were sloppy - placing dishes, glasses, and finally, the check on the table with apparent disregard for where they landed.  Finally, they were rude - telling us to go find our coats ourselves ("They're over there on the hooks on the wall somewhere") after we had paid the bill.  This is not an acceptable response from any server at any restaurant, especially given that it was the host had insisted we not hang our coats on the backs of chairs and had taken them away when we were seated.  

The server's response was unacceptable under any circumstances, but after paying a nearly $300 bill and - because we're apparently a bunch of suckers - tacking on 20% despite the frustration inducing experience, it carried extra sting.  (Note to self: Tell my bleeding heart to stfu the next time it tries to convince me that it's reasonable to tip 20% for bad service.)

Dosa does offer a really rather delicious, distinctive menu.  Despite my increasing frustration with the subpar server, busser and hosts, I enjoyed the potato patties, dosa, and exceptionally tender lamb curry.  The galub jamun was about as good as it could be - which is to say - fine.  On the whole, the food was quite wonderful, with the perfect balance of flavors and textures. 

If you aren't put off by the overbearing din of the restaurant, the extraordinarily long wait for a table, and the amateur and - at times - 
appallingly disrespectful service, then it really is worth sucking it up a little in order to enjoy a meal here.  In fact, I think I would recommend that everyone try it at least once.  Just know what to expect.  And after you leave -- well-fed, basking in the memories of your delicious meal but fuming about the crappy service -- just remember that you don't have to go back.  

I'm pretty sure I won't.
author: Nzinga K.

description:
I understand why Dosa is so well reviewed here. It is probably the only South Indian place in the city. It is one of the few in the Bay Area that serves booze. Probably the only one that serves cocktails of this calibre.  

The positives are very good service and decor. The negatives are the food and execution of the dishes. The quality of ingredients is high. Some of the appetizers like the Chennai Chicken were well done. However the rest of the meal was very mediocre for the price point and the quality of ingredients. The Tamil Lamb curry was extremely  over spiced with the wrong spices. My wife is Tamil and I am very familiar with the cuisine of south india. The Tamil Lamb Curry evoked no memories of Tamil cuisine in the spicing. The chutney served with the Dosa dish was decent but the sambar that  came with the south indian moons tasted nothing like sambar should. 

Dosa is a great concept and for the masses  unfamiliar with South Indian cuisine it is a good introduction and  adds to the variety of cuisine in the City. 

However,  the food here is neither creative enough nor authentic enough for the prices charged.  I would expect a highly skilled chef creating great dishes given the quality ingredients and the price point and service level. What your get at Dosa can be had in many of the other south indian places in the Bay Area for far less albeit with no booze or decor.   Some how I can't help imagine that people of SF could do a lot better if Dosa's chef would tighten the execution of the dishes.

Updated to reflect the dessert: 
The Rasmalai here is excellent. The quality of the milk used shows.
author: Arun R.

description: The dosa was really yummy.  But, 2 couples each ordered a curry dish and they were both so spicy that none of us could eat any of it (including the men).  I hate food that's so spicy it has no flavor.  Maybe you can request  easy spice, I don't know.  So, 4 stars for the dosa, 0 stars for the curry, I'll give you three.
author: a e.

description: I only have been here once, my boyfriend friend took us there to eat. Little portions. The menu is huge, didn't know how to really order but we order chicken curry, I forget what kind but not enough meat for 4 people. None of the items were big portions. We order some other stuff but I can not remember but I do remember it wasn't;t enough. The taste was good. Nice and Spicy. I read that this is the best Indian restaurant... I am not sure about that one.  I would want to go back and try other stuff since they are considered the best Indian.
author: Ge I.

description: So yes, I keep reviewing Asian food, specifically Indian, because you know what???  That's where my expertise is.  ANYWAY.  DOSA, hands down, best authentic South Indian, specifically KERALA style food I've eaten out.  They have a variety of curries (Cochin Calamari is wonderful too bad only an app because I could eat 4 plates of it), breads, and foods that are unique to South India.  There are a lot of restaurants that claim to be so, but the only thing they will serve is dosa.  DOSA does serve dosa, but a lot of other authentic food.  Every time I'm in San Francisco, I make a stop there, and I like to try something different every time.  I wish there was one in DC.
author: Sarah G.

description: Great food...good service...fun atmosphere.  We happened upon it for lunch and were pleasantly surprised.  I would definitely eat here again.
author: stephen c.

description:
The food here was absolutely delicious. I have met the chef before and he was lovely.

The experience in the restaurant was not what I hoped. In spite of the fact that the restaurant was completely empty,  the host informed us that he would not seat the first four guests until all six of us were there. His delivery was less than friendly. We ordered a bottle of wine and were seated shortly thereafter. The waitress was a bit condescending in explaining the food options to us. One of us has several allergies and she seemed annoyed to have to answer all the questions. She never refilled our wine glasses. All the  food came out at once and we had eaten both the appetizers and main course in less than 30 minutes. We had empty wine glasses and were ready to go. Dinner for 6 in less than an hour? Weird.  Again, the food was delicious and I would go back one more time just for that.... but the snotty service and bad timing definitely marred the experience.
author: Sarah M.

description: The food is really great and the sambar and dosas are very authentic. They do try to do a few unorthodox items like cheese dosa, which tastes quite odd. I suggest trying the dishes that are more traditional on the menu like the masala dosa and sambar vada. It is a pain that they don't take reservations for any groups under 5 people.
author: Anand S.

description: great flavors on the masala dosa. i ordered the one with habanero chutney though and that didn't mix so well.
author: Debbie Chiou S.

description: I came here for dinner after work.  I had the fried chicken appetizer which was very light, tender and flavorful.  The firewater lentil soup was tasty but at $4 was kind of pricey for such a thin soup, I think they should give more or charge less for that item, people would like that better.  I had the pepper chicken which was a little salty , but then I like salty.  Instead of rice I got the plain dosa which was a big rolled up crispy crepe like sheet.  It was great for dipping into the curry.  Overall a very enjoyable meal.
author: John T.

description:
Mysore Masal dosa was good, place was a little too crowded (then again, it is the only good South Indian establishment in the city)...definitely call ahead or you will have a 45 minute wait.

Bar has some good cocktails (try the lychee) and has a decent selection of Indian Beers.
author: Aditya P.

description: This is a first! A bar inside a South Indian restaurant is a nice change from the conventional places. The decor is welcoming and if the long lines are any indication, they haven't compromised on the taste either. The presentation was nicely done with the fresh dosas folded just right and the chutneys were very very good - a must try when in SF.
author: Sujata S.

description:
You won't go wrong with hip tunes and a glass of good Rioja while waiting for a classic paper dosa. And do not forget to try the calamari appetizer. 
You will find Anjan walking around to keep an eye and a friendly smile on his face. Creative, trendy, great food and nice people what else do you need ?

Just one word of caution, perhaps my personal choice. Indian food just does not go well with good wine, so make sure you finish your wine before start eating food. I do not think too much about Indian food abroad but I can't wait to be here again soon!
author: Kingshuk g.

description:
Food is good but portions are a lot smaller than what you would find at other south indian restaurants.  It is also somewhat overpriced for the quantity.  I will say that the food is tasty though, so if you are looking for a good meal then you can't go wrong with Dosa.

Pros: Good food, trendy atmosphere, Friendly staff
Cons: Overpriced, crowded, long wait, loud

We were quoted 35 minutes and ended up waiting 1 hour.  It seemed a little chaotic inside because there were people everywhere.  It was also very loud, but I guess that is to be expected from a trendy place like this one.  Unfortunately, the place was so crowded it was almost uncomfortable.  There were a lot of people waiting outside because the restaurant is so small that there is no waiting area inside.  Pretty much every inch of space is occupied by a table.  During dinner, we shared a table with another group.  You're literally eating with other people, but it's so loud, they can't really hear what you're saying anyway even though they are sitting right next to you.  

On the upside, I really liked the decor of the place.  If you're looking for a trendy hot spot that serves good food, this is the place to go.  Just go after 9:00 PM so you won't be waiting an hour for a table.  The staff was also very friendly.  The owner apologized for the long wait and looked like he was very involved in helping the staff get things moving.  So in that respect, it's not like the staff is lazy.

I just wish the restaurant was bigger and that we were quoted the correct time for the wait.  If we had known it was going to be an hour, we would have eaten at the bar.  But since we were told it would be 35 minutes, we thought it really wasn't that long to wait.

We ordered:

Chennai Chicken
Idly Sambar
Masala Dosa
Uttapam
1 Beer & 1 glass Wine

Altogether, our bill came to about $75.

I probably won't go here again unless it is with a large group after 9:00PM.
author: Sheila S.

description:
the food was good. . not super great . but good. - i would have to disagree with the person up top who wrote that the service was excellent. . the waitress that waited on my girlfriend and i was super inattentive, to the point my girlfriend thought she was going out of her way to be rude to us. . . (oh yeah, when she greeted us originally she said "hello" and walked away . . . . . . huh!?) 
----ps. .luke warm tea. not hot enough to allow jasmine blossom to do just that . . . blossom. . ima say ima find another spot next time.
author: peter m.

description: I can't believe that Patricia Wells of the NY Times called this her favorite place in San Francisco.  She claims she has to eat here everytime she is in town.  It's OK, but definitely not anywhere close to any decent Indian restaurant in London.
author: Scooey O.

description:
come on. i don't get it.  i thought this was supposed to be south indian food.  i didn't know you can get away with jazzing up the interior and charge $14 for a crepe.  wait, but its valencia.   (chile and cilantro uttapam - the thicker kind) with some dips. good to eat, but was a little underwhelming on portion. and the sauces it comes with were good, except for the lentil soup thing.  the menu tells you you're supposed to dip each piece in the watered down sauce soup.  but what they don't tell you is that it makes each bite taste really bad, because it makes it soggy and cuts, actually takes away, what little flavor was happened with the chile and cilantro...

And is south indian food (chicken and eggplant masala or some shit) supposed to taste like bland vegetable puree?  the people next to us got the jumbo prawn curry, which was our second choice, but it came in the same terra cotta colored bland vegetable puree soup.  i've never had indian food so bland, flavorless, and spiceless.  desserts were . good.  we got fried doughnuts swimming in hot simple syrup.  and mango indian ice cream that comes in small cubes, like laughing cow cheese cubes.  delicious.

good wines, well priced for glasses. 

but service, i don't like to make an issue out of service, because the taste and quality of the food's what really matters - and having people whose job is to mediate between me and it and try to create an experience for me, or serving, waiting on me, bringing me my food and drink and whisking away dirty dishes and the refuse ,  the whole institution just makes me uncomfortable.   but this guy was downright awkward.  blond, flaming, and creepy thin mustache.  wait.  i don't mind flaming.  in fact, i appreciate a good flamer who's proud, loving life, and seriously on top of their shit.  oh, i can appreciate that.  very much.  but this guy was of the other kind - hating on me for being female and not a cute gay boy on this sad and rainy night in the mission.  i'm sorry. but  screw off.  he tried to be friendly though, it needs to be said.  everything i said was followed with "right-on".  i mean really!?  everything is right on?  really?!? come on.

i would not go back.  need to find me a place with good indian food cause going there just made me seriously crave the real thing.
author: Nikki F.

description:
The atmosphere is nice.  The food is okay, but not great.  The wait is bad.  Also it is very loud inside and difficult to have a conversation outside a very small group.

Having to wait outside for 30 minutes makes me enjoy the experience so much less.  If I was not with other people, I would have just gone somewhere else.

You don't find much South Indian cuisine in SF.  But if you go to the South Bay, you can get equally good food at one third the price at several places.

Clearly the place is popular (hence the wait times).  I would not go back, but also would not tell others to avoid the place.  It may be a great place for someone else.

I go to restaurants primarily the food.  Someone who goes out more for the atmosphere and hipness factor may enjoy it more.
author: Deoskar M.

description:
I just took my 17 year old brothers and my mother there. We were seated immediately, service was some of the friendliest I've encountered around the city, and mango lassis fucking rule. I am a huge fan of dosas. We each got a different one. They were all delicious,  and with the sauces and chutney they were possibly even spectacular. Major points for decor. I love dives, but sometimes I want to feel a little less tl, if you know what i mean. Dosa really hit the mark with the colors and low-ish lighting. I took a star away because we were seated at a table directly behind the hostess stand, and the front door kept getting left open and it wasn't exactly a warm night.
This is one of my new favorite places to eat. I can't wait to go back.
author: Emily D.

description: I have had a lot of Indian food, but never a "Dosa".  The texture is like a Crepe but I think the ingredients are healthier for you.  Great for vegetarians.  The chips they give you are so delicious and the shrimp curry (MmMmmH!)  and chutney is probably the best I have ever had.  And the service is great to boot ... even when it gets really packed.  I was pretty hungry when I got here, so I will come back and review when I have a more objective review, but this place was pretty damn good.
author: Janny J.

description: I find it odd eating south indian food with a napkin on my lap but i like how this place has turned out. The food is OK but the condiments are delicious. I feel the price is too much for the portion size though or maybe its just how it is in the city.
author: Aparna A.

description: After being on the road for a while, trying new things around the country and eating way too much Subway, Dosa was a great welcome home treat. The atmosphere and vibe always sets the tone for a date night or a good time out with friends. This was my third time coming here and the second with my girlfriend. We celebrated her move to San Francisco by getting a couple Dosas and sharing them.  There is no bad Dosa here. Some just hit the spot a bit better than others but there is something for every taste bud. I ordered the Spicy Mung Masala Dosa and was in heaven. Its a tighter dosa that makes it almost burrito'ish. Some Dosas are a little thinner than others and some a little crunchier. The chutneys are amazing (we even got a mint chutney for fun for only some chump change extra). If you end up with extra chutney, I recommend loading them all up into the left over Sambar (lentil soup) and topping your meal off with something spicy. In prior times, we have had the Spring Dosa, Cilantro Mint Masala, and the Rava Masala. Never a dull moment for your taste buds and if spice is your thing, you wont be dissapointed. Can't wait to go back.
author: Daniel P.

description:
The food is excellent, and the service and ambience very good. However, this is the experience we had when we went last. 

We asked the owner why they added an automatic 20% tip after we paid, just out of curiosity. He said that it was because Indians and Europeans don't know how to tip. To a table full of Indians, who had just spent a decent amount of money in his restaurant. 
Naturally, we were pretty shocked, upon which he said that he didn't mean to be offensive but that he was right because he grew up in India. For someone in the hospitality business, it was a seriously inept and inappropriate comment, not to mention pretty insulting to his Indian customers. Odd, when his restaurant's thing is to be authentically Indian, except for the Indians who don't know how to behave of course. 

Pity, because the food is truly phenomenal.
author: Niranjana B.

description:
great ambiance and good food, but a bit expensive.
if that's what you're looking for, dosa's right up your alley.

i personally prefer casual and affordable (while still flavorful and delicious), and i frequent pakwan over on 16th.
author: b g.

description:
I have been to this place a few times now., and never been disappointed. I always order one of the dosas, they do carry good north Indian food too but you can get that anywhere. This is the only place in the city that actually serves dosa, and good ones. There are a few south indian restaurants in south bay, but then..
anyway my favs are the mysore masala and chicken Chettinad.
I feel the service is pretty decent too.
Last I heard they were planning to open a new joint in fillmore, hopefully that would reduce the wait time.
author: sachin n.

description: South Indian food is SO good! In general, I have been okay with Indian food but never an all out fan until I ran across this place by accident. Highly recommended. I liked the experience of sitting at the bar and eating better than at the tables. Atmosphere is really good, service is friendly and knowledgeable, and the drinks are different and delicious. Must try.
author: Moto L.

description:
go here for good foods if you have little extra money to spend. 
 
however i don't like their trick of adding the "side order" cost to the main entree dish's cost!  the total cost should be more obviously stated to customers than how they currently imply it...
author: Truc N.

description: The atmosphere is great.  Clean, pretty, great music, wonderful service... but the food could be better.  I know of better places for Indian food and for cheaper too.  My friend and I actually have terrible stomach aches now.  ugghh...  too greasy.
author: F S.

description: Ehh...overrated. First let's get this straight- this is definitely Americanized/San Franciscanized South Indian food. Because of the (sad) lack of South Indian restaurants in SF (mostly only North Indian places here), people here seem to believe that they're eating authentic South Indian when dining at Dosa. There's nothing wrong with that- I don't believe Dosa claims to be authentic South Indian- but the food is overpriced and lacking in the usual South Indian flavor explosion. The portions are small and many of the dishes seem almost identical to each other. I'm still hoping for a good South Indian restaurant to open in SF.
author: Jonathan M.

description: I am reading the other reviews of this place and wondering if Dosa's marketing agency has flooded Yelp and CitySearch with fake favorable reviews.  If there is a restaurant God, and if that God is even moderately retributive, Dosa should be out of business in 6 months (although, Andalu is still around, so all hope may already be lost).  The first thing to notice about Dosa is that someone pumped alot of money into the space.  Then note it is crowded.  That rounds off the list of the only two remarkable things about Dosa.  It's a great place to eat if you don't care about food.  Otherwise, the food is sophmoric and just plain bad.  Try the chick pea appetizer if you doubt.  The masala dosa is self-billed as the "must try" entree, yet it is so bland it suggests the person who wrote this was trying to be ironic.  The onion pecora appetizer is, well, let's leave it at misguided.   And, I'm not sure why a restaurant that has a wine list selected by Michael Minna's sommelier has to pretend that it can only serve dark meat and bones in its chicken dishes.  But then again, I'm not trying to be an authentic South Indian restaurant in a dining room straight out of Limn furniture, so there are many things I do not understand.
author: Alice G.

description: don't believe the hype - yes, it's pretty, yes it's got the buzz but there are better indian food restaurants in the city. the drinks are incredibly weak, the spice levels are inconsistent from dish to dish, and for the most money ever you'll pay for indian cuisine, you'll leave not all that satisfied. in the area, check out radio habana, garcon, and firecracker, and with recent improvements, rasoi deserves another look.
author: Domenique B.

description: I have been a Yelper for almost two years and never felt it necessary to write a review... until I went to Dosa. Yes, it's that bad. The first time I tried to go, I was told there would be a half an hour wait.  I promptly walked out the door and ate somewhere else.  Indian food is not fancy, it's not hip, it's supposed to be fast and easy and good. It does not necessitate wine pairings. But given all the hype and good reviews and people lining up outside the door, I figured I should give it another chance.  So I went back for the second time, where we were again told there was a wait, to which we made faces of disgust, upon which they said "Oh wait, here's a table, we can seat you right now". So we sat down and I tried to be understanding of all the mission hipsters and non-Indians who were all dressed up and having the red AND white wine pairings with their meal.  I tried to set that all aside because I was sure the food would make up for it.  But when our food came, it was NOT SPECTACULAR by any stretch of the imagination.  And it was overpriced.  The whole place is totally ridiculous. If you're looking for good south Indian food, go to the south bay or the east bay.  Try Udupi palace in Berkeley.  It's cheap and tasty.
author: Julia S.

description: I don't get it.  Am I missing some special gene that makes a newish restaurant in a "hip" hood good?  Bad service ( begged for water, ordered things that never showed, strange servers that look at you as if you owe then further comments or instructions), loud (it wasn't even packed) and expensive.  After two times trying I have to say " don't believe the HYPE".  (lastly, a small thing but utterly anoying... tables that are too low for the chairs so that you can't relax and leave with a back ache. Calgon take me away)
author: Ann L.

description: In San Francisco you can rate the Indian food with a five star system and say the second best Indian restaurant in the city is a five.  Then you will have to give Dosa 7 stars because it is levels above the rest.  The food is amazing even after you take away the fancy decor.  This place took dosa, a south Indian breakfast dish and made it available all day!  The dosa is wonderful.  The curries here are a rich blend of spices and nuts, with very little oil and cream which piles its way into the curries at most of the bad Indian restaurants around the city.  The classic dosa is the masala dosa with a potato filling, and comes with sambar (a south Indian lentil dish) and sides of chutney.  I have been to South India and the food at Dosa is authentic.  They have added a lot of originality to their dishes as well, and in India this type of cooking would be considered very upscale.  Don't be fooled by the American wait staff, they put the Indians back in the kitchen to ensure the food is great.  I'll see you there in the long line outside.
author: Ryan S.

description: I have to admit I've never been here, BUT my frend told me she wrote a so-so review and got scathing emails from the owner of this place. the truly mixed bag of reviews shown here make me question whether it's worth putting aside a true revew from a personal friend to try out what alot of people are calling overpriced and not worthy of the hype. OH, and don't write me a nasty email, mr. owner...
author: joy o.

description: Fresh food, this is a allright place.
author: Noor K.

description: Well I guess I must be in the minority cause this place sucked. I chose this place for lunch for my birthday and was utterly disappointed. I was even more sorry that I dragged my family there. The food was wasn't good. We started off with some chips that they give everybody and don't ask me why but as soon as I took a bite I thought to myself...this must be what licking the sidewalk must taste like. I took a couple more bites hoping that it would get better but it didn't. We then ordered some dumplings, the uttapam moon cakes, the paneer dosa and the paper dosa and nothing tasted any good. Not even the chai was good. Everything was so bad that when the waitress was like...are you guys ready for dessert...my mom yelled no by accident as a reaction. During the meal I joked with my mother and told her that I was going to buy her a gift certificate to Dosa for Christmas and her response was I would die. I honestly really like Indian food and so does the other 3 people that I went with but this place was just terrible. I seriously will never step foot in this place again even if my life depended on it. What a way to start off my birthday... :(
author: Diane M.

description: i've lived in london and i have to say that dosa does not hold a candle to even the most out of the way hole in the wall indian joint over there. dosa is all flash and no bang. i thought the price was way too high and the food was just okay. i guess when i buy something expensive i expect something with expensive taste (so to speak) and dosa just doesn't deliver on that front. if you don't care about $ or someone else is paying and you don't care about their $ then tuck right in and have some indian at dosa. i don't have the casual budget to waste on this place. i'm looking for something to remember - anyone know of a place in SF that delivers the south asian goods.
author: Sara J.

description: "Let's go purge and do it all over again!!!" was PartyBot's suggestion at the end of our absurdly delicious meal at Dosa. I was ready to strip naked and offer myself up to whoever they have cooking that crazy crazy indian grub. The food was so new and exciting, the spices so rich and layered, the delicate dosas so light and smooth. When Autumn neglects a glass of champagne through an entire meal, it's a pretty good indication that the food is out of this world. We arrived at 5:20 and were turned away til 5:30. Went next door. Came back at 5:31 and there were only about 4 tables LEFT in the cozy, gently-lit dining room. PartyBot and I always have leftovers but as soon as that food started coming, it was every man for himself. I had that Spring Dosa divided and conquered so fast, Party didn't even see me sneaking a little extra for myself. The onion pakora and it's divine dipping sauce was more or less inhaled and I tell you, if I could get that in a drip feed, I wouldn't hesitate. The highlight of the meal was the Niman Ranch lamb curry, worth every last penny ($16). The sauce was like a mole with asian flourishes. Oh I ate it every way but dirty: On rice (delicious!), on rice scooped up with the crispity-crunchety pappadam that they give you loads of, by itself, on my dosa, and yes, with my fingers. I licked every last drop off of my plate and would have finished off the whole thing had I not begun to sport an early-pregnancy belly from overindulging. I am already planning my next meal there and I am so happy to have found a new place to further my weight-gain efforts...
author: Autumn K.

description:
Finally, a South Indian place in the city so that those of actually *from* South India don't have to drive BACK to south india (aka Fremont) in order to get some traditional home food.  While there were some glaring exceptions (no yogurt rice! no pickle! no idli!) from the menu, the food overall was good.  The rasam (which they served as soup) was so spicy that some tamilian friends of mine at the next table over called it "Too Authentic."  I personally found the sambar (with either the capcicum or the okra) to be a better choice either as a starter or as a dipping sauce.  The dosas were better than the uttapam (which I think is still attempting to fit into the western style eating mode, instead of the indian style "Tiffin" mode.  Just as an aside, I love that all these sort of super-casual home foods are getting such american love because of their novelty.  It would be like an american restaurant opening serving like hot dogs and rice krispies - the stuff your mom makes for snacks :).   
But I digress.  The food came out prompty, and was served hot - and while the uttapam wasn't spicy, the masala dosa was.  The desserts were excellent and hopefully the other items on the menu will not disappoint.  A recommendation (especially to the carnivores): south indian food is vegetarian, as a general rule we are orthodox and veg.  so unless you are really unable to do without the meat stuff, try giving up the flesh for a night, you won't be disappointed.

My two complaints:  I ordered Dahi Vada, and since i've never actually heard a white person say this, i didn't know how to "White-ify" the pronounciation... and the waitress didn't understand me!  I had to point!  Second, someone else's order came to the table.  Now, my dinner companion and I know the difference between a dosa and an uttapam, but an unsuspecting first timer would not be able to protest such a mistake and would be forever misled.  

I think these might just be the kinks getting worked out though - the owner and his wife are gracious, excited and INCREDIBLY dedicated to making their cute space work.  I think I'll be a regular... now if only someone could find me easy parking in the mission...
author: Anjali K.

description: Excellent salads! The fiery fruit completely took my breath away with its deliciousness. I also had the mung bean salad, which was really flavorful and interesting. My friend and I shared an eggplant dosa, and the texture and flavors were wonderful, and the three sauces made sure you didn't suffer from any kind of palate fatigue.
author: Sarah Y.

description: I'll be honest- I am not really a fan of Indian food. However, on a Friday night around 10:30, Sonia and I were in dire need of food and drink, so without straying too far from my apartment, we found ourselves sitting at the bar at Dosa, happily ordering whatever was left in the kitchen before it closed for the night. This upscale and trendy Valencia street restaurant is beautifully decorated with lights and mirrors. We were attended to by the bartender, who immediately took our order (the dosa appetizer and heirloom tomato salad with crispy noodles and coconut milk). I was taken aback at the care that went into crafting the dishes when they arrived. Each plate looked like a piece of artwork, almost too pretty to eat (although I somehow managed to lick my plate clean). The appetizer consisted of two thin pancakes (dosas) filled with a mixture of vegetables and paneer cheese. To finish off the plate were a smattering of different sauces, neatly dotted on the plate almost like an artists palate.  This stuffed creation tasted quite good, I was pleasantly surprised- the flavors were not as overpowering as I find in some Indian dishes. The heirloom tomato salad was also delicious- I particularly enjoyed the crunchy noodles and coconut sauce at the bottom. Both of these dishes were completely different than any other Indian food I've ever tasted (more refined perhaps) and I would definitely go back to sample some of their main course meals (late at night though, as I've seen this place packed around dinner time).
author: Kate A.

description: looking for somewhere tasty in the mish mish, we stumbled upon this awesome southern indian place. it was packed, but we put our names in and got some drink nearby while we waited. we were all pleasantly surprised. we ordered four things off the menu, and other than the free range lamb, i couldn't really identify what the other dishes were other than damn tasty!
author: Alex L.

description: What did I miss here? I honestly can't figure out what all the buzz is about. First, I have traveled to India, and adore Indian food. This seems to be a very watered down version for Marina tastes. On our recent visit, we ordered what amounted to spiced mashed potatoes. Over priced,bland and disgusting. To add insult to injury our waiter took our order never,  returned to check our meal and only returned to deliver the check. This was a truly bad experience, and I wouldn't reccommend to anyone.
author: Mike S.

description: Being from South India myself, I was very impressed with the food here. The price is a little more than I would ever pay for a dosa, but it is definitely enjoyable to say the least. There are other restaurants that provide this type of food and of the same caliber but for a place in the city with great atmosphere, this is probably a good place to start.
author: V J.

description: As usual I'm a little late to the party on this one, but we've had such good experiences here that I had to add my 2 rupees. It didn't hit me until I went to this place just how Northern the Indian restaurants around SF tend to be. In Boston the Indian restaurant scene was a little more pan-Indian; even the Punjabi cafe served dosas. But then I realized, whoah, I've really been missing out on the mustard seed, the coconut, the lighter vegetarian focus of South Indian cuisine. And of course.. dosas! They were fantastic! Day-old rat ass would taste exquisite if you wrapped it in one of these and dipped it in sambhar. We also tried some of the curries, which were rather intensively spiced with masala but we found delicious. I suppose paying $10 for a crepe could seem a little ridiculous, but when you look at it as a restaurant experience, and consider how well everything is executed, and the friendly and professional service, it's really a great value. You may have to wait a bit at the bar for a table, but this was a blessing in disguise as it gave me the opportunity to try my first Indian wine -- a Shiraz from Sula Vineyards that was quite good.
author: Tom L.

description: Yumm.. I went here for brunch on a Saturday morning. The service was very informative and the waiter recommended ordering the chaat, which we did. We got the paad puri, which were like fried puff balls that you had to stick your finger or back of the fork into to poke a hole. Then, you filled it with home-grown mung beans, some mashed potatoes, and garbanzo beans. Top that off by pouring in some tamarind sauce and spicy cilantro water. Eat it in one bite. My god.. MOUTH PARTY!!!!! The flavors all mixed together in a most powerful fashion. Delightful taste sensation. On the side we had the Indian scrambled eggs, which were very light and flavorful. Perfect scrambled egg texture. Then, we had the paper dosa. Humongous! We split it between 3 people and there was enough for everyone. The paper dosa came with potatoes and chestnuts, and on the side were coconut chutney and some other kind of sauce. The dosa was crispy and light. The only thing was that the coconut could have been more coconuttie (I am, however, obsessed with coconut, so nothing can ever have enough coconut for me!) Also tried the mango lassi and it was very rich and fresh tasting. I would definitely go back here. Also if you show up at 11:30 for brunch (when it opens) you are guaranteed a seat :P
author: O K.

description: This place was great - all around. There were just two of us but we ordered a little of everything. All dishes were around $10 which seemed a great price. All the flavors were perfectly balanced. The restaurant was loud (too loud - I say cut the music on a busy Saturday night!) but the ambiance was still lovely.
author: Shelly A.

description: Being of South Indian descent, I feel pretty comfortable commenting on Dosa.  Typically, outside of the South Bay, North Indian restaurants outnumber South Indian ones by at least 10:1.  And usually the South Indian restaurants that exist are cheap (read: poor ambience/bad service/generally ghetto), vegetarian and only cater to Indians.  As such, Dosa is a breath of fresh air and really destroys all of the stereotypes generally attributed to South Indian restaurants --- plus it's in SF.  I've been 4 times and have really enjoyed my experiences each and every time.  For apps, I'm a big fan of the dahi vada.  The vada is crispy on the outside and soft/chewy on the inside and probably as well-presented as I've ever seen the dish, even in India.  The accompanying yogurt and chutneys match well with the vada.  I don't really care for the Chennai chicken --- it's a little too greasy and flavorless.  The sada paper dosa is my favorite dosa.  Even my mom, who is universally considered the best dosa cook in my hometown, really likes them.  The sada paper is buttery and crispy and perfect for dipping in sambar and chutney.  I don't really care for masala-filled dosas but everyone I've been to the restaurant with seems to like them.  I really like the channa bhatura as well.  It's pretty rare to find a restaurant that serves good bhatura.  Also, Dosa's plates are actually big enough to hold the bhatura, which is a big plus in my book.  Once upon a time, I went to Vik's and was utterly disgusted to see some woman eating her bhatura directly off the nasty table.  (Btw, do any Indian people actually like Vik's?  I think that place is perhaps the most overrated Indian restaurant ever.  I understand it's cheap, but it's also disgusting.  The quality has seriously gone down hill in the last 5 years or so.)  Anyway... Dosa also has some quality meat dishes.  The tamil lamb curry is great.  It's a little greasy, but very tasty and one of the better South Indian meat dishes I've had in a while.  The prawn coconut masala is pretty good too.  The restaurant also has a good selection of beer and sake cocktails.  Overall, I'm a big fan of the restaurant, but the lack of a reservation policy bugs me (actually, I think they may take them for parties of 5 or more).  I would definitely go more often if they took reservations.  Also, the restaurant is a little cramped with the tables being set pretty close to each other.
author: Saw T.

description: Being a big fan of south indian food I was after reading the reviews here on Yelp very excited about Dosa. However, I must say I was rather disappointed. The food is nice, but to be honest I would rather pop next door to Udupi Palace which have at least as good food but with much more reasonable prices.
author: Carl Henrik E.

description: this is not 4 star south indian food. the dosas were no where near as awesome as i've had in other places, and they were far less spectacular than they should be if your restaurant is named after them. the prices were reasonable - i could see thinking it was expensive if you were getting the tasting menu at $40 a pop ($56 if you want the wine pairing), but a paper dosa, an appetizer, a mango lassi, the coconut chicken dish and a 7up came in under $50, which isn't that bad for a night out in SF. the two stars is for the portion size, the fact that we had a really nice server and the ambiance. the food, however, just wasn't that good and if i'm paying to go out, then i want it to be good.
author: Toisha T.

description:
After our delicious meal at Dosa last night, my friend and I felt traumatized. Traumatized not by what we'd eaten, which was delicious, but by the service, which, from the moment we arrived, was officious, aggressive, impatient, and just plain rude. I will refrain from firing up my own hostile jets again this morning by enumerating each and every moment we felt rushed, when we had to snatch back our plates from the eager bussers, when our waitress checked back in to find out what else we wanted to order, if we were done, if we liked it, and so on. WHen the owner accidentally put a bill on our table before we had even been served the dessert we had ordered, I was appalled but not surprised. It turned out he had mistaken us for another table. Okay. But the last straw came as we were leaving: the host, seeing us moving toward the door through the narrow passage between bar stool diners and table diners, ordered us to WAIT while he brought a group of 7 or 8 folks into the restaurant to seat them. Huh? Isn't it basic etiquette that you allow the person who is leaving right of way? Apparently the rush to make a profit at Dosa is SO dramatic that pummeling diners with an army of aggressive servers, and then expecting them to pause in their flight from such punishment is simply how business is done. 
I feel sad. I loved the food. I hated the experience. Dosa doesn't get another chance to treat me like I'm a sack of lentil flour.
author: polly s.

description: Mmmmm. Spicy mung masala dosa was excellent. The Habanero mango masals dosa was intensely and amazingly spicy but even in the end too spicy for the person at the table who revels in the spiciest of spicy food. We also got an order of Chennai chicken, which was nothing special but good as it's just spicy boneless fried chicken.
author: Sarah C.

description: went again, on a way busier night, and the service was amazing - fast and super-attentive. seems entirely likely my first trip was a fluke.
author: Dani B.

description: How has it taken me so long to eat at this place?  I was there on Sunday evening around 6:30, no waiting to be seated.  We ordered a mango lassi and pomagranate juice to start, they were excellent!  Ordered the mango, goat cheese, & walnut salad, 1 dosa, and 1 uttapam.  The uttapam was GREAT, the salad and dosa were even better.  Service was Excellent!  Definitely one of my new favorite places!
author: Sonja H.

description:
