Good food, the WORST SERVICE EVER!. Came around 840pm was told that we could get a table within 40mins. I told the hostess that we would be waiting at the bar. We had wines, and 30mins later we asked the progress, and was still told that we needed to wait for another 10-15 mins. We were pretty hungry, so we ordered some food. I saw another group got seated before us although they came later, so I asked them and another hostess (a guy) told us that they might come before us. Not True, because I saw them came after us, and put their name after us. So the hostess didn't even apologize, even came up with another "Cheeky comments', like "Sorry for the perception". What was he talking about? It's not a perception it's real. If he shut his mouth, it would better. Our bad experience didn't stop there, the waitress wasn't very attentive. She didn't us whether we had more order, we actually waited for our Dosa for more than 30 mins. We called her, and finally got our dosa. She took my friend's wine glass away although we still had a half bottle of wine. 
Suggestion: Fired everyone and  hire a better employees. This i snot a cheap restaurant, I have certain expectations for that amount of money. I will definitely spread the words to my friends not to come to this place anymore
author: F w.

description: Yeah, I'm totally on this bandwagon. Dosa is not perfect, but it is pretty damn good. In order to get the full effect, you kind of have to be willing to put with with some bullshit. Like, the wait. Even though I had made reservations (only taken for parties of 5 or more), we still had to wait about 20 minutes for our table to clear up. Probably because they only have about two tables in the whole place capable of seating five, and the place was PACKED on a Wednesday night. But, I was in a good mood, so we just sat at the bar and had a drink while we waited. When we finally got seated and ordered, all of the food was fucking awesome. All of it. Almost too good, considering that the place seemed to be staffed almost entirely by caucasians. Seriously, I don't think I've ever seen an Indian place with a single non-brown person working there before, much less the whole staff. I'm just saying, it was a first for me. They were very polite, though. Anyway, where was I? Oh yeah, try the South Indian Moons uttapam sampler and the vada sambar. Good stuff.
author: Tom H.

description: Maybe it was because I was sucked into all of the hype and had high expectations, maybe it was because I happen to be friends with some master Dosa makers, maybe it was because I waited 45 minutes to sit down, or maybe Dosa just had an off night, but I walked away from my meal at Dosa largely disappointed.  I ordered the Onion Rava Dosa (dosa made with caramelized red and yellow onions), expecting it to be slightly sweetened by the aforementioned caramelized onions, but the dosa was neither sweet or especially flavorful.  What's the point of onions if they don't accentuate the flavor of the underlying food???  In addition to lacking much flavor, due to the onions in the mixture, the dosa was rather firm and filled with holes where the batter didn't fill in the gaps making it extremely difficult to use the dosa for actually gathering the lentil mixture or chutneys.  One last note, the lentil mixture was overcooked.  Ok, so you get the point about the food.  The service was generally good, if not a bit overbearing.  That being said, Dosa's atmosphere was very trendy with house music playing in the background.  I thought the design of the restaurant was the best part of the experience, but, unfortunately, I couldn't eat that.
author: Matt P.

description: I really wish I could give Dosa more stars, because the food really is great. But somehow, they can't seem to get the timing issue fixed. This was my second time at Dosa, second time having a reservation, and second time that we were made to wait upwards of a half hour to be seated. It took them 45 minutes to seat us, and because we were a party of six and the bar was packed, we couldn't even really get a drink while we were waiting. Now I am not one who ordinarily needs a lot of coddling by restaurants, but if you keep us waiting 45 minutes when we had a long standing reservation, you could at least offer us an apology or a round of drinks or appetizer or something.  Instead, it wasn't even acknowledged - it seemed to be treated as fairly standard (which based on the fact that it's happened to me before is perhaps actually the case). Much as I like the food, waiting 45 mins in heels with no drink is just not something a girl is going to want to repeat.
author: S T.

description: Its commendable they finally came up with a South Indian restaurant in the city and at that a decent one. The location, decor, and ambiance were good. The food was OK. As a South Indian myself I believe I know the true taste of dosa, uttapams, idlis, etc. and quite frankly you can find better in the south bay but for the city this will definitely suffice. If you have never tried south indian food and you were going to make a judgement on it with this restaurant I would recommend you go elsewhere first.
author: Padma K.

description: Indians are so fucking hot right now. I mean, they are the new minority America is falling in love with, am I right? As a fellow immigrant, I know the pain of being from a country that doesn't measure up to America's standards of law and order. (I mean, my people were typecast as toothless descendants of the Hun).
author: Veljko S.

description: I was contacted by one of the owners about my previous review. He apologized and quickly sent me a check to cover the amount of the gift certificate.  I appreciate the gesture but it doesn't make up for a crappy experience.
author: Sai S.

description: I have been to a lot of Indian restaurants and this one is close to the bottom for me.  It is great for atmosphere, but the food was too hot, WAY too hot.  With the first 2 bites, I knew that I would not be able to finish the meal.  If it's that spicy, you can't really enjoy the other flavors.    When I told the waitress that it was very hot, and is there a milder version, she told me that I could get some yogurt (yes, I was charged) to cool it off.     I don't mind spicy, but there has to be a balance.  EVERYTHING was spicy...the soup, the dosa,  the chutney.    If given the choice to go back, I would respectfully decline.
author: S C.

description: Fabulous!  One of my favs.  I love when people mix it up - - every indian restaurant serves the same food... it's refreshing to have new options and HEALTHY ones to boot.  Beet soup wonderful, veggie dosa - spring fab, and the sprouted salad - - could you get a more healthier meal out?   Oh and the decor is great too, heard the filmore location is even nicer.
author: Candice C.

description:
2nd time eating here. this time the chicken bangan bharta melted in my mouth like butter on a hot pan. never had chicken so soft and moist, makes me want to eat it all up!! 

that had great texture and flavor. make sure to get it, esp if you like eggplant.

also got the paneer dosa, good as well, the fun is dipping it into the 3 different sauces! apparently fillmore has 2x the menu options, which i found out after i inquired with our waitress about the new place. probably i will go there when i am in the dosi dosa mood-ah
author: Porkers T.

description: I liked the busy scene even on a Wednesday night, and I liked how great they were with our friend's almost-one-year-old, and that without reservations we got seated right away at 7pm (an hour later though and not a seat in the house!). I didn't like the waitress' annoyance when asked for advice on the menu. I enjoyed the Indian beer. I did NOT like the prices. It's just hard to spend $60 a head on Indian food when we're used to spending like $15 a head. The food was very good, although we were encouraged to do the fixed 4-course and share everything when it's hard to do that setup family style - it was a lot of effort to get everything split up 4 ways and back on the original plates. My favorites were probably the Paneer Dosa, Dosa Masasla, Chennai Chicken and the lamb curry, although everything was good, and toward the end it really all started tasting the same. I liked the flavors and am glad to have finally tried it but for the spend I don't think we'll be back.
author: Sarah R.

description: I'm probably unqualified to rate Dosa, given that I just started eating Indian food this year and have a lot to learn, especially about Southern Indian food.  But I'm going to do it anyway...mostly based on the service, which was excellent.  The two of us only had to wait 10 minutes when we showed up at 7:15 pm on a Saturday.  When I misheard the bartender and ended up with a glass of pinot blanc instead of pinot noir, she graciously and immediately replaced it with the desired red.   We just got two entrees (the chef's menu at $35 was tempting, but I was still full from Thanksgiving and the meals that followed): lamb curry with rice and masala dosa.  The lamb was very tender and perfectly spiced, and the masala dosa was very crisp and delicious, and the sauces that came with it added great flavor.  Our server (Kent?) was really cheerful and sweet and checked on us often.  Overall it was a great meal, and I'll have to come back to learn more about good Indian food.
author: Gina K.

description: I've enjoyed every meal I've ever had at Dosa. And last night's meal was no different. The Masala Dosa, Tamil Lamb, and Kerala Chicken was simply heavenly. Dosa puts a lot of care into every dish they serve. All dishes are noticeably not greasy compared to other Indian restaurnts. We savored every bite of the dosa, along with the chutneys and sambar. Dosa's ingredients and alchemy of spices cannot be beat.
author: J W.

description: I sorta assumed that the food at this place would only be okay, simply because I figured most people are drawn to this place because it's trendy and not because of the food. I was surprised, however, by how good the food actually was.  I'm no expert in South Indian food but I can tell a good dosa when I have one. That was one fucking good dosa. Everything else was good too. My new favorite upclass Indian food place in the city, though I'm always a little suspicious of any Indian place that doesn't seem to employ any Indians.
author: Hmmm W.

description: Went to this restaurant about 3 weeks ago...very busy place, get there early or be prepared to wait 30 min+. Food is fantastic...had the Pepper Chicken and the meat was falling off the bone (!!!!). Curry was very tasty..going back there this week to try other dishes!
author: Steve K.

description: delicious!!  the dosa style indian crepe is wonderful... they're pretty big - generous portions.  various fillings offered with great curries to dip into.  we had an awesome appetizer lentil salad.  and the free papadum (crispy flat bread) which is a tasty chip-like dish, will hold you over until your meal comes.
author: Ken L.

description: Pretty much everyone has their favorite cheap Indian eatery (I don't have one... I have many :P).  While I'm used to the usual hole-in-the-wall style places with blasting Indian techno music, it's nice to go to ... well... a nicer place.  Which is exactly what Dosa is for me. The food is amazing and adds a gourmet flare to the usual indian dosas by adding european influence. While it's not so much as to label this place as a "fusion" restaurant, since it serves indian food at it's core, it still is nice to see innovation that looks and tastes great.  Everything is really well thought out and balanced in terms of spice, which is nice from the usual "GIVE ME A GLASS OF WATER NOW" kind of feeling I get from going to most other Indian places.  While it's certainly not as cheap as your usual Indian place, I beg you to at least taste what Indian food can be like when its dressed up and refined.
author: Patrick C.

description: OK, I've eaten at Dosa about 20 times (most of the time get take-out because the wait is horrendous and they don't take reservations unless you are 5 or more).  The first time, I thought it was the best food I've ever eaten - so unusual, different from Indian food you are used to.  Now, after sampling half of the menu, I have to admit - almost everything tastes the same.  All of the dosas seem to be essentially the same - be it masala or lentils, the different varieties of dumplings, you name it, kinda tastes the same.  But that same is DELICIOUS.  Service is always solid and helpful.
author: Kristi S.

description: Yummy! That is all I can say. They have a tasting menu at around $30. We had 2 kinds of dosa, vadas, lamb curry, and some prawn dish. It was a while back, so my memory is not absolutely clear about the names or specifics. What really, really stuck out was the lamb curry. It was a fairly dry curry with so much flavor. The lamb was incredibly tender, probably the most tender meat that I have ever had. And it tasted like lamb. I often find myself a bit dissappointed by lamb because so many restaurants choose to serve very mild lamb that tastes as much like beef as lamb. It's a very crowded place, they don't take reservations as a rule, and the wait was about an hour. So that could be annoying, but I think it was well worth it. There are plenty of bars nearby. Speaking of drinks, do try the lychee soju.
author: Vernon S.

description: Dosa is a fresh concept definitely worth hassling the parking in the Mission and a no-reservations policy. The space is small but never feels cramped due to a thoughtful space plan, although it does get a little too warm at the back of the restaurant. Service is friendly and helpful all around, from the hostesses to the servers to the busboys, an achievement few restaurants can claim. Another nice touch is Dosa's wine list, which is much more varied and unique than the offerings at most Indian restaurants I've been to. The menu has a good array of choices and makes nice use of fresh local ingredients. The spring dosa was good although not as fabulous as we'd expected, but the prawn coconut curry was delightfully sweet and spicy with a generous amount of prawns. While I think that Dosa is a good value considering the quality of ingredients and overall atmosphere, I'm not sure I agree with the Chronicle's designation of Dosa as a "Bargain Bite" unless you only order one dish and a glass of tap water.
author: Heather F.

description: we couldn't get a table for our party of six at 7:30pm on a Friday night, so we were told to 'walk in'.  There was barely standing room for a while, then we got seats at the bar and waited a record breaking TWO HOURS until we got our table.  you think I'm nuts at this point? well, the owner/manager guy was absolutely charming and plied us with complimentary  drinks and apps at the bar and the environment was cool.  It was utterly frustrating to wait so long, but worth it.  The food was great, we had a fun gang of people and the super nice staff made it all OK.  i would definitely go back... maybe not a Friday/Saturday tho!
author: laura j.

description: I cannot fathom why this place is as popular as it is or why the reviews are generally so glowing.   The space was cramped and noisy, and  the waitress pleasant but fairly uninformed about Indian food.  As for the food, the size of the dosa divided the opinions of our group ( thrilling or goofy) but everyone agreed that they were  a bit hard to eat in that form (somehow I remember them as being smaller in India or more manageable in India.)\. The dosa's flavors, definitely unlike those in India,  were flat and ponderous. I am not sure if it was the result of less than fresh ingredients, overcooking or simply ineptitude about spices.  The price was a bit high as well, but here I may be remembering my old days in Berkeley when dosas were a few bucks and just as mediocre.
author: Pan K.

description: I originally loved this place.  I still think the food is great, but the service is really going down hill.  Not sure what's happening, but it's time for the wait staff to check the attitude at the door.
author: Jason R.

description:
After weeks of anticipating the grand opening of Dosa, we finally went the other night. It was busy so we waited for 20 minutes before being sitted by the kitchen. It was very noisy. We ordered pakoras and when we asked for chutney the waitress refused at first by saying that the chef did not want us to eat with chutney but she finally brought the coconut chutney. The pakoras (which are fried onions in cheapea flour) were tasty and spicy. We ordered the masala dosa and we liked our food. The wine we ordered was good but we were amazed at the half empty glasses served at $7.50....per glass.
We then ordered the Goulab Jamum for dessert and what a let down, they were falling apart and did not taste good at all. The owner came to our table to apologize for that but did not take it off our tab which we would expect if the owner himself feels that they were soaking too long in the syrup.
We were overall satisfied with the place and would go back since we love dosa and don't have to wait until we are in Berkeley or South Bay but it is a bit pricy compared to other South Indian restaurant.
author: Bianca R.

description: OMG, seriously, this place is DA'BOMB. My favorite is the spring mix uttapam. I can't find another south indian restaurant that makes this particular uttapam. But really I've never had anything that wasn't TO DIE FOR here. I would eat here every single night if I could!
author: suz q.

description: Dosa and and samosa great ... But curry medicore and it and the rice littered with unground spices which were hard, unexpected and overly intense.  Also a bit pricey and a bit pretentious - but in general good food.
author: Brian G.

description: It's a rare thing to go to a restaurant and not only enjoy the food you've ordered but also covet the food delivered to other tables to the extent that you're already looking forward to your next visit while you've yet to finish your first meal there. I made the small mistake of ordering both an especially flavorful rasam soup (made with tomato, lentil, and tamarind) and a dosa mysore, each of whose complex blend of spices was enjoyable individually, but when taken together, they were a bit overwhelming. Next time I think I'll try to keep an eye toward balance and to save space for the truffle desserts, if they are still available. The service was great; our waitress was attentive, cordial, well-spoken, and witty.
author: Eugene P.

description: I give five stars for the service at Dosa and some of the food was amazing. However, $120 (the sample platter plus two glasses of wine) for two seemed a bit overpriced for a restaurant where Sublime played loudly in the background and I sat shoulder to shoulder with other diners.  Maybe I would've liked it better when I was 20?
author: Fawn D.

description: yum.  much more i can  write about it, but generally...food was good, service was friendly if not all that great. would definitely come back.
author: Jennifer L.

description: The food was good. I don't know enough about South Indian food to comment on its authenticity, but I liked it. The restaurant was noisy, the service good, and prices fair. The management did a good job of trying to make us feel comfortable, despite our reserved table not being ready, even if it took the bartender a while to acknowledge us for a drink order.
author: Joe C.

description: My wife spared me today and left me in San Francisco while she and a friend went to the Gilroy outlet mecca. Since she didn't like the Dosa we shared in San Jose back when we started dating, I took the opportunity of her absence to make a long-anticipated Sunday lunchtime trip to Dosa. Since it was Sunday, I found a yellow-topped meter right out front, parked, and walked in to a fairly busy place. The bar was empty and comfortable - perfect for dining solo. I knew I wanted the standard Dosa (Dosa Masala), but wasn't sure what to get as a starter. I asked the bartender, and she recommended the Pani Puri. She showed me how to crack open the fried puri and demo'd how to make one by starting with the most dense fillings (potato) first, then filling up with the tamarind and mint "water". She was very helpful and friendly. The Dosa Masala arrived and the crepe-like shell was larger than the plate! The filling was tasty, and the lentil soup and other sauces were really tasty. My only complaint was that the filling was probably only in just over 1/2 of the dosa, and I re-spread it around inside to avoid too much empty shell (tho that was nice for dipping in the sauces as well). Good stuff.
author: Scott M.

description: Quite good, very authentic provincial Indian food. Not what I was expecting but was quite delicious.  The wait staff was extremely knowledgeable and helpful.  I would certainly go back.
author: B B.

description: my dosa looked like a huge scroll made of flat dough. perfect for dipping into my shrimp with spicy sauce.
author: Regina C.

description: Our first experience eating South Indian food took place at Dosa on Valencia. When you pass by the restaurant, the place smells amazing and it's intoxicating. Great ambiance, service, food was pretty good, however the vegetarian selection is not that great.
author: gibronandsahar K.

description: Amazing service! The waitor was extremely knowledgeable and helpful when we told him we had never been to a south indian restaurant. We are not vegetarians, were a little skeptical when he said there was one non vegetarian dish,  but the food was so amazing we did not even notice!!  The food was delicious. Very nice interior and great atmosphere!
author: Sarah R.

description: Very good place.  Exotic food and a sexy clientele.  I am certainy going to return!
author: Marko C.

description: I went to Dosa on a Sat night and had reservations. This is the way to go- otherwise you could end up waiting a long time. It was 4 of us. We were seated in the back corner. While the music was really good and fun, it also made it a bit hard to hear and we ended up having to speak very loudly to hear each other. The waiter was great and attentive. We all had fancy drinks from the bar that were delicious. I got some sort of drink that was similar to a mojito. The food was quite good. The ceviche appetizer was ok, but I don't think I would get it again- its small. The lamb curry was the best thing we ordered. Fun atmosphere.
author: N L.

description: hmmm....i don't get why there is a line to get into this place. The food is good. But not 2.5 hours of waiting good! The times I have come here, I usually get an appetizer, a glass of wine, and a meal. I always feel unsatisfied compared to how much the bill is. AND I am usually still hungry and want to get a burrito or something.
author: Kataneh F.

description: amazeable food, but too busy; go to fillmore location instead.
author: John M.

description:
after years of wanting to go to dosa and never being able to get a reservation at the right time, i finally went last night!  i don't know whether its karma or the fact that they opened a new location on fillmore and more people want to go there, but for whatever reason it worked out.  it was worth the wait - everything that we got was delicious!  our waiter was great - he took care to explain the menu and gave great suggestions and was very patient with our indecisiveness.  we started with 2 appetizers - the lentil dumplings and the chicken.  both were delicious!  the chicken was very spicy but the raita it came with helped.  then we shared the shrimp entree and the spring dosa.  i feel like you have to get a dosa, i mean, its the name of the restaurant!  both of these dishes were also great - good flavors, spicy, and different from any indian food i have ever had.  
i can't wait to go back and try more!
author: Carolyn B.

description: Dosa is great. The best South Indian food I've had. In fact, some of the best Indian food I've had.  The stuff I enjoyed most which keeps me going back for more:  the lychee-soju cocktail, the Tamil Lamb Curry, the Chicken appetizer and the cucumber salad. Oh, and of course the Masala Dosa. Great ambience, without being over-done.  Can't wait for my next visit...Well worth the trip across the bay and short wait at the bar.
author: Neeta D.

description: Dosa was a nice change up from the Indian food I'm use to.  It took a couple extra readings of the menu to decide what to get.  I do think you can easily order too many similar things if you're not familiar with the food.  All in all, a good dining experience in the Mission.
author: Huy T.

description: The staff at Dosa is not only helpful and knowlegeable about south Indian food but they are attentive and quick. The atmosphere is pleasant and the food is incredible. My favorites are the chickpea and mango salads and the spring dosa. The paper masala is my second favorite but there are so many delicious things for a vegetarian (they also have stuff for you meat eaters!) to enjoy I always leave wishing I had more room. You will have a wonderful experience at dosa. I honestly have become addicted to the food there and love the location. There is also a weekend brunch with "Bombay street food" like these little yogurty things to die for and spicy fruit salad. I have not encountered southern Indian food very frequently and we are lucky to have such a high quality example here in the mission. This unique restaurant keeps me coming back again and again.
author: Eve S.

description:
DOSA IS A NO-SA!

My girlfriend and I just had the misfortune of stumbling upon Dosa for a weekend brunch.  We knew nothing of its reputation, so entered with no expectations - good or bad.  The space is warm, if a bit pretentious.  The menu is comprised of very basic Indian dishes, yet is presented, both in the menu and by the staff, with an air that reeks of condescension.

When we entered, the dining room was less than a third full.  Yet, it took our waitress nearly 20 minutes to make her way to our table.  We ordered drinks, the fire broth, sunny side up eggs uttapam, and chatni masala dosa.

After another 15 minutes our drinks came.  Following a lengthy discussion on how good they weren't, our food finally arrived.

The soup and dosa were both inoffensive, if a bit coarsely seasoned.  However, the "sunny side up" eggs were raw.  I like my eggs runnier than most and would gladly take underdone eggs to overcooked ones.  We were ultimately treated to both at Dosa.   Now when I say raw, I mean RAW.  The whites looked like a pool of translucent snot.  Literally.  Translucent.  Snot.  When we were finally able to flag down our waitress (no small feat, I assure you), she advised us that "that is the way you ordered them.  You said 'sunny side up' and that's the way they're cooked."  She apparently missed the point that they were not cooked.  She tapped my girlfriend on the arm, and said with a great deal of presumptive condescension, "I'm just letting you know how to order for the next time."  Her tone and demeanor clearly expressed her belief that we knew nothing about the food we were ordering.  (I should mention here, I am a former professional chef of several years).  However, this was not haute cuisine.  This was not even ethnic cuisine.  This was a sunny-side up egg.  There's no requirement for a refined palate in this instance.  It's an egg.  You put in a frying pan.  You COOK it. 

Finally, after she continued arguing with us and refusing to acknowledge that the egg was uncooked, I ran my finger through the translucent snot, at which point she picked up the plate and clearly annoyed, said she would fix it.  The plate returned a few minutes later, with the same eggs that were now completely overcooked with a burnt crispy bottom and hard yolks.   

For this splendid feast, we were set back a mere 40+ dollars.  I would have been much more fulfilled and less annoyed had I handed the money to a stranger on the street.
_____________________________________________

I received a prompt and very kind response to my above post from who I presume to be the owner of the restaurant.  He apologized for our experience and asked when we were in so that he could address the our issues with his staff.  I was rather impressed by his timely action and raised my original rating by a star on account of this alone.
author: Michael G.

description: Finally, someone does southern indian cooking right.  I haven't had a paper dosa this good since I was in Bangalore.  Definitely worth a weekly visit for the Rasam to clean your system.
author: A A.

description: We came here for drinks, and ended up having a really nice time eating dinner at the bar. The place was packed, but we we walked in just as a few people were leaving the bar area.  For starters, unless you're knowledgeable about South Indian Food, I suggest you do a little reading beforehand....it's nothing at all like "normal" Indian restaurants you will find.  That being said, the food is quite tasty and flavorful.  We started with the "Samosas North and South" which were excellent.  For entrees we tried a dosa and  an uttapam.  Both were delicious.  One word of caution:  I was going to order the Habanero-Mango Dosa, but the waitress actually asked me if I was sure I wanted to order that dish, and I'm glad she did.  She put the sauce on the side and we instead ordered the Rava Masala dosa.  It was very tasty, and the habanero sauce (on the side, thankfully) was one of the hottest things I've tasted...ever.  And I'm Indian.  We also had the caramelized onion uttapam...also very good.  The service at the bar was excellent, and overall, I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Sonal P.

description: I've eaten at Dosa twice and am in love with the place. Everything from the lighting, music, decor to the amazing food leaves you with a fulfilling experience. The food is beautiful...It's better than the southern indian food you get in south India. The ingredients are fresh and alive, the recipes creative and satisfying, but not overly-filling, the wine list is great, and the wait staff is knowledgable and attentive. The lamb korma is delicious--this from a person who doesn't generally order meat--and of course, the chai is delicious and subtle, as a good real Indian chai should  be. It's a little pricey, but I think it's worth it.
author: Madeleine T.

description:
poor server - brought us the wrong dish. ouch.  would stop by the table and miss getting empty glasses refilled with water.  ouch.  started at the bar and also added water but it did not come (at all).  too busy-  need more bus peeps?

food - good.  big pancake with chic pea veggie dip was awesome. 

nice company :)
author: Henry F.

description: If you don't mind waiting a long time and paying very high prices for Indian food, then this place is worth checking-out.  The food is tasty, but there's other great options in SF for a lot less money and a shorter wait time.
author: Callie C.

description: after 840 reviews you think one would not even review on this hot spot pujabi joint....jus got introduced to indian food about a couple of months ago~only downfall if eating indina grub is that its hella fulfilling...but i have to say i want to be fulfilled lol....dishes here were good...spicey~appetizers were yummy...as u can tell i dont have the indian food list memorized hahah....good luck on a busy nite...youll be waitin outside for a while....pricing is not an issue~area is the mission...so u cant go wrong....unless your wearing gangsta colors in the hood.....
author: elmer d.

description: Went there with wifey last week and had a very nice experience there.  Service was great and the food was very good.  We tried the tasting menu to get a broader perspective of their food.  Our conclusion:  stay with the Dosas !  They're great.  The curry dishes are decent but not extraordinary.  Deserts are quite good too.  The only reason its not a 4 star is that the air ventilation was not adequate  - the balmy temperature combined with the spiciness of the food made us sweat like wild animals !
author: Matt S.

description: finally got a chance to try this popular mission restaurant recently.  interior is definitely a step up from the indian places i usually go to.  authenticity is difficult for me to judge since i'm not indian, but i found their offerings to be flavorful and reasonably priced.  despite the fact that the portions weren't what i'm used to when i usually go out for indian, i still felt filled up.  my spring dosa tasted really fresh and i enjoyed the chutneys that came with it.  service was attentive.  they also get props for sitting my 2 friends and i in a matter of seconds on a busy saturday night (they squeezed us into a 2 top table but we fit fine)....  will most likely be back.  only drawback is it is really loud... could barely hear what my friends were saying even though they were just across from me.
author: Yvette H.

description: We came to this restaurant without a reservation, and were told a 45 minute wait.  There's nowhere to stand in the bar area, so the hostess took my cell phone number and we went to a bar next door.  After an hour and 10 minutes I had heard nothing, so we called the restaurant.  She told us to come over, that a table was just clearing out.  We went back to the restaurant, and after twenty minutes, now an hour and a half total,  still no table.  When I pointed out to the hostess that she had said 45 minutes and that it was now double that time, she snottily told me "sometimes we can't predict these things."  No apology.  After an hour and forty minutes we gave up.  Pretentious, rude staff and a ridiculous wait.  Just the kind of place San Franciscans seem to love nowadays.  Not me.  We went down the street and got super burritos in five minutes.  If you're in the neighborhood skip this place and do the same.
author: Jeff M.

description: This was possibly the most interesting eating experiences I have had.  The waiters were good, but a little too over bearing for my liking as they kept explaining things to us.  Of course I am interested in the culture of eating South Indian food and I am always willing to learn but I don't know four different waiters telling me the same thing.  That aside the food was really good.  We were also convinced to get an appetizer that was yogurt filled bread fried, now that was an experience.  The one thing they tell you about this appetizer is that you have to eat one in one bite.  Sounds easy right?  Negative, that SH is hard as they are not small and when you put one in your mouth and begin to eat you have cold yogurt (which was completely unexpected) shoot down your throat.  This was a huge surprise for me and one of the most interesting things I have ever had.  I still don't know if I liked them or not.  The flavors were great but they kind of made me want to throw up?  Anyone else have that problem?
author: matt g.

description: dropped in here with a friend after seeing an exhibit at the film studio across the street. i love sitting at the bar, and this is a great place to do so (it's also first-come, first-serve). food was delicious- i would have liked to try everything on the menu. i had one of their bio-dynamic wines (which since having it i've noticed are popping up on menus everywhere) and it was tasty as well. can't wait to go back!
author: Kate M.

description: i usually eat verrry slowwwly, but when it comes to dosa, no one can keep up.  the food is so tasty!  the food isn't as authentic as saravana bhavan in sunnyvale, but if you're looking for something little more swank (and with a long wait time) go here.
author: cindy c.

description: The whole dining experience was very exciting and adventurous! This was my first time eating South Indian cuisine and I had such a fun time trying everything. We started off with the dahi Vada. It came with two lentil dumplings covered with yogurt sauce. I didn't know what to expect in presentation, but after taking a bit, I absolutely loved it. It had a texture like a falafel and the yogurt sauce made it so refreshing. Next, we had the marsala dosa. It was so huge! The dosa was light and crispy and the potato filling was delicious. The coconut chutney was so unique and flavorful. Then we had the south indian moon sampler, which was a sampler of all their uttapam. It came with 5 different uttapams and it was fun trying all of them. It also came with a side of channa (garbanza beans) and it was so good! I loved all the spices it was made with.. I could have ate the whole thing by myself. For dessert, we had a fried milk balls in cardamom syrup. It was okay.. very different from what I ever had. It tasted like a donut hole soaked in syrup. Overall, I would definitely want to come back to try all the other dishes... It would have gotten 5 stars, but the service was not that great. I had to ask for water at least 5 times and then I was informed that they ran out of glasses! AND it took 15 minutes to get my cocktail!
author: Denise L.

description:
this place is amazing. as a tamil and a sambar-snob, i have to say, this place is one of the best places I've had south indian food at. the quality of the food is on par with some of the better restaurants in the bay, sambar head above shoulders over the rest. and most importantly, something I have not seen much - presentation. Even in high class restaurants in Madras, they do not pay as much attention to presentation of the food because our food somehow lends itself to being messily presented. But these guys have really worked at it. This place is the best marketing mechanism I have for telling people to eat south indian coz it is just that cool.
At first, when I walked in, I thought I had entered the wrong place as it has loads of wine and nothing south-indian about it. Amazing food, amazing experience. Their chef's from trichy, I think.
author: Arvind A.

description:
i came here knowing that this place is not my kind of place.

$30-$40/person meals very rarely excite me.  normally i pay $15/meal, and don't get double my money's worth when i go to a $30/meal place.  thus i stray from places like dosa, 

having that disclaimer set up, my experience was not as horrifying as i anticipated it would be.  the wine was bad (malbec) but i think i know why.  i saw the bartender use those air-sucker-wine-saver mabob's, which do work, but only for a day or so.  my glass of wine tasted like metal grapes garnished with some rust. i should have just asked for another glass of wine, my fault.

the food!

the food was very tasty.  i really liked the halibut, which was soft and tender.  normally halibut is very steak like, or shark like - this was not so.  the curry was delicious, and the calamari was rather interesting as well.

overall the food was good, and the experience was fun. i'll prob only return for dates or more 'special occasion' type dinners.

---------
EDIT: two to three hours after posting this review i received this message from a dosa owner:

"Hey Ameer - Thanks for visiting us at Dosa.   I apologize that your experience wasn't everything you expected it to be!  Since your review is read by thousands of people I do want to comment and clarify on a few things you've said. 

- Our prices are comparable to (or less than) other full-service restaurants in the Mission such as Delfina, Range, Foreign Cinema, Garcon, Beretta, etc.   
- We use organic and natural ingredients wherever we can and make everything fresh daily.   You might not be able to taste it but you were definitely eating healthier food that you would find in a $15 / meal place, especially if you're eating fish. (We get our fish from the same vendors as Gary Danko.  As a matter of fact, I'd be concerned if I were paying $15 for a plate of fish! :-)) 
- You can walk away from Dosa with a great meal for about $20 or $25.  It depends on the food & wines you order :-), which brings me to my next point! 
- We ALWAYS pump the air out of our wines and store them in our coolers overnight (including reds) to preserve the wine.  ANY good restaurant should do that since the air oxidizes the wine.  I don't believe you will find a single restaurant that dumps all their wine overnight.  Considering we serve about 6,000 customers a week, 7 days weeks, our wines never last for more than a day!  The Malbec is a popular wine for us. You were probably tasting the casis, spice and smoky notes of the wine which is exactly the reason why some people like it and, of course, some people don't ! :-) 

I hope you do come see us again whether or not it's on a date! 

Kind regards, 

Anjan 
(one of the owners)"


i gave dosa 3 stars in my initial review, i think these guys take themselves just a bit too serious. i considered dropping the rating to two stars after i was told that i know nothing of fish or wine in a poor attempt at convincing me to revise or retract my non-5-star review, but a message through yelp shouldn't alter the experience i had and the review of it.
author: Ameer N.

description: Excellent food. The Dahi batata sev is the best I have tried in the Bay Area - better than the chaat houses in the South Bay. Paneer peas dosa was more like a roll - but surprisingly flavorful. Service was fast and from the time we ordered, we received our meals in less than 10 minutes. Friendly waitfstaff. I'd definitely come here again.
author: N R.

description: I had been to Dosa several times over the last couple years before last Tuesday's experience.  The food was tasty, as usual, though I missed the entire reason for coming to Dosa, which was the lamb curry, which was no longer on the menu.  The server tried to convince me that the lamb kofka (meatballs) were the same thing, so we ordered that instead.  While tasty, they weren't even on the same level as the lamb curry, not even close, so I felt misled by our server.  In addition, I wish they would leave the "fine dining" experience (i.e. the four course menu and wine pairing) for their Fillmore location, and go back to being a great neighborhood restaurant, like they used to be.  They are good enough to ride on the yumminess of their food, and the fact that South Indian restaurants are virtually non-existent, they don't need to aspire to be something greater.
author: Reyna J.

description: good food with a lot of options. The only place for good dosas in SF. Nice ambiance doesn't hurt as well
author: Beena A.

description: The food at Dosa is delicious and they would have earned 5 stars if it werent for the service.  I went on a Sunday afternoon so it wasnt exactly a full house either.  We were seated promptly but werent even given water until right before the appetizer came out.  And speaking of the appetizer, we werent told how to eat it until we had to ask.  The waitress gave definite attitude and was less than helpful because we werent ready the first time she came to take our order.  And its not that we were taking our sweet time, its a very interesting menu full of dishes that I had no experience with prior to Dosa.  So needless to say I didnt feel that the 'tude was neccesary.  We ordered the Paneer Dosa and the Spring Uttapam.  We also tried the Fire Broth soup and the Pani Puri.  Everything was packed with such flavor and just exploded in our mouths.  I've been talking about Dosa all week and would recommend it to anyone that is open to new flavors and can appreciate the art of cuisine.  I will even give it a second try to earn back that lost 5th star! :)
author: J L.

description: The best Indian restaurant in town. This place is quite small for its popularity and gets really crowded so you need to get there a little early. However the food is totally awesome and so is the ambience and service.
author: Suddha B.

description: Best Spring Dosa. It's always busy here but you can usually find a seat at the bar and service is super fast. Great wine selection, too!
author: Molly M.

description: The wait can be long, but if you have a craving for a dosa, idlis, and sambar, this is the spot!  The menu strikes a great balance of being authentic south indian, while fusing other elements to make the menu unique.  The moong salad is one of my favorites.  I definitely recommend this place.
author: Aunkur A.

description: yummmm thats all i can say!! delicious and healthy what more can you ask for
author: alisa o.

description: This is some of the best Southern Indian food I've had, and it was presente well, but the execution at the front of the house leaves something to be desired.  I came in a party of 4, and we came at 7:15, so were prepared to have a wait.  The issue I had was that we were told upon arriving that the wait would be 30-40 minutes, so we grabbed the only seat at the bar (way too small) and ordered some drinks.  An hour later, the bar tender asked us to order more drinks or appetizers, seemingly implying we were taking up space and not putting down enough cash.  We ended up waiting an 1 1/2 hours, and I thought the host should have given a more realistic wait time.  The atmosphere was ok - small tables with club music in the background.  The food was good, especially the mung bean salad and Kerala Chicken.  The dosas were good, but I prefer them less buttery and with the potatoes inside, not on the side.   We specifically asked for the food to be spicy, and it was not at all, even with three of my party being Indian.  My boyfriend even asked for a plate of chilis, which they brought, but they were diced and had the seeds removed, so they were not spicy either...   The coconut sorbet was delicious and a huge portion, easily serving two.  It was a good meal, but just an ok dining experience.  We'll be back, but earlier or not on a weekend.
author: Leslie R.

description: Panda crossed over to the southern indian border and wanted to see how this joint's food tasted.  WOWWWW!  My fur is on fire!  We ordered the behl puri which was this delicous assortment of advocado, lentil, onion, tomatoes, mint, chick peas along with tamarind chutney and green mint sauce....it was incredibly delicious and authentic!  Also, tried Madu Vedi which was these little fried potatoe puffs with some lentil in them, they were absolutely yummy.  My owna ordered the chicken curry special (not on menu), it was the special of the day and it rocked...the chicken was flavorful thru and thru and the breaded parati was incredible...melt in your mouth!  I ordered a mynsa dosa which was a potatoe-lentil filled crispy pancake wrap; ohmawgawd, talk about delicous...dip it in the tamarind and mint sauce and proceed to devour.  Panda loves indian food and loves the southern indian delicacies even more...this furry bear will definitely come here again!   YUMMY!!
author: Steven L.

description: Masala dosa was greasy and had a strong mustard taste. I kept thinking about honey mustard pretzel pieces. What was excellent was the idli vada sambar, really special. Service was great, price was a little high. For dosa's stick with Vik's in Berkeley or Udupi down the street.
author: Sarah J.

description: +1 cause the owner actually bothered to ask me about what I ordered and what was wrong and wanted another to change to "make it right". Obviously they care about their patrons as well as the quality of the food. Can't wait to try their new restaurant! :)
author: Trishan A.

description: OK, before anyone says this place is over-priced, take it from me...it is but it's worth the food. I grew up in the east/south bay where there are tons of cheap dosa places but being in SF, this is one of two spots available and does a great job. The food is really good and pretty authentic and they even have some twists of their own, such as the dosa with Indian style scrambled eggs. So if you want a nicer decor and food equivalent if not better than a more smaller, cheaper south Indian place, be sure to hit up Dosa.
author: pankaj l.

description: I have eaten there 10+ times now. The left side of the menu. The right side of the menu. The specials. It is all good.
author: Maximilian A.

description: I think the food and wine cocktails at DOSA are delicious and I am so glad there is a South Indian restaurant in  San Francisco.  Tonight I went with a party of eight for my sister's birthday this week and the food was fabulous as always, but the experience could have been better.  The waitress came by, told us about the special and recommended the $39 per person four course dinner for a party of our size.  We weren't really interested in dessert, so we decided to order from the menu and eat family style.  Normally when I go there the food comes out in courses, starters first, then dosa and uttapam, then curries.  I don't know if they wanted to hurry us up or what, but we got bombed with food.  The dishes came fast and furious, and we spent most of the meal passing things around and couldn't really talk or socialize.   I felt like we were being punished for not going with the waitress' recommendation.
author: Bea A.

description: First of all, I have to preface this review with the fact that I love South Indian food and am used to more mom-and-pop South Indian restaurants in New York and D.C./Maryland, so the hype and modern edge here is a little off-putting.  But I just didn't feel that the dosa were that good.  Again, it's acceptable, but just too much on the bland side, especially their idly and sambar.  Anyway, we ordered on dosa and one more modern interpretation dish, and that was a big mistake.  Stick to the dosa.  Nice try, but disappointing.  Next time, I'll try Udupi palace one block south on Valencia.
author: N G.

description: Southern Indian food is great. The flavors are strong, a good kick in the head. The lamb meatball curry is great (I normally do not like lamb at all), paper dosa is awesome. I thought the mango lassie was a little too sour. Parking sucks, for those of you who are not familiar with the area, so arrive early.
author: DT l.

description: Food is great and if you get there at 6:00 you don't have to wait.  Service is usually OK, occasionally the wait staff has a bit of an attitude.
author: Eric S.

description: Went there for brunch. Really impressed. A clean, Southern Indian cuisine with great attention to presentation. Good service. The waiter made some excellent suggestions for my first time. The signature dish "Dosa" I chose was Paneer. I was impressed with all the fresh peas tucked inside. The Dahi Vada is not to be missed, our table neighbors even had to inquire!
author: Joe B.

description: the food's really nice at dosa. so while the food is great, the dosa experience is just not for me. it's definitely the hippest indian restaurant i've ever been to. maybe it's just the way i've been brought to experience indian food, but i'm all about the brick lane curry with a bag of cobra beers, art students on one side, shouting door men on the other, and all the confusion of east london. this isn't an attack "authenticity" or anything like that. in conclusion, dosa is nice, just not for me.
author: Brenton W.

description: Wow. I never knew chicken could be so good. The bartender wasn't very happy (it was near the end of the night), but she seemed to brighten considerably when we decided to eat at the bar instead of at a table. Otherwise, everyone else very nice.  I had the black pepper chicken dish and my man had the lamb. Spicy, amazing, so unbelievably tender. Loved the decor, nice crowd in there. Can't wait to go back! YUM!!
author: Kathryn W.

description: I am from South India and visited this restaurant because of referrals by co-workers. This place is pricey and does not have authentic Indian food taste. It is more of a fusion food and 'Americanized'. If you are looking for authentic food, this is not the place. I must say that the ambiance is very good. This is definitely a good option for a date.
author: kasi g.

description: very good food, but over priced.  the wine list is also good, and well suited for spicy foods, but waaaaay over priced.  there are so many fine restaurants in the area, for $45/person I'll take my money elsewhere.
author: jordan h.

description: The food was good but I can go to South Indian restaurants in Berkeley & pay far less for far more & get better sauces. I also don't have to wait for hours to be seated. Still, South Indian is a little rarer in SF - Pasand used to be really good but had to stop going long ago b/c of their unethical practices.
author: Fidel M.

description: Randomly went on a sunny Sunday afternoon to catch their tail-end "brunch" at 2:45pm. With aboslutley no crowd and a lazy breeze, it was a very enjoyable experience. The food was quite tasty overall.The Medu Vada appetizer is a bit dry, but works well with the accompanying sambar. The Bhel Puri, however, is just plain spectatcular and should be a must order. Their namesake dosas are very tasty, especially the paper masala. Will definitely return and will coordinate to come around this time again to avoid the crowds.
author: chris k.

description:
***THIS IS NOT AUTHENTIC SOUTH INDIAN FOOD***
(oh, and update 11/16/06, negative reviews will get you ridiculously snide and emails from the owner.  i didn't even bother to open the second one he sent me, since the first was rude enough.)

I joined Yelp for the express purpose of reviewing Dosa which, in my opinion, is one of the poorest excuses for a South Indian restaurant I have ever experienced in my life.  I am South Indian and am amazed that any other South Indian person could approve of the food here.   I would have much less of an issue if the place said it was "inspired" by South Indian flavors, but to call it an authentic South Indian restaurant is insane; all you need to do is take one trip there to realize immediately that this crap is not served in real Indian restaurants.

THE SERVICE: we showed up at 9:30 pm on a Friday night.  To Dosa's credit, a twenty minute wait meant a twenty minute wait; however, that was the only thing that went right.  The bartender clearly gave preference to the white people seated at the bar, serving and paying attention to white patrons who clearly arrived after I did.  When he finally came around to me, I asked loudly and clearly for the drinks menu; he returned with the food menu.  It took literally 10 minutes to get his attention, all the while being completely ignored by the useless barback.  He seemed annoyed when I asked for the correct menu and didn't come back for another 10 minutes.  Just as he was done pouring our drinks, the hostess came to seat us.  She was forced to wait on us while rudy mcrudetender took his time closing our bar tab.  The drink, by the way, was the pomegranate garnet and it tasted like Strawberry Shortcake had vomited into my glass.

THE MENU: appalling.  First of all, I can't believe this place can get away with serving heavily overpriced breakfast food as somewhat classy dinner food.  Secondly, none of the "curries" on the menu are  authentic -- I dare anyone to tell me when they've seen such dishes on mom's table, in the way that Dosa prepares them.  The salad and soups section is hilarious -- we don't eat that stuff in India, at least not in the western sense of the words.  Give me cucumber pachadi any day.

THE FOOD: I ordered the mung sprouts salad, rava masala dosa, and salty lassi.  The salad was fine, just not authentic.  The dosa was ... disappointing at best.  Nice and thin, but soggy rather than crispy.  The masala, rather than being stuffed in the center, was underneath the tri-fold of dosa -- how the hell was I supposed to reach it without making a mess? I was expecting at least some delicious coconut chutney and perhaps coriander chutney.  What I got were some strange tomato (?) chutney that I've never seen on a South Indian table, and a garlicky, runny version of coconut chutney.  The lassi was terrible -- more sweet than salty, and with strange spices that I've only ever tasted in North Indian versions of lassi.

THE LANGUAGE BARRIER: imagine, a South Indian having a language barrier at a South Indian restaurant?? Well, that's what you get from the awkward kurti-laden servers at Dosa.  I had to resort to hideously Americanized pronunciations (it's not Lassy the dog, people!) and had to endure a night full of hearing these girls take requests for "doe-sah" and "oo-tah-pom." ugh.

I would rather make the trek down to the south bay for real dinner (rassam, more kozhambu, bisi bele bath, etc.) or authentic breakfast food than ever set foot in Dosa again. 

I would never, ever bring my parents to eat here if they visited.  UGH!!!
author: pitter k.

description: food is very good but service is absolutely horrible. because i had such a horrible expereince with the hostess i don't know if i'd ever go back sadly.
author: Miss O.

description: i'm heading back to dosa for my new weekly south indian brunch. ironic that i'm eating there every weekend, for neither me or my bf are vegetarians, infact we are predominantly semi-savage carnivores,  but the food at dosa is so dynamic and full of flavor, as well as interesting and fun to eat, that suprisingly we don't miss the meat whatsoever. try the pani puri, cute little puffs you get to puncture little holes in, in which to insert other small good things accompanied by a multitude of sauces. i enjoy comprising each bite of food with the array of table items. they do offer one special changing meat dish during brunch that is not listed on the menu, but after having tried it i realized that it was best to stick to the menu items without meat-its clearly their specialty. i love eating meat off the bone, but theres something less convenient about having to dip your fingers in a couple inches of liquid for it. the menu can be a bit overwhelming at first, but the staff is very friendly and does an excellent job of making suggestions which always turn out great. today i am taking my vegan friend who's never been, it is the perfect place for us to both be satisfied. also, the atmosphere differs from other indian restaurants with its more contemporary flare. dosa has a very clean and pleasant feel and its unique food is very affordable.
author: little gem z.

description: This place is great.  I went there with a group of 7 friends last night and we had a wonderful time.  Admittedly, with a group that big you can actually get a reservation here (6 person minimum for a reservation) and that appears to be 90% of the trick to enjoying yourself at such a packed, popular restaurant.  Anyway, everyone at our table ooh'd and ahh'd over almost every dish although the cheese dosas were a particular hit and everyone said the chicken curry was too spicy for them although I found it just right.  Anyway...I was tempted to give this place 5 stars but there was a bit of a rush at the end where the servers swooped to clean our table ASAP in hopes of flipping it to the next group of hungry folks in line.  I totally appreciate that but would have liked to savor my time with my friends without the pressure.  So once this place isn't the IT spot of the moment anymore, I'm sure it'll be a 5 star winner in my book.
author: Joseph S.

description: finally got a chance to go and loved it.  the menu is so different and fun. almost every item was new to me so can't wait to go back and explore some more. the dosa was delicious as were the lentil dumplings and yogurt.  the chicken curry used fresh organic chicken and you can tell the difference. the flavors of the veggie curry were nice and the garbanzo curry.  my favorite dish was the dosa.
author: Yelper S.

description: nice place to sit and have a drink but i must say the food was disappointing. you can better indian around the corner for less $. nice space though great job of creating that alluring environment.
author: Jason M.
